file: GALP - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 29July2016 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: In Iberian, the oil market has increased about 2% in a year-on-year comparison, mainly due to a higher demand  for diesel and jet, which, to some extent, was supported by higher tourism activity in Iberia. In what concerns to  the natural gas market, this region benefited from lower seasonal temperatures, which supported volumes sold for  the retail and the wholesale segments.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: As for FPSO number 4, the Cidade de Itaguaí on Iracema North area, the case is pretty different. The units  production is still constrained due to gas handling. Therefore, the connection to the Cabiúnas pipeline has been  prioritized for the course of the current quarter. And considering that five producer wells are already connected  and high productivities in the area, these units could reach full capacity as soon as the connection is completed  later this quarter.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: As for FPSO number 5, the Cidade de Maricá, which has started production last February. It is already producing  over 90,000 barrels per day through three producer wells, also again providing an excellent productivity of this  reservoir.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: And the last but certainly not the least, we highlight the entrance of a new unit to our pre-salt fleet, the sixth one  as planned, called Cidade de Saquarema, which started commercial production on July 8 in Lula Central area.  This unit is, for the time being, connected to the first producer with flow rates currently averaging 30,000 barrels  per day. This is another milestone for Lula/Iracema project.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: Still on Lula/Iracema, and in what concerns to the efficiency improvements, we continue to see a reduction of  drilling and completion times, which are now around 20% faster than the average time that we have reached in  2015, an important milestone for cost improvement in this project.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: Crossing to South Atlantic to our projects in Africa. In Mozambique, the area for consortium continues to work and  optimizing the EPCIC contract for the offshore FLNG Coral project. We're also working on a financial solution and  on finalizing the off-take contract for the LNG. As for the onshore Mamba project, the EPC proposals continue to  be reviewed.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: Moving on to the downstream business on slide 8. The hydrocracker unit has resumed operations after  maintenance during Q1 and has contributed to a quarter-on-quarter increase in raw materials processed, despite  the planned outage for maintenance in our Matosinhos refinery involving the distillation atmospheric unit and as  well the vacuum visbreaking unit.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: We were able to achieve a premium over the benchmark of around $1.7 per barrel, as we continue to benefit from  gasoline arbitrage opportunities in United States. The marketing of the oil products activity contributed steadily to  results, even though volumes will decrease in a year-on-year basis as we continue to optimize our portfolio of  clients, concentrating our efforts on higher-margins trading clients.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: On the Gas & Power side, again a resilient quarter with our natural gas sourcing utilities contributing to lowering  our cost of gas during this period and offsetting the effect of the lower volumes sold. Our gas marketing activities  in Iberia were relatively stable, except for the decrease in electric segment on the back of our hydro-based power  generation here.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: A final word about the partnership that we have announced yesterday regarding the metro gas infrastructures  business. So, Galp has reached an agreement for long-term partnership with a Japanese consortium led by  Marubeni for Galp Gás Natural Distribuição, which we call GGND, our holding company for the regulated  infrastructure businesses.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: After the completion of this transaction, GGND will become an independent, ring-fenced and self-funded entity.  GGND will be owned by Galp Group, holds stakes in nine local distribution companies that offer the gas  distribution infrastructure to all gas marketing operators.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: E&P EBITDA was down 27% to €86 million, with production growth insufficient to offset the much lower oil prices.  Production costs this last quarter were also impacted by maintenance activities. And you will see at the back of  the presentation that, on a unit basis, costs were also affected by the lower production levels quarter-on-quarter.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: On the other hand, Gas & Power EBITDA was up 10% year-on-year to €97 million, and this comes from sourcing  optimization and the normalization of results from our power activity.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: Our summary balance sheet on slide 14 already earmarks GGND, the gas infrastructure business, as available  for sale, which leads the group assets and liabilities to be netted off of the respective GGND line items.

file: GALP - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 31July2017 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Let me briefly cover our operations during the quarter, starting with our upstream on the slide number 5 of our  presentation. So, our main project in Lula and Iracema, it has progressed – continued according our plan. Back in  May, we announced the start-up of our P-66, the seventh FPSO in Brazil and the first of the replicant unit. That  unit is developing Lula South and is currently producing over 25,000 barrels per day from just one well.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: P-66 ramp-up should drive our production growth over the next quarters with at least two additional producers  until the year-end were expected. Meanwhile, the sixth unit, Cidade de Saquarema, placed in Lula Central,  achieved the plateau in June following the gas export start through the Cabiúnas pipeline and the connection of  the sixth producer. Once again, a great performance from all parties involved with units fully ramped-up in just 11  months.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Moving now to Mozambique, on slide number 6. So, on Mozambique, we announced back in June the final  investment decision for our Coral South project. This is an important milestone which puts Mozambique Rovuma  LNG on the map. Rovuma is a key asset for Galp strategy towards a lower current portfolio mix. We are now in  project execution mode in Coral with first gas expected during 2022. On Mamba, the onshore project, we are  progressing with the project preparations for the initial stage of the development of this very large and competitive  discovery.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding the Gas & Power, results were up Q-on-Q as we recovered from the Q1 sourcing restrictions from  Algeria. However, we continue to experience a lack of LNG trading opportunities with our trading mainly bas ed on  our structured contracts. We also have a lower contribution from the natural gas marketing activities in Iberia.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In addition, Brazil is going according to plan. So, we confirm our production guidance. As such, we are now  expecting full year EBITDA to be above our guidance. On the other hand, CapEx intensity should increase during  the second half of the year staying, however, closer to the bottom of our guidance.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Thank you, Carlos. I will be brief today as our financials this quarter are quite self-explanatory. Starting with the  P&L on slide 10, group EBITDA in Q2 was up 40% year-on-year to €473 million. This is up 13% from Q1 despite  weaker oil prices in the second quarter. E&P EBITDA was €188 million in the quarter, supported by both  production growth and higher oil and natural gas prices year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Refining & Marketing EBITDA was also up significantly both year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter to €233 million,  supported by the strong performance in our Refining & Marketing businesses. Gas & Power EBITDA decreased  year-on-year to €46 million. And this is impacted by the deconsolidation of the gas infrastructure business and a  smaller contribution from the natural gas supply and trading activities.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now, below the EBIT line, we have a higher contribution from associated companies now including our share of  earnings from the gas infrastructure business, whilst financial results reflect the swing year-on-year in mark-to- market of refining margin hedges. Higher P&L tax charges reflect primarily higher corporate results and  production taxes. Net income was €151 million in the quarter, this on a RCA basis. Under IFRS, net income was  €99 million, with the main difference arising from negative inventory effect of about €35 million in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On slide 11, CapEx during the first half of the year amounted to €411 million. And this is mostly allocated to  development activities in BM-S-11 in Brazil and block 32 in Angola. CapEx numbers showed the expected  reduction in drilling activities in Brazil with over 75% of the wells already drilled in Lula and Iracema. For the rest  of the year, we should see some pickup in E&P CapEx intensity given that Coral FID took place in June.

file: GALP - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 30July2018 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Thank you, Pedro and good morning to you all. We are pleased to present another strong set of operational and  financial results. Galp continues to be focused on its strategy execution. In the Q, the EBITDA reached €628  million and our production growth story continues to be supported by higher oil prices and refining performance.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Moving to the downstream on slide 7. So, refining had a good quarter with our utilization rates and a positive  performance. Galp's realized refining margin was $6.1 per barrel. We captured the strong middle distillate cracks  during the quarter as well as the slight recovery in gasoline cracks, when comparing with the last quarter. Exports  to U.S. also contributed positively with a supportive RBOB and EuroBob spread in the quarter. It is also worth  highlighting our refining system flexibility to accommodate different raw materials and energy sources, which  allowed us to optimize our sourcing and energy costs supporting our margin.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the Gas & Power, we had volume sold to industrial clients by higher than in the Q – in the past Q, especially in  Iberia. And we also increased traded volumes, even though this was mainly due to lower margin network trading  activities, which offset the decline in LNG trading volumes.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Also in Brazil, we have spudded the Guanxuma exploration well in BM-S-8, where oil was found. The preliminary  results are encouraging, but further analysis and evaluation is needed. In Mozambique, Area 4 partners submitted  to the government, the Plan of Development for the first phase of the Rovuma LNG project, which will start  developing the large number reservoir. This first phase POD comprises two LNG trains, each with 7.6 mtpa  capacity. This is an important milestone for Mozambican project, and we are targeting FID for next year and first  LNG for 2024.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In relation to the Coral South FLNG project execution, we are observing that the project is proceeding according  to plan, and we expect to have the first [indiscernible] (09:26) during that second half of this year. The  Mozambique projects are key to Galp's strategy, [ph] longing us to have (09:34) equity LNG as well as  progressing forward a lower carbon portfolio mix.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: As for the downstream, and as previously mentioned, we have a feasible solution to supply high and low [ph]  compliance products (09:51) by 2020. We are already producing some bunkering batches according to future  specification, which are being tested in a real environment.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the Gas business, we have established a long-term agreement to access 1 mtpa of LNG to be supplied from  the United States. This is part of our well-select gas sourcing strategy to secure a balanced and competitive long- term Galp's sourcing portfolio.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Thank you, Carlos. And I'll go straight to slide 10, and on some of the items which drove our P&L. EBITDA was –  E&P EBITDA was significantly up year-on-year to €411 million, and this is supported by increase in production  and oil prices and this despite the weaker dollar, when we compare with last year.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Gas & Power EBITDA decreased €11 million and that's year-on-year to €34 million. This was impacted by the  expected lower contribution from LNG trading, not really much else worth highlighting here.

file: GALP - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 29October2010 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on in a brief business-by-business analysis in slide five, you can see that the E&P EBITDA  reached €37 million in the third Q 2010, up 31% year-on-year, driven by the increase in both net  entitlement production and crude price. Nevertheless, net entitlement production showed a Q-on-Q  decrease of 12% to 9,500 barrels per day, mainly due to the trends of the Angolan PSA leading to  the decrease of production allocated to the cost oil component.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In the gas and power business, the EBITDA reached €56 million in the third Q taking advantage  from the positive Sines cogeneration contribution. The natural gas infrastructure business  continued to produce an important contribution as is referred in slide seven.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Concerning the natural gas volumes for the fourth Q, we are expecting a slight increase on a  quarterly basis.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 3 and that was indispensable to assure that hydrocracker being built in Sines is world-class in terms  of efficiency, performance and size. It is one of the largest hydrocrackers that is installed in  refineries [inaudible] you remember, 45,000 barrels a day of processing capacity. The Matosinhos  refinery is on schedule, if anything ahead, and it will be ready to deliver VGO for the Sines project  in due time. The key components of the projects had a vacuum distillating unit as well as a  visbreaker, also some tankage and complementary desulfurization facilities.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: As I referred before, the original program for Matosinhos is always one quarter ahead of Sines and  that is being totally assured from the development that we see there. So that the relevance of this  project is that it will bring us much more stable and more aligned with the market refining margins,  which put our refineries in terms of process efficiency, energy efficiency and cost efficiency among  the top quartile refineries in Europe for their type of refinery.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: I am now in a solid position to tell you after discussion with our colleagues under construction after  analyzing all the data that we have that the recoverable reserves of oil and gas in the complex  Tupi-Iracema is solidly in the range of 5 billion to 8 billion barrels of oil a day, of oil, I apologize. So  the numbers are – I remember that this number was generated after the second well and  comprehensive 3D seismic and the drilling that has happened simply confirms and strengthening –  strengthen our confidence in the numbers that we have there.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: So, as far as Tupi nothing new. We are actually – I was yesterday in Cidade Angra dos Reis and I  could see in the neighborhood two wells being drilled. One was the gas injection well that will  receive gas from the reservoir while the commissioning onshore of the gas infrastructure is not  complete. And it’s obviously going to be used to maintain the pressure in the reservoir. The facilities  itself – that well will be completed in January. The facility itself, the plant, is able to use that well to       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 4 inject CO2 isolated if that is necessary to inject a mixture of CO2 and natural gas or methane and  to inject only methane. The facilities there is operational, is waiting for the completion of the well.  Not farther away, I saw the drilling of Tupi South drilling completed. It would be one of the last –  one of the few remaining appraisal wells that need to be completed. Everything is going according  to plan, no surprise other than solid confirmation of the range of reserves that we have for this well.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: So now let’s move to Iara, block BM-S-11 includes these two areas Tupi and Iracema and  separated area that was not relinquished in the Phase 2 of exploration that is the Iara area. The  Iara, as we all know, have been shared with the market as recoverable, expected recoverable oil  and gas reserves in the range of 3 billion to 4 billion barrels. I can simply tell you that we maintain  these assessment of the reserves of Iara after – even recent discussion on the data that we have  about the reservoirs and the well drilled and we will be drilling an additional two appraisal wells as  soon as possible.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In the last page, I refer to Jupiter. Jupiter is a reservoir that has – of the size of Tupi, is quite a big  reservoir, which extends itself beyond our contractual area. And in which we only drilled one well. I  want to note that reservoir has oil ring, relevant oil ring complemented by a catch of gas and  condensate and with a very high concentration of condensate. Reservoir studies had been  intensive in the last – nearly two years. And we’ve already agreed the location of the forthcoming  well, which will be drilled in 2011 to purify basically the expected concentration along the reservoir  of gas and condensate. All in all, this is Galp’s opinion that the concentration of condensates is  extremely relevant for the future of this reservoir. And we are an optimist about outcome of the  forthcoming well, particularly having in mind the kind of studies and analysis that we’ve been  making.

file: GALP - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 28October2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Claudio de Marco
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: First of all from a negative side, our operation and the financial results were negatively impacted by the  accomplished important milestones that will contribute to helping Galp's future success as an integrated energy  company.

texts.speaker: Claudio de Marco
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now, let's move to the third Q results in slide number five. Gas and Power business was the main contributor in  the quarter due to the better natural gas supply margins driven by natural gas purchases optimization. In line with  our expectations, the E&P economic performance took advantage from the increase in Brazilian production,  reaching more than 4,000 of oil barrel per day in the last month. But unfortunately, the performance of the R&M  segment continues to be affected by the depress of the European refining environment.

texts.speaker: Claudio de Marco
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In [inaudible] gas, the refining business notwithstanding but still negative environment we expect that margins  will be positively impacted by the Matosinhos upgrade which as you know is already up and running.

texts.speaker: Claudio de Marco
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: However on the oil distribution business we expect volumes to decrease on a quarterly basis on the back of  continued depressed economic environment in Iberia. Also I remind you that usually the third quarter of the year  show the most robust volume sold. Finally on the Gas and Power business we expect higher natural gas volume  sold this quarter not only driven by the winter period but mostly due to a higher leverage to better LNG market

texts.speaker: Claudio de Marco
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding the natural gas infrastructure sale previously announced, although we have received binding offers this  transaction has been impacted by the current macro environment. And we still have to take a final decision on this  process. However, I remind you that the Brazilian transaction is the key to ensure a solid and trustable capital  structure capable of supporting our strong growth going ahead.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: First I would like to – I would highlight the exploration drilling company in Mozambique. As you know, we have  announced last week a giant natural gas discovery at the Mamba South prospect in Area 4. This discovery well  found a continuous gas play in high quality [inaudible] to construction to confirm at least 15 Tcfs of gas in place.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Yesterday we also – as you know, we – it was with great satisfaction that we announced that even before reaching  the total depth of the well, we have confirmed a new separated reservoir that contains up to 7.5 Tcfs this time in  clean sense of [inaudible] , thus we're dealing an unprecedented potential of this tertiary play in Area 4.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: This discovery which shows by now a potential of up to 22.5 Tcfs of gas in place further supports the multi-trained  LNG development scenario. Results on this prospect far exceeded our pre-drill expectations and confirm the  and in high risk from peer regions high value exploration. We can have – we can now see that we are on the right  track in terms of diversification and Mozambique is already called appraisal area for our company.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Then on the high potential Potiguar Basin, we will be drilling our first exploration well spudding this year. This –  this is as you know an unexploited high risk, high potential area as it was the [inaudible] basin not so many years  ago. Drilling on these two areas may bring material resources addition to our already strong base of [inaudible]  resources thus reinforcing our upstream portfolio potential.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Moving on to these execution of our major projects the Lula/Cernambi development, we are once again happy to  say that this is growing as programmed at full speed as usually has been happening in that area, with production  reaching 80,000 barrels a day by the end of this year.

file: GALP - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 29October2012 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: As far as Júpiter is concerned, I'm very pleased to see that finally this field is being de-risked after the discovery  back in 2008. So far, we have already confirmed the reservoir continuity between Júpiter North East and the first  well discovered as I – the first discovery well as I referred in 2008. And the continuity of the reservoir is now  evident with a similar hydrocarbon composition, i.e., oil, natural gas and condensate. We are still drilling the well  to reach the target depth to potentially find deeper origins. Only after this we'll have – may be able to have a better  estimate on the total recoverable resources.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: While drilling this well, we have also encountered the same level of CO2 in line with the first discovery confirming  in this way the continuity of the reservoir and the formation mechanisms. And next year, we will evaluate our best  to monetize this gas. As you know, the potential of injecting CO2 in the pre-salt reservoirs has already been tested  both into analytical models and in the laboratory, and we started to test in a small scale in an operation in our  Lula project.  Once this potential is established and more oil is, is confirmed in Júpiter or nearby like in the Bracuhy prospect in  the same block, we have to decide under development options for Júpiter including the potential contribution of  the condensate volumes. What we learned is to have a clear project for the monetization of CO2, for the recovery  of the condensate, and for the production of oil. I highlight, however, that we are already anticipating that an  FPSO will be allocated in this field in 2018.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Let's now move on to our Lula project where we continue to deliver remarkable progress. Not only have we  already reached the plateau production at the first FPSO in one year and a half, we would also now start to test  enhanced oil recovery techniques. I'm referring to the WAG, i.e., water alternating with gas injection, as well as  the production through highly deviated wells which we expect to initiate in 2013. We've also started to inject CO2  in the Lula pilot project in order to confirm the effectiveness of replacing nitro gas injection by CO2 in this type of  carbonaceous reservoirs.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Next year, we will also start producing from a highly deviated well, already drilled through the south and which  shares the potential to increase the recoverability through the reservoir. I emphasized that relevance of this work  on EOR techniques to increase significantly. We expect the oil volumes to be recovered by increasing the huge  conservative recovery factor currently in our economic and reservoir models.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding Area 1, I want to reassure you that the consortium is working restless to the fast development of the gas  resources already discovered. We continue to develop appraisal activities in the block and at the same time  proceed with exploration. In fact, after shooting seismic this year, it was the team who will de-risk more gas  prospects, but as well and oil prospects in the south of the block.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: I would also like to give you an update on our refinery upgrade project. The commissioning of the hydrocracker is  underway and will be completed in the short-term. We expect steady production from the upgrading – upgraded  refining system this year, hopefully by the end of November, but the upgrade full impact in earnings will only be  seen as from early towards 2013 with relevant impact in cash flow generation.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding our oil marketing business, it will continue to be impacted by the demand down in Turkey and Iberia,  due to the austerity measures in place in Portugal and Spain and others recently announced. We monitor this  closely and we are working to optimize our business in order to partially offset the macro contacts.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the other hand, looking into our natural gas business, the falling demand in Iberia, which is impacted due to  the increased competitive of coal coming from the U.S.A. has allowed us to divert LNG cargos to the markets with  strong demand needs like Japan. We've been able to capture interesting opportunities, and we are confident that  we will continue to do so. Not only that, our increased focus on this activity enabled us to secure access to key  international markets going forward and the lowest to [ph] gather (09:12) relevant experience on the global  energy business, which at the end will be truly important for our participation in the Mozambican project  development.  Lastly, I'm glad to tell you that we are recent – that we were recently included for the first time in the Dow Jones  Sustainability Index, both at the European level and worldwide. It is really a recognition of our focus on the soft  skills, which are key to the sustainable success of our strategy, such as our employees development programs, our  safety and environmental practices, our stakeholders engagement in risk management policies, as well as our  social corporate responsibility.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In the Iberian business, the marketing business, we will continue to suffer from Iberian's past economic  conditions, but on the positive side, we will have the start-up of upgrade project and increased support from the  LNG trading activity induced by the reduction of demand of gas in Iberia.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Having said this, let's go over our third quarter results. On the P&L statement and I am now on slide 13 of the  presentation, you will have seen that our Q3 EBITDA increased by 38% year-on-year to about €306 million with  growth coming particularly from higher production in Brazil and the increased LNG volumes sold in the  international markets.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Our E&P business continues to perform well with EBITDA up 74% year-on-year having accounted for roughly one  third of our EBITDA this quarter, as the production from Lula continued to advance steadily in line with  expectations. On the other hand, I'm referring to our refining and marketing business, the oil demand downturn  in Iberia continues to wait on volumes sold, which largely offset the better refining margin environment in the  periods.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: However, and as Manuel mentioned, the decreased demand for gas from the utilities in Iberia allowed us to divert  LNG cargos to international markets, especially to Asia helping our gas and power EBITDA to grow 31% versus  the same quarter last year. Our EBIT was up 55% year-on-year to €173 million, notwithstanding the abandonment  provisions of Kuito and BBLT fields in Angola of €17 million, higher provisions for doubtful accounts in our  refining and marketing business, and higher depreciations resulting from the start up of the new units in the

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: The natural gas business should continue to be supported by volumes sold to premium markets leveraging on our  flexible natural gas and LNG sourcing base. All these considered, we see 2012 EBITDA is standing at around €1  billion in line with the previous guidance and confirming the positive characteristics of our integrated business  model. As the worst economic context in Iberia and the refining upgrade startup delay were offset by higher  Brazilian E&P performance and by the LNG trading activity.

file: GALP - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 28October2013 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Thank you, Tiago, and good morning to all of you. I'd like to begin our call today with an update on our Lula  project. First regarding Lula Northeast, you saw that production already increased during the third quarter. This  was due to the connection of the first gas injection well, which allowed us to ramp up oil production to around  30,000 barrels a day, just from the single producing well.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now as for the remaining works on Lula Northeast, we are planning to have the second producer connected until  the end of the year using flexible risers. This is in fact the contingency measure that we are considering to mitigate  the delay in the installation of the buoyancy-supported risers.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: As you know, the works for the installation of the [ph] BSE (2:16) – BSR at the [ph] Sapingo-1 (2:19) field suffered  delays due to tough winter weather conditions with impact on the [ph] works (2:27) in our area. Nevertheless, we  expect the weather window we have now there in the summer season to improve in the coming months, allowing  us to proceed with installation of the BSR in Lula Northeast. We now anticipate that the first buoy will be installed  during the first quarter of the next year, starting in early January.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: I want to make it clear that all the steps that could be taken in advance to the installation of the buoy were already  taken, not only have we drilled more than half of the development wells need for the entire project, but we have  also concluded the eight foundations for the two buoys at the subsea level. So, we are prepared for the buoy  installation and to connect additional producer wells as soon as this is possible.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: As we mentioned before, we see two bottlenecks in what regards production ramp up at the Cidade de Paraty and  these are the buoy installation, which should be overcome early next year, and the connection to the gas export  line, which we expect also during the early phase of the first quarter of next year. So yes, there has been in fact a  delay and it will take our – and it will impact our 2013 exit production targets for Lula Northeast of 37,000 barrels  per day. However, I want to make it clear that this effect is not material when considering the value of the project,  as we are confident on the full ramp-up in 18 months, as initially projected.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Let me tell you that we do not regret having chosen this technology for Lula Northeast. We believe that, depending  on the [ph] area (4:25) of the slope, the use of BSR will prove to be positive in the long term in terms of reducing  equipment fatigue throughout the project and increasing competition in the market of the oil service company.  Thus, it was a valuable strategic decision made with a long-term view.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding Cabiúnas, the second pipeline to export gas from Lula, [indiscernible] (6:22) in that aspect, the works  are progressing as planned, with most of the pipes already manufactured and already in Brazil. As you know, this  will be key to increase all the production in line with the capacity buildup in the field. We feel confident that the  pipeline will be working by 2015, but in case of any potential delay, we should be able to inject more gas into the  reservoir. At the same time, we proceed with the reservoir data acquisition campaign, namely at the flanks of the  Lula field. This increases our knowledge on those areas and helps us to better adjust the development plan of  Lula/Iracema allowing us to adapt the infrastructure to be allocated to each part of the field.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: As you know, [ph] in crude (7:12) wells, RDA wells were the main reason behind the increase of the expected  recovery factor of the field. Continuing with the value upside opportunities, I remind you that we continue to test  the water-alternating-gas injection in Lula, and with the first WAG well in the gas cycle after having gone through  the water phase, and the second well is now presently injecting water. So far, we have some positive indications  that we expect to have preliminary results to share with you next year at our Capital Markets Day.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Clearly in the Santos Basin, I'm glad to share with you the success we have achieved in Bracuhy, where we have  found a significant oil column of 100 meters and the same mix of hydrocarbons that we have seen in Júpiter,  proving in this way that the two areas are just one structure. So, what are we doing now? So, what we are doing  now is not only evaluating the data gathered in Bracuhy, but also reprocess data from Júpiter in light of these  results. This means that when we announce, we will be announcing our first estimate for Bracuhy resources, we  may also revise our current assumptions for Júpiter.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We will see in the future that the Júpiter/Bracuhy structures are one single structure. In any case, the results from  Bracuhy that we already obtained are telling us and supporting the reinforcement of the development case for  Júpiter, with first oil planned for 2019. We will first focus on the development of the oil and condensate. Our base  case as of today is that we will be able to develop the oil, strip the condensate, and reinject the gas, including the  CO2.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now in Mozambique, works will continue in preparation for the final investment decision by 2014. To pursue this  objective, we have concluded this quarter the appraisal campaign in the Mamba/Coral complex, and we are now  focused on the establishment of the LNG supply contract of [indiscernible] (11:13) legal framework that supports a  medium long-term project of this magnitude and also on the finalization of the unitization agreement, which with  all the discussions currently ongoing.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the exploration front, I must highlight the positive results obtained in the south Area 4 – in the south of Area  4, where the Agulha well proved the existence of a new flank. More important and finding up to 7 Tcfs of natural  gas in place, we have discovered wet gas in the Cretaceous interval, which was tested for the first time and  increased the probability of finding oil in the area. We expect to have better understanding of this potential after  executing a three-well exploration campaign in the area next year.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: [ph] It's reasonably (12:18) important message I want to convey today, considering the results of the Agulha-1 and  the volume of resources in reservoirs exclusively located in our area, which are already over 30 Tcfs. We are able  to – we are now able to consider new alternatives to monetize those volumes of gas in place being FLNG and [ph]  GPL (12:44) options under study.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Not only that, we continue to evaluate new ways of extracting more value from Lula/Iracema as we continue with  the reservoir data acquisition wells with six of these wells completed so far this year and we continue to test the  impact of the EOR techniques like the two WAG wells currently connected and in operation.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In addition, in the short term, we will continue to de-risk the developments of another high potential project, the  Iara. In fact, on Iara we are currently drilling the Iara High Angle well, which after completed we'll proceed with  the production test.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Just a word on Carcará, we have the plan to drill an appraisal well on this juncture later this year with potential  results to be – we expected by the beginning of 2014. This plan has changed as a consequence of the required [ph]  feasibility (16:03). And now the well will be drilled in two phases. The first phase starting this November and the  second phase planned for the second half of the year using a [ph] different tree (16:15), meaning that the results  on Carcará extension will only be [ph] available (16:20) by the end of 2014. The first rig will drill the well up to the  south layers that will not enter the reservoir [indiscernible] (16:33) because as you remember, we expect a high  pressure reservoir. The second rig will [indiscernible] (16:40) will enter into the reservoir and they have the  specifications to do their job.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On downstream and gas business, I will refer in short. In refining and marketing, the hydrocracker is having an  exceptional operational performance since it began its operations. However, not being able to shine in our  numbers due to the very harsh environment that is currently impacting the refining industry in Europe.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the positive side, we see – we are seeing now the first signs of recovery in the Iberian market with the third  quarter numbers showing an increase on construction on diesel [ph] inject (17:20). Let's now hope that these  signs are sustainable.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In the gas and power business, our LNG trading team is doing an amazing job in capturing value from our LNG  portfolio contracts. And the work done so far gives me great comfort that we should be able to maintain this  performance at least for the next couple of years.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In a nutshell, the dreadful conditions in refining have taken the shine off an otherwise very strong quarter for our  LNG trading activity. I highlight that unless otherwise indicated all my comments relates to this third quarter.  E&P EBITDA of €110 million was in line with the previous year. Net entitlement production was up 12% to 22,000  BOEs per day from which about 60% came from Brazil. However, the higher production and the increase in the  average realized price per barrel equivalents were offset by higher operating costs.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Refining and marketing EBITDA was down to €74 million. On the back of a much worse refining environment, we  benchmark refining margins down a whopping $5 per barrel from last year. However, Galp's refining margin was  down by only $2.8 per barrel given that the new hydrocracker operated at 105% load factor during this quarter.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Volumes in the oil marketing business in Iberia were just marginally up this last quarter versus last year after  significant declines, as you know, throughout the last few years. We are hopeful that we have hit the bottom here.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Gas and power EBITDA was up 16% to €122 million in the quarter. We continue to leverage on our strong LNG  trading position with about a dozen cargoes sold in the quarter mainly to LatAm and Asia. It could have been even  better without the Nigerian force majeure, although this situation improved a bit since the previous quarter.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the refining and marketing business, the higher depreciation charges are related to the hydrocracker, which  was commissioned at the end of Q1, that's about €21 million there and another €21 million in provisions for a  major client receivables, a nasty consequence of the tough economic environments in Iberia.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now to conclude, I'll go through the main drivers that we expect will impact our performance during the last  quarter of the year. I'm on slide 19. Working interest production is expected to increase marginally to about  27,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, as we will have two extended well pads in the Lula field offsetting the  lower production of the Angra dos Reis FPSO.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: This low production is due to maintenance activities in the Mexilhão platform, which impacts the level of natural  gas we can export, and thus constraining oil production. For the avoidance of doubt, there are no problems with  the FPSO itself.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: The refining and marketing business may continue to be impacted by macro factors; namely, the persistence of  tough refining conditions in Europe. However, these headwinds are expected to be cushioned by the hydrocracker  operations and hopefully by the slowdown in oil demand contraction in Iberia.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Gas volumes are expected to come down comparing with the last quarter, with the third quarter, as we may not be  able to maintain such high LNG trading volumes. We have eight LNG cargoes already contracted to be sold during  the fourth quarter.

file: GALP - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 27October2014 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Thore has an extensive career in oil and gas industry, we are most pleased to have him with us, in our executive  management team. I'm sure that Thore will successfully lead our highly motivated E&P division.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Now, let me start with an update on the execution of our main upstream projects. I will start with Lula/Iracema in  the Brazilian Santos basin. As you might remember, commercial production in the Lula field started at the end of  2010 with FPSO Cidade de Angra dos Reis only four years – I would emphasize again, only four years after the 2P  discovery.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Today, we have three production units installed in the field. These add for us particularly exciting times. After  having the first FPSO at full capacity for a couple of years, we have accomplished another two important  milestones since September. FPSO Cidade de Paraty reached full capacity in mid-September, 15 months after  starting production, three months ahead of our plans. This faster ramp up was only possible to the excellent  reservoir characteristics with well flow rates of around 30,000 barrels a day. The timely ramp up period was also a  result of hard work from those involved in this operation.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Additionally, we have – we recently had another very important milestone. It was the start of production of the  FPSO Cidade Mangaratiba in Iracema South. This is the first unit deployed in the field, and the first with the  capacity – the capacity to process 150,000 barrels a day. 8 million standard cubic meters of gas a day and 264,000  barrels of water injection capacity.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Now, let me move ahead for the next upcoming units, the hull of Cidade de Itaguaí, our FPSO #4, is ready to leave  the Cosco shipyard in China to the Brasfels shipyard in Brazil for integration works and is expected to be in the  Iracema North on-time for the first oil during the first quarter of 2015.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: We expect to issue the declaration of commerciality by year end. The extended well test that started in June in the  Iara West location has been showing positive indications, and should last until the end of the year. I'm happy to  register the excellent results of this EWT so far, with average flow rates of around 29,000 barrels per day.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Moving now to BM-S-24, during this quarter, we continued with appraisal activities with a conclusion of the  Apollonia well, which confirmed hydrocarbons in the same – with the same fluid characteristics as those  discovered in Júpiter and Bracuhy. We are now conducting an important DST test in Bracuhy and we expect to  spud an additional appraisal well until the end of the year. Both these – the results of these DST and this appraisal  well are extremely important.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: The new well to be named Elida, will contribute to the increase of our knowledge of the Júpiter area. As we have  already stated, the consortium is fully committed to de-risking these major reservoirs and you should expect the  appraisal campaigning in BM-S-24 to continue towards 2015. And remember that we have to declare the  commerciality of this field throughout 2016.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Regarding the development activities, we have now three consortia contracted to carry out the feed and the design  and to submit an EPC contract for the FLNG option to the Coral area. We expect to receive these offers during the  first half of 2015. Based upon them, we'll take the decisions about how to proceed.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Regarding the development of the Mamba reservoir, based on onshore liquefication units, the consortium has  already launched an invitation to tender for an EPC with four entities pre-selected with offers due to be received in  the first half of 2015. And these two works both the EPC proposals and the EPC for both Coral and Mamba will be  the basis for the future development of the Coral and Mamba.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Now, let me go over to our downstream and gas activities. After a historically low refining margins in Europe,  during the first half of the year, finally, in the third quarter, market conditions improved on our benchmarking  margins to around $2.3 per barrel. And this was the basis for the improvement of our results in this area.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: We took advantage of these market conditions with our hydrocracking facility and our FCC running at full  capacity throughout the entire quarter. And we have been able to improve our premium over benchmark by  optimizing the crude and VGO intakes. This was only possible due to the operational flexibility of our units and  the quality of our logistics infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: This recovery of the refining margins and the positive contribution of our marketing business supported the  improvement of our reserves in the oil downstream activities. In fact, I would say that even during adverse times  in Iberia, we have been able to maintain our market share in a very competitive and difficult market. However, I  must emphasize that we continue to be cautious on the refining environment and it should show impacts on our  downstream results since the existence of refining overcapacity in Europe is still evident and uncertainty remains  in the market.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: On the gas side, in addition to operating efficiently our regulated assets and our Iberian commercial activities, we  have sustaining our international energy structured sales with good contribution for our results, even if not as  strong as the last quarters, as previously expected, and flagged out on our last short-term outlook. We are taking  old actions on our Gas & Power business to ensure that the results we are presenting are sustainable for the  forthcoming few years.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: Finally, Gas & Power EBITDA was down 18% year-on-year to €99 million in the quarter with lower volumes of  LNG traded in the international markets. Our regulated infrastructure and power businesses maintained their  stable contribution to EBITDA during the period.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: Finally, our usual guidance for this upcoming quarter, we are expecting Q4 production of around 35,000 barrels  of oil equivalent per day supported by the production plateau of FPSO #2 in Lula Northeast and by the  contribution of FPSO #3.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: We are expecting Iberian oil product sales to remain stable year-on-year. Natural gas volumes are expected to be  stable quarter-on-quarter as we don't anticipate material changes to LNG volumes traded in the international  markets.

file: GALP - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 26October2015 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: Thank you, Pedro, and good morning to you all. I'm glad to be here today, presenting another set of solid results.  In a scenario of low for longer oil prices, the benefits of the integrated business model stands out. Effectively,  Galp's EBITDA was up 9% in an environment where Brent was down 50%. This was due to the contribution of our  Refining & Marketing activities and to the strong execution in the E&P business, where the net entitlement  production was up 56% year-on-year, partially offsetting the lower oil price.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: On the demand side, the Iberian oil and gas market is growing 6% and 2%, respectively, on the back of lower  prices and the economic recovery, both in Portugal and Spain, which is supportive of our marketing activities.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: You see now here on slide number five that over the last 12 months, its production has gone from around 30,000  barrels per day to an average of 46,000 barrels during the third quarter due to the start-up of the FPSO #4 in  Lula/Iracema. Those reservoirs continue to perform strongly with wells producing over 30,000 barrels of oil per  day. And we are now over 50,000 barrels per day. This is a symbolic but important milestone for Galp on our  journey to much, much higher production levels. In fact, our current production should double again over the next  couple of years.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: Moving to the next slide, in the slide number six, a word to the FPSO #3, Cidade de Mangaratiba, installed in  Iracema Sul and where we expect to see the fifth producer coming on stream in the first Q. With the 30,000  barrels of oil per day and per well, we expect unit to reach plateau production of around 150,000 barrels of oil per  day by the end of 2015. This will be achieved one year after first oil vis-à-vis the planned 18 months' ramp-up.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: As such, by the middle of the next year, we would have 820,000 barrels of oil per day of installed capacity in  Lula/Iracema about five years since the first oil and eight years after the first discovery. This in area which was  considered to be frontier. As for the replicants, the first unit is at Brasfels in Rio de Janeiro and we are  comfortable with the expected deliver date of 2017.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: In Potiguar, we are currently drilling Pitú North in order to appraise this offshore discovery in Brazilian equatorial  margin. We are positive on this area, but we need to conclude the well and then decide if we will have a DST there.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: On slide number 10, moving to the other side of the Atlantic in Angola, we continue to focus on extracting  additional resources from Block 14 with relatively low marginal CapEx. The tie-back connection of Lianzi field to  the platform in BBLT has been concluded during September, and Lianzi is ready to start production shortly. In  Block 32, development activities are proceeding according to the plan, and this project is on track for first oil  during 2017.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: In Mozambique, the area for consortium continues to work on Coral FLNG in order to prepare the investment  decision. There is not much I can advance at this stage other than to say that the consortium continues to  negotiate the EPCIC with the contractors and that we continue to work on a robust LNG offtake agreement.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: [indiscernible] (9:15) the FID on Coral would be an important milestone for the Rovuma Project, I would stress  that the key development will be the onshore solution with the first phase of development of Mamba expected to  be sanctioned late in 2016.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: Turning now to slide 11 and the downstream businesses. Performance was supported by the high refining margins  observed during the first nine months of the year. This was possible due to the recent refinery upgrade and to the  reliability centered management system that is in place. We continue to focus our increasing of the return on  capital employed in these businesses, mainly through the optimization of the refining process and the energy  efficiency. Marketing has also been stronger this year, with an improving Iberian market and the operational  efficiencies which we continue to implement in the business.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: Gas & Power has also taken advantage of the increased focus on LNG trading and on the medium-term supply  contracts that have been secured. And we continue to diversify our trading activity, namely by gaining access to  new European markets. These trading capabilities will support our strategy for the future when our equity gas  from Mozambique becomes available.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: Group EBITDA was €411 million, up 9% year-on-year despite much lower oil price. As Carlos mentioned, this was  mainly driven by higher refining margins and upstream volumes. Refining & Marketing EBITDA increased over  €100 million to €245 million. Marketing also provided a solid contribution during the quarter, benefiting from  higher efficiency. E&P EBITDA, however, was down year-on-year by almost a third to €89 million. Higher  volumes and the stronger dollar could not make up for the lower oil prices. Gas & Power EBITDA was also down  to €72 million, with fewer arbitrage opportunities in the LNG markets only partially offset by network gas trading  activities in Europe.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: Group EBIT was up 8% year-on-year to €263 million, and this was driven by the improvement in EBITDA. Net  income was €180 million on an RCA basis. Under IFRS, the bottom line was €27 million. This was impacted by  the negative inventory effect of €115 million in the quarter and nonrecurring items of €38 million, €27 million of  which relates to a temporary energy tax in Portugal.

file: GALP - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 28October2016 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Thank you, Pedro, and good morning to you all. And thank you for attending to this call today. Galp has just  celebrated its 10th Anniversary since the IPO. It has been quite a transformational journey. At the time of the IPO,  Galp was a small energy player focused on its downstream and gas activities in Iberia.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In 10 years, the company grew into a mid-size integrated oil and gas company with a strong international  presence, developing world-class projects in the upstream, and supported by a competitive downstream and gas  business. We have done so by transforming our company internally and by establishing strategic alliance with key  entities in regions we operate, and that's how we will proceed in our path.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now back to what bring us here today. Q3 delivered a strong operational performance with an EBITDA up 14% Q- on-Q on the back of higher production and oil marketing seasonality. However, year-on-year, we are still impacted  by the challenging microenvironment. Brent has stood at around $46 per barrel during this third quarter with an  unbalanced supply and demand as well as high inventories.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: The benchmark refining margin was down both on year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter basis to $2.3 per barrel  following the lower gasoline and diesel cracks. On the positive side, the Iberian oil market increased around 4%  year-on-year mainly due to higher demand for diesel and jet supported by a strong tourism activity this summer in  Iberia. As for the natural gas market, demand decreased slightly year-on-year, reflecting a lower gas demand for  electricity generation on the back of high renewal and the nuclear generation.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now on slide seven to take a closer look to our operations during the quarter and starting with E&P activities. Our  averaging working interest production stood at 74,000 barrels per day, up 35% from previous quarter. This was  mainly driven by the ramp-up of FPSOs #4 and #5, as well by the start-up of the FPSO #6 in Brazil. FPSO #1  Cidade de Angra dos Reis and Cidade de Paraty, the FPSO #2, were back to their plateau production after  completing maintenance work. FPSO #3 Cidade de Mangaratiba in the Iracema South continues to produce at  plateau level with the connection to the unit of the Cabiúnas gas export network, expected during the fourth  quarter.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: During the third quarter, FPSO #4, Cidade de Itaguaí, in the Iracema North was connected to the Cabiúnas gas  export pipeline, allowing the unit to reach its plateau during August, only 13 months after start-up. So we have  now [ph] four (05:18) units running at plateau level with one almost there, in fact, FPSO $#5, which started  production in February in Lula Alto area and its fourth producer well connected during the third quarter, with the  fifth producer expected to be working by the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: This is a fantastic work from Petrobras with helping hands from our colleagues in Brazil. We currently expect to  beat our production guidance for the full year, as the operations are running on schedule with a good  performance. The expected exit rates for year-end is somewhere between 82,000 and 85,000 barrels of oil  equivalent per day.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Moving to our projects in Africa. The offshore Coral South FLNG project in Area 4 in Mozambique saw the  signature in October of the gas off-take agreement with BP. This contract ensures the sale of the Coral LNG  volumes for a period of 20 years.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: This contract is, however, subject to FID investment decision for these FLNG projects. Regarding the Mamba  onshore project, we continue to analyze the EPC proposals. In Angola, production from block 14 and 14K remain  steady. In block 32, Drilling & Completion [indiscernible] (07:18) in the development area of Kaombo and the two  FPSO units are being built in Singapore.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In the marketing, oil products had a stronger September, maintaining its positive contribution to results. The  Iberian oil products market is recovering and Galp continues to optimize its clients' portfolio and to reduce  volumes to lower margin wholesale clients.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the gas and power, LNG trading was impacted by fewer arbitrage opportunities with activity in the quarter,  mostly based on structure contracts. This was only partially offset by the increasing sales to the electrical  segment. [ph] Under (9:12) regulated infrastructure business, the results were impacted by the well-flagged  decrease of the regulatory rate of return effected from July, from around 7.9% to 6.2%.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In what concerns to the power business, we continue to see results normalizing after the steep decline in  commodity prices during 2016 and benefiting from increased sales to the grid and to direct clients. I remind you  that, strategically speaking, this is a gas to power integrated business.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: E&P EBITDA was up 43% year-on-year to €127 million with a significant increase in production more than  offsetting the lower oil prices. Also, upstream unit production costs continued to be diluted down on the back of  higher production. During Q3, unit production costs were particularly low, but here we have a one-off adjustment  from over-charges from previous periods.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Gas & Power EBITDA is flat year-on-year at €73 million, with a normalization of the Power business offsetting the  lower rate of return on the regulated infrastructure business. So group-wise, we have EBITDA sequentially higher  at 14% quarter-on-quarter, even if the sector headwinds continue to affect our year-on-your performance. Having  said this, and now with almost 10 months under our belt, we believe we should be able to beat the top end of our  EBITDA guidance of €1.3 billion for the full year, and this already considering the deconsolidation of the  November and December EBITDA of GGND.

file: GALP - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 30October2017 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In slide 5, you can see our last Friday announced two transactions, which reinforced our Brazilian pre-salt  footprint. Actually, during the Brazil bid rounds, which included pre-salt acreage, Galp acquired a 20% stake in  Carcará North, the area adjacent to our high-quality Carcará discovery within block BM-S-8. We bid through our  Brazilian subsidiary, Petrogal Brasil, in partnership with Statoil and Exxon. Our interest in these assets had been  well-flagged. And we are very happy with the outcome. We did not bid for any other asset, and we will continue to  be disciplined with our portfolio decision.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Refining & Marketing benefited mainly from iron international refining margins and exporting opportunities, namely  gasoline to the United States. Our Gas & Power business continues to be a stable contributor to cash flow,  though with limited trading opportunities in the LNG market. Overall, I would highlight that the strong operating  performance supported a positive free cash flow before dividends of about €170 million in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Additionally, the current economic momentum in Iberia has been supportive with higher volumes sold. On the Gas  & Power, we are increasing sales, particularly to industrial segment. Consumption from the electrical segment has  also been strong, given low hydro generation in Iberia. So, all in all, the increase in volumes sold to direct clients  has offset the lower volumes strength in the international market.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Starting with the P&L on slide 11, group EBITDA in Q3 was up 27% year-on-year to €487 million. This was just  3% up quarter-on-quarter, partly given reporting currency effects. E&P EBITDA reached €215 million in the  quarter, up year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter and this supported by production growth and a higher oil and  natural gas prices, despite the effects of the dollar depreciation against the euro.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: As for Gas & Power, EBITDA would have been stable if we exclude the impact from the gas infrastructure  business deconsolidation. At the EBIT level, I would just highlight that depreciation charges in upstream were  lower than one would expect considering the higher production, driven by a weaker Brazilian real against the  euro. And below the EBIT line, we have a higher contribution from associated companies where we now also  book the 77% of the gas infrastructure results.

file: GALP - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 29October2018 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: I will now briefly go through the main drivers of our performance in the different division starting with the upstream  on slide number 6. The working interest production Q-on-Q has decreased and it was driven by the concentration  of planned maintenance in Brazil including three units, three FPSOs, and a key gas export pipeline. Both the units  and the pipeline are now fully operational.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Looking to the margins in the quarter, we see that the margins were hit by lower gasoline [ph] Brent (00:07:00)  and higher price refinery self-consumption. At the same time, we had less supportive contribution from gasoline  exports to the United States due to planned inventory build ahead of the FCC unit shutdown that I referred to you  and also a lower EuroBob, [ph] RBob (00:07:22) spread. Still, Galp's realized refining margin in the Q was $5.8  per barrel already capturing $0.30 from our plan for an extra $1 per barrel by 2020 in energy efficiency and the  announced conversion in our refineries.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We are taking the opportunity to implement some projects and making some tie-ins related with these initiatives,  while performing the ongoing planned maintenance. Some of these projects will also help Galp during the IMO  transition period as we are able to improve our conversion capacity while also executing other small investments  to prepare our solution to supply tanker fuel fully compliant with IMO specs.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: And let me emphasize again that we do have a feasible solution for the IMO cap growth and that we are  expecting IMO to be neutral to slightly positive for our downstream operations. Middle distillates are expected to  appreciate and more than offset higher sourcing costs. But more importantly, it should be clearly positive for our  upstream performance which should benefit from the widening of the sweet-sour spread as we only produce  sweet crude.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: So, coming back to the quarter and looking to the marketing, the marketing activity continues to benefit from a  robust sales to direct clients in Iberia and the positive economic environment, and we can see that in the results.  As for gas and power business, this was the last quarter we have a contribution from the structure LNG trading  contracts that we have established back in 2015.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Going forward, gas trading activity will be based on potential opportunities in the international LNG market, but  also on the European natural gas hubs where we have already developed a relevant position. I would also  highlight that our electricity sales are growing nicely in Iberia. This should be supportive of our growth in these  segments in the future.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Thank you, Carlos, and good morning. Just a quick overview from me on the quarterly numbers, and I'll move to  slide 9 on the P&L. E&P EBITDA was unsurprisingly up year-on-year, driven by higher oil prices. And on a  quarter-on-quarter basis, EBITDA was actually down 4% or so with a relatively stable Brent, but lower production  given the significant maintenance we had in Brazil.

file: GALP - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 25February2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on slide five, we have to refer back the fourth quarter incorporates all to this extendable test  production since its beginning and which contributed with a production of 283,000 barrels net for  Galp. This contribution together with the increase in crude oil price were the key to reach the fourth  quarter EBITDA level which was up 18% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: And now slide six. The operating performance of refining margin business in the fourth quarter, as I  said earlier was hit by the continued depressed refining margin environment and as well by the  negative time lag effect of €19 million. The full year time lag effect was minus 56 million. On the  positive side, the market in the oil business performance is boosted also by the Iberian acquisition  partially offset the worst performance of the refining business.
