In the gas and power business,  despite the stable contribution from the regulated infrastructure business, natural gas volumes sold  were down fundamentally due to strong hydroelectric generation during the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: I can say that it rained a lot in Portugal. In this segment, I have to mention that the top of Sine’s  generation plant with an impact on Galp Energia electricity generation of 165 gigawatt hours, 53%  of the Galp total electricity generated in the fourth quarter, and as well we deposited impact on the  energy efficiencies of Sines refinery.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 2 lower debt cost. In 2009, the cost of debt was 3.8%, which compared to 5.1% in 2008. In terms of  tax, the decrease is due to lower oil tax paid in Angola and lower earnings before tax due to the  decrease in operating profit.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: On yearly basis, in the E&P, the CapEx was focused in development works in Angola, Tômbua- Lândana field and in Tupi field in Brazil. In Refining and Marketing, an important component of  CapEx was allocated to the refining upgrade project which is on-time and on-budget. In the Gas &  Power, CapEx was related to the cogenerations at Porto and Sines refineries and to the gas  network of distribution and development.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now in slide number five, in Angola you already know that that Tômbua-Lândana project is now  ramping up. This platform is on place, wells are being connected and we hope that this unit will be  producing 90,000 barrels a day in 2010, achieving at a later stage 1,000 barrels a day. This project  is now close to completion on the well site.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In slide number six, I am referring to the Tupi’s pilot project which is developing on track and  offering us valuable data for future development of the area, totally consistent with our  expectations. The Tupi development is as I said are on track and has producing 209 -- 283,000  barrels of oil per day net took out.  And I must remind you that the flow rate is limited by facilities  and the licenses to 20,000 barrels a day. The timing of development of this project from exploration  to production was at – was impressive and we are really happy with the results obtained so far.  This field as you know has recovered from volumes of five to eight million barrels of oil equivalent  without considering the upside that would come from review of recovery factors as we know and  learn more from the reservoir.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: By the end of this year, the Tupi pilot as it is known or the Tupi first commercial operation as it  could be known will come on stream with operation capacity of 100,000 barrels a day. That will be a  major milestone and de-risking of all the Santos Basin and in particular from the area where we are  operating BM-S-11.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The development CapEx associated with this pilot is estimated to be $3.7 billion not including the  FPSO because it is leased although it includes the pipeline cost to be shared by at least the next  three modules in the area.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now let us move to slide number seven and talk about the full Tupi development and refer to some  major milestones. The next steps that we will support the development of block BM-S-11 includes  further test in the successful Iracema’s DSTs and in the Tupi Northeast wells. The second module  to be filled is in the process of sanctioning, which is – and will be initiating productions by the end of  2013 and it is expected with the capacity of 120,000 barrels of oil equivalent, of oil. The main  concept for the future development of the field of the field, will consist as it is already been shared  with the investors with eight to 10 FPSOs the development of which will be basically phased on with  one every two years.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 4 Now in slide number eight, I referred to the Iara appraisal works that’s still ongoing. Iara another  great discovery of volumes between three and four billion barrels. We are continuing the appraisal  works, namely doing additional 3D seismic as a basis for the seismic interpretation that will help us  to understand better the reservoir. In addition an appraisal well will be drilled during 2010 following  by DST [inaudible] invest in 2011. We expect an extended well testing Iara to take place by 2012 to  2013 which in practice represents the beginning of the production of the another material field  workout.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Currently we are about to finish the drilling of the Ambrosia well. It is – which is targeting post salt  prospect which we’ll expect to be an extension of a neighboring discovery. As you are aware, this  block has already been defined, as in this block, we have already defined some pre-salt prospects  which will be drilled later. We also have the policy of news BMES-31 in the forthcoming months.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now to slide 21. We’re looking at the number there, you see sorry to slide 11, looking at the  numbers in the slide you can see the intensity of our exploration program for 2010 because besides  drilling- the drilling program in Brazil with the well seen BMS 11, 8, 21 and 24. We also have the  tool exploration wells in the shallow blocks in the Espírito Santos basin as well as appraisal wells in  Angola Block 14 and 32. We will also be drilling an exploration well in Angola NLNG project and in  Block C in this East Timor.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: All together, we will be drilling in 2010, according to our plans 18 exploration in the appraisal wells,  which will be a major source of the new flows that we hope we will support the value of our  company.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now let’s move to slide 12, to finish is this presentation basically I want to emphasis of this part of  the presentation. I want to emphasize that we also have a portfolio of perspective resources. This  portfolio has been reviewed from again these are numbers that have been 35 by DeMac that this  portfolio has been reduced from to 1.8 billion barrels because some of these prospects were  included in resources.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We will have oil in the second quarter for Porto and oil in, in the third quarter for Sines. I must  highlight to you that this project with another – will enable us to add value from a more efficiencies  in our refineries, mostly regarding to the decrease of the energy consumption key factor in the       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 5 refinery, the refining margin mainly when crude oil prices are high I note to you it’s 70% of the  operating cost in a typical refinery and fuel consumption. So the relevance of making energy  efficient – energy efficient the refinery is of extreme value.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The project is on schedule as already have been referred and from 2011 onwards we will benefit  from the margins that we will come from the quake between fuel and oil and [inaudible] rates and it  will offer us that double digit positive impact in cash flow generation from this project.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now let’s go to slide number 16, referring to natural gas. In natural gas supply, we are well  positioned to capture market volumes and margin growth in Iberia. Starting from our sourcing base,  we are currently studying new midstream options which we hope will put us in advantage in terms  of positioning when compared with our potential competitors.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We are also anticipating an increase in volumes. Due to the structural change in market dynamics,  which will fuel natural gas consumption in Portugal, a still immature market. In Spain, we plan to  increase penetration, acquiring new customers such as the recent acquisition of Gas Natural’s  assets.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: So in Portugal, volumes will increase with mark-to-market growth, including natural gas  consumption by gas power projects and in Spain, through organic growth gaining market share.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In slide number 17, I referred to the natural gas infrastructure. This is a stable business with  warranty cash flow. We have as you know, a warranty return on investment of about 9% on  distribution assets, and we presently have a ramp close to €1.2 billion as of – at the end of 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now let me conclude with slide number 22, which – with slide number 22, yes. We are, as you  already know, the most leveraged player to the pre-salt with valuable E&P portfolio which is not  replicable and we feel very proud and very committed to these – to the development of our – of the  projects in the pre-salt basins.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We had – we have – additionally, we have strong Iberian position that will be leveraged by the  upgrade projects in Sines and Porto, and we now have leading positions in natural gas and oil  distribution markets, will be generating cash flow to supporting the growth of our E&P projects.

file: GALP - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 11February2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: During the fourth quarter, we reached a very important milestone for Galp Energia’s long-term  strategy with the beginning of the first commercial operation from the Lula field in the Santos Basin,  where in October, and ahead of schedule, the pilot project started operations.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Very important is the fact that by the end of 2010, Galp Energia’s reserves posted a very significant  increase following the submission to the ANP, the Brazilian National Petroleum Agency, of the  development plan for Lula and Cernambi fields. That increase is a major breakthrough and has had  a read across to de-risking the Galp Energia’s resource portfolio, which at the end of the day is  translated into more valuable resources portfolio and more value added for the company. I would  also like to mention that our Iberian downstream business is also benefiting from increasing  efficiency, which helps us to disclose good results even in a not so positive macro environment.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Slide number four refers to the gas and power division. Looking at the gas and power, operating  performance in this business segment was negatively impacted by lower supply margins, due not  only to higher natural gas costs, due to less natural gas bought in the spot market but also due to  increasing market competitiveness. However, during 2010, this negative impact was more than  offset by higher volumes that were at 5% with the liberalised market accounting for 75% of total  sales.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: EBITDA of the gas and power division reached €60 million in the fourth Q, with natural gas  infrastructure business continuing with its stable and predictable earnings contribution.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: So let’s start by outlining the handled increase in EBITDA in the fourth Q and the full-year 2010. In  the quarter, it was mainly driven by the exploration and production and the refining marketing  business, which was pulled by higher price and production and refining margin, respectively. On an  annual basis, also the gas and power business segment increased, thanks to the higher natural gas  volumes sold and Sines cogeneration plant cooperation.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Below the EBIT line, we have associates were positively impacted by our result improvement of the  international natural gas pipeline companies. Financial results were €27 million negative in fourth  Q, and despite of the average debt increase, I would like to emphasize that during 2010 Galp  Energia maintained a solid and trustable relationship with the banking system, benefiting from good  contractual financing conditions. In fact, our cost of debt decreased 25 basis point, which confirms  the ability to reduce the impact of the turmoil that hit the credit markets.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Net profit was also negatively impacted by the higher oil tax paid in Angola, due to higher profit oil,  and by the increase of marginal income tax in Portugal. All in all, the net profit which reached €40  million in the fourth Q posted an increase of 16% year-on-year or 43% in the 12 months to €306  million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In refinery marketing, the CapEx was mainly allocated to the refining upgrade project, which  accounted for around 50% of 2010 total CapEx. The fiscal execution is running as planned, of  course, the spending in the quarter has rolled down. Manuel will go through these projects later in  the presentation.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In the gas and power division, the spending was mainly focused on the Matosinhos cogeneration  plant, which is expected to start in operation by the fourth Q 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In the exploration and production business, production is expected to reach 20,000 barrels per day  on a working-interest basis. In fact, the decrease in Angola production, we de-compensated by the  ramp up of the production from the FPSO Cidade de Angra dos Reis at the end of the quarter with  the end of the gas flaring element.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The turnaround started on January 13 and we expected the refinery to come on-stream by mid- February. Concerning the natural gas volumes for the first quarter 2011, we are expecting better  volumes than in the last quarter 2010, driven by the electrical segment in Portugal based on low  hydro levels and higher electricity generation levels. The level of liquidity facilities available give us  comfort to support our current project execution.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In less than four years, the construction was able to develop the first discovery made in 2006 with a  well Tupi. It is quite an achievement. Going into detail, Lula and Cernambi fields have already  announced a recoverable reserves of 8.3 billion barrels of oil equivalent. The development of these  fields envisages at this moment nine FPSOs from which seven in the Lula field and two in the  Cernambi field.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Natural gas metro gas export infrastructure needed to develop the production because flaring gas  is not permitted in Brazil. As you already know, the Mexilhão pipeline is already concluded with an  investment close to €800 million and it will be enough for the production of the first FPSO vessel  capacity. We can also add that the gas treatment unit in Caraguatatuba will be finished until the end  of the first Q2 2011, and it is an infrastructure critical for the increase in the production of oil in the  field.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 5 In addition, I want to refer that the front-end engineering and design by three firms for the FLNG  option to process the associated gas in BM-S-11, I was saying this FEEDs have already been  concluded and the consortium is presently studying them in more detail, so that we can have a final  investment decision during this year. I recall that FLNG is one of the options being studied to export  the gas from the fields. Alternatively, we will have sending the gas to internal market or liquefying  the gas onshore.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In fact, after the FPSO Cidade de Angra dos Reis, another FPSO with a capacity of 120,000 barrels  a day is due on-stream in the 2P Northeast area of the Lula field in 2013. This will be followed by  the third FPSO to be deployed in the Cernambi field in 2014 with a capacity, an oil capacity of  150,000 barrels a day.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: So by 2014, we will have three full FPSOs operating, one in 2011, Angra dos Reis, another 2013,  another is Cidade de Paraty and another in 2014 in the Cernambi field. Additionally, we will have  the small Cidade de São Vicente continuing its EWT projects to further evaluation of the reservoirs  in the fields and in the neighborhood. The first three FPSOs will be leased as already announced to  the market.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In addition, from 2015 to 2017, another six FPSOs also with an oil capacity of 150,000 barrels a  day should be allocated to the Lula and the Cernambi fields. The hulls for these FPSOs were  already awarded to a Brazilian company, Engevix Engenharia, thus respecting the local content  policy for the development of the pre-salt fields in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving to slide number 19, I’m going to refer to you about the evolution of our reserves and  contingent resources as well as later in prospective resources. In slide 19, we show you the results  of our strategy from the point of view of identified resources. We have successfully – we have been  successful in expanding and maturing our resource base. At the end of 2010, the 3P reserves  reached 574 million barrels of oil equivalent with 2P reserves reaching 397 million BOEs on a net  entitlement basis. The latter number compares with 35 million barrels of oil of entitlement reserves  at the end of 2009, which were only coming from Block 14.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: However, we must note now that based on our audited, updated technical review, the reserves in  Angola decreased to – from 34 million to 20 million barrels of oil equivalent when compared to – in  comparison with last year. And that was due to the worst performance of the wells versus the base  case.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In addition, at the end of 2010, the total amount of 3C contingent resources reached 2.356 billion  BOEs, which confirms the expected high quality of the projects we have in the pipeline and which       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: At the end of 2010, the risk of the prospective resources reached 2.5 billion BOEs. The annual  increase in prospective resources was driven by the intense seismic work and G&G studies, not  only in the Santos basin, but also in other projects worldwide. I alight that even if the pre-salt  Santos basin is the mostly referred basin in which we operate, our prospective resources shows  that we are active in several projects worldwide, clearly diversifying our resource base.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving from reserves and resources to our upgrade project in Matosinhos and Sines. Here I would  like to reaffirm our confidence in our upgrade project which is on time and on cost with €970 million  already invested until the end of 2010. In Matosinhos refinery, the works are ahead of schedule and  full production should come on one quarter before initially thought. In fact, the production of vacuum  gas oil, the main purpose of the investment in Matosinhos refinery, will start in the beginning of the  second quarter of this year. The outage in the fourth Q 2010 in the Matosinhos refinery allowed for  the necessary interconnections and now similar work is being done in the Sines refinery.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The Sines project is to be completed by the fourth Q of 2011. I must tell you that we are extremely  proud with this project. This is an extremely complex project which – and its successful execution  and the capable demonstrates our project management capability. The upgrade project is almost  finished and ready to return cash to the shareholders. Presently the crack between the fuel oil and  10 ppm sulfur middle distillates is well above 300 tons and ensuring a good return of the investment  we are making.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Let me now move to slide number 22. I’d like to make an overview of our oil production distribution  business in Iberia where Galp Energia currently has a market share of 15% following the  acquisition of ExxonMobil and Agip Iberian operations back in the end of 2008. At the end of 2010,  Galp Energia had around 1,400 service stations from which 44% were located in Spain. We also  have more than 500 convenience stores in Iberia, a value-added service that we offer to our  customers and which together with our premium fuels, contributes to the cash flow generation in  the marketing business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now let’s just refer to our Spanish acquisition. And referring to slide 23 where I’d like to draw your  attention to the natural gas supply business. The acquisition of the natural gas business of  Madrileña Gas in the region of Madrid, corresponding approximately to 400,000 customers, had  rational of being a growth platform for the natural gas business in that country. As from May 2010,  until the end of the year, we sold 111 million cubic meters of natural gas in the residential sector.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In Portugal, Galp Energia already has a very comfortable position. And so we need to grow our  activities business in Spain taking into account that we have natural gas – that our natural gas  sourcing is able to allow us to have that ambition and offer gas to new customers in Spain. This  acquisition is of – was a non-organic growth option that will enable us to grow organically in the  future by conquering nuclear clients based on our multi-fuel value proposition.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: I want to conclude referring to the Matosinhos cogeneration project, which is a project that is going  again in line with the schedule. The current strategy of this project both mechanical and electrical –  in both the mechanical and the electrical erection is under progress and the installation of  measuring equipments such as gas turbines and the heat recovery boilers are currently under  conclusion.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: According to our estimate, Matosinhos cogeneration should start operations in the beginning of the  fourth quarter of the present year. This cogeneration will have an annual natural gas consumption  of 250 million cubic meters as much gas as the city of Lisbon consumes and the same as the Sines  cogeneration consumes. And as such, it will be very positive to – as an incremental contributor to  Galp Energia’s natural gas supply business and to the power production business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of financials, this cogeneration should post an EBITDA close to €16 million a year from  2012 onwards, which I recall is the same level of results we obtained from the similar cogeneration  at Sines refinery, not considering the energy efficiency benefits that those projects bring to the  refinery operations.

file: GALP - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 10February2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Claudio de Marco
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now let's move to the fourth quarter 2011 result overview in slide number five. Once again the Gas & Power  business was the main contributor, now driven by higher volume sold and better natural gas supply margins on  the back of natural gas process optimization. E&P business also posted a good performance with both crude price  and production going up on a yearly basis. Production was positively influenced by the two additional wells that  were connected to the FPSO Cidade de Angra dos Reis in Lula field during the fourth quarter. In fact with the  production coming from this field already represents 50% of total net entitlement production, which shows that  the project is delivering.

texts.speaker: Claudio de Marco
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Production in the first quarter will also benefit from the [indiscernible] (8:35) this month. And with concern the  refining business there is slightly optimistic as refining margins has been showing some improvement in this first  actual economic context and the crude supply disruptions arising from the oil embargo may impact negatively the  refining sector in Europe.

texts.speaker: Claudio de Marco
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In our Distribution business, we expect volumes to be down quarter-on-quarter, both due to seasonality and to the  current economic context in Iberia, which should not allow oil shipped in the horizon, negative trend. And finally,  on the Gas business, we expect volume to go up on a quarterly basis, driven by the trading segment, as we see  favorable LNG market demand dynamics mainly in the Far East Countries, thus creating interesting  opportunities.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Moving on to the upgrade project in Sines, as you know the dimension of this project at the refinery of Matosinhos  was completed by the end of June. And in the Sines refinery physical completion there achieved to-date a level of  99%, and will be completed in the short-term. I would like to keep in mind the magnitude and complexity of this  project. We are, as you already know, building probably the largest full conversion hydrocracker in the world with  over more than 600 interconnections between the new facilities and existing refinery and which involves  including the upgrading the Matosinhos refinery and expenditure of €1.4 billion. We expect the completion to take  place during March and as soon as the works are completed we will start the commissioning of the units during  the second Q so that in the third Q we have the refineries fully converted, operating at its full capacity and at  steady state conditions.  Proceeding with, now with our exploration program we have been able to consistently de-risk our exploration  resources, thus continuously adding value to our Upstream portfolio. After the Mamba South discovery in the  Rovuma Basin in Northeastern Mozambique, we now expect results on the Mamba North exploration well in the  very short-term. In fact, the DST was already completed, but we are in the process of interpretation of the results  before releasing the results to the market. I can however, tell you that we are very confident on the potential of  Area 4, given the exception midshaft of the reservoir as it was already announced and we are already looking at  these discovery as an asset of extreme relevance in our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We are working towards starting production from this area as soon as 2018, although a more aggressive option in  terms of timing is also being considered. This is why we are accelerating the exploration appraisal program in  Area 4 in the Rovuma Basin with up to four exploration and appraisal wells already scheduled to be drilled in  2012.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now moving from Mozambique to Brazil, let me say that during the fourth quarter two additional wells as was  already stated initiated production into the FPSO Cidade de Angra dos Reis. So we have now connected to this  facility one gas injection well. The facility is also linked to one deep offshore pipeline, and we also have three  production wells operating and one water and gas injection being drilled. The production has achieved very close  to 80,000 barrels a day of which 70,000 barrels are oil and 10,000 barrels are gas in terms of oil equivalent.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: During 2012, we'll connect additional wells, particularly, as I said one production well and two water and gas  injection wells. The next well to be connected is scheduled to start producing before the end of the quarter. With  these soon to be connected wells, we will reach full capacity at the FPSO and will ensure an optimization  management of the reservoir.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Still in Block BM-S-11 the EWT Cernambi South should start very soon in this quarter through the FPSO Cidade  de Angra dos Reis – sorry, Cidade de São Vicente, the smallest one, the pilot unit. However, production from this  field should be lower than the Lula EWT because the gas/oil ratio is higher in Cernambi than it is in Lula.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Vice Chairman, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On a side note I'm glad to see and share with you that the Lula development project is running with remarkable  development pace and that we're set to continue delivering from this project, particularly with the next permanent  production unit, the FPSO Cidade de Paraty which will have a capacity of 120,000 barrels a day being now  converted and on time to start production by mid 2013. This notable performance is only possible, let me  emphasize, given the experienced people that is working on the project and the key partners involved in this  project.

file: GALP - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 11February2013 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the E&P front, despite maintenance works in Brazil and in Angola, production during the fourth quarter was  23,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which around 60% from Brazil.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding gas and power, lower gas demand in Iberia allowed us to continue to divert cargos to premium  international markets, namely to Asia. Gas and power earnings were, however, impacted by lower margins, as  [indiscernible] (2:57) closes led to higher sourcing costs during the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Moving on to our balance sheet on slide 15, net debt increased €328 million to around €1.7 billion, which resulted  in part from anticipated higher CapEx throughout the fourth quarter. We have now also reduced to almost zero all  outstanding factoring balances which had been in place since 2011. Our crude and product inventories were also  up €115 million in 2012 as a side effect of the hydrocracker commissioning delay.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We are expecting to adjust this amount downwards during the course of 2013 as the hydrocracker regime  stabilizes. Considering our loan to Sinopec of about €920 million as cash and equivalents, our year-end net debt  would stand at €780 million, or about 0.8 times last year's EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now let me go briefly through the main drivers we expect will impact our performance in this first quarter of 2013.  Working interest production is expected to be in line with the fourth quarter of 2012, around 24,000 barrels of oil  equivalent per day as some Angolan fields mature, while the Lula pilot recovers to full speed after the  maintenance works of the last quarter.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the refining business, we will see for the first time the positive impact from the upgrade. However, it will still  be a partial impact, considering that this is a quarter to ramp up and to stabilize production. On the oil marketing  business, we expect volumes to be lower compared to the first quarter of last year, as austerity measures in  Portugal and Spain will continue to impact demand for oil products.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the natural gas business, volumes are expected to continue to benefit from a strong LNG trading activity as this  market remains supported by healthy Asian demand. We have a few LNG cargos contracted for this first quarter  already, supporting increased volumes in the period.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We have concluded drilling in Carcará and Júpiter, both in the pre-salt Brazil, two key wells that allowed us to  gather relevant information for the future development of these reservoirs. Regarding Carcará, the well reached  porosity and permeability characteristics. In addition, we have found high pressures in the reservoir, which is a  positive variable when estimating future well flow rates. Let me add that the quality of this reservoir is the most  attractive among what I have seen so far in the pre-Santos – in the pre-salt Santos basin.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Nonetheless, Carcará is unequivocally a commercial discovery that unlocked the development of the block BM-S- 8. As we still have to better understand the extension and the characteristics of the reservoir, an appraisal well was  scheduled to be drilled in the second half of 2013, targeting the flank of the reservoir, which will give us more  certainty on its recoverable resources and on the full characteristics of the reservoir. We expect first oil on Carcará  to occur in 2018.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding our Júpiter Northeast, the well has reached the final depth of 6,018 meters, and it confirmed an  hydrocarbon column of 176 meters. It is a reservoir that is much, much, much larger than Carcará, and ends with  lower thickness, with good permeability and porosity characteristics.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Additionally, as we have been – as we have already announced, the well proved the connectivity of the reservoir  with the first Júpiter discovery, and it confirmed our base case reservoir border and the same hydrocarbon mix,  i.e., one-third of oil, one-third of gas, and one-third of condensate, with volumes in line with previous indications  of the reservoir size.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Let us now move to the Rovuma basin in Mozambique, which in 2012 delivered excellent results, far exceeding an  initial expectation as we almost doubled the already outstanding volumes estimated to be in place in Area 4. We've  drilled six wells during the course of the year, and we will continue with appraisal activities in the block during the  first half of 2013. These activities are key to better outline the development plan of the area. So far, an impressive  75 Tcfs of gas in place have been identified, leaving no doubt, whatsoever, about the commercial development of  these discoveries.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: The FEED, the front-end engineering and development studies have already been conducted, and we anticipate  that the final investment decision for the area will be taken at the beginning of next year.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: I want to reassure you that although it will be the first time that semi-rigid risers are deployed in the field, we are  comfortable with our previous ramp-up estimate. We have always guided for around one year to one year and a  half of production ramp-up. We anticipate that three production wells and one gas injection well will be connected  by the end of the year with an exit rate of production at around 75,000 barrels of oil.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: But we are not only delivering on upstream. Since the beginning of the year, we have announced the start-up of  the production of the Sines hydrocraker, the central piece of our refining upgrade project. After the first months of  operations, I'm glad to share with your that it is already running at around 80% utilization rate and with 99%  conversion, which is clearly an extraordinary positive result.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We will continue operations with maximum safety and to ensure that we do not jeopardize the value delivery  going forward. We will expect that the hydrocracker will add the full contribution to our results in the second Q  this year by achieving not only full utilization rate, total conversion and full stability by [ph] Q of March (15:41).

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: To conclude, in 2013, we are on track to deliver additional value to our shareholders. On the Iberian Peninsula,  earnings will be impacted by the refining upgrade as we'll continue to benefit from the LNG trading activity. On  the upstream, we will continue to deliver production growth and de-risking resources and prospects which will  have a positive impact on earnings and value. Considering all these variables, we are prepared to deliver improved  performance in 2013. Furthermore, with at least 10 high-impact wells scheduled for 2013, we also have the  potential to unlock and add further value to our portfolio and ultimately to our shareholders.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: I also want to share with you our satisfaction for having been included in the 100 Global Most Sustainable  Companies in Davos recently, which confirms our commitment to sustainability as it is our duty.

file: GALP - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 10February2014 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: During the year, the first FPSO operated according to plan at around 90% of its average nominal capacity. More  importantly, we are seeing technical costs below $15 per barrel, very much in line with our previous guidance and  confirming our statement that the Brazilian [ph] results (0:02:10) can be developed with crude oil prices [ph] at  that $40 (02:13) a barrel.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding the second unit, Lula Northeast works are also progressing well. The second producer well was  connected to Cidade de Paraty through a flexible [ph] process (0:02:52) as a contingency plan and started oil  production on the 12th of January. We are now producing very close to 60,000 barrels of oil per day from the Lula  Northeast from only two producer wells. This shows the outstanding flow rates in this reservoir, which are higher  than what we expected.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: As you might remember, the base case for commercial development of Lula was assumed as having a production  on average of 20,000 barrels of oil per day. As for the Buoyancy Supported Risers system, its ins tallation went  very well in our block. The first buoy has already been installed, submerged at a depth of 250 meters with all the  [ph] eight keepers (0:03:46) already in place.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: During the second quarter, we will proceed with the connection of two additional production w ells. The remaining  two wells will be connected in the second part of the year. As far as the gas pipeline, the connection to the FPSO  was concluded by the end of January, and we anticipate that the gas export facility will be initiated by April once  the full installation and commissioning process is completed.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: All these considered, we see no constraints in achieving full capacity by the end of the year as promised with a  total of six producer wells connected to the FPSO. By the end of the year, we will also have the third FPSO, Cidade  de Mangaratiba, operating in the area of the Iracema South. Works are ongoing at the Brasfels shipyard, in Brazil,  with the execution rate of the topside installation currently at around 80%. We anticipate first oil during th e  fourth quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We have two appraisal wells and two production tests planned for this year for Júpiter, which shows the clear  commitment of Petrobras and Galp to the Júpiter project in which we have a 20% stake. Our current base case is  we have one FPSO operational in 2019 to develop the oil rig.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding the important extension well at Carcará, we have to interrupt the first stage of drilling because of the  poor performance of the rig contracted. We are now evaluating whether we will resume the first stage of drilling  before the use of a suitable rig for high-pressure reservoirs, or else, if we will drill the well in one phase starting  the second half of the year. This decision is in the process of being taken and is dependent on rig availability and  on its associated costs.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Moving now to Mozambique, we and our partners at Area 4 continue to work on all fronts in order to be able to  take the final investment decision on the LNG project as soon as possible. This includes the engineering and  design works, the unitization negotiations with Area 1, [ph] plus (0:08:26) discussions with potential buyers for  the gas, working with the government to consolidate the legislation framework that supports the project  development and obviously also its financing.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: As for the exploration, I am now in slide number 10. We announced recently the Pitú discovery in the fourth  quarter. I am happy to say that this was the first time that the material oil accumulation was found  offshore  Potiguar. Consequently, we are now confronted with a whole new play in offshore Brazil. We are still analyzing  data obtained during the drilling stage, and we will proceed with the DST before elaborating more on our timings  on this play.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now let me turn to our downstream and gas activities referred to in slide number 11 and 12. I believe that the year  of 2013 might have been the inflection point for our refining and marketing business. Allow me to explain you  why. As you all know, the refining industry in Europe is affected by a surplus of supply. What I can te ll you is that,  we are now – is that we now have a much more complex and competitive and flexible refining system, which is  already contributed to positive cash flow generation and we will continue optimizing our operational costs and  energy consumption.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: And for the gas and power business, I must refer that the shift we have made towards the international market  continues to be very rewarding, and that we have once again, beaten previous year's [ph] excess (0:12:31) sales.  We achieved a record of 3 bcms of LNG sold internationally with the grand total of 7  bcms.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We already have some LNG cargoes contracted for this year under the contracts already established and we plan  to reinforce our presence in the international markets through low-risk opportunistic [ph] presence (0:12:53). Our  downstream and gas activities will continue to contribute with resilient cash flow generation through our growth  plans in the upstream, fulfilling its [ph] role of (0:13:07 ) complementary to our upstream growth project.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: E&P EBITDA reached €109 million, up 42% from the previous year, as both net entitlement production and  realized sale price increased in the period. Production from Brazil accounted for 64% of tot al production in the  quarter, with oil production making up 98% of the total versus 91% last year. This higher oil mix was mostly due  to gas re-injection in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: The marketing business has now stabilized on the back of higher oil volumes in the fourth quarter. Overall  Portugal volumes are up 4%, and Spain was flat year-on-year. We also had cost optimization measures  implemented throughout the year, which helps EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Gas and power EBITDA was up 7 % to €93 million in the quarter, with higher volumes of LNG traded in the  international markets. Group EBIT in the fourth quarter was flat year-on-year at €149 million. Higher  depreciation charges in E&P and refining offsets the improved operating performance shown in EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In E&P, non-cash costs were positively impacted by the upwards revisions of results in Angola, but we had a  similar impact back in 2012. On the refining and marketing business, the increase in DD&A was due to the  commissioning of the hydrocracker. Concluding with the P&L, net profit was €92 million in the quarter, that's up  10%.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Finally, and for guidance, in this first quarter of 2014, we expect to produce about 26,000 barrels of oil equivalent  per day. Our refining throughput will be affected by the planned maintenance of our main refinery in Sines, which  should begin in mid-March and last until the end of April.

file: GALP - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 9February2015 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: On the other hand, in the second half of the year, margins returned to what I would call normality, benefiting from  the sharp decline in oil prices. As you already know in the year, market-wide such volatility in the oil and gas  markets, Galp Energia is able to deliver a good set of result. I take this opportunity to reaffirm how strategically  important is the integration of our upstream and downstream businesses, particularly in a period when we need  cash from operations to support our investment burden required to put into production our valuable, discovered  reserves and contingent resources.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: As for additional replicant units, works are ongoing both in Brazil and Chinese shipyard. In this regard, [ph] I  must tell, I like (05:21) the progress on the hull P-66, the first of the replicants to be delivered, which arrived in  December at the Brasfels shipyard in Brazil. I want to reassure you, that we are closely monitoring our works, or  these units are progressing, in particular, in water resource to local suppliers' performance, and when necessary,  do whatever we can to promote mitigating actions.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: As an example of these, we had the performance issue in one of our local suppliers, IESA, who was responsible for  the supply of the gas compression and injection modules to be integrated into the six replicant units. The BM-S-11  consortium decided to terminate the contract, in order to not to further compromise project timings and to fast- forward and mitigate a solution. An international tender was launched, and for the construction of these modules,  and proposals would – are expected very soon to recover the lost time.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: The Production Individualization Agreements that will result from the unitization process, once finalized, shall  then be submitted together, with the development plan for the unitized Iara [ph] via (07:49) ANP. In the  meantime, we will proceed with additional reservoir data acquisition works in Iara, which are required due to the  heterogeneity and size of this area, which most likely will be developing stages.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Now, let me move on to block BM-S-8, slide number 10. During the fourth quarter, the construction concluded the  fist drilling stage of Carcará Extension, and the drilling works have already started in Carcará Extension-2 which  is like the first well, an appraisal well, with a rig using MPD, managed pressure drilling equipment, suitable for  this kind of reservoir. This rig will later be used to complete the second stage of the first Carcará Extension well.  We expect to perform a formation test in the Carcará Extension-2 in the second half of this year.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Let us now move to Mozambique, mainly to the area for Rovuma project, referred to in slide 11. After the approval  of the enabling law, the government of Mozambique has approved a specific Decree-Law that will support the  development of the Rovuma project in complement to the already approved revision of the Petroleum Law. From  the legal point of view, we consider ourselves comfortable with the legislation that has been put in place by the  government of Mozambique. Meanwhile, the consortium was already submitted to the Mozambique, the capital of  politics of Mozambique, the Declaration of Commerciality and the plan of development for the Coral FLNG  project, which are subject to the partner's final investment decision at a later stage.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Engineering works are ongoing both for the Coral and the Mamba projects, and we expect to have proposal for the  FLNG EPCIC contract by mid-year and for the EPC for the first development stage of Mamba, particularly, for the  onshore facilities by the second half of the year. So far, the project in Mozambique is going according to plan.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Now, let me go over to our downstream and gas activities. Market conditions in the fourth quarter continued to  support the refining margins, essentially, due to the lower oil prices with our benchmark margin averaging $2.90  per barrel. As you can see in the chart on the left-hand side of slide 13, we took advantage of these market  conditions.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: In 2015, we will continue to implement further cost reductions in our downstream business, namely, in what  refers to energy consumption, logistics optimization, and adapting the support structures of these businesses in  order to improve the cash flow that they generate and their resilience. As mentioned in the previous quarter, we  are still prudent regarding the evolution of the refining margins, as because the refining overcapacity in Europe  persists and the current margins continue to be mostly supported by the prices of oil.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: On our Gas & Power side, it is worth noting the stronger than expected international LNG structured trading  activities in the quarter. Even under difficult market conditions and lower unit margins, we have been able to  increase the volumes that associated with this activity. This activity allowed us to compensate the decrease of  volumes sold to our direct customers in Iberia, and to reach, as well notice, a historical high in the sales of natural  gas.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: Before I finish, let me give you a quick word about the proposal, recently proposed tax law announced by the  Portuguese government last week. This tax [indiscernible] (14:05) to specifically target Galp Energia's non- regulated long-term natural gas supply contract, with a charge that the government announced to be around €150  million to be paid in three years.

texts.speaker: Manuel Ferreira de Oliveira
texts.text: The draft legislation does not include the value of critical parameters required to calculate these, the tax impact,  which will only be stepped by the Minister of Energy after the eventual enactment of the law. So far, we cannot  provide any additional information in this respect. What we do know is that, there are no economic nor legal  grounds for this measure to be legislated. Be assured, as our shareholders if we've invested in our shares, that we  will do not be waiting seated for any unreasonable measure of tailor-made law, and that we will do all we can to  protect the legitimate interests of the capital.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.text: Thank you, Manuel, and good morning to you all. Starting with the P&L on slide 14. Group EBITDA was €399  million in the quarter. This was supported by an improvement in European refining margins and the stronger  dollar. The contribution from higher LNG sales in the international markets mitigated the fall in natural gas sales  to our direct client, as is the higher E&P production. E&P EBITDA was down 7% to €102 million, as the  production increased it has not managed to offset the large fall in average realized price.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.text: Refining and Marketing EBITDA was €191 million, benefiting from the in European refining margins, a stronger  dollar and a positive contribution from our marketing activities. Operational cost-cutting played a relevant role  here, namely in energy efficiency, marketing and personnel.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.text: Pages 28 and 29 of our results reports published this morning provide a detailed reconciliation of such  adjustments. But in a nutshell, during 2014, we had €455 million of negative inventory effects at the EBIT level,  about €100 million in asset impairments and about €100 million spread between provisions for the levy the  Portuguese government is imposing on the energy sector and deferred tax assets which we have reversed in Spain  and restructuring charges.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.text: Now for downstream and gas CapEx, for the full year, it reached €137 million, a significant part of which going to  the plant maintenance of the Sines refinery. Our Capital Markets Day is only a few weeks away, so we are not  providing guidance to the markets for the upcoming years. Except that we will be revising downwards our  previous CapEx guidance of €1.5 billion to €1.7 billion. More color on this on March 10.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisostomo Silva
texts.text: On slide 18, you see that at the end of the fourth quarter, the average life of our debt was 3.7 years with two-thirds  of our gross debt only due from 2018 onwards. This is a reimbursement schedule which is better aligned with the  expected free cash flow turning points. Our liquidity remains high at €3.2 billion, which together with our  integrated business profile and financial discipline, positions us well to face a period of low oil prices and  significant CapEx in the upstream business.

file: GALP - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 8February2016 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: In this last quarter, our production increased, an integrated portfolio allowed us to deliver an EBITDA of €309  million, despite the shortfall in the oil prices. And this was possible due to the contribution of our downstream  and gas activities, the flawless execution of our main option projects, and as well as of the efficiency  improvements. Our 2015 performance on a replacement cost basis exceeded the guidance provided during the  March 2015 Capital Markets Day. We did pursue the path that we have define d focusing on execution and  optimization, and I emphasize that, execution and optimization. And at the end of the day, we were able to deliver  more and spending less.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: We achieved a 50% production growth during the year with reservoir performance delivering our expectations in  Brazil. We were able to maintain a high availability of our refining system, allowing us to take advantage from the  strong market conditions. In the Gas & Power, our ability to seize market opportunities and as well as managing  our gas sourcing led us to achieve solid results in this business as well. All-in-all, we were able to capitalize on our  integrated business model achieving at a EBITDA over €1.5 billion during the year while keeping CapEx below the  lower end of our guidance range.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: The volatility that marked 2015 affected both oil prices and refining margins. We will be updating our market  assumptions during our upcoming Capital Markets Day, but I can advance that we remain quite conservative both  on oil prices and on refining margin.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: Low oil prices together with an economic recovery contributed to the high Iberian oil demand recovery of around  2%, supporting our marketing activities. The natural gas market benefited from higher demand from the electrical  segment, leading to a 6% annual growth.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: The unit has the total installed capacity of 150,000 barrels of oil equivalent and we estimate to achieve a high  productivity from this first producer well, in line with what we have seen in the other areas of Lula fie ld. It is  expected that these units will reach full capacity during 2017.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: In Block – sorry, in Block 52, the development drilling campaign have started. The [ph] FPSOs (09:39) allocated  to this project are currently in Singapore [ph] to (09:44) conversion work in order to start production in 2017 and  2019. We are working hard to make this project as lean as possible, focusing on cost reduction measures and fiscal  term financing.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: As for Coral, the Area 4 consortium keeping working hard to develop a floating solution that is economically  competitive. Under the current environment, there are challenges, but also opportunities to be considered. And  that is why we need to continue to work in this direction, even if – take more time.

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: Moving to the downstream gas and business – downstream and gas business, it is – I'm speaking in slide number  11. Strong refining margins supported this business during 2015. Of course, the first Q was weaker Q-on-Q and  year-on-year. Overall, we were able to capitalize on the good market conditions because our refining system's  flexibility, conversion capacity, and high availability of our refineries to help [ph] the oil yield (11:33).

texts.speaker: Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva
texts.text: In Gas & Power, despite fewer trading opportunities, we accomplished a steady performance, not only through the  LNG contracts previously established and our [ph] structured contracts (11:48), but also through our ability to  find new market opportunities, such as trading in European hubs, and always keeping an eye on how to optimize  gas sourcing opportunity.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: Thank you, Carlos, and good morning to you all. As usual, I will start with the P&L on page 13. This last quarter,  group EBITDA was €309 million, down 22% year-on-year. And this deduction is driven by oil figures. 2015 was a  good year overall for Galp. But these are challenging times for our industry, even considering the natural  stabilizers within our portfolio. E&P EBITDA was down to €53 million, as the higher volumes we re enabled to  offset the effect of much lower price.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.text: Gas & Power delivered an EBITDA of €88 million, with natural gas and infrastructure activities performing  steadily, plus some good sourcing optimization opportunity. The power activity, however, was impacted by  suboptimal utilization of our Porto Refinery co-generation unit.

file: GALP - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 11February2019 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Carlos, the floor is yours. Thank you.  Carlos Nuno Gomes da Silva  Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Galp Energia SGPS SA  Thank you, Pedro, and good morning to you, all. Welcome. I will start with a quick recap of the 2018 year. During  the year, during 2018, the energy sector faced very significant volatility with oil prices moving up and down, more  than $20 per barrel throughout the year. This only reinforces, once again, the strategic importance of Galp's  integrated business model.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the upstream front, we continue to develop the giant Lula and Iracema fields, ending the year with eight  producing units, with the deployment of P-69 that has been located in Lula Extreme South at the end of October.  Earlier this month, we had the first oil in unit number nine that has been located in Lula North. Now, the  construction is working on the enhancements that will allow us to maximize the value extraction from these  outstanding assets, with the ambition to reach a 40% recovery factor.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In Angola, production from Kaombo North project that is in block 32, started in July and the second unit or  Kaombo South is already on location. In Mozambique, the development plan for the first phase of the Rovuma  LNG project was submitted, now with much larger trends than the initial plan.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On the downstream side, we have taken advantage of the plan, the maintenance work in our refining system to  implement some of the projects included in the $1 extra per barrel initiative that you all are aware of.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We are also taking the opportunity to make some adjustments to meet the future demand specifications that will  arise from the upcoming IMO regulations that will enter in force next year. We continue to deliver a solid  performance from our oil and gas marketing activities in Iberia and also in Africa. And we have done so, whilst  continuing to develop our business with a more client-centric approach, making progress in adopting our value  proposition to meet customers' demands.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Everything we do reflects our commitments to sustainable practices. And once again, I'm glad to reinforce that  this year Galp was recognized by several of the most important independent entities as an industry leader in  environmental, social and governance matters.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Jumping now to the next slide in slide number 4. Quick notes on the progress we made in building our upstream  resource base. The successful developments of our core asset, together with the increased exposure with strong  set of new ones have led us to a 15% increase in 2P reserves and 2C resources to 2.4 billion barrels of oil  equivalent.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In respect to 2P reserves, we were slightly up due to the upwards revision of Lula and Iracema fuels performance  and up the estimates on Iara from the newly drilled wells. This more than offset the 2018 production. 2C  resources were also up 23%, mostly considering the larger trains in Mozambique and the additional 3% stake that  we bought in BM-S-8 where we have now 20% shareholding.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: In Lula and Iracema, we are ramping up the last two of nine units already producing. In Iara, we expect first oil  from the new FPSO that will be located in Berbigão and Sururu during the second half of 2019 while the new  FPSO for Atapu is expected to start next year. In Carcará, we are moving towards the phase development. The  first phase is now assuming a larger FPSO with 220,000 barrels per day of capacity, with full reinjection capability  since the first day to increase the options around the development plan.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: These projects should see first oil in the next decade between 2023 and 2024 and there has a breakeven that  should expand below $35 per barrel. Regarding the appraisal works, which will support the next development  phases, we expect to spud a second well in the northern area very soon.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Carcará looks quite promising, based on its recovery resource estimate of circa of 2 billion barrel of oil equivalent.  Still in Brazilian pre-salt, the first exploration well in Uirapuru is expected by 2020. In Mozambique, we are  working towards an FID this summer while the first development phase of Rovuma LNG with off-taking, financing  and [ph] EPC (00:09:14) well underway.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We have also been making good progress with Coral FLNG project with activities intensifying significantly this  year both with units construction and as well in what we expect to the drilling activities. In Angola and I've  mentioned before, the second unit in Kaombo is already on location. We may see first oil slightly before what we  consider in our plan which was around mid-year.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding exploration activities, we have started in January the 3D seismic campaign in our operated Namibian  deepwater offshore license in PEL 83. The survey will comprise an area of around 3,000 square kilometers and  scheduled to be completed during March.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: With these, [ph] grounds' (00:11:26) production is expected to grow 8% to 12% this year and at a 12% to 16%  compound annual growth rate up to 2020. Post to 2020, we are assuming a higher production versus the previous  guidance. We expect to benefit from the increased contributions from Lula and Iara where we see positive signs  that should lead to longer plateaus and an increased plant capacity and larger exposure to Carcará. And, of  course, the larger development solution for the Rovuma LNG project in Mozambique. Beyond 2025, the upwards  revision is even higher as we see additional upsides from the recent additions in Brazil. To sum it up, 2019 and  2020 production growth should be less steep compared with the previous plan, but production is higher in the  medium to longer-term.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now, moving on to the downstream on slide 9 and starting with the Refining activity. 2019 so far has been  challenging for Refining with margins impacted by the high levels of gasoline inventories. In addition, we are  having some constraints in our system given a recent operational upside in our Matosinhos refinery which may  also lead to slightly suboptimal operations during the Q1.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: The planned 40 to 50 days outage of maintenance that is planned in the atmospheric distillation units in Sines  during the second half of the year is not expected to compromise the operational availability of the conversion  units that should run at the optimal capacity. We will use the opportunity to perform works to increase the  efficiency and the conversion ability of our Refining system towards achieving the full capture of the extra $1 per  barrel in Refining margin by 2020.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Additionally, we aim to capture the benefits of data-driven operations through various projects, which are currently  underway and which will leverage on the digitalization and the supply chain management to increase the  efficiency and the profitability of our operations. And as we move closer to the start of the IMO sulphur cap, Galp  is ready to supply compliance rule.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We are actually expecting a more supportive environment for 2020 onwards, mainly driven by middle distillate  crack increase. This effect should more than offset the increased sourcing costs from sweeter crudes target, and  please note that on the upstream, we will have the reverse effect of selling our medium-gravity low-sulphur crudes  at the higher price. All-in-all, IMO should be a clear net positive for Galp and I would say that both in the upstream  and also in the downstream.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding our Marketing activities, we will continue to adopt our value proposition and invest in digital and  innovative solutions to improve the customers' journey. In Gas & Power, we are ensuring the long-term  sustainability of our supply and trading activity securing new natural gas sourcing contracts for which we are  considering alternative options including our equity gas from Mozambique.

texts.speaker: Pedro Dias
texts.profession: Head-Strategy & Investor Relations, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: We are also strengthening our commercial position in Iberia, leveraging from digital tools and the innovative  business models to provide gas, electricity and services as an integrated commercial offer. Additionally, and  aligned with our strategy to develop low carbon businesses, we are building optionality and integration alongside  our electricity value chain. We will continue to develop a portfolio of renewal energy projects. Our growing  presence in the electric mobility business will also allow significant synergies with the existing network of retail  stations.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Free cash flow reached €120 million in the quarter. You will have seen on the P&L we published this morning a  negative €71 million in mark-to-market changes and the financial results. This is mostly related to financial  derivatives we added into to hedge the price risk of natural gas we placed with a B2B clients in Iberia. The  positive impact from these economic hedges should be realized over the coming quarters as the underlying gas  volumes get delivered. Now, for the full year and still on this slide 13, EBITDA plus associates was over €2.4  billion and that's up 21% year-on-year with the increased contribution from E&P, more than offsetting Refining  weakness.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Now let's now look at our plan to 2020 and I'm on slide 14. Now just for context, our Brent price assumptions  remain unchanged from the previous plan at $60 per barrel in 2019 and $65 in 2020, same for the dollar which  stays at €1.2 throughout the period. We are revising upwards the Galp Refining margin assumptions for 2019 to  about $5, $6 per barrel, that's on the back of the expected strong demand for middle distillates. And for 2020, we  add another $1 per barrel, driven by the full contribution from the Refining efficiency initiatives and the expected  IMO disruptions during that year. Now I would highlight that our figures are now based on IFRS 16. Slides 19 and  21 provide some detail on the expected impacts to Galp and this relates mainly to leased FPSOs and subsea  equipment. So, for clarity, IFRS 16 has no impact on free cash flows.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: On this basis, we are guiding towards organic cash flow from operations annual growth of 10% to 15%  compounds to 2020, mostly driven by upstream growth and a supportive Refining environments. Even with oil  prices lower than during 2018, upstream cash flow from operations should grow at above 10% compounded to  2020, benefiting from higher production, but also from higher unit cash margins in the upcoming Iara FPSOs,  which are less heavily taxed.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: As for Gas and Power, we expect it to be at the lower end of the €100 million to €150 million EBITDA guidance  due to the end of the structured contracts. And we need to add about €19 million per annum from our associates.  For 2019, Group EBITDA is expected at €2.1 billion, €2.2 billion and this will trend towards €3-billion-plus from  2020 onwards.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Regarding CapEx on slide 15, we are keeping our guidance at about €1 billion per annum in 2019 and 2020. E&P  should still account for about 70% of Group CapEx, now with Mozambique gaining traction even Coral and the  larger onshore trains of the Rovuma LNG project. Our CapEx estimates assume that the unitization processes in  Brazil will be completed by 2020. Now, as of the end of 2018 considering the unitization processes under  approval, Galp was in a net receiver position of about €100 million under the equalization calculations. We will be  updating you on this net position over time as things progress.

texts.speaker: Filipe Crisóstomo Silva
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Galp Energia SGPS SA
texts.text: Non-upstream CapEx is expected to average €250 million to €300 billion per annum until 2020. This reflects a  higher concentration of payments related to the one extra dollar per barrel initiatives in the refineries, which are  now nearing completion. After 2020, we expect this number to fall to a more normalized €200 million to €250  million including low carbon renewable power production and the new business solutions.

texts.text: Let me highlight our market outlook with the Middle East and Africa region. In South Africa, we expect only  a stable building construction sector after growing market last year. And we remain to be critical for the Northern  Africa region and Middle East due to the ongoing difficult political situation.

texts.speaker: Christian Buhl
texts.text: And now, a few words about the raw material price environment. We expect average raw material prices in the  second quarter to be substantially above the level of the second quarter last year due to further increase in raw  material prices and the low price level last year.

Average raw material prices in the second  quarter will be above the level of the second quarter last year, driven by the already increased price level and a  further price increase in the second quarter compared to the first quarter this year.

texts.speaker: Christian Buhl
texts.text: And finally, let me briefly update you on the Geberit outlook 2018. We expect for the full year, total CapEx of CHF  170 million.
