texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: Let's go now to slide 10. The acquisition of Naturex fits fully our 2020 strategy to expand our offering of natural  products to our customers, to expand our portfolio of Integrated Solutions and Active Beauty natural ingredients,  as well as to further complement our customer base. Givaudan is the global leader in the space of natural flavors  and Naturex complements perfectly our capabilities with its strong portfolio of plant extracts and natural  ingredients across the food and beverage, nutrition, health and personal care sectors.

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: The final steps of the acquisition of Naturex are progressing well. All regulatory approvals have been secured,  and finalizing for the transaction is completed. The purchase of 40.5% of the shares of Naturex was completed on  June 4, 2018. The mandatory cash tender offer was launched on June 28, and it will continue until early  September. We expect the closing of the transaction in September 2018.

file: GIVN - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 16February2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Let’s turn now to slide 15. Fragrance R&D Group continued to be very active in 2009. Two new  molecules, Mystikal and Petalia, were introduced to the Givaudan perfumer palette. The Fragrance  Ingredients business launched Cosmone to the market, a novel musk, which is at the same time  biodegradable. In connection with our Givaudan’s Innovative Naturals programme we announced  earlier this year, a new sustainability partnership in Laos to secure the sustainable sourcing of  Benzoin, a precious raw material used in Fine Fragrances, but also in consumer products.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The year saw also the introduction of a cooling agent that is six times more efficient and longer  lasting than any other currently available agent on the market.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Let’s turn to the next slide. On the Flavour side, with our TasteSolutions program, we continued to  capture important business opportunities in the area of Health and Wellness, particularly for sugar  and salt reduction. In sodium regulations will continue to tighten and we are up to the challenge to  help our clients reduce salt in their products without compromising on taste. Today, 40% of sodium  reduction in food can be achieved without taste compromise. Going forward, the goal is to shift  towards even more demanding targets.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Natural ingredients are increasingly important in Flavours. Within our TasteEssentials Flavour  range, we launched new natural ingredients for chicken and vanilla flavours. PureDelivery systems  are designed to provide flavour release in a product without compromising the end product stability,  visual effects or authenticity. Further progress was also made here. Our longstanding success, the  Virtual Aroma Synthesiser, the VAS, is now in its third generation and this means an even more  possible tool through which large amounts of data on consumer behavior can be collected at a  competitive cost.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Finally, with the help of our TasteTrek research, we were able to discover seven new molecules  that will help further sodium and MSG replacement in food. In addition to our unique collaboration  with the University of California in Riverside, we are examining over 100 different citrus varieties in  order to develop new citrus molecules.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Please turn to slide 20 which shows the business statement. We have already explained the sales  development. Looking at the gross profit margin, you see that it has declined to 45% from 45.6% in  the previous year. Although basic commodity and energy prices have declined from the peak in the  first quarter of 2009, the impact of this decline on Givaudan’s margins was not fully reflected in  2009. Furthermore, production volumes were significantly lower in 2009 than in 2008, driven both  by lower sales volumes as well as a strong focus on reducing our own inventory levels.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Let me now turn to the financial position on slide 25. We were able to significantly strengthen our  financial position in 2009. As a result of the strong focus on cash generation, lower capital  expenditures, and the right issue, we reduced our overall debt by CHF 528 million, and increased  our cash position by CHF 406 million during last year. Equity including the MCS represents 50% of  our financial position compared to 41% last year. And the leverage ratio defined as net debt divided  by net debt plus equity decreased to 30%, down from 46% last year. In view of the increased  volatilities and uncertainties in the current economic climate, we have reduced our mid-term       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: On this slide, I’d like to draw you attention on the fact that we are on track with our cost savings,  and at the end of 2009 we have achieved CHF170 million as Matthias mentioned. Our additional  cost containment measures enabled us to save an additional CHF30 million throughout the 12  months last year. Those savings are sustainable going forward.

file: GIVN - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 8February2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 8 and development as well as sustainable sourcing of raw materials, we expect to outgrow the  underlying market and to continue to achieve an industry-leading EBITDA margin.

file: GIVN - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 16February2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: The EBITDA margin declined from 22.7% to 20.2% on a comparable basis. For 2012, we remain committed to  have the pricing actions translate into an additional CHF100 million of EBITDA improvement. This will mean we  will have fully compensated the CHF200 million of raw materials increase in absolute terms by 2012.

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: Please turn now to the next slide. One of our five-pillar strategies is on sourcing raw materials to create a  competitive advantage, whether from a facility, from an innovation or cost point of view. Naturals account for half  of what we buy; we have many important partnerships with innovative companies or organizations around the  world to ensure we safeguard the supply of key natural ingredients for Fragrances or Flavours. And I would like to  highlight some of the ongoing initiative.

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: Under the theme of biotechnology, starting in this area, biosynthesis helps us producing ingredients from  sustainable natural sources as opposed to traditional chemical synthesis. We have several exclusive partnerships  with specialized research companies to advance in this area along with the work we do in our research  department.

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: In Fragrances, we have a partnership with Amyris for their Biofene product derived from sustainable based  material, sugarcane. Biofene is a key intermediate for making fragrance ingredients.

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: In Flavours, we have several partnerships; they include projects that use natural raw materials like proteins or  biotechnology methodologies, we have created important dairy fresh notes and more complex savoury flavours  ingredients.

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: Givaudan has made considerable progress in sourcing important natural materials around the world, including  the related and responsible farming communities. We have established ethical sourcing programs focusing on  sustainable development and saturates through long-term exclusive partnership with local farmers, as an example  in Benzoin, vanilla, ylang ylang, sandalwood, tonka beans and many others.

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: Modern perfumery is as much about delivering the scent at the right moment as it is about creating the right  smell. Givaudan is at the forefront of providing these new century benefits. Through our Mechacaps technology,  we have taken perfume delivery to the next level. For example, we can deliver a fragrance that will last for several  days on dry fabric or a fragrance that will respond to the release of water, to temperature, or friction which is  particularly interesting for deodorants where we have made significant progress in 2011.

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: Givaudan flavour delivery technology is leading the industry, especially in the beverages, confectionary and  savoury markets with our wide range of flavour encapsulation products. Marketed under the PureDelevery brand,  our technology provides longer lasting taste, sequential taste release, and flavours can then resist to high  temperature baking processes.

texts.speaker: Matthias Währen
texts.text: The negative impact of the higher raw material prices, which was about CHF200 million for the full year, could be  mitigated by about half or CHF100 million. The remaining CHF100 million will be mitigated throughout 2012.  This is in line with our communication at this year's half-year conference.

texts.speaker: Matthias Währen
texts.text: As mentioned before, we plan to achieve an additional CHF100 million through price increases this year. Raw  material prices will be in the best case flat, most probably further moderate increase of 2% to 3% based on the  current visibility. We will be transferring our European savoury production from our existing sites based in  Kemptthal, Switzerland and Bromborough, UK into Makó, Hungary. Running dual sites during the transition will  have an estimated impact of CHF15 million for the year. By the third quarter of 2013, the existing two sites will be  closed and we will generate annualized savings of CHF30 million.

texts.speaker: Matthias Währen
texts.text: Economic uncertainties remain such as the difficult macroeconomic climate in Europe as well as the uncertainty  around the global growth outlook for the forthcoming months. These are excellent factors on which we have no  influence, but we have proven the interesting resilience of our business and our ability to adjust a challenging  environment.

file: GIVN - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 5February2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Feb-13.pdf
GIVN - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 30January2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-14.pdf
GIVN - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 29January2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jan-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Gilles Andrier
texts.text: The global environment is providing us with a demanding agenda ahead for 2015. Listening to our customers and  to leading economic institutions like the IMF or the World Bank, we will continue facing a difficult global  economy this year, but we are best positioned in a defensive industry combined with our unique exposure to a  broad range of customers of geographies, and of product categories.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & IR Contact, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: If you look at claims incurred, we had an exceptional mild winter in 2012 with no prolonged periods of frost, and  we had fewer [indiscernible] (02:28) than at the same time last year. texts.speaker: Janne Merethe Flessum
texts.text: In Nordic, we also had a stronger focus on profitability, which has led to good bottom line results this quarter.  Even though we are very satisfied with the results, you need to bear in mind the unusual mild winter without  prolonged periods of frost. This has resulted in considerably lower claims incurred compared to a normal first  quarter.

texts.speaker: Janne Merethe Flessum
texts.text: For Nordic general insurance companies, the first quarter is normally the quarter with the poorest result, as  winter is associated with poor driving condition, more fires and cost-related problems. This quarter is not  representative for a normal first quarter. However, it is only two years ago that we experienced the winter in the  Nordic countries that fell outside our definition of normal. Put them on the other side of the scale. Having such a  good first quarter and partly as a result of the unusual wild winter, I would like to remind you that our long-term  financial goal for the insurance business is still a combined ratio of 90% to 93% on a yearly basis.

texts.speaker: Janne Merethe Flessum
texts.text: Turning to page 14, as mentioned, the effect of large losses is lower than expected, with a 1.9% effect on the  combined ratio compared with the expected 4.8%. This means that major natural events in the  time ahead will be included in the large losses figures, including expected values. There were no natural events in  this quarter, and large losses mainly relates to the Commercial Norway and Nordic segment.

file: GJF - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 7May2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Janne. Figures for the first quarter indicate a good start to 2013 and profit before tax expense was  NOK541 million. It is a  satisfactory first quarter result, a period that's normally characterized by a lot of weather-related events in the  Nordic region.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Increase in combined ratio from 88.4% in the first quarter last year is mainly due to a more normal proportion of  large losses combined with a lower run-off gain, so adjusted for this the combined ratio was on par with the first  quarter in 2012, which as you remember was particularly good. Good underlying profitability was driven by  continued good customer and risk selection and no significant negative weather effects in the quarter and as  always is a element of random variation.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & IR Contact, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: In addition to the underlying profitability in the quarter, the claims frequency is still above favorable level.  Although, we have a more normal winter this year than in 2012, the frequency level was positively affected by the  lack of extreme weather events, and the negative weather effects in the quarter. The favorable frequency level  continues for motor claims in the private market in Norway and the same applies to properties where we see lower  frequency level than we would normally during winter although the figures are somewhat weaker than the  corresponding quarter last year. There are also somewhat weaker frequency developments within the commercial  portfolio and especially within agriculture.

file: GJF - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 25April2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Janne. Good morning and welcome, everyone. 2018 has started off with a harsh winter with heavy  snowfall and low temperatures. Several places in central areas of Norway reported up to three times high snow  depth compared to normal levels, resulting in difficult driving conditions and heavy snow creating huge damages  on buildings. This, together with volatile capital markets characterized the first quarter results.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: As previously communicated weather conditions in the first quarters over the past few years have been relatively  benign contributing to better results than we would normally expect for winter quarter in our region. Last time we  had a really harsh winter was in 2010. So it's important to remember the seasonality we have in the Nordic region  and there are strong variations in the Nordics, and Nordic weather conditions which this winter is clear reminder  of.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Our results are summarized on page 2. Profit before tax amounted to NOK 727 million in the quarter. The  underwriting result was for NOK 411 million, and the combined ratio was 93%. We had a premium growth of 5.7%  and we managed to continue operating in a very cost efficient and lean way. Considering historical average  claims levels, we estimate the weather-related deviation in the frequency claims level during the first quarter this  year to be in the range of NOK 250 million to NOK 300 million, and even more if we compare with the first quarter  last year which was benign weather-wise.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Large losses were also high compared with the first quarter last year partly due to the heavy snowfall. Demanding  weather conditions primarily impacted the Norwegian business. We are happy to see our operations outside  Norway deliver significantly improved results compared with the first quarter last year, despite weather also being  more adverse in this region. The operations outside Norway contributed to a total of NOK 104 million to the  group's underwriting results.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Looking aside of weather effects, the underlying inflation trend we had seen in motor insurance over some  quarters now, continues into 2018. We had price measures in place and more are to come to higher and more  frequent increases as our tariff system is set to be even more agile going forward.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The maps shown on page 3 illustrates both the difference in weather between winters 2018 and 2017 and also  that they are quite extreme in opposite directions, with regards to long-term and medium snow depth. We  encourage you to study the weather statistics every quarter as it is the highly relevant leading indicator for Nordic  concerns.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Just to give a few examples of winter weather effects this quarter, we saw four times more damages year-to-date  compared to the same period last year related to roofs collapsing due to heavy snow. At Oslo emergency ward,  they have treated 30% more fractures so far this year compared to the same period last year. And we had an  increase of more than 15% in the number of motor claims in Norway during the first quarter this year compared to  the same period last year. Based on the large amounts of snow this winter, the Norwegian Water Resources and  Energy Directorate sees a higher than normal risk of severe spring floods in Southern Norway. If such large floods  occur, it should impact our second quarter 2018 results.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: As the largest general insurance company in Norway, we see claims prevention as an important part of our  mission. So as a precautionary measure, we are in the process of delivering pumping and drying equipment to the  high risk areas for floods. This is the first time an insurance company in Norway takes this kind of large scale  preventive measures.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Helge, and good morning, everybody. I will start on page 6 where you can see that the report, a profit  before tax of NOK 727 million in the quarter. This is down compared to the profit reported for the first quarter last  year driven by lower underwriting and financial results. Both the private and commercial segments in Norway  were impacted by the regulated increase in claims. We estimate the weather-related deviation in claims compared  to historical first quarter averages to approximate NOK 250 million to NOK 300 million. The difference is even  larger compared to Q1 2017 which was particularly benign weather wise.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The development in the loss ratio is shown on page 8. Both large losses and frequency claims were up compared  to the first quarter of last year. The harsh weather conditions in Norway negatively affected by frequency claims  and impacted the loss ratio [indiscernible] (00:13:38) percentage points more than expected based on historical  averages.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Large losses were up 2 percentage points, partly due to the weather conditions in Norway. The run-off gains  came in somewhat higher than the expected level of NOK 250 million per quarter and reducing the loss ratio by  1.5 percentage points compared with last year.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Let's turn to page 9 for an overview of large losses. Total large losses amounted to NOK 225 million, somewhat  lower than the expected level and corresponding to 3.8 percentage points on a combined ratio. The impact is 2  percentage points higher than the first quarter last year ago. And the commercial segments recorded a significant  portion of large losses, NOK 118 million for the quarter, partially related to the heavy snowfall this winter.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Moving on to page 10 to comment the run-off gains. The runoff gains for the quarter came to NOK 340 million,  higher than the current expected level of NOK 250 million. Random variations as well as adjustment of large loss  provision explained the additional NOK 90 million of runoff gains. Our expectation remains that there will be  approximately NOK 250 million per quarter in runoff gains for the rest of 2018. The run-off had a positive impact  5.8 percentage points on the combined ratio.

file: GJF - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 25April2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Mitra. Good morning and welcome, everyone. The first quarter in 2019 was characterized by more  favorable weather conditions in Norway compared to the first quarter 2018, as well as strong financial markets  driving a significant improvement in results. Starting with a few comments on our first quarter results on page 2.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: We generated the profit before tax of just above NOK 3 billion. This is including the gain of the sale of Gjensidige  Bank of NOK 1.6 billion. The group's underwriting result for the quarter amounted to NOK 798 million  corresponding to a combined ratio of 86.6%, significantly better than the same quarter last year. The improvement  was mainly due to more favorable weather conditions in Norway compared with the harsh first quarter last year.  Our operations outside Norway showed a mixed picture with progress in underlying results in Denmark and  Sweden while the Baltics were impacted by demanding weather conditions in the first quarter. And our strong cost  discipline resulting in a decline in the cost ratio.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Our ambitions don't stop at the reporting process, but rather extends into straight-through claims processing. So  far, we have reached almost 14% of all claims in Norway. Efforts are under way to increase automation further.  We are working to reduce claims cost, in short, through use of technology in combination with analytical insight.  We will be reporting on this on an annual basis. And we have an ambition to reduce our own and claims-related  carbon intensity. We are in the process of finalizing the method by establishing a zero point for CO2 emissions  and we'll report status on an annual basis. And we are very encouraged by, once again, ranking number one in  the financial sector in Norway in the Sustainable Brand Index study.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The underwriting result improved due to a decline in underlying frequency loss ratio and lower large losses, with  more favorable weather conditions in Norway being the main driver for this. I am particularly satisfied with the  development in the Commercial segment, proving our strong position and pricing over in Norway. Results from  the investment activities reflected the rebound in the capital markets, and our pension business saw yet another  strong quarter with a significant increase in earnings compared with Q1 2018.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Now turning on to page 9. The loss ratio decreased by 6 percentage points to 71.7 percentage points primarily  due to the improvement in the underlying frequency loss ratio and lower large losses. The harsh weather  conditions in Norway in Q1 last year drew up losses from motor and property. With more favorable weather this  year, we saw losses coming down. Underlying profitability for motor in Norway, adjusted for weather effects, was  lower year-on-year, reflecting the [indiscernible] (00:13:46) trend seen throughout 2018.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: As Helge mentioned, we reached a turning point for the 12-month revolving underlying loss ratio in Q1. Having  reached this point, we expect profitability for this insurance line to gradually improve from the second quarter.  Underlying profitability for private property in Norway adjusted for weather effects in 2018 was also lower year-on- year. We also recorded lower frequency loss ratios in Denmark and Sweden. Less favorable weather conditions  drove underlying frequency loss ratio up in the Baltics.

texts.text: For the general insurance industry in Europe as a whole, it was flooding that dominated the news this quarter. texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & IR Contact, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Besides the flood, it is largely commercial that is affected by other large losses in the second quarter. file: GJF - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 13July2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Mitra. Good morning and welcome, everyone. 2018 started off with a harsh and long-lasting winter,  also severely affecting the first part of the second quarter. Luckily, we did not experience severe flooding in  Norway as initially feared since we had a warm but also very dry climate in the last part of the quarter.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Areas in the south and southeastern part of Norway were hit to a larger extent than the rest of Norway, and it is in  this part of the country Gjensidige has its strongest presence. In addition, this is also an agricultural area which is  an industry where we have a very high market share. Therefore, both private and commercial property portfolios  were hit. We estimate the weather-related deviation in the frequency claims level in second quarter compared  with historical second quarter average to be in the range of NOK 150 million to NOK 200 million. This means we  have had a total of NOK 400 million to NOK 500 million in claims during the first half year in 2018 related to the  particularly harsh winter in Norway.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Large losses were also higher compared to the second quarter last year, partly due to the heavy snow leading to  damages on buildings. Aside from weather effects, the underlying inflation trend we have seen in motor insurance  in Norway over some quarters now continued into 2018, which I will come back to on the next slide.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Then turning to page 3, I will comment the Norwegian motor situation in particular. I will start by saying that we  are not satisfied with the profitability development we have seen over the past couple of years. As you remember  back in 2014/2015, we anticipated a 1% claims inflation. Motor profitability was very high with claims ratios in the  50s, and as we communicated, it was better than what we could normally expect partly driven by benign weather  situation over several years.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The decline in the underwriting result was mainly a consequence of significantly higher claims in the Private and  Commercial segments, and mainly impacted by the long winter in Norway with large amounts of snow in several  of our largest regions.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: We estimate the weather-related deviation in claims in the second quarter compared to the historical second  quarter average in the range of around NOK 150 million to NOK 200 million. The results in Norway were also  impacted by the continued deterioration in motor profitability, as Helge mentioned, affecting both Commercial and  Private.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The deterioration in Norway was two-fold. The first being weather related. The large amounts of snow in south  and South Eastern Norway lasting well into Q2 caused [ph] melting and freeze (00:19:28) damages for a  significant number of commercial and private properties.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: And finally, with respect to weather related claims, the settlement of some property claims in Q1 exceeded the  provisions made at the end of the first quarter. The second main reason for the rise in the frequency claims level  is the deterioration in the motor segment, as Helge's discussed, reflecting the change in Norwegian vehicle fleet  and related dynamics.

As a result, the effects of the cloudburst in Copenhagen in July are not included in these figures.

There has also been few natural events so far in 2012 compared  with last year. In addition, the loss ratio will be volatile from one quarter to the next as a result of more random  factors.

file: GJF - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 21October2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.text: First I will give some overall comments to these results. Growth in premiums was 6.9%, 3.2% adjusted for  currency and transactions. The experience continued due to underlying claims development for the motor  products. However, it was somewhat weaker for the property product as a result of a lot of thunder and lightning  at start of the quarter. The property products are volatile and vulnerable to the wind and the weather. Claims  incurred in the quarter were approximately 27% higher than last year and 30% compared with the last five years.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.text: In the calculations presented here, we have assumed that our interpretation of the regulations as regards natural  perils fund and the guarantee provisions will apply. [indiscernible] (11:48) that they will largely  account as Tier 2  capital. There are two elements that are not yet included in the calculation as excess capital in the standard  formula that will contribute to increasing the excess capital further, and these are the definition of premium  provisions and potential tax effects on the required capital.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.text: As of September 30, the natural perils fund and the guarantee provisions amounted to NOK 2.9 billion, but also  the Norwegian FSA proposal is that natural perils funds accounts to some extent. So, if their view becomes defined  contribution, the negative effect on excess capital would be approximately NOK 2.5 billion. We view these items as  part of Tier 2 capital, so if the FSA's interpretation were to become the final outcome, our capacity for  subordinated debt will increase probably at the same amount.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.text: On the insurance side, the capital requirements are particularly high for long-term products such as occupational  injury and liability insurance while the [indiscernible] (18:22) fo r motor and property insurance are high because  they are such big products for us. The property requirement includes the effect of the natural catastrophes. In  summary, our opinion, that is a reasonably balanced portfolio. The full effect of the diversification benefits is,  however, [indiscernible] (18:42) through the internal model which is also a tool that will be used as our active cap  management tool.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: Effect on the combined ratio was 3.8 percentage points this quarter. The largest individual claim in the third  quarter was the cloudburst over Copenhagen and the south of Sweden at the end of Au gust which resulted in  claims totaling NOK 7 8 million.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: Accident and health products continued to produce favorable good results. But as Helge has already men tioned,  the property product were on the weaker side this quarter due to many weather -related claims. With more fires  and more water-related claims, some of it is normally expected. Finally, I will make some comments to the  investment portfolio, which again contributes with the satisfactory return seen in the light of a challenging interest  rate environment.

file: GJF - Q3 2015 Earnings Call Oslo 23October2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.text: Moving to the investment return, we reported a loss of NOK 150 million in the quarter, mainly driven by the  widening of credit spreads and weak equity markets. Catharina will comment more deeply back to this afterwards.  Summarized then, the annual return on equity for the year-to-date is 15.8% and that's satisfying given the very  challenging climate for investment returns.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.text: Based on the signals received during the quarter, as regards to Natural Perils Fund, we expect to achieve final and  positive clarification of this issue before the turn of the year. And we expect that the Natural Perils Fund will  qualify as Solvency capital from January 1, 2016.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: Property private have also developed good or delivered good profitability in the quarter and better than in the  corresponding quarter last year. We have a negative effect from torrential rain in Norway in September, but last  year, there were many more water damage claims and thunder and [ph] lasting related (17:24) claims during the  quarter.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: So, if you look at page 16, I will talk you through the available capital and capital requirements from the statutory  perspective for [ph] giving on the point where they defer (25:59). The basis for the available capital is the IFRS  equity. The Natural Perils Funds and the guarantee scheme provisions are included in the IFRS equity and we  have not excluded these elements from the available capital.

file: GJF - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 26October2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Claims expenses this quarter are somewhat affected by a short period of heavy rain in the parts of Norway early  in the quarter. However, we still have a good underlying frequency claims development, and when it comes to  run-off and large losses, it were at expected level in third quarter.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: If you also adjust for changes in run-off and large losses between the two quarters, we see an underlying  weakening of the underwriting result of NOK 89 million. Some of the underlying change can be related to one  short period of heavy rain in parts of the country in August which affects both private and commercial. The  remaining weakening is well within what we would expect in variations in an industry as general insurance.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: And as mentioned, some of the deterioration can be ascribed to the heavy rain which led to a weaker frequency  claims development, especially for property, which otherwise shows good underlying profitability in the quarter.  The motor portfolio in private Norway shows continued good profitability, on par with the same trend last year and  better than we normally expect. We do see signs of a somewhat increased claims inflation, and monitor the  development closely to ensure appropriate pricing initiatives.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA

Over the long-term, profitability trend is  still good for this product. The accident and health products saw stable, good development. We see signs that the  economy in general is stabilizing, but we're still experiencing price pressure in the market, as we have previously  communicated.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: As shown on the right, Gjensidige last week received the IPSOS 2017 reputation prize in Norway. texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA

We and competitors operate with general price increases in the SME  segment, which should support continued good profitability going forward.

file: GJF - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 25October2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Mitra. Good morning and welcome, everyone. This has indeed been an extraordinary year for  Gjensidige. The occurrence of extreme weather events continued into the third quarter, this time with a heat wave  we have not seen in Norway in a long time, and the dry summer since 1947. This took us all by surprise and  naturally impacted our results significantly, compared with the extraordinary strong results in Q3 last year.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: For the third quarter in a row, extraordinary weather conditions drove frequency claims high above last year,  putting pressure on our underwriting result in Norway. Large losses were also considerably higher partly due to  weather adding to the deterioration of results.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Intense heat waves and the drought led to significant crop failure in Norway. Having a significant position in the  agriculture sector and customers with crop insurance, we do expect cycle claims currently estimated to NOK 80  million.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Our property insurance line in Norway was hit by fires as well as damages from heavy rainfalls and storms during  the quarter. And in general, nice and warm weather leads to higher leisure activity and more accidents. We  estimate the weather-related deviation in frequency claims in the third quarter related to property and crops  compared with historical third quarter average to be in the range of NOK 130 million to NOK 160 million. This  means we have had a total of NOK 530 million to NOK 660 million in claims so far this year related to the  extraordinary weather in Norway.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Preparing for unexpected events is part of our business. This is the nature of insurance. But, of course, when  several events occur within a short span of time and with such force, it temporarily challenges our results. And  listening to the experts in this field, it is prudent to expect more volatile weather conditions and a higher frequency  of extreme events going forward. We acknowledge this and will need to reflect it in our pricing as well. This still  applies particularly for the property insurance lines which are most exposed to weather effects, meaning price  increases will have to exceed the building index to reflect more frequency going forward.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Large losses, they're significantly higher compared with the third quarter last year, reflecting property damages  from fires, heavy rains, and storms. Profitability in motor insurance continued to deteriorate, as expected, driven  by the lag effects from pricing measures relatively to claims inflation.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: I will comment on status for our ongoing mitigation actions on the next slide. Outside Norway, we continue to  deliver significantly improved results. Our results were also impacted by provisions of NOK 80 million related to  restructuring measures. I will come back also to this on the next slide.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Including Gjensidige Bank, the pre-tax result would have closer to NOK 1.1 billion. The decline in the pre-tax profit  for continuing operations compared with last year was primarily driven by the underwriting result. The underwriting  result was significantly impacted by the extraordinary weather conditions, driving claims in both the Private and  Commercial segments in Norway. The result also includes a provision of NOK 80 million related to the  restructuring measures Helge mentioned. We estimate the weather-related deviations in frequency claims in the  third quarter compared to the historical third quarter average to be in the range of around NOK 130 million to NOK  160 million.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Higher frequency claims impacted Norway related to the extraordinary weather conditions and difficult  comparables due to particularly favorable underlying frequency claims situation in Q3 last year. The weather  impact was related to our property and agriculture insurance lines, estimated at NOK 130 million to NOK 160  million, above an average Q3, corresponding to 2.1 percentage points to 2.6 percentage points on the total group  Gjensidige. Still adjusted for this, the underlying claims ratio deteriorated by around 4 percentage points. This can  partly be explained by the strong results in Q3 2017 and partly by the underlying situation in motor insurance in  Norway.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Let's turn to page 9 for an overview of large losses. Total large losses amounted to NOK 319 million, somewhat  above our expected long-term average of NOK 295 million. The losses translate into 5.2 percentage points on the  combined ratio. The large losses are primarily related to Commercial and Private property in Norway, and that's  significantly influenced by the storms and heavy rainfalls in Norway during the quarter.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Jostein. To sum up, on page 16, our Q3 results were significantly impacted by extraordinary weather  conditions. We continue to generate improved results outside Norway, proving successful restructuring measures.  Our results so far this year have been hit by the weather conditions and the pressure on the motor insurance line,  challenging our ability to deliver on all our financial targets this year.

file: GJF - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 9February2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Thank you Yvona and welcome to all of you. Our first year as a listed company has passed, and given the  challenging international macro-economic situation, the Nordic countries, Norway, and the Gjensidige  particularly has had a relatively stable position and we are pleased with the total return and buoyancy we have  from the lifting to the end of 2011 of 35%. As you may know in December, the Gjensidige Foundation, our biggest  Gjensidige listed and [ph] who have kept (1:19) these shares throughout the year. So the total of about 2.2 million  bonus shares were distributed to more than 42,000 shareholders and the same retail investors will also next  December or December in 2012 receive bonus shares. In 2011 we delivered an underwriting result of NOK 1,421  million, and that's 29% better than 2010. The 2010 results were affected, as you know, by a particularly hard  winter while 2011 has shown significantly milder weather, but had more high levels of extreme weather and  weather-related claims.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Snowing in Norway in June, the torrential rain in Copenhagen in July and the storms called Berit and Dagmar  towards the end of the year here in Norway have altogether resulted in net claims for you'll see here of about €330  million. This has led to a challenging reinsurance renewal late in 2011 with a market dividend in its view of terms,  conditions and capacity. And I'm pleased to tell you that Gjensidige however renewed its reinsurance without any  material changes compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Despite this long-term and continuous focus on profitability, correct pricing and adjustments of the organization  have enabled us to deliver good 2011 results of a combined ratio of 91.9% whereas the mentioned weather-related  claims represent 1.9%. So adjusted for these weather-related claims it's 9% in 2011.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Then turning to point four, and turning into the fourth quarter. The results for the fourth quarter isolated were  affected by lot of abnormal weather. We delivered an underwriting result of NOK 186 million in the quarter at a  combined ratio is 95.7. That's not satisfactory to see in isolation.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Two extreme storms in Norway, Berit and Dagmar, represented as much as 4.1% of the combined ratio in the  quarter and these together with provisions in the quarter related to ongoing restructuring of the Private  distribution, reduction of the branches and collective bonus to all of our employees, that's representing 1.9% of the  combined ratio. And so if you are looking to the underlying results, we are satisfied with the underlying results  and developments. The collective bonus is related to a successful first year [indiscernible] (5:47) in combination  with our ROE deliveries of 16.3% and the underwriting result.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & IR Contact, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Turning to page 15, combined ratio in the quarter came in at 95.7. I would just like to remind you that this is on a  discounted basis. On a discounted basis, the combined ratio would have been 91.2. The loss ratio was 79.1 in the  quarter and as already mentioned it was impacted by weather-related trends. In total claims insured for on  account for the two storms Berit and Dagmar amounted to NOK108 million corresponding to a negative effect of  4.1 on the loss ratio in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & IR Contact, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Turning to page 16, the impact of large claims was somewhat lower than expected in fourth quarter 2011 with the  2.3% impact on combined ratio against expected 3.6%. Large losses mainly affected the segments Commercial  Norway and Nordic. I would just like to point out that the weather related claims are not included in these figures  as they are regarded as frequency claims and not large losses. As a result the effects on claims secured of storms in  the fourth quarter are not included in the large losses figures.

file: GJF - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 14February2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: When we are to summarize the results for 2012 there is no escaping the fact that the loss frequency was unusually  low seen from the perspective of Nordic general insurance company. This was especially the case in the motor and  property insurance. We have also seen this while you have looked into the figures from our peers reporting before  us. We had no major weather-related events in 2012, unlike what we saw in 2011. The return on investment  portfolio was NOK3 billion, corresponding to a return of 5.4%, and given the appetite for risk and risk portfolio  profile in our portfolio management, we are very satisfied with this return.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & IR Contact, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: An important explanation for the good results in the quarter, in addition to good underlying profitability, is a very  low proportion of large losses and major weather-related events in the quarter. The bank also recorded  [indiscernible] (21:06) performance in the quarter, while the result in pension and savings was negatively affected  by a strengthening of claims provisions for disability risks related to different pension products, in addition to the  fact that the return on financial assets for the year above the guaranteed interest on the paid-up policy portfolio  was allocated better for longer life expectancy.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & IR Contact, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The same applies to the property products. They are also being priced highest in the quarter, which normally  accounts for some medium price change in the range of NOK1 million to NOK10 million; however, the loss ratio  for the quarter was also probably less affected by the [indiscernible] (23:33), large losses and weather related  events.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & IR Contact, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Reserving is done on a best estimate effort, implying that the expectant run-off level is zero. The level of run-off  will, of course, vary between the quarters, thus over the last 13 years the run-off results have on average have a  positive effect on the combined ratio of 0.9 percentage points.

file: GJF - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 5February2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Janne Merethe Flessum
texts.text: The frequency claims development was more normal this year compared to 2012 and was on a satisfactory level  overall. However, we have had more weather-related events this year, both in the second quarter and the fourth  quarter, as you will hear shortly afterwards.

texts.speaker: Janne Merethe Flessum
texts.text: Finally, before Catharina gives you some more information about the fourth quarter, it's important to comment  the dramatic fires that have been experienced in Norway over the past few weeks. Luckily, no [ph] life (05:52) had  been lost, but it has been dramatic for the local communities and for all the people who have been affected, and  it's important for us to assist our customers in the best possible way. This is a reminder to the whole organization  about the importance of our core business.

texts.speaker: Janne Merethe Flessum
texts.text: Finance Norway, [ph] common (06:14) organization for the insurance companies in Norway, has estimated the  total market loss for the fires in Laerdal and Flatanger to be NOK 350 million as these are two separate events.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & EVP-Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: In addition to the storms, we also had another NOK 7 0 million of large losses in the quarter. In total, large losses  have affected the combined ratio by 9.2 percentage points. In comparison, there were no weather -related events in  the fourth quarter 2012 and only a minor proportion of the large losses.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & EVP-Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The Nordic region experienced a great deal of extreme weather in both 2011 and 2013, and this also has had an  effect on the reinsurance prices related to weather-related events. Based on an assessment of reinsurance costs  versus the expected results from the reinsurance program, Gjensidige has decided to increase the group's  retention level relating to weather-related events from NOK 100 million to NOK 200 million from 2014. And the  rest of the reinsurance program is more or less unchanged.

file: GJF - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 4February2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.text: If you look at page two in the presentation, you can see the fourth quarter results where we re ported profit before  tax of NOK 1.159 billion and record high fourth quarter underwriting results for more than NOK 800 million,  NOK 807 million. The underlying premium growth of 5.1% is an important contributor to this result, together  with the benign weather situation in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: The strong underwriting result is due to good underlying risk selection and pricing, which contributed to a  favorable underlying frequency situation. In addition, the proportion of large losses was relatively low with a low  impact of weather and natural peril claims. In addition to that, the run-off gains are higher than in the  corresponding quarter in 2013.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: For the year as a whole, the profit before tax expense amounted to NOK 5.4 billion, up from NOK 4.6 billion in  2013. The main explanation for this development is the favorable frequency and weather situation as well as  higher run-off gains and that's the most lower proportion of large losses.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: So, moving to page nine; you can see that we have a solid combined ratio of 84.5% in the quarter. This is a very  strong fourth quarter result and also stronger than in the third quarter where we have a combined ratio of 85.5%.  This was driven by favorable weather and run-off gains.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: As you can see from the illustration, the Corporate Centre also makes a positive contribution of NOK 85 million to  the growth in the quarter. This is because of reinstatement premium of minus NOK 8 million was charged to the  Corporate Centre in the fourth quarter in 2013. That was a result of the very extensive natural disaster claims in  that quarter in 2013. Over time, we expect organic growth in line with GDP in our market.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: Drop in oil prices in combination with lower interest rates, the weakened Norwegian currency will affect the  Norwegian economy, it's still too early to say and there are forces working in different directions.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: We have a limited direct exposure to the oil sectors, and this mainly relates to accident and health and workers'  comp product. If we are to see substantial workforce reduction within the oil sector or increased unemploy ment in  Norway, this is mainly where we will see lower activities.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: So, turning to page 11, you can see that we have had a lot of impact from large losses this quarter, affecting the  combined ratio 3.8 percentage points versus the expected level of 5.1 percentage points. The biggest individual  loss announced this time was the flooding in Norway in October, which affecte d the Gjensidige's results in the  amount of NOK 95 million. In the fourth quarter, the year before, large losses affected the combined ratio with 9.2  percentage points mainly due to several severe storms.

texts.speaker: Catharina Elisabeth Hellerud
texts.text: It is worth mentioning that randomness can have significant effects, of course, on looking at the weather and large  losses. And in January 2015, Norway was hit by storm Nina. And so far, the total market loss is estimated to NOK  450 million and Gjensidige's share of this will be around 25%.

file: GJF - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 9February2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: We report yet another good underwriting results of NOK 700 million. We saw a more normal winter this quarter  and thereby a more normal overall frequency claims level compared to the corresponding quarter the previous  year, which was record strong due to a very benign weather situation.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The loss ratio was 70.6% this quarter or 75% when adjusted for normalized large losses and our run-off  expectations. This is a satisfactory asset level taking into consideration that the fourth quarter is a winter quarter  in the Nordic region. The reported level is 2.6 percentage points higher than the corresponding quarter the year  before. Adjusted for changes in run-off and large losses, the underlying loss ratio was 5.5 percentage points  higher. This reflects the very benign weather situation in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to a more normal  winter this quarter.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Motor and property insurance in Norway were particularly affected by more cold weather. And as Helge  commented, the development for motor insurance both in Norway and Denmark during the fourth quarter  confirmed a less benign claims inflation development than anticipated, and measures have been taken to offset  the higher expected claims inflation going forward. The reason is more expensive repairs due to a combination of  higher input costs, currency movements and more advanced cars that contain more technology. We still expect  the frequency of personal injuries to develop positively long term due to safer cars and safer roads, but at a  slower pace than before.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The underlying loss ratio for the property products in Norway were also higher compared to the corresponding  period in 2015, due to a more normal weather situation. Claims inflation expectations are stable at around 4%.  The Nordic segment recorded a high loss ratio than the same quarter in 2015. This was mainly due to weaker  underlying profitability in Denmark for agriculture and property insurance. In addition to frequency of mid-sized  claims within the agriculture sector especially was unusually high in the quarter. Measures have been taken to  compensate for higher expected overall claims inflation in Denmark. Better risk selection and re-underwriting will  be prioritized in addition to premium increases. Putting new tariffs in place and continuously improving existing  tariffs will gradually give effect.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The runoff gain of NOK 314 million had a positive effect of 5.5 percentage points on the combined ratio in the  quarter compared to 4.2 percentage points in the fourth quarter of 2015. The gain is related to motor TPL workers'  comp in Norway, as well as a positive effect from Danish worker comp this quarter. Helge has already  commented that we now expect average annual run-off gains at around NOK 900 million over the next three year  to five year period. This will still be related to personal injuries in motor TPL and workers' comp in Norway.

file: GJF - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 26January2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jan-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: When it comes to weather-related issues, Q4 and Q1 are, as you know, winter quarters in our region, which  normally leads to higher claims ratios as seen also in the past. Q4 2017 was a quite typical winter quarter in our  region overall, but there will always be variances from year-to-year with regards to temperature and the frequency  of snow falls, et cetera. This can lead to variations in frequency levels. For instance, we experienced more  slippery roads this quarter especially around Christmastime leading to higher motor claims frequency.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: In addition, we had two larger natural peril events in Norway in the quarter affecting large losses with NOK 199  million. As for the underlying development in motor in Norway, we see the same trend as before, but we also  experienced the somewhat high competition this quarter related to bonus initiatives from some players.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The combined ratio was 85.4%, better than our target range of 86% to 89%, or 90% to 93% exclusive runoff.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President for Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The large losses are impacted by two natural perils claims, a flood in Southern Norway in October and a storm in  Norway in November. They had a combined impact of NOK 199 million, of which most is recognized in the  Corporate Center.

file: GJF - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 24January2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Jan-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Mitra. Good morning and welcome, everyone. 2018 was indeed an extraordinary year for Gjensidige  with extreme weather impacts hitting our earnings for the first three quarters. The fourth quarter was a more  normal quarter from a weather perspective.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: The improvement was a result of premium growth and a more favorable underlying profitability, particularly for  motor in Norway, mainly as a consequence of more benign weather conditions compared with the fourth quarter  2017. Our operation outside Norway continued to show good progress and our strong cost discipline resulted in a  decline in the cost ratio. Market turmoil resulted in negative returns of NOK 231 million on our investment  portfolio. Jostein [ph] will work (00:02:37) with more detailed comments on the results.

texts.speaker: Helge Leiro Baastad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Turning to page 3 and looking at the year as a whole, we reported a pre-tax profit of NOK 4.3 billion. We are not  satisfied with the underlying results we have delivered in 2018, even when adjusting for the extraordinary weather  effects last year hitting us with somewhere between NOK 530 million and NOK 660 million through the first nine  months. Hence, first and foremost, our focus is on getting our Norwegian business back on track. I will revert  shortly to this.

texts.speaker: Jostein Amdal
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Finance, Gjensidige Forsikring ASA
texts.text: Turning over to page 9, the loss ratio decreased by 21 percentage points to 53.8%. Majority of this is related to a  significant increase in run-off gains recorded in the quarter. However, it is also important to point out that  underlying profitability improved. The weather conditions in Q4 2017 drove up losses for motor in Norway. And  this year, with a more benign Q4 weather-wise, we saw claims coming down. We've seen the positive effect of our  pricing measures starting to come through. This in combination with other measures such as increased retention  levels make us confident that the underlying loss ratio for private and motor in Norway will reach a turning point  during the first half of 2019.

texts.text: And again, implementation of LEAN programs across our manufacturing complementing the cost reduction we  have achieved through the Irish manufacturing operations over the last two years.

texts.profession: Group Managing Director & Executive Director, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: As noted earlier, we completed the sale now 60% of dairy items, so this is discontinued in this set of results.

texts.speaker: Mark A. Garvey
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Executive Director, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: A number of factors have caused our inventory level to rise including higher dairy prices, some recent  acquisitions, a build-up of raw material stock in conjunction with the implementation of a new inventory  management system and longer lead times as we expand our international business. We would expect some of these issues to be mitigated in the coming months leading to a  reduced inventory balance at year-end. As I mentioned in our last update, I do expect overall working capital to be  a net outflow this year following a number of years of inflows.

file: GL9 - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 2March2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The backdrop to much of this in the end consumer and a variety of end-segments reflects global  dairy consumption being driven up, particularly in developing economies where it’s a function of the  rise of the middle class, and dairy is driven in developing economies by rise in income per capita.  Indeed, the rise in oil prices while somewhat of a double-edged sword probably does deliver ability  to pay in many economies, also driving dairy demand.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: As many of you would have heard elsewhere, I believe clean labels and natural ingredients, which  plays to the dairy space and indeed our whey protein derivatives are also a growing issue for other  food manufactures where we sell ingredients. Our Nutrition business, we’ve seen strong growth  there. Performance Nutrition has performed strongly in the year as a whole, interesting to see  endorsement of protein supplementation by the International Olympic Committee coming through  before Christmas. And we see more mainstream uptake of that into endurance and other sports, all  positive for all the growth we’ve seen in the business. Demographics also driving natural  ingredients and indeed protein use in supplementation, we see that as a key area of focus for us in  the post-baby boomer generations, supporting initiatives and innovation around active aging. And  as I referred earlier the use – the opportunity for clean labels and therefore naturally derived  ingredients in the food sector generally supporting demand.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of a quick review of both of the key business groupings, in Dairy Ireland we have three  businesses, the combined revenue of €1.1 billion and an EBITA margin of 4.2% for 2010, and that’s  an integrated chain very much beginning with Agribusiness producing and selling about 430,000  tonnes of animal feeds, delivered 5% growth in volume last year and 220,000 tonnes approximately  of fertilizer with about 4% growth in volume in 2010. That integrates with our farmer supply base of  approximately 5,000 in Ireland, supplying us with 1.8 billion liters of milk going to two businesses.

file: GL9 - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 29February2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Feb-12.pdf

texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Managing Director, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: In terms of Global Nutritionals, we've seen strong growth in all the key nutritional markets. We see a growing  number of nutrition-aware consumers. texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Managing Director, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: We've also launched a number of new products coming in to the start of this year, including a cholesterol-lowering  milk beverage which we are reasonably optimistic on its contribution to improving value through a mix effect as  we come into 2012.

texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Managing Director, Glanbia Plc

texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Managing Director, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: Additionally fertilizer usage in the year was down somewhat, by about 5% against a market down overall 11%. So  overall Agribusiness delivered a solid performance, the improved mix and cost improvements driving a good  outturn overall.

texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Managing Director, Glanbia Plc

texts.profession: Thanks Siobhán. I'll continue now to a conclusion just with some strategic issues and the outlook. In terms of the

texts.speaker: Siobhán Talbot
texts.profession: Group Managing Director Designate, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: In fact, as we say on the next slide, that innovation center has undoubtedly enhanced our capability and we can  see that already with some very nice customer collaborations we're doing with some of our key U.S. Cheese  customers which allows us to stay close and tight with them as they are developing products for markets  particularly in the U.S. We did too, as I say, continue to develop our value-added systems and solutions and that's  effectively blending our ingredients or blending our protein with non-dairy ingredients that gives particular  function of solutions to our customers playing into agendas such as clean label.

texts.speaker: Siobhán Talbot
texts.profession: Group Managing Director Designate, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: For a number of years now, our Global Ingredients piece has been positioned well to play to tho se opportunities  particularly at protein and dairy protein's efficacy is increasingly recognized, and that plays into other trends both  at clean labels and the importance of that in food nutrition and Consumer Products.

texts.speaker: Siobhán Talbot
texts.profession: Group Managing Director Designate, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: So our solutions and systems spend, both dairy and non-dairy, it encapsulates our vitamin and minerals  premixing operation, and indeed as I mentioned, we're increasingly interested in where we can combine dairy and  non-dairy, some very nice things that we've done combining [indiscernible] (21:38), and, for example, whey  protein.

file: GL9 - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 25February2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Siobhán Talbot
texts.text: When you look at the protein energy product, that's playing to consumer insights around the desire to capture   both protein and energy to fulfill the requirements of the day and get people efficiently through their daily energy  and protein needs. Very early days, but I think will be positive. And we did our first global launch of the  reformulation of NOX 3.0. Again, the team did a great job, largely, too, driven on the back of very specific  consumer insight and research, a capability that we've expanded within performance nutrition organization in  recent years.

texts.speaker: Mark A. Garvey
texts.text: Dairy Ireland revenues fell primarily due to softness in Agribusiness, resulting from unusually good weather  conditions, but EBITA and margins improved as the ongoing rationalization program is delivering good bottom  line results. EBITA was up 25.8% to €19 million and EBITA margins were up 80 basis points to 3.1%. Our wholly  owned businesses then reported revenues of €2.5 billion, an increase of 6.4% over 2013 in a constant currency  basis. Wholly-owned EBITA was €208.6 million, an increase of 11.1% constant currency and EBITA margins  improved 30 basis points to 8.2%.

file: GL9 - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 24February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Siobhán Talbot
texts.text: And while a large part of our portfolio is dairy based, our non-dairy business did do well in 2015, and we continue  to develop that.

texts.speaker: Siobhán Talbot
texts.text: From a market perspective, clearly the environment does remain competitive. But our ongoing investment in our  brands and indeed the extension of some of our brands off the island of Ireland will continue I think to deliver  growth.

file: GL9 - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 22February2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-17.pdf
GL9 - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 21February2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Siobhán Talbot
texts.profession: Group Managing Director & Executive Director, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: As noted earlier, we're pleased to add Amazing Grass and Body & Fit to the GPN brand portfolio. Amazing Grass  is a strong brand in that high-growth, on-trend category. It's a growing brand that complements our overall  portfolio, helping us to broaden our appeal to the health-conscious lifestyle consumers that are seeking plant- based nutrition.

texts.speaker: Mark A. Garvey
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Executive Director, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: As I touched on previously, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act was signed into U.S. law in late December 2017. Although  there are many aspects to this law, one of the primary changes is the reduction of U.S. federal corporate tax rate  from 35% to 21%. When we reviewed our deferred tax balances related to U.S. taxes, we made a determination  to reduce our deferred tax liability by €38.7 million at year-end and we have recognized this benefit as an  exceptional gain in our financial statements.

file: GL9 - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 20February2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Siobhán Talbot
texts.profession: Group Managing Director & Executive Director, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: From a strong dairy heritage, our consumer-led innovative approach has now broadened our portfolio to now  span a range of high-quality offerings of ingredients and consumer brands, those appealing to a wide spectrum of  consumers seeking both dairy and nondairy nutrition. Our future growth in primary dairy will be through building  on the successful current partnership model. Our focus for growth and capital allocation will be further off the  value chain, where through focused investment on innovation and organizational capabilities, we have developed  leading positions and higher value offerings as world's leading experts in a wide range of dairy and bioactive  ingredients and specialized nutrient premixes. And as a brand owner, we are a global leader in performance and  lifestyle nutrition.

texts.speaker: Siobhán Talbot
texts.profession: Group Managing Director & Executive Director, Glanbia Plc
texts.text: Nutritional Solutions is a leading provider of customized nutrient premixes, advanced-technology protein  solutions, functional beverages and flavors. Within Nutritional Solutions, we have a diverse product portfolio in  both dairy and non-dairy. And we support our customers on both a global and regional basis, where we can  supply solutions that improve product functionality and the nutritional profile. Ultimately, helping our customers to  value-add to their brands based on key consumer trends.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In that context, we also have pursued efforts vis-à-vis cost expense. You know that it's a very important target for  us and for me, and we will continue our efforts in that perspective. Second element, I will comment in more  details in a few minutes. Capital building, we are there both from a Basel 2.5 perspective and for Basel 3  perspective. It has created, if I've read your comments in detail, some difficulties to analyze effective impact of  the deleveraging this quarter.
