texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Second, we also have made some progress in deleveraging of the CIB and mostly vis-à-vis the legacy assets. You  don't see that in the risk-weighted assets; it's mostly about losing on the deduction of capital. So it's not exactly an  impact that you might see if you look at the risk-weighted assets of the CIB. But the impact in terms of Basel 2.5  whether it's about disposing of this asset or cracking the CDO is a positive one. It's relatively positive under Basel  2.5 definition, above 10 bps. It's even more efficient than the Basel 3, which is not material yet, but which is  important for my next point regarding our roadmap to Basel 3. But we make more than 20 bps with this legacy  assets active management. So on Basel 2.5, 9.4%, 40 bps achieved this quarter. It's quite promising and  encouraging for the quarters to come.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The good news – it's not totally news to us; it might be news to you – is that we started well with this first quarter,  40 bps increase, and of course, we will continue to transform the bank. It was to a certain extent easier that  quarter given the environment, which was better, and we have seized all the opportunities to reduce our balance  sheet, to increase the quality of our refinancing, to work on the CIB model, and of course, to pursue efforts in  terms of cost control.

texts.speaker: Frédéric Oudéa
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Société Générale SA
texts.text: But more importantly structurally, again when we look at our businesses, where we did not deliver, it is in the  capital markets, you will see that on the financing side, things have gone on the contrary very well. When I say Fixed Income, it's Credit Rate and Commodity. And when I say this, it's taking  into account not only the environment and it's not a reaction just to the fourth quarter. It's a reaction to the fact that  when we see now the next five years, the way the market is evolving with the regulation in Europe, whether it's  more capital demand, whether it's MiFID, we will not, if we don't [ph] act – meet (00:04:21) an acceptable return  on normative equity and that's why we will refocus and concentrate the capital allocation to our areas of  excellence as well as having an efficiency plan, an additional one of €500 million at the horizon of 2020 in this  division.

texts.text: Ivan Glasenberg  Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc  Good morning. Thank you for coming today for the first half earnings report of Glencore. Today I'm accompanied  by my – with my colleagues. And on the right-hand side, you have Gary Fegel, Head of Alumina, Aluminium. We  have next to him Telis Mistakidis, the Head of Zinc, Copper. Next to him Chris Mahoney, the Head of Grain  division; Steve Kalmin, our CFO; Tor Peterson on the left, the Head of our Coal division; Alex Beard, the Head of  the Oil division and Paul Smith, the Head of Investor Relations.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The growth projects are all on track and we will talk about that when we look at the industrial assets. But turning  to the next slide, looking at the Marketing division of the business and as you well know we split out the marketing  from the industrial assets. We also breakdown within the Marketing division, the Metals division, the Grain  division, and the Energy division, and if you're looking at first half 2010 as opposed to first half 2011, the  marketing side of the business has grown 45%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Looking at the industrial side of the division, as you can imagine, with volumes growing on the industrial side of  the business. As you well know, we are expanding most of our productions, especially our production bases in the  Congo in respect to copper, in Kazakhstan in respect of the gold production, and the growth in our coal operations  in Prodeco. So, with volumes higher, higher prices during the first half of 2011, as opposed to first half of 2010,  we've increased the profits on the industrial side of the business from $1.3 billion, up 54% to $2 billion.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: If you look at most of the production, looking at the metal side, Kazzinc's own gold production is up 62%, Katanga  copper production, up 72%, Mopani copper production, up 58%, and Mutanda copper production at 25,000  tonnes. The coal production is up to – 12%, including both our South African and our Colombian operations.  We're up to 11.1 million tonnes and Prodeco production up 32% to 7.1 million tonnes, and the Aseng oil field is  expected to come on-stream during fourth quarter 2011, and this is ahead of schedule.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So most of our industrial assets, as opposed to what we're seeing with the other mining companies, we are  delivering them on budget, on time. Some of them a little bit delayed. Katanga has a few delays. The gold  production in Kazakhstan has delays; however, this is well-compensated by the Mutanda expansion, which is  ahead of schedule, and even the Katanga operation, even though it's behind on schedule on copper produced, it's  not behind on schedule on copper mined in the ore. There we're up to – right up to budget our expectations and  slightly ahead, but few problems on the concentrate, and the smelter has affected this, but that backlog will be  picked up well in 2012.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On the oil side, turning to the next slide, I mentioned about Mutanda, how we intend growing Mutanda, which is  very important. Mutanda will produce 60,000 tonnes of copper this year. However, by the end of the year, it will  be annualized at around about 110,000 tonnes. And we are now developing a feasibility expansion of Mutanda to  merge it together with Kansuki and look at an operation of around 210,000 tonnes at that site.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The oil, as I said, the Aseng field, well, is already covered earlier, but the Alen field commenced development  drilling earlier this month and first production there is expected in 2013, once again, ahead of schedule.

texts.text: But on the Industrial side, the shape of this graph would look very familiar with others that you would have seen  in many of the commodities. The pricing  benefits, again spread, weighted mostly towards Metals and Mining in our Gold, Copper, Zinc businesses as well  there, that's $557 million in fact, is Metals and Mining and $107 million relates to coal within the price variance.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So the $325 million split roughly a third between FX and a third then between normal CPI-related activities and  another bigger portion would relate to just general increases that we've seen also in consumable explosives at the  surface operations, diesel, power cost, and in Zambia, we've seen tariff increases down there as well. As you know, that is producing 60,000 barrels of  oil a day. We get 24% from that. And on the [ph] grassfield (0:03:41) products was mainly just effect on the sugar  side of the business.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So I think that gives you an idea of the various assets which we got. I spoke about most of them. If you look at  metals and minerals, we spoke about that; energy products, the important issues there. If you look at the energy  products, the ramp-up at Prodeco is fully online and on schedule, on budget, once again, on time. These are  brownfield expansions, not difficult expansions, with limited risk.  We had additional contribution from our new acquisitions in South Africa from Optimum, Umcebo and our  Shanduka transaction, which Clinton would talk about further later on. On the ag production side, as I think you  know, we got the new crushing facilities in the Czech Republic and Poland that is coming on stream; and the  results were, on the sugar side as I said, little impacted by the sugarcane production during the year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Kazzinc, we – as you know, the gold and silver equivalents is growing and production is ramping up there. We  have now, I think, sorted out the situation that was occurring at the Altyntau gold projects, and now that is up to  speed; and the copper smelter which is ramping up at Kazzinc is now up to 80% design capacity, so performing  fairly well.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: On Katanga, that is the one the results were announced recently. The situation at Katanga, we are still on line on  budget on capital expenditure. However, we do have delays and Telis can take you through later on in more detail  on those delays; and the large amount of the delays and why we didn't have the increase in production that we're  expecting during the first half; and for the year, we will be below our budgeted expectation, I think which was  announced by the company, so we cannot say much more than what the company announced. But a lot of those  delays is due to the power situation in the Congo, and that is a situation which we've worked on and I believe we've  resolved. So we will – Katanga will get up to speed and we have now processed with the Phase IV expansion to  eventually get Katanga to its design capacity around about 300,000 tons.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Mutanda, the good thing about Mutanda, Mutanda is ahead of schedule and Mutanda will reach its capacity this  year of around 100,000 tons production and growing. We are expanding Mutanda and it will hit its annualized  ramp-up of 200,000 tons by the end of next year. So just giving you a profile of Mutanda, as I said, we will get  there. We are now looking at areas [ph] of sulfides (0:07:23) expansion over there at Mutanda. But you can see it  has had a 48% expansion during first half 2011 to 2012. And as I said earlier, we will merge Mutanda and Kansuki,  and eventually those two projects by the end of 2013 will be annualized at around 200,000 tons.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: The goods part on the E&P portfolio in the oil division, as you can see, we had a very successful development of  the Aseng field in Equatorial Guinea, which started up in November 2011. And that is, as I said earlier, a 60,000  barrels of oil a day. We get 23% of that, so a very successful operation. The other field in Equatorial Guinea, the  Alen field, where we should have production around about 40,000 barrels per day, will be up around quarter- three 2013, we believe, early around about July there and that we will get 24% of the 40,000 barrels a day. So  those will be cash generators of income into the company.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: We also successfully did our first 100% owned exploration in the Cameroon. That's the Oak-1x Times project. It's  been a successful project for Cameroon, and there's a 13.7 meter oil column was discovered in the main prospect  with a total net oil pay of 6.2 meters, which has significantly de-risked the adjacent lying areas at similar depths  there.  So we will have further appraisals of that during 2013, and we believe this is a substantial field with recoverable oil  potentially between 38 and 90 million barrels of recoverable oil, if the adjacent untested structures are included  over there. And note very important, this is 100% owned by Glencore.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Prodeco, as I said earlier, moves ahead. We will have the port operating, the new port, in the first half of 2013;  once again, on time and on budget. And we are ramping up that Prodeco; as you can see an increase of 12% first  half to second half, and by 2013 when the new port is in play, it will be producing around about 19 to 21 million  tons of coal.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So then that gives you a full sum up of our various assets, and as I said earlier, the trading – the assets are  brownfield expansions; easy, low cost expansions; very little likelihood of cost overruns; on time, on budget, which  is lot easier than some of the other mining companies with large greenfield projects. And just – we keep  emphasizing, as we said at the IPO, the trading is resilient to falling commodity prices, and I'm pleased to say I  think we've proved it during the first half of this year with the resilient trading results even though commodity  prices have come off.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: There were few smaller impairments that we booked; the gross effect was around $100 million. We've commented  on the biggest component of that being an impairment we've had against one of the plants in the European  biodiesel. It's something that's within our agricultural, a very over-supplied, over-capacity market, tough margins.  We had a few plants and we've shut down, we've mothballed one of the plants and that's an impairment against  the carrying value there; and some various other smaller pluses and minuses which aggregate to the $466 million  as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: If we look at Viterra, which is one of the big acquisitions that we're looking at now for second half which Chris will  talk about, that's also very different to a mining company from a credit perspective. You're buying a utility-like  operation that's sitting with the different ports and facilities and grain-handling facilities for which they charge a  fee. So they generate that service-like fee. The infrastructure is been built there. It's not particularly complex;  technically very low ongoing maintenance. So it's a very different profile to then buying a big mining or an oil  operation that you continually need to invest to, to sustain those operations and it's very expensive.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: If you think of all the potential which now exists and that's largely been funded, we've got the oil E&P portfolio;  the whole entire African copper base that we have, which has been heavily invested; the South African coal assets;  Kazzinc gold; Colombian coal; many ag processing assets. These are all parts of Glencore's earnings stream and  asset cover that didn't exist in 2010, yet with still the same debt levels at we are today against those periods.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Just some variances and bridges on the industrial side of our business both sequentially, so this is first half 2012  against second half 2011; in fact on Glencore's consolidated assets, you can see at the EBITDA level, we were in  fact up 30% sequentially; and it's more the associate side of our business, which is where we've been flatter  half in energy. And on the metal side, nickel and zinc were the two big contributors. On the energy side, coal was  lower in price.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Strong volume growth in the sequentially six months, $307 million. The biggest, part about $280 million of that  was on the oil – was in energy, and most of that was the oil E&P. There was of course some coal expansion both in  Colombia as well as South Africa. On the cost side, there was savings; you can see $28 million positive on savings,  that's in nominal terms. In real terms, in fact, it is better because that includes some inflationary elements as well.  FX year-on-year – or period-on-period was largely immaterial. Extra depreciation on the back of the volume  growth that we spoke about.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: And the associate income, which includes the Xstrata side, that's where there's some sequential $253 million  down to keep a flat structure. The next variance you can see is the period-on-period to the first half of the last  year, which is quite a different period – quite a different pricing period; as you can see, $571 million reduction in  prices; $475 million of that was in fact metals. We've commented about the metals pricing environment being the  main driver of the industrial lower earnings. That's with nickel, you would have seen prices on average down 28%,  is higher zinc 15%, copper 14%. So, $475 million, metals affecting those operations. $90 million in energy. Coal, it  was a 20% reduction.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: On volume growth, $575 million fully covering the drop in prices. Strong volume growth at Kazzinc, which was on  the gold side. [indiscernible] (0:28:17) as much as nickel is a tough commodity that had a very good operational  production performance, record performance in fact in Q2. And on the energy side, volume very strong, there was  no oil production on the comparable first half 2011. So there's about $300 million E&P; volume growth in coal  was about [ph] $115 million (0:28:35).

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So with that, we have done a lot on South African coal in the last 12, 15 months. We've brought Clinton up from  Johannesburg. I think it's an area which is from a modeling and an understanding is quite narrow. So, we'll try  and see if we can upgrade all that.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. A quick run-down of South African coal; it's one of the newest areas in  Glencore, one of the newest growth areas in Glencore, which we've been building up for the last few years.  Basically, the next few slides from our perspective is just to try and give you a run-down of our vision of South  Africa, what we've been doing for the last few years down there and to give you some sort of perspective of what  we see for the future.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: So back in 2005, we teamed up with a prominent businessman, previously politician Cyril Ramaphosa to create a  Black Economic Empowerment Company, where previously Glencore owned 70%; we owned – Shanduka owned  30%, which is Cyril's company. And we decided we're going to try and as best we could consolidate some of the  industry in South Africa, where there were still some reasonable sized independent coal companies.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: And we set out on a task and we initially bought Shanduka Coal back in – we created Shanduka Coal, which  bought a number of smaller collieries back in 2005. That company produces approximately 6 million tons of coal  at the moment. And then over the years, we've managed to, let's say, opportunistically build up this company to  today which is approximately 27 million tons, as you can see I've got little pointer over there.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: So we started off with Shanduka Coal back in 2005. By 2009, we started negotiating with a company called  Umcebo Mining and we subsequently bought into that company, which gave us 43%. Cyril Ramaphosa also owns  approximately 35% of company Shanduka and there's one other outside shareholder in that company. And we've  split it up into two segments part of this – part of our South African coal assets being the Glencore controlled  assets and being the non- Glencore controlled assets, where we have a large minority stake in this [indiscernible]  (0:33:19) and I'll talk about it now.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: In South Africa, just to give a quick run-down, the market is pretty simple. You've got an export market, which is  basically out of RBCT, which is Richards Bay Coal Terminal. You've got a big local market for the power utility  called Eskom. They burn approximately 125 million tons. And then you have a residual domestic market, which is  the metals market, the paper markets, the sugar industry where they use coal from a domestic perspective, from a  heating perspective.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: So over these last seven years, we've accumulated this business, which has approximately 2.5 billion tons of  resources at the moment. All these resources are in the main coalfields. I've got a map and we will just give you a  little bit of an understanding of that. So today, at 27 million tons, and I'm just talking about the Glencore  controlled entities at the moment; at 27 million tons, we are the fifth biggest coal company excluding Xstrata in  South Africa. So it's quite a good footprint from where we stand, and it's – like I say, we've accumulated the three  companies that have various operations, cash-producing operations and resources to develop.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: What we like about South Africa really is the projects and what the growth is and what our potential is for South  Africa. The important thing about the coal industry – and when we get to the map, I'll explain to you, is that the  existing coalfields, which lie to the east of Johannesburg, about approximately 100 kilometers east of  Johannesburg, they are your main existing coalfields, which have been mined for the past 120 years. Those  resources are coming to the end of their useful life, a lot of them.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: The main resources in the country are up in the Waterberg, which is approximately 500 kilometers away. We,  through our acquisitions, have managed to still secure some strategic resources in the main coalfields very close to  our existing operations. In many instances, brownfields; in some instances, you could call them greenfields, but  they're 30 kilometers away, which means that our infrastructure that we have in South Africa can be easily used as  a base to develop these resources. And the reason why we wanted to develop the resources is the opportunities  that exist in South Africa, which the next three slides will explain to you.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: All these colored items are all Glencore resources that we have in the area; some of them developed, some of them  undeveloped. And as you can see, the distances are not that great. While you're looking at the map, if you look  somewhere down to the south, 600 kilometer south would be RBCT and 500 kilometers to the north would be the  Waterberg. And this is where we secure our resources. We have a central office located here in Middelburg, and  this is office that operates most of our coal mines.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: Okay. So now you're probably going to be asking why South Africa and why coal in South Africa, we see two main  fundamental opportunities in the country and we like to believe we are one of the first considering that some of  the other mining companies are not interested in expanding their operations in the country. We are interested in  expanding and I think we're going to hopefully be able to capitalize on this graph.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: This graph was presented in 2012 by Dan Marokane, who is the Head of Primary Energy of Eskom. It's a very  interesting graph, and we base a lot of our strategy on this graph, and I'll explain to you right now why. This graph  shows obviously the timeframe and the amount of tonnage that Eskom uses per annum. So currently, we're sitting  in 2012, Eskom is burning 125 million tons of normally low grade unwashed material, where you can actually  upgrade this material and export it; but for the main part, Eskom burn it on a raw basis.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: So what we show in here is the graph of what Eskom is going be required to burn over the next, say – well, it goes  all the away to 2040, but up to 2023 their burn ratio is going up. They've obviously got two new builds, Medupi  and Kusile, with massive cost overruns. But as a result, they will be coming online within the next five to seven  years. So we see Eskom be burning close to 160 million tons in order to sustain very close to 50,000 megawatts in  the country and obviously to sustain growth of the country.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: The problem comes in, in that the committed and contracted coal is falling approximately 40 million tons short by  2018. Now, to start-up any mine in South Africa, you need at least five years lead time. And any companies  wanting to start to take advantage of this gap would have had to have started now if they have the resources.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: So this is quite an interesting graph which Eskom is pretty open about to say, you know, we've got a shortfall, we  need to cover it, you know, who is going to make up these tons. Going back to our little graph here, hopefully,  some of these tons will come from there. We've allocated export and Eskom, as you can see, in all the projects. But  in fact, ultimately, if Eskom pay us the price, we have no problem in selling directly to them and we've made that  very clear to Eskom as well.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: The second part of the opportunity that we see is that the government has allocated ZAR300 billion to  and they've allocated a substantial amount to upgrading the rail of all the various commodities in the countries. So  you will see that iron ore is getting a certain amount of money, coal is getting a certain amount of money, the ports  are being upgraded, et cetera, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Clinton Ephron
texts.profession: Non-Executive Director, Optimum Coal Holdings Limited
texts.text: So as a result, we do believe that the Richards Bay Coal Line will go from approximately 70 million tons to over  100 million tons in a matter of 10 years. And as you can imagine, you have Eskom competing for the same coal  that's potentially being exported. So we have quite an interesting scenario developing in South Africa. We like to  believe that we're at the forefront of taking advantage of that, and that's basically the strategy behind what we  have done in South Africa in a nutshell.

texts.speaker: Chris Mahoney
texts.profession: Director-Agricultural Products Business Segment, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Just a few words now about the outlook for the second half of the year, because you probably read a bit about this  in the FT and various newspapers, but it is a very unique   and I think it deserves mention. The U.S. weather  staring in mid-May through June, through most of July and certainly through the first five or six days of August  has been amongst the worst years, the worst three or four years this century comparable to the dust-bowl years of  the mid-1930s.

texts.speaker: Chris Mahoney
texts.profession: Director-Agricultural Products Business Segment, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: As a result of that, the U.S. corn crop, which in May was estimated to be around about 380 million tons, is now  estimated – and this is the USDA, United States Department of Agriculture, is now estimated to be only 270  million tons. That estimate may still be high, it might be as low as 260 million, 265 million. Some months ago,  U.S. domestic consumption was estimated to be 300 million tons. With the crop of 376 million tons, these are the  estimates of May, the U.S. was expected to export about 50 million tons of corn and that would – since the  production exceeded consumption by 70 million tons odd, that would lead to a stock-build in the US.

texts.speaker: Chris Mahoney
texts.profession: Director-Agricultural Products Business Segment, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: That 50 million tons of corn compares to a total global seaborne trade in corn of about 85 million tons. So the U.S.  would supply 55% of all the corn traded seaborne wise in the world market. With the new production estimate of  270 million tons, that production estimate would not even cover the original domestic consumption estimate.

texts.speaker: Chris Mahoney
texts.profession: Director-Agricultural Products Business Segment, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: And you can see here that the United States Department of Agriculture, they have slashed the estimate – the U.S.  estimate of domestic consumption from 302 million down to 252 million. But that's a process that is yet to take  place. They've also cut exports from 48 million to 33 million. The rest of the world will have to make up the 50  million, that's assuming the U.S. can, in fact, export 33 million, which I think is debated.

texts.speaker: Chris Mahoney
texts.profession: Director-Agricultural Products Business Segment, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: This is a very unusual situation. We've had crop problems in the past. Notably in 2008, there was a wheat  problem. But I think we've seen nothing of the scale of this. One also has to remember that within this 300  million, domestic consumption of 300 million, 126 million of that goes to the ethanol industry in the U.S. So that's  currently mandated. And so when the USDA calls for domestic consumption to drop from 300 million to 250  million, at least for the moment the 126 million can't drop, because it's mandated.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: A big reason, we believe, we have positive growth on high assets. We have easy assets to develop, not difficult. We  do try to stay away from those large greenfield projects and emphasize on added opportunities to existing assets,  brownfield projects. You just heard Clinton, how we developed the coal business in South Africa. We saw  opportunities. Now, those aren't opportunities where we go out and we say, we want to get big the coal business.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So we will – then that's how – and if you look at Viterra, if you look across the commodity cycles, since we bought  Viterra, which is another interesting thing, anything, anyone bought in the last six to eight months has not been a  good investment. You see the other mining companies, some of the investments they've been hit hard with the  shale gas or the areas in certain – iron ore, whatever it is, has come off, so people are being hurt. But the one  commodity which in fact gone the other way is Viterra worth more today than it was six months ago.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Another expansion to show how Glencore operates the manganese business, we're fairly strong on the manganese  side of the business. But because a lot of the producers don't like always sell to traders the manganese ore, they  like to sell it to the end consumers, we devised a way and we were dealing with Vale about their manganese assets  and purchasing the assets in France and Norway, getting those smelters that allows us to purchase manganese ore  from all the producers around the world, now that we are a producer of ferro-manganese.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Now, that asset is a good example. We bought – both these two smelters, as I say, in Norway and France, what  does it give us? It gives us the opportunity to increase our manganese ore book to allow us to deal with every  producer around the world who now will sell to us because we are able to take it into our own smelters. Plus, in  the process, we get an off-take agreement from Vale at a price – top price agreement, whereby we get the follow of  the manganese ore from their operations to supply into these two smelters; plus on top of that, we get entire  marketing of their manganese ore book.

file: GLENL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 20August2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The energy sector of the company performed very well, in particular coal. Even with falling coal prices, the  marketing part of the business did very well and this is due, as we always talk about how the marketing division  operates and where money can be made where there are geographical arbitrages around the world, planning  opportunities and various ways to trade within the system where opportunities can be taken. And I think coal is a  good example of that. Even with falling coal prices, the trading part of the business performed very well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: What will also complicate things slightly going forward, and I think Paul and [ph] Martin (13:17 ) and Elisa on the  side will sort of provide both the basis and the means with which to analyze and look at those businesses going  forward. There were some changes in some JV of accounting going forward in respect of Xstrata's three big JVs  historically, or sort of combination projects. Down in South America, you've got Cerrejón on the coal side,  Antamina and Collahuasi with the respective partners. Y ou're very familiar with those operations.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: So hopefully, we provided everything that makes sense in the pack this morning. We've certainly attempted to. If  there's still areas that you wish to go through in further detail, please get hold of us. We have all the building  blocks and all the numbers to go into that. So these numbers, as we said, on a pro forma sense half year on half  year, revenue fairly stable. It's not a number we tend to focus on. We do in, obviously, other companies, because  it's so massively effected by the marketing part of the business, which is more of an overall gross income or  EBITDA business than necessarily what the revenue it's going to be influenced by, what was oil prices, what were  volumes doing that particular period.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: For where we are in the cycle, given trough-type earnings in coal, nickel and with the CapEx trajectory still going  through 2013, but then starting to materially decrease into 2014 and 2015, a 28.2% FFO net debt, we  feel is a good  position to be at the moment, and where we see trends in both leverage and in the relationship to cash flow over  the next 12 months to 18 months getting positive. We do have a few asset disposal processes, I'll talk about that  later on, a few non-core Viterra that we've announced a few and then clearly, where we end up on Las Bambas will  also be quite a – quite being able to move those numbers materially potentially as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The fact it itself is represented by multiple commodities and components within the copper, zinc, within  aluminum, within all the steel products area, it's been a more stable performer of Glencore's overall segments over  the years.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Good volume growth you've seen as well in the marketing and supportive demand conditions. Iron ore business  from that small base has also increased volumes, up 50% there, strong zinc volume growth as well coming through  the structure as well. The energy products, that was the big recovery from a tougher half-one 2012. Y ou've seen  that went up 43% both on coal and oil side, meaningfully contributing to that increase, and looking good on the  energy side. The agricultural side, as Ivan said, was the weakest spot clearly in 2013. But again, within the overall  portfolio, it's played a significant role in previous periods, and we would expect that to also support the business  going forward. It was a tough general environment, also exacerbated, and Chris is with us today, he can talk a little  bit more as to maybe some Q&A on that.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The main weakness was in the coal business, clearly, in the industrial side, maybe less weak than some may have  even envisaged, given that particular environment, but we saw declines of 32% and 59% respectively. Just given  the relative sizes between coal and oil, the oil business is growing in significance, it's a nice absolute value, but it  does get dwarfed currently within the overall energy spectrum. Oil was down a little bit, but wasn't enough to sort  of counteract what was happening clearly in the coal business as well. But again, positive stories on the production  side, Prodeco clearly delivering under its expansion. Unit cost savings there, we announced of 12% by virtue of  moving to direct loading as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: So a good performance in the Australian coal thermal, [ph] is (22:59) currently in a low priced environment also is  making headway, and at some point in time, that will be set up for positive earnings momentum and we'll allude  to a lot more of that on the Investor Day on the 10th of September.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Agriculture, very small part of the industrial and generally weak and lower processing margins. It's crushing, it's  biodiesel, it's sugar at the moment as well. At some point, that'll start heading in the other direction, but currently,  it's not going to be and neither move one way or another in a particular business. It's a small part of the business,  and generally it's there more to facilitate trade than there to derive standalone earnings.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: As we said on the – this is the industrial bridge on a pro forma. You can see price clearly the main impact between  2013 and 2012, $2.2 billion, of which a little over $1 billion of that was purely on coal, with prices at least in index  terms down anywhere between 10% and 15%, but our realized prices were more like 15% to 20%, be it in both the  coking and in the steam coal products as well. So that was $1 billion and then, $1.2 billion was on the metals side  with copper, $820,000 making up the full extent, with copper prices being down 7 %. But also some impacts on  zinc being felt, not through the zinc price itself, but some of the byproducts, particularly in silver and as it gets  extracted from some of the primary zinc and also copper producing some secondary gold as well impacting prices.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: But overall, even in this environment, where synergies was not really a feature, that $254 million net -net was a 2%  reduction, around 2% of the opening cost base, and that's net of the inflation. So that was all good. Most of it was,  in fact, coal related. Prodeco, we said delivered unit cost savings, but also the Australian portfolio. I think of all the  businesses that was part of both Glencore and the former Xstrata, particularly either to do with the merger coming  and the general coal environment that was the one that the coal team led from Sydney and looking at Australia  first, but other parts of their business started their rationalization cost reduction streamlining already towards  about September last year. So they've had a head start and some of that $254 million would have been delivered  through the coal business.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: FX contributed $334 million, essentially all South Africa, the rand impacting the energy side, which was – which  is coal that we have in South African, and the metals side, essentially the chrome business that we have down  there. The rand was about 16% weaker period-on-period. The Aussie, in fact, only really came down towards the  end of the quarter and we'll start feeling the benefits of that mo re over the second half. It's still averaged over  parity for the first six months of the year, almost similar to what it was the previous year.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: So, Aussie dollars definitely going to provide relief, and somewhat of a lag positive impact in earnings trajec tory  going forward as we look towards the second half. As Ivan alluded to between EBITDA and EBIT, we've got an  extra $500 million of depreciation, and of that, metals is $362 million of that and the copper is $229 million,  Africa copper, et cetera and South America. And the energy side is about $129 million of that, of which is all coal  through Prodeco and thermal coal in South Africa. The $7 9 million of other is some corporate savings, which  already manifested themselves during the first six months of the year. So you've seen the bridge there.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Now, that wasn't a number that that was in our thinking necessarily, it was just a number that said, you need to  start with this particular number. Separately, to that, clearly a comprehensive process was then conducted across  on a global basis, using external valuers and some arms and legs clearly to support that process. That's a  comprehensive process to almost rebuild up Xstrata's valuation from an accounting perspective from the bottom  up, look at the coal business, look at the copper, look at the nickel, look at their debt, look at mark-to-markets,  look at provisions, looking at tax. You've got to look at everything there, which we took the Q2 macro -environment  sentiment in commodities was more cautious and semi-bearish at that particular point in time.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Now clearly, and it's been a consistent stance within Glencore on the general both attitude, approach and  commitment to early stage greenfields on some of these things, so clearly that was an area where we were  conservative. But those are – they may well have their day again and their day in the sun. We've just taken the  conservative stance on those projects going forward.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The other – we got the diversification of the different commodities. None of the other mining companies or  trading companies has both the assets and the trading plus the diversification of the commod ities. We have the  metals, we have the oil side and we have the grain side and as demonstrated this first half, when grain is down,  metals is up, when oil – coal perform in a different manner also, so the diversification definitely works. As I say,  the commodities and the assets and the marketing part of the business.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: As I said earlier, the merger integration is tracking ahead of expectations. We are getting the benefits very quickly,  definitely on the marketing side of the business and as we said, when we're getting further into the corporate  overheads and looking closer at the assets and as Steve mentioned on the coal side, we've started getting quickly  into those assets and the cost savings have been fairly dramatic over there. And as I said , we will far exceed our  previous indicated $500 million figure, but we'll give further details on that on the 10th of September.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: And you know our policy regarding greenfield expansions and as to a certain amount of the write -downs Steve  mentioned were regarding the greenfield projects which were sitting on Xstrata's books. We know they're coming,  pushing those projects. We will keep them delayed, et cetera and maybe some time in the future, but we're in no  rush to develop any greenfield project. So I think the companies will position now going forward. And with that,  we open for any questions.

file: GLENL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 20August2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Okay, good morning. Welcome to the first half results. Today we've got a big team here. We have Tor Peterson, the  head of the Coal Marketing division; Alex Beard, the head of the Oil division; Peter Freyberg, the head of Coal  Operations; Daniel Maté, Zinc division; Kenny Ives, Nickel division; Andrew Caplan; Aluminum; and Telis  Mistakidis, the head of the Copper division. So when it comes to question and answers, they'll be available to  answer any of the questions.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: We have numerous organic growth opportunities to pursue when appropriate. Most of our growth opportunities  are brownfield expansions. We'll take you through details later on. And those brownfield expansions are easy  expansions against our existing operations and just add on to our existing operations. So the expansions, as we  always say, they don't create high risk as greenfield projects have. They're not these massive capital expansions in  new areas of the world where you have the risks and the cost overruns which the industry has experienced over  the past years. So they're simple, easy expansions, and we'll go ahead with these expansions if we believe they give  the right returns.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Sustainable development and governance, here is a slide to show how we're improving in this area. We've rolled  out SafeWork, which is starting now towards developing our coal division over the years and we rolled it out to the  rest of the group, and this is an area we are improving. We've got a lot of work to be done there. We still had 10  fatalities in the first half of 2014, but we are improving in that area. And the LTIFR [Lost Time Injury Frequency  Rate], as you can see, is improving considerably.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: We have become a member of ICMM [International Council on Mining and Metals] this year in April 2014, and  that was a full independent expert review. And Glencore, I'm happy to say, came out with flying colors and we  understand one of the best reviews they've done. So this is an area the company continues to work on.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: And the good thing about being a diversified operation is that it's very seldom to see everything firing on all  cylinders at any point in time. If we did have that, then energy clearly is historically both on the coal and the oil  side. That has been sort of up at those levels in years gone by. And at some point in time, you would see that back  at levels where we would see it being able to extract more out of the markets clearly as well. We have decent  market positions. We have a decent structure clearly in both coal where particularly we're a very large player; oil  significant business as well there. But lackluster market backdrop in terms of both volatility and weaker coal  markets nearly put some pressure on the Agri side.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The energy side of the business is very big in coal. But of course, coal numbers-wise is not contributing, and that's  what I would call a more neutral level, and a growing oil business as well clearly in the West African ups tream  portfolio, and we'll have a leg up going forward as we've taken over and look to integrate and control and run the  Caracal business of the Chad business going forward as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: On the Metals & Mining side, of course lower prices except nickel, so your mainstays of copper, zinc, and the  precious metals, not that we produce them in a primary sense, but they are significant byproduct contributors  both in the copper and the zinc operations, both gold and silver going anywhere between 16% and 20% on the  pricing.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Pleasing in this business as well, which we do make slightly more [ph] anneal (24:42) of now because I think it's  been ignored historically within Glencore's overall asset quality is that the EBITDA margin across the entire  mining business actually improved from 29% to 32%. Now that's the weighted average across copper  and zinc and  ferroalloys and nickel, et cetera. Copper is a little bit higher, zinc is a bit higher as well. But that weighted average  mining margin, if you look at the portfolio that we do have, starts exposing the fact that the assets that we have in  our portfolio in the commodity prices that existed during that period are very good quality assets. And Ivan will  talk to the cost structures that we have and even the improving cost structures that we're looking to implement  then.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Similarly, the EBITDA margin across the energy side was stable at 29%, notwithstanding coal prices that fell  anywhere between 15% and 20% and even higher on the coking coal side of things as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: This slide, which will be familiar to many of you as well, a common feature of most presentations for the mining,  shows the waterfall bridge. This is just on the industrial side between 2013 – 2014 for the first half. Y ou can see  the big hit clearly from pricing; a lot of it coming from the energy side, in fact, $657 million of that $980  million,  all of which was coal. So a big headwind coming from coal prices, they seem to have bottomed, stabilized,  improved a little bit in recent periods.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Tor [Peterson] no doubt is there either in a Q&A sense if we want to talk coal markets as well as some of the [ph]  imported (26:15) price. We've also got a few slides later on where we give our views on some supply/demand  parameters across different – at least in the current pricing environment, which shows favorable market  structures evolving over the next two to three years. We should see some pickup there and hopefully be able to  turn these negatives into positives in the coming years as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: So $980 million on price and the metals was the $323 million down. Of course, we had lower prices in copper ,  zinc, and the precious metals, positive from nickel coming in there with its average price. Higher and we should  even get more positive things because you still had at least in the first quarter 2013 nickel prices weren't too bad,  and then you had a dip and then they had come up a bit.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: These things would tie in pretty well to the commodity price and exchange rate sensitivity slide that we gave with  the full-year result where we showed what a 10% price movement does in copper and coal and currencies. You'd  be able to apply that and get pretty close to those numbers as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: And contributing to volume would have been the standout volume performances half and half, which was oil  where we saw some big increases both in Equatorial Guinea and Chad, so oil volume was about $83 million, coal  contributing $55 million on the volume side. And then on the metals about $274 million, and that was essentially  all copper, which had a 13% year-on-year increase in copper.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: And then $551 million represents about a 6.3% real cost reduction across the overall asset base as well. And that 's  coming from coal and oil a bit, which makes up the energy side, which is $296 million. And the metal side was  $255 million. Clearly, that captures some of the synergies from the Xstrata transaction. We put $1.9 billion in ex - marketing synergies. But of that $1.9 billion, it wasn't all operations. There were financing synergies. We've got a  slide later on there. It was about $200 million.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Some of the operating synergies period-on-period wouldn't be captured necessarily here because coal particularly  when we acquired Xstrata had a head start in terms of putting in their aggressive program around cost cutting that  didn't start June or July 2013. That very much started towards the end of 2012 as we were getting ready to close  on that particular transaction. So a lot of those costs already came through in coal in the first half 2013, so they're  a part of our number. Y ou won't necessarily see that coming through in a period-on-period movement over there.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: And there's also in terms of cost movements which we'll see those reverse as well, so that number would have even  been a bit higher but for a few operations. When you do go through an expansion phase at some oil operations, as  it staggers through, you will have to already scale up in terms of costs ahead of whe n the expansion currently  comes. So you'll actually be maintaining certain costs which we've got. Katanga and McArthur River are probably  two examples of that. We'd only then get the unit cost reductions as you then start delivering the volumes and  getting the economies of scale when it comes.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: So you do have periods, and we're just in that phase at the moment in a few operations where we've actually got  some cost increases without getting the volume efficiencies that come with that. And particularly, McArthur River  and Katanga would be two that would apply in that case. So the gross cost savings would have been a bit higher, a  few temporary extra costs as we expand the operations, which come off as we deliver those tonnes, which we will  be doing during the second half, and we'll talk about that later on as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: That $8.7 billion does represent the fact that there have been one or two ups and downs. Koniambo, which is a  slide later on, Kenny can talk about that. There is some additional CapEx as the ramp up was slower than one  might ordinarily have seen, so a bit of extra CapEx there. But that's been picked up through lower CapEx that we  found, annual savings that we've been able to achieve across some of the operations, notably in coal, and some of  their expansions are going pretty well and coming in less than original budgets as well.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Balance sheet, as Steve has said, is repositioned much stronger, where we are now BBB. And we also have a  strong, [ph] lumpy, dual (42:12) growth projects. Now we do have a strong pipeline of growth projects. I will point  you to them later. But once again, all the brownfield projects we talk about, they're not the difficult mess of capital  greenfield projects. They're simple add-on brownfield projects which we know we can execute. We know they're  going to give the right returns, and we'll go ahead with them once we are certain they give us the right returns.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The earning power of the marketing business has been rebased, as I said earlier. We're now between the $2.7  billion to $3.7 billion. And once again, we proved this is a very sustainable long-term business and continues to  grow, and we even expect it to grow further with the further brownfield projects where we get the advantages on  the marketing and the blending and all the other benefits we get by owning the assets and they add on in the  marketing side, which was what we can do with them, whether they're smelters, whether they're mines, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: We also, as we said, if we can fund acquisitions which make sense and give us the right returns, we will do them.  And as proven, we did do $2.5 billion of acquisitions we believe which meet the hurdle rates we've got in the  company. We did do the Caracal acquisition. We expanded our shareholding in Mutanda. We bought out the  partner and we also did opportunistically Rio was selling their claim on coal assets. Together with a partne r we  bought that, which gives us great returns.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: We've moved as much – most of our assets are first quartile. We've managed them well. They're all big assets.  Some of them are big long-life assets. And as you look at the real key, most of our assets are all sitting in first  quartile. Ferrochrome has always been there. Thermal coal is one of the better, much lower quartile, and gives the  biggest margins out of all the other coal companies which are out there. Zinc, we're moving towards first quartile  with the McArthur River expansion, and George Fisher we're there. Copper, with all the copper operation in the  Congo kicking in, we're one of the lowest cost producers there because of the high grades of copper being  produced within that area. And nickel, eventually when Koniambo kicks in, we'll move towards that area. So we  really believe we've got the assets, good assets and in the right places.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: If you look at the demand slide, there's one towards the back. On all the commodities, demand is there. The ones  with the problem is where we've killed the supercycle because we've oversupplied into the market and production  has gone up. We know the commodities, I know is towards the bottom end. Why, because I think 25% of the  world's iron ore, new iron ore production is coming 25% over the next four years. So we are oversupplying the  market, and that's what's killing the supercycle.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: But the fact that the supercycle is there is not the – it is there, the demand is there. It's a matter of what people are  going to do about supply. So we believe in the commodities in which we are. There's no new big supply. And as I  said earlier, in a commodity such as zinc, it's not a matter of increased supply, it's a matter of decreased supply  even though you have the increase in demand occurring in those commodities.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: If you look at our growth pipeline, as I said, no greenfield, easy brownfield expansion, some are commissionin g  the ones which we see in 2014, which we spoken about. 2013, we've got Nkana Synclinorium. We've got the DRC  Power, where we're going to ensure that we get the power. We've got the expansion in Czech, which we'll talk  about, as Steve says, towards the end of the year, showing exactly what we're doing in Czech. But the Krim  expansion, those are there; those are going to add more growth. Mopani Deeps is happening in 2016.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: More growth, as we said, we're going ahead with the small iron ore project in Mauritania, 7 million tonnes, which  is a brownfield expansion because we're using the rail line and the port of SNIM, the existing producer, the  government producer. It's an easy expansion, very little risk there, not a high capital cost. It will run about $800  million – $900 million.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: In coal, we have the expansions. And as I said in oil, easy brownfield expansions around Chad, the development  over there, and the Diega Block in Equatorial Guinea, so these are expansions which the company can do. And  depending upon what returns, we will only go ahead with them.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Are we going to go and do greenfield, brownfield, greenfield projects? Y ou know our feeling about them.  Brownfield, will we go ahead with them? If they make economic sense; if they don't, we don't need to repl ace a  depleting asset. I've heard this story in the mining industry. You have to replace a depleting asset, otherwise your  business gets smaller. We don't mind. If the asset depletes and we don't get the right return in replacing it, no  need to expand. If your business gets smaller, what will you do, kick out cash back to the shareholders.

file: GLENL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 19August2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Fortunately, as I've said on the energy side, very strong earnings. On the marketing, as we said last year, the  structure in the oil side was very – it was good and favorable for our business. And therefore, we were able to  increase the marketing part and the oil in the first half. And hopefully, that will continue well into the second half.  Coal was down because of the challenging markets we've add in coal. We've seen what the markets have done;  reduction in the Chinese imports of coal. Fortunately, we have had a reduction in the exports from Indonesia, but  still a challenging market.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Very important is reducing the CapEx of the company under this environment. A lot of it comes anyway with  devaluations of currencies, et cetera, lower cost of material input. So, a lot of it happens anyway. A big amount, we  reduced CapEx in operations, especially in oil in Chad, et cetera. We don't need to spend more CapEx.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: On sustainability and governance of the company, very important. We treat this as an important part of our  business. And unfortunately, we had eight fatalities up-to-date. This is by halfway through August. Last year, we  had 16 fatalities and we continue working very hard in this area. And you can see on our LTIFRs, we've reduced  considerably down to 1.34, which is a 51% reduction.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: If we go back to 2012, 2013, it was around $13 billion. So, you can just see where those numbers have come from  those sort of levels. And things are standing around production levels. And some of the growth in the CapEx that  Ivan alluded to is really restricted to a few key areas primarily in copper and zinc, and a few sort of coal  expansions and sort of reserve life that we'll see as well later on in terms of the expansion CapEx underpinning the  $5 billion. So, that number is coming down, makes the business, again, more predictable, more manageable, more  in control. No particular nuisance around our neck as we manage the cash flow trajectory.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Clearly an aspect of Glencore that's more unique than some other pure-play industrial mining companies, oil  companies that you may see is that working capital element, the marketing element, where we're showing –  there's always been, if you like, a theoretical sense that there is this big unwind that can potentially happen. There  is working capital. There is a natural hedge, if you like, in a down cycle where this business is going to release  working capital. It's going to increase liquidity. It's going to lower leverage ratios. And I think during this  particular period, there's another evidence of that coming through. There was, of course, some natural release of  working capital both in a non-RMI and RMI sense just in the lower price environment, be it oil, coal, copper, zinc,  et cetera.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: But we'd be one of the few companies I think out there in this general natural resource environment to have  metals commitments, paid its CapEx, paid its dividends, funded interest and tax, and still be delevering at $1  billion during this period and looking forward. So, our initiatives, still be delevering happening by the end of 2015.  And we've set ourselves that $27 billion target at the end of 2016 as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: In terms of the industrial part of the business, of course, our pricing environment was fairly brutal in many  commodities from the start of the year to June. We're seeing price reductions up to 40% in some commodities, be  it oil for us, small exposure there; iron ore 40%-something, no exposure there. Some of our key commodities;  copper, down 17% on average; and on the coal business, sort of 15% to 20%, depending which grade, quality and  function we're talking about as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, the hit overall 29% EBITDA on the industrial part of the business, the big impact, just given our overall scale  and size, is clearly in copper and nickel a little bit as well as zinc, earnings generally flat around production  growth. Zinc price less affected as well. You've also got by-product price reductions where we've got quite  significant silver and gold, which also saw price reductions coming out of many of our businesses as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And Alumbrera is a bit all over the place at the moment as they approach end-of-life in terms of grades and  volatilities and the likes. But that was well flagged at our Investor Day last year in terms of copper. The effect on  the energy side was more muted, having had a pretty low base to begin with. So, notwithstanding 15% to 20%  price reductions, the effect on coal was only down 14% given the base itself and just given the general cost  reductions that we're seeing across our own base due to efficiencies, due to currencies, due to oil price reductions,  et cetera, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, we'll show – if we look at the slide over here, looking at the EBITDA level, which, of course, is everyone's focus,  as opposed to EBIT and net income, it's all about cash flow generation and the quality of margins, if you like. We  did see a 29% contraction in industrial EBITDA, $4.8 billion to $3.4 billion. The biggest pricing, of course, on the  biggest sensitivity on the pricing side, $900 million of that $2.3 billion was in energy, $600 million coal, about  $300 million in oil. And the metals $1.4 billion, bringing up the balance there, which copper you would expect  would have been the biggest. We've shown some sensitivities historically around a 10% movement in copper being  sort of $1 billion, $1.2 billion. So, 14% for six months, there was a price [indiscernible] (22:07) about $800 million  of that was just in copper, of course; I mean, nickel and the likes as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Volume fairly muted during this particular period; would have been a bit higher. Part of it was slamming the  brakes on in particularly coal through the $15 million production cuts. Now, that's sort of taking time to work its  way through the system but that would have had an impact. And oil itself could have been higher. There still was  oil volume growth, but it would otherwise have even been a little bit higher.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And then, you had certain copper and zinc and – so, that was generally pretty flat. We would see, as we look  towards both second half, and Ivan will talk about a slide later on in terms of our trajectory, in terms of unit cost  both in – so, we've got some volume growth coming in copper and zinc in particular. And we've got some positive  unit cost projections as we look towards second half of 2015 and also full year 2016 that's going to help, clearly, in  volume. It's going to help in cost. There's also the $400 million of cost reductions we've talked about as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, there's a lot of that stuff that's obviously maturing. $10.5 billion is the available liquidity at the moment. And  around the portfolio, we'll also sort of keep managing around the edges in terms of non-core assets and sale of  assets, releasing capital that way, that just doesn't fit into greenfields and/or other geographical territories. You  saw the $300 million or so in disposal we announced the other day in respect of Tampakan and Falcondo as well.  So, that all contributes as well towards that net debt reduction.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: The good thing about us on the copper side and as we've indicated here, our C1 cost is all coming down as we  expand our various operations in Katanga, Mutanda and Mopani, get going with the new [ph] TARP process we  have in place. During 2015, you'll see our copper cost of $1.42 per pound going down in 2016, down to $1.38 per  pound.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: A big part of that also is Katanga. Now that we've – we've decided that we're going to leach the material at the  plant at the Katanga operation to split the sulfides and the oxides. We've now approved the project. The project is  already in place. And it will come into action, we'll start production in early 2017, late 2016, and that will definitely  push down our cost and, therefore, we will also get additional production. We said during the second half of this  year, we've given the range, but we should increase 38,000 tonnes to 88,000 tonnes of copper production at those  operations.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: So, looking very good. Definitely lowest quartile. Some of our operations, we believe, definitely lower so second  lowest cost producers in the world. We have high grades of copper in the Congo, the highest grades of copper. So,  we'll always be competitive in those areas.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: On the zinc side, once again, we all know the supply of zinc is very tight. We have two major operations shutting  down, Century and Lisheen, this year. So, therefore, once again, no new supply. We are the only – increasing  because we got McArthur River coming into production – I mean, increasing its production. And therefore, we're  growing – we will have an additional 59,000 tonnes to 109,000 tonnes in the second half of the year versus the  first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: And as you see, our costs are coming down. We're going from $0.55 per pound down to $0.45 per pound in 2016,  also making us the leading low-cost producer of zinc in the world. So, these assets, once again, also first quartile  assets.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Coal, the difficult one. Supply, no new supply really coming in the world except in China. We all know that China's  imports have decreased considerably, going from 200 million tonnes, going potentially down to 130 million  tonnes this year, and that has caused a bit of pressure. But the good thing about coal that has happened is we had  less supply in Indonesia. The Indonesian exports have reduced considerably from 425 million tonnes, I think  roundabout to 360 million tonnes, 370 million tonnes this year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: However, good with our side, we produced a higher-quality coal. We produced a better product. We're not  competing with the lower quality coming from Indonesia. But our costs have gone that we still are – we are in the  lowest quartile here in the coal side, $44 per ton in 2015. We believe if currency stay as they are today, in 2016  we'll drop our production cost down to $40 per ton.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: So if you look at all our commodities, if we talk about nickel there, our C1 cost right now down to $3.10 per pound,  dropping slightly next year, down to $3 per pound. Koniambo is still our problematic asset, but we got two groups  around the problem. We are rebuilding Line 1. We're rebuilding the furnaces. There's a slide on it giving the  details of it. Kenny can talk on them in more detail about it if you need more detail.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: So, we got something there. We can be cautious how we expand that operation and when we take it to 50,000  tonnes and what we do.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Deliver volumes for the remaining projects that we have, I've discussed Katanga. Important, we know what we're  going to do in Katanga to get it to the 300,000 metric tonnes, to now at least 300,000 metric tonnes production.  We have the solutions. We will get there by early 2017. When the leaching comes into place, we'll reach that.

file: GLENL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 24August2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: We're pleased to say during this tough commodity environment, we have worked very hard on reducing our  operational cost at all our operations around the world and we're proud of our drop in our production cost. And as  you will see, we all definitely have mines in the lowest quartile, Tier 1 good assets. And today, we're producing  copper all-in costs at $0.97, and Steve will take you through the actual cost structure of our copper division later  on.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: We're producing zinc at negative $0.03 if we take the gold created; excluding the gold created, at $0.15; and  nickel at $2.46; and thermal coal at $37. And this definitely is a unique cost structure of the company.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: But if you take oil and coal combined, at these sort of levels, it's still performing sort of below sort of historical  averages for us. And we'd expect some improvements across that segment going forward. So, a pleasing  performance within the annualized range and where we expect, and particularly, agricultural, we expect a strong  second half performance as we move forward.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The energy side of the business made up of our upstream coal and oil businesses was impacted by much lower  prices, particularly in Q1. We have seen, both in coal and oil, we have seen some strong sequential  improvements each month, in fact, since March. So, we expect that business to have troughed in terms of  earnings going forward.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: What is worth just noting here in terms of the energy business just on the coal side and you would have noticed in  the second half of the year, in the second quarter of 2016, once we've seen already a strong replacement in coal  prices from Q1, we saw a strong flattening in the curve. So, the forward margin environment was looking good.  Our cost structure, we were suddenly preserving and protecting and locking in some strong cash flows. We did  lock in and hedged pricing of about 15 million tonnes of our coal just out for the next 12 months. So, that's the six  months ended December 2016 and the first half of 2017. It's still very good margins for us.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
