texts.text: There might be a bit of opportunity cost in having taken some of those hedges through the April to May period or  so. And you can see in our accounts, on those derivative contracts, we have reported a mark-to-market on those  of $395 million, which is some potential opportunity cost. Net-net, we'll still be ahead because there's still a lot of  unsold tonnage. But assuming prices of coal as they might have been at the end of June at $395 million is  obviously staged and staggered over the second half 2016, first half 2017. So, split the difference there, you'd  have a potential $200 million impact on the overall group EBITDA by virtue of having hedged some of those future  sales.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And we felt it was prudent to do back in Q2, we were clearly wanting to ensure we derisk the debt reduction  program that we locked in the free cash flow that we expected over the next 12 months, and that's certainly the  case. Because where we stand at the moment, we've seen a pickup, we've seen Chinese government action in  terms of coal domestic reduction. Prices have increased, but there's always some nervousness that maybe it  comes back.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The agricultural side as well, it's a small business for us, but again, a stronger second half performance is what  we expect quite significantly on the back of improved processing margins, particularly in Europe, both in crushing  and the biodiesel environment.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: That $720 million, you can see real cost reductions through lower fuel and energy costs, operational efficiencies,  restructuring, procurement, a whole range of things, that's a very strong performance, quite a big percentage  across overall industrial base.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: In terms of the pricing impact of a little over $2 billion, $1.25 billion was in metals. Copper down 21% or so year- on-year average price, it was $550 million of that $1.25 billion and $800 million impact in the other commodity,  $675 million of which was coal.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: In a volume sense, we actually improved margins notwithstanding that the overall weighted average margin of  Glencore was broadly flat, we were able to increase where there's very strong variable and margin contributions.  So, Antapaccay actually increased in copper production, 21%. Alumbrera, through a sort of more period where  they've been going through, there was a significant variability in gold. But gold was actually up 46%, very strong  contributions there. And Mutanda over in Africa, performing very well in copper, improved its cobalt production, it's  a big byproduct there, 73% increase in cobalt production to 10,900 tonnes there as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The zinc business, of course, as well has with our Kazzinc operation has a lot of gold, including a primary gold  mine coming through, which is treated for unit cost purposes of byproduct that in fact goes into negative from a  primary zinc perspective, we've included those gold credits, or $0.15 excluding it, and again a very good first half  zinc performance of $770 million.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And the thermal coal business as well, overall, we were looking at an $8 per tonne margin is what it delivered,  $500 million of EBITDA. And we've shown how that off a GC NEWC, $51 with a blended discount of $45 showing.  That's all the domestic tonnes and a build of some coking margin in there. We were $8 a tonne of margin coming  through that particular business as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The zinc business will be a touch of a $2 billion at spot prices. And nickel will be a touch of a $400 million. The  coal at spot prices today with an $18 per tonne margin is around $2.2 billion. And the various other businesses of  Glencore net out to about $100 million, less some oil, less the ferroalloys, less some overhead, a bit of agri or so.  So, that's $7.7 billion spot on the industrial side.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Some of the reductions in CapEx has clearly come from the reduced spending profile with the limited expansions,  the lower sustaining CapEx through the proactive supply reductions that we've made as well. That's across  copper, zinc, lead, coal, oil. And the same factors that have led to OpEx savings also seen earlier have also  featuring some of the CapEx savings, FX support, and just the general overall procurement benefits that flow  through the business.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And of course, the GRail process, where we own fleets and operations around our haulage of coal down in the  Hunter Valley. We're not necessarily a natural owner of those assets. So, there is a process underway, all of  which could be announced and concluded potentially before the end of the year. So, that's it in terms of asset  disposals. I think we've made some very good progress there. None of which – and all of which is focused around  more than noncore areas. And none of which changes the prospect, the profile, the platform, the franchise of  Glencore going forward.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: We are supported by a very good set of assets, Tier 1 assets. And as you can see, we've worked extremely hard  to cut the costs across the board of all our assets, and we're now really in the lowest quartile. Steve took you  through details of where we're producing copper at an all-in cost of $0.96. And zinc, as I say, negative $0.03 if we  take the gold credit. Excluding the gold credit, we'll average for the year around about $0.18.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Thermal coal will be around about $39, and nickel at $0.0273. So, we're in a very strong position on the cost  curve. And at current commodity prices, all our assets generate very good free cash flow. As we said earlier, we'll  generate around about $4.5 billion including the trading business.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: And as Steve said, the diversity of the marketing business really helps. And if we have a lower oil – 2015 oil had  very good results. 2016 oil and coal not as good as 2015. However, the metals is performing very well during  2016. And as Steve said, the ags, we should have a much better second half, but the diversity of having the  agricultural, the oil business, and the metal business really helps.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: As we said before, there is a lot of growth optionality within our business. We have reduced production. It was  well documented, advised last year. We cut 300,000 tonnes of copper out of our capacity; 500,000 tonnes of zinc;  100,000 tonnes of lead; and 15 million tonnes of thermal coal. This can be brought online if and when we wish.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: The copper is a bit restrained towards when we finish the production profile and the upgrade of Katanga and the  sinking of the three new shafts at Mopani. This will occur during – they will come back on stream during 2018.  Katanga towards the first half of 2018 and Mopani will be ramped up third quarter 2018. And that's in line with our  strategy. We delayed the CapEx expenditure there. We had a few progress of that to import equipment into the  DRC. But that is comfortable with when we'd like to bring this copper back into the market looking at the supply - demand profile.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: The same relates to our zinc. When we will bring it back? We will monitor very closely the supply -demand profile  like we did when we pulled it back that we felt that it was the right time to [ph] either (39:52) leave the material in  the ground and not dig it out with lower zinc prices, and at the right time where we believe supply-demand justifies  bringing it back into the market, we'll do the same day.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: So, that thermal coal, the same relates to that. We're closely monitoring what goes on in China and how the  profile is of the production pullbacks in China, and the 265-day work weeks, which they're putting in there, which  has helped the imports of coal into China. And we'll closely monitor what the Chinese do on that side, demand  around the world, what's happening on the supply, and then we'll decide when we bring back further coal  production. But we'll be very cautious on that and we don't want to bring back the production, which will have a  negative effect on the market.

file: GLENL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 10August2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Naturally, these results are underpinned by stronger commodity prices and higher margins, which we have  achieved based on the higher commodity prices period on period. And as you can see, if you look at the various  commodity prices, copper is up 22%, cobalt up 109%, zinc up 49%, and thermal coal realizations up 50% to 70%  within the same period last year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The company, once again, has proven that the reduction of the cost structures across the board of our assets has  been maintained during 2017, and we continue pushing the cost structures across these Tier 1 assets. And as  you will see, our costs are extremely low across the range of the commodities, copper, where we're producing  copper at $0.88 per pound; zinc at negative $0.09 per pound, if we take the gold credits against it; and nickel at  $2.40 per pound; and thermal coal $45 which was giving a significant margins around about $32. So, once again,  proves the strength of our asset base and the quality of our assets, whereby we are able to produce at these  extremely low costs.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: It's worth noting just for coal at the moment, because it's a commodity that's maybe less influenced, as in metals,  by the spot price from time to time. There is collection of longer-term fixed price contracts. There'll be quality  discounts. You've also got a curve currently that's reasonably backwardated. We've been quite conservative in  the projected margin within our coal business. You can see we've got page 22, we've put a margin of $31 a ton,  which is based on – of a Newcastle, more of a forward curve scenario looking into Cal 2018 of around $83 of the  Newcastle with an adjustment of $6.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: If we had to really use the spot price today for Newcastle in coal, which is a very strong in the sort of mid-90s, you  would add – if that was to stay flat, there was a backwardated curve, the coal business would increase by well  over $1 billion in terms of a typical spot analysis. But we are being conservative there, reflecting the  backwardated curve and reflecting some of the quality adjustments and the timing [ph] there (9:42).

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, with all the commodities, coal is more looking at where we see the full year 2017 rolling out in terms of the  Coal earnings at about $4.1 billion. So, we have the appendixes there and I'd certainly encourage to work through  those.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: On the industrial part, if we go over to page 10 and some of the increases in waterfalls that we provide from  period to period, so that's up 95% to $5.3 billion with strong increases both on the energy side and the metal side.  The margins itself, EBITDA margins across the mining side of metals, you can see on the right side, that's up from  28% to 38%. I'm sure you'll see that plot extremely favorable against the peer analysis in terms of margin that  reflects the low-cost structure and the robustness of that particular business. Similarly, the coal mining margins  moved up from 17% to 41%.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: If we look at some of the variances as to going $2.7 billion up to $5.3 billion, of course, pricing was the major  impact there, contributing a $3.5 billion positive variance. That's made up about half and half between the metals  and the energy; $1.75 billion, $1.75 billion, making up the $3.5 billion. If we break that through on the coal side,  $1.75 billion. That's with realizations on thermal coals, as you'd be aware, we have exposure to both Atlantic and  Pacific. We've got Colombian origin. We've got South Africa, and we've got new Newcastle origin, different quality  [ph] brands (14:38). But our thermal coal realizations, even including domestic, were up between 50% and 70%.  And our coking coal realizations, that semi-soft and hard coking, were more than double from the corresponding  period. So, that was up $1.75 billion.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: On the metal side, $1.75 billion as well; $0.8 billion coming through the copper industrial business, which is  supported by both copper and cobalt itself as a significant byproduct; cobalt up 109%, copper up 22%. Zinc was  up $0.5 billion on the basis of a zinc price up 49%. $0.3 billion increase in the ferroalloys business with higher  realizations on the chrome business, and a little bit on the other side of that business. So, the key variance, as  you would expect, was price. There has been some minor cost, FX and inflation adjustments the other way within  the volume variance, a little bit in the copper business, where there's some variability in end-of-life volumes and  costs related to Alumbrera, which has got a short mine life left now. So, that had a volume as well at 17,000 tonne  reduction or 45% from the first half 2016.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: We've noted also some lower African copper volumes, 19,000 tonnes, primarily weather-related there to do with  Mutanda. And a smaller effect as well, you'd recall we sold 30% of Ernest Henry business in November last year  that also took out about 7,000 tonnes of copper, which would have contributed somewhat there. And some of the  oilfield depletion as well, which would have contributed a volume variance in terms of contribution there.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: On the cost side, we've seen some higher costs there to do with grades at Antapaccay, mostly temporary there.  That should pick up as we move forward. The coal portfolio mix as well, it doesn't come at a margin, but  sometimes you'll have higher costs, depending on your mix of coking and thermal. And expansions as well as  increases in some JVs that we had at Newlands, Collinsville, which we acquired the 45% of those assets we  didn't own last year. And there has been a slight uptick in some of the more passive energy-related costs that  have come through. You have seen Brent up 29%. We're a big field consumer in the diesel side of our mining  operations as well. And a little bit in Kazzinc, which has a mix of hydro and normal grid power, there was less  hydro draw, which is a much cheaper part. So, there was a bit of cost variance coming through there.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, there's full transparency around this. So, actual cash cost that can derive the fully-loaded built-up EBITDA  cash flow generation. So, it's including all the mining costs, all the freight costs, the treatment charges, the  smelting, and the entire costs of the business as opposed to some that you might be more familiar with the sort of  C1 cost definition. This is much more fully loaded in terms of building up the cash costs.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Within the copper business, you can see six months ago in February, we gave guidance of $0.89; for the first half,  we've come in at $0.88; and for full year, we're now dropping to $0.86. Some of that clearly helped by the cobalt  byproducts given the price elevation there. If you looked out at the nickel business, we guided towards $2.48,  that's coming at $2.40, so good cost control generally despite some FX appreciation on the – or weakness on the  dollar and some fuel-related increases, and a little bit in some volume contraction. Again, nickel business enjoys  byproduct credits through copper and cobalt coming out of both Canada and Australia. For the full year, we're  expecting cost to go down to $2.13.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And the coal business, a very pleasing overall cost performance there, $44, you can see $45, actual $46  guidance. You have had the more potential headline pressure coming in cost of the coal business, given our  various structures, you have royalties linked to prices which have been very strong. You've got fuel-related costs  and you've had currencies, strengthening Australian dollar, South African as well as Colombian peso. So, they've  been able to hold costs fairly well with some productivity improvements. We highlighted about $300 million  targeted cost reductions through the coal business at the end of last year. That's about a two-year project and  that's being delivered through the system, and that's the margin of $28 was guided, we've come in $32, $31 or so  for the full year as well. But in a true spot scenario, that would be much higher given the strength in coal prices  that we're seeing at the moment.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: If we move to page 14, you can see the capital allocation wheel, which we introduced December last year and  covers the distribution policy that was introduced and how we're applying that both through 2016 and into 2017  and 2018. Maybe if we just go through the – at the top right, the green part of the circle and the priority clearly to  maintain a strong BBB/Baa, which has been signaled and it's been a priority throughout the business. We are at  BBB flat today with positive outlook from S&P, and Baa2 for Moody's. We think the trajectory and the strength of  the business is both consistent with financial policy, hopefully, moving up towards the upper band of that.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: As we are aware, today, China has a GDP per capita around about $8,000 to $9,000. And as they move along the  curve and towards the United States or where we got to a around about $60,000, you got more towards early  cycle, late cycle commodities. So, what we talk about, you'll see on the slide, on the right, we talk about early  cycle commodities is naturally iron ore, coking coal, and manganese; mid-cycle commodities, copper, zinc, nickel,  aluminum and lead; and late cycle, cobalt, oil, gas, thermal coal and agricultural products.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, we believe Glencore is well set up for these late, early cycle commodities what we call Tier 1 commodities  moving towards coal, agricultural products, copper, zinc, et cetera. So, that bodes well for us in the future, and we  should see strength in demand for those commodities as economies grow towards the later cycle.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: But what is also good is we haven't seen a supply reaction from the mining companies. As you are aware, with  the tough times that we've all been through since the 2015 drop in commodity prices, not many of the producers  have big supply projects coming forward. So, what we see with this demand growth and with the PMIs growing in  all these different zones across the world where everyone synchronize, we will need more demand for  commodities, but the supply growth is being limited and greenfields are not on the drawing boards of many of the  mining companies and there's limited brownfield opportunities to increase production. So, this definitely bodes  well for commodity prices going forward.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We talk about in Glencore, which is good for us, we have the greening of the global economy, which is  underpinned by policies to curb greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution, and this is definitely being led by the  electric vehicle phenomenon which is occurring today. We've done a slide to show the amount of nickel, copper,  and cobalt, which is utilized in electric vehicles going forward and amount that has to be utilized; copper, 50  kilograms to 75 kilograms; nickel, 40 kilograms to 50 kilograms; and cobalt, 5 kilograms to 15 kilograms. That  displays what is being utilized in the batteries.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, if you take electric vehicles today, the amount of cars which are produced today, today we only have about 2  million electric vehicles being produced in 2016. But you can take various different scenarios. But people talk  about trying to have 30% electric vehicles by the year 2030. Just looking at those figures, they're phenomenal,  because today you produce 87 million cars a year, that would indicate around about 26 million electric vehicles  being produced in the year 2030.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, to give you an idea, that would require annually around about, if you don't even take the charging points and  the requirement of copper for the charging points, just the battery alone, you're talking about another 2 million  tonnes of copper being produced per annum. You talk around about 1.2 million tonnes of nickel being produced  per annum. And we all know what – today we only produce around about 2.1 million tonnes of nickel per annum.  So, really, if this does occur, you need another 1.2 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The same, if you look at cobalt today, you will require around about that amount of electric vehicles being  produced, 26 million vehicles, you need around about an extra 260,000 tonnes of cobalt per annum. Noting today,  the world only produces 100,000 tonnes of cobalt. So, this is a phenomenon that whether we believe 30% electric  vehicles are up, but even if you take it lower, 20% and people have different scenarios out there, it definitely will  have a major effect on nickel, copper and cobalt prices, and the amount of production that the world's going to  need.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Looking further, as I've said, we have Tier 1 assets, and that is well demonstrated by our cost profile. Steve has  taken you through the cost profile of our commodities, copper where we're producing at $0.86 per pound; zinc  where we are, nickel where we are very low-cost producer of thermal coal, where we have relatively high margins  at current commodity prices. So, we're really well positioned with our asset base, long-term asset reserves and  very low-cost producer.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We talked about the right mix of commodities, which I've just mentioned earlier. We believe we have the right mix;  copper, coal, and nickel, very important in the areas of electric vehicle, but also the late-cycle-type commodities.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: If you look at, going forward, the growth prospects the company has without entering into greenfield expansions,  we have a copper profile where we talk about the extra 400,000 tonnes we'll be producing over the next two  years. We have Katanga, which will come in operation during 2018, 150,000 tonnes of copper in 2018, plus  another 150,000 tonnes coming from Katanga in 2019, being a 300,000-tonne producer, which will also produce  around about 20,000 tonnes of cobalt when it's in full production.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: And then, we have Mopani, which these shafts Steve spoke about, and the concentrator will be completed at the  end of 2018 and therefore bring in around about 80,000 tonnes to 100,000 tonnes of more copper during 2019.  We have our zinc assets, which you are well aware. During the low zinc price, we put them on care and  maintenance and we'll bring them up at the right point in the cycle when we believe is the right time. And it will not  cause a negative effect on the zinc price when it comes into production. But there, we have around about 500,000  tonnes of zinc to bring back on line.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Plus, around a lot of our assets where brownfield expansions which we could bring on cheaply without big capital  expenditure and without getting a surprise on cost and time factor as you do get towards greenfield type  operations. So, we have a lot of significant growth prospects around our existing assets without having to enter  into building a new greenfield mine.

file: GLENL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 8August2018 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Copper, our cost of production is down at $0.88 per pound; zinc, negative $0.11 after by-product credits; nickel,  $1.77; and the coal margin is round about $35 with the higher coal prices around the world.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The copper and zinc mine costs are higher than the initial financial guidance, which we gave early on in the year.  And that is basically due to the lower by-product credits which we're getting from some of the commodities where  we get the by-product credits. And, also, there is some modest energy cost inflation. However, this is helped by  weighted production during the second half of the year, and Steve will take you through the costs later on in the  second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, jumping to page 7 then where we – slides that will mostly be familiar to you. We just show the period-on- period performance in the Marketing part of the business, overall a 12% increase. The two – Metals and minerals  continues to be the key engine room of the firm, with a 17% increase, generally supportive market conditions, as  we've said, with also an overall increase in volumes handled. We show the volumes handled within the detailed  part of the financial statements. And you'll see both in the oil and copper, zinc, ferroalloys and iron ore, we've  seen volumes increase by generally greater than 20% and up to 50% in the iron ore business during the period as  well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Energy products, up 23%. That's made up of coal and oil as well, improvements we've said period over period in  both those commodities, which shows the strength of franchise as well. The weaker part of the slide just for that  particular period was obviously the base and the materiality is much less, but we've seen a decline period-on- period in the Agricultural business. We've attributed quite a big portion of that to the wheat crops in Argentina and  Australia in particular where we have both procurement and handling businesses that do depend on volumes, as  well as processing margin depending on the domestic crops as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And with the commissioning of train 1 of the whole ore leach project in December last year, that did produce  63,000 tonnes of copper and even in Q2 alone, I think it was around 35,000 tonnes, which is already almost  running at the 150,000 tonne run rate. And we've confirmed guidance of 150,000 tonnes of copper and 11,000  tonnes of cobalt for this year materially increasing into next year as well. I'll spend a bit of time on the cost  increases both just passive inflationary through Energy and the like and a few other cost pressures that we're  seeing in the business as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: I think a good place to just look which would cover all the other comments that have been written down there is to  look at the bridge on the bottom right-hand corner. As our Industrial has gone from $5.3 billion to the $6.6 billion,  clearly the big driver has been increase in commodity prices, $1.9 billion. To break that up, we've seen increases  in the copper business, which is helped by the cobalt by-products and various others. $0.6 billion of that $1.9  billion is in copper. Zinc's had an increase, $0.3 billion on pricing, the nickel business $0.3 billion as well, ferro  $1.1 billion. Giving $1.3 billion overall for the Metals business. And on the Energy, we've had $0.6 billion, which is  coal at $0.5 billion and oil is at $100 million increase. And expanding off a low base as well, we should see some  – having bottomed out in terms of our oil production in West Africa, we should start seeing some increases over  the coming periods as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Australian coal has also improved volumes owing to a fairly weak base period due to both industrial and weather- related issues in first half 2007 (sic) [2017]. We have acquired, have now consolidated the HVO business from  May which of course brought some additional both steam coal and semi-soft tonnes into the business as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Some of the negatives, mostly temporary from a volume perspective, was Prodeco, 2.5 million tonne reduction  period-on-period. We've spoken about a significant investment period now as they develop and set the mine up  for future rates of production consistent with their normal handling levels, so they are going through some  temporary reductions in product as they move more overburden. That, of course, had a volumetric impact.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Mount Isa in copper, you've seen a reduction in copper tonnes out of that as they did a re-brick of the smelter  during the first half. That's an event that only happens every three or four years. On the zinc business, there was  the sale of the zinc African assets in August last year to Trevali, so, of course, during the first half. There was  production last year. That was about 70,000 tonne of zinc metal. So, we didn't have that in this period. That will be  more than compensated volume-wise as we move forward with the Lady Loretta tonnes and, ultimately, the zinc  product and lead coming out of Zhairem in Kazakhstan.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: In terms of cost variance period-on-period, it's been a fairly modest and mostly passive increase in costs as we've  seen during the business in terms of real cost, $348 million. By far, the highest aggregate contributor would have  been the higher fuel prices and other energy costs. We've seen average Brent prices, as an indicator, up 34% first  half of this year compared to first half last year.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: FX was actually a small negative variance for us this year, primarily due to the stronger rand period-on-period. But  the rand's weakened significantly in the second quarter and beyond. So, that's now going to turn into a more  positive indicator going forward. Positive coal hedging variance, or not having any, so that was an impact on first  half last year which is obviously now no longer the case.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And at this point, it's also worth mentioning, which we do talk on page 20, which I'll get to later on, is that in the  copper business, we did close the books off on the first half of 2018 having sold 32,000 tonnes of copper less  than what we produced. We flagged that in our production report on the basis that it was a material impact which  we knew at the time. We've now confirmed the financial impact on that, because you've obviously got both the  copper and the by-products coming out of cobalt, zinc and gold in particular, depending on where those tonnes  were, of course, South America, some in Africa. And there was a $298 million variance EBITDA-wise on pure  timing of having not had those sales go through in the first half, that will come through in the second half.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Before I just move into some of the details of that page, just a few highlights from the appendix that's worth noting  as well. Pages 19, 20, and 21. If we go to 19, which will make sense of some of these numbers as we go through  both 2018 and I think as we think forward also into 2019. So production guidance on page 19, you can see in the  chart we've shown actual H1 production. The guidance which we updated two or three weeks ago, unchanged in  almost all areas except a slight reduction in lead. The 5% that we commented on, the 300,000 tonnes to 285,000  tonnes, not as material as clearly some of the other commodities and a slight tick down in coal, 2 million tonnes,  134 million tonnes down to 132 million tonnes. Minor adjustments around South America, Colombia, and South  Africa that fell into those particular components.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, off those particular guidances we've spoken about on the left-hand side, you can see quite significant H2 on  H1 volume improvements which will drive performance and are impacting or factoring into the cost performance.  So copper, we're expecting 73,000 extra tonne H2 on H1, the continued ramp-up of Katanga, and Mount Isa  recovery, as I said, from first half smelter re-brick.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Cobalt, 29% increase, an extra 5,000 tonne period-on-period. That's the Katanga ramp-up. As you would recall,  the cobalt circuit was only commissioned in March. So, you had a period which really only had a small number of  months and it's now functioning very well as we've gone through six weeks or so in the second half period.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And page 21 as well is then the full year having baked in now the full mark-to-market numbers of all the  commodity prices as they are now. So, of course, this is just a point in time. If we'd been cutting these numbers  six or eight weeks ago, that would have been higher because, of course, commodities both copper, zinc, cobalt  and the likes would have been higher back then. And if we cut it off in six or seven weeks' time, hopefully it's  higher again. So, these numbers are – need to be taken with that in mind. It is obviously sensitive and clearly  volatility. Although, as Ivan said, there's a – given both the commodity and geographic distribution and the stable  commodity part of the business, it should be more cushioned than many of our peers.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, we've run these numbers at a – you can see the spot copper prices. So, cutoff I think in the last few days or  so before we finalized. Copper was at $2.80, which is pretty much where it is now, the $6,171 per tonne. Zinc at  $1.21, just over $2,600 per tonne. Nickel, that was $13,400 per tonne, which I think has picked up a few hundred  dollars since that, so maybe a bit conservative there. So, I'll refer to those numbers later on, but as always, we  provided those building blocks.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, copper is getting significant by-products for us out of cobalt of course. Zinc is a very big broad by-product  normally and particularly now in Antamina, and we've also got gold out of Antapaccay and Ernest Henry and the  likes and there's also some silver by-product that will be coming out of Antamina and some other operations, very  sizable by-products.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The zinc business similarly is affected by very big by-product materiality out of lead and out of some of the  precious metals as well as copper, because zinc, as you would know, produces 70,000 tonnes or so of copper,  and we have quite significant copper as well coming out of the Canadian zinc operations as well. So, it is material.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: If we just provide on a year-to-date basis against where we were in January the last time we gave some of these  guidance, so – and so in the copper business what was relevant to them, you've seen zinc down 6%. This is the  average prices against – for the year against what it was in January, zinc 6% lower, lead's 5% lower, copper is  4% lower, and gold and silver themselves about 5% lower. So clearly, that's obviously had an impact.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: We've said some tick-up in the fuel and power prices. As mentioned before, Brent price was up around 18% from  January's price to where we were for the average for that particular period. The business is very, very exposed to  that diesel price and the fuel price through its mobile equipment and some power associated costs, which could  also tick-up through either being exposed to coal or through oil or various other utility like prices as well as they  come through.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So as we move between copper and zinc that have been affected by by-product pricing, fuel and power prices,  and we've shown the effect of that, and some production that was – we've shown you the guidance on that page,  page 20 against initial expectation, we've seen modest lower productions than what we might have thought for the  half year. I think only about 7,000 tonnes in both those cases as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The bigger impact I think is as we go clearly now for the spot full year basis in costs which is the next table. I'm  looking at 2018 revised, because now we're fully marking to market the entire by-products on an illustrative  annualized basis. And the movements in by-products is significantly more material than obviously just a year-to- date average. So now, we're fully mark to marking the entire zinc by-product in copper at the prices of currently  which is the $2,600 per tonne. It was $3,400 per tonne back in January. So, zinc is 26% less. That will have a  material impact in the copper business.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Lead is 17% lower over that same period; cobalt, 13%; gold and silver is 12%; and copper is 12% as well. So  within the copper business as well, we've seen the biggest impact on by-products is cobalt, zinc and gold. We've  also noted some higher costs generally within the group, and copper Africa has been singled out for the reasons  that I will now go into.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: But as we look at the copper costs of the $1.03 for 2018, we would expect all things being equal with even prices  where they are now by-product-wise, we think is generally at fairly conservative levels now. Obviously, one can  mark-to-market that on a go-forward basis. But with the incremental production we have going forward in 2019,  both copper 150,000 tonnes to 300,000 tonnes at Katanga with the cobalt from 11,000 tonnes up to  approximately 30,000 tonnes with marginal cost being very low to deliver that extra.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So those are the main costs. We'd expect them all to – as I said, copper and zinc to start coming south as we  bring those extra tonnes. Coal, steady business as we go forward, significant cash generator and nickel holding in  its costs as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Oil prices, we mentioned, was up 18% year-on-year. Just to mention that as we stand at the moment, given the  metal prices have come down since that period that that increase has now been fully reversed. So we're now at  levels that are below where we are at the beginning of the year and should see a continued reduction on that –  reversal of that increase in the net funding line.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Yeah. Thanks a lot, Steve. If you look at slide 14, it gives you an idea of the power of our diversified business, the  type of commodities which we produce, and it shows the earnings and cash flow momentum. As you can see, if  you look at the momentum of our commodity prices during this year, where we've had volatility with all the  commodities during the year, look at our year-to-date illustrative spot EBITDA momentum, it's definitely superior  to our peers. Because if you break down our commodities which we produced, you have copper which is weaker  since the beginning of the year 14% negative; zinc, 21%; cobalt, 15%. But this has been partially offset by the  strong coal price during the year in both Newcastle, South Africa and Colombia and the – where Newcastle price  is up 17%. And you have nickel up 7% and ferroalloys.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The coal price is extremely strong at the moment. As you know, there's tightness of supply in both Newcastle,  South Africa and Colombia and this is keeping the price up with strong demand definitely in Southeast Asia. This  is comparative to our peers and if you look at our peers, if you compare it to iron ore, where you have the CNF  price down 19% whilst you have the FOB price of iron ore down 16%. So, if you take the balance, that definitely –  if you look at the slide on the right, shows the differential of year-to-date spot EBITDA momentum versus our UK  peers.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: And as we displayed where we had higher prices during the first half of the year, we hit $1.5 billion EBIT on the  Marketing business. So it's clear, the EBITDA momentum is superior to the peers who have more iron ore in their  portfolio, and this has been advantageous to us during the year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, the commodity fundamentals of our commodities, we believe, remain favorable. It's clear you've got a bit of  volatility with the potential trade wars occurring. However, there is limited supply in our commodities. As we  mentioned, there is limited new supply in coal. There's limited new supply in copper. Cobalt, most of the supply,  new supply comes from us, and there's limited new mines being produced on – being developed on the horizon  which produces our commodities.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, we think we have the right mix of commodities, and the fundamental demand for these commodities remains  robust in the world. And even with the potential trade wars and the noise around the trade wars, we don't see  much decrease in the demand for these commodities, even in China. If anything, in China, with the shutdown of  some of their operations because of environmental issues, demand is, in fact, looking better in certain  commodities.

file: GLENL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 5March2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Looking at our marketing activities, as I said earlier, the Metals and Minerals division, generally, the profit is –  EBIT is $1.2 billion. That is 11% lower than 2010. Looking at this quarter in the division, you've got to remember  on the copper zinc part of the business, there was massive restocking which took place in China in 2010. The same  restocking did not take place in 2011. That's the reason volumes were slightly down and profits were lower.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Looking at the Energy side of the business, as you are aware, the first half of 2011 was very strong towards the –  the profits were up 55%, with an EBIT of $697 million and the reason is that on the oil side, as I said, the first half  of 2011 was very strong [audio gap] (3:14) and was a very good year for oil. The coal part of the business was  strong even though there's reduced volatility and lower freight rates, which resulted in less arbitrage  opportunities. The pickup of agency business, the increase of various volumes around the world enabled the coal  division to perform very strongly.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: On the Energy side, it's well known, the expansion of our coal assets in Colombia, the Prodeco project. Prodeco  has increased considerably, up 45% and we produced 14.6 million tonnes in 2011. The development of the port  there is going very strongly. This will be developed by the end of 2012 and eventually, that project will get up to 21  million tonnes.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: The good news on the oil side, the Energy side was the Aseng oil production in Block I in Equatorial Guinea came  on stream earlier than expected and development there started in November 2011. We ramped up to 50,000  barrels per day. I think today it's getting closer to 60,000 barrels. And as you know, we own 25% of that  investment and we will be developing the Alen field later on and that should add another 40,000 tonnes of  production there.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: We've also increased the reserves over there on the zinc side and there's been significant increase on the JORC  reserves, which took place during 2011.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Katanga copper production went up. As you are aware, we are mining one of the highest grades of copper in the  world, around about 4.5% cooper grade. We increased 57%, up to 91,000 tonnes at Katanga. During 2012, we  expect to get to around about 140,000 tonnes of copper production. We've also developed the – we've increased  the ramp-up to 310,000 tonnes and we're moving fast ahead on that. So therefore, at Katanga, we expect to get to  around about 310,000 tonnes development by the end of 2013. So that is moving along nicely.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: If you look at our E&P portfolio in Equatorial Guinea, as I've said earlier, we developed that project earlier than  expected, during November 2011. We kicked up to 50,000/60,000 barrels a day. And we expect to be at 60,000  barrels a day during 2012. The other subsea development there, the Alen field, we expect that in late second half  2013 to add another 40,000 barrels a day production. So, with these two fields, where we own approximately 25%,  we should have about 100,000 barrels of oil today and with current oil prices, it's not hard to see how that will  generate significant profits to the Group.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Prodeco, I mentioned earlier. Production increased to around about 14.6 million tonnes this year. The new port,  which will allow us to load 21 million tonnes of coal through the new port, will be developed by the end of this  year, early next year, 2013, and that will really give a massive expansion in that world-class operation.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: I'll talk about net debt and some of those metrics for this slide later on. 2012, Ivan will talk a little bit on the  outlook towards the end as well, but I think you can see a trend in Marketing. We have alerted that that [ph] stow  well (16:27) across each segment. And on the Industrials side again, looking forward, we are expecting big growth  in coal, be it Colombia, the oil, we'll have our first full year of production going forward in coal and, of course,  copper and gold, we've got quite big expansions going forward.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: If we look into Slide 10, really nothing much to add. It's just a geographical showing the Marketing performance,  down 18%, really a function of the Agricultural year-on-year movement as well. Metals and Minerals, a largely  consistent performance and good volumes and good premiums. Energy was the big increase, at least over 2010,  particularly the oil market in the first half of 2011 which we spoke about last year, and some continued drag which  both – we have some long exposure there which is a drag and in what that does to providing some arbitrage  opportunity as well. And the Agricultural side, I think Ivan's covered it largely in the cotton side.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Own production, of course, much higher up in zinc, copper and gold as you can see. The Energy side is off a lower  base but growing nicely, both on coal in Colombia. And a little bit of oil production, but that should really start  seeing material benefits flowing through in early 2012.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: If we look at Page 12, that waterfall chart, this is just looking at the Industrial side of the business, at the EBIT  going from $2.9 million up to the $3.5 million in 2011. We're showing a price variance of $774 million positive and  a volume variance of $272 million. To give you a split on the price variance, $523 million of that was Metals and  $250 million was Energy, and that's very much gold and copper were the main contributors on the pricing on the  Metals side.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: And Prodeco, we've provided you the realized pricing for them on their export sales, which averaged $95 million  against $82 million for year 2011 and 2010, which should still remain fairly robust down there given we have got  27 million of those tonnes have been sold forward at an average price of $94 million as well as the coal side.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: As far as volume variances, $182 million of that $272 million has come from Metals and $89 million from the  Energy. And again, you've seen the extra gold production, 26%, copper 35% and the extra coal production, 18%,  making up the $89 million.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So we did see certain what we would say is temporary in Asia, build up in working capital. There were some  profitable funded opportunities. We would expect that to reverse over the course of first half 2012 in a stable  commodity price environment which, of course, have seen oil also go up, as I said, in the first two months which,  of course, is going to have some impact as well on our working capital.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: On Industrial side of the business, as I mentioned earlier, that we do have these big ramp-up operations. At  Katanga, we will be taking Katanga to 310,000 tonnes, which we envisage to be completed by the end of 2013.  Mutanda, we will ramp up to 200,000 tonnes and we're going to get the full year's production from there. And  then Aseng field in 2012, as I said earlier, the 60,000 barrels a day, our 25% of that and on the Alen field, towards  the latter end of 2013, which will add another 40,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: We also, as you know, acquired the Optimum Koornfontein, Umcebo operations in South Africa. That is going to  give us a massive resource base in South Africa and you will see us increasing our production from those South  African reserves, which will add a lot to the Energy/Coal division.

file: GLENL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 5March2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So, once again, during the IPO and during previous discussions with investors, we said that Glencore prefers to  invest in less risky projects on the asset side of the business, development side of our assets. And we prefer to  distance ourselves from greenfield projects which create more risk and more uncertainty, delays, et cetera, which  we've seen that a lot of the other mining companies have experienced. We really develop brownfield, the easier  projects, and our pipeline remains overall on time and on budget. So we're performing relatively well on  developing the various assets which we have, and Telis will talk in more detail regarding the major assets we have  on the copper side, both Mutanda and Katanga.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Robust 2012 as I reported on on the marketing. I mentioned the figures, but we generated $2.1 billion EBIT on the  marketing. And as I said earlier, it's an increase of 11% against 2012. Strong performance despite lower prices  across base metals and coal, but this higher profit was delivered by volume growth and generally higher premiums  sitting on the metals side of the business.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Looking at the industrial assets, if you break them down and you exclude the Xstrata earnings, as I said earlier, we  are down 27% and this compares favorably to our peers. This has reflected tight cost control on our assets and  capital efficient growth philosophy where we, once again, focus on the easier brownfield-type projects.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Looking at the growth of the company going forward, between 2012 to 2016, the big growth through 2014, once  again, emphasizing the growth of our assets on our brownfield, easy expansion projects, once again, little risk in it.  We have demonstrated in the past, on time, on budget. We continue – we will hold the same going forward. As  you will see in most of these projects, our brownfield projects, Kazzinc, Katanga, Mopani, Mutanda, Prodeco, and  they all have good CAGR growth between 2012 and 2014, 19.3% growth. And if you look overall between 2012 and  2016, 11.2% CAGR growth and, once again, emphasizing non-risky projects, non-greenfield, easy projects to  develop, with little risk on expansion.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: We had long-term loans that's getting serviced in a combination of cash and various deferrals. It's a business that's  performing very well. It's a business that leverage has been coming down markedly, of course, in an environment  where you've got the $100-plus oil prices. It's around $1.5 billion EBITDA. We have equity exposure to the  business. But the loan comfort factor has never been better in terms of Glencore's visibility and its comfort in that  carrying value loan.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: And on the agricultural side, in the European biodiesel market as well, where we have two plants. We've  mothballed one – two plants, I think, Chris, as well and we've taken some impairment against the mothballed  element of those particular. So very low levels of classic impairments in reflecting our comfort now in our balance  sheet and where the prospects hold.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Energy was the laggard in 2013 on 2012 for reasons that we've mentioned as well. Low volatility, particularly  second half of the year; weak freight markets, which is a factor in accessing and opening up the opportunities –  the arbitrage opportunities and, just generally, a weaker coal price environment that we saw given the US  displacement as well. That should show improvements also as we look forward into 2013.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Metals and minerals was the heaviest hit, of course, given the backdrop in some commodity prices there. Nickel,  zinc were two to highlight, down 23% and 11%. Aluminum as well does affect us. We don't have too much alumina  exposure that's coming directly through our own consolidated assets, but via our alumina smelter – refinery in  Sherwin, Texas. There is clearly aluminum exposure and they struggled in the lower commodity price  environment there.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So the metals and minerals, down. But, again, positive signs going forward in terms of production growth,  business had a strong performance during 2012. And again, diversification helping there the oil business, finally a  full year of production out of the Aseng field, which commenced at the back-end of 2011, and that's performed  very well both in a volume sense and in a price sense as the oil price – January has held up better than the metal's  price environment.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: And we do have the second field which is due to come on line in the third quarter this year. So that's going to be  another leg up in terms of our oil business getting forward and augurs well for the energy product side. And nice  to have the oil balanced compared to coal which is, obviously, in a difficult part of the cycle.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: But South African coal, amongst coal producers, geographically, where we did make some acquisitions is in much  better shape cost-wise, given rand and other factors down there, and maybe there's some other origins at the  moment. So those businesses are actually performing quite well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So if we just jump into page six – that waterfall chart – as I said, on the industrial side, $3.5 million, down to the  $2.3 million. In terms of price, to give you some split of the $537 million, metals was $374 million of that; energy,  $141 million; and agricultural, $22 million. And on the metals side, nickel certainly was a big factor with pricing  down 23%; aluminum, 16%; and zinc down 11%, as I said. On the energy side, $141 million. That was spot coal  prices essentially out of Colombia. That would have been the major contributor there with spot prices and indexes  down around 20% where Murrin and Prodeco were two of the larger assets impacted by price during 2002.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: On the volume side, good growth. And that momentum, as Ivan said, with our future growth prospects out the  next four or five years is also going to hold in a positive direction. Of the $807 million, $58 million in metals. So  only a small piece coming out of the metals. We would expect that to accelerate going forward. The energy side  was $700 million, in fact, of the volume growth, and that's a big piece, was in the oil assets, as we said, the first full  year and also South African coal business contributed nicely to that.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: On the cost side, $237 million negative. That is made up – $75 million is metals and $161 million is energy. The  big impacts for us was essentially in some of our growth assets where the growth – wasn't quite there in 2012, but  you still set up your business in terms of infrastructure and people and resources and everything else is geared up  for being at higher levels of production.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So with that, I'll hand over to Telis to talk through DRC Copper.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Just to go forward and explain a little bit on the power side in Katanga province, what was 2012 and hopefully  what will be 2013. The Katanga – the demand for power in Katanga is about 650 megawatts, which is actually just  about half the power in the whole country. The generation and the two electric plants in the province is 240  megawatt. And we got 150 megawatts from Inga that came down and 100 megawatts from Zambia, which, if you  see, basically caused a shortfall of around 60 megawatts for the province.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: What's changed this year? This year, the big change will be the amount of power that can be transmitted from  Inga. And what curtailed that, last year, was the fact that the converter station that was supposed to be ready, the  World Bank was not. And there was a blowup in one of these things called the synchronous condenser which  basically modulates the frequency, so you can receive the power, that blew up. There used to be three. There were  operating broke down. So, basically, that left us really without the possibility to receive power, essentially, or to  receive – not being able to receive clean power.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: What are we doing to mitigate that? This is a program that we had started already about two years ago, which was  an agreement with SNEL to invest in the form of loans, $320 million, for power generation, transmission and  distribution. What the project does is it makes available 450 megawatts. 350 megawatts is new power generated  and 100 megawatts is power that we can transmit. And this will be completed by 2015.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: We will require, we think, 400 megawatts, and the 50 megawatts surplus goes to SNEL. And we will get paid back  by deducting from our electricity bills over a period around six to eight years, depending on how it actually goes.  The surplus goes to SNEL.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Just have a look here, a little bit on the next slide. The picture here on the right is the synchronous condenser. The  one on the top is the one that blew up. That's what it looks like. So, essentially, it's a big magnet that goes around  very quickly and you can see what happens. And the one at the bottom is the one that we refurbished and it's now  operating.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Just to go a little bit back on investment, $95 million will be spent to refurbish the three turbines in Inga and  Nzilo; $110 million is for the transformers at Inga and on the Kolwezi end, so we can receive the power; and the  $115 million is investment in transmissions line. Most of that is for the new line that feeds Mutanda.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: The time line for the power generation, 25 megawatts is coming this year – will come in the fourth quarter this  year, 160 megawatts at the end of next year, and another 160 megawatts at the end of 2015. And that should see  us, we hope, comfortable in terms of our power requirements. This is, obviously, something that we now really are  trying to keep a handle on because, as we'll see later, it was really the single reason why our production and our  revenues were down.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Just to go to Mutanda where we are on the expansion, last year, we produced 87,000 tonnes of copper. We had 18  lost days of production just due to power. The requirement for Mutanda was 45 megawatts last year and the peak  this year will be 78 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Next one, Katanga, just picking up a little bit on what I said before, if you look at the total copper in ore mined,  there was 228,000 metric tonnes on a finished production of 93,000 metric tonnes. So you can see what happens.  We mine the copper. That part is not energy-intensive, but we couldn't process it because we lost 67 days, shut  down, because we had no power. So, obviously, we've mined the copper, but we couldn't produce it, we couldn't  sell it, we didn't get the revenues which is a shame because – not only in terms of the results of what we showed,  but also we've built up a lot of working capital. And, hopefully, what we will do now is we will see that working  capital flow out. We subscribed for 128 megawatts. We were load-shed down to 93 megawatt. And out of that, 67  days we didn't get any power.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Now, one of the things that we're doing in Katanga and you'll see some pictures later on is we will – we are  inefficient and power-intensive. So you can see that the old electrowinning, what we call, EW 1, with 150,000  tonne of capacity, needed 53 megawatts. We've got a new plant, 220,000 tonne capacity that needs 34 megawatts.  So we are investing. We're upgrading as we're producing.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: The peak power draw last year was 100 megawatts. And this year, even when we get to 200,000 tonnes with the  new refinery, we will require less power than we did last year when we're producing around 100,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Just going to the next slide, there's some pictures there. You can see the top picture is the solvent extraction lines.  There's three lines of 100,000 tonnes. You can see the one on the right is finished and that is feeding the SX. You  can see the copper and the solution at the bottom which goes into the refinery.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: We will be at an annualized rate of 200,000 tonnes by the end of this year. In April, you can see this stage, we'll  have the sulfide receiving by the end of April. EW2, which is the new tankhouse, you'll see a picture later on, will  be finished by May already this year. The roaster in September. The oxide receiving and the CCD tanks in  September. And finally, we'll finish the new flows that we need to build in the concentrated plant by October. And  the EW plant is exactly the same as – that we're putting in as the Mutanda 1, so we know it's kind of the standard  EW. We don't think there's any risk and those – the next 100,000 tonnes will be put – will be finished and put in  by the end of next year. So we should have Katanga running at 300,000 tonnes by December 2014.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Now, if you just go look a little bit on the next page, just some pictures of what we're doing. If you look on the top  left, that is what was the old electro-winning plant, old Luilu. That's the one that I said was built in 1956. That's  the one that we inherited, that we bought, that we operated for the last two years. That's what we've been  producing copper from.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: And on the right, that is the quality of the copper that's been coming out. And essentially, it was trading at a scrap  price. Why? Because these were old equipment, old cathodes. We couldn't strip in. It was falling to bits. You had to  do it manually. And if you look at the EW2 at the bottom, which is the new refinery that was commissioned at the  end of last year, you can see what's the difference. And you can see the difference on the refinery itself and also the  cathodes coming out. It's automatic stripping. This is what one would consider today a modern plant.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: If we just go to the next slide, just again, that's what the bundles look like from the old EW1 on the left and this is  what it looks like, the copper that's coming out now. So this is essentially grade A copper that we're producing  now.

texts.speaker: Aristotelis Mistakidis
texts.profession: Director-Zinc, Copper & Lead Commodity Department, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: And we think by – if you look at the production on the next slide, that's a little bit where we've come from.  Katanga is the mauve one. The blue one is Mutanda. This is what we were in 2008, a total of 29,000 tonnes to  180,000 tonnes last year. And this year, we'll get  an annualized capacity of 200,000 tonnes on each by December

texts.speaker: Christopher Mahoney
texts.profession: Director-Agricultural Products Business Segment, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: This slide shows our ownership of processing facilities globally. And I should say that particularly with regard to  crushing, our processing facility is also part of the logistics infrastructure. We have 12 soybean and swap seed  with Viterra, one in China, one in Canada. We have 14 mills, wheat and rice mills. The mills are in Brazil and  Uruguay. The crushing plants were in Argentina, Europe and the FSU. We have six biofuel plants. We have seven  malt plants, six feed mills and two pasta plants. And those last three, the malt, the feed mills and the pasta were  acquired as part of the Viterra acquisition.

texts.speaker: Christopher Mahoney
texts.profession: Director-Agricultural Products Business Segment, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: If you look at the total crushing capacities or the processing capacities on the right, the crushing plants processed  7 million tonnes, the mills just under 2 million tonnes; the biofuel plants just under 1 million tonnes; the malt,  700,000 tonnes; the feed mills, 300,000 tonnes; and the pasta, 250,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Christopher Mahoney
texts.profession: Director-Agricultural Products Business Segment, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Secondly, and I think there's nothing new for most of you here, but nevertheless, it's interesting. If we look at  China, if we look at pork consumption per capita, the Chinese were consuming 11 kilograms per capita per year in  1980. That was up to 38 kilograms in 2012. The equivalent number in Hong Kong is 80 kilograms per capita per  year. And I don't say it will, but if China were to reach the same consumption as Hong Kong, that increased pork  consumption would require an additional 160 million tonnes of corn, which compares to seaborne trade today of  about 80 million tonnes, 85 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: It helps our trading business. It helps us more, especially on the coal side where we get Xstrata flow of their  commodities into the Glencore system. We have the ability to blend more on the coal side of the business, on the  smelting side, acquiring their smelters, we will run the business in a different manner where the smelters are  rarely utilized as a trailing unit, whether you put the Xstrata flow of concentrate into the smelter or you bring in  third party or utilizes that.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Mutanda was already partially developed by the previous owner. So we had a good grasp of what had to be done  there. So it wasn't a greenfield expansion with the risks involved. And as you can see, besides the power situation,  which is slowly being resolved, we will be, potentially, by the end of 2014, producing 500,000 tonnes of copper in  the Congo, potentially even taking it up to 600,000 tonnes in the future, with very little risk going forward.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: Prudeco, the other asset which we have in the portfolio, once again, a brownfield, getting various mines together,  expanding there the port capacity and building the new port, once again, on time, budget. First vessels should be  loading from the new port in March this year. As shown, we will get that to 21 million tonnes with very little risk.  The same with the other assets, Kazzinc and the various industry – agricultural expansions and facilities which  were bought. The big one, the crushing facility in Argentina, once again, on time, on budget, not high risk type  projects.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So I think our industrial assets have performed well. The expansions have performed well because of this more  conservative approach we take within Glencore and not pushing the limit on greenfield risky type projects.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So, overall, this is the philosophy Glencore will be taking going forward. Of course, at some stage, we will have to  look at greenfields. And as time goes on, we will review the different greenfield projects within both the Glencore  portfolio and the Xstrata portfolio and decide whether – how we move forward with them. And there's been  transformational projects at Viterra going forward. We will continue to add those which will help the trading side  of the business.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore International Plc
texts.text: So having also, as I've said earlier, the Xstrata flows going forward will help the business considerably. So, overall,  the outlook looks good. How do we see the market going forward? We do see growth in the United States stronger  than most people envisage. We do see demand for commodities picking up. We do believe the shale gas and the  cheap power generation being developed in United States will grow the industrial side of the United States, which  should bode well for the commodity – for our commodities demand in the United States.

file: GLENL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 4March2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Within some of the components of that, of course, the continuing strong performance of the core metals and  minerals business within Glencore; generally constructive physical market conditions. Y ou can see that thro ugh  premium structures and general opportunities in non-particular markets and just given the scale of business that  we do have. It's made up of many businesses across all the base metals and carbon and stainless steel products.  Iron ore is a developing business, clearly, within Glencore as well. Y ou've seen volume improvements across the  board in copper and zinc, iron ore, ferrochrome, for example, are some of the ones that we've increased volumes  quite nicely and Xstrata acquisition will potentially move that even further ahead as we move forward.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Energy off a relatively low base in 2012, was up nicely, 45% in 2013 as well. But still, in terms of its overall size and  general weigh that it can punch overall across both coal and oil and with synergies expec ting, that is a business  that clearly offers potential and would need to find its next gear to get us to within the $2.7  billion to $3.7  billion  level.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Within the industrial part of the business, you'll see a slide later on of providing the bridge. Overall EBITDA only  dipping modestly, 4% to $10.5 billion there. Some big headwinds clearly in commodity prices at the headline level  and you can see copper prices clearly for the year down about 8% year-on-year. Nickel prices was about 14%, 15%.  Gold and silver not commodities you'd typically associate with Glencore but we do get sizeable byproduct credits  in gold and silver. That clearly has an impact as we report earnings, particularly in zinc business. Copper clearly  also has some gold, like an operation like Alumbrera, for example, that has quite a bit of gold output as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
