texts.text: The energy side of the business; coal, clearly a weak spot in terms of the coal price environment. We've shown  average realized prices down generally around 20% year-on-year across both the coking and the steam clearly  having a big impact. And a lot of that has been – a lot of hard work's gone into the assets themselves around  efficiencies, operations, shutting down more marginal operations that so ught to defray some of that coal price  pressure as much as possible. We'll see some of the graph later as well, an overall good portfolio and ready and  waiting for the inevitable uptick in that particular commodity at some point. And agricultural, a very s mall base  but again, a much stronger second half performance as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: So coal has found another $43 million up to the $619 million. Copper, another $100 million or so up to the $288  million, a little bit in nickel and a little bit in zinc as well. But as I've said, ongoing process and we're at $2.4  billion. This is not a target. This is not identified. This is delivered. This is banked. This is happening. It's flowing  through the business even as we speak. And to some extent, if you look at the second half performance of 2013,  there was already – some of these synergies were clearly flowing through in the corporate side and some in t he  asset side as well. This as I said was the industrial bridge EBIT looking at the progression which was down 21%,  flattish at the EBITDA level. Y ou can see the impact on pricing $4.4 billion across the years as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: So, on the commodity side, by far, copper and coal leave us with the biggest upside and downside in terms of  commodity exposure. And then you've got rounding out, you would have zinc, nickel and ferrochrome, bringing  up some of the other operations. Of course, as we grow in commodities like oil, for example, and we expand that  clearly a 10% movement in oil price at some point in time is going to be more than $7 0 million as we grow that   part of the business.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Cost benefits, as well, again most of that is copper, $636 million or so on the copper side and coa l delivering $582  million there in net cost. And that's the ongoing cost reductions efficiency, delivering low cost tonnes. Synergies,  of course, that could be delivered, that are operationally based with flow through, that number.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Currency relief, $1 billion positive flowing through; metals about $500 million; and coal about $500 million as  well. That helps, of course, copper, zinc in places like Australia. Ferroalloys, of course, in South Africa, it's a major  driver for them; and the coal business both cross Australia and South Africa and to some extent, South America as  well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Nothing too much to talk about other than just providing a snapshot and looking at the sustaining level of CapEx  $4.1 billion, that's the level. $4 billion to $4.5 billion is where we'd see it in the next two years. And in fact from  2016, 2017, we'd see it drop even to between $3.5 billion and $4 billion. So that's the average $4 billion sustaining  of maintenance CapEx over that three-year or four-year period. And of course, if we then go to the next page, you  can see the big expansionary CapEx. That's continued clearly during the year, around $8.5 billion, Las Bambas  $1.7 billion of that during 2013. Koniambo, of course, is a major undertaking and it was clearly during 2013. It  continues during the ramp-up phase at the moment. Some more coal expansion in Australia, in three big projects  there; in Rolleston, Ulan and Ravensworth as well. Katanga Phase IV, Tweenfontein and a variety of others. That  number, clearly, going down if we look across the – across on the chart.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: One of the new brownfield projects which we are pursuing, and again, there's a slide on that later on in terms of  major project update and Telis can talk a little bit about more later on is a new shaft concentrated expansion over  at Mopani in Zambia which really transforms that operation from being a high -cost, short-term mine life  operation to one that now – it is really a new mine if you look in terms of the tonnes, the cost structure, and the  overall profile of that particular operation. So if the overall size of that brownfield expansion is $7 7 2 million,  there's a slide on that later on, comfortably above 25% in terms of IRR or return on equity and we 'll talk about that  later on.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: In terms of efficiency and the overall sort of handling of material of the underground material, it really is a game - changer for that particular operation. So that was just to highlight one of the new brownfield – the only really new  brownfield that's come up since that day that's come onto the approval status. A little bit more in budget into the  oil exploration, and other that's going into 2014 and 2015 relative to what was there in Investor Day.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: As with other and even more so than other mining companies given the big CapEx profile that we've had as well,  that trajectory now from $12.6 billion, $8.7 billion to $6.6 billion would see our CapEx declining 31% and then a  further 24% in 2015. This still is within the CapEx budget, if you like. There still is one or two unapproved  brownfield expansions that there's placeholders for that. So there is a little bit of allowance for things we are  looking at that are, I would say, is very likely. And when we do announce that we are doing these one or tw o things  which I would expect to happen, that would not increase the CapEx amounts per se. So there is a bit of allowance  for one or two brownfield projects that are currently getting close to – given the go ahead within the business and  we'll, of course, provide that data as and when we're in a position to do.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The world's copper, we got to grow and produce another 3% copper every year and it runs about to 500,000  tonnes per year. Now, can the world keep producing that amount of copper every year? This is what we got to see.  There's the talk of the oversupply. We read about it which is occurring in 2014, but a lot of those mines [don't]  believe the oversupply is occurring in 2014 and Telis can talk in more detail with you later whether those are really  coming into a production, a lot of them are delayed, a lot of them are replacing old mines. A nd therefore, it is not  new production in the system as you well know. We built the Antapaccay mine but it really replaced Tintaya. So a  lot of these new mines which everyone's talked about oversupply is in fact replacing old mines and a lot of them  are delayed.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The other commodity is zinc. It's a commodity that has not been a great commodity for many years. But as you all  know, it's been – going to be – there have been shut downs in 2013. We shut Perseverance, you have Lisheen  shutting down, you have Skorpion shutting down. In 2015, you have the big mine in Australia, Century, shutting  down. So there is a lot of shuts on the zinc market. Daniel can talk in more detail there also, but we don't see any  new big production coming on stream. Dugald River, that was meant to be replacing part of Century, we all know,  has been delayed and is having problems.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The next big one is nickel and we can debate this. It's clear that with the nickel ore restrictions, the exports from  Indonesia which did come in place in our belief, they would really come in place and they have been applied, I  think, since the 14 of January. I think 14 of January, they are in place. There are no nickel ore exports during the  second half of January and February from Indonesia.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: As we all know, China produces around about 530,000 tonnes of nickel pig iron from nickel ore imports. The bulk  of that does come from Indonesia, small amount from the Philippines. But if that has been stopped, you're talking  about 1.8 million tonne more, with 530,000 tonnes being produced in China will now have to be moved to  Indonesia and it's going to take time for these nickel pig iron plants to be developed in Indonesia, delays in  permitting, et cetera. So we got a time factor how long it's going to take to replace the 530,000 tonnes in China is  going to be interesting.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: The next one coal, it's clear we are the biggest seaborne coal producer in the world today. So coal is a big factor.  Coal has had a negative outlook. We know the situation. Market is not looking great at the moment. The pricing is  not great. Naturally, we've been helped with the depreciation of the exchange currencies in both South Africa and  Australia. That has helped. So the mines are profitable. A lot of mines in Australia are under water. I think we  have a slide showing how many mines and what percent are losing money at these current prices. A lot of the  Australian mines are still producing because of the take or pay agreements where they lose less but are still  exporting.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: But the market looking interesting, the big demand that is occurring in India. Tor can give you the numbers and  the amount of demand that is growing. I think India has gone up 150 million tonnes last year to roundabout 185  million tonnes import this year and continuing to grow with the demand. New power stations being built in India  and the supply side of the various countries tightening up, and especially United States redu cing their exports  from about 65 million tonnes, we reckon, to about 50 million tonnes this year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: What we do have – this gives you an idea what we have in the Glencore portfolio today. All the c ommissioning of  the assets which we spoke about in 2014, the ones that are occurring in 2015, the new Synclinorium shaft at  Mopani, and then what Steve mentioned about the commissioning and potential new big shaft at Mopani in 2016.  So, most – or as we said, when we showed the capital expenditures, how much we've reduced our capital  expenditure, we'll have maintenance CapEx in this company of roundabout $3.5 billion to $4 billion and – when  the sustaining – when the expansionary CapEx concludes in 2015, the $2 billion whatever it is, unless we go ahead  with any of these brownfield expansions, we should have minimal CapEx in this coming year as displayed in the  previous chart.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: But what we do have in the company, we do have these potential easy brownfield exp ansions, which we can go  ahead with as we've always said. Greenfields we're scared like hell about because of the cost overruns and the  difficulties with them. But if commodity prices do start moving and we do get what the miners are saying and  cutting the CapEx expenditures which will reduce the new inflows of commodities into the system, it should bode  well for prices.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: If that occurs, the company has a room to move with cheap, add-on brownfield expansions. We have them there. I  don't need to take you through each one of them, it's no secret. In the Congo, we'll have Congo up to 500,000  tonnes production; 300,000 tonnes at Katanga. 200,000 tonnes at Mutanda, but we do have the expansion of the  sulfides at Mutanda, not a large amount of capital has to be spent, and we could add another 100,000 tonnes  there at Mutanda.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: We have the expansion at Coroccohuyaco in Peru where we can develop that brownfield expansion, why it's  brownfield – because you have the old Tintaya plant which was stopped and this is ore which you can feed into the  old Tintaya plant, but Telis can take you through that. But that's a large amount of tonnes of copper you could add  to the market with very low capital expenditure. So the company is geared to move, if we've got to move with very  low capital expansions and only these brownfield expansions with absolutely no execution risk.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: Health safety, environment, et cetera, that is an area we've got to push as a company. We are not leading i n that  field. We do have more difficult operations. And we don't need to use that as an excuse but we do operate deep  underground mines. We do operate in difficult regions which we go to and therefore push in those areas. We are  working hard in that area. We are improving.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Xstrata Plc
texts.text: If the change has occurred and everyone is talking about it, reduction of CapEx, reduction of new expansions, no  new big expansions and if we all believe what the mining companies and ourselves are saying, there isn't going to  be new big supply kicked into the market. And if demand is there, it should bode well for pricing. And pricing on   most of the commodities, except the ones where people are putting more expansions, brownfield expansions,  should bode well for the future.

file: GLENL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 3March2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Most of our commodities, there's no new big supply coming into the market. We believe we are transitioning most  of our commodities into a deficit, if we are not already in a deficit on some of the commodities. But if you take a  look at our commodities: zinc, copper, nickel, coal, et cetera, you don't see new big supply coming into the market.  So, we're pretty comfortable we're in the right commodity mix and we should bode well for the future.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, the – we'll see a waterfall chart later on, but the metals and minerals is definitely still the biggest side of the  overall business as well. There's 2% reduction down there. Of course, lower prices impact particularly in copper  and the by-product credits we get on the precious side, gold and silver, we do produce quite a bit of those, but  again, within our portfolio, mitigated by some volume increases. And some prices actually showed some relative  strength in 2014. Nickel and zinc in particular were actually up as commodity prices as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The big impact on the energy side in coal, particularly on the pricing side in 2014 compared to 2013. Y ou'll see on  the slide all that reduction was essentially in coal about $500 million net on – net in prices was of course the  biggest impact where most realized prices depending on the quality was 10% to 20% down. And for the first time,  that's not sort of a flat line there, a little bit of contribution from the agricultural, industrial side, having invested  in certain processing plants, crushing. South America and Europe is where we're – Eastern Europe is where we've  most penetrated, but for a business that was almost a rounding error, you're starting to see some contribution on  the agricultural side. And that should continue at some positive level going forward as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, that's on the industrial side. Just a quick – this is the industrial waterfall. We've put it into a two-year  perspective just also to show the combined work on the cost synergies and efficiencies over the two years. Some of  that is our own drive. Some of that, of course, was to do with the synergies on the industrial side by the  assumption and integration of the various Xstrata assets as well. Of course, pricing, major impact in 2014 of close  to $2 billion. $1.4 billion of that was on energy. $1.248 billion was on coal, and a little bit on the oil side was about  $136 million. And the metals side was the balance of $585 million there. Again, you got pluses and minuses there.  Copper and precious was down 2013 to 2014, but zinc and nickel gave some positives. And in fact, zinc – nickel  overall industrial was quite a big positive as well from 2013 to 2014 as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, a lot of the pricing, you did have some positive elements there. But if we look towards 2015, no one quite  knows where pricing is going to work out. At the moment, there's – in terms of average prices, 2013-2014, we feel  and we'll talk a bit little bit about that later on. There's some spring in the step in coal that seems to have come  back. That's obviously a key commodity of ours, and we'll see where the overall net works out.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: But every one of these other drivers, as we look forward to 2015, is going to be a positive development. We've got  some volume growth and particularly in zinc and copper, expected from 2014 to 2015. We've got some big cost  reductions expected from 2014, as we've transformed and bringing in lower unit cost par ticularly again in zinc and  copper.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Just on CapEx, a couple of slides as well, and then we'll wrap it up. This was just looking at 2013 to 2014, of that  24% reduction that we saw as well. So wrapping up a lot of projects here, a lot of legacy expansionary projects that  are coming on line, African copper, big expansion and some CapEx reductions there. Australia zinc across the  portfolio, you're seeing some big reductions there. And in the energy side of course, we've seen some reductions  on the coal side particularly in Australia, a little bit in South Africa as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So $8.6 billion total CapEx, down 24% as we said from the $11.3 billion, and trending significantly downwards as  well, that you can look at this chart as well. This is the 2015 guidance now, and the industrial CapEx stood at range  of $6.5 billion to $6.8 billion down from $7.9 billion. Most of it, as you can see – so sustaining CapEx, we said  $4.3 billion down to $4.1 billion; so $200 million reduction there. And the range we've kept on the expansionary  side, we were $3.6 billion, now $2.4 billion to $2.7 billion. Most of that is in energy block which makes up oil and  coal for us as well. So you've got reductions of $1 billion to $1.1 billion there. And we've just made a comment that  that's come broadly evenly from oil and the coal side. So oil, as you would have seen, we're $1.2 billion or so. Y ou  can all take 50% of that and on the coal side similarly. There's obviously a range still as we're working t hrough the  final plans, but that range is quite – is obviously quite lower. And I think one of the flexibilities and just allowing  for that range, and I'm sure there'll be questions on that later on, is just a little bit of what's the final capital as we  move forward in terms of Koniambo as well. So there's a bit of flex in it for that as well between the $6.5 billion  and $6.8 billion range as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Negligible expected impact on earnings through these – there may be some volumetric effects which we can talk  about later on as well. Not so much on the metals side, but of course, we've announced some coal reductions last  week, and there could be not so much nearer term, but at some point the rate of growth on the oil side is clearly  going to depending on how much CapEx we commit to that business both in exploration and development going  forward as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So with that number coming down, but obviously alert to opportunities that may be around the corner, that  number fairly stable, of course, around our commodity concentration, the marketing business and greener, have  some flexibility around working capital. If we want to target areas there, we do have some impact around working  capital. It would not be at the expense of returns that we expect and opportunities in the marketing business as  well and the reduction, of course, in net debt was particularly pleasing for 2014. So with that, will hand back to  Ivan.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: On zinc, we've always said, towards the middle of this year when you're going to have the shutdowns of the two  major – two larger operations. We have Lisheen shutting down, you have Century shutting d own. There's no new  zinc production coming in to the system, so therefore, it is transforming into deficit on the zinc side.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Nickel. We've discussed the main – big reason is the ore export from Indonesia. The ban is still sitting in place. We  do see ore stockpiles running down in China of the nickel ore, and we believe this market is definitely  transitioning into a deficit during the year and that should bode well. Exactly when pricing move, we cannot  predict, but the market is looking good in these commodities.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Regarding coal, we all know, coal – we are big part of the coal supply side. We represent 150 million tonnes in  managed production in a billion-tonne seaborne market. And as we've always said as a company, we do not want  to cannibalize our own production, and therefore, we're not going to put our tonnes where we believe it can have a  negative effect on pricing if demand is not there for those extra tonnes.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Our priorities for 2015, this is nothing new. This is how we see this company operates. Naturally, the main fact we  want to deliver growth on the assets which we have which have had the capital spend. McArthur River is ramping  up. It's performing well. Katanga, we believe we will hit the 27 0,000 tonnes annualized tonnes by third  quarter of  this year. So that operation is sorting out its previous difficulties on the power, et cetera. Telis can talk in more  detail if there are any questions on Katanga's performance but we will ramp it up to full phase, to full production  capacity by third quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Koniambo is still an ongoing issue on the plant. It is a large plant which has been bought. You know it is a  greenfield project. You know a feeling on greenfield projects and we are experiencing the difficulties with this  greenfield project. It is the one we inherited, but we got to work through the problems on that. And Kenny is  available here and Peter Johnston on any questions on Koniambo.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Chad oil, in – within the Glencore philosophy, it is a big reserve. It's a reserve for the future. We have cut back on  capital expenditure there. And while the oil prices are where they are, we'll limit the expansion profile on that and  when markets turn, we can increase it. The oil is in the ground. It's not going anywhere. The same like  we talk  about coal. We're not going to dig the material out of the ground if we're not generating the right returns we want  as a company. We'd rather leave it in the ground, it's not going anywhere, and dig it out of the ground when it can  generate the returns that we requires in this company.

file: GLENL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 1March2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: Like all other mining companies, we had to reduce our CapEx and very important to reduce the CapEx profile of  the company and in 2015, reduced the CapEx by 31% down to $5.7 billion, and we reduced working capital by $6.6  billion.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: As we said, we would deliver on asset disposals and gave an indication of what asset disposals we would do within  the company. And during 2015, we delivered $1.1 billion of asset disposals. As you are well aware, $900 million of  that is the sale of the precious metals stream from the Antamina mine to Silver Wheaton and some smaller asset  sales, which we did at the small copper operations around the world.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: The good thing about our asset disposals, we are not selling assets which this company does not wish to sell so  precious metals streams, we don't trade the precious metals ourselves. So, it makes good sense to sell these  precious metals streams, bring the cash into the company. And you are aware that we also announced a further  precious metals stream from our other mines in Peru, and we did a $500 million precious metals stream to  Franco-Nevada and that we did during the first months of this year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: We keep emphasizing about our Tier 1  assets. We have a great set of assets, Tier 1 assets. You'll have a look; Steve  will take you through our costs later on and our various assets. Today, copper, we average around about [ph]  $0.104 (6:19) cost of copper production average around all our operations. We'll give you a breakdown of those  operations. And this is the true cash cost of the copper. That's after TCs, after RCs, after delivery charges, et  cetera, taking those necessary adjustments in hand and that gets us down to those levels. We talk about our zinc  production, around about $0.27. Margins on our coal, we'll talk about. Nickel production around about [ph]  $0.0295 (6:49). So, really low-cost producing assets, long-term assets. We definitely have these Tier 1 assets in  our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: What we also said and we spoke about and which we did and we implemented very rapidly, production costs. We  will cut production at our various assets and that's what we're going to do. If our assets don't deliver the right  returns and they're not giving us the returns that we believe those assets deserve, we will cut production. This is  clear. It does two things. First, you are not wasting the asset where you're not getting a decent return. This asset –  this material can be dug out of the ground at a later stage when you get better returns and you get required returns  that you want from these assets. Secondly, and I've been a proponent and I continue to state, there's no reason to  dig more material out of the ground and supply it into an oversupplied market.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: So, hopefully, these type cutbacks have a positive effect on the commodity price and this is what we've done. It's  no secret, we cut large amounts of production at our African copper assets in both Katanga in the DRC, and in  Zambia. And we will be still building these mines and building them up, and then delivering on the production  profiles, we will have a much lower cost when they finally come into operation. And Katanga, we said will come  back into operation in second half 2017. And Mopani will slowly come back when we deliver on these three new  shafts, which we are building. And then, they will be a low-cost producer, and that's when we'll dig this material  out the ground, and hopefully, we will be delivering into a higher-priced copper market, and therefore getting the  right returns on these assets.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: We've spoken about other further smaller asset sales, both Cobar and Lomas Bayas. And those will also occur  during the first half of this year, and we're looking at various other precious metal type transactions, which we can  do at our precious metals operations, which we have around the world.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: There's also various infrastructure-type ideas that we're looking at where we can sell part of infrastructure, and  these are all asset sales which don't affect our ongoing business. They're not asset sales that going to affect our  trading business. Precious metals streams don't affect us. Doing any transactions on the precious metal business  don't affect us because we don't trade precious metals. It's not part of our trading business and it's not affecting  our ongoing business. And as I say, anything we do on the ag sale of the business, on the ag part is really  something for future growth where we're going to bring in partners, and they're going to be strong partners where  we can utilize that to grow the company going forward.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.text: On another note, our sustainability and governance, regrettably, we've had 10 fatalities at our operations around  the world. Once again, we have certain focus assets, which we've got to focus safety in this company, because of  these 10 fatalities, seven of these fatalities occurred at our focus assets. And six of them, in fact, occurred at our  African operations in Mopani.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, that's kept overall EBITDA down to 32% or so, and that follows the cash flow during the business as well,  which is then EBITDA 32%, the cash flow then down 35% or so, which, again, relative to peers, relative to  industries, the overall portfolio we've seen reductions in, of course, copper and nickel where you've seen  reductions of anywhere between 40% and 50%, but coal actually held up reasonably well for us industrially in  2015. We'll see those numbers which was only down about 14%. EBIT, of course, is going to take a hit given the  fixed nature of the depreciation charge. Right around $6.5 billion of depreciation come through in 2015.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And the other amount contributing to the exceptional charge was the loss from dec onsolidation of Optimum Coal.  That, of course, was a sort of second half last year saga, if you can call it that, in South Africa, and the asset  through its domestic coal challenges went into business rescue. As you all know, it's since been sold, and we'v e  deconsolidated that. So, that's out of the books. And the net effect was around $600 million on that, although we  do show close to $1 billion because there was an FX loss that was booked in previous years, translation loss that  had to be recycled back through the P&L. So, those three amounts, if you think Optimum upstream E&P and  Koniambo account for the vast majority of NAV exceptional charges as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: But part of the reflection down to the range of $2.4 billion to $2.7 billion is a reflection of then the low working  capital levels and the impact that that will have at EBIT but, of course, less tax, less interest, and that was clearly  the more marginal business. As I stood up here I think last time and I said yes we can bring working cap ital down.  What would the impact be? Some impact but not a very material magnitude so as to affect that business in terms  of its core earnings, its core franchise value and the likes as we move forward. So, the oil business, in terms of any  particular comments, of course, oil had a good year. It was flagged already, I think, this time last year to say that  we were looking towards a good 2015 the way that was shaping up in terms of oil.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, above average performance there, but by the same token there were a few commodities that flagged aluminum  particularly in the first half, coal generally in terms of market conditions in 2015 that would've performed below  cruising speed. So, as we sort of go into this year, can oil hold its levels of last year? Maybe, maybe not, but you've  got the slack. That's clearly going to pick up in some of the other commodities that are looking to sort of gear up  hopefully back to a more normal contribution as well. So, very comfortable and, again, shows the strength of that  model and the diversification across what's ultimately 91 different profit centers that we have within those core  segments. So agricultural, there's probably 15 different products. Within oil, there must be 20 different products.  Coal is multiple segmentations. Copper and zinc is metals, concentrates, blisters, all sorts of stuff as well what we  have.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: On the industrial side, of course, this is where the big impacts where and this is where, of course, you've seen some  earnings and cash flow contraction just through the lower prices. But again a little bit of containment through a lot  of diversification there that EBITDA fell 38%, but energy was much more contained for us which is primarily our  big coal businesses, small oil business as well. That itself was only down 14% in coal down 20% overall in energy  and that was a function of pricing environment that was a bit more stable.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Of course, you see some gyrations in derivative markets, but that's not how a lot of pricing in the coal business is  done through annual contracts, Japanese contracts, premium business, domestic business in various countries as  well. So, the coal business had a very strong and focused relentless cost out – cost reduction program you'll see in  the chart that we have later on. We'll see some of the cost savings. A lot of that in fact came from the coal business,  and they continue to make good strides in that as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And even in the metals and minerals, of course, you've got the likes of copper and nickel in particular that came  off, but something like ferroalloys for us and zinc. We're far more stable in terms of those particular products. And  now, we're starting to see some byproduct credit enhancements as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: On that $5.8 billion, just a little bit of background into that. You've got $4 billion of that from metals, and copper  $2.2 billion, zinc $0.8 billion, nickel $0.7 billion, alloy is $0.3 billion, and the energy was $1.7 billion pricing  impact, with coal $1.3 billion, and oil was $0.4 billion.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The volume side, this is where we slammed on the brakes across the business, as well, would've been a bit higher  but, clearly, thinking that that's a sensible proposition both in oil, in coal, in zinc and copper having particularly  sort of curtailed production, both through some higher cost production. But in some cases through also curtailing  profitable production particularly in zinc and coal around being able to sensibly manage supply/demand over a  period of time, exactly what Ivan said. So, the net effect on volume was a little bit higher on oil and a little bit  lower on coal. And you've seen some of those volume statistics.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: On cost, $643 million of cost savings. As I said, a lot of that came from the coal business, about $0.5 million, with  about $150 million on the metals side. The metals story doesn't tell the full picture because there is then some  significant savings we'll see over in one of the slides of some unit cost reductions happening in our various assets  as well. But you can have year-on-year movements particularly in operation like Alumbrera. And we'll also explain  why Alumbrera looks very different between 2015 and 2016. It went through a period in 2015 of much lower  grades and higher investment generally in that business, so its unit cost was naturally higher.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: But now, it's going to jump the other way. We'll see that in terms of the copper cost out. But that's really just got a  year or two left in terms of life. So it's very variable. And your cost movements are really ramping down. But this  particular year 2015 saw a high unit cost as you then need to access what we're now doing is just pulling out  material for cash as we move forward. So, Alumbrera itself was actually a negative $150 million in there in terms  of cost out. So, you sort of keep adding some of the positive cost outs that we've got as well. And we'll see a big step  down in unit cost in 2015 to 2016.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, exactly as Ivan said around the [ph] $.104 (32:22) compared to maybe some other numbers that you may see,  that's a fully baked in number including all TC/RCs, freight charges, everything else that would drive EBITDA,  headline EBITDA within that particular business based on the number of tonnes that we are producing in those  commodities. And we gave the denomination at the bottom. Of course, we produce – our zinc assets also produce  some copper. So, we've said for copper take the guidance of the 1.39kt and then take out 150,000 tonnes of copper  that comes from a little bit in nickel, a little bit in zinc, and you take the spot prices that are there at the moment  pick you a number at a positive [ph] $1.04 (33:03) copper, you're looking at on a spot base around $2.8 billion of  EBITDA at the moment.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, if we work through all those numbers and it's similar across zinc, coal. We've done it on a margin per tonn e  basis in coal. As you would appreciate, there is export business. There's some domestic business. There's some  coking coal business that we have as well. So, that is an off working – off a Newcastle spot of a few days ago. I  think it's ticked maybe up to about $50 or so now and just taking down there and looking at over 130 million  tonnes of production at $10 a tonne margin you're looking about a $1.3 billion blended margin across our entire  portfolio. Of course, there's tonnes that are generating much higher, sometimes generating much less, but that's a  good way of looking at calculating it.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Now, how is that up? We had $2.3 billion at December, so we've added $700 million spot cash flow, $300 million  of course come through CapEx reduction and the sort of $700 million, $800 million on the EBITDA side, $7.7  billion up to $8.1 billion, the $400 million has come through some lower cost reductions but also – and part of  those lower cost reductions is some byproduct benefits that we've got from gold and silver in particular. When we  were back in December, I think gold was maybe $11.20, $11.30 – about $10.40, $10.50, it's around $11.50. Silver  was maybe $1 or $2 a pound less as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: $2.7 billion at current volume should be a level at which we can sustain this business into perpetuity at the current  level assuming that level of production. Of course, if we were to – there is latent capacity in coal, cooper, zinc as  and when subject to market conditions. Some of those tonnes were to find their way back in the market, of course,  that's going to creep back up. But at that point, it'll only be done with an eye on what's the cash flow enhancement  of doing that, what's the NPV of doing that, can the market – is it going to be supportive to the overall businesses  as well. So, I think we'll take a responsible and disciplined approach towards bringing back supplies moving  forward.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Some of that has partially reversed out in the second half to the tune of about $1 billion as well. So, pretty close on  those sort of numbers as well. Just in terms of RMI, what we flagged as well there is that we  have – part of our – a  big part of – particularly in the metals side of Glencore's trading environment and its trading tools is its custom  smelters. It applies to zinc, it applies to copper, it applies to nickel. These are not the industrial assets in a s ense  that we have the mining guy responsible, they're actually managed and fully controlled commercially and  managerially out of the headquarters in Switzerland.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, whereas, historically, we would have – there was a bit more of an arbitrary allocation to some of the – in terms  of non-RMI. If there was some inventory that was owned by a smelter, it just came up out of our systems  arbitrarily because it's an industrial entity. We're going to treat it as non-RMI, whereas now we've had a closer  look at the nature of that material, how it actually works and particularly in the early part of 2016 what sort of was  a catalyst if you like to, making sure we've got it right in this area. Because they were sort of – I mean, each day is  really good. Glencore might be buying and selling product to these entities and suddenly you had a tonne of metal  or a tonne of concentrate was from one day to the next is becoming RMI, not RMI because of that arbitrary  allocation that we're doing across the board.

file: GLENL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call Preliminary 23February2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: And as you can see, we have Tier 1 assets. Look at our copper assets, we're producing copper after the by - product credits of cobalt, et cetera, at $0.87 per pound. Our zinc, after the gold credit, you can see at minus $0.05  per pound; nickel at $2.65 and our thermal coal roundabout $39 and that's giving an $18 margin during 2016.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The same cost structures were slightly increased as I expected to be sustained into 2017. Steve will give you  further details on that where we expect them during 2017. And naturally with the higher coal prices, we will have  higher margins on the coal with the cost came up slightly to $44.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Ivan mentioned a strong 2016 financial performance. Across the board, industrial marketing, the debt reduction,  the asset disposal program, that, of course, delivered as well, the cost positioning, which is being cemented in.  We've seen strong improvements 2015 to 2016 in particularly the base metals. Coal margin improving, that's  always a balance between cost and margin as you look to obviously go and mine different segments and different  coal qualities. And we look at that business in as much as cost, but it's equally important from a margin  perspective.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: But across the metals and mining, of the $2 billion, if we break up the waterfall components, all the volume of that  $0.5 million to $500 million was in respect of the metals business. We've given some components of that cobalt at  Mutanda. In terms of that additional volumes, we saw 25,000 tonnes of cobalt come out there, an extra 8,000  tonnes or 48% increase in the cobalt. And it really does underpin on it, post by-product basis, the lowering of the  cash flow structures we see over at Mutanda.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: That was a big – in terms of the mix of businesses as we move towards that, we sort of speak about higher- margin businesses in the section. That's really been a feature of Glencore without necessarily putting more  volumes. We've been very disciplined around supply constraint, but where we've been able to within the coal  segments, with the copper, within the zinc, within by-products, ferrochromes, some of these things we've been  able to enjoy quite strong margin selectively. And cobalt was a big contributor there. Nickel at INO, we've seen the  extra volumes come through there. It was a function of the maintenance period on nickel in 2015.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: If we then move to reinforce some of those cost structures that we're speaking about that have been coming in a  lot over the years, particularly in copper, zinc. Nickel, despite some grade declines, has also been holding quite  well in terms of cost structures. That's been bedded in, those are sustainable as we also look forward to 2017,  reflecting the volumes and cost structures. We've updated the guidance of 2017 two months after the December  2016 guidance. And in all cases, except coal, which I'll speak to you, we've actually seen a further lowering down  in guidance there. So, copper, I think we're about $0.94 back in December for 2017. We're now looking at $0.89,  very much helped, as I said, by some of those by-product credits coming in the copper.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, cobalt, for those watching, that part of the market, just in the last six weeks or so, has doubled in price from a  little over $10 a pound up to trading about $20 at the moment. We produced 30,000 tonnes of cobalt when  Katanga is up and running. In 2018, our overall cobalt production goes into the 50,000 to 60,000 range. For us,  sensitivities to different commodities, cobalt has now eclipsed nickel and ferrochrome and the likes. It's number  four in the pecking order of the coal, copper and zinc at the moment. And it's definitely a commodity that's  enjoying its stay in the sun at the moment.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, that's helping that on the zinc side, we got further into negative territory given by-product credits on the  precious gold and silver. As I said before, lead is an important by-product. We produce 300,000 tonnes of lead,  one of the largest lead producers. That's primarily a by-product all out of our zinc operations as well. Prices on  lead were up 5% in 2016 and 2015. And where we sit at the moment, spot today is 22%; the price on lead higher  than what 2016's average. And all that's coming through in terms of reducing overall cost within our zinc business.  That's a quality business at the moment.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: By-product is also helping the nickel business. We were higher at – previously, a few months ago, we were  showing a tick up in unit cost in the nickel business. For 2017, it's now actually come back to the $248. Again,  you've got cobalt and copper in particular coming out of Australia and Canada in those particular businesses.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Just to dwell on coal a little bit as well. Coal, up to $44. Again, as I said, we focus that business more on a margin  basis as well, so we've seen a slight tick up in margin, which is part price-driven, as you obviously prioritize that.  You've also got some cost impact in coal on revenue-linked aspects that – particularly royalties in Australia,  Colombia and others that the high prices you're paying more, it's a variable, ad valorem-type royalty structure that  you have there.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, you're getting a pickup of a sort of $1 or $2 in cost, extra costs that's coming there by virtue of the pickup in  prices, the coking coal, the thermal coal and the likes. You're also seeing – just given the size of the operational  cost base, we've seen a little bit of [ph] give back (19:17) of some of those FX headwinds that we set into 2016- 2017. Since December, we've seen a slight pickup in Aussie. Rand strengthened a bit. Colombia has also  strengthened a bit in currencies there. So, that accounts for $1 or $2.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: What they have identified in coal in particular just, again, given the size and scale, number of operations,  operational footprints, synergies, the whole supply chain, they've identified a further $300 million of savings  through a quite an extensive coal. You can see a cost-out/margin-up, COMU project that they've initiated as a  whole range of projects they will then look to execute. These are bankable, these are deliverable, and they'll look  to bring those annual sustainable cash flow benefits of $300 million-plus. By the end of 2018, you take that over  135 million tonnes, that of itself should bring down unit cost around about sort of $225 or so per tonne as we look  to execute on those.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: This is partly explain where we are today also in terms of industrial footprint, sustainability, well-capitalized  business as well. When you spend $64 billion over the last eight years, 2009 to 2016, $38 billion of expansionary  CapEx, $64 billion all-in including sustaining, averaging over $8 billion a year in terms of CapEx, you've now got a  business and a lot of that did come through the, obviously, Xstrata's CapEx program through the sort of 2011,  2012, 2013 year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: It's essentially complete now, but across zinc, coal, copper, nickel and the likes, you've got very well-capitalized  business as the net does feed into some of the guidance that one can now give in CapEx and how those costs so  people try to – well, why use depreciation and your CapEx and why is that out. There's a lot of reasons why cost  different structures and things were different in our $8 billion in 2016. I wouldn't look as to why depreciation is $6  billion and CapEx is $4 billion. It is what it is and that's how it's going to play out over the future.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, our CapEx in 2016 came in at industrial $3.4 billion, down 40-odd percent from the 2015, being in line with our  guidance. We've said 2017 unchanged from December 2016, $4 billion, wrapping up some of the projects that are  still working their way through the transformation phases, particularly African copper. We got Katanga, as they go  through Whole Ore Leach, look to commission by the end of this year, bring back tonnes, obviously, in 2018.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, that should be sufficient in the next three to five years. That would be sufficient to allow for the levels for the  full recommissioning of the full African copper volumes, which we spoke about close to 400,000 – 350,000 tonnes  to 400,000 tonnes there. And EBIT within there, there'll be questions I'm sure later on on zinc, but as and when  some of those tonnes potentially come back on some staggered basis, there's almost no CapEx, or very little  CapEx ultimately when those come back. So, even these levels could allow for quite decent volumetric pickups  across the businesses as well.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: And with, obviously, things that we've done in blue boxes and the red boxes, those are things that ultimately  support that. So, M&A and other doesn't mean money going out. It also means money could come in, and that's  where disposals, monetizations, recycling – Glencore tends to do a lot in our portfolio. We're still looking at areas  of the portfolio where we think that we can unlock values, too, within the business. So, potentially, watch that  space.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: In 2016, we looked at most of the commodity's consumption, was up in China, was up 4%, 5%. If we take copper,  it was up 4%. If we take zinc, it was up around about 3.7%, 4%. If we take nickel, it was up around about 10%,  11%. And in the stainless steel market, et cetera, the demand has been pretty good. And that's what we've been  saying for a while, it's not the demand side we should be worrying about, it's the supply side.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, in the last 24 months, and recently, we've seen better commodity prices. Why we have better commodity  prices? It was because suddenly, supply, there wasn't this new massive increase on supply. We saw voluntary  cutbacks; ourselves, one of the leaders in that area. It's clear we cut back zinc production. We cut back 500,000  tonnes of zinc production. From 5 million tonnes, we brought it down to 1 million tonnes. We cut back our copper  production. We cut back copper in Katanga and Mopani, and we pulled that back, and we pulled back some of our  coal production in Australia and various other parts of the world.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: And that had a very positive effect. We know when we cut back on zinc, I think the zinc price was roundabout  $1,600 at the time we did the cutback. We now know zinc is right about $2,900, very positive effect. The same  with copper. Okay, we know 300,000, 400,000 tonnes of copper is not as big as in the 23 million-tonne market.  But no doubt, it also had an effect. And the same goes with coal.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Now, what also had a favorable effect on commodities was a lot of [indiscernible] (32:28). We were one of the few  guys who did it voluntary. Other people had involuntary CapEx, which in the end really helped them, whether it  was strikes or it was technical issues. I don't want to go into the various operations. We all know [indiscernible]  (32:42) technical issues, and a large amount of tonnes was pulled out of their own production. But if you do the  calculations, a bit like what we did in zinc, when we cut back our zinc production, we looked at the benefit it had  on the rest of our zinc production. So, we cut back 500,000 tonnes. There's 1 million tonnes there. The zinc price  had to move a certain amount for you to get the benefit of your 1 million tonnes, so you got the benefit on the  other tonnes.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The other thing that had an effect on pricing, which as I've always said, China. We don't understand China exactly  what may or may not happen from one day to the next. And we all saw it in coal last year. The Chinese do have  the ability, they can coordinate their cutbacks. [ph] They don't have like us (33:53) with antitrust. We can't agree  with other producers, but they can. They control most of the coal mines in China. And the ones they don't control,  they can put a [indiscernible] (34:02), which they did, and the coal prices were very low in China. The coal mines  are losing money.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: What did the Chinese decide to do one day to the next? I don't think any of us in this room saw it coming,  ourselves included. And, suddenly, the Chinese decided they didn't like these low coal prices and they cut their  working days from 330 days to 276 days within a week, and they implemented it very quickly. And we saw the  effect that supply cutbacks can have on coal prices and what they did to the coal prices in China and took it up to  about RMB 600.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We also know during the tough times, producers were high-grading mines, we know for sure. And the coal market  in Indonesia, for example, and many other places, people were higher-grading. Eventually, that catches up on you  and that's going to affect supply going into the future. So, we think supply is going to be hindered in the future, so  we are in a pretty good position at the moment.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: And the chart at the top, the fundamentals. You can see what is happening with the supply, what happened with  the supply in 2016 if we take copper and iron ore as an example. And the so-called – what people have missed –  I think got wrong. In 2016, we all heard of the copper wall of supply, the massive wall of supply, and we were  going to get new tonnes of – a bigger mine of copper coming into the system.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The other graph quite interesting below, if you have a look and they're saying, I've been in the industry for a long  time, it's very few times I've seen no new big mine being planned to be bought. Yes, there are some of the  existing mines, they're not being finished around the world with a copper, zinc, et cetera. Mines which are being  bought, they're now going to come to them to be bought and they'll be in production shortly, but there's no big  mine plans around the world and that's an interesting graph. If you look at the pipeline of highly-probable copper  mines at the end of 2016, it's now almost half of the pre-super cycle in 2001.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We thought we'd just put a slide on about Glencore's coal portfolio. We are the biggest producer of seaborne coal  in the world. We've had the discussions of so-called stranded asset, that coal will not be consumed in the future  and will decrease, et cetera. So, we thought we'd put a slide to give an idea. Now, we all hear about demand  decreasing of coal consumption in Europe, et cetera, seaborne coal going down, which is correct. And as you'll  see from this slide in the right, in North America, in Europe, the consumption of coal is decreasing. However, the  consumption of coal in installed coal generating capacity in Asia, you do see new installed coal capacity going up  and that will need more coal going into the future.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: However, we do know these renewables in the other forms of coals, energy production, et cetera, renewables,  solar, wind, et cetera, and that is increasing and we don't like that. But if you have a look between 2013 and 2030,  the billion tonnes of coal equivalent being consumed in the world, even though coal is decreasing – no doubt, coal  is decreasing, it is going down from 29% or the world's energy generation down to 25%. However, in absolute  numbers, we are going to still burn more coal in the world and we're going from 5.6 billion tonnes of coal being  burned in the world, to 5.8 billion because of the new installed generating capacity, which is required in the world.  So, therefore, coal will be resilient for the future. We do have this new bottom which has been set in coal by the  Chinese.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The Chinese have said they want to set the coal price around about RMB 550. Going forward, actually, they want  to keep it and we've seen the Chinese can do that, they can control it. We've seen what they've done from the  330 to the 276-day work productions during the year. We've seen every week that we get more and more talk  about it, when they're going pull it back, when they're going to let it go, where they're going to keep the coal price.  But it's clear, they want to keep it at RMB 550. That's what we sort of get the feeling where they want to keep it.  What does that translate to? That translates to roundabout, if you take our top coals, we produce the better quality  coals in Australia, South Africa, Colombia. In Australia, it goes back to new cost of coal roundabout $73. That's a  pretty good price for us going forward into the future.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Once again, we believe we've got the right commodity mix, especially key supply and good commodity is used for  electric vehicles. We're a big supplier of cobalt and nickel, and we believe that is going to bode well for the future.  Even if you just look at nickel today, 100,000 tonnes of nickel is being consumed in the battery industry. Going  forward, we believe at least 300,000 to 400,000 tonnes of nickel will be consumed in that industry. And as you  know, the market is about 2 million tonnes today, total nickel market, so that should bode well for the future.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We're in the mid or late-cycle commodities such as copper, zinc and thermal coal. So, therefore, even towards –  when China is not getting bolt-on and move to second chart, rate commodities, we're in the right place for them.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We have expansion – significant growth potential still to come on stream, as you know. We've discussed Katanga  will come on stream [ph] on that (43:03) 300,000 tonnes of copper during – we will start that up in 2018 and it will  move its way into full production between 2018 and 2019. So, Katanga will be coming on stream then. Mopani will  come on stream – the balance of Mopani, when we are finished building all the shafts, will come on stream  towards the end of 2018. And we have other brownfields which we could add when the time is right.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We're not going to rush to do that. Once again, we are very supply-restraint. We don't want to be the ones forcing  down commodity prices. We don't want to cannibalize our existing base by putting more supply in the market. So,  we will only put supply in the market or develop any brownfield-type operations when we are sure we're not going  to cannibalize or push down prices by existing operations. And that's what I believe is key.

file: GLENL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 21February2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Strong point of Glencore is a strong unit cost and our margin performance has naturally boosted the industrial  earnings and industrial EBITDA is up 60% to $11.5 billion. Our mine unit costs and margins are generally better  than the previous year. And as you can see, our cost of production across the board on our various commodities  is really at the low end of our competitors, et cetera, really Tier 1 assets performing very well on the cost side of  the curve. And post credits, again, copper is $0.87 per pound, zinc negative $0.16 cents per pound post-credits,  $0.10 per pond ex the credit, nickel $1.91, and coal, we're realizing $32 margins. So, exceptionally strong on the  cost performance across the board which, once again, proved to be really have Tier 1 assets, low-cost and long  reserves.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: If you just look historically what we did during the year and improved opportunities presented themselves to us  and we invested $1.6 billion in capital efficient growth. You saw we bought the Volcan stake, we bought the  Mutanda stake, but along the way, we also did other partnership-type transactions and this is the strength of  Glencore because of our relationships across the board, our strong trading activities and our relationship with  various parties around the board. We were able to do these type partnership where we don't give up the entire  asset, we form partnerships, we did the Trevali transaction where we merged our assets into Trevali and we hold  a 25% stake and we have the marketing right. We did oil storage business with HNA, it's now HG Storage and we  own 49%, they have 51%. But we still utilize those storage tanks and we have the benefit of that and we have a  strong partner for future growth in those businesses.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, good performances generally across the board. Energy also solid performances across both coal and oil with  meaningful contributions in that close to $1 billion performance. Pleasingly, we've seen some volume kickers  come through having been a little bit more slow in terms of volume growth and as much as the market itself was  slower, our own suspension and curtailment of some facilities of zinc and copper which we did through 2015 and  2016, ferroalloys, low playing some of those things to some extent. This year, if you look through the marketing  attributes, you can see some good volume growth, copper 14% up, zinc 40% up, ferroalloys 14%, and on the  crude oil side, we saw 33% increase. Of course, transactions and partnerships like we had with Rosneft, and  then, structure with the [indiscernible] (09:40) last year, some of the African business development opportunities  that we've had across the board is contributing meaningfully on the volume side [ph] within the low (09:50).

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: If we just turn over to the industrial side, as Ivan said, we're up 60% to $11.5 billion. We'll look at some cost and  production numbers on the next few slides, as well as you would expect given the scale and franchises we have  particularly in coal and some of the bigger metal businesses, that's where we've seen the increases on that  particular side.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So clearly, higher commodity price is the primary driver. There's no denying that clearly, there's that leverage to  that business. Of course, higher prices is going to have you – what you take in one hand, you're going to give  away a little bit on the other hand through some inflation as those very high commodity prices themselves are  feeding through into some of your input costs. So we are a big consumer and procurer of the likes of diesel and  explosives and general CPI is going to work its way through the system, cost of construction materials, steel  development projects, if you like, as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And of course, price is, as I said, a big factor. You can see on the waterfall chart $6.3 billion of pricing variance  that is made up in the copper/cobalt, which is where that commodity that more than double this year is manifested  in terms of results, that was $1.9 billion, zinc $1.1 billion of price variance, nickel $0.3 billion, ferroalloys $0.4  billion, coal $2.5 billion and other $0.1 billion. So $6.3 billion is clearly the big factor that's gone into those.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The industrial bridge, there were some negative factors, of course, on volume, and cost volume, we – was  primarily copper and coal, 8% down in copper. Factors that have been well reported on and discussed during the  ongoing production performance, we saw lower production through consumable and power available in Africa,  Mutanda and Mopani a little bit as well, Antapaccay, a little bit slower on that side and coal down 3%, primarily  due to weather and strike-related actions. So that clearly is going to have a volume impact and the associated  cost impacts. But you can see in a unit performance, it's still being very solid as we work our way through the  system.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So the near-term volume pickup, which is going to have a factor in terms of both performance EBITDA and value,  is in near term. We've got copper 1,310 kt up to 1,465 kt that's up 12% volume growth, primarily due to Katanga  now coming on line with its first train. 150,000 tonne copper and 11,000 tonnes cobalt. Performance is going.  There's been a successful commissioning down there.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: We've also got material volume growth in cobalt clearly, up 42% this year, 27% to 39% (sic) [27 kt to 39 kt] given  the pricing environment there, that's quite a material catalyst, that's primarily Katanga, 11,000 tonnes, a little bit  over at Mutanda and some of the other operations as well. And coal itself, if we look second from the bottom, up  around 11% from 120 mt to 134 mt. You've got HVO that's baked in there, 49% share which would be between 7  million tonnes and 8 million tonnes on an annualized basis. We'll assume we're going to get about nine months or  so of that coming in, plus the restoring of normal operations, post some more weather and strike-related action  during the course of 2017.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Longer-term which will also feature into some of the modeling and thinking, so you've got more 2017 to 2020  production outlook. At the bottom right, you can see copper, 25%; cobalt, 133%; zinc, 19%; lead, 25%; nickel,  30%; ferrochrome, 6%; coal, 14%; and oil, 39%, so quite material volume growth across all the commodities. We  went through this back in December. I'm not going to repeat it, but you can see the projects. And we did spend a  bit of time on some of the projects and we have a page on each of those to do with Zhairem in Kazakhstan, the  INO on the nickel side, of course, the African businesses as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So if we then jump back to the unit cost, which is clearly a factor as well, you can see some improvements  generally in mine cost and margins across the businesses from 2016 to 2017 and continuing on through 2018.  Some of that is inflationary pressure, some of which is passive. I would regard as this the sort of good inflation,  because it's really getting offset through the price and that's a function of just the CPI impact, the weaker U.S.  dollar on the currency that's coming through, some of the diesel and fuel costs that's coming through, nothing we  can do about that. That's a factor. It's as good as we run the businesses and has good efficiency drive as you do.  You're going to have that coming through, but as I said, you sort of get three in one hand and pay out one in the  other hand.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So copper, we sort of – we were flat unit cost. As we've discussed, this is a feature of Glencore's building blocks  that we've given now over the last few years. These are fully loaded, fully baked in numbers from which to sort of  mathematically calculate the volume times price expectations you have for a full EBITDA. So this captures all the  cash costs, all the ancillaries, all the royalties, all the freight costs, the TC/RCs, the smelting businesses that we  have within the business as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So copper was sort of steady year-on-year, clearly help us some of the by-products both in zinc and cobalt. We've  seen quite a material down shift from $0.87 to $0.80. Katanga, of course, through volume and others is a factor,  by-products is helping there. The only change we've done relative to December is that now Katanga and Mopani  are part of this all-in unit cost blended calculation at the 1.5 million tonnes or so we've done. We previously had it  excluding those given their ramp-up phase and we had a placeholder I think of around $500 million, but that's fully  in those numbers as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The coal, the other big part of the business, now based on some Newcastle benchmarks pricing at the end of  January and our mix, we're looking at around a 37% margin there. You've got some cost increases, but again, it's  really passive coming through royalty-related increases which is based on the price itself, so this is just a flow  through as you add that to the prices as well. We could maybe separately itemize that in the future as well just to  show the linkage against that.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: You've got the higher diesel costs. You've got currency movements clearly that you've seen quite big strength in  rand, which is sort of a double-edged sword there. It's good in terms of what's happening down in the country, but  the strength of the rand is clearly having a material impact down there in a market where it's not necessarily the  price set like it is in ferrochrome. You'd expect ferrochrome potentially to be able to pass that additional cost  benefits on.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Nickel also improving through by-products and some increased volumes which we'll see coming through in 2018  and zinc continues to power along. By-products is a big factor there. Lead and the various precious metals  streams as well. So if we look at actuals and then, later on, on the slide, you'll see illustrative spot generation  using those volumes, you'll see a big shift. We've got copper. $4.4 billion was the EBITDA industrial 2017 going to  $7.1 billion illustratively 2018. Zinc goes $2.6 billion to $3.5 billion. Nickel $0.6 million to $1 billion, which is a nice  movement and starting to present itself in a more positive light. And coal $3.9 billion up to about $5 billion as well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Just to spend a couple of minutes just on RMI, you would have seen that go up the sort of $5 billion. If you looked  at pricing movements during the course of 2017 from the start of the year to the end of the year, collectively, you  would have to come up with a number that says it's not going to stay at 2017. We've got prices in our core  commodities. Copper was up 30% during the year start to finish, zinc 30%, cobalt 130%, aluminum 32%, nickel  28%, lead 24%, oil about 25%. These are big movements. They all blend out to anywhere between 25% and  30%.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: If prices stay where they sort of are at the end of January driving that $19.7 billion of spot EBITDA where we're  generating about free cash flow towards the $10 billion, there'd be no reason and nor would we allow RMI to sort  of go up from these levels. If anything, I think that's a cyclical cap. If prices go up, copper is $10,000, oil is $140,  well, different story, you are better off. You're going to see that, but our EBITDA will be $25 billion or so at that  stage.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We're the most exposed to the mid or late cycle commodities and it's clear that's the area we're moving into. So  we're going into the mid cycle commodities: copper, zinc, nickel, aluminum, and the late cycle commodities:  cobalt, thermal coal, agricultural products. We don't have PGMs and diamonds, but we definitely have a  compelling commodity mix.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: And breaking down the different commodities, if we look at where the markets are sitting, et cetera, copper, it's  clear there's a looming supply challenge. We all know that demand for copper is going to go up whilst the copper  market today roundabout 23 million tonnes, if we get 2%, 3% growth around the world, it's what happens in China,  right, you're talking about another 500,000 tonnes, 600,000 tonnes of copper required per year.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Cobalt, it's clear, the electric vehicle story. We all know the studies that have been done on the growth of electric  vehicles and where it will end up being. We've seen investments that motor car companies are making in electric  vehicles and they will need battery supply, so the demand for electric vehicles is strong. It will require a lot of  cobalt and we all know the geological scarcity of cobalt. You can't mine pure cobalt. It's not like lithium. It's a by- product mainly of copper and nickel around the world and the bulk of it comes from the DRC. So we know the  demand for cobalt and this as an alternative method of making batteries will be strong and the supply is relatively  constrained.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Zinc, demand is increasing in the emerging markets. We know that we're galvanizing and there's been an  underinvestment in new zinc mines. The growth that we were expecting in China did not occur because of the  environmental restrictions taking place at the zinc mines in China. So therefore, the big growth that people are  thinking would come in zinc is not coming and the demand grows. So once again, the commodity we believe there  are supply restraints.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Lead. The same applies to lead, with the robust battery and energy storage dynamics and once again, mainly  also a by-product of the zinc mines underinvestments and, once again, the environmental restrictions which are  occurring in China.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Nickel, demand, once again, electric vehicle batteries, critical alloys, austenitic stainless steel growth, et cetera,  that's occurring in the world. And once again, no nickel mine has been opened around the world. But what you're  getting in Indonesia, the pig iron production that's occurring, nickel pig iron occurring in Indonesia, but it's taking  time and not growing as fast as people expected, so limited supply coming in nickel.
