texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Sulfides are declining around the world. So therefore, we see it already there's a shortage with reducing the  stockpiles around the world and we believe there's going to be an undersupply once again during this year and  we're going to have to reduce the stockpiles around the world in order to feed the demand for nickel that's  occurring around in the market. So once again, undersupply there.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Thermal coal, I know this is not a loved commodity, but once again, it is powering the Asian growth and  urbanization which is occurring in the emerging markets. Demand continues to grow in emerging markets. And  once again, underinvestment in supply, you don't see new coal mines being built around the world. And where  you do see the increase of new production of coal, it is occurring in Indonesia. However, in volume terms in metric  tonnes, it is growing, but in heating value, in fact, there is no growth, because we're getting decline in caloric value  being mined from these various mines and the CV is reducing considerably. So really, when you see production  increase, it's not really heating value increase which the world needs.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So looks very good. Also, we see what's happening in China where they did restrict the amount of coal being  produced because of the pricing. We now have higher prices in China. It's that they put a cap on roundabout RMB  750, that accounts, if you work back and do the adjustments for quality, it gets back to Australia roundabout $100  if they maintain the RMB 750 in China.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So looking pretty strong in thermal coal and one thing I emphasize, you got to remember there's no new mines  being produced around the world or developed besides in Indonesia, which is lower heating value and you do  have decline in production, because the mines eventually will come to an end and they have a life of 20, 25 years  and some of them are soon coming to an end. So we see it in South Africa, we see it in various parts of the world  where you will have reduction of coal production occurring there.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We are today, and you saw the numbers, Steve showed the production numbers going forward whereby copper  will grow to 1.6 million tonnes, coal 134 million tonnes, cobalt 65,000 tonnes. So really, we are the major producer  of cobalt in the world. Cobalt, zinc, nickel, we may – a bit lower, down number three, thermal coal, seaborne  thermal coal, the largest in the world. So we're really a major producer of what I believe are the Tier 1 right  commodities that the world is going to need going forward.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The big feature, as we said, at today's spot prices or one call the forward curve, more towards the forward curve  on the coal price, we would generate roundabout $19.7 billion of EBITDA, generate $9.6 billion of free cash and  that's how we look for 2018, posted out to 2019, as Steve indicated, with higher production figures that are  occurring in 2019 that will even be higher than that level. So very cash generative at current commodity prices  and very high EBITDA going forward.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: What's happening in the electric vehicle industry? We're the best place for that out of all the large caps. We get  the advantage what's going to happen in electric vehicles with the demand that's required for them in copper,  cobalt and nickel. Cash generative, unique business model, as I said, Tier 1 industrial assets, very low cost  producing, long-term life, marketing highly generative, and once again, emphasize how the EBITDA will look  during this year at these current commodity prices and the free cash flow that is going to generate.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We look at growth. We don't just look at growth for growth's sake. It's going to be cash flow generative and when  we look at cash flow, we will look to grow our business that's why we are more M&A rather than building  greenfields. You know my feeling about building new assets and greenfields. You don't get the cash flow for a  while and eventually, when you do get it, you may have overspent, and it doesn't generate the returns you want.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: We've always said we – we'll cut back capacity. We think we're oversupplying the market and we'll do the same  on the other side, and we'll reactivate the idle capacity as you saw we did with our zinc operations when we  believe it's appropriate. We have a lot of low cost brownfield options that we can add to our existing business.  Bolt-on acquisitions, we always look at different synergies, we can have with next door neighbors.

file: GLENL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 20February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Going to sustainability, as you can see, unfortunately we had 13 fatalities at operations around the world. We  continue working on this area and we're spending a lot of time. However, we still have a large amount of  underground mines in difficult regions of the world, which is taking time to ensure that we're running those mines  safely and to ensure there are no fatalities to aim for zero fatalities at all our operations around the year. So, it's a  continuing effort by the group, and hopefully we will get there as we move forward.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Once again, climate change, furthering our commitment to the transition to a low carbon economy. We believe the  company is well-placed in this area. We have the right commodities, and as you are aware, cobalt, zinc, nickel,  copper, which is a complement for battery supply, and we continue to grow and hopefully grow in those areas  which we aim to capitalize on there, which is as we move the energy and mobility transition into electric vehicles,  we will be at the forefront producing the commodities in that area.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: What we have also done, we will limit our coal production capacity broadly to current levels, and as you are  aware, we're producing around about to have capacity for about 150 million tonnes of steam coal, and we have  agreed that we will limit it to that amount of tonnage going forward, and we will not increase that tonnages of  thermal coal produced by the group on a future basis.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: Coming to Tailings Storage Facility management amongst the group, we moved in this area in 2014 after the  Mount Polley incident. We appointed a team to review all our tailings dams around the world. We had a person  who heads up this tailings facilities and the investigation of all our tailings facilities around the world. And we  worked aggressively from 2014 after the Mount Polley incident.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: This company is working with us, and they will continue working with us reviewing all our dams on an ongoing  basis, and we'll review every dam and continue to review them with this group over a yearly basis. And we  believe, over a 12 to 18-month period, they'll be able to review each dam again and again over that period. And  that gives you an idea of the dams we have, which are upstream dams, which are centerline and downstream  dams, which are active and non-active. And naturally, we are aware that problem dams are potentially the  upstream dams, and you will see if we got the 51%, 31% of those are active and that represents around about 22  of our tailings dams around the world which are upstream, and we're working very closely to monitor those and  ensure that they are safe.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: But strong cash flow generation, obviously, as Ivan said. Funds from operation up at $11.6 billion, that gives us  the capacity to fund the business, spend the CapEx, do any M&A. It was a period during last year where there  was a handful of announced acquisitions, probably more back in beginning of 2018, almost into 2017. We've sort  of gone through all the funding and the commitments associated. So we do start the year now 2019 in terms of  cash flow generation that can be applied more generously towards share returns. But I think the M&A, objectively  looking at some of the coal acquisitions, expansions in zinc in a constructive commodity and some of the  longevity and optionality that Volcan is going to give us in zinc, and some of the downstream plays we've had in  oil, I think it sets the business up nicely in terms of its cash flow generation as well, but we start the year 2019 sort  of unhinged in terms of any previous commitments on M&A.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Net income, as Ivan said, it was around $2.4 billion what we'd call significant items, most of that impairments, $1.6  billion at the time, flagging Mopani, $800 million; Mutanda, $600 million as the two. There is sort of chapter and  verse of that in the financials. By all means go and have a look at that. We show the reasons, the sensitivity to  various macro and micro assumptions have gone into that. Of course, Mining Codes impacted the margins at  Mutanda and the oxide sulfides, that sort of $600 million impact there, Mopani, even the asset price assumptions,  it was quite a big value driver there. It has a smelter producing asset, we think the regional balance is going to  deteriorate in favor of lower prices, including ourselves building an acid plant at Katanga, which would obviously  makes sense for that operation, but that was a change on a – that happened at Mopani.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: If you look at the contribution between two, that was up 15%. Metals and minerals overall still dominates across  the main commodities, the copper, zinc, nickel, alloys and the like, but the big increase has come through – has  come in the increase on the particularly the coal contribution, higher prices plus the contributions from the  acquisitions during the year, the HVO, the Hail Creek.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Cash margins, EBITDA margins, mining margins, very healthy. If you can see in the graph on the right, the coal  side which contributes the 46% there, so good buffers around the cash generation there.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: This chart would look pretty similar across the industry on the industrial side, where did we see the movement  2017 to 2018. Price helped clearly during the year. Some point – hopefully we're sort of mid-cycle, and we can  see that continue to improve across various commodities. Copper, nickel, cobalt, we've given some increases  there. Cobalt was a tale of two halves. We'll speak about that later on as well. The average happened to be 32%,  but compared to middle to end of the year, it was off 50%, and that's continuing to be a drag today in a relative  sense in the cost structure on cobalt.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: But from the $2.1 billion, the copper-cobalt $0.6 billion, nickel $0.3 billion, coal $0.9 billion contributed the major  aspects of the increases. On the volume side, some small impacts, you'll see some volume trajectory going  forward, that will be a tailwind going forward across various aspects of our business, but again copper cobalt,  particularly Katanga, the coal M&A would have had positive contributions. That's cost including inflation. In the  past, we've broken inflation out. Inflation would be about just sort of – the sort of automatic CPI linked inflation that  tends to apply across most consumer price increases would have been about $500 million of that $1.347 billion,  you've got some relief clearly on currencies.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Clearly, higher energy and commodity input costs. So as much as we got oil price, on the left you can see up  31%. We're both a producer, but we're actually a larger – a much larger consumer than we are a producer  currently in the oil business, so that's coming through in the diesel, various other input costs reagents, asset  prices, these are all across the different businesses, lower grades, lower smelting custom profitability that should  turn around this year, particularly in our the copper business. That comes through the cost line as well and of  course to the extent that there's higher royalties linked to the higher prices, that will flow through that number as  well.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: A few things to flag, we have had higher production which clearly helped on the Katanga side, that journey  continues. That was the first year of a line 1, 140,000 – 150,000-odd of copper and a little bit of cobalt as well.  This year is the year of taking that operation up to its capacity close to the 300,000 tonnes copper and around  26,000 tonnes cobalt, so that will have a positive bearing on our overall footprint.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: A few factors to – at the EBITDA, a few opportunity costs was the timing of sales versus production both in copper  of about 22,000 tonnes. But more importantly, the cobalt currently that's stockpiling with the excess levels of  uranium to be at Katanga just in the year 2018 alone, we got 3,900 tonnes of cobalt which even at the poor  margins, spot margin environment of cobalt at the end of December had an EBITDA opportunity cost to us of  about $134 million. So, that's just being stockpiled in anticipation of the [indiscernible] (00:15:48) plant and the  various other treatment initiatives.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Katanga also, if they haven't already, there's going to be their own release before Canadian market goes up,  which will clearly go into more chapter and verse around what's going on around cobalt and particularly around  suspension in the uranium and how to treat that. And now, that project is clearly going. So, all the costs around  2018 is broadly where we said at the – towards the end of last year. Copper is $1.04, we guided to $1.03 at the  end of last year, and they all come in pretty close to where we said.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Increases, year-on-year, 2017 to 2018 has clearly been impacted by DRC Mining Code, higher energy costs, and  that sales versus production variance, which at some point is going to catch up. We'll see the evolution more as  we go from 2018 to 2019 as we go across.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And cobalt was sort of a double punch if you like for us during the sort of from about August, September, October  towards the end of the year in a variety of factors. We've had some Chinese non-performance. We spoke about  that as well around certain fixed price realizations on hydroxide. We did have to sit around the table and reset  some of those. Hopefully, this swings and roundabouts around that over a longer term cycle. Cobalt is going to  have its day in the sun again, but we clearly had to take that performance risk.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: And also, as I flagged within the – back in December, it's a little bit left and right hand, but within the marketing  business, we do have to continuously off-take the material from both Katanga when it's [ph] selling of course  (00:19:03) and obviously Mutanda under those agreements. So, this is coming on to the marketing's books. It's  not an easily hedgeable commodity. It's not a commodity that you can lay off the demand strength today. So you  will have lag effects of having to take material on to your books and you will have some length in cobalt today,  we'd like to have less length, but we do have some length in cobalt. And just in the month of December, you saw  cobalt price has dropped 22% on some index.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Clearly this is not all a realization, that could turn around as well, but that's what have to be absorbed through the  earnings for that particular period. What we've highlighted is the graph on the top right, I think it's interesting to  note that even at $2.4 billion in some historical sense, excluding Agri, which has been a bit noisy from a  comparison perspective and I'll talk about Agri as well at $2.4 billion. It's sort of in the [ph] pattern (00:20:02), last  year particularly good on the Energy side, and we should – the Agricultural side should be at $200 million, which  obviously you've got challenges in that market as well, it's effectively contributed zero, which is the green line.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: CapEx, not much to say, it's largely a rehash of where we were in December we've come in $4.9 billion against  the $4.8 billion, and no changes to guidance around the $4.8 billion average over the next years. [ph] There's a  range of (00:22:23) more brownfield developments now averaging $1.2 billion, as they've all been pretty well  flagged. The only one that's still in a not-approved phase, but we've put it in the highly likely is that Collahuasi mill  expansion to the 170 ktpd. Some of you were over at the site visits, we advised back in December that would be a  potentially around a $200-million commitment. That's what Glencore shared that's not an approved project per se,  but it's been factored in to the as-good-as I guess.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: In terms of balance sheet, finish up before we give you some of the modeling details as well, still a pretty strong  balance sheet in terms of cash flow generation and coverage. We spoke that the net debt – net funding was  actually broadly flat year-on-year, notwithstanding the increase in net debt, about $4.5 billion and that was that  release of the working capital of about $3.5 billion, down to down to $17 billion. So, that's – we still have, I would  say, there's still RMI that can be unlocked in the business in the current commodity price environment, but it's  always subjective. If you're going to see some explosion in metals prices and oil prices clearly go up, you're going  to see just a price variance there, but I think you'll see more than a positive compensation through the spot cash  flow generation, the EBITDA in the business.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: So, it's being – you can see bottom left, I would point towards a range of outcome as probably being something  that's more sensible. So, we said $1.04 is the cost, that's what the actual was in 2018. 2019; anywhere between  $0.92 and $1.25. Now, the spot cash flow illustrate $15.8 billion is the higher cost, $1.25. So we've taken the most  conservative part of that range. What's driving that range, $0.92 to $1.25, cobalt. There's nothing else that's  driving that range. So, at the bottom end of the $0.92, what we've assumed, let's say in the $1.25 is that we are  not selling about 25,000 tonnes of cobalt this year on what we're producing.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: You can say Katanga, okay Katanga, but just a general assumption to say Katanga will, of course, is producing  26,000. They have said they will sell some of their production this year, but most of it is going to be 2020. Across  that as a modeling assumption, we've seen 25,000 tonnes of cobalt not being sold. We've also run through that  particular model on spot prices the realization of cobalt hydroxide as some benchmark would indicate it might be.  It's very low volume, it's very illiquid at the moment, but we've taken about $11.50 a pound is the price that that's  [ph] on the market (00:26:29).

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: $11.50 a pound and 25,000 less tonnes of cobalt is what's driving it that $1.25, against what would have been a  $0.92. That's $1 billion variance against the cobalt revenue that we were running just two months ago at the  beginning of December. It would have been more sales and high prices. So, you can have your own views as to  where the volume and price is going to potentially – and we do speak about the cash flow generation, the $6.8  billion that Ivan said, that's at the conservative $1.25. So, I think a range of probably $6.8 billion to closer to $7.5  million is probably a more book-ended around cobalt realizations at the moment in terms of how we go. I'll show  you how cobalt in terms of the assumptions.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: That's the main variable. There the businesses are pretty steady state around its production and obviously, cobalt,  there is the assumption then within copper. We have the expansion 46,000 tonnes this year. That's the net of the  extra 150,000 tonnes at Katanga, and Mutanda being rebased to closer to the 100,000 tonnes, which we'll see on  the slide as well later on. Based on an optimized plan, an optimized cost structure, you would have seen some  headlines on that.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Where's all the building blocks for all these numbers? That's the production. Longer-term guidance unchanged in  cobalt and all the other metals. Copper is the only thing, which is a drop of 40,000 across all the years on account  of Mutanda.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Yeah, but 2018 to 2019, we've got some reasonable volume growth in cobalt still. Sort of query the sales impact  on that, but physically you'll be able to go and see the bags of hydroxide there and ultimately it will convert into  cash. Whether it's a 2019 or a 2020 story, we'll obviously wait and see. Zinc, you got Lady Loretta. There's some  further nickel. And coal of course is M&A and just general recovery, mostly in Prodeco.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: But across on the right-hand side, you've got overall – that's not an annual growth rate, but it's an overall absolute  growth rate 2018 to 2021 across the different metals, and I think it's in commodities that should be favorable  economically for us going forward.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: The downside was the average 2016 prices, we all know 2015-2016 was not a pleasant period. And on page 40,  we show the various assumptions that underpin all those. So if you sort of quickly glance to page 40, you can see  the downside, that was copper averaging $4,800 per tonne, that was zinc $2,000 per tonne, nickel $9,600 per  tonne. That was the free cash flow at $49 billion (sic) [$4.9 billion]. So, pretty downside from where we are at the  moment with that sort of cash flow generation.

texts.speaker: Steven F. Kalmin
texts.text: Upside of $10 billion, that's prices we've had in the last 12 months. You don't have to go too far back into the  history to see those sort of prices. That was copper at $7,000, we were there at Q1 last year. Zinc at $3,200,  nickel $15,000, we're not that far away there. Cobalt, you would need to sort of kick up to $24 a pound there, but  not a million miles away from potentially getting up to $10 billion of free cash flow in this business.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: And demand hasn't been bad. If you look at the slide on the right, demand has remained solid and if you look at  the various commodities, you look at seaborne thermal coal is up close to 8% growth last year. If you look at  nickel, we're up above 6% growth. Copper above 2%. So, demand has been relatively good. And as I say, if you  look at the left slide, with supply tightening up because no new CapEx expend, no massive CapEx and no new  mines coming into the system is definitely limited the amount of supply in the market.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: The same applies with zinc. I don't want to go details, but, [ph] Ryan (00:36:56), you'll need negative 2% demand  growth going from 14.32 million because there's less supply coming this year of metal. So, therefore, you will  have to have that. And the interesting one is if you look at copper, we all know, yes, there is new supply coming  from various mines, but a lot of mines are losing supply. We know what's happening at Grasberg and various  mines around the world where you're going to have supply reduced. So, we don't see much supply, net-net  supply.

texts.speaker: Ivan Glasenberg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Glencore Plc
texts.text: So, what is the investment case of Glencore? As I said, we believe we've got the right commodities, we're an  attractive part of the commodities talking about their supply side, which I mentioned earlier. So, we believe nickel,  zinc, copper, we are in the right commodities moving forward. And, therefore, with a limited supply/demand we  believe still being strong, it should be favorable going forward.

file: GRGL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 20March2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard John Hutton
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Greggs Plc
texts.text: And occupancy costs, still up 2% which might surprise you in this kind of market. That's not driven by rents. It's all  driven by rates. So business rates went up almost 5% last year and that's the thing that's driving occupancy costs  because business rates can be about 40% of your rental bill. So, there's still a significant chunk at a time when  rents are clearly not under pressure. And energy costs actually works in our favor slightly last year.

texts.speaker: Richard John Hutton
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Greggs Plc
texts.text: Looking forward, we've currently got ingredient inflation running about 4%, which is very much in line with what I  think you'll see in kind of market stats. And we've got a pretty neutral outlook on energy rates for the year. I would  imagine rents to be stable or possibly falling as we manage to renew leases, but business rates are continuing to  rise. So that's – still be an element of pressure from business rates in the year. And we fixed our wage and salary  award at 2% this year.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Greggs Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Richard. So, obviously, last year, was a difficult year for Greggs. We saw no let-up really on the pressure  on customers' disposable incomes, and especially for us, I think extreme weather compounded all challenges.  Unfortunately, it is pouring rain on a Monday, you don't consume braving the weather for a sandwich, you don't  [indiscernible] (00:21:30) compensate.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Greggs Plc
texts.text: Last year, we led the bakery market by introducing nutritional labeling on all our products which we sell nationally  and giving customers clear information to enable them to make informed choices about their diets. We also  completed the removal of all the artificial colors and flavors from all the products we make ourselves, as well as,  reducing fat and salt content wherever we're able to do that without impacting flavor of the product.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Greggs Plc
texts.text: And of course, as well as that, we're introducing a wider choice of healthier products, including a new range of  sandwiches at below 400 calories. It might surprise you to learn that low-calorie sandwiches already account for  over 20% of our sandwich sales. There's definitely more scope in this area and we've got new categories growing  in salads, yogurts, porridge, fruit pots, smoothies, and the like, all of which are potential new business for Greggs.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Greggs Plc
texts.text: Value is always an important part of Greggs brand. And Greggs longstanding commitment to corporate social  responsibility lives at the core of those values, and I'm happy that – to give my personal commitments I've done  internally and I'll give it to you here to maintain the vision of putting people, the community and our environment at  the very heart of everything we do. We welcome 750 new people to our retail teams through shop openings in  2012, and we continued our efforts to make Greggs a great place to work for all 20,000 employees. I'm delighted  to say that the gain shared in 10% of our profits this year, a total of the £5.7 million, which links their efforts to the  success of the business.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Greggs Plc
texts.text: Last year, we also made good progress across a wide range of our corporate social responsibility objectives. We  reduced the carbon footprint of our supply chain and the amount of waste that we send to landfill in particular.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Greggs Plc
texts.text: So, let me turn now to current trading and the outlook. There's no question, the first two months of this year has  confirmed that the consumers remaining cautious. And extreme weather, unfortunately, has continued to impact  sales. In the first 11 weeks, total sales are up by 4.2%, but like-for-like sales are down 4%. So, the pattern of like- for-like sales though does show an improving trend. Snow affected January, and we were minus 5.7%. But when  we got anything like reasonable weather, we will improve to minus 2% in February.

file: GRGL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 4March2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard John Hutton
texts.text: And there's been another £6.5 million, which has come from our ongoing cost saving program, which is a whole  raft of things. Some of it is rollover from the activity we did in 2013 with a couple of million coming from that  year. In the 2014 year, you have activities such as waste reduction. So, it has been a really impressive move in  terms of the amount of waste and loss that we have throughout our operations and supply chain in the year,  efforts to reduce energy, structuring the way that we manage the staffing in our shops, and then a whole raft of  things across the supply chain as we try to consolidate production and look at automation and those sort of things.

texts.speaker: Richard John Hutton
texts.text: Across 2014, our wage and salaries, the annual pay award was 1.6%. And when we take account of the phasing and  timing of that, overall inflation was 1.8% in the year for 2014. We saw deflation of about 1.5% in our ingredient  and packaging costs. And on occupancy costs of shops, it was marginally down. So we did see good decreases in  rents; the annual rate of rent decrease is running at 3% or 4%. But we saw a similar increase in rates, business  rates. Now that looks like it's going to be capped now following review by the government. So we shouldn't expect  quite so much rate increase in the future. Energy and fuel across the year was broadly neutral and obviously, we've  come into the year with a stronger position on energy, which I'll just come on to now.

texts.speaker: Richard John Hutton
texts.text: And in terms of energy costs, we think the outlook is broadly neutral, that's based on a reduction in fuel costs, a  reduction in gas costs, but a slight increase in electricity costs across the year as a whole, and electricity is, by far,  our biggest commodity because of the big usage that we have in shops.

texts.speaker: Richard John Hutton
texts.text: Now, we've got about six months forward cover overall. We have more than that on the ingredient side, which is  why we're pretty confident on the deflation on food inputs. We haven't got quite as much cover on energy. We've  left that more open. So there is some uncertainty on energy costs at this stage in the year, but overall a pretty  strong position.

texts.speaker: Richard John Hutton
texts.text: Just to think then about the efficiency program and what we're doing to continually try and drive cost down and  give ourselves options then in terms of whether we invest in value, invest in margin, just to highlight some of the  things that are going on. I just talked about the structural change, £2.9 million benefit in the year, and that will  annualize at £6 million next year. The other cost savings that I highlighted earlier, in 2014 delivered £6.5 million.  Looking forward to 2015, progressively, that program of efficiency is merging with our process and systems  program.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.text: All right. Thank you, Richard. Just to reflect then on the operational highlights from last year, we acknowledge  right up front that we know that market conditions improved last year as well, so these things have – the changes  we've made in the business have come at the same time as we've seen a recovery in the economy. And very  importantly for us, much more settled weather conditions. So if you lump that on top of the fact that there has  been a commodity price deflation for much of last year, that's been helpful in supporting margin as well. So al l  these things have come together.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.text: This chart, as you've seen before, basically tries to give a summary of where our estate profile lies. So it's a  constantly moving chart and if we're doing our job right, it should always be moving to the right as you have fewer  and fewer stores that are no longer profitable. But you can see that we've got 76 shops that we've identified we still  need to close. We've got 149 that are in the right high streets typically, but just need to be relocated normally to a  larger unit because they were constrained for space in some of these shops. And then, the green bars are all those  shops that we believe are in the right place and that we are busy refitting.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.text: More generally, we made good progress across our broad spectrum of corporate social responsibility areas and I'll  just highlight one which the diversion of 100% of waste from production sites away from landfill when we set the  target of 90%. So we're particularly pleased with that accomplishment.

texts.speaker: Roger Whiteside
texts.text: So just to finish then, turning finally to current trading and the outlook for the rest of this year. Y ou have seen  2015 has started very strongly. Like-for-like sales in the first eight weeks are up by 6.3%, but that does partly  reflect the fact that we had a very wet start to 2014 and we've not had anything like that sort of weather this year.  We expect our initiatives will continue to deliver growth, although as Richard has pointed out, we are mindful that  the sales comparatives become much stronger as the year progresses.

texts.text: We promised you that we would work on essentially 15 programs during 2011 and 2012. We're keeping a very  close eye on this scorecard. Of those 15 programs, 12 of those programs have reported data already, 10 of them  have reported positive data.  This is a slide, which just reflects where we were a year ago. We've had data back on just a handful. A green bar  means that we've had good news. A red bar, creatively enough, means we have bad news. And that really reflects  to you where we were a year ago.

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, GlaxoSmithKline Plc
texts.text: And so overall, as we look at the year going forward, we're still confident in the strategy and its delivery and the  execution that has been recorded in the first couple of quarters of the year, but clearly the environment is  presenting a number of challenges.

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, GlaxoSmithKline Plc
texts.text: And Consumer, while we've called it out in the green line, remember this year is really contributing very little  growth to the overall group position given the washout of the disposed businesses that we've sold off over the last  12 months. But the underlying performance of that business about up 7%, and I think most encouragingly, very  broadly based with not just Emerging Markets, but also the U.S. and Europe contributing, but also the categories  that we've now identified as our key focus areas for Consumer both on the Wellness side, on Nutrition with India  again a very strong grower and Horlicks contributing nearly 15% growth in the quarter; so a very good base there  and also building up new categories of investment.

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, GlaxoSmithKline Plc
texts.text: But we're planning and have put in place, a number of measures to improve this over the balance of the year, given  the environment that we're now facing. And those will come from managing the supply chains and managing our  procurement, and most importantly, going back to the financial architecture, really looking at where the volumes  are, where the right forecasts are, how we try those to the best returns and make sure our manufacturing  businesses are focusing on those rather than areas where our returns are being pulled back and we're facing  negative sales pressures; so really back to that reallocation theme.

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, GlaxoSmithKline Plc
texts.text: And alongside that, we can also then push back up to the upper end of the procurement lines and say, okay, how  many presentations do we need? Can we save on packaging? Can we reduce our response time? So, you can see  how it becomes a circle and a cycle that can contribute on a sustainable basis going forward, which is the most  important thing.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, GlaxoSmithKline Plc
texts.text: Turning to our operating profit, our adjusted margin of 28.8% was up 30 basis points of actual rates and 80 basis  points on a constant currency basis. COGS as a percentage of sales increased, primarily reflecting an adverse  year on year comparison for vaccines, which benefited from a £45 million settlement in Q2 2017 for lost third- party supply volume. Aside from this, we saw a broadly flat COGS performance, as favorable mix and continuing  supply chain efficiencies offset U.S. respiratory pricing pressures.

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans

And we're well on track here and consistent with our  earlier OE program we're ahead of our plans on delivery of benefits. The new savings are also on top of and  separate to the £1 billion of annual cost synergies we expect to realize from the proposed Novartis transaction.  We're making excellent progress towards completing that transaction, and we still expect to close it in the first half  of 2015.

texts.speaker: Andrew Witty, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody. Thank you very much for joining us today for our 2009 results briefing.
texts.text: We also have real opportunity to further reduce our real estate footprint. And you can see from this  slide, over the next few years we expect to exit up to another 11 million square feet, about 13% of  our real estate portfolio. That gives us a real chance to reduce our infrastructure costs, at least  partially. I’ve already mentioned some of it in R&D. What it also does is simplify the organization. It  allows us to really concentrate our activities in a few places and take away what is clearly a lot of a  cost driver.

texts.speaker: Andrew Witty, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody. Thank you very much for joining us today for our 2009 results briefing.
texts.text: So you see in the green box – the green bar, we did significant sales of products, that included  Wellbutrin XL that we sold back to Biovail. And we will continue to do that – and also some       corrected transcript

file: GSKL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 3February2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew Witty, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: And we’ll get underway in just a couple seconds. I thought before we did, there is just one or two
texts.text: Now, three years ago, we set out what our view of the environment would be and bluntly speaking,  very little has happened that we didn’t anticipate. Some of it’s happened more quickly and some of  it might have happened a degree sharper or blunter, but very little has happened that we didn’t  anticipate in terms of pricing, in terms of the development of the emerging market pharma  businesses, all of those things were very much behind the strategy we laid out three years ago,  strategy focused on delivering a business which would deliver sustainable sales growth, an R&D  operation which would fix the economics of R&D and deliver products of value to patients and to  payers, and a strategy which would simplify GSK takeout costs and allow that cost to be reinvested  behind growth opportunities, all focused on delivering a greater return to our shareholders as we  went forward.

texts.speaker: Andrew Witty, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: And we’ll get underway in just a couple seconds. I thought before we did, there is just one or two
texts.text: U.S. pharma, probably a part of the business we haven’t talked about so much in the last few  years. But U.S. pharma is absolutely turning the corner in terms of its future. What we can see in  that business, first of all, like everybody in the U.S., we’re having to deal with tremendous  challenges from the environment. U.S. is changing very rapidly, the way customers are structured,  who owns the customers, who controls the customers, where the decisions are taken, is changing  extremely rapidly. The whole industry is trying to figure out a new model to fit with that.

file: GSKL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 7February2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, GlaxoSmithKline Plc
texts.text: So overall and if you stand back from that position, you can see why we feel comfortable that as we go into 2012,  the momentum behind the business leaves us in the position that we anticipated throughout 2011 of being able to  convert underlying sales growth into reported sales growth despite some of those challenges. And we're mindful of  the risks that there are out in the marketplace. We're anticipating in our plans a number of pricing measures that  face of some very tough challenges last year. But going forward, we're anticipating the environment remains tough  and we're continuing to work that.

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, GlaxoSmithKline Plc
texts.text: And what we've been able to identify also in the last few months is areas where we can do that between the  business. So Aranda, our big Respiratory plant in Spain, had some space in one of their plants that was otherwise  sitting there in a mothballed way. We are now going to put the production of Panadol into that plant. So it saves us  going to an outsourced third party, we're loading our own plant more effectively and we're driving down the costs  of goods in the Consumer business by tens of percent. And that makes us much more competitive in what you  know is a competitive market. So you can see some of the things already coming through that are hidden within  this green box here, but allowing us to offset the regional and product mix on an ongoing basis.

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, GlaxoSmithKline Plc
texts.text: So at the COGS level, that simpler manufacturing platform is allowing us to simplify our supply chain, drive cost  out, simplify logistics for instance which are hundreds of millions of pounds in terms of how we think about  distributing our product around the world. If you align the plant more closely with where you're actually selling it,  you can reduce those significantly to pick one example, but it also allows us to knock out working capital  throughout the chain because we're now looking at it in a much more joined up way.

file: GSKL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 6February2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The net-net of all of that: very significant reduction in process time, very significant reduction in cost, carbon  footprint, inventory and speed. All of those things are on offer and we've been spending in parts of the  organization we almost never talk to you about, in our platform sciences units, we've been working over the last  five or six years on a series of technologies, which we believe now are ready to industrialize. We commissioned the  first – we began building the first facility in September of last year in Singapore where we're going to start  deploying the enzymatic technologies into amoxicillin actually, first of all, but it's already being deployed in two of  our pipeline assets and will now be accelerated across the rest of the organization.  Just to give you a little sense of what that all means – because I could see when I said enzymatic reactions one or  two people kind of glazed over just for a second – just to bring that into what that might mean from an economics  point of view, couple of metrics. So when we normally make a chemical which goes into a medicine, we need a  facility which is about 900 square meters in size. That gives you a sense on average. To do it this way takes about  100 square meters, so you're talking about a massive reduction in capital deployment and space occupancy,  obviously. You'll see something like a 50% reduction in carbon footprint and solvent use, up to a 50% reduction in  costs. These are enormous levers on the biggest part of the cost base in terms of the cost of goods.

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans
texts.text: Moving to the operating margin. We delivered a 40 basis point improvement in the group margin at constant  exchange rates. COGS as a percentage of sales improved 50 basis points with benefits from product mix and  cost savings, helping to offset price pressure in the inhaled Respiratory market, as well as investment in our  supply chain.

texts.speaker: Simon Dingemans
texts.text: We're also stepping up our focus on procurement through a new global organization. I'm very much using the  lessons from the Consumer integration to target a much more consistent level of annual savings across our global  spend. This will contribute to COGS, but also SG&A efficiency, even as we invest behind our growth drivers. This  will also be helped by the benefits of our restructuring program and the multi-year upgrading of our systems and  functional organization that is now coming to an end. We are particularly targeting non-customer facing spend to  keep G&A costs flat to down, even after absorbing inflationary pressures globally.

GTT - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 22July2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: First of all, I would like to spend a bit of time on the highlights for the first six months of this year. We obtained 31  orders in the first half of 2015, 28 LNG carriers, two FSRUs and one LNG bunker barge of 2,200 cubic meter.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: We created also a subsidiary in Singapore in order to promote our technologies in Southeast Asia to know that  there is plenty of LNG in Southeast Asia. That's where Northeast Asia used to get its LNG, there are also plenty of  islands and LNG could be an ideal energy for providing electricity to the archipelagos of Indonesia and the  Philippines.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: You know that, in Japan, they like to build the other technology, the Mark technology, and here, with this  contract, for the first time, we have a major [ph] trading pass (3:48) relying on our technology for bringing LNG to  Japan. So, otherwise, I will say that the orders are coming from the three large current shipyards. We are long- time partners with LNG carriers and FSRUs, and it's fairly well balanced with large number of orders coming from  DSME, but also others coming from the Hyundai Group.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Well, sector forecasts, you probably read our press release and I said in this press release that these first six  months have been contrasted. I think that whenever you want to assess the company, you should have a long-term  view as LNG, it's for the long term. You need to make very significant investments for having a liquefaction plant.  And you can amortize these very large investments only on very long periods, and for that, you need long-term  purchase contracts.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: So, the short term is a bit misleading for assessing the company. Still, we saw many changes, quite a lot of  movements on the oil prices in the last six months. And for a large part, at least in Asia, the LNG price is derived  from oil. So I think that we should spend time on that in order to see what could be the consequences.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: So, first of all, on the upper part, we need – we see what are the trends in terms of energy consumption with a  decrease in oil and a decrease in coal, which are considered as the two energies which are generating a lot of CO2  and emissions. In addition to that, oil is considered despite some phenomenon as being – supposed to become  more and more expensive in the years to come. And so the use of that according to the International Energy  Agency should reduce.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Besides that, we see that gas should increase. Gas is representing now about 23% of the primary energy  consumption in the world and should increase to something higher than 25% in the next years. Inside that, while  we will see that LNG is representing about 10% of gas, so only something like 2% of the international energy  consumption for a very clean energy and an energy which is more affordable than oil. So that's what is leading us  to believe that gas is going to continue to develop, and gas is – and energy will take a larger share of the energy  consumption in the world.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: On the lower part, you see the gas in the energy mix in different countries. You see that gas should represent more  significant part in most of the countries, except maybe in Japan. You know that Japan is heavily relying on gas  currently due to Fukushima as all the nuclear power plants are stopped. Still, we are four years at Fukushima and  we did not see any nuclear power plants restarting.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: But in the – all the other energy mix, gas should increase and [audio gap] (9:43) for energy. In fact, here on this  graph, we see provided by Wood Mackenzie, we see that the average growth for gas should be up 6% per year, so a  very significant increase with the bulk of the market in Asia and with certain increase which should come in the  next decade in Europe.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Well, in fact, each year there are new importing countries for LNG. I don't know whether we remarked, but each  year we are selling FSRUs. FSRUs, it's a floating terminal for importing LNG. We sold already two this year, we  sold three last year. Each year, it means that countries are going to receive these FSRUs and are going to be able to  receive LNG. The good news for the development of LNG and, of course, if countries have these facilities, there  will be a need for LNG carriers to deliver LNG to these FSRUs.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: So, this year, we are quite glad to welcome three new countries, Egypt, Jordan and Pakistan who've joined the club  of countries importing LNG. Egypt used to be a country which was exporting LNG. And that is more and more the  case, I could talk about Indonesia, which was the largest exporter of LNG and which is now importing, [ph] like  (11:31) the case of Abu Dhabi, which is exporting and [ph] importing (11:33) some of the Gulf countries. Of course,  the emission regulations are going to further enforce the drive towards LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: So, if we look at the dynamics of the market, we see here that there are countries which are providing LNG but  feels are getting depleted. So there is a need for additional sources. Well, we feel that, in the next years, the shale  gas, the U.S. will provide the bulk of this need, but we know that there are huge reservoirs in East Africa, in  Mozambique and Tanzania, which may take a bit more time to be developed, but which could be developed in  order to address the market.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: On this graph, we see that by 2020, 2021, we need additional capacity of LNG in order to cope with the demand,  once more, due to the fact that this energy is affordable and clean, we expect that it continues to grow in the  current environment.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Well, a look at the projects which have been decided. First of all, in this contrasted first six months of the year, we  saw three FIDs, two for Corpus Christi, which are greenfield, it means everything has to be built in Corpus Christi  in Texas. So there was no [ph] visiting (13:24) terminals, so the tanks have to be built, the network, the piping  network has to be built. The shipping – the ship terminal has to be built. So it's a major investment. It has to be –  it has been decided, representing 9.5 million tons, 9.5 million tons to be compared with 250 million tons produced  last year in terms of LNG, it's very significant.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Freeport in the U.S has also decided a third train, [ph] yeah, it's an advanced field (14:00) and Sabine Pass has  decided train number five, it's also [ph] advanced field (14:06). So, we saw in the first six months of this year close  to 19 million tons [ph] decided (14:14), it's about 8% of the current LNG production. I think it's a major signal of  confidence in the development of LNG. It means that they are biased in order to be able to take these decisions.  And [ph] whilst (14:30) they will look at it because the U.S., as you know, is very far away from countries which  are needing energy. So if they are very far away, you need a lot of ships.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: The pricing environment are – you know that the LNG at least in Asia, which is representing [ph] the bulk of  (14:57) the oil price. So, while the oil price is low, LNG price is low. In the U.S., it's depending on the Henry Hub  demand and supply mechanism. We see currently the NG price in Asia at a fairly low level, which is probably  making decisions for major projects, for example, in East Africa, a bit difficult to decide as its major investments  are difficult to amortize with the current price level and, in addition to that, with the current CapEx discipline of  the majors.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Well, what does that mean for the American exports relying on Henry Hub? I don't know whether you see very  well, but it may be better on your booklets. You can see very well what it means on this graph. So with – and we  have – we try to see what is the equivalent between Henry Hub and Asian prices. So at $14, we arrive to an Henry  Hub of $6/MMBtu, while, for the time being, we are at $3/MMBtu. It means that Henry Hub is still very  competitive compared to the Asian price. To the Henry Hub, you have to add the cost of liquefying gas and the  cost of transporting gas to Asia.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: So it's why we think that there is a very strong driver for the liquefying and exporting the American gas to other  countries and mainly to Asia. I'm visiting regularly Asia and mainly Japan. And there for the utilities, 37% of the  LNG is exported to Japan. Other utilities, there is also a unique opportunity for diversifying their portfolio of  procurement contracts, thanks to the export of American LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: So we think that the phenomenon that we saw will continue, maybe it will take a bit of time. We saw a very strong  flow of new projects in the first six months, but with that in the years to come, the LNG is for the U.S.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Well, I guess, you are quite [audio gap] (18:31) with this graph and, in particular, the gray oval where we indicate  which is the shipping intensity. It's a shipping intensity based on the 160,000 cubic meter LNG carriers, while the  LNG carriers are now fairly standardized around 175,000 cubic meters. We – that does not take into account  either the hedging possibility, whether you swap a cargo for Japan against a cargo for Europe which may have an  impact on the shipping intensity, but still, at the end of the day, the U.S. are far away the main areas of  consumption of LNG. So, if they are far away, you need a lot of ships for transporting the American LNG to the  markets. And once more, that's what is currently supporting the demand for LNG carriers. And having in mind the  competitiveness of the American LNG, I have the feeling that it's going to continue over the years to come.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Offshore markets, I was telling you that each – there are new countries buying or having FSRUs and importing  LNG through FSRUs. We see that in many different areas, well, in Southeast Asia, we see that in South America,  we see that in Northern Europe. We obtained FSRU for Kaliningrad. So you know that Kaliningrad is more or less  in Europe, but it's a Russian territory.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: And in order to have access to energy on an indefinite manner, they ordered FSRU this year, but also Poland, also  Lithuania ordered FSRU. So we see that in Europe or in Italy, there is FSRU in Tunisia. So we feel that – in Italy,  sorry. So we think that it's going to continue and it's supporting our forecast of three FSRUs per year in average  over the next decade, which means a lot of regasification capacity, new regasification capacity every year.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: FLNG, we obtained the three big FLNGs with – to name the first one, Prelude. They are going to be delivered in  the next years. We can see them actually in the current shipyard. I would say that they are in a bit – we are  working on different new projects, but of course, I do not know when they are going to be decided as there are  different opportunities for new fields developments between the American liquefaction projects and the different  projects in Asia, but it's still a very active segment.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Onshore tank, that's an area of growth there. We could show you pictures of our two tanks currently built in the  Philippines and in Indonesia because the walls are quite built and we are already preparing the containment  systems inside, so that could be a good illustration. Still, the fact that we are heavily relying on existing facilities is,  for the time being, limiting the demand. I guess, it's not going to last like that forever.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Well, something quite dramatic in the change of this industry. We sold [ph] this in this first six months of barge of  (22:45) 2,200 cubic meters in the U.S. with the Conrad shipyard. It's a shipyard in – which is based in Louisiana  and Texas and they are going to – you know that there is a regulation in the U.S. where such kind of floating  structures have to be built in the U.S. We could not rely on our usual industrial partners, so we found one in the  U.S. It's a small one, it's for delivering LNG to ocean-going vessels relying on energy. So it's the beginning. We  were talking to you about LNG as a fuel for a while and some of you were asking when are you going to get orders,  we got one. [ph] We are working (23:31) activity with them. We are working with different American entities, the  Coast Guard, the different people on the East Coast, West Coast, the Mississippi River as this structure could  apply very well to different applications in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: Well, another specific topic of this barge, we designed the transfer arm that you can see here, which is transferring  LNG from the barge to the ocean-going vessel. It's a cryogenic arm and it's the first-time such a structure is  existing for such a small barge. We expect that it's going to be a selling point for this structure in the years to  come. So it's an entire design that we provided and we are quite pleased. We worked with the shipowners, WesPac  and Clean Marine Energy, and this barge has been classified by the American classification society, ABS.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: We have Inspection and Monitoring with MOON, the balloon moving around the tank in order to detect possible  defects in the tank,  and SloShield, a software monitoring the liquid motion inside the tanks. And we've installed  our first systems this first part of the year, TAMI, this thermal camera inspection test, which is quite well- demanded and performing quite well through the Cryovision subsidiary.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.text: We are putting a lot of emphasis on Performance and Optimization services with the training subsidiary that we've  launched last year and which is allowing us to develop new training tools and to enter more and more in the  modeling aspect of the LNG gas. And also in the pre-project vessel – pre-project aspects, where we are working a  lot on different modifications, feasibility studies, and you will see that this aspect of the front-end engineering has  significantly increased the overall [indiscernible] (27:03). That is telling a lot because finally it's a market that we  could have tapped in that manner a long time before. We did it in a very significant manner in this first six months  because the answer that we are – the answers or the deliverables we are providing to the industry is considered as  very useful, very credible. And so, we are more and more [ph] after (27:36) to work in these pre-project studies.  And we have other services in mind, but that I will tell you more next time.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: And then, basically there are three main priorities in our innovation. The first one is of course to secure, to  support the very strong position we have on the LNG market. And that's what is at, let's say, the bottom left part of  the slide. That means continuously enhance the performance and the value of the product that we – and the  technology that we propose to the LNG chain, to shipyards, and ship owners. Thanks to these efforts, we are – as  Philippe said earlier, we see that – I mean, something like 75% of our current order books is made of new  technology. That means that the quality that we propose meets the expectations of our customers.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: So that's the first priority. Second priority is, and I will give some illustration about that, how we can expand our  market, the use of our containment systems, so onshore tanks, new other cryogenic gases and also small scale  LNG carriers. And beyond that, we continue, and as I said, the top line to work on new products like new services  for instance, and completing new businesses like the development of the LNG as [indiscernible] (37:24) on which  I will come back.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: The first illustration is small scale LNG. Why do we believe in the development of small scale LNG transportation?  When we say small scale, we mean several thousands or several tens of thousands of cubic meters, when  compared to a regular LNG carrier, which is now 175,000 cubic meter, 180,000 cubic meter.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: Why small scale? It's for the supply of – I mean, the downstream of the supply chain, and so for the supply of LNG  as a fuel, but also the supply of LNG as an energy source for smaller countries, Ireland, where we see we can see  for instance the switch of power plants from coal or diesel to gas. And in order to allow this switch, [ph] it is not  safe (38:53) of course to supply these areas with gas. And the best way to supply the gas is to bring it as LNG fuel.  Thanks to the adequate supply chain, so with this type of smaller tankers 5,000 cubic meters, 10,000 cubic  meters, 20,000 cubic meters, 40,000 cubic meters.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: Second point, somewhat about LNG as a fuel, there are great expectations from that. And I think it's important to  give some color in this area. So first, you know what is the context? The context is the introduction of stricter  environmental regulation. So from 2015 onwards, in some selected areas in Northern Europe, all the North  American course, the ship has to comply with as to reduce their sulphur oxide their emission down to below 0.5%.  So, this means basically that they cannot continue to use the regular [indiscernible] (41:03) oil that they have been  using for decades.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: So okay, as of today, these areas seem rather unlimited in terms of geographical reach. However, I mean we  consider that thousands of commercial ships, ocean-going investors are concerned as of today by these regulations  first point. And second point, in the years to come, on the long run, we expect these areas to expand some – there  are some new emission control areas under consideration. And let's say, on a more local standpoint, we see that  some ports introduced strict regulations for instance from I think it's from June onwards this year. The port of  Hong Kong introduced stricter regulation regarding the emissions of [ph] per grams (42:06) in this area.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: So that's the context – as enhanced of that context, I mean the ship owners, they need to make a choice. They need  to take a decision. And they can either change to cleaner fuels, change the fuel to use, or install [indiscernible]  (42:29), or they can clean the smokes, I mean the emissions of what goes out of their engines. So thanks to the  installation of turbine.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: So there, I mean our strategy is twofold. First, we need to convince the industry, the ship owners that the right  decision is to go for LNG. In the alternative that they have, LNG is the best one from a technical and economical  standpoint and industrial standpoint. So technically speaking, we are developing all of the – there are a number of  solutions available. Economically speaking, the key point for the ship owner is to see whether the spread between  the low sulfur marine gasoil and the price of low sulfur marine gasoil and the price of LNG is sufficient to justify  the investment in a new system, in particular in a containment system of LNG.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: In the client context of low oil price, clearly the spread between a low sulfur marine gasoil and LNG is relatively  small. And we see [ph] quite collections (44:00) from the ship owners to really go for to decide as of today in the  current context to switch to LNG. There is not a lot of activity in this area. However, I mean, this situation, this  question must be considered on a longer term. And the question is, when deciding to LNG is what will be the price  context in the coming year?

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: So, that's why we try to present here, how the question has to be considered by ship owners, when they have to  decide whether they go for cleanup fuels [ph] cover (44:45) LNG at the top. And we're taking a mid- to long-term  price context of $75 to $80 of per barrel for the oil price. We have let's say an estimate of what will be the price of  the low sulfur marine gas oil and what can be – could be the price of LNG for the ship owner. And there, we feel  days of credit, which provide a very good profitability to the conversion of LNG.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: First element of the strategy, to make sure that – to convince that LNG is the right decision; second element to  make sure when it comes to LNG, the best solution [ph] lies with the (46:12) systems that we develop. And there  we have some convincing, compelling arguments to make regarding the – especially the integration of our system  in the vessels. Clearly when you go from oil to LNG, you lose energy density. You need more space to store the  same quantity of energy. So for ocean-going merchant vessels there is a commercial aspect into these, how can I –  as a ship owner, I need to minimize the adverse effect of losing space of losing cargo space.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: So there, the optimization of – the utilization of spaces is key in the decision-making process. And from that  perspective, when we compare our membrane systems with cylindrical tanks, the Type C tanks, which are  cylindrical, which are less, let's say, versatile in terms of space utilization, which are pressure vessels as well. I  mean we have very good arguments to make. Yeah, I think the possibility of space utilization, just one point.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: Where you have a Type C tank or cylindrical tanks, for let's say, statutory reason, you cannot use 100% of the  tanks. And you must – the limit is 90%. So [indiscernible] (47:47) and the first element, and second element, you  see that when you have to fit a cylinder into a rectangle unit space, basically that's what we collate to ship on else.  We allow them to use completely the space that they will lose in terms of – for transportation.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.text: So regarding development of LNG as a fuel, clearly, we expect that more favorable economies come in the next  months or years, from $70, $75 [indiscernible] (48:33) clearly, there are very good profitability, very good. It  makes from an economic standpoint to go for LNG. Clearly, there's no doubt about that when compared to other  solutions. And when it comes to LNG, our membrane systems [indiscernible] (48:52-48:57).

file: GTT - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 22July2016 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Okay. Good morning, everybody. Welcome for this presentation of this – the first six month results of 2016 of  GTT. Immediately, I would like to start with the highlights for these first six months. So we had 13 deliveries and  two new orders. We had a strong order book of 107 units with 96 LNG carriers. We had a quite sustained  subsidiaries activities. You know that we have several subsidiaries providing services.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We set up new partnerships dedicated to LNG as a fuel and small scale activities. You know that something that  we consider as really an area of goal and on which we've been able to set up a significant partnership. We've  opened a new office in Shanghai in order to tackle the Chinese market. And the last highlight that I would like to  talk about is that in September we are going to pay an interim dividend of €1.33.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So strategy and update. I think that you are familiar with this chart. Maybe, you can notice some differences with –  we had some new services, which is quite in line with the strategy we detailed in the past, which is that, we are  keeping on introducing new services, we have already a quite wide offering in terms of services. But we've  introduced new ones. You see G-SIM, which is a simulator of LNG carrier that we are selling. We are used to sell  trainings to shipowners for – in fact, for not long, for a couple of years. And now we are selling a simulator and  that has attracted quite a lot of interest from [indiscernible] (02:25). We have also some evolutions on the LNG as  a fuel as we are looking very much at very large vessels on which we could offer our systems.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So activity update. Consolidate our position in LNG shipping industry. Currently, the overall demand anticipated  from 2022 due to strong long-term demand drivers. So 2022 by LNG standards is not that far away, because if  you want to be able to satisfy this demand, you've got to take decisions on LNG plans in the not too distant future.  If it's a great field, in fact you have to take decisions about now. And if it's brownfield you have a year or two or  couple of years to wait before taking the decision in order to meet this demand.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: LNG price, current low LNG price should offer new market opportunities. Well, that – you could consider that I'm  over-optimistic, but please look at it in a minute – for a minute. Low LNG – the lowest source of [ph] energy  (03:58) for the time being, the word is coal. The gap between coal and LNG has never been as thin as it is now.  And so there is a very strong incentive to switch from coal to LNG and that is very much helped by the current  prices.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: LNG charts. Some vessels are not chartered, I will not argue about that. And people are talking of 40 ships which  are not chartered. I would say that LNG carriers, it's not the commodity and in these vessels you have old ones  which are small, which are small in terms of quantity and which are using – which are quite high boilers, which is  the thermal characteristic of LNG carrier, and you have also some more recent ones. We will come back to that  later on.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: As far as LNG projects, some are in the offings, quite ready to be decided. We – probably the low energy price is  not helping major projects to be decided still we saw a decision in July, Tangghu number three, the third train in  Tangghu, so it's relying on an existing facility, you have the harbor, you have the tanks, so it's just the  construction of a third train, but at least – and I think that we need to see – not to watch only the black swans but  also the pink flamingos, and that is definitely a pink flamingo, this decision for a new LNG facility.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: LNG carrier order intake. So it's a low level of orders. We have ongoing discussions and the industry is quite  active in discussing about new facilities. We are confirming that we still see 50 vessels to be ordered for satisfying  the need for transporting LNG from plants which had been sanctioned, decided over the last two years. You can  see on the left hand side, part of the chart that the supply of LNG should begin to decline by the beginning of the  next decade and there is a need for launching new projects. You can see also that currently on the lower part of  this chart, there the excess capacity. So currently you have a kind of fitting that there are some excess capacities,  while in the medium-term by LNG standards you need significant additional capacities, and it probably are the  kind of products in which we are, where people – LNG players are suffering from low prices and from some  quantities that they have difficulties to sell, while in the mid-term, they need – we need additional capacities.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, that's what I was talking to you about, about the low LNG price, what you see on the left hand side part of  this slide compared to coal. The megawatts coming from coal or coming from LNG, it has never been a  megawatts, [ph] energy (8:37) is mainly for power, it's not so much for cooking. It's mainly for power in Asia for the  time being and a little bit in, also in Europe and in some other places, but the megawatt coming from LNG has  never been as cheap as it is now compared to coal, and obviously it's a very strong factor of support of the  demand for LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: On the other side of the chart, you're seeing the price of LNG coming from the U.S. compared to the Asian prices.  LNG in Asia is based on the barrel – oil barrel and LNG in the U.S. is based on Henry Hub, which is a price based  on the supply and demand of gas in the U.S., so not related to oil.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And for buyers in Asia who are – the fact of having supplies quite different with totally different pricing formula is  an opportunity to maximize or to minimize the cost of the supply. So it has a very strong interest. And with the  current oil price, we see that American LNG is attractive. And that is something which is very important including  for market assumptions, because I would be challenged on that piece. Keep that in mind as the pricing structures  are very different and with the current barrel price, the American LNG is very attractive.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So LNG carriers, you can see the incremental shipping demand over the next years. I'm sure [ph] that's  something (10:54) to be challenged about that.
