What I can say is that, of course, there are a lot of deliveries but  once more in order to satisfy the need for transporting LNG from plants, which has been decided in the last  couple of [ph] terms, (11:11) there is still a need for new ships. And then this demand should be relayed by the  new projects to be sanctioned.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: While the other activities, FSRUs or FLNGs, that's segments which are of particular significance. They are not  that big in our overall turnover, but we have 100% position there. We designed all of them. There are a lot of  discussions on FSRUs and FLNGs. FSRUs, FLNGs I would say that it's a bit more remote, even though there are  some. And we could see some activities, which is important not only because we may have to design the FSRU,  but also because each time FSRU is decided, it's a new outlet for LNG which is appearing, so, new opportunity for  delivering LNG and a new need for LNG gas for supplying this FSRU.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Onshore storage tank, very small activity for the time being and as it's very much linked to new facilities. So  capitalize on the expected potential in adjacent sectors. I give the floor to Julien.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President, in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Yeah. Good morning, everyone. I will run you through the remaining pillars of our strategy and give you an update  on each of them. The first regarding our target of capturing the potential, what we feel is a great potential in  adjacent sectors, just especially in the development of LNG as a fuel.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President, in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, there – to give you an update, so, it is a nascent market. It is an emerging market. It is a real energy transition  for the shipping industry. What we see is that the various elements that will make this happen in the future or  progressively and continuously developing or progressing. So, all these elements are necessary to make that this  LNG as a fuel becomes a reality, and this is progressing well for each of them. The first one is, of course, the  regulatory framework. So emission control areas have been introduced last year in Northern Europe and in the  coastal areas of North America.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President, in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Other areas in the world, in China, in Australia are deciding to introduce progressively a specific emission control  area, especially with a cap on sulfur emissions. And we expect that probably by 2020 depending on the final  decision from the International Maritime Organization, a global cap for all the ocean-going vessels be introduced  regarding the emission of sulfur oxide. So really this regulatory framework is expanding and is the first base for  the development of LNG as a fuel.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President, in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The second element, of course, is the characteristics of LNG. Just keep in mind that as of today, the shipping  industry represents something like 30% of the global emission of sulfur oxide in the world, so, just the vessels  themselves. So, there is a lot at stake regarding the reduction of the emissions of nitrogen oxide and sulfur oxide  from the shipping industry.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President, in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And there when you go from the existing fuels to LNG, basically you reduce by 80% nitrogen oxide and by almost  100% the emission of sulfur oxide. So, this is really – here you have a real solution in terms of – to the  environmental concerns. Of course, the third element that will make this possible in the future is the economics.  [indiscernible] (15:59) LNG must prove economically feasible and sustainable. And this comes down to two  elements which are also progressing. The first one is the price of LNG, of course, so the merit of the present  situation is that LNG appears as a convenient fuel.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President, in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And the second point is the competitiveness of the supply chain, because you need to bring the LNG to the final  users. And there also we see a number of initiatives and we are part of them. For instance, in the U.S., when we  introduced the bunkering barge. We are part of the initiative that will make the fuel competitive for the final user,  that is the shipowner.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President, in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And last point I want to touch is the industrial aspects. Of course, it is not only an energy transition, it's also an  industrial transition. The owners must have access to the industrial solutions to equip their vessels with new  tanks, new cryogenic gas change, et cetera, and there the industry is progressing.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President, in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: You see here on this chart a bit more elements, slide 19, a bit more elements regarding the type of initiatives that  are taken by the governments, in order to limit the emissions of nitrogen and sulfur oxides [indiscernible] (18:25)  China, Hong Kong, California. And also development of incentives, tax incentives, subsidies, in order to, let's say,  catalyze [ph] ,  accompany, and (18:39) accelerate the development of this new, cleaner fuel system.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President, in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: That was for this point regarding adjacent sector and especially LNG as a fuel. The third item, this third pillar  [indiscernible] (20:11) the service. We have devoted over the last years a lot of efforts in expanding innovative  service offerings to the owners and to the major oil and gas industries. We are continuing to do so.

texts.speaker: Cécile Arson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Revenues, they grew by 11.4% and amount at €170 million of that. Revenues coming from royalties grew by  15.2%. There is an increase of about 19.5% in royalties coming from LNG and ethane carriers and they amount to  €111 million. There is an increase by about 25.5% from FSRUs. Nevertheless, we experienced significant delays  in the construction of the vessels, and I will come on that a little bit later.

file: GTT - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 21July2017 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Good morning, everybody, both for those who are here in the InterContinental Hotel in Paris and for those who  are following us on the net by telecommunications. Well, I'm very pleased to receive you to present the first six  months of 2017 results. And very quickly just a slide to – we kept – as you know, we are an engineering company  developing proprietary technology for transporting or storing LNG, we've developed a membrane technology that  we are keeping on improving and applying to new applications.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, in these first six months, we delivered 21 LNG carriers. We received 13 new orders and among these  deliveries, we had in particular the delivery of the Prelude FLNG. I don't know whether you saw pictures of this  FLNG, but it's totally huge, 500 meters long, 90 meters wide. It's the largest floating structure ever built.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We delivered also formally the first ice-breaking LNG carrier, the Christophe de Margerie. I come back  immediately to the first page and you can see in this first page, this ship performing its ice trials. So, she's going  backward as she can't go directly front on as she is facing strong ice, so she has the capability to go backward.  So it's very impressive. It's very, very impressive.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: By the way, just on the side, you can see a barge, a very tiny barge we are currently building in the U.S. It shows  you the wide range of things we are capable of doing from small floating structure to very large ones, very  complicated, capable of breaking the ice.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, this year, we introduced a technology for LPG. We did not sell it yet, but we've marginally been in LPG. For  example, on Prelude, there are eight tanks and four tanks for LPG. But here, it's very optimized for containing  LPG and we are promoting it. We introduced also GBS technology, Gravity Based System. It's a kind of concrete  tank that you can install near shore. And we are also actively promoting that, especially for islands which would  like to rely on gas, whether it's LNG or LPG, and which can see that as a very easy way to install storage on the  place where space is scarce.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, LNG market, we see several positive signs on the LNG market. On the operational point, for a year – about a  year now, we [indiscernible] (05:27) is operational. There are four trains now which are operational and beginning  to deliver LNG from the U.S. So, it's quite interesting, in particular to see where this LNG is going to.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: On the demand side, we saw, for example, 12% growth in the import of LNG from the top four importing countries.  So that is quite impressive. We will come back to that, but it's largely coming from a switch from coal to LNG,  which is very much favored by the low prices of LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: When you look at the market, you always look at the black fonts but you have to look also at the pink flamingo.  And the pink flamingo is the decision for FLNG of Mozambique, the [ph] Coral one (06:33), which has been  decided with a 3.4 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So let's say it's about 1% of the market is going to be by 2019. And so 1% you may say is small. Still, we'll see  people keeping on saying that there is a lot of LNG and some are, therefore, saying while this market is great,  we've got to take decisions now in order to provide additional quantities as soon as possible as this order for  FLNG is highlighted.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We got four FSRUs order in this first six months. It shows that while people are looking for new gates for  delivering LNG, we'll see that a lot of LNG has been – LNG facilities have been decided and you've got to deliver  that, you've got to find ways of delivering that. And for that, you need infrastructure facilities and these floating  ones, the FSRUs are very easy, flexible, quick and economical manner of opening new ways of delivering LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, another way of looking at the market, when we look at the evolutions of the demand in Asia, we see a very  strong increase. In fact, overall, when we compare that from – on the first five months of 2017 compared to the  first five months of 2016, very strong increase. You can see, for example, in Japan, which is the largest LNG  importer, we see an increase by 12%.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: When we talk about China, we see an increase of 38%. Well, in fact, Japan, it's 7%, sorry for that. China is 38%,  South Korea is 15%, and it was before the announcement South Korea wanted to move away from coal and  nuclear energy.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, in fact, the switch is really at work. The switch from coal to LNG is really at work. And that of course, we see  that is very much facilitated by the low prices of LNG. We can see that here. We can see the China LNG prices.  While the other Asian LNG prices are about the same, we see the Europe natural gas prices which are much  more reasonable. I mean, they did not experience the bump the market experienced in Asia in winter.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And we see coal and the coal prices and we can see that all that is now very close. And of course, switching to  LNG, you have a much cleaner solution for providing an energy, and you have a cleaner solution and not high  price, at very affordable price. And so, LNG can become a solution for base load power generation.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Low LNG prices are attracting new countries. What is fascinating is that each year – years after years, we see  new countries coming to LNG. We can see that on this slide. Of course, it will have a limit at a certain point of time  because LNG cannot go everywhere, and there is – the number of countries is limited. But we're expecting this  year Philippines and Ghana to begin their imports of LNG. But, of course, that is supporting the long-term demand  for LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, the trade of LNG is very active, and over the next five years, we are planning to see a growth of 6.5%, which,  of course, is very important. We know that for us, we are in the shipping side of this activity, and that depends  very much on where this LNG is going to go to. And the fact that it's going to go mainly to Asia, and we saw that  on the slide before, the increase of LNG imports in Asia is, of course, a positive news for the shipping of LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, that we'll have still to be confirmed in the next years as the contracts are much more open than what they  used to be in terms of destination clauses, but we see that the thirst for LNG in Asia is still there.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: LNG supply and demand could be balanced as soon as 2021, which is, in terms of building new facilities, very,  very close. Once more, the low LNG prices we are seeing currently are very much favoring the adoption of LNG  as a source of energy. Still, we are keeping on talking with LNG players and they have a lot of quantities. So, they  are looking at innovative ways of selling these quantities and that's why the demand for FSRUs is so important,  because it's a good way of providing a country with this source of energy, opening a new gate.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, this balance could be as soon as 2021, could be a bit later. When you count, let's say, five years to build a  new greenfield, a liquefaction facility, in fact, decisions should come for meeting the market requirements in the  next decade.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, for LNG shipping, we said that we delivered many ships in this first part of this year that did not have a [ph]  decreasing (15:25) effect on the market. In fact, the charter rates are maintained at – to a certain level, which we  expect to see higher in the second part of this year as new facilities are going to enter in production in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We saw a certain growth rate in bcm miles per ship since January 2016, and that means that the shipping  intensity is increasing. You can see from the left side part of the slide to the right side, there is a significant  increase. Of course, it's linked to the [ph] first trends (16:20) in the U.S. and the necessity to deliver this LNG in  places which are far away. So the distance are increasing. The needs for ships is increasing. So, more this  phenomenon is going to be confirmed, the more there is going to be a need for ships. And then market could get  out of its wait-and-see attitude we are suffering from for a couple of years.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: There are ships which are very performing, the recent ones. And there are some which are much less performing,  which are consuming much more and which are much smaller. It means you need a lot of ships to transport the –  or more ships to transport the same quantity.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And so, when you did this order book and the overcapacity, you arrive to a figure of 51.7 for the orders, or the  ships needed to satisfy this transportation need. So, that's where this figure is coming from. But it depends, of  course, on some assumptions, and in particular where this LNG is going to. Here, we did not assess that all this  LNG will go to Asia. We had a more or less conservative approach there. But still we see that. Of course, we  would like to see that more and more confirmed. But it's why we think that at a certain point of time, these orders  will be badly needed on the market.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: I'm continuing on this, I'll give you some hints about what have been the highlights of our activity during H1, during  the first half. So as Philippe mentioned, the company added 13 orders, eight for LNG carriers and four for FSRUs,  which is a significant level. Here, we recall what were our order estimates on a 10-years horizon. Of course, what  happened during the six months cannot be compared like this on a 10-year horizon. But it's worth reminding what  are the overall perspective.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And in terms of structure of turnover, it's worth noticing that FSRU and services and FLNG represent now 20% of  the turnover of the company, which is an increase over the last year. FSRUs were only 10% last year, which was  an improvement – an increase over the year before. So this demonstrates how beyond LNG carriers that our –  the market on one hand and then GTT on the other hand evolve.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Just focus on FSRUs, a high level of orders during H1 on that front, and that corresponds really to a structural  evolution. Here, you see that FSRU capacity represented in 2016 10% of the global importing capacity of LNG,  which is huge and sharply growing. And when we take into consideration the units that are to be commissioned in  the next year, we think that this percentage will grow to 12% and probably higher in the year after.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And as a matter of fact, what we see is that this corresponds really to a choice. It means that the FSRU are the  solution of choice for new LNG importing countries. In 2015 and 2016, there have been seven in total new LNG  importing countries, and six of them have chosen to use floating units as storage capacity instead of onshore  terminals. So this is because of the flexibility, the economic advantages of floating storage units, FSRUs as well.  This is now the solution of choice, and this together with the growth of the LNG translates in our order book and in  our revenues.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And last, before I hand over the micro to Marc, regarding LNG as a fuel, you know it's a – we actively are looking  at this market as a major opportunity for LNG, for the shipping industry, and for GTT. So, now what happened  during the first half? Well, a lot of activity there. So, many owners are looking at LNG as a fuel. This has not  translated into orders for GTT, but there are really a lot of discussions.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The context, one must look – have a look at the overall context. From the one end, it's favorable because  regulations are really putting a pressure on the industry. On the other hand, in terms of pricing and development,  you know that, for the owners to decide to go for LNG. They must assess the economic advantage of this fuel  over the alternative fuels. So, what they are looking at is the spread in prices between the price of LNG, here it's  the red line in Asia and the price of [ph] between brackets (27:46) clean fuels derived from oil and this is the line  here.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Vice President in charge of Innovation, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, three years ago, the spread was much higher than it is today, now it's about $4. So, it means that it's more of  a challenge for LNG propulsion systems to get introduced. And that's the reason why most projects that have  been implemented or decided in the last couple of years were rather for smaller vessels, the ones [indiscernible]  (28:21) that sail predominantly in ECA zones. Whereas for bigger vessels and so bigger tanks, and we know that  our systems, our solutions are, by nature, well recognized for cost base efficiency for bigger tanks.

file: GTT - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 27July2018 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So we are going to present you the main facts of the first six months, but first, some words on the company. We –  as you know, we are an engineering company. We are providing technologies for containing liquefied natural gas.  We have a very long track record as we began this job 50 years ago, and we always continue to improve our  technologies and to provide solutions to our customers.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: In the LNG as a fuel, as you know, it's something, which is quite promising. It's supposed to be a market which is  going to grow. We had, last year, 9 orders for container vessels for CMA CGM. In the first part of this year, we  received an order for a bunker ship for 20,000 cubic meter. And in July, we signed for tanks for a cruise vessel for  PONANT, and we will talk more about it.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Another important highlight, important fact on – in the first part of this year, the FEED, Front End Engineering  Design, studies that we got for Gravity Based Systems that's onshore tanks that you put on the seabed, which are  in the sea. So it's a kind of oxymoron, if I may say so, an onshore tank in the sea. But it offers a lot of advantage.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Having said that, let's have a look on the market and the activities. Well, the LNG demand forecast, as Wood  Mackenzie is saying, should go between 2015 and 2030 by an average growth of 5.2%. So it's something which is  in the long term very positive with a split between the different regions of the world, which should remain the  same. It means that Asia should continue to dominate the LNG market.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The – in 2000 – in the first part of 2018 compared to 2017, we saw the Asian LNG import growing at a very  significant rate of 14%. So we saw, for example, China increasing its import by 55%. So a very strong increase of  imports in Asia. We could say the same about India, about Korea, which saw its imports increasing by 17%. Well,  that is – should, if I may say so, by the ways, to rebalance the energy mix, giving a larger place to LNG, which is  cleaner than fuels like coal, still very much used in some energy mixes.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: In this year, we saw new importing countries. All that I use in these meetings to celebrate countries, new countries  joining the club of import – LNG importing countries. This year, we have 2 new countries, the Philippines and  Panama. While the amounts are still small, but we expect that in these countries, for example, in the Philippines,  it's going to be significant over the next years.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Something, which is important also, it's not only new countries for importing LNG, which is good for the LNG  carrier business. Very often, these new countries are importing LNG through FSRUs, which may be designed by  us. So if we look back in the past, we see that compared to 2013, which is not so far away, the imports have  increased by 30%. So we are really in a very active market.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Let's look at the pricing dynamics on the market. We see on this figure the – you see the blue points, that's the  Henry Hub price. And the red line is the price of the LNG according to oil prices. You know that LNG in most parts  of the world is based on oil. And if oil prices increase, then LNG prices increase.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: That renders the American LNG not based on oil but based on the Henry Hub, which is a kind of a supply-and- demand pricing. That renders the American LNG particularly competing – competitive. That's the case currently  with American Henry Hub at about $3 per MMBtu, while the LNG in Asia is at about $10.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: If we look at the LNG shipping, we – that's a table where we follow the need or the needs of ships for the projects  which are currently in construction. We arrive to a figure of about 30 ships currently needed as of July 1, needed  by the market for transporting the LNG for these projects already decided. So that's a table we are presenting you  regularly. And last – in February, I was telling you that I was really feeling that the market was really needing  these ships. That's what we saw at work during the first part of this year, and we still consider that the market is  needing ships for these – for transporting this LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Let's – if we look at the projects now, we see that many projects are in the offing. Here, you can see many  American projects. You can see project in Canada, LNG Canada or Woodfibre in Canada as well. You see  projects in Russia with Arctic LNG 2, which is very close to Yamal. Another one in Sakhalin in the eastern part of  Russia. You see that Qatar is more or less ready to significantly increase its production capacities, and you see  that Mozambique is also ready to launch its projects. So many projects are more or less ready to accompany the  need for additional LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So on the – on this slide, you can see the production of LNG in blue. That's the plants, which are already  operational. You can see that some fields are experiencing quite naturally depletion and need to be replaced. In  red, you see what is under construction. And you see that by 2022, which is not that far away, additional  capacities are going to be needed. And in fact, we saw already in the first part of this year a positive decision with  – taken by Cheniere for a new train in Corpus Christi, the third one, adding 4.5 million tons of production.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Something – well, something new, we deliver many ships. These ships are with our modern technology and are  very efficient in terms of boilers as their boilers is very – they are very balanced, very optimized. That's – the  boilers is consistent with the needs of the propulsion. So it renders all ships more and more different in terms of  consumption. And especially for long voyages, such as Gulf of Mexico to Asia, the relatively high consumption  may be quite penalizing.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So if we want to look at what we consider for our core business, we – in the beginning of this year, we had a long- term view of about 225 to 240 units. I would say that the flow of orders we had last year and this year is fully  supporting this vision. For FSRU, we see between 30 and 40 units over the next 10 years. And for FLNG, we see  between 5 and 10 units over this period. For onshore tanks, we see between 5 and 10 units.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So if we want to look at new businesses, let's talk about LNG fuel developments. First of all, we had recently a  contract with PONANT for an icebreaker cruise expedition ship vessel capable of going to the North Pole or going  close to – or going to Antarctic. It's going to be the very first cruise icebreaker with LNG propulsion. Its delivery is  planned in 2021.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The tanks, that's the Mark III technologies. There will be 2 tanks. And we've offered to the yard a turnkey solution.  It means we are not only providing the design, we are going to conduct the construction of the tanks, and we will  select the subcontractors, and we will coordinate them on the yard. So it's quite important. I mean, we signed for  container ships last year. We signed at the beginning of this year for a bunker ship, and now we are signing for a  cruise ship.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, container ship, after the 9 containers – container ships we signed for with the CMA CGM, well, these ships  have tanks of 18,000 cubic meters, and you need to fill them. So you need to fuel them. You need to bring the  LNG. And for that, you need a bunker ship, and we are designing this bunker ship, which is going to be built by  Hudong-Zhonghua. It's going to be operated by MOL, the very large Japanese owner. And it's going to bring LNG  for CMA CGM, Total LNG. It's Total, which has signed for this contract.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So in the LNG as a fuel market, you can see that there are quite a lot of interesting things. Of course, there are  the tanks on these big ships. There are these bunker ships, which are not small when you talk about an 18,000  cube ship. And if we look – if you look at the quantities of LNG that CMA CGM is going to burn in a year, it will  represent about currently 0.1% of the world production, which is not at all negligible for only 9 ships. So quite a lot  of interesting things.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, talking about shipping industry. If we look at the worldwide shipping industry, we see that it's about 90,000  merchant vessels. It has about 3,000 newbuilds per year. It represents 90% of worldwide transportations, 3.1% of  the worldwide emissions, which is fairly rough figures because there, you are mixing different kind of emissions.  Some of the emission from the shipping industry, like for sulfur oxides or nitrogen oxides, are not particularly  friendly particles.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: But if we compare to the – if we look at the French emissions, the shipping industry are representing twice French  emissions. So it's really – there as well, not negligible, and it's an area where the world is decided to work on in  order to improve the emissions in this sector.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So different approaches are contemplated. Among them, there is the LNG, which is compliant with the – fully  compliant with the current regulations. The availability of LNG is improving. We can see that whenever an owner  is switching to LNG, major oil and gas companies are finding the solution. As we saw with the bunker ship we are  providing for Total, for CMA CGM.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The technology is available. There are already 248 LNG fueled ships in the world even though they are small, but  the technology is there. By the way, it's used for ages by LNG carriers, so it's something that we know quite well,  we, at GTT.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, we have solutions for providing LNG. We are currently finalizing the construction of a barge in the U.S. We  have this contract for a bunker ship. We developed a self-supporting membrane tank named Brick, which is  attracting quite a lot of interest. So what I want to say is that we have a wide range of solutions in order to answer  to the needs of the shipping industry.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Simultaneously, we developed a wide network of partnerships with yards, including new ones. So for example,  VARD is – which belongs to the Fincantieri group, is a new partner with whom we are working on these solutions.  We work also with some other partners, Wärtsilä, which is a very important player in the shipping industry, and we  signed a partnership last year in order to provide solutions for LNG as a fuel.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We signed also an agreement with DSEC to build membrane tanks in third-party shipyards. We have an  agreement also with COSCO in China. We have outfitters, people capable of building our tanks. We have several  of them, and shipowners are already turning to our solutions.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, something we are working on for years, it's developing our service activities. I would say that it's not only for  business, if I may disappoint you a little bit. It's really for helping the industry to operate in a very optimized  manner, LNG carriers and LNG-fueled ships. We – you saw that this industry is going to continue to grow, and  that is raising plenty of needs, for example, training needs.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So our strategic road map. Of course, we are keeping on working on intensifying the cutting-edge aspects of our  technologies on the LNG carriers. We are deploying these technologies on some immediate different sectors such  like – such as offshore. We are keeping on working offshore with FSRUs for – especially, but also FLNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We are keeping on working on multi-gas carriers. We are mainly working on LNG, but we sold ships for  transporting ethane. That's something which is still of interest for us, and we are looking at what we could do with  LPG. Gravity Based System, I talked about it early on. And in order to do so, we are keeping on improving our 2  technologies, NO96 and Mark technology.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We are enlarging our activities in LNG as fuel. And there, we developed biosolutions. Here I name, for example,  one, REACH4, which is a transfer arm between a bunker ship and an oceangoing vessel. It's something which is  far – fairly far away from a tank, but we designed it. And it's – this arm is already existing on the barge built in the  U.S. We are developing our services, and we are continuing to do so.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Beyond that, we are looking at what we can do in smart shipping. We have solutions – smart shipping solutions  in-house. And last year – this year, the beginning of this year, we acquired a company in Singapore named  Ascenz, which is providing this solution. Simultaneously, we are developing our activities in gas handling  technologies, and we are looking at what we can do there in the future to provide further optimized – even more  optimized solutions to the industry.

texts.speaker: Marc Haestier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Having said that, for 2019, we are showing already revenues of €201 million, which is a strong level of revenues  already booked. And for 2020, €102 million, which is also quite respectable. Just as a reminder, these numbers  are only for the core business, the royalties business. So they do not include the revenues derived from services  or LNG as a fuel.

file: GTT - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 19February2016 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, I would like to start with a short recall of what we are doing. You know that GTT is an engineering company  which has 50 years of experience in designing energy containment systems. We license our technologies to  industrial partners in different places in the world. We are currently employing close to 380 people mainly in  France, but also in the shipyards where we are building our systems. We've close to 80% or 70% of executives,  engineers, and other higher education people. Well, to turn quite quickly on our figures, in 2015, we achieved a  total revenue of €226.5 million, very close to the figure we achieved in 2014, and the net income reached the level  of €117.2 million determining a net margin of 51.8%.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, our global market share over the last five years reached 83%. Well, you know that we are intervening mainly  on LNG carriers, but also on some of the floating structures such as the LNG FPSOs which are called FLNGs, the  FSRUs, then the floating platform of their ships with regas facility and they are acting as Floating Regasification  terminal, they're very much demanded currently. We are working also on onshore tanks, and in 2015, we built a  barge for delivering LNG to ocean-going vessels. So, this barge, we are going to talk about it later on, has been  built in the US.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We are working with many stakeholders. The classification societies such as Bureau Veritas, ABS, DNV, Lloyd's,  which are approving our technologies whenever we develop them. Once that is developed, we have to talk with oil  and gas companies to get them, adopted by them, approved, adopted. And once that is done, we've got to talk  with shipowners in order for them to understand these technologies and to consider that they could implement  them on future ships. And once that is done, we've got to turn to our industrial partners, the shipyards, in order for  them to build them, to incorporate them in their offering to shipowners.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, the strategy of the company is to consolidate its leading position in the LNG shipping industry. You saw that  our market share is quite large and we are keeping, improving our technologies in order to satisfy the needs of the  stakeholders we saw. Our systems are – let's say, to summarize them are less expensive and more efficient, and  we are keeping on working on these systems in order to maintain these advantages.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We capitalize on the expected potential in adjacent sectors. I talked to you about FSRUs. I talked to you about  FLNGs. I have shown you the barge we are building on. We feel that in LNG, there are plenty of things to do. We  have tremendous technological potential with our experience, our expertise with our engineers, and thanks to that  we think that we are able to address requirements in adjacent sectors.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: They are young, highly educated, but we invest a lot in their training. We have also a highly incentivizing system  of compensation for our employees, and that is determining a very strong loyalty from them. This loyalty is  enabling us to enjoy capitalizing on their experience. We have societal responsibility as we maintain a very strong  dialogue with the LNG stakeholders.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: As far as our environmental responsibility is concerned, I would say that our systems are the most efficient ones.  And it means that LNG carriers with our systems are burning less energy than the others, less energy than the  others. And that is speaking for itself in terms of environmental responsibility. So, we have a very productive,  sustainable development policy.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, as far as our key figures for 2015 are concerned, what we can say that in 2015 we received 35 orders, 31  LNG carriers, 3 FSRUs and 1 barge. So it's a quite strong order group that we built. And in fact, our order book at  the end of 2015 has increased compared to what it was at the end of 2014, slightly 5.7%, but increasing.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The LNG bunker barge we've secured is the very first floating structure built in the US for delivering LNG to  ocean-going vessels relying on LNG. So, it's a kind of breakthrough. And we are very pleased, well, to go back to  the US where we did not build membrane tanks for [indiscernible] (00:09:12). We are very pleased to see that we  are on one of these floating structures.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And so, it's a major event although it's not very significant turnover overall for the time being, but it's the beginning  of a new era. We've signed cooperation agreements aiming at the industrialization of our new systems, Mark V  and NO96 Max with different shipyards in carrier, we've created new subsidiaries. We're in Singapore. We believe  very much in the development of LNG and LNG as a fuel in Southeast Asia. So, we would like to be down there to  be as close as possible to potential customers. And we set up also another subsidiary, Cryometrics, in order to  offer assistance for providing higher efficiency through a software to LNG carriers. We find our license agreement  with the Cochin Shipyard in India. You know that in India, there is the Make in India policy and the Indian  government would like to tell more and more to LNG and to rely less and less on coal. And they would like that  the ships which are going to deliver this LNG, we built in India. So, it's a natural landmark in the implementation of  this niche. So, we propose a dividend for 2015 of €2.66 per share, determining a payout of 83%. It's the same  dividend as in 2014, and you saw that the turnover figure is about the same as it was in 2014.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, we communicated recently about the KFTC, Korean Fair Trade Commission which has opened an inquiry  on us. We were notified about that on January 29. I will say that at this stage, we don't have any precise  information on that. We just received this notification. We consider that it may concern a possible abuse of a  dominant position in connection with the Korean shipyard LNG carrier construction business. Well, we can talk  about that, so that we are building a lot of LNG carriers in Korea, and that they are very much relying on our  technologies. We should not prejudge at this stage of any kind of conclusion on that.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, you can see here the stronger order book we received last year. And on the upper left side of the slide, you  can see that, in 2015, we delivered 29 LNG carriers to, in fact 26, 2 FSRUs, and 1 onshore tank, while we  received 35 orders. There were – a cancellation for two orders, in fact, which we just passed at the end of 2014  and cancelled at the very beginning of 2015.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We have a quite diversified shipowner base. I would say that all the LNG carrier shipowners are working with us,  and none of them is representing an overwhelming part. Apart from that, these shipowners are coming from  everywhere in the world, I would say, Asia, Africa, the US, Europe. So, it's quite diversified.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, let's spend a bit of time on the market drivers. We think that the long-term market drivers for LNG are strong.  There is a strong natural gas demand. There is a need for exporting gas. The share of LNG in the – and gas and  in the energy mix is still very small. We think that there is a need for additional capacity and we are going to show  you that, and there are new trade routes which are determining the higher need for LNG carriers. Well, we don't  deny the fact that we are currently in a quite troubled context with significant oil and gas price tag. You know that  LNG prices are determining according to a percentage of oil prices. So whenever oil is falling down, LNG prices  are falling down or it was largely like that. It's a bit different now with the American gas which is determined  according to a price of gas in the US, but this price as well is very low. And I guess you should know that  [indiscernible] (00:16:28) is – there are global economic concerns which render decisions a bit difficult currently.  How long it's going to last, I do not know.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: But we think also that low gas prices should lead to opportunities for LNG, and we're going to show you that. The  price of the energy – electricity coming from power, coming from LNG, is far more competitive than what it was  one year ago or two years ago, and against coal, against other energies. And that is quite a strong factor  foreseeing energy earning market share in the energy mix is a bit everywhere in the world, but particularly in the  countries highly relying on energy. It's a very strong factor for supporting LNG demand in the years to come.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, yeah, to speak a little bit more about that, yeah, you can see that that has coming from the International  Energy Agency. They consider that coal should decline over the next 25 years. Gas should increase and basically  by 2040 gas, coal, oil should be about the same percentage in the energy mix. While for the time being, coal is  still the largest energy use in the world and as you know it's a very polluting energy.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We think also that gas which is representing only – LNG which is representing only 8.6% of gas exchanged in the  world should increase its share. So, gas should increase and LNG in this increasing envelope should increase its  own share. So, gas is abundant. It's fairly well spread out. It's by far the least carbon-intensive fossil fuel. And  there are some geopolitical and original drivers which are determining that. So, we think that additional energy  capacity are needed. Why? In fact, if we look at the fields which are operating currently, we can see the other  projects decided we can see that by the beginning of the next decade, let's say by 2020 or 2021, production  should begin to decline. And, of course, if what I say is true, it's a – if gas is clean, if gas is attracted in terms of  pricing. If gas is not raising major political concern compared to other energies, gas should continue to be  demanded and we should not see a decline of LNG in the next decade.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, in order to cope with this increasing demand, new fields have to put in operation. And in order to do so, in  order to produce more LNG, we need liquefaction plants, which is something taking several years to build  depending on whether it's a greenfield project, where it may take six or seven years or brownfield project where it  may take four years. So, if we need additional capacities by 2021, decisions have to be taken last year for  greenfield projects or this year or next year for brownfield projects. So, we think that even though once more the  current circumstances are a bit troubled and people may have the feeling that the environment, the overall  environment and the energy environment and let's say the LNG environment are a bit gloomy, we think that the  underlying factor for a new project is there.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, just want to look at pricing. Some – on the left hand side upper part of the slide, you see what is the American  price. You buy the molecule and the mmBtu at a given price. Here we have $2.3, which is price for the gas in the  US. You have what we call – what they call in the US, the tolling fee which is the cost of liquefying this gas, $2.25.  And then you have to add the cost of shipping this gas to Asia which is $1.75. So, you arrive at a price of about  $6.1 or $6.3 per mmBtu. How does it compare with Asian prices for LNG? Asian prices, it's 14%, basically, a bit  more complicated than that, but it's visible, 14% of the oil price mmBtu per energy unit.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, we see that we are at a breakeven level for price per barrel at $40. Currently, it means that the American  price for LNG is a bit higher than the Asian price. So the driver of the market for a couple of years which has been  exporting the American shale gas to Asia is not so much there as the American price for LNG is higher than the  Asian price. Though, it still remains the opportunity for Asian buyers to diversify their procurement portfolios, and  not to rely on certain given number of – on a given number of providers, but also on American providers.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Also Asian buyers are very conscious of the fact that this price of $40 may not last forever and in particular, not  for the entire duration of their contracts. Whenever an American project is launched, it's for delivering LNG in  2020, and it's you pass the contract for 10 years, or 15 years, or 20 years. And so, it means that between 2020  and 2030, we have to assess what is going to be the Henry Hub price and what is going to be the oil price in order  to see what is the most advantageous for you. And I would say, I was in Japan last week, nobody's considering  that in these let's say between 2020 and 2030, the current market conditions are going to remain as they are.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, a consideration about lower LNG energy prices which in fact are creating opportunities for LNG. LNG is  mainly burnt for power in Asia. You know that the first customer, 37% is Japan and they are relying on LNG for  power. The second one is Korea [indiscernible] (00:25:00). And then you have other countries which are also  relying on LNG for power. So, it's in competition against some of the other energies and for example, coal. In  China, it's very much the same, but also Japan or Korea are still relying very much on coal for their electricity. So,  coal is cheap, but the fact of the matter is that the reducing price for – the reduced price for LNG very significantly  improved the competitiveness of LNG compared to other energies, and in particular, to coal. Still a bit more  expensive, but far less than what it was some years ago, two years ago.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, in many countries, in fact, there is this policy. Not so much announced, because I would say that the  syndrome we are suffering from in [indiscernible] (00:26:07) our gas maybe looked at coming from shale gas with  some environmental concern, but are still CO2-emitting energy is still there. So they are not so much announcing  that, but they are very concerned that it's very clean, no particles, no NOx, no SOx, far or less the CO2, and very  affordable. So they would like to increase the share of gas and LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, on this map, you can see projects which have been decided, and which could be decided. There are many  projects in the world which are contemplated. I would say that, so a lot of them are in the US or in Canada, some  in the south part of Africa, mainly in Mozambique. So, it's a bit difficult for me to tell you what are the projects  which are going to be decided this year, in the next month or next year. But I would say that a lot, many of them  are in the [indiscernible] (00:27:20), quite ready to be decided if the market conditions are improving slightly.  Whenever I'm talking with LNG companies, they share with you that in the medium term we need more LNG, and  so decisions have to be taken. And there are some projects which are ready to be decided. While the routes are  getting more complex, in the good old days, LNG was coming from Southeast Asia. It was going to Northeast  Asia. It was quite simple, a little bit across the Mediterranean Sea.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Now, it's far more complex with Qatar, [indiscernible] (00:28:01) further into the US and now going to Asia. And  soon there is going to be the exports of Shell gas coming from Gulf of Mexico to Asia and probably to Europe as  well. So, these routes are getting more complex. That means that there is a need for ships in order to  accommodate that.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And if the – what I call the pendulum pattern of LNG is disappearing, it means a ship going from a given  liquefaction plant to a given regasification plant somewhere in Indonesia to somewhere in Japan, if that is no  more the case, then it means that you need more ships because you cannot optimize this pendulum pattern. It's  not the pendulum pattern and you need more ships because ships may go from one place to another one, longer  one, may wait – maybe trading opportunities, so that is determining a much higher need for ships.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We see also – even though it's quite slow in the current conditions, and I will explain that, we see definitely the  development of LNG as a fuel. LNG can be used by ships for their progression. And as it is a much cleaner fuel  as the existing fuels, it may comply, it will comply with the environmental regulations. And with more standard  pricing structure, it may be a very affordable solution. It's with the current price structures that we don't see the  market development we were expecting, but still we are seeing some initiatives. Here you can see a ship that we  designed for delivering LNG on rivers. So, it's for [indiscernible] (00:30:18). And this market is starting slowly, but  it may, at a certain point of time, take off in a much more significant manners.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: There are regulations in different parts of the world for having clean emissions. For the time being, people are  very reluctant. Ship-owners are very reluctant to switch to LNG for meeting these regulations. And they try to find  some caveats in order to meet these regulations, relying, for example, on marine diesel oil  which used to  be far more expensive, which is with the current oil prices not so expensive. So I would say that the economic  driver for switching to LNG is not so much there, but it could come.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, just some words to tell you that LNG is a very clean energy. There is no SOx, sulfur oxides with LNG. There  is almost no NOx with the LNG, far less with the other fossil fuels, and there is lower CO2 emissions with LNG  compared to the other fossil fuels, and no particulates at all. So, when you look in detail about this issue of  cleanness, the LNG is definitely a beautiful energy.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And all of that, one important item, one very important aspect of our strategy is innovation. Innovation is about  one-fourth of our resources, more than that. If we look at our people, more than 100 people within the company  are dedicated to LNG and innovation activities. That's hundreds of patents. And innovation is delivering products  that our customers like, appreciate. If you look at our order book at the end of 2015, well, 80% of the order book is  composed of products that were not available in the market 4 years ago. So, really what we bring is adopted by  the customers.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Innovation is also at the renewal of our portfolio of technologies on our core business with the introduction of new  systems in 2015, Mark V with lower boil off rate and NO96 Max. So on our two families of technologies, we are  bringing innovative systems with better performance.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Where do we stand on that? Well, the designs of this systems have been completed and approved. We are in the  process of industrializing the systems together with the shipyards with Samsung and Hyundai regarding Mark and  with DSME regarding annual NO96 Max.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Lower boil off rate, you know that what we are bringing to the industry, lower boil off rate means better thermal  efficiency. It means better competitiveness for the LNG carriers because it means better operational efficiency.  Boil off account for very significant part of the OpEx of the vessels. So lower boil off, it's lower OpEx, it's better  results for the charterers. And in fact, it also leads to a better competitiveness of the LNG itself, because you  might have seen on the slide before, the cost of transportation has an impact on the competitiveness of the LNG  in the end.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And when it comes to boil off, we believe we have very good systems. It's very important in the context of these  days to recall what are the merits of our products, why we have such a position on the market and why we are  confident in our ability to continue to demonstrate to the owners, to the industry, that our products are the good  ones. We just make a very simple comparison to – because we have competitors, we have significant  competitors, people who do – develop systems. KC-1 is a new Korean system in membrane. The two ships are  being built in this system – with this system. Well, our assessment of this system is that the operational  performance is less attractive than that of our Mark V system, for instance, because we consider – we asses that  the boil off will be about twice as high as it is for Mark V.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And when it comes to Moss systems, which are the systems – the LNG carriers with spheres, well, the price in  terms of CapEx, the Moss systems end up with a higher CapEx with a more expensive LNG carriers than ours.  And that looking at the actual prices as we can – with the information we can have access to So, we're talking  about difference of 18%, which is we believe material.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So now, segment by segment, here we present what are our forecasts, our perspective, long-term perspective.  Philippe explained a lot what are the – our understand of the market drivers beyond that, so I will now come back  to that. And how does that derive in terms of long-term perspective for GTT. Well, this translates into for LNG  carriers, 270 to 280 LNG carriers over the next 10 years. Of course, I mean, from one quarter to the other, from  one year to the other even, there can be significant differences. But over the long run, the fundamentals of the  LNG market lead us to estimate to have this type of forecast.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Another segment is – so the ethane carriers, multi-gas carriers, so ethane, ethylene, and LPG, for which there are  specific drivers related to the abundance of ethane supplied in the US. You know that we have taken six orders in  2014 and we have the capacity to demonstrate the advantages of our system for such an application.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: FSRUs, so floating and storage and regasification unit, [indiscernible] (00:39:11) this concept of many merits in  terms of permitting when compared to onshore, there our estimate on long run is 25 to 35 FSRUs. Today, the  whole new builds in FSRUs are using GTT technology.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: FLNG, we estimate 7 to 13. So, around 10 floating units on the long run. As for FSRUs, we believe that these  systems have potentially a better level of acceptability than onshore systems. They are also allowed to monetize  to exploit offshore gas reserve.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Of course, these systems are still to demonstrate their operational efficiency, but three FLNGs are being built and  will soon be commissioned, and then they will be able to demonstrate how they operate.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Onshore tanks, we are confident in the advantage of our system. Of course, we have not the same position there  as the one we have on floating units. Still we estimate and we target 10 to 15 large tanks over the next 10 years.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, let's come a bit to LNG as a fuel. Philippe mentioned this bunker barge in the US. So it's really the first of its  kind and that's important. It's a new product. A barge like this, there is no – it's a new market, LNG as a fuel in the  US, and with new industrial partner. Conrad Shipyard is a new licensee of GTT. So, it's really, for us, a very  significant achievement. It will really make possible the development of LNG as a fuel in the US. And why do we  succeed there? We believe with our expertise in LNG, we are giving confidence to all stakeholders, to the  authorities, to our industrial partners, to the final customer. And that's very important in this market.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And overall, on the LNG as a fuel, our strategy is really to, even if the context is challenging to make the  emergence of LNG possible. One, we believe, as Philippe said, that LNG is the right solution to comply with the  new environmental regulation. It has merits in terms of environment. It's – technically it's available. So, the  question, the challenge is really to make it happen. So make it happen means providing to the industry all the  bricks, all the elements in terms of supply chain, in terms of technologies that will make this possible. And we are  bringing there competitive solutions, technically reliable solution based on our experience, and we are setting up  the right industrial partners as the one we have created in the US, which is a way of convincing the owners that  the solutions are available.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Services, just to repeat how important it is for the owners to have GTT along with them all along the life of their  vessel. Not only at the time of design, not only at the time of construction, not only at the time of commissioning  the vessel, but throughout its lifetime, LNG carriers are complex systems. They always require assistance,  advisory services and all this create a lot of opportunities for us to propose the innovative services. That's what  we have been doing over the last year and this translates into our turnover in 2015 and we will continue to do so  in 2016.

texts.speaker: Cécile Arson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So this allows the board of directors to propose for the year 2015 a dividend payout of 83%. If we look now at the  revenues, revenues related to royalties reached €209.3 million, driven mainly by LNG carrier and very large  ethane carriers, and by the offshore segments, FSRUs and FLNGs. So the decrease on revenues from royalties  amount to 3.2% and it's linked to the composition of our order book and also explained by some time lag in the  shipbuilding construction.

texts.speaker: Cécile Arson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So revenues from LNG carriers and very large ethane carriers represent a little bit less than 80% of our revenues  at €180 million and more than 72% of this revenues come from orders that we received in 2012 and 2013.

texts.speaker: Cécile Arson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And regarding FLNGs, revenues increased because we had an order – a further order in 2014. So what you can  notice also is that, of course, in 2015 we saw the first revenues from the banker barge that is being built in the US.

texts.speaker: Cécile Arson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: If you look now at revenues coming from services, they grew by 65%, and this is mainly due to several studies we  performed this year, especially sensibility and pre-project studies and that's a very good sign of the interest of the  LNG industry in our technologies, but revenues are also coming for services we offer to ship-owners to maintain  their ships in operation.

file: GTT - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 24February2017 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, you know that we are a French engineering company, a global leader in liquefied gas containment system.  The key figures for the company in 2016 is, royalties amounting to €223.9 million, and services of €11.7 million.  For services, it's a strong decrease compared to 2015, but 2015 was very high. Still compared to 2014, it's just  small increase, it's an increase. Royalties, it's a strong increase compared to 2015.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The net margin is [indiscernible] (00:01:17) of 50.8%, a bit below what we reached in 2015 but still something  fairly acceptable. As of December 2016, we were employing 358 employees, of which 70% were executives,  engineers, PhDs, especially [indiscernible] (00:01:45). As you know, we have been all along in the LNG chain on  the exploration with tank on liquefaction facilities. We transport LNG from liquefaction facilities to regasification  terminals, thanks to the LNG carriers we designed. Liquefaction terminals, we can provide tank, onshore tank, but  more and more – there are less and less onshore terminals by the way, and more and more floating terminals,  what we call FSRUs, floating storage regasification units. And we have a very strong position on this market.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: But [ph] we have been (00:02:33) also on other parts of the LNG value chain such as barges to deliver LNG, LNG  as a fuel to ship which are relying on LNG. We are currently building one in the U.S. and actively promoting this  solution. We've delivered in 2016 [indiscernible] (00:02:56), for example, so we do other things [indiscernible]  (00:02:59) all along the LNG value chain.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The ecosystem where we work is characterized with classification societies for approving our system. The Lloyd's,  BV, ABS, we have a very strong relationship with [indiscernible] (00:03:20). As you know, we introduced very  often new technologies, and they have to approve them. So, we have a very dense relationship with them.  Relationship with the big payers of the LNG industry, the ExxonMobil, the Shell, ConocoPhillips, Chevron, Total of  the world, and there as well we have a very strong relationship with the shipowners, the club of shipowners  operating LNG carrier. And we see, by the way, that with LNG as a fuel, more and more people would like to use  LNG, and this club should get larger over the years.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, we think that when we look at the industry, we think that the capabilities we are gathering in cryogenic  technology is unique and the relationship we've developed in terms of R&D with a partner with external  laboratories with universities is also totally unique and is putting ourselves in a very particular position because  we are gathering unique competencies not only in energy but in cryogenic technology.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Metrics for the R&D effort, it's the number of patent we are selling, we are beyond 1,000 active patents. So, it's a  quite strong portfolio of assets. Well, I will not tell too much into these details about our technologies, the  improvements of our technologies. That's one where – on the left hand side of the chart, you can see Mark V,  enlarged the thickness of the polyurethane foam, which is providing the thermal performance. And thanks to that,  we are able to reduce the boiler down to 0.7% (sic) [0.07%] (00:07:51) of the cargo per day

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: On NO96 Max, we are supporting the plywood plates by pillars and that allows to reduce the thermal conductivity  placing through this plywood structure. So that's the improvement we are including. And then, I think, on the Mark  V, the secondary membrane is replaced compared to Mark III by a metallic secondary membrane and we expect  that it will facilitate the action of the system in the ship.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, we are a responsible company with social responsibility – a very strong social responsibility. First of all, with  regards to people, basically as you know we are not investing into many things, [indiscernible] (00:10:05). And we  used to say that we invest in people. And we've gathered a fantastic team of engineers. And the way we treat  people is something which is absolutely important in creating value, value for shareholders. So that is really at the  heart of the way we manage our business.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: As far as the environmental responsibility we have, we are taking that very seriously. We know that sometimes  people are portraying fossil fuels as polluting. LNG is a very clean energy. It's the solution for the energy  transition. When we see that we are still using very much – the first energy in the world is coal, LNG is much,  much cleaner and much cleaner than HFO as well.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, switching to LNG for the world would be fairly easy, affordable solution for [indiscernible] (00:11:55). So we  are going to keep on improving the thermal efficiency of our system. It's a very good way of bringing  environmental improvement to what we do.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So Technigaz, with news for the full year 2016 to €235.6 million, it's an increase by 4% compared to last year  2015. We received five new orders. One LNGC order received in early October with the new Mark V system. That  is a major milestone for us. We have to say that the previous version, the Mark III and the NO950 have been  introduced at the beginning of the 1990s, so something like 25 years to go. We're introducing a new version, it's  something very important for us.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: FSRU is another checkpoint. Each time a FSRU is ordered, when it's going to be in operation, there will be  another gate for delivering FSRU. So, four FSRUs, four additional gates, maybe four new countries which will  switch to LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
