texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: In 2016, we delivered 27 vessels, including the very first FLNG, the fact that [ph] Petronas 1 (00:14:21) built by  DSME, and the very first multi-gas carrier such as ethane carrier. It can transport LPG, ethylene or even LNG. It's  dedicated for transporting ethane between the Gulf of Mexico and India [indiscernible] (00:14:38).

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And you may feel that this company is a little bit growing, always designing tanks, but in fact we, through our  activities, R&D activities, we apply our technologies to new applications such as FLNG, such as ethane carrier,  something which is different from a LNG carrier. And we are able, in doing so, to open new market for the  company even though they are not yet as big as LNG carrier, but we open new door.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We took several initiatives to develop LNG as a fuel. We may talk about that later on. As this market probably due  to the hierarchy between the energy prices is not picking up as quickly as we could expect. New services offering,  including the simulator for LNG carrier, which has been adopted immediately by several shipowners. First  contract, by the way, with the American shipowner TOTE for the training of the crews, not only the simulator for  the entire training. Global service agreement with Teekay that we announced recently was not in 2016. It was in  2017.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We opened another office in Shanghai. We do think that China is going to fill more and more to LNG, and there  will be a new applications – new opportunities for us over there, while there is no way to [indiscernible] (00:16:51)  in China but you can deal that from elsewhere. You've got to be down there. We maintained the dividend at €2.66.  So, well, it's appreciable.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: On the second part, you can see all the shipowners who've tested it, so it's quite a large number of shipowners,  and basically all the LNG carrier shipowners are our customers. And in terms of final customers, it's also very  balanced in terms of country. We have customers either in the States, in Asia, in Japan, in Korea, in Southeast  Asia, well, in Russia [indiscernible] (00:18:18).

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, the market fundamentals, first of all, LNG, we saw in 2016 the supply increasing by 5.5%. So, supply of LNG  is increasing quickly. We saw additional volumes coming from Australia, very large facilities, liquefaction plants  we have decided at the very beginning of the decade in Australia. Now they are coming online.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, while people are saying – while they're saying that there is too much LNG, some others say, well, at the end  of this decade or beginning of next month, there is going to be a need for additional energy and we've got to take  this decision. 6 million ton is not really small. I mean, it's [ph] 2% (00:19:32) for us compared to the current  maximum production. So, it's not insignificant.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: While you have opportunities for developing much leaner projects to existing facilities, that's the case in the U.S.,  that's also the case for Tangguh, it – the third train in Tangguh using all the existing facilities. The demand has  increased by 6% compared to 2015, in 2016. We saw five countries, not less than five countries joining the LNG  importers club with Colombia, Jamaica, Malta, Poland, and Abu Dhabi. It was three countries in 2015. So, this  energy is convincing more and more people.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, the volumes of these five countries are not that big yet, but it shows the dynamic of the market and that LNG,  thanks to its advantages, cleaner and affordable energy is convincing more and more people. While seven new  regas terminals became operational, including five FSRUs and it turns back to what I told you earlier that the  FSRU now is the solution of choice for opening new gate for delivering LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: You know that in the energy mix of these countries, coal is still representing a very important part. And that is  creating a kind of concern locally, because obviously, you need electricity close to big cities and if you have coal,  you generate quite a lot of pollution for the cities, which is now a matter of concern in China, we very well know  that, but also in India.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: On the other part, we saw some countries, like Japan decreasing a little bit their consumption of LNG. We know  that Japan is the first customer of LNG and has imported very large quantities of LNG since 2011. But we saw a  slight decrease and an important decrease in South America and that depends very much on the power  generation – generated by hydroelectricity in South America.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: But, this phenomenon has been largely compensated by the increase in other countries and mainly in Asia. Well,  the Asian price for LNG, thanks to the increase in the oil price, has increased and that is allowing American LNG,  not based on oil, but based on gas price, what we call the Henry Hub price, is now becoming competitive  compared to LNG – Asian LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The LNG produced mainly [indiscernible] (00:23:47) different formulas, but what we can say is that most of the  other prices are willing – are based on oil prices. So, there is the fact that all the [ph] quantities decided (00:24:03)  in the U.S. are very much competitive compared to Asian prices, this is a very good point for American LNG and  the dynamics of the market.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, something which is really very important is the fact that the decline in LNG prices due to low oil prices has  very much helped this energy to get – to increase its market share against coal. It has been further helped by the  fact that coal prices have increased in the second part of 2016. And while a lot of people know that they should  switch to LNG gas, they may wait just a little bit as coal is a more affordable solution. But when it's not the case  anymore, then the decision is much easier.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And in trying the current low LNG prices, it's an ideal situation for the switch from the coal to gas in a lot of energy  mixes. We see that and it is coming back to [indiscernible] (00:25:24) where we saw consumption of LNG in India  and in China increase. So, LNG market, how it looks? Well, India, that is coming from BP. I would like to thank  Shell for publishing outlook for LNG. It has been published twice at the beginning of the week, so I cannot – we  have not introduced that in [ph] our talk (00:25:54). They are strongly positive for the picture of LNG that we took  for this analysis, BP outlook.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And you can see that gas will increase, while oil and coal should decrease and the increase of LNG over the next  20 years should be very strong. So, the long-term perspectives of this energy are considered as very positive.  And well, something by the – sometimes by the end of the next decade, gas should be more important in the  worldwide energy mix than coal. We can only wish that.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: A strong anticipated LNG demand; in fact, calling from new FIDs for – preparing for the next decade. Well, there  will be additional demand in the next decade [indiscernible] (00:27:06) are going to be reduced. So, we are  expecting that FID should come back in year 2016, in year 2017, and in year 2018. And FIDs, you need a ship to  transport the new LNG quantity decided for a new facility.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: But meanwhile, we see that in this graph, which are coming from Wood Mackenzie that we may have a kind of  oversupply of LNG compared to the demand. So, we think that there will be an adjustment in this between supply  and demand and that will be facilitated by the low prices for LNG; low prices due to low oil price, but low prices  also due to the fact that the Henry Hub prices are going below. And that is standing back to this issue, that is –  the fact of a very affordable LNG and so a lot of people should turn to LNG to increase the share of this energy  into the energy mix.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: In the long run, what we say is that most probably [indiscernible] (00:28:38) U.S. American projects are still a  potential in the U.S., both in terms of LNG quantities, but also in terms of facilities which can be transformed –  importing facilities which can be transformed into exporting facilities in the U.S. and that has quite a lot of  importance in terms of shipping intensity. It means, in terms of ship you are needing for transporting LNG from the  U.S. to the markets.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, we think that the market for LNG carrier is going to continue to tighten over the year 2017 with higher rates.  And so, [ph] it will mark an instant fees (00:31:08) for ordering new ships. So, we kept on saying that the market is  needing between 50 and 60 ships. And you are – you may say, well, where are they? We did not see them in your  orders of – for – in 2016, so what's going on?

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The low chart rates have given a feeling of overcapacity in the LNGC market which is not that good. Well,  anyway, you need now two years to order a ship. If you have an overcapacity in a given point of time, it does not  mean that two years down the road [indiscernible] (00:33:29). But a lot of people who bought LNG and who were  supposed to arrange the shipping were under the feeling that there is an overcapacity on the market.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The absence of destination clause, which is a very important factor in the LNG industry, the absence of  destination clause in the contract for American LNG has created a kind of uncertainty of where the LNG can go. Is  it going to go in South America? In that case, [indiscernible] (00:34:09). Is it going to go to Japan? In that case, it's  very far away.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And so, that has created a major uncertainty which has not helped the decision in the overall environment. I think  that in the long run, it will be very beneficial, because this uncertainty will create more selling opportunities, people  looking at the higher price they could get which will mean that the average speed of the fleet – the overall fleet will  decrease and there will be an additional need for purchase. But in the first approach, that has created a certain  kind of uncertainty and has fueled this wait-and-see attitude [ph] from the industry (00:35:08).

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The last point is that the spread between the [ph] highest (00:35:14) prices of LNG, basically the Asian price  based on oil and the American price based on [indiscernible] (00:35:23) in North America. [ph] So, the small  (00:35:29) spread has not created shipping – trading opportunities. So, ships which were very much dedicated to  trading were available on the market and as vague on the market given [indiscernible] (00:35:44) of overcapacity  which maybe a little bit misleading if the condition [indiscernible] (00:35:52).

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, FSRUs, I talked several times about FSRUs. What we can say is that it's becoming more and more popular  with so many contracts in 2016 and we see that it's continuing to develop in the years to come. And by the way,  not only – it's not corresponding to an urgent need [indiscernible] (00:36:44) in the world, it's also a very quick way  to benefit from the low price of LNG. If you want to switch an onshore facility from coal to LNG, you have to build  the onshore facility. With a floating facility, it can go much, much quicker. So, it allows – it facilitates very much the  switch between the energy.

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: The first one is improving our product portfolio, our technology portfolio, and our core business. And that's what  we are doing when we introduced Mark V to the shipyard. It's then how to deploy our expertise into markets that  are close to our core business and that's what we are doing with FLNGs, with most of the gas carriers, and of  course, with LNG as a fuel. And introducing service fees, we – the quality of our relationship with owners and the  big energy companies [indiscernible] (00:38:49) opportunity to introduce new services and to improve, say  [indiscernible] (00:38:58).

texts.speaker: Julien Burdeau
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, that's also what you have here, maybe [indiscernible] (00:39:09) high, but in – that you have on the document,  it's the same strategy; three pillars – three main pillars and the fourth one which is here to [indiscernible]  (00:39:23) acquisition in the LNG shipping industry, thanks to our portfolio of technology. How to use our  expertise to benefit from the expected growth of adjacent sector [indiscernible] (00:39:44) and it's on the service  offering. So it's – we believe that external growth can be a lever to the pillar which we will improve – deepen our  [indiscernible] (00:39:54).

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: So regarding LNG carrier, as Philippe explained, extensively the situation of the market. Yeah, maybe a couple of  points to highlight. First we adjust it, we fine tune our long-term forecast for order of LNG carriers. It's an  adjustment coming from, let's say, an adjustment of the forecast of the long-term demand for LNG. And then, of  course, we monitor closely the way the vessels are operated, their operating profile, their average speed and  things like that, which allows us to model our security as possible the long-term shipping requirements. And that's  how we came up to these figures. So with the range of 235 to 255 unit of order the next 10 years.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Long-term industrial partnership, I mean, especially in a situation where [indiscernible] (00:41:53) this long-term  partnership with GTT has really is worth mentioning. It has been the key of success for them as – has built out of  LNG carriers and for GTT as a technology provider. And the third point is our position within the ecosystem and  it's not just about technology, not just about building LNG carriers. It's about creating confidence with a very  demanding industry, all along the supply chain.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Still on our core business, so close to LNG carriers just what we're doing on FSRU, that's LNG and onshore  storage. We also adjusted, fine-tuned the long-term estimate there. For FSRUs, let's say, we acknowledge the  stronger development of this way to bring gas to important countries. For FLNG let's say the first unit was  delivered last year and was put in production at the end of 2016.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Well, I just wanted to mention this fourth item there. It's kind of something in between a floating storage and an  onshore storage, gravity-based structure. It's an illustration of the type of innovation that we are bringing to the  market together with partner. Interesting concept in terms of reliability, in terms of experimenting so they finished  it off being offshore and in terms of either installation and the simplicity of a gravity-based system. So, that was for  the first pillar. The second pillar, what we are doing, let's say the opportunities offered by adjacent market and  especially [indiscernible] (00:44:40) LNG actually is a greater opportunity on the long run.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: As we said, maybe when one could have expected some years ago a quick uptick of this market, everybody  realizes how important it is and that it is really an energy condition for the whole shipping industry. And when I say  the whole shipping industry, I'm talking of tens of thousands of vessels. I mean, there are 80,000 to 90,000  vessels worldwide.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Here, we just mentioned the bigger ones, the ones that consume the higher quantity of energy. So, the big bulker  carrier, big tankers and container vessels and the equivalent [indiscernible] (00:45:27) Ro-Pax ships. So 25,000,  27,000 vessels. It gives an order of magnitude of what the whole industry will need to go through in the next years  in order to comply with stricter emission, stricter regulations in terms of environment. And there LNGs video  showing a compelling solution from an environmental standpoint, sorry, for reduced emissions of nitrogen oxide,  sulfur oxide, but also particles and CO2.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: So, if we're talking of an energy transition, so it means a lot of things to do, maybe a wide range of initiatives and  we are taking our share of that. And so, it's worth mentioning for a few of these initiatives in 2016. And industrial  initiatives, technical initiatives together with the shipowner, with the engine manufacturers, with the classification  society, so lots of partnerships and codevelopments have been undertaken last year.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Really what is key is to be able to bring the best technical solution to this market. It's also, let's say, initiatives to  improve the whole awareness of the market. And there the big energy companies, the big owners, the equipment  manufacturer, they are thinking together about what will be required in terms of commercial initiatives to  realignment, make this happen and that's what we are doing within the LNG which is a consortium fixated in June  last year.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: From an industrial standpoint, we are building the network, the industrial network in Asia, in Europe in order to  offer the possibility to owner to find and to direct our technologies at the shipyard. But still, I mean, we know that, I  mean, with the decrease of the – the hierarchy of energy prices today, I mean, the situation is not as favorable as  it could be. And that the economics probably still need to improve from where we are. We must bring also with  improved with a cost-efficient solution, and that the economy will still need to improve in order really towards this  market to [indiscernible] (00:48:19).

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: So there we're talking of technology, we're talking of energy efficiency, we are talking of expanding our market  reach on the adjacent market. We're talking about a cautious approach, of course, and we are very selective. We  continue to work on that. We believe, it's one lever among other to let's say, allow us to execute our strategy  based on the technology and expertise.

file: GTT - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 19February2018 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Good morning, everybody. I'm very pleased to be with you today to present to you the results of GTT for Year  2017. [audio gap] (00:00:15-00:00:27) Well, you know the company, just some elements to remind you the  principal elements. You know that we are an engineering company designing containment systems for LNG. We  have more than 50 year of experience. We are licensing our technologies to shipyards and to various industrial  partners. We are assisting our industrial partners in the construction of our systems.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Key highlights. We have currently an order book of 89 units. We obtained in 2017, 21 others: 8 FSRUs, 12 LNG  carriers, and 1 FLNG. We obtained large contracts for services from very large companies such as Teekay, which  is one of the largest shipowner in the world; from Chevron; from Shell for the management of the Prelude FLNG,  which is, as you know, the largest floating structure ever built by man.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We acquired in 2017, a company in Singapore, Ascenz, which is providing smart energy management solutions  for ships. And we proposed to maintain the dividend of €2.66 that we are paying for several years.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: To some market updates. While, as you know, the gas is regularly growing in the worldwide energy mix. Within  the fossil fuel, this is the only one which is growing probably because it's by far the cleanest among all the fossil  fuels. And in gas, LNG is growing very quickly. So, that what we saw in 2017, that what we saw also in the recent  years.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Now, this graph is showing the balance between supply and demand for LNG. We were under the impression  some time ago that between all the new projects which were launched in the current decade and the demand, a  balance could be reached by something like 2023. We are more positive about that now. We think that this  balance can be reached by 2021. That is very important because it means that by 2021, you may need additional  quantities of LNG. And if this assumption is true, it means that final investment decisions on new projects have to  be taken almost immediately. And, of course, final investment decisions are determining new – an additional need  for ships. So, new ships to be ordered. So, that's the fundamental point about the demand for ships.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, when we look at how the market behaved for LNG in 2017, we saw that – a very strong increase in Asia of  the imports for LNG. If you look at China, for example, the quantities have been increased by 47%. So, it's totally  huge. By the way, China has become the second largest importing country in terms of LNG, behind Japan.  They've overtaken Korea. Of course, we know the situation in China. They are very concerned about pollution.  They would like to turn to cleaner fuels, and a fuel of choice is LNG. Their capacity to increase at such a rate  shows that the infrastructures necessary to import additional quantities are there and are developing fast. In other  Asian countries, you see maybe in the smaller extent, but you can see this switch from coal to LNG, which is also  determining an increase of imports in LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, we see also new importing countries which have contributed to the demand growth, whether it's Pakistan,  Jordan, Singapore, even a country like Malaysia, which is exporting LNG, is more and more importing LNG. So,  the demand remained strong all over the world. And once you've begun to import LNG, generally you continue.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, this graph is showing the competitiveness of American LNG, including shipping, against Asian LNG. You  know that there are different pricing structures for LNG. American LNG is based on Henry Hub, which is the price  of gas in U.S., while Asian LNG is based on percentage of the oil price according to the energy power of LNG and  transported to Asia.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And we see that American LNG, now with the current oil price, has – we become very competitive against Asian  LNG. So, that is very positive for American projects and, also, for all the projects which had been decided in the  U.S., which we'll be able to find easily, customers, in the years to come.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, the charter rates, the – so, our – you can – [ph] I hope (00:08:39) you can rent your ships on the market. We  can see that for a year also, you can see that in year 2017, there was a very strong rebound of the charter rates  for LNG carriers. So, basically, that confirms what I was explaining to you, that there is a demand, there is a very  strong need for ships. And we could see that on the LNG carrier market, this need for ships has been confirmed  by the charter rates.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, well, we are below, of course, the figures. We are talking to you about a year ago, which was closer to  something like 50 ships. Of course, that takes into account the ships which have been ordered in 2017. But these  – the need, of course, is still there. Bear in mind that all these projects except the last one, Coral LNG, are  supposed to come in service by 2019 or 2020. So, well, we can see that there is demand potential which is  significant there.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We could add other projects. Those following the LNG market could talk about Arctic 2. It's a kind – after the  success, the amazing success of Yamal, built in four years from the decision up to the delivery of the first LNG  quantities. Russia and Russian partners are contemplating, deciding a second Yamal project named Arctic 2. We  could talk about the debottlenecking of Qatar, and we could talk of other projects such as in Mozambique. So,  there are many projects which are getting much closer to be decided. And it will be interesting to see how it's  going to move in 2018.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, our business activities, core business. We can see that our core activity is still the LNG carrier business, even  though we are developing fast on FSRUs and on services. But our bread and butter is still the LNG carrier.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, LNG carriers, we can see that we are still – we have still quite very strong position on this market with the –  after the flow of orders we had last year, progressing regularly on technologies for LNG carriers, [ph] LOS  (00:14:08), to maintain this strong position. And, of course, our past experience on this system, this system is  helping us very much.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: FSRUs, we had last year, eight orders of FSRUs. I would say that it's quite amazing. I would like to remind you  that all the new build FSRUs ever designed have been designed by us. So, we – it's a really very particular field of  expertise for us. People are looking at that as a kind of special LNG carrier. We see that very differently. And the  more we improve these systems – the more we work on these systems, the more we take into account the  specificities of these systems, which are facilities which have to remain operational in any kind of conditions. And  then you can maximize the return on investment on this piece of equipment.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Of course, the feeling of having a kind of – plenty of LNG was very much pushing the demand for FSRUs  because people were considering that they were needing new gates for delivering LNG, and ordering FSRUs  could be an opportunity for that.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: FLNG, we obtained in 2017, another for FLNG. So, that's the fourth one. There as well, all the – two FLNGs order  in the world have been designed by us. That's the fourth one, after the Prelude and the two Petronas. So, two  have already been delivered. So, it's still very new, but very strong advantage. You can operate on those  [indiscernible] (00:16:16). And as you can move the facility, the period for amortizing this very expensive piece of  equipment can be much stronger. So definitely, it's of interest for large LNG companies.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, LNG as a fuel is something I'm talking to you about for quite a while. We saw in 2017, a very large order from  CMA CGM for nine containerships with very large tanks, 18,000 cubic meters, so one-tenth of the volume of LNG  carrier. So, it gives to the owner, the capacity to go from Europe to Asia and back with only one way shooting. So,  I think that for the owner, it's a [indiscernible] (00:17:17) count, allowing them to bank at a very competitive price  in a given place of the world, because you have a quite large spread in LNG prices according to the place in the  world where you bank. We can see there for these large tanks, Membrane is the solution of choice because you  don't want to space commercial space. You don't want to compromise places dedicated to cargo. These volumes  can very hardly be reached by other systems. So, we – the choice of Membrane is a kind of no-brainer for  owners.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, the regulations are entering – are coming into place more and more all around the world, and LNG is a  solution which is complying with all the regulations. So, it's a – once it's competitive, which is the case now with  the oil price, it's a solution of choice.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, we are going to work on this shipping segment, while on the others, other solutions could develop. Anyway,  for us, it's, I would say, contemplating on some market segments. It's allowing us not to spread our resources on  too many things. And also, if LNG developing on some shipping segments that we cannot address, it's always a  development of LNG. It means more facilities, more LNG carriers, more bunker ships. So, more opportunities for  us to develop on these things.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We are looking at some of the large ships such as VLCC, the big tankers, or VLOCs, very large oil carriers, the  big bulkers for which we think that our solutions can apply as well, and we are that market segment's of choice.  On the left-hand side of the chart, you can see the PCTCs or the cruise ships which are also segments we are  looking at.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, just to illustrate the solutions we are working on, you can see how we install the tank on container ships.  You can see, in fact, on the cruise ship that this tank could be very much very low in the structures of the ship. So,  not really diminishing – decreasing the number of cabins. We imagine some retrofit solution, where you keep the  ship, it's something which is done regularly in the shipbuilding industry, and you add a block with the membrane  tank.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: And, of course, we – whenever the LNG as a fuel is developing, we can propose our technologies for the bunker  ships, the ships which are going to deliver LNG. We are building a barge in the U.S., which is going to be  delivered soon. And we've been selected by MOL for building the bunker ship which is going LNG to the CMA  CGM ships.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, in fact, when you look at CMA CGM, probably the LNG which is going to be transported for bunkering the  CMA CGM, it's going to be a membrane ship. The bunker ship is going to be a membrane ship, and the tank for –  in the CMA CGM container ship is going to be membrane. So, we are on all the segments of this chain.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We acquired Ascenz, which is providing energy management systems to ships, and we are very excited to what  we are going to be able to develop with them.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, they have 10 years of experience. There are few energy management system company which are successful,  capable of selling their solutions and capable of being profitable like the case of Ascenz. They are supplying that  to ships which are not LNG fueled or which are not LNG clients. So, they are going to continue on this line, while  we are going to work with them on developing solutions for LNG clients and for LNG-fueled ships.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, when we look at our road map, so on the left bottom part of the chart, you see a chart that you know quite  well, that we are showing you with the enlargement. On this column, you had the services that we are developing  for several years. The new – on the upper line, you have the new applications we are developing, mainly energy  as a fuel. And now, we are going to – we are looking beyond as – we are looking at very smart shipping solutions,  well, thanks to these Ascenz solutions.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We are looking also at gas and [indiscernible] (00:27:38) technologies. We think that for energy as a fuel, there  are [ph] expertises (00:27:45) which have – which are going to have more and more values. We are working  there. And we are looking at the convergence between these two directions, between smart shippings and gas  handling technologies. That's the area of growth we've identified.

file: GTT - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 27February2019 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, some key highlights, we obtained 51 orders in 2018, 48 LNG carriers, 2 FSRUs, 1 onshore storage. We  delivered in 2018 42 ships, so less than the number of ships we signed for. We – since the beginning of this year,  in fact, we signed for 11 new ships, so I would say that we are continuing on a – the very positive trend of 2018.  Also we had a several FEED, Front End Engineering and Design studies for the GBS, it's a technology we  launched in 2017. And as soon as 2018, it has attracted a lot of interest for the industry as we had already these  two study contracts. We signed three license agreement, one with the Sembcorp in Singapore, one with Keppel  for a shipyard in China, and one with Hyundai Mipo, subsidiary of Hyundai building small ships or fairly small  ships.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We obtained an authorization principle from Bureau Veritas for our latest technology, NO96 Flex on which we are  working. If we want to look at LNG first of all, gas we have to recall it remains like that and it's even increasing,  gas is the only fossil fuel which sees its share in the worldwide energy mix increasing. And more and more gas is  exported, thanks to LNG. So, the fundamentals there are strong and positive. If we look at the demand for LNG  over the coming years, we can see that [ph] weather forecasts (00:04:07) are coming from oil and gas [ph]  mutuals (00:04:13), banks or independent analysts. All of them are very pretty bullish and are very consistent. So  I would say that it's pretty much comforting. Also the LNG demand forecasts keep rising. You can see over the  past two years when we look at that whatever the terms are its increasing so also it's a quite comforting element.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We see that at work and when we look at the imports of LNG in some parts of the world and especially in Asia, we  see that its increasing quite strongly by 12% last year with a country like China which saw its import increasing by  44%. And China has overtaken last year Korea as the second largest importer of LNG.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Supply and demand that is coming – this study is coming from or this graph is coming from Wood Mackenzie. We  can see that if we want to cope with the increase of the demand looking at the depletion of the existing fields and  looking at what is currently in construction, we've got to come with new facilities quickly in order to cope with this  demand. That's a graph that we are presenting to you every six months. And some years ago in fact, people were  seeing a kind of crossroads between demand and supply by 2023. Now it's earlier which just shows what we  talked about before which is a very strong demand from the market

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So we need new LNG and for that we need investment decisions on liquefaction facilities. Some have been  decided, last year we had the third train for Corpus Christi, we had the LNG Canada project led by Shell which is  a huge project. We have the Tortue FLNG in Mauritania and we have Golden Pass which is regasification  terminal converted into a liquefaction facility in Texas.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So, we achieved all of them and some of the things you can see here the names. So I'm not in the [indiscernible]  (00:07:21) so I cannot tell you the projects which are going to be decided and when they are going to be decided  but many projects are ready to be decided. And we think that in the two coming years, we are going to see many  of them decided leading to a need for LNG carriers to transport these new LNG quantities.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: In fact, if we look at the shipping market, we can see on these two graphs on the left hand side, we can see the  spot rates. And we saw in 2018, a big bump, a big jump in the spot rates which were reaching almost $200,000 a  day which is a lot and which – well, it went down. But that shows that in fact there are very few ships available for  spot markets. So this market is very, very volatile. While it may be, I would say, it's quite exciting of course for the  people who are on this market, but it shows that in order to satisfy the requirement for LNG spot trading, there is a  need for more vessels.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: When we look at one year charter rates, we saw also a kind of jump not as significant as for spot trading, but a  significant jump. And in any case, figures now are above the cost of the ships. So in fact, it's a healthy market  which can be – can attract new comers or can decide existing LNG carrier owners to further invest in LNG  carriers.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: If we look at the existing ships, we see before year 2000, there were very few ships in fact delivered. LNG was  born in the 1960s, but up to the beginning of the past decade, few ships were delivered. Most of these ships are  still in operations. They are smaller than the existing ones and they have a fairly high boil-off rate, which means  that even though they have low rates – low prices to be fairly affordable to chart, their economics are not that  compelling on very long routes such as Gulf of Mexico to Asia where the shipping segment is [ph] waging a lot on  the cost of the delivered molecule (00:10:30). The ship on this trade is performing five voyages about a year and  so the cost of shipping is very significant in the [ph] cost of the delivered molecule (00:10:46). So what we think is  that as time goes on, these ships will have to be replaced. And that's something we did not factor in our market  forecasts up to now and that we have to take into account.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So looking at our core business and talking about our estimates of the market, we consider that over the next 10  years, there should be for GTT between 280 and 310 LNG carriers taking into account of course the more positive  forecasts about LNG and the need for replacing old existing ships. For FSRUs, we are between 30 and 40  FSRUs. We saw many decided in 2017 to in 2018. We think that as LNG is proving that it's an affordable and  fairly clean energy, having FSRUs will be as it has been a very attractive proposition. For FLNG, we see five  FLNGs to be decided in the next 10 years. And we have a new agreement where we add two onshore tanks, GBS  because that's not so far away. It's a kind of onshore tank that we put at sea near shore. And we plan to – we see  between 10 and 15 units over the next 10 years. So a certain increase compared to what we were planning  before.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So looking at new businesses, you know that we are getting close to January 1, 2020, when the global sulfur cap  is going to enter into force. The only way to fully cope with that easily is LNG. And you can see compared to all  the other solutions that LNG is a very compelling story, as far as emissions are concerned. Also a new factor on,  for the time being, a lot of ship owners are equipping their ships with scrubbers, which are cleaning up the  emissions – cleaning up the emissions in terms of sulfur dioxide not in terms of nitrogen oxide, [ph] now that much  (00:13:57) in terms of particles. Now more and more places around the world are forbidding the open loop  scrubbers. So, it means the scrubbers which are dumping into the sea the [ph] acid melts (00:14:16) that they get  from the scrubbers. Of course that is not that bad for water. So, I think it's an element which should be considered  because making this investment for not being able to use it so much in some areas is penalizing the return on  investment.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: If we look at the logistics, if you want to switch to LNG, you need to be able to get LNG, you need to be able to  bunker LNG. There are more and more bunkering ships, LNG bunkering ships around the world. You can see that  we got some and so the logistics is being put in place for supplying LNG to vessels, which is a kind of chicken and  egg issue, which begins to be [ph] a walker (00:15:31) . In 2018 we entered or we walk into two new market  segments in LNG as a fuel. The bunker ships, we had a bunker barge in the U.S. [indiscernible] (00:15:50)  vessels for bunkering the CMA CGM container ships an 18,500 ship – cubic meter ship built in China for MOL.  And we walk also into the cruise ship segment with the Ponant cruise vessel that we are going to equip with  tanks.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So we don't guide on the size of our expectations on LNG as a fuel. It's too early to say and we would not like to  mislead you. We'll just give you some – we just would like to give you some elements on this market. We have the  big container ships between 3,000 TEUs and 20,000 TEUs boxes, the bulkers more than 100,000 tons of  deadweight. Oil tankers, big oil tankers, and there are about 260 of them ordered each year. Now also the cruise  ships, the car and truck carriers and where capacity the space you occupy with the tank is absolutely critical.  There are about 40 a year. And you have the figure of the total fleet.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We see finally a fairly significant market with about 2,600 ships – new ships, new oceangoing ships over this year.  We are particularly focusing on about 300 ships but if there are some others coming, we would be very pleased.  So we are working on that, taking our time to walk into new segments as we did in 2018 and in order to make  sure that whatever the conditions [ph] already (00:18:26) so probably in 2020 with a sufficient gap between heavy  fuel oil and LNG prices then our solutions can take off. We are quite confident on that. We are working hard on  further refining our technologies to be able to address this market.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So we keep on developing our services. Originally, we wanted to assist LNG carrier owners, that is working well.  Now, we see a great merit in these portfolio of services in order to make the switch to LNG as a fuel as easy as  possible. You need to think about your designs, you can work with us. You need to train your crews, you can work  with us. You need assistance for LNG operations for bunkering LNG, you can rely on us. You need emergency  hotline 24/7 with very skilled people, we have that.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: You need sensors on the ships in order to optimize the way [ph] you have varied (00:19:49) the ship. We have the  solution. You need maintenance. You need to repair some something, we can do that. You need to test our  systems, we develop that. So we have the solutions. Of course, we are going to keep on working on that. But  what we have in mind, it's to make the switch to LNG as a fuel as easy as possible.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: We are investing in the future. We are bullish on LNG and we are not alone there. I would say that we've always  been and – but now a lot of people are convinced about that and showing this conviction. So we are keeping on  investing and working on the new developments. Here, you have new technologies, and in particular, High  Density Foam in order to cope with the liquid motions. You can add in LNG as a fuel, where you have all kind of  fitting levels in the tanks. You have the Brick, which is a block you can deliver to a third-party shipyard, which has  not to learn the Membrane Technologies.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: LNG as a fuel [ph] buyers (00:21:35), LNG as a fuel solutions, we have LPG applications on which we are  keeping on working. We have a GBS, I talked about that earlier. Well, we are keeping on working on all that and  investing on these developments to prepare the future. In fact, we are – you may see us as an engineering  company, but basically before providing detailed designs on our tanks, we develop technologies. It's at the origin  of the company, and we still have this DNA, we are still working on the various technologies while we keep also  our [indiscernible] (00:22:27), where we are lean and fit. We keep spending money on that.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: Well, just to give you an idea on the performances over the recent years, over the last eight years, we divided by  in fact a bit more than two. We divided in half the boil-off ratio, which is one of the fundamental characteristics of  LNG containment system. We are trying also to deploy digital strategy. So why do we do that? First of all, we are  working on that for several years since 2013, where we began to work on several software applications. We think  that softwares can help owners to switch to LNG, whether we are relying on expertise of [ph] cruise (00:23:35) as  on LNG carriers, a lot of things could be done by software, so we are working on that. We think also that in order  to be more efficient, ships should rely more on data management. You can collect a lot of data on the  performances of the ship, on the engines, on the conception of course on the cruise, on the route, and you can  optimize the performances, the energy performances of the ship. So we – that's what sustain our digital strategy.

texts.speaker: Philippe Berterottière
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Gaztransport & Technigaz SA
texts.text: So we acquired Ascenz in Singapore, which is a company which was offering software systems for ships. We  know LNG – well, to make a long story short, we know LNG quite well in fact, and they know digitalization for  ships; they are doing that for about 20 years. They know how to install that on ships, they know how ships  behave, and combining our two expertises, we think that we can provide a state-of-the-art solutions for the future,  in particular bearing in mind the switch to LNG as a fuel.

file: GVC - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 20September2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Sep-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Kenneth Jack Alexander
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: Okey-dokey. If you move on slide three, that's the content. I'll just move straight into the presentation. Slide five, in  terms of 2016 first half, the key highlights. Our pro forma NGR grew by 8% to just shy of €442 million. And on a  constant currency, on a pro forma basis, we were up 12%. Our Clean EBITDA grew 256% to €91.2 million. And  more relevantly probably on a pro forma Clean EBITDA basis, it was up 42% to €104.4 million. Our EBITDA  margin percentage has improved from 24% on a pro forma basis from 18% last year. And our adjusted PBT was  up 135% to €51.3 million.

file: GVC - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 14September2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Sep-17.pdf

texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: In terms of the first half highlights, Group NGR increased 10% to €486.2 million and that was up 12% in constant  currency in the first half of the year. Our Clean EBITDA improved by 28% to €133.9 million, versus €104.4 million  pro forma in the first half of last year.

texts.speaker: Kenneth Jack Alexander
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: Our Clean EBITDA margin percentage improved to 28% from 24%. I think this illustrates the synergies, the last of  the synergies coming through and the scalability of the business. In fact, we own our own technology. And as we  grow, the EBITDA margin should increase the scalable model.

texts.speaker: Paul Miles
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: Now, turning the page, you've got the statutory income statement here. So this shows five months for 2016, the  actual period that we owned bwin. A few items in the table worth highlighting and below the Clean EBITDA  number, share-based payments. They were €10.5 million. They reflect the long-term incentive plan and the  management incentive plan charge for the half year. This compares to a total charge last year of €31.1 million.  Going forward, that share-based payment charge will continue to reduce as this existing set of schemes runs out  through to August 2018.

file: GVC - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 13September2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Sep-18.pdf

texts.speaker: John Paul Maurice Bowtell
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: Turning to UK Retail, wagers were down 8% in total, but 7% on a like-for-like basis after the closure of around 100  shops. However, if you then adjust for a couple of other one-off items, positive and negative, including the World  Cup which is a benefit, full program of horse racing content, which you remember Ladbrokes and Coral didn't  have during 2017, which was a benefit. But the adverse impact of the cold weather in Q1 particularly, wagers  would have been down around 6%. And on an ongoing basis, we believe the underlying decline in sportsbook  wagers will be around 5%.

texts.speaker: Kenneth Jack Alexander
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: In terms of corporate social responsibility, we recognized we are one of the biggest players in the UK. We are  also probably the biggest licensed fee in the UK Gambling Commission. Corporate social responsibility is at the  core of everything that GVC now does. We have a new CSR Board committee and a new position of Head of  CSR. Responsible gaming, we take very, very seriously. We have a very, very good relationship with the UK  Gambling Commission. We have strengthened the regulatory and the compliance team within GVC and LCL  since we acquired Ladbrokes Coral. And it's, as I said, to the core of everything we do and it will continue to be  so.

file: GVC - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 23March2017 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Kenneth Jack Alexander
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: In terms of our pro forma Clean EBITDA, that also grew by 26% up to €205.7 million. Our EBITDA margin  percentage pro forma improved from 20% to 23%. Our adjusted PBT was up 102% to €93.8 million. The net debt,  which Paul can talk about more, was €131.5 million at end of the year, which is only 0.6 times pro forma Clean  EBITDA. We have just declared another special dividend for 2016 of €0.151, which takes a total of €0.30, which  we've declared last year, and that will be paid in 2017, the €0.151.

texts.speaker: Paul Miles
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: NGR, this increased by 9% in the year to €894.6 million, up 9%, 12% in constant currency. 69% of those  revenues were generated in jurisdictions that were already regulated, taxed or in the process of being regulated.  It's up from 68% last year. Kenny will talk a bit more later on about the drivers of the growth.

texts.speaker: Kenneth Jack Alexander
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: So, improved the product to get better cross-sell. We have also – we now have dedicated VIP management  teams on – offer our casino customers on the Sports Labels far more efficient bonusing. There's no wastage or  minimal amount of wastage. Far greater segmentation as well. So, we are a lot more efficient, a lot more cleverer  in CRM than what was previously the case. So, we've got a lot more content.

file: GVC - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 9March2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Mar-18.pdf
GVC - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 5March2019 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Kenneth Jack Alexander
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, GVC Holdings Plc
texts.text: Corporate social responsibility. We take this very, very seriously. We've made big, big improvements in terms of  the social responsibility, [ph] we lead the industry (00:46:09) to improve standards, i.e., the UK whistle-to-whistle  advertising ban. We recently just launched our Changing for the Bettor strategy. We've got very, very good  relationship with the UK Gambling Commission. We've  got a very good relationship with them. And as I say, I'm a lot more optimistic about the UK regulatory  environment than maybe many others. I think we're in a pretty good place in terms of the Gambling Commission,  and we're working very closely with them in terms of the UK regulatory environment ongoing.

file: GXI - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 7April2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Apr-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Just as a reminder, within five years, from 2005 to 2010, we have expanded the plastic business  within two dimensions, regionally and through product diversification. This is how plastics became  one of our two strategic pillars. The other is certainly glass. We are the only supplier to the  pharmaceutical industry offering prime repacking product made of out of glass and plastic. Clearly,  this gives us a unique position in our industry.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on to slide seven. I would like to spend a few words on our product portfolio. While offering  already – while our offering already consisted of a wide range of different plastic containers, plastic  bottles as well as of Insulin pens, as can be seen on the picture on top, Vedat’s product portfolio  comprises many different plastic closures as well PET bottles and other plastic containers. Now,  with the combination of bottles and closures, we are offering a unique and fully comprehensive  range of products for liquid and solid dosage packaging including dosage systems and closures to  our South American pharmaceutical customers on a one-stop-shop basis. Vedat will help us to take  an important step forward as a market leader – as a market leading full service partner for Plastic  Systems in South America.

file: GXI - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 12April2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: As you probably recall, in 2011, we expanded our activities in Brazil with the acquisition of Védat in order to  strengthen our pharmaceutical plastic packaging business in South America. Védat is a major Brazilian  manufacturer of pharmaceutical plastic packaging products with a special focus on plastic closures.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: Just to give you an idea about the size of the business, we do produce about 760 million bottles a year. That is  equivalent to roughly 20% of the total number of Moulded Glass container we produced in 2011, our Chinese  business [ph] excluded (0:09:52).

file: GXI - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 10April2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Apr-13.pdf
GXI - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 10April2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: From a divisional perspective, our Plastics & Device division once more was the strongest revenue driver within  the group. The pharma market continue to be very robust, especially the growth in generics and the increasing  trend towards self-medication are drivers behind our business.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: Moving on to slide five. I would like to spend a few minutes on our divisional performance. In Plastics & Device,  the strongest revenue growth was created in insulin pens, inhalers and our tooling business, but also in plastic  packaging. Revenues for the syringes also developed favorably.

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.text: This slightly positive development was fueled by margin increases in all three of our divisions. To  start with, the  Plastics & Devices margin went up slightly to 15.5% compared to 15.3% in the prior year's Q1. The main reason  was the very strong tooling and engineering business in the first quarter 2014. Positive effects came from the  higher revenues from plastic primary packaging, insulin pens and inhalers.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: One major investment was kicked off in our U.S. plant, our Plastics & Devices division in March. We will expand  our production facilities substantially and afterwards, this will not before the end of 2015 or beginning of 2016, we  will be initiating production of new inhalers.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: Our assumption for the year are based on good prospects for the Plastics & Device division where we expect to  generate strong tooling revenues and we will see further product launches. In Q1 again, we recorded a very strong  tooling revenue growth, and we are excited about the quality of the pipeline.

file: GXI - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 14April2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: About half of that improvement was due to €7.8 million lower CapEx spending compared to prior year. That's  however only a timing effect. We continue to execute our key initiatives in Plastics & Devices and Primary  Packaging Glass that we have addressed during our last two calls, and we keep pushing all of those projects that  will drive revenue growth and efficiency improvements over the next year. In fact, we are making excellent  progress on those investments and growth projects. See on slide 6, we have a few pictur es documenting that. As  you know, we are about to build a new building for a new inhaler in the U.S. We started last year, and now in the  first quarter we have successfully completed the set up of the clean room in our Peachtree plant.

file: GXI - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 13April2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.text: This was fully as expected and as indicated on the full-year 2015 results conference call. The earnings power for  that business has now become visible, and compared to our other business, the margin profile of the Plastics &  Devices business is now clearly superior.

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.text: The first position on top in light blue is the Schuldschein emission that we concluded in November last year. The  total amount here is €425 million. Figure remains absolutely unchanged compared to the end of November,  because this debt consists of tranches of 5 years, 7 years and 10 years to maturity with interest rates roughly  between 1% and 2%.

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.text: Secondly, we are fully devoted to primary packaging – primary pharmaceutical packaging. You see now, our  strong setup with both Plastics & Devices and Primary Packaging Glass showing mid single -digits organic growth  rate in Q1. And that is what lays the foundation for the overall very positive financials in the first quarter 2016.

file: GXI - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 6April2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Life Science Research Division, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: These revenues are booked following certain stages of project completion and as such can be lumpy on a  quarterly basis. Overall, we will have a total for the year, which is at minimum in line with 2016. Additionally, lower  demand stemming from some of our large pharma customers, for which we act as simple source supplier, has  also driven part of the revenue decrease within Plastics & Devices year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Life Science Research Division, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: Let's start with Plastics & Devices. Adjusted EBITDA margin was 24.5% in Q1 2017 versus the 23.7% in Q1 2016.  This translates into an improvement of 80 basis points year-on-year, which essentially results from the reduced  portion of the lower margin tool revenues in comparison to the same period last year.

file: GXI - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 12April2018 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Speaker of the Management Board, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: Let me start with Plastics & Devices. As a whole, revenues increased by €0.8 million or 0.5% year-on-year. As  anticipated, we recorded in this division a noticeable decrease in our tooling revenues this quarter. As you know,  temporary fluctuations throughout the year are normal, and the tooling business essentially reflects the invoicing  of large-scale projects. So, we do expect the same level of tooling revenues on a whole year basis compared to  full year 2017, but lumpiness and the quarterly phasing of these revenues. On the plus side, however, Peachtree  continued to perform well and could have compensated lower demand stemming from a selected number of  device customers where we are single source suppliers.

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Speaker of the Management Board, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: Please move with me to slide number 6 to review the main drivers behind the decrease in our adjusted EBITDA.  On a currency neutral basis, the adjusted EBITDA decreased as anticipated by €4.1 million year-on-year. Let us  start with the profitability review of Plastics & Devices on a currency neutral basis. In the quarter, the adjusted  EBITDA remains more or less flat, at €39.6 million compared to €39.5 million in Q1 2017.

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Speaker of the Management Board, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: In absolute terms, almost no change. Several drivers to be in mind here, although it is important to realize that we  are really talking about several effects, none of them are substantial, but in some they can explain the positive or  negative developments we are commenting here. So it is important to keep a sense of proportion here. So with  regards to Plastics & Devices on the negative side waiting to – in the adjusted EBITDA, we have the negative  temporary impact due to the higher resin prices. We've also to take into account that in devices, the capacity  utilization in some of our plants is also negatively impacted by the lower demand stemming from a few of these  customers, where we are single source suppliers.

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Speaker of the Management Board, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: We continue to invest further in growth opportunities as well in initiatives to improve quality and productivity. As a  whole, CapEx amounted to €10.8 million, and a large chunk of it was deployed in Plastics & Devices, in particular  with the aim to further expand our innovation capabilities in Peachtree and more generally our product portfolio.

file: GXI - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 11April2019 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Dietmar Siemssen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member-Management Board & Plastics & Devices and Advanced Technologies Division, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: We bring our attention to the external environment of our business. There's not much change. It remains pretty  stable at the beginning of the year. Worth to mention is probably the FX impact as we encounter it to the last year.  At present, enjoy a slight tailwind. Let's have a look at the operations.

texts.speaker: Dietmar Siemssen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member-Management Board & Plastics & Devices and Advanced Technologies Division, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: The construction work actually begins in June. The start of production is planned for the second half of 2020. We  will start at the beginning with the production of medical plastic systems and  later also use the plant for prefillable  syringes.

texts.speaker: Anke Linnartz
texts.text: Let me also tell you that I'm really excited about our pipeline in Plastic Systems, which might call for some  additional investments in 2012. Clearly, the investment in the Czech Republic, where we are about to double our  production area, is also a share in putting our pipeline to work.

file: GXI - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 11July2012 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: Adjusted EBITDA was flattish quarter-over-quarter at a level of €58.6 million with Plastic Systems and Moulded  Glass being the strongest contributor. The adjusted EBITDA margin came in at 18.7%, about 110 basis points  below Q2 2011. With regards to the sales mix of Plastic System, two furnace overhauls and temporarily higher  quality cost in Tubular Glass that's fully in line with our expectations.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: So I'm moving on to CapEx. Several growth opportunities in Plastic Systems and in the area of Moulded Glass in  India drove our decision to increase CapEx spendings by €20 million. And please move on to slide seven to take a  look at the new opportunities we have identified to grow the business.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: All in all, highly interesting and intense programs which I'm really excited about. So what does it mean for our  growth in Plastic Systems? I would like you to remember three things. Number one is we always need to invest  first in order to allow for the production of new products. And second is we need some time before we actually can  turn the investment into revenues. And number three, not all new business – well, not all business is new business  and not all business is incremental since they are also products within our portfolio in MPS that will be phased out  at some time. Well, that's the lifecycle management for projects.

file: GXI - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 10July2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: So overall, Tubular Glass delivered a margin performance clearly below target in the second quarter, while Plastic  Systems, Moulded Glass, and Life Science Research performed nicely.

texts.text: Please move all with me to slide 5, since I would like to spend a few words on our operational performance. The  main driver of revenue growth was once more, Plastics & Devices. Within the divisions, our primary packaging  business generated strong revenue growth, but also our tooling business and our syringe systems contributed  nicely to the growth of the division. The adjusted EBITDA margin was slightly up on prior -year quarter mainly  because of revenue growth in plastic primary packaging and syringe systems.

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: On a divisional net level, let's start with Plastic Systems & Devices, where the margin went up slightly from 20.5%  to 20.6%. By the very strong tooling and engineering business in the second quarter 2014 had a dampening effect  on the margin, this was overcompensated by positive effects from higher revenues was plastic primary packaging  products, and slightly higher productivity in the syringes.

file: GXI - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 9July2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Rainer Beaujean
texts.text: To sum it up, we managed to increase profitability in Q2 compared to the previous year and that was achieved by a  good business performance in Plastics & Devices and then also by our continued high cost discipline in Primary  Packaging Glass.

GXI - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 13July2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Jul-17.pdf

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Primary Packaging Glass Division, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: Second, also worth noting that tooling revenues were still lower year-on-year. So here, as in Q1, we had some  residual timing effects. On the flip side, we could see organic growth of primary plastic packaging in line with our  expectations. So, overall, the revenue decrease of 3.8% for Plastics & Devices in Q2 2017 year-on-year or minus  5.7% on an organic basis.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Primary Packaging Glass Division, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: Three main initiatives I would like to cover on this slide. First, over the past years, we have been systematically  upgrading our glass and plastics product portfolio. COP, syringes, and multi-layer COP vials have been added  before.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Primary Packaging Glass Division, Gerresheimer AG
texts.text: Here, we have made further progress during this year and I wanted to show some examples for drug delivery  solutions. Our product offering has been really bolstered in the past 12 to 18 months as we can offer now baked- on, ready-to-fill syringes with a drastically reduced amount of silicone oil particles, ensuring the stability of drug  formula during the period of medication storage, metal-free and low tungsten syringes that exclude or reduce  potential residues with tungsten.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: As we said on our last call, we consider today’s environment more favorable for acquisitions. We  aim for acquisitions either in the Tubular Glass or Plastic Systems division, and consider North  America or the pharmerging countries to be appropriate regions for expansion.

GXI - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 4October2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: All divisions contributed to our revenue growth. The main driver behind the positive development were Plastic  Systems and Moulded Glass. Growth in Plastic Systems was seasonally a little weaker and we haven't yet recorded  growth out of the new project that are currently being ramped up in our new hall in the Horšovský Týn plant in  the Czech Republic. We assume that we will show stronger growth rates in Q4 again.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: When talking to customers in our Plastic Systems these days, we see more price sensitivity. Our best view as of  today is that our Plastic Systems margin presumingly will be affected as negotiations on a few long-term contract  renewals might require pricing concessions. Hence, we might need to allow for rebates for a few large customers  with high volume, long-term contracts that are up for negotiation, in order to keep our market position and the  production volumes in place.

texts.speaker: Hans-Jürgen Wiecha
texts.text: Moreover, our product pipeline in the Plastic Systems division continues to look very promising and we are in the  process of building new factory space for future growth.

file: GXI - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 2October2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: To sum it up, very good Q3, with Plastics and Moulded Glass doing very well. We saw further improvement in  Tubular Glass, and we keep managing costs, Life Science Research. As we have stated in our press release, we will  adopt the new structure as of the beginning of the new financial year on De cember 1 to ensure a more efficient and  effective management of the group.

texts.speaker: Uwe Röhrhoff
texts.text: Our new structure will allow to adjust to customer needs more quickly and consistently, accelerate growth, and  achieve greater efficiencies from scale. From December 1, 2013, we will manage the company through three  divisions: first, Plastics and Devices; second, Primary Packaging Glass; and last but not least, Life Science  Research.
