With few exceptions, Group companies in Asia Pacific have beaten their results  for the previous year.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. We are pleased to welcome you to our 2009 results
texts.text: The result is operating EBITDA growth of 5% relative to the fourth quarter last year. Operating  EBITDA includes proceeds from sale of CO2 emission allowances in the amount of CHF29 million.  In comparison, we had 34 million in proceeds in the fourth quarter 2008. Adjusting also for the  provisioning of the plant closures and restructuring costs, the operating EBITDA reduction of only  3% testifies that the still ongoing volume decline was mitigated to a large extent by the cost  reduction.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. We are pleased to welcome you to our 2009 results
texts.text: Operating EBITDA declined to 4.6 billion, representing a decrease of 13%. The movement in  foreign exchange rates has also negatively impacted the operating EBITDA. Adjusting for this and  the changes in scope, the decline in operating EBITDA was 5% in 2009. The figures include CO2  sales of a total amount of CHF90 million last year, 34 million.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. We are pleased to welcome you to our 2009 results
texts.text: Our energy costs also declined, although the reduction of CHF1.40 per tons of cement produced  did not meet our expectations. In Group region Europe, like-for-like operating EBITDA dropped by  33%, driven by volume declines across Europe and a precipitous drop in both volumes and prices  in Russia, Azerbaijan and Spain.

file: HCMCF - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 2March2011 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: for 2010. As always, we shall concentrate on the financial aspects of Holcim. However, I would  particularly like to draw your attention to the preprint of our annual report, which in 2010, the UN’s  International Year of Biodiversity, especially addresses this issue from our perspective, as well as  dealing with our topics such as our fundamental strategy, innovations and employees.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: Despite the financial crisis and recession in many mature markets, Holcim decided to continue with  the capacity expansion program initiated in 2007. The main focus of the expansion has been and  still is on the emerging markets, where needs in the housing and infrastructure sectors are on a  huge scale and will continue to grow as urbanization continues. All new plants deliver cost  reductions, as well as improvements in our environmental performance.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: Between 2008 and the end of February 2011, Holcim commissioned some 22 million tonnes of  cement capacity the locations of these plants are colored in red on the map. Investments under this  program already peaked in 2009. In the year under review, expansion investments have been  reduced by one-third totaling CHF1.2 billion.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: Projects which are still in the pipeline are marked in black on the map. One such project, due to be  commissioned in the first quarter of this year, is a kiln line at the Shurovo plant in Russia, which will  have an annual capacity of 2.1 million tonnes. The new facility, which will replace an old, inefficient  wet line from the Soviet-era, will deliver not only a substantial reduction in production cost, but also  improve the environmental footprint.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: In Azerbaijan too, we shall be commissioning a modern kiln line with a capacity of 1.7 million  tonnes of cement before the end of the year; here too, a very old kiln line will be replaced in an  attractive building materials market. The other expansion projects or new builds on France’s  Atlantic Coast, at the Fès plant in Morocco, at the Guayaquil plant in Ecuador and at the new  Tuban plant in Indonesia will follow in 2012 and ‘13.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: North America, in the U.S., construction activity recovered slightly during the course of the year. As  part of the stimulus programs, major road building projects were also given the green light in the  second half of the year. The Canadian market remains robust and consumption of building  materials increased, particularly in Holcim’s key markets of Ontario and Quebec.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: Demand was supported by ambitious construction plans, such as tunnels, airport expansion  projects and motorway building. Consolidated sales of cement and ready-mix concrete increased.  Shipments of aggregates declined slightly.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: Shipments of aggregates and ready-mix concrete declined, mainly because of weak demand on La  Réunion. The plants managed by Holcim Trading in West Africa and the Arabian Gulf increased  their sales of cement. Work on a project designed to double the clinker capacity at the Fès plant in  Morocco is progressing according to schedule and the plant is due to come on stream in 2012.  Operating EBITDA of Group region Africa Middle-East declined slightly due to currency factors.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: Now to Asia Pacific, developments in Asia Pacific were positive. High infrastructure spending and a  positive investment climate gave a boost to many countries. Housebuilding and major infrastructure  projects supported sales, which increased across all segments, partly, thanks to the first-time full- year consolidation in Australia.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: A new kiln line commissioned at ACC’s Wadi plant has a daily capacity of 12,500 tonnes of clinker  and is currently one of the largest of its kind in the world. This plant also supplies the new grinding  stations in Karnataka. ACC also expanded its ready-mix concrete network in the urban centers.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: Cement Australia was able to maintain its cement sales despite adverse weather conditions. Owing  to delays on major construction projects and the weaker construction market in Queensland,  Holcim Australia experienced a fall in sales of aggregates.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: A word on resources and biodiversity. The extraction of raw materials such as limestone, crushed  stone, gravel and sand generally has an impact on biodiversity. In 2007, Holcim therefore signed an  agreement with the International Union for Conservation of Nature, IUCN.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: In addition, to minimizing the impact of extraction operations, the aim is to promote biodiversity at  these locations. Independent experts have developed the biodiversity management system and  Holcim has made, protecting biodiversity part of its Group strategy. Thanks to their positive  experiences, Holcim and IUCN have decided to extend the partnership for a further three years.  Themes of the extended cooperation include defining transparent indicators for measuring success  in the field of biodiversity and the development of the Group water management program.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: 4 again Holcim has been marked SAM Gold Class from the Sustainable Asset Management Group,  SAM.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: For the full year 2010, total energy cost per tonne of cement produced remained stable meeting our  expectations. The still low cement capacity utilization in Europe led to sales of CO2 emission  allowances in the amount of CHF95 million compared to CHF90 million the year before. In Q4, the  positive trends in Europe, North and Latin America reduced the gap in operating EBITDA to minus  4% on a like-for-like basis.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: However, U.S. cement consumption will rise slightly. In Canada, construction activity will remain at  a high level.

texts.speaker: Markus Akermann, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to welcome you to the Presentation of our Annual Results
texts.text: Asia Pacific will witness further growth in 2011. Holcim is benefiting from the additional production  capacity in India. In Australia, the devastating floods will initially have a negative impact on the  operating results of both Group companies. However, in the second half of the year the  reconstruction of the damaged infrastructure will lead to rising sales. In New Zealand too, last  week’s major earthquake in Christchurch will affect demand for building materials.

file: HCMCF - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 29February2012 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: One of the most modern cement plants commenced operations in Shurovo in Russia primarily serving the  booming market of Moscow. Shortly before the end of the year, Holcim also produced the first clinker at a new  kiln line at the Garadagh plant in Azerbaijan. The strong Swiss franc, higher costs for energy and transport, lower  receipts from the sale of CO2 emission certificates and the difficulty of adjusting prices to cost inflation in a  difficult competitive environment, all had an impact on the operating result. In addition, the non-cash  impairments affecting fixed assets and goodwill in Spain and Eastern Europe also weighed on the group result.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now to North America. Also, the U.S. economy grew slightly. Particularly in the second half, the construction  economy did not really get going due to savings measures in the public sector. In Canada, the economy weakened  a bit following a strong previous year. In this country too, a number of cement-intensive infrastructure projects  were postponed.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Africa Middle East, the construction sector developed in this region very positively in the markets relevant to  Holcim. Cement and aggregate volumes declined, however. This is attributable to increased competition in  Morocco, where new players have joined the market. By contrast, sales of ready-mix concrete increased. The  project to double clinker capacity at the Fès plant continues to progress according to schedule. This facility will  commence production in the second half of 2012.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And now to Asia Pacific, economic growth was strong in the group region Asia Pacific. Thailand's economy stalled  temporarily following the serious floods in the fall. In Oceania, the year kicked off with severe flooding in Eastern  Australia, while the earthquake in New Zealand also hindered the construction sector for a while. In India, ACC  and Ambuja Cements sold significantly more cement, thanks to capacity increases. Siam City Cement in Thailand  supplied rather more cement domestically, and deliveries of aggregates and ready-mix concrete were up sharply.  Holcim Vietnam won a number of key orders in the commercial and industrial sector. In the Philippines, cement  sales declined due to weak infrastructure construction, and Holcim Indonesia posted robust sales increases in all  segments, thanks to a booming construction sector.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The project for a cement plant in Tuban on the main island of Java progressed according to schedule and will  enter production in 2013. Cement Australia sold rather less cement, while Holcim Australia also suffered from  poor weather conditions but managed to increase its sales of aggregates. Ready-mix concrete sales only just fell  short of the previous year's level. Operating EBITDA for the group region Asia Pacific declined due to inflation- related cost pressure, which could not yet be passed on to the prices everywhere. On a like-for-like basis, however,  significant growth was recorded.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: Net sales increased to CHF5.3 billion or a strong 13.1% on a like-for-like base. This result is a combination of good  overall volume growth and improving pricing levels achieved towards the end of 2011. The increasingly positive  impact from pricing, together with the good volume growth and some CHF32 million higher sales from CO2  trading, more than offset the increased costs. As a result, the like-for-like operating EBITDA improved by an  impressive 15.5%. And this is important to note, for the first time since the first quarter 2010, the operating  EBITDA margin increased on a quarterly like-for-like base. As already previously announced, the impairment  charge and provisions of CHF775 million after tax recorded in the quarter under review negatively impacted net  income attributable to Holcim shareholders.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: The overall volume increases benefited on the one hand from an improved demand in a number of developed  markets, while on the other hand, from continued building activities in many emerging markets. Net sales  amounted to CHF20.7 billion, down 4.2% due to the negative currency impact with the very strong Swiss franc  contributing a negative 12.5% to the top line development. On a like-for-like base, sales increased by a good 7.5%.  The operating EBITDA declined by some 12.3%, just falling short of CHF4 billion. However, on a like-for-like  base, the operating EBITDA only decreased 0.2%, reflecting the good volume and pricing momentum recorded  during the second half of 2011 that nearly managed to offset the negative impact of higher raw material, energy,  distribution costs on the other hand, and lower income from CO2 trading on the other. Net income attributable to  shareholders of Holcim Limited amounted to CHF275 million, down 76.7% year-on-year due to the impairment  charges.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: Operating EBITDA reached nearly CHF4 billion, representing a decline of 12.3%. Adjusting for the negative  currency impact, amounting to a negative 12.3%, and the change in scope of consolidation, the operating EBITDA  remained more or less flat, at negative 0.2% compared to 2010, which is in line with the outlook we have given last  year. The positive momentum recorded during the second half of 2011, with good volume and pricing growth,  more than offset negative cost impacts but could not fully compensate for the weaker result recorded in the first  year of – first half-year of 2011. However, excluding the impact from lower CO2 sales of CHF32 million compared  to 2010, the like-for-like operating EBITDA, in fact, increased by CHF21 million, or some 0.5%.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: Turning now to a regional overview on operating EBITDA, Europe like-for-like operating EBITDA decreased by  3.8%, prompted on one hand by lower performance in Hungary, the United Kingdom, Belgium and Italy, and on  the other, the lower sales from CO2 transactions. This negative development could not be fully offset by favorable  price developments. Full year operating EBITDA therefore reached CHF930 million, down 11% year-on-year.  North America operating EBITDA reached CHF346 million, down 24.9%. On a like-for-like base, the decline  amounted to 15.5%, mainly driven by slightly lower prices and additional costs related to distribution; and the  closure costs, which have mentioned before, of two plants in Holcim U.S. This was only partially compensated by  positive volume developments. In Aggregates Industry U.S., prices developed positively but could not fully offset  the increased variable cost, such as raw material, but especially in the case of asphalt.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Sustainable development is something that really means for the teams and they are dedicated to it. And of course,  when you see a company, there are strength that you can find and that's the right opportunities for improvement  and upside potential. And I focus my time on building on the strength and identify and getting upside potential  [indiscernible] (32:52).

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Now I come to the growth initiative in India. [ph] Holcim India (39:47) decided to expand the cement production  capacity of the group in ACC in East India in a market with a strong potential [inaudible] (39:59) tonnes. So this  will impact the existing Jamul site in Chhattisgarh state. It's 35 kilometers west of Raipur, the capital of the state  where are the current facility will be replaced by a state-of-the-art clinker plant with a daily capacity of 9,000  million tonne of cement per year. At the same time, the capacity of the existing Sindri grinding plant, which is a bit  northeast in Jharhand will be increased by 1.35 million tonne per year. And a new grinding plant will be built with  a capacity of 2.7 million tonne in Kharagpur, that is east of Jamul and it is now located in West Bengal and quite  close to Kolkata. And both grinding plants will be supplied with clinker from Jamul, and it's planned to start  operation of the new facilities toward the beginning of 2015. Globally, it's a CHF600 million project, and we come  with a cash consumption in 2012 of a bit less than CHF50 million.

file: HCMCF - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 27February2013 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of cost leadership part, the main contributions on a net basis came from procurement with CHF48  million and from energy and alternative fuel with CHF40 million. In addition, I can mention that the 2013  composition scheme of the top 1,000 managers of the Group has been adjusted to be aligned with the delivery of  the Holcim Leadership Journey.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Holcim also optimized its capacities outside of Europe. In the Yocsina plant in Argentina, the clinker production  was stopped. And in Australia, in Brazil, in Mexico, the aggregates and ready-mix concrete business were  optimized.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The development on the Pacific Rim, on the other hand, was less dynamic. Nevertheless, there were certain  impulses; in Australia, in regions with strong mining activities; and in New Zealand, in connection with  reconstruction after the earthquake in Christchurch. Overall, Holcim increased cement deliveries. Mainly due to  Australia, aggregates and less pronounced ready-mix concrete deliveries decreased.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: With regard to ready-mix concrete, the reduction can directly be attributed to the strategic repositioning of our  ready-mix concrete business in Brazil. The operating EBITDA increased. Excluding the one-off restructuring  costs, the like-for-like operating EBITDA rose by 10.7%. Primarily the Group companies in Ecuador, Colombia  and El Salvador contributed to this positive result. However, the weak construction activity in Argentina impacted  the financial results of our local Group company. Shortly before year-end, Holcim sold its participation of 20% in  Cementos Progreso in Guatemala to the local majority shareholder.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In two important markets, we're expanding our presence in the cement segment; in the Brazilian plant of Barroso,  a substantial expansion will be realized by 2014, and a new kiln line to increase clinker capacity will be built at the  Guayaquil plant in Ecuador by end of 2015.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now Europe. The recession that has continued in EU after the difficult start to the year caused by bad weather  conditions, the European construction industry never really gained momentum. The austerity policies of  governments and the cautious private sector led to a decline in demand for construction materials. Only in Russia

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: CO2 sales in the fourth quarter were CHF12 million lower compared to last year. The operating profit increased by  3.6% to CHF575 million, adjusting for one-off restructuring costs. As a result, the adjusted operating profit margin  reached 10.8%, up from 10.5% in the fourth quarter 2011.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: As a result, the adjusted operating EBITDA margin expanded by 0.4% to 19.6% year-on-year. CO2 sales were  lower by CHF1 million, and therefore did not really impact the comparison to 2011. The operating profit grew by  10.6% to above CHF2.5 billion, adjusting for one-off costs amounting to CHF736 million. As a result, the adjusted  margin recorded an increase from 11.1% in 2011 to 11.8% in the year under review. Cash flow from operating  activities reached CHF2.7 million (sic) [CHF2.7 billion], representing a slight decrease of 2.6%, or 1.8% on a like- for-like basis.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: Cement prices increased in all regions, albeit to varying degree, while aggregates pricing was mainly driven by  Group region Asia Pacific, North America, and Europe. With the exception of Group region Africa Middle East, all  regions recorded positive sales impacts from ready-mix concrete pricing.

file: HCMCF - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 26February2014 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: In particular, the logistics, the procurement as well as the energy and alternative fuel streams gathered pace in the  course of 2013. This means that together with the achievements of 2012, the total contribution is now at CHF1.1  billion.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Asia-Pacific, overall, the economic climate in Asia-Pacific in 2013 was solid, although there was considerable  heterogeneity across the region. Growth in some emerging countries was lower, whereas others witnessed an  ongoing high level of economic momentum. Over the course of the year, tighter global liquidity as well as local  structural impediments impacted growth in India, although the pressure eased slightly towards the end of the  year.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: The proportional consolidation of Cement Australia led to lower cement volumes in Australia. Holcim Australia,  which focuses on aggregates and ready-mix concrete, was affected by the declining mining boom as well as by  delays in some building projects.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Holcim Mexico recorded lower sales volume in all three segments due mainly to reduced or delayed spending on  infrastructure projects as well as the closure of ready-mix plants in non-profitable markets. Nevertheless, the  group company benefited from clinker exports and also managed to keep costs in check.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: In Spain, the deteriorating macroeconomic climate was once again felt harshly by the construction markets, and  the local group company only increased cement volumes due to exports. As the situation in construction markets  in other parts of Europe remained challenging and also lacked momentum throughout 2013, Holcim was only able  to increase volumes in a few markets.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Cement volumes at Holcim US decreased during 2013. An unusually wet spring and early summer, which  postponed concrete projects in the first half of the year, affected Holcim US as it shortened the construction  season. Some of the backlog, though, could be recuperated during the second half of the year. Still, we were able to  witness a positive price development.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Aggregate Industries US sold more aggregates, primarily in the West Central and the Mid-West regions, with  improvements in single family home and public segments as well as commercial construction. Asphalt sales  volumes were lower due to change in construction activity in the South West region and ending of major contracts  in the Mid-Atlantic region. Ready-mix concrete volumes in 2013 almost met the previous year's level.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: In addition, we had a negative impact of CHF35 million compared to last year as our income from CO2 trading  activities was CHF27 million compared to CHF62 million a year earlier. This as a result of the current uncertainty  on the future allowances and generally lower prices for carbon, for CO2.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: Like-for-like operating profit growth and margin, excluding the impact from CO2, amounted, therefore, to 2.6%  and 12% respectively. Variable costs showed a slight negative contribution as reductions in variable production  costs of goods sold were more than offset by an increase in variable distribution costs, however, clearly, beating  the rate of inflation.

file: HCMCF - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 23February2015 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Let me now give you a more detailed overview of the 2014 performance in our five group regions. Asia -Pacific's  economic climate was characterized by the start of the rebound in the Indian economy and solid growth levels in  most of the major markets in the region. Most Indian Group companies of Holcim have benefited from the more  promising situation in construction markets in the country. Ambuja Cements and ACC benefited from various  commercial initiatives across the country that opened new markets and increased sales of cement products.  Ambuja performed particularly well with an operating EBITDA margin above 20%.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Holcim Philippines reported a strong increase in cement volumes as the government continued to trend  infrastructure projects, while the positive business environment has emboldened the private sector to push  through these expansion plans. Volume developments in Indonesia was positive for cement and aggregate, while  ready-mix concrete deliveries were flat.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Holcim Australia was impacted by the decline in resource sector investment as large scale projects, particularly in  Western Australia, were completed in the course of 2014, and subsequently aggregates for new decline. In  response to the continuing low growth environment and the decline of the resource sector investment, the Group  company adjusted its footprint and reduced headcounts to be more agile and more effective.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Fourth quarter figures were particularly strong. Volumes in aggregate and ready-mix concrete declined  significantly impacted by the closure of several plants in 2013 based on our strategy to focus on the most  profitable market. After Holcim Ecuador reported solid cement volume growth over the last years with 2013 being  a record year, the Group company was affected by the country's declining cement consumption in 2014. Public  investment was subdued as a result of liquidity restraints by the government.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: Holcim Morocco reported higher cement volumes. While domestic demand was lower, the group company  benefited from clinker exports to the Ivory Coast. Less dynamic activity in residential construction, which  represents the majority of the local market, was the main driver behind the domestic development. Aggregates   and ready-mix concrete volumes decreased.

texts.speaker: Bernard Fontana
texts.text: In Lebanon, Holcim Lebanon held cement sales, but lost on ready-mix concrete volumes. In the Indian Ocean  region, Holcim sold more aggregates and ready-mix concrete, mainly thanks to the group's operations in La  Réunion, where Holcim is involved in a major road-building project.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: Ready-mix concrete unit volumes were lower, the result of restructuring and divestment activities as well as the  market contraction in Latin America.

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: In 2014, Holcim realized total operating profit contribution from CO2 of CHF 47  million. This is CHF 21 million  more than in 2013, as we took advantage of favorable stock prices for emission rights in the fourth quarter.

file: HEI - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 5May2011 1100 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Our results have significantly improved, sales up 19%, EBITDA up 48%, and EBITDA margin also  improved to 9.7%. Just a clear message now to avoid any misunderstanding, there are no CO2       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 2 gains in Heidelberg nor this year nor last year. That’s different to some of our competitors, who  have already realized CO2 gains in Q1.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Net debt is down by about €330 million compared to the same period last year. Our focus on  expanding cement by brownfielding and greenfielding remains on track. We have successfully  started our second Kiln line in Gorazdze, Poland, adding 2,500 tons clinker capacity. That’s now  the largest cement plant in Europe. We have a daily clinker capacity of about 12,000 tons, which  gives us a cement capacity of about 5 million tons per year. This new capacity comes in due time.  We expect a very strong run in the Polish market this year and also next year with volumes clearly  ahead of 8%. And Heidelberg as the market leader in Poland will then be in a good position to  benefit from the strong development in that market.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: If you look on slide four, on the sales volumes per area, just a short snapshot. If we start and here  you see, if we start with North America, you will see cement 3%. However, if you go more in detail,  then as we said in our presentation in Canada, especially in the Prairie provinces, we had an  extremely harsh winter. I was personally up there in February for business, but also for skiing. We  had temperatures between minus 25% and minus 30%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: However, we had a negative growth in China of minus 10% due mainly to an accident in one of our  quarries in Central China at a big cement plant from us in Shenyang, where we had to stop  production for a while and that impacted sales volumes and also our margin, because we could  start the operation again. However we had to buy clinker from the market and then to grind it to  cement.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Slide seven shows the trend in the EBITDA development. It shows clearly that the EBITDA trend on  a 12-months average is moving upward, so we are improving profitability. Our FOX program with  cash savings for the next €600 million and P&L savings of about €200 million is well on track. We  have already done 11 pilot sites in the quarry optimization program, starting in North America and  UK and also here in Central Europe. And during the pilot site visits, we clearly recognized that the  saving target which we have announced to the market of €120 million by 2013 seems to be clearly  possible. The same is true for our OpEx excellence initiative in cement, which is focusing on a  reduction on electricity and fuel consumption

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Cement capacity expansion, we plan to install around about 6 million tons new capacity in 2011.  That’s shown on slide nine. Two key projects, Tula in Russia close to Moscow, 2 million tons should  come onstream at the end of Q2. And we have Damoh, Central India. 2.9 million tons should come,  should be finished by Q4, 2011, then a new big mill in Chittagong, Bangladesh and Gorazdze, we  have already done. We have also outlined here again the investment costs. We think that CapEx  for these investments is relatively modest.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now, if we look to energy management, it is clear that we were a little bit caught by surprise  compared to the budget or operating plan discussions we had with our operational units by the  clear increase in coal and electricity price and are also in the fuel and gasoline price, namely in  North America. The problem is that the crisis in the Middle East and in Japan and also the decision  of the German government to move away from nuclear power happened all in March, whereas we  had our operational plan meetings in December.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now what you see here, what we show you here is the coal index. On the left side, you see here  that for Europe, for example, API, and also Australia Newcastle, the coal price went clearly up,  whereas local American coal is relatively stable and you see also on their electricity pricing, we  show the forward costs for Q3 2011. Also here you see in U.S., Texas, electricity prices are going  down. That’s what we see also in our cement units, whereas in Europe, more from Europe but  especially Central Europe, that’s Germany, electricity products are clearly moving up. And you see  clearly the decision of the German government to move away from nuclear power created a spike  in the forward pricing for electricity for the company.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: If you look now to the question, how does that impact our figures compared to plan? If we talk coal  and electricity, we have practically no increase in North America, because we are locked in and the  price increase is not very relevant. In U.S., the problem is more on gasoline and fuel, where the fuel  price per gallon went up by about 30% compared to the beginning of the year and this is a burden  of maybe about €30 million, €40 million for us and we will try to push that on the customers by fuel  surcharges in the market. That’s an item which is mainly our ready-mix and aggregate divisions.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Ii you look to Europe compared to plan, the nowadays forward prices for electricity and coal are a  burden of maybe compared to plan of about €20 million. It’s mainly electricity, €13 million which  would assume that we would cover now all remaining spot volume by forward contracting, what we  are not doing at the moment, because spot at the moment is getting cheaper in Germany again.  The sun is out, it’s windy, so we have a lot of spot volume available. And that’s where we are on       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 4 energy, so energy, we manage that market-by-market, commodity-by-commodity and excessive  price increases, we will try to push over to the customers by surcharges.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In UK, we have already done two price increases now across all business lines. First one in  January, second one in April, so in UK, we will be in a position to offset any increases in energy  costs by increased pricing. In Northern Europe, we have done price increases beginning of the  year. We have announced a further fuel surcharge for Norway. In April, Sweden will follow and we  watch the development on the other markets very closely.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: One characteristic of these market is that due to the continental climate, the season is relatively  short. So typically in summer the demand for cement is higher than the production capacity and  that leads always to local shortages, which we can then use in order to push prices and we have to  watch how the situation is developing. We are pretty confident that especially in Russia, but also  Kazakhstan, Georgia and also Ukraine and Poland, we can go for a second price increase.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Canada, volumes down, as I told you, due to the harsh winter weather in the Prairie provinces;  however, our order book is in good shape. Our orders from the oil well industries are up 5% to 6%  compared to last year. We had already done price increases for gray cement of C$5 and for C$8  for oil well cement in the Prairie provinces and have also now announced a price increase for BC of  C$5 starting from 1st of April. Building products, I think we have done a good job. You see that  result significantly improved. We have changed top management last year and we have started to  restructure further in pipe, but also in bricks, which leads to a clear results improvement.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 5 now up to above 80%, 85%. Last year, it was around 71%. That means we have to use also less  efficient kilns, older kilns and we have higher fuel costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Australia, good development, we have set a significant price increase of AU$7 to AU$8 per ton of  aggregate and also concrete in April, and we expect good price development in Australia for the  remaining of the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: So, story is simple for Asia Pacific. Volumes are continuing to run at a good level. The main issue  are higher coal and electricity costs, which put pressure on margins. Africa-Mediterranea, Africa as  I said, very strong development plus 20% increase in volumes, also Turkey good, Israel good.  Spain remains weak, result improved and it will expect a recovery for Spain group services.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Another key message on bullet point three, FOB cement prices in Asia, that’s typically free on  board, Shanghai are clearly moving up. In March they went up by US$8. That’s a significant rise in  one month. That is a clear reflection of the Japan crisis. You know that Japan, which used to be an  exporter, will become now neutral or even an importer, which puts cement and clinker prices in Asia  on the rise.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Targets, unchanged, what we communicated, CapEx, cost of gross debt, operational tax rate mid- cycle. And management priorities remain unchanged. We will have, again, a dual policy on the one  side, manage cost and cash aggressively with a target to come back to investment grade metrics  as soon as possible. A big instrument is our FOX program and at the same time, we will continue  our growth policy in cement in emerging markets by focusing on brownfielding and greenfielding.

file: HEI - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 3May2012 1100 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On the other side, operating EBITDA declined by 16%, around €40 million down. And if you look to that and you  run through the areas and you see the only area where we are really down is the area Western and Northern  Europe where the EBITDA came down by about €54 million, which is to a large extent weather related. I come to  that later.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We had higher costs for energy and freight, especially diesel. On the maintenance, we had a timing effect because  due to the better outlook on volumes for 2012, we have changed the repair strategy in some core markets. For  example in Indonesia and China and also Germany, all cement kilns were under repair in the first quarter whereas  we had the repair jobs stretched out over the full year in 2011.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Western and Northern Europe, you see cement is down 8%, aggregate 6%. Here the picture varies really from  country-to-country. In Northern Europe; Norway/Sweden volumes were up between 1% and 2% against the  strong Q1 from last year. This shows the growth and the robustness of these markets. We had a significant drop in  volume mainly in the UK [indiscernible] (04:40) partially market related in Netherlands, partially weather  related, and the slowdown was double-digit. In Germany, the volumes there were only down 5%. That underpins  the strong condition of the German market because also Germany obviously we had a very cold – the cold wave in  February and last year we had a very mild winter.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If I go to the key figures, we've already mentioned EBITDA. If we then go down to operating income, you see €60  million last year, €14 million this year, that's a difference of about €46 million. The region Western and Northern  Europe is down on operating income level by about €58 million and explains the difference. Dr. Näger will come  back on cash flow and balance sheet.  Now if you look to cost development and price decreases – price increases, then you see on the energy side we had  a price inflation in energy compared to last year of about 6% to 7%. The scale that we were running against the last  year, which was not very much influenced by the Japan nuclear disaster which happened only in the middle of  March and that's why we were running against the low base rate from last year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We see in the energy side a clear softening trend mainly driven by lower gas prices in U.S. with the consequence of  lower electricity prices. We see electricity prices in Germany coming down. We see also coal trending down below  $100 per tonne. So overall, we see a softening trend on the energy cost side.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The key risk remains the higher diesel price, which went up significantly in March. It's now flattening out a little  bit, but especially in U.S. the price per gallon remains an issue. Maintenance costs I already mentioned. We expect  maintenance costs to stay flat or even decline on a tonne basis for the full year. On pricing, a message clear in  aggregates, overall pricing is solid as in the last years. We have done price increases between 1% up to 5%, 6% in  our major markets in U.S. and Canada, in UK, Australia, and Northern Europe.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We have further price increases to coal now by 1 of April. That applies especially to Germany where we have  announced a price increase by about €5 per tonne. We hope that we will get something between €1 and €2  depending on the regional markets. In California and Texas, price increases became effective especially Northern  California and Texas by $5 by 1 of April.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Okay. On FOX, our program is on track. You see that from the left part of the chart and some additional  information on our supply chain optimization project. We go here for a savings target of about €150 million. We  had a lot of questions on what about – what's the background of this saving target of this initiative. The issue is  relatively simple. We had overall in the Group about – logistic costs of about €1.8 billion, €1.9 billion and we are  focusing mainly on two areas. We want to increase the truck utilization rate in the Group especially between  aggregate and cement because here we can use the same vehicles for transport.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: I come now to the area Western and Northern Europe. You see Europe EBITDA is down about €54 million and  operating income by €58 million. And we highlight here again we had a double negative impact in Europe in Q1  compared to 2011. First of all, we had the cold wave in Europe for about three weeks which stopped production in  quite a few countries. And secondly, we were running against the very strong and mild Q1 2011, which even  December 2010 was a very weak month because we had an early winter in Europe and this volume we did then in  Q1 2011, that's why the 2011 figure were in addition to the mild weather additionally inflated.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In India, we had still problems with increasing coal cost. Our volumes were more or less flat, the market was  relatively strong compared to a relatively weak 2011. The first two months, the market was up about plus 14%, I  think haven't seen the March figure yet. We are sold out in India and we are waiting now for our Damoh Jahnsi  project to come on to the market in June, July.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Australia, volumes were negatively affected especially in ready-mix – aggregates, we're down about 8%, 9%. We  had very wet weather in Queensland and also in West Australia, the markets in Sydney and Melbourne are rather  flattish. On the other side, we are very confident on the mining industry iron ore/coal. In Northern Queensland  and Western Australia north of Perth, order book is good. The volumes will pick up during the year. Pricing in  Australia, very strong, clearly up compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Africa-Mediterranean Basin, slide 14. If you look through the figures, the figures operating EBITDA is up and  operating income also slightly up. We had a good trend in Africa, volumes are up, pricing in the market is good,  and our clinker costs, an important clinker to Africa is coming down compared to last year due to very low  shipping rates so this improves the profitability. Outlook for Africa is positive.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Prices came down a little bit now in April. The FOB prices in Asia are still up compared to last year. Freight rates  still remain low and coal prices, as I said, I think will soften during year.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.profession: Yeah. Good afternoon to everybody also from my side. I will lead you through the financial section, which start on
texts.text: The net loss from discontinued operations, you know this is our asbestos and environmental activity in U.S. We  settled one case was more than €3 million during the first quarter, which brought our cost up to €8 million.  Throughout the year we should see the normal amount which we have seen also in 2011. So the Group share of  loss comes to €204 million compared to €161 million last year. Finally if you look at the old picture, we saw that  what we had not reached in EBITDA dropped through the whole P&L down to the bottom line.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.profession: Yeah. Good afternoon to everybody also from my side. I will lead you through the financial section, which start on
texts.text: Net debt went down to €8.38 billion. I had explained the development of this on the previous slide 19. Liquidity  head room is still very strong. Our maturities, which are shown on slide 22, for the next 12 months amount to €1.9  billion. This now includes the Hanson bond in U.S. dollars, which matures on 15 of March, 2013. That's the green  plot on the left side, the €562 million. The €962 million then are different debt instruments such as debt  certificates under German law or commercial papers and the other positions are subsidiary debt and accrued  interest.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On the energy side, also here the situation looks a little bit friendlier than one year ago especially maybe then in  January, February. What we see is that cash price has come down in quite a few states in the US which has a good  impact on the electricity price in North America. Electricity also in Europe is very much down due we had now  warm weather in March and in April. We had a lot of windmill and solar energy so the spot prices in Europe are  down. Coal is down at the moment in Asia, also coming down more in Europe. In Asia the main reason is that the  biggest coal importer is obviously China. China has stopped by law cement and steel production in the first  quarter in some provinces. That's reduced the imports of coal significantly and that has a softening trend on coal.  And what we have then done, we have started to buy spot cheap especially for Indocement in order to use spot  market rates in order to lower the coal costs.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: What's the strategy? We want to switch to natural gas wherever it's technically possible and commercially  attractive. We switched to pet coke which is on a record low at the moment where it's technically possible. And we  focus on international coal spot market for Asia and also stay short on electricity in order to use the cheap spot  rates for the moment. So overall, we think year-over-year flat 5% which is to a very large extent driven by the  lower base rate we had in first quarter 2011 compared to 2012. So we see at the moment a softening trend. It is  clear that any political turmoil in the Middle East could change that picture overnight, but that's what we see at  the moment and that's what you see if you follow the financial press a little bit, what you see in newspapers.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you look to our growth strategy on that chart 28, you see we have done Górazdze and Russia, Tula. This year,  Damoh Jahnsi will come in the middle of the year with 2.9 million tonnes, Liberia 0.5 million tonne end of 2012,  Ghana 1 million tonne at end of 2012. Bangladesh is already running 800,000 tonne, and in Indonesia we have 2  million tonnes additional capacity coming into Europe by a vertical mill and debottlenecking of our existing kilns  in Citeureup. And then we have now that is new effect on the chart is that in Indonesia we are starting a project of  a new brownfielding plant in Citeureup in Jakarta because we are – we think that to put up a Greenfield plant in  Indonesia will be time wise very time consuming and in order to bridge the time between starting the project, we  have two Greenfield projects running in Central Java and Sumatra, and really getting it up for operations. We  have to bridge that time difference by brownfielding and we plan to put up a 10,000 tonne kiln with clinker  capacity of about 3.5 million tonnes, 3.6 million tonnes and cement capacity of about 4 million tonnes, 4.2 million  tonnes in Jakarta and Eastern Europe in our existing plants. And we are at the moment in the phase where we are  looking for offers for the technical equipment. We have not made a final board decision in the cement level, but  that's a project which has also been announced by Indocement.

file: HEI - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 8May2013 1100 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: I'll start with chart number 3. First remark, maybe, Q1 in our industry depends very much on weather. It's also a  little bit a weather forecast, especially if we talk about Europe and North America.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: That's the first. We had very wet and long winter here in Europe. We still had snow in April here. And also, on the  U.S., East Coast and northern half of U.S., we had, compared with last year, a very long winter. It was still snowing  in half of the northern part of U.S. in April.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Operating income – OIBD was up 3% based on good pricing performance and lower energy cost. If you look to  operating income, it's even up 30%. If I look to the other players in the industry, I think our results are  operationally pretty much okay.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Cost structure continues to be well managed. And we are well on track with our efficiency programs. As you know,  I always say that if you talk about efficiency programs, it's always important to look what's the head count doing.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Another result driver is, as we told you in March, the energy cost in the first quarter for the Cement division – our  fuel cost, meaning coal and electricity. Energy cost in total is down compared to last year by 3.6%, driven mainly  by fuel. Coal is down by about 9%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 5 shows you the weather. I think you have to look to March. March in our industry typically is very  important because, obviously, January, February in Europe and in U.S. there's not much activity. If the winter is  warm, we start with the building activities already in March. If the winter is very long and cold, then in March, not  a lot of things are happening.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And what you see on the picture is the red color shows you the warm weather. That's what happened in 2012. And  the blue color shows the cold weather and that's what happened in 2013. And you see that Europe was pretty  much covered by snow and cold.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And you see the same also for U.S. We put that on chart number 6. You see that, especially in last year, we had in  U.S. an extremely mild weather. U.S. was only to a very low extent covered by snow. And we run against a very  tough benchmark. And that's why we think it's better to compare 2013 with 2011, where we had a normal winter.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And you see then in Cement, our Cement sales are up 32%. That shows that the underlying market trend in the  U.S. is pretty strong.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We see significant upside potential in North America. Chart 13 shows you the key figures. Housing starts are up.  Cement consumption is up.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Energy costs, chart 15 shows you the first quarter. We are minus 3.6% in the Cement division. Our forecast sticks  at around 0%. For the full year, that would mean we would see in our energy price inflation of 1% to 2% in the  coming nine months.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We are relatively confident that we can keep the whole energy piece more or less flat. We see some energy price  increase, especially in North America, in electricity. That has to do that the gas price in U.S. went up again. And  then, we have a special situation in California. California introduced the CO2 trading scheme as in Europe. And  now, the power utility companies have to buy CO2 rights and that's pushing up the electricity price quite a bit.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: What's the reason? Germany is down by about €15 million, only due to weather. Then, here, we are strong  whereas others are not present or are relatively weak. Northern Europe, we are down compared to last year, €16  million. That's Norway, Sweden, Denmark, where we are the only player more or less. That's only due to weather.  In Bene, Belgium and Netherlands is down by €7 million; also volume-related.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In China, volumes are down by about 9%, especially due to winter and a long Chinese New Year, but also market  weakness [ph] in the south (19:14). Result is improved due to a significant drop in coal prices.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Okay. Very shortly, outlook. Outlook unchanged. Basic pillars, our strong recovery in the U.S.; growth in Asia and  Africa; Europe challenging, except for Germany, Scandinavia and also Russia; we see positive pricing climates  throughout the globe in Cement, strongly pushed by our project PERFORM and in CLIMB Commercial focusing  on North America and on UK at the moment; energy cost flat, that's the target.

file: HEI - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 7May2014 1100 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart seven gives you a little bit more transparency on the weather impact. Y ou see that in North America, our  business was significantly impacted in the northeast region. The ones of you who cover us regula rly or follow us  regularly know that the region north in our North American business has about 40% to 45% of our volumes in  Cement but also in Aggregates. And obviously this region was very much impacted by negative weather and also  negative inventory impact.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Western Europe and Eastern Europe showed just the opposite. We had a very mild winter and that translated then  in a very good volume development. However, what we have seen in North America in the markets which are not  that weather-exposed like in the region west in California or also in Texas. As soon as weather was drying up,  demand picked immediately up and we are very confident for the development in North America for the coming  months.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Good news also from the energy side. What you see on chart nine is the pure price inflation impac t from the  Cement division. And here you see negative price inflation was again 1.5%. That's mainly driven by a low coal  price. Coal price is soft throughout the world, especially in Europe but also in Asia. Coal is around $7 5, $7 6.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And on the electricity side, we saw very low electricity prices, especially in Europe due to the very mild winter. On  the opposite, we saw a lot of price peaks in electricity in U.S., mainly region East Coast, New Y ork, Pennsylvania,  but also California, where they had a harsh winter and that's why electricity prices went up significantly.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 11 gives you a little bit idea on our pricing initiatives in Europe. In UK, for example, we think we will get a  price increase in Cement of about [ph] £0.50 (07:12). That sounds low. However, we think that in Concrete we  will  see a price increase between £2 and £3 and you have to see it from an integrated margin that shows that the  market is also clearly coming back.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We expect significant cost savings by this new organizational model that's also supported by the first results we  see coming through in UK. In UK, we introduced this system already last year and at the moment, we think that  we can reduce the logistic cost in the Ready -Mix division by about £1.50 and we sold about 4 million concrete  [indiscernible] (11:00) in UK. That gives you, as I mentioned, the cost savings only in Ready -Mix of our LEO  approach.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Australia was also relatively strong. We see a strong rebound in the residential sector, especially in Sydney, which  is our biggest market. But also in Brisbane and Perth, whereas the business in the coal mines in northern  Queensland is clearly drying up, whereas our mining business north of Perth, which is concentrating more on the  iron ore field is still going well. We got a big job in Port Hedland for the expansion of the iron ore mine. And so  here, the order book is improving and has a relatively good shape.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Group services, good result development and what you see is demand for cement and clinker is clearly going up.  Y ou see our revenues are up about 44%. That shows you that the demand for our product is very strong and  another key issue [ph] that you've known (18:14) from us is always what's the export price for clinker. In Shanghai  FOB price for clinker is now $39 per tonne. Last year, as we talked, it was about $35 so it shows you the clear  trend upwards. That shows you that the big export markets in Asia have a strong domestic demand and that's why  the export price is going up.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Price increases in all core markets supported by [ph] pro forma client (33:54). Energy costs are flat; however, we  will see some headwind in some markets like in Indonesia where PLN has announced a price increase of about  16% every two months. And we see also electricity price increases quite significantly in Ghana and Tanzania of  around 30% to 40%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you look to Asia, [ph] chart on (35:47 ) Indonesia, you see that the key project is now the brown fielding in  Citeureup is 4.4 million tonnes. And we think we will get this going by mid or end next year. We expect the  market, as I said, to pick up in the second half. Kazakhstan Shetpe is running and on chart 36, you see our  expansion program for Africa, in total about 5 million tonnes of cement this year. If you look on the right column,  you see the investment cost per tonne of cement. I think these are pretty competitive figures. And that should  contribute to our profitability next year.

file: HEI - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 7May2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We look to chart five. I think I said already everything that looks, in my opinion, pretty solid. Chart six makes it  quite transparent, nothing to add. If you look to volume, you see North America had a relatively good start, even  with a harsh winter in the region. Also Connecticut, New York, New York State, they had a very long winter. We  still have snow in May in Chicago.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: As I told you already in March, energy is our friend at the moment. In the Cement division, we are down year-on- year 4.1%. Electricity is up. That has to do with the price increase due to the public tariff in Indonesia which is up  about 30% compared to last year. All other countries are rather down. And in aggregates, we are down in total  energy cost on running our pits about 18.8%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Okay. Now, North America, chart 14. I think the first quarter is okay. Operating income clearly improved 43.3%.  We had a very good run in the Region North and in California. South was weak in volume. Result was okay,  because we focused very much on price increases, so and we could sell the lower volume in oil well cement in  Texas, we could sell in the gray area. But the weather was difficult in the South, in Texas especially and also, April  volumes were not great, because the weather was, again, difficult.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Canada had overall, let's say, a solid start. We have two different developments. In the Prairie provinces, Alberta,  Saskatchewan, and the other one, Manitoba, we are down on oil well cement. For the full year, we would expect  about 150,000 tons. However, we're going to sell this more in the south, in the state of Washington, and so on.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: April was, for us, in Canada now, surprisingly strong on volume in cement. It's up about 9%. So at the moment, we  do not see a slowdown of the residential sector in Calgary, Edmonton yet. That was a little bit of concern, but due  to the sluggish oil price and the CapEx reduction of the big oil sand companies, you would also see a slowdown in  the residential or commercial sector. That's, at the moment, as we speak, not visible. Our price increase in Canada  implemented okay.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Western and Northern Europe, if you look to the results, operating income improved by about $12 million 30.6%.  The improvement comes very strongly from UK, which had a very good result. Germany is weather-related, down  compared to last year. The same applies to Benelux. And also, to Norway, especially the comparison with last  year's weather makes it difficult really to compare the figures.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Poland, volumes still down in the first quarter also in April, due to weather. But the outlook for the Polish market  overall is good. We see lots of infrastructure projects, EU funded, coming in Poland, so we are confident on the  recovery of the Polish market.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Africa-Mediterranean also very good result up 50%, Africa was very strong. Our new plant in Togo had a good  start. Tanzania was okay. Turkey, weather related volume decline. Prices are, clearly, above last year. Spain  recovering on a low level. Group Services up, especially international volumes increased. And overall, outlook is  that the clinker price, worldwide, is a little bit going down, due to increased exports from China and lower freight  rates.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: Then discontinued operations, minus €13 million, that's our asbestos and environmental liabilities, mainly in U.S.  Last year, we had still a positive effect in from our Hanson Building Products business.

file: HEI - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 4May2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Now, key financial, on Slide 4, I think underlines what I just said. Y ou see especially that the margin in cement  and aggregates went all up, driven by – mainly by lower energy costs, partially price increases or flat pricing in  Europe. And on the Chart 5, you see the EBITDA bridge. So operationally, like for like, we are up 13%. A good  organic growth in our core business line, cement and aggregates.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: A challenge remains the increased competition, but we see, on the other side, a significant reduction in variable  cost. Our new plant, P14, has not produced in the first quarter. We are producing clinker now. We started the  production end of April and we think we will have a reliable production probably June/July, which then leads to a  reduction in variable cost of about $10 per tonne.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Energy costs are down. I think the Chart 11 are quite self-explanatory. That obviously helped us quite a bit. We  expect coke – pet coke to stay low. Also, electricity in U.S. looks very favorable, also in Germany and Scandinavia,  even electricity is down in Indonesia. Oil price is fluctuating, as you know. Italcementi transaction, what's new? I  think one key issue is we have entered into an agreement with the European Commission last Friday, so we have  finally filed.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Weather was our friend, obviously, so result is significantly up in cement and also in aggregates by about €24  million. And we had an increase also in the region south, speaking mainly about North Carolina, South Carolina,  Florida, Georgia, Texas, where also the weather was okay. We had very strong shipments, especially in South  Carolina, but also in Texas, except Houston. Also there, operating profit is up by about €23 million.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Canada is, overall, flat. Volumes in Canada were down by about 8%, That's about 25,000 or 30,000 tonnes, but  that's mainly oil-well cement because last year in Q1 we were still selling quite a bit of oil-well cement in  Edmonton that dropped. On the other side, volumes in DC and Washington are up 10%, so the result jus t is offset,  whereas in the region west, that's California, Arizona, the result is down by about €6 million, mainly due to  weather.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: El Nino had a clear negative impact. We had very bad weather, especially in February, partially in March. So  volumes are down by about 5% to 6%. Then we had also a long winter repair in our [indiscernible] (12:25) plant,  which brought inventories down and which had a negative inventory impact. You see that the margins in cement  and aggregates developed quite favorably. I think it's worthwhile to note that, in the cement business, in our result  is included a negative impact on inventory on ROI level of about $18 million because due to strong sales we had to  reduce inventory quite significantly.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: So as in real life, if figures are good, in reality they are even better. So U.S., we had really a good run. If you look to  Western and Southern Europe on Chart 15, you see the result is up €7  on operating – €7  million operating  EBITDA, OI €13 million. Here we had a very good run in Germany, where volumes are up by about 6%, obviously  driven by weather, but very strong residential Building permits in Germany are up 30%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: So result in Germany was clearly up by €8 million. In Benelux, we see that Netherlands, the market is back by  about close to 18%. So the residential sector is back. We have been waiting pretty long for the recovery in Holland.  We see that now happening. Belgium is more or less flat. Result is also clearly up. UK, result is slightly down,  mainly due to two impacts. On the one side, we had a problem in our Ketton plant, which is the closest cement  plant to London, where the stack was blown away in a storm.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Romania, market, step by step, improves. Margin improvement also due to lower pet coke costs and electricity  cost due to an investment in a waste heat power generation in our main plant in Fieni close to Bucharest. In  Russia, result is more or less flattish. Market remains challenging. We have done pretty well. We are more or less  sold out. Our volumes are only down minus 3%. The total market in Russia is down by about minus 12%, minus  13%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Ukraine, business climate has improved. Volumes up 49%, pricing up, result improved. And in Kazakhstan,  market remains difficult. Volumes down 18%, pricing clearly up. Result has, overall, improved. Core message is  that our, let's say, risky markets, like Russia, Ukraine and Kazakhstan, have done better in first qua rter and our  outlook is more confident for these markets than maybe as we were in December or January.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Costs are clearly down. Variable costs down double digit, whether it's distribution cost, whether it's coal, whether  it's electricity. And also in fixed cost we continue our efficiency programs and we plan to reduce by about at least  250 people during the current year. Another country which was problematic was obviously China. In China the  market is clearly in a downturn. Volumes are down between 14% and 15%.

file: HEI - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 10May2017 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Okay, let's go through the figures. You have received our presentation. And for the industry insight, as you know,  Q1 is always a little bit difficult to read in our history, the industry is weather impacted and especially in the  Northern Hemisphere, obviously the winter, and the timing of the winter plays a significant role.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And then we talk about weather. Weather, you see it in our regional results, played mainly in three areas. First of  all, West Coast U.S. was extremely wet, [indiscernible] (03:13) the volumes were clearly, heavily impacted, and  were down in the first quarter in a double-digit way on the West Coast U.S. Australia had Storm Debbie, which  has impacted our volumes in March, quite significantly.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And the next chart talks about the energy. And you see that in the first quarter, we had a price inflation of about  3.5%. You know that our forecast for the full year was about 10%, and the people who follow the company very  closely know the figures, our energy costs in Heidelberg are around €2 billion all-in. And if you want to see last  year, we had energy costs of only about €1.840 billion or €1.850, because energy dropped by about 10%. In  2015, we had energy cost of about $2.040 billion or $200 million more, and our internal budget for 2017 was  about $2.050 billion. So again, on 2015 level, and our management target is now to get that figure below €2  billion, meaning we are reducing a little bit our negative energy outlook, yeah. And so the trend in energy is at the  moment our friend, but that can change pretty fast.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And we just wanted to show you a little bit also on operational data what we have done. Clinker production is up  34%. The daily production, the throughput per tonne is up 27%. And the MTBF, that's the running time without  [ph] stop (13:52) more than doubled. That shows you what good management in a relatively short period of time  can achieve. And that you see that in the results that the results are up by about $33 million. And that shows you  a little bit, that's our power. We are delivering on our promise that we are the ones in the industry at the best  position to get more value out of the undermanaged Italcementi assets.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And if I look to other areas, we see a similar trend, not as sharp as in U.S., but we see clearly that the KPIs of our  kilns are step by step improving. The MTBF in France is up. The heat consumption is down. Maintenance and  repair costs [ph] are down €0.50 (14:34) per tonne. We have reduced in Italy compared to 2015 already about  100 people in the plant, et cetera. So we are moving in that direction.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: If you look to the group areas, North America, I think, the figures are pretty good. If you look also to comparables  in the North American business is very good comparable with our peers. Then you will see that we have I think  again performed pretty well. We see overall, we had a relatively strong demand, except of the West Coast. And  then what we see in north and south, the business was good. Good for us is that also the oil and gas industry in  U.S. and Texas, Houston and also in Alberta is coming back. The number of rigs has more than doubled. And if  you look to our joint venture, Texas Lehigh, which is not included in the volume figures, their volumes are up 12%  versus last year. Pricing is also up, so that shows also in Texas, in South Texas, things are improving.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: The same is in a way true for Canada. In Canada, we had a good run in the region Alberta, Edmonton, Calgary. I  think we have seen the worst. We have a big project, the project [indiscernible] (16:01) project in Northern  Alberta, yeah, which has a huge volume, which kicked in, yeah. And on the West Coast, Vancouver volumes were  still a little bit negatively impacted by bad weather, whereas Washington, Seattle was very strong. So overall, I  think U.S. is good, pricing is good, volumes are good, so outlook is okay.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And the second point is, in France, on a high level, the result is negatively influenced by about €5.2 million by  purchase price allocation, meaning increased depreciation on the French cement assets. Overall, the other main  reason was UK was relatively weak. We had a heavier winter repair. We did it earlier than last year. And  secondly, the bitumen price and asphalt has obviously hit our margins by I think it was about €5 million, yeah.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: In Poland, also volumes were up. We have done our price increase in April, which seems to stick. Czech Republic  flat, and in Romania due to weather, especially also to Bulgaria, and Russia and Ukraine volumes were  significantly down because the weather was relatively harsh. Good to know that we had very strong price  increases in Russia and in Ukraine in the cement sector, so target is to get in this area, prices as fast as possible  to a level of $60 per tonne and we are working in that way. So, in Russia price is up 13%, Ukraine 35%,  Kazakhstan also 6%. So, overall Northern and Eastern Europe, I think good outlook.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: If you look at the balance sheet, the purchase price allocation appears to be stable. It's almost finalized. We will  finish it calling to IFRS by end of June. Currently, we do not expect any major change. If it comes to the big  blocks, meaning goodwill, mineral reserves and fixed assets, this seems to be pretty stable and, as I said, we will  finalize this by end of June.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And I think the key issue for us is, obviously, if you look to the upside, it's North America, it's Northern Europe,  Germany, France doing maybe better now after the election and the Netherlands and the recovery in Eastern  Europe, and on the downside it's the question what's happening or what's the risk, what's happening on  Indonesia. We are more confident on Africa. In Ghana, we have done a price increase in April of about $10 and  the market has followed. Also, in Turkey we are increasing pricing. So, we are a little bit more confident on that  and then maybe a better-than-expected energy development than when we did the budget.

file: HEI - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 9May2018 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: I will lead you through the operational results. Dr. Näger will comment on financial results. And then I will come  back at the end on the outlook. Okay. As you know, I think we are the last in our industry who is publishing. Our  key cement competitors have already published, and also Martin was out, I think, yesterday or today. You have  seen that weather had a significant impact on our numbers mainly in North America due to our footprint in the  region north and also in Europe where we had especially harsh and long-freezing periods in the month of March,  which covers Germany, UK, but also France. And in France, we had the flooding in February in Paris.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
