texts.text: Energy cost had a significant impact on our result in Q1 mainly due to the comparison base from last year where  we still had a lot of cheap coal and pet coke on stock, and secondly, we were negatively impacted mainly in Asia  due to the fact that the Chinese – as you all know Chinese were importing a lot, and pricing went up especially for  the Newcastle Coal significantly above $100, which had a negative impact mainly on the margins in Indonesia but  also in Thailand.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If we look by cost from a functional point of view, cement/energy is up by about €40 million, and maintenance  repair, we had a negative impact due to a timing issue. We had two big plants, which were in winter repair this  year in March, and last year, they were in April. It's our plant permanently in the Silicon Valley, which had a  negative impact of about €16 million, and it's our largest plant in Europe, Slite in Sweden on Gotland Island, which  is about €12 million, and that together has a negative impact of €26 million.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If we look to the results per area, I will start with North America. That's the biggest impact on our negative  deviation compared to last year. You see it did about €62 million. I explained about €50 million. Another €6 million  come from Canada. What we see is that we had a negative inventory impact also mainly due to the region north  because in the region north, especially the whole area around New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Maryland,  and then up to Ohio and up to Chicago had a lot of snow. We still have drizzles now even in April. So, it was a  really harsh winter, and that is about 40% of our cement volume. So, we are really at a footprint disadvantage.  That's why our cement volume is minus 4.6%. If you compare them, for example, with our Mexican comparables  where we are up 5%, then that is absolutely consistent because they have no footprint in the north. They are  much more in the south, and that's what you see.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And also Texas was weak because Texas was very wet in February, and you saw that also in the numbers, which  were published by Martin, I think, yesterday where they were down in cement by more than 80% mainly due to  bad weather in Texas, and you see we are a little bit in the middle of the road because – which is a clear footprint  impact.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Canada, the Prairies were down due to weather, whereas the Pacific Northwest, Vancouver, Seattle, Portland,  were clearly up, and we expect a relatively good run in Canada and we have price increases except for the  Prairies of about $5 to $6 a tonne.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you go to Western and Southern Europe, that was the other market there where we lost about €53 million  compared to last year. Major impact comes from UK with close to €18.5 million; then Bene was also down by  about €9 million; Germany by about €7 million or €8 million; Italy and Spain were up. And especially UK, we had a  clear weather impact and also an inventory impact. And last year in the UK, we had property profits in of about €7  million, which we are missing this year, and we have a property gain in the UK in the month of April that was a  timing difference. So that's about Europe.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Asia-Pacific, we are down €26 million. That's mainly explained by Indonesia. I told you €40 million, the €40 million  investment coming from volume and pricing. Volumes are strong. In the first quarter, we were up by about 8.5%.  Also, April is again up 6%, so we are growing. The market is stable. So in West Java, especially in the Jakarta  area, private projects are coming back to the market. This is okay. Pricing has stabilized. In April, it's even up a  little bit by 1%. The main impact comes from the high coal price from the Newcastle Coal, which is in the first  quarter, compared to last year, up by about 23% or 25%. I guess, we have a chart maybe laid off or not. That's  the main impact. India was also down for us by about €8 million mainly due to market weakness, especially in the  region south. China clearly up and also Australia clearly up.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On trading, what you see, trading result is up. We have high volumes in the first quarter by about 21% up. And  what you see is that the clinker price in Asia FOB is up by about $5. We see the same in the Mediterranean. The  Turkish exporters managed to get about $4 to $5 per clinker more than last year. The pricing is now about $35.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: As outlined by Dr. Scheifele, this was, first of all, due to the success in our portfolio optimization where we had a  capital gain in the range of €100 million from the sale of the sand-lime bricks in Germany and our U.S. white  cement business. And we have reshifted this money spend into the acquisition of Cementir, of Fraser in Australia  and the grinding unit in Canada. So, we have really reused our monies here.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: Working capital, as I said, is slightly higher due to the weather conditions in the first quarter, and we expect this to  normalize over the remainder of the year. Net debt stands at €9.9 billion, and we stick to our target to bring that  down over the remainder of the year to a value of €8.2 billion to €8.3 billion.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Yeah, I come back to the outlook. We keep our guidance for the year mid to high single-digit organic EBITDA  growth. That's obviously more ambitious now after a relatively difficult start. We see strong order backlog in U.S.,  especially in coal markets for us like Texas, California, Canada, and the West Coast, Seattle, Vancouver, and in  Europe. We expect a price recovery and price increase in Indonesia after the Ramadan period and also in Africa,  and we will push very strongly for pricing in all other markets.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We have seen from our earnings that pricing environment at the moment is favorable mainly due to new reasons.  Import costs from clinker are up and also due to the rising oil and fuel costs, obviously, imports are less  competitive than last year. Question mark is the energy cost inflation. We see in the South African coal and in the  Newcastle Coal a clear easing. Pet coke remains price-wise challenging, and we have to wait a bit and see a little  bit what the oil price is now doing after the Iran decision of the U.S. government of yesterday evening.

file: HEI - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 9May2019 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 7 gives you a little bit idea about the energy cost development. The message is coal is clearly down. It's  about 20% down versus last year. That trend will continue, we believe an increase now in the Q2 and Q3.  Petcoke is still flat and up. Petcoke will come down, in our opinion, in the coming months. And the only area  where we're up is power that's mainly in Europe, but we are now very much hedged in Europe and we expect  power prices in Q2 to come down versus last year, because in last year, we had in Europe some extraordinary  price peaks. Core message here, energy should be our friend in Q2, Q3 and should support further margin  expansion.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And in the U.S. numbers, we'll come to that in a minute in more details. It has also showed that due to a very  good weather situation in the second half of March, we had a relatively strong draw on our inventories, which led  to a negative result effect on RCO level of about €10 million. So, let's say, the operational result is even better as  shown.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Western and Southern Europe, I think it is – volumes were good. Weather was normal and we had a significant  push from pricing. We had strong pricing all over the area, as in Italy prices are up now versus last year about €7.  The actual cement price in Italy domestic is above €70, it's about €70.5 and up. That's very significant. France is  even up close to €3, that's the first time since a long time that in France the cement prices are moving up again.  Also ready-mix is up in France. Germany is also up by about €3. Belgium, Holland is up by €3.50, that looks pretty  good.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: North and Eastern Europe, also here good result development, especially Eastern Europe is really coming back.  We have significant volume increases in Hungary, Czech Republic, on Romania, partially weather, partially also  due to production shortages in the market where we had to step in.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you go to chart 12 and you look to North America linked to RCO, then you see like-for-like, it's up 7.3% if you  take the consolidation of white cement [indiscernible] (15:52) and also dollar and forex. But the increase in RCO is  rather low. But as I told you, we have about close to €11 million or €10 million we have on inventory impact  because we had a significant draw on our inventories.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If we look to the sub-regions in U.S., region North is very strong where the RCO is significantly up versus last  year, about €20 million, €21 million. Whereas the region West had a difficult first quarter for us, volumes were  down double digit due to very wet weather. And here, the result is down versus last year by about €10 million or  €11 million. South was okay. Canada was a little bit weaker, but only due to weather.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you look to Group Services, maybe three messages. First of all, clinker [indiscernible] (19:33) Shanghai is  moving upwards because China has stopped exporting. China is importing clinker, and that has limited the  surplus in Asia. And then, we have a totally different development in the Mediterranean. In the Mediterranean,  there is more clinker available due to the market collapse in Turkey where the market is down in the first three or  four months by about 40% and also Algeria became a cement exporter, so we talk now about clinker prices below  $30 per tonne.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And on the energy side, coal is down 20%, 25% especially in Newcastle, but also South African coal for Europe,  petcoke will follow in the coming months.

file: HEI - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 30July2010 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The management stays focused on the four targets, which we published at the beginning of the  year focused on cost and operational excellence. We have started a new initiative for cost reduction  in energy in the cement division. I will come to that late on. We stay focused on cash and  deleveraging. We have further improved the liquidity and maturity profile of the company. We have  cash generating initiatives in the Group running. We watch also on growth, especially cement in  emerging markets, and we have further improved transparency and investor relations.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Slide four gives an overview about sales volumes, I think that’s self speaking. You see in the Q2  second quarter, cement is up about 1.2%, a little bit held back by a relatively weak month of June  mainly in Indonesia, where we had heavy rain and we had also a problem with the gearbox in our  large cement plant in Guangzhou. Aggregates up 6.7%, that’s driven by infrastructure mainly in  North America, Canada and also U.K. Ready-mix also up 3.8%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Slide five gives you an interesting development of the monthly volumes. Volume development, I  think, it shows a good trend in North America. Last time at the Q1 presentation I told you that, April  was rather good in volumes, May weakened a little bit but, June again came out pretty strong. And  in Western Europe, we see also that the trend continues to go to break-even with last year’s  volumes, in Eastern Europe, trend also improving. June still negative mainly by a flooding in Poland  and Romania, both countries are about 40 to 45% of our sales in Eastern Europe and we had a  negative weather impact in these two countries. Africa okay, Asia-Pacific okay, June I already  mentioned the rain in Indonesia that also had a technical issue in China.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We have launched a new operational excellence initiative in the Cement division, the target is to  reduce on a plant-by-plant basis, the fuel bill by about 3% in each plant and the electricity bill by  about 5%. We’re at the moment doing an audit on plant-by-plant basis in order to check what’s the  status and what kind of technical possibilities do we see in order to reduce the fuel bill and the  electricity bill. The pilot plants are defined the full effect on the P&L, which will only come through  step-by-step in 2011 and 2012, ranges between 30 to €40 million, that’s our target.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: On the growth side, our capacity expansion program for cement, which runs until 2012 will bring us  20 million tons additional capacity. The focus is clearly now on India and Indonesia and also on  Bangladesh. By 2012, we’ll have moved about 62% of our cement capacity to emerging markets,  mid-term targets for the company is to reach 70%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 3 Now – I come now to Western and Northern Europe. We have aggregate shipments in Q2 improve  year-on-year in all regions. In Northern Europe, we had overall a positive trend, mainly in May and  June at good prices, also volumes in July look promising. In U.K., we had a clear pick-up in  volumes for ready-mix and aggregates. We have further improved our operating margin in cement  in the U.K. We have implemented a price increase in cement in May, also for ready-mix in June. So  the market climate in U.K. is better than what we expected at the beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Slide 15 shows the exposure in Europe. We are relatively strong in European markets, which are  on the track to recovery, that’s U.K. and Sweden, whereas we are practically not present in the so  called hotspot countries like Spain, Ireland and Portugal. If I look to Eastern Europe-Central Asia,  as I told you, Poland and Romania – the rain and flooding impacted our shipments. If you look to  the Q2 result, operating income is down by about 24% and our turnover was still down.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Okay Eastern Europe, flooding in Poland, Romania and I showed you slide – I showed on slide 17.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In the market, we had some price erosion mainly in Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Texas, California  and Arizona, we had started now with selective price increases, which we have partially already  executed in Texas. In aggregates, mainly in Houston, Dallas and in cement, in the oil well cement,  it’s [inaudible], and we have in our price announcement, a price increase announcement also  California and Arizona for the second half. Our win project is on track as I mentioned to you earlier.  If you look to our margin in the second quarter, you’ll see cement up to at least 27.2 and also  aggregates up to 28.8% and I think, that shows the underlying health of this business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Israel, market is growing five to 6%, solid volume growth at attractive markets. Spain, volumes and  price is down. We operate in Barcelona and in Madrid and that shows the [inaudible] cement  EBITDA in the second quarter, about 20.4% that has mainly to do with Turkey where we had higher  energy cost due to the fact that the petcoke price went up significantly, and we are burning mostly  petcoke in Turkey are now also about to switch our kilns to coal, which is becoming cheaper again  compared to petcoke.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Group services, our shipments worldwide went up, yeah, that’s what you see. In the turnover result  is down, because last year we had a one-time gain from a contract with a Nigerian importer.  Overall, we see a balanced demand and supply situation for clinker and cement due to two effects,  the main export countries Turkey and China, which are exporting about 20 in Turkey and China 25  million tons have strong local markets and Africa, which is in North Africa, but also in Southern  Africa, the biggest importer, markets are also strong. We do not expect a significant move on the  coal and oil price for the second half, so no risk from that side.

file: HEI - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 29July2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We are well on our way with our efficiency program FOX 2013. I will come to that later. We have already achieved  savings of about €134 million against the target of about €200 million, especially in the client project on the  productivity optimization in the aggregates division runs well. We have continued our dual strategy as in the last  two years. On the one side, manage costs aggressively and on the other side, expand the business in emerging  markets. We have opened our new cement plant in Moscow in Tula with 2 million tons. We started a new kiln in  Gorazdze, which gives us an additional clinker capacity of about 900,000 tons and our expansion projects in Asia  and Africa are on track.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: I just skipped chart 4, that shows you just the volume development. I already explained that in detail. If we look  through the key financial figures, I think you'll see, if you look to the second quarter, that the operating income is  down about 10%, that's about €51 million compared to last year. And the question is what the reason. First issue,  is the cement division which is really down and in the cement division we see that the increase in fuel costs we  were not able to fully compensate by price increases. So, we have a contribution margin issue there. And the  second point, if you look to regions, it's mainly two.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: That's the one part, and the second part relates to North America, and in North America is on the one side Canada  not due to a market weakness but we had a very long and harsh winter in the prairie provinces, we had snow until  middle of May. So, we had a very slow and late start. We expect to recover that during the summer and in fall.  Order book is in good shape. Pricing is solid. The other part in U.S. is the region north, that the largest U.S. region  of Heidelberg.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We do about 60% of our cement volumes and 50% of aggregates in that region. That region goes from Washington  up New York, Boston, Chicago, Midwest up to Minnesota. And we have especially along the East Coast a very long  wet season, we practically had no April. We had four weeks of rain in April and that has obviously slowed down  sales. Significantly, we saw an uptick in this region, an uptick in sales and in volumes in June and July. And okay,  if you look through the full half-year, you see the operating income is up 6%, margin is down 0.7%. Dr. Naeger will  go through cash flow and so on.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If I go on, on slide 6, we show you a little bit the resilience of the aggregates division which is the second pillar of  the company. It shows very clearly that pricing in aggregates is more resilient than in cement. It is also less  exposed to energy increase and in our core markets in U.S., U.K. and Australia, we have in the past always priced

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Slide 7 covers the energy issue and I think that's interesting to see, and from a management point of view, from a  company point of view, you have to watch a little bit what happened let's say beginning end of 2010, about  November, December, our board approved the budget beginning middle of December based on discussion with  the operational management end of November. And you see here very clearly that, for example, the coal price at  that time was about $95, $96, went up to $130, back to $120.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: You see electricity price was well below our current level due also to the Japan crisis and you see also of the diesel  on the fuel price. You saw December we did a calculation of oil price of about $100 per barrel and oil price peaked  in the latter half of April at a level of clearly north of $130 and is now coming down again. And, obviously, the oil  price is a heavy burden for our aggregates division because we run our trucks and big lorries, obviously, with  diesel and that has raised the bill for that significantly.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Okay. Then on the growth, you see chart 8. You see a little bit what we are doing throughout the world. You see we  have done Poland and Russia. You see the focus of the company is clearly on Brownfielding and Greenfielding. I  think Heidelberg does this at very attractive investment costs. Here, our costs to turn of capacity installed, I think,  is on a very good level and all these projects exceed our group ROCE target of above 20%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Slide 9 deals with our most recent completed projects in Russia and Poland. Gorazdze, we put up the second line,  the investment was about €75 per ton of clinker and in Russia, in Moscow, we have a 2 million tons cement plant  and the total investment is about €300 million, which leads to about €150 per ton. I think that's a very  competitive investment. If we look to FOX on slide 10, the left part shows you the overall status, the target for this  year is about €200 million, the run rate is now €134, working capital is well underway. We made progress in  CLIMB and OpEx and also purchasing, so we are well on track with that efficiency initiative.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The right part of that chart deals with our CLIMB project. Just as a reminder, in CLIMB, we target to reduce  production costs in our aggregates division by $0.50 per ton. Last year, we sold about 240 million tons. We think  we have a saving potential of about 120 million tons. Now, what the chart shows you is the out of the toolbox of  our CLIMB project, we have covered in U.K. four sites which do about 31% of our volume in the U.K. The U.K. is  the second largest aggregates country for Heidelberg, so it's quite representative. And you see that the original  saving target was ₤1.5 million on annualized basis, we just doubled now the target for ₤3.1 million, so the results  are very promising, we have similar results also in North America and in Australia.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Okay. Then on – you see construct slide 14, I just keep that you know that it shows a little bit different  development in Europe. The northern part of Europe develops pretty well, whereas the south over to mid- countries are still in trouble and continue to be questionable. Now, North America, slide 15, if we go to North  America, what I said, we had a very long wet season in U.S., and we had a good however, whereas in Texas and  California which are our two biggest markets in U.S.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We see a clear volume recovery in California, driven by the San Francisco Bay Area. Los Angeles is still lagging a  little bit behind. But in the Bay Area, also residential comes back. We have a very strong market position in San  Francisco. In Texas, it's mainly the oil-and-gas industry which is back. The oil well cement is up. The demand is  more than 10%. Our joint venture Texas Lehigh is one of the prime suppliers of oil well cement in Texas, and that  runs relatively well. We have announced new price increases in North America for July and August, especially also  in California and Northern California, of about $5 but we have also pricing initiatives in Texas.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Canada, the key issue is what I mentioned in the beginning, we had a very long and harsh winter. In the prairie  provinces, BC is coming step by step out of the prices. Volumes are recovering and we announced fuel charge of  about CAD$5 by 1st of July in the three provinces. Building products, I think we have managed a good turnaround  that business was in the big trouble, we changed the management one year ago. We restructured the company the  company, we cut cost. We streamlined operations, and we see that the result and also the margin of that business  gained back. However, the market continues to be weak in the pipe business, except for pressure price which is the  fresh water pipes, where we have a very good market development.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: However, the margin is under pressure because we have very strong volumes between 16%-17%. In Indonesia, the  market is very strong. Pricing is stable but the coal cost went up by about 25% to 30% because the two main  Indonesian coal suppliers increased prices to international coal prices. And we have announced now a price  increase 4th July in Indonesia. China, I mentioned North is in a consolidation phase. In the South weren't sure,  volumes are okay; pricing is okay; profits are up.  India had weak first six months. The cement market grew only 1%, it was even negative with minus 1% in the  second quarter. There are the questions what's the reason for that. We see two main reasons. First of all,  government projects were very slow, practically no new infrastructure projects. And on the second – and the  second part is, India experienced a very high inflation rate in 2011, starting in the later part of 2010. The Federal  Reserve has reacted in India, and I think they have pushed interest rate three or four times. And inflation is eating  up the money at the Indian level, which is available for building materials because they have to spend more money  for food. And that's what we saw that also private consumption in rural India was very weak and that has negative  impacted our volumes and sales.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Australia, overall, okay development taking account that they had this big flooding in Brisbane in the springtime.  We have done – we have executed successfully significant price increase in aggregates and ready mix which will  come through during the year. We are working off the cheaper order book at the moment. Result level is okay. So  we expect solid second half.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Group services, that's mainly our trading business in cement and clinker and in fuel, and what we see in the  cement and clinker trade is that we see a significant drop in international trading activity. And what's the reason  for that, the big exporter countries like China, Turkey, India, Indonesia are reducing their export significantly due  to strong domestic markets.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And in China, I think – we believe that the government has a clear policy not to export cement and clinker. They  do not want to waste resources and we expect Chinese export to come down to 4 million tonnes. Two years ago  they were up at about 30 million tonnes and that obviously has a good impact on the clinker price in Asia. Freight  rates are at record low level, they are again on the pre-crisis level and coal price as we expect that we have seen the  peak and we see a certain downward trend on coal pricing. Okay, that's it from my side from the markets and I  hand over to the [indiscernible] (20:48) who will report on the financials.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: India, as I said, is growing, and the first half it went slower but we expect that growth to come back after the  monsoon season. Margins are lower because especially coal prices in India went up. India coal – Coal India  increased the coal price by about 50% beginning of the year, just to give you an idea on the dimension of pressure  we faced on the energy side.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Africa, no news; I think the markets are growing. We see growth of about 15% in our coal markets like Ghana or  Tanzania. Growth especially in Ghana has been around 18% to 20% due to the oil and gas exploitation, so Africa  we see okay. Now, the key issue is North America. I'll start with the easy part, that's Canada. Canada, that's again a  resources-driven economy, in the prairie provinces, that continuously all the book is in very good shape.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The oil sand industry which is a big customer for us, they have just started an enhanced projects in the Fort  McMurray, Fort MacKay area of about $128 billion. The Chinese oil company are buying in in these projects. So,  as long as the oil price stays at the level of 100, I think there is no issue. The minimum price they need is about  $60 to $65 per barrels. So we are far more ahead of that. I think that will continue. Pricing is robust and we see a  step by step recovery in British Columbia.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On U.S., first answer very clear. Our scenario is not a default scenario for North America, for U.S. yeah we think  that the politicians will agree. Congress goes for vacation, I think, on the 7th of August. Obama has his birthday on  the 4th or 5th of August. Normally he goes to Hawaii. So, I think he will try to – he will try to get it settled before  that. So, it's a not a default scenario. Obviously, so we expect the recovery to continue.  Personally, I expect in the U.S., if there is no default, a stronger economic development in Q3, than in Q2.  Why,  we had a lot of factors in the second quarter which brought growth in my opinion down temporarily. We had first  of all weather, weather was bad, that's clear. We had oil price, which peaked in April with about 28% up, which  took a lot of money away from U.S. consumer which is an important factor for the industry.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We have good positions in Texas and California which are two top states. Texas is our largest state, California is  the second one; volume in these – volume gross in these markets is pretty solid. And we have launched price  increases in Texas, but also in California and partially in the south in order to offset a price erosion from last year  and to fight against increasing energy cost.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Western and Northern Europe – no trend change. I think Europe is on a good way. We would expect a solid result,  solid volumes in the second half. We see that the price, that the pressure from rising energy costs will slowdown in  the second half. We see that in Germany energy – electricity prices are coming down. We expect the coal price to  come slowly down. So pressure on margins from the input cost will slowdown.

file: HEI - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 31July2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And now you see the cement margin is trending upwards again. You see clearly the development. We're coming  from 29.5% in the year after the crisis 2010. The target for our cement margin is 30% to 32%. And the project  PERFORM obviously has the clear target to come back to this good level.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: FOX, slide nine, is well on its way. We have already achieved €138 million of our savings compared to €200  million. We clearly will exceed the plan significantly especially our two efficiency initiatives in our two core  divisions in aggregates CLIMB and OpEx in cement. And heat and energy consumption reduction are running  very well. And we'll be for the full year clearly ahead of our targets.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Slide 10 gives an insight in our logistics project LEO, which goes for saving of about €150 million. Maybe two or  three important points, total logistic group cost Heidelberg are about €2 billion euro. That means after personnel  cost which are around €2.3 billion. That's the second largest cost item in the company and that's why we want to  improve the efficiency there and see some saving potential.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And with that in place, we can increase the driver utilization rates significantly, for example, ready mix drivers,  which are typically have not much to do in the afternoon, could drive cement trucks in the afternoon and we can  Target is to do over the year 10% savings, €150 million. We think that is possible. We have done a pilot in Poland  and Hungary and we are confident to do that.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Now if you go to the next slide and we look to North America, then obviously if you look for the half year result, it's  significantly up by about €66 million. We continue to outperform the market in North America due to our  footprint. Result is obviously supported by good weather and easing of energy costs. In U.S., the volumes are still  healthy. We had a good growth in the first half year of about 20% in North America and of about 2.5% in Canada.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: India, good volumes, pricing is strong. Bangladesh, very strong volumes, good price development, up about 13%.  Australia, split economy again. We have a big development especially in Brisbane, Sydney, partially also in  Melbourne and in Perth, so in the four metropolitan areas where volumes are down 8%, 9%, especially Brisbane,  10%, 11% and we are cutting cost. And this is sharply contrasted by a booming mining business in Western  Australia, north of Perth, so Broome area going up to Darwin, and then also Northern Queensland. So  Rockhampton, going up to Cairns where the coal business is in the Australia. So here, the order book is very good.  It looks very promising and that should offset a little bit the weakness in the metropolitan areas. Overall result  okay.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: If we then look to the net income from continued operation, we had the settlement of a court case in the  environmental area, which led to a profit of roughly €17 million, which turned the normal cost item and it is  continued into a small profit. For the coming years – sorry, for the coming quarters, we will see the historical  structure to continue with the loss in the range of €5 million, €6 million, €7 million, €8 million.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: Now as you see from the lowest line, we are well prepared for the Grexit scenario and the muddling through  scenario, which cover, I mean, the biggest part of the likely scenarios, 80% of our debt is denominated in euro, but  only 10% of our EBITDA is in euro. So combined with high liquidity and a long-term secured financing, we feel  quite comfortable for this scenario.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We are also confident in Asia that, in our main markets, pricing will trend upwards. That's true for Indonesia  where the market is totally sold out. Gresik's expansion is delayed. We see good pricing also coming through in  India. And we see also good pricing in China, especially in the region north. At the same time, we see energy costs  really trending out through – trending down throughout of the world which will continue to ease the input  pressure. So prospects unchanged, volumes up, revenues up, operating income up.  Key target, to get debt down, to make a further significant step towards deleveraging of the company. Outlook,  volume pricing slight – so this too I think, that's speaking for itself. We might have further degradation later.  Energy prices, that's what I already covered. I told you that shale gas is a trend change not only in U.S. It brings  pressure on electricity and coal prices, especially also in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Due to the Chinese policy to stop from time to time steel plants and cement plants, the amount of imported coal to  China clearly goes down with a consequence that there is a lot of coal available on the ships in the Asian market  which you can buy at spot prices. And we are using this opportunistic strategy for the moment.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: At the same time, we have shifted in U.S. from coal to gas which brings us a good saving between $1 and $2 per  ton and, at the same time, electricity pricing in U.S. is going down because most of the American power plants are  run on gas. And you see what we are doing, we're trying to optimize the energy mix as far as possible.

file: HEI - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 31July2013 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Operating EBITDA margin improved by 90 points to 19.3%. Very good news is that all region and all business  lines managed to increase the operating margins, driven by three factors: good pricing, lower energy costs, and  strict cost management.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: PERFORM and CLIMB are on track. We had a strong operational leverage espe cially in North America, where  we're still ahead of 100% and we have a very professional energy management which led to a energy – to a  negative energy inflation, meaning our energy inflation in the cement sector is around 4% below last year or in  absolute terms it's about €51 million.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If we look a little bit to Q2, it's clear that Q2 was in a way weak in May, June especially in North Am erica and  Europe, which is mainly weather related. I'll come to that later. We had the flooding here in Europe in Germany  and also in Eastern Europe, which obviously held back volumes.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Operational performance, chart five, I think is self explanatory, no c omment is needed. Now, if we talk now about  slide six, the group sales volume. If we look to North America, cement, plus 4%. If you go in regions, the picture is  very different. In the second quarter, Canada was up about 5% even taking into account that we  had this big  flooding in Calgary in June, which was obviously negative. Region West, California is up 9%; South, up 12%; and  region North and that's the reason for the only 4% is down 3%, which loss is about 45% of our cement volumes  and here it was clearly weather related.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Quarterly volume and price, I think that gives you an overview, that's a rough overvie w, we can discuss that later  in the Q&A. Chart eight shows you the weather. You see the rainfall on the left side in Europe in May and June. In  May, it was mainly Germany, then in June it was more in the Eastern part. And in U.S. you see very clearly that in  June, especially region North was heavily hit by more than 10 inches of rain, which held back volumes.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Margin improvement, slide nine, in all regions, I think good picture. The same is true for all business lines. Y ou  see clearly that in cement we are trending up again. We are recovering from the low margin after the Fukushima  tsunami disaster that's exactly in line what I told you in our call in May and also at the beginning of the year that  we expect the recovery in cement driven by good pricing and better energy costs.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 15 shows you the energy side we discussed at our last call. And now for the first half year, in the cement  division we're down about 3.9% or in total terms about €51 million, €44 million in coal, about €7  million in  electricity. Our forecast is between zero and minus 1% for the full year. So we have been quite right with our  forecast already from the beginning of the year, where we said about zero to plus 1%, now we're adjusting our  forecast maybe to zero, be at below minus 1%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: One reason is that we are on energy pretty good, is the point that with our structured and balanced approach, we  decided to stay more short because we were assuming that due to the shale gas revolution, coal would stay low in  the world market. It's close to production cost for a lot of countries and to say – and we also assume that due to  the renewable policy for energies in Europe, electricity wo uld also on the spot market stay relatively cheap and  that has clearly paid off.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If we turn to the regions, then we see that we on U.S., if we look now to the figures year -to-date, I think, that's  more meaningful than only the quarter because that has lot to do with weather. If you look to the first six months,  our operating income is clearly up by about more than 50%. Pricing is okay in all business lines; we have increased  the price in cement by roughly $4. In U.S. we have further announced price increas es in Florida, Texas and  California for the next – for the second half roundabout $5 each. Our order book in our ready mix operations is  strong, clearly better than last year. Pricing in ready mix is up by about $7.50 [indiscernible] (0:14:29). That also  shows that the profitability in the ready mix business is improving, which is a good signal for further prices  increases in cement.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Demand was very strong in the West and South. If I take year-to-date, the West is up close to 12%, South is up by  about 12% and Canada is up by about 11.7 %. In Canada, it is so that our markets in Vancouver and Seattle are  coming back strongly. And the Prairie continues to grow because the oil sand and gas business is doing fine. In  Northeast, year-to-date, we are volume wise about 4.8% down. I explain that with the weather effect. We expect a  clear recovery in the region North now in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Germany, we increased prices successfully between €3 and €4 per ton. Volumes negatively impacted by  flooding. We had a good order book and good projects for the second half. At the end of the day, in Germany,  [indiscernible] (0:16:33) we missed one month of shipments, because due to a long winter and due to the flooding,  we at the moment we missed about one months of sales and we hope that we can recover that in fall and hopefully  late start of winter.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Our UK business is excellently positioned to benefit from the large infrastructure projects of the UK go vernment.  We are heavily involved in the Crossrail project in London and also on the River Thames and on this big harbor  project for the River Thames. We are also – we also got the contract for the restructuring of the Sellafield nuclear  power plant. So our order book especially in concrete is really good.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In China, in our two regions, the situation is so that surprisingly in China, at least in the cement industry, volumes  are relatively strong. We still have infrastructure projects and also residential picking up, so in the region South  Q2 volumes were up maybe in the market plus 10%, Northwest came about plus 5%. We focus really on pricing.  Prices in both markets under pressure due to overcapacity. However, variable costs were significantly down in  China due to lower coal and energy costs. And that overall result was more or less okay.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Bangladesh, politically difficult but result wise, okay. Margins were better due to higher pricing and lower slag  costs. Australia, overall we had a good run. Region North, that's Brisbane, Queensland was okay. Especially on the  country side, our mining project that's mainly coal mining run still pretty well.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Sydney is up. Housing in Sydney is up. That's a strong region for us. Weaker was the region West, where in the  mining sector, north of Perth we see a clear slow down in mining, especially on iron ore and also on these liquefied  gas plants. Overall Australia was doing okay.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Secondly, and I mean, that's a major step forward for us in reducing our risks. We had a final favorable ruling  from the California Supreme Court in our Hanson Asbestos cases, where we got final judgment that the insurances  have to reimburse us for all cost of asbestos. This allowed us now after the final ruling to capit alize the receivables  against the insurance companies and this had a €96 million profit effect, which really reflects the risk reduction,  which we have seen in this field. For the future, this, of course, will also improve our cash flows by about  [indiscernible (0:26:59) per year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Now what do we see? Continued recovery in U.S., I think the momentum comes from the Sunbelt states. We  expect a good Q3, continuing demand growth in Asia and Africa. Europe, challenging, however, Germany, UK,  Scandinavia should do all right. The CIS countries should be more or less okay. And the difficult mark ets are  mainly in Eastern Europe, in Poland, Czech Republic, Hungary and also Benelux; and target to keep energy costs  flat.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Targets are changed. CapEx we will increase, that's what Dr. Näger already mentioned due to the acquisitions we  did in the first quarter. The expansion programs, chart 39, are on track. Well, this year we talk mainly new cement  capacity coming with vertical roller mill in Indonesia in October, November. And we hope to finish our cement  plant in Kazakhstan close to the Kazakh oilfield at the end of the year. The Togo clinker plant should come on  stream in 2014, the project is on track. I will be onsite in September. And this applies also to the mill project in  Burkina Faso, Ghana and Tanzania.

file: HEI - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 30July2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart five gives you the key financial and confirms that. If we look for half year, that's typically what we more look  because quarter per quarter is always difficult, especially first quarter, weather related. If you look to the full half  year, you see revenue up like-for-like 11%, operating income up 28%, cash flow up €363 million, net debt down  €27 million compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The good volume development in our market is confirmed by chart eight. It gives you a little bit the global view.  And what you see, except for Southern Europe, we see clear growth in our industry. We expect globally cement to  grow about 5% this year. That would mean 150 million tonnes more cement demand in 2014.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: You see also the increase in the cement margin, obviously has to do that in March we had problems with two  major kilns in Indonesia, one in Citeureup, one in Cirebon. That led to production losses. We got the repair done  end of April and started full production again, which obviously had a positive impact in margin and which really  went up, and so that looks okay.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Now, energy management, good news is forecast for the full year is about 0%. Per, as we speak, per end of June,  we are down minus 1% for the cement division. In coal, it's down 1.1%, in electricity minus 0.9%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you have watched the coal market in the last days, you saw there was some activity and fluctuation going on.  Due to the discussion about the sanctions, the coal price jumped from $72/ton sharply to $78/ton, because there  was a concern that the sanctions would also apply the gas sector.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The coal price now -- once the sanctions were announced, the coal price now came back again to $75/ton, and we  expect that to continue to go down again to the level of $72/ton, $73/ton.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On power, we expect the low pricing in Europe and also in Canada and partially in US to continue. That's why we  have increased our forward buying for Q1 and Q2 next year, already up to 50%, because the forward price for  electricity in these markets are at the moment about 15% lower than last year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Western and Northern Europe, also a good run in the second quarter, obviously driven by U.K., Germany,  Benelux; 10% up in Europe. I think it's better to watch for the full half year, because we had a significant weather  impact in the first quarter. If you look now over the six months, this weather effect obviously [ph] waters (12:44)  gets smaller.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Group services, what you see we have a good result development. We're going to trade this year probably more  than 20 million tonnes of cement, clinker and coal. So, the trading goes up. A key issue is obviously that the export  prices in the Mediterranean, mainly Turkey, and in Asia, mainly Shanghai, go up or remain firm. That gives you a  clear signal that the demand for our products on the world market is high, and that's why pricing remains high.  Freight rates remain at a very low level.

file: HEI - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 29July2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Texas, cement volumes in the first half year were down about 15% due to weather. We had an extremely wet  weather in Texas, but also Florida in the south is down due to an overbuild, especially in the condominium areas,  whereas the region west was up with 7% or 8%. Canada was up maybe 1% or 2%. We were down in Alberta due to  a slowdown in the oil sand industry, whereas we were clearly up in BC and Washington State.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Canada, we have not seen, on our financials, the negative impact of the drop in the oil sand business. As in  Texas, our volumes in oil well cement are down by about 40%. However, we could compensate that by selling  more cement, grey cement, in other segments and especially in other geographic areas. And we do not expect a  recovery from the oil industry during this year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Western and Northern Europe, if you look to Q2, I think also a solid result, obviously, driven by U.K., where, in  cement, but also in aggregates, volumes were up 8% and 5%. We had also strong pricing in the U.K. overall  between around 5%. We had a clear decrease in energy prices, whether it's in coal, or in electricity, or in asphalt,  in bitumen, which helped on the margin side. So, again the U.K. result will improve significantly. We will have, in  the second year in a row, an OI increase which will be clearly above 50%. So, U.K. is clearly on the way back.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Northern Europe, strong Sweden, volumes up 7% or 8%. Norway saw a slowdown in volumes due to a market  weakness especially in the oil region of Stavanger, which is a mature market for us, where, obviously, also, we saw  a slowdown in the oil industry.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On group services, figures didn't move that much. What we see is that freight rates continue to be down, energy  cost continues to be low, and we see, obviously, – import is a little bit increasing from China and we expect also  export – we also expect export volumes from Iran to go up. Overall, globally the clinker price at moment is moving  down due to slow markets in Asia and, obviously, low freight rates and cheap fuel. Okay with that I hand over to  Lorenz Näger for the financial report.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On the outlook 2015, we do not change the outlook. We keep our guidance very firm. We see good growth in our  key markets. We're confident for U.S., also for U.K. We see a good run in Germany and Australia. We expect pick  up of volumes in Indonesia and India and we expect continued demand in Africa. Tailwind in the second half will  continue from depressed energy prices. Energy price inflation in the first half-year was again negative with about  2.9% and Mr. Draghi will keep the euro weak.

file: HEI - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 29July2016 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart eight shows you the rolling EBITDA margin. It shows now over a period of two years how we were capable  to push EBITDA margin up. And if you compare this, especially with one year ago, group EBITDA margin is up  1.2%, which is a very good development. Chart nine shows you the falling energy costs. Here you see – the red  line at the bottom of the page shows you the energy cost in absolute amount of euro, and you'll see that they are  coming down quite nicely, and [indiscernible] (06:38) the main driver was coal, pet coke and also oil. Obviously,  we have seen a certain trend change in coal, pet coke prices and also oil prices at the end of Q2. We think the  impact for the full year will be very limited because we are covered by [ph] former (06:54) contracts for the  remainder of the year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In U.S., maybe two figures are important; First of all, our pricing in U.S., gray cement is up around $5 per tonne,  $5.50 per tonne. At the same time, the cement production costs are down by about $2 per tonne compared to last  year, driven by lower fuel prices and electricity prices. So overall, outlook for U.S., okay. In Canada, obviously,  Alberta remains difficult. The oil well volumes dropped again by another 50% in 2016. If you recall, originally, we  sold about 300,000 tonnes of oil well, in Western Canada, it dropped last year to 150,000 tonnes. Our forecast for  this year was 120,000 tonnes, but it will go down by another 60,000 tonnes, 70,000 tonnes, and we see the same  development if you want in Houston. On the other side, the BC and Washington are clearly moving very well,  which has a certain compensatory effect. We have executed also price increases in Canada by about $6 to $7 but  not for all our cement.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And now, we are more confident that the impact at least into 2016 in the [ph] real (12:17) markets of our business  will be rather limited. We have only one major project, which was now postponed due to the Brexit. That's the  major apartment block in Canary Wharf. All other projects are continuing, especially also the decision of Hinkley  nuclear power plant from EDF, but we also have the expansion project from Tata for Land Rover in [indiscernible]  (12:45) is continuing. They have a big project in Manchester and also the UK – The England Highway program of  [indiscernible] (12:55) will continue.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On chart 18, we give you a little bit impression about the big infrastructure projects which we are seeing in  Northern Europe. There we have a very strong, or you even say, dominant market position, especially around  Stockholm but also in Oslo, mainly Oslo and Norway, Stavanger. We have huge highway – I mean, huge  infrastructure projects. If you look, for example, the Follo Line Tunnel, that's the largest cement contract we ever  won in Norway, that's about 300,000 tonnes [indiscernible] (14:22) for the next three years. That's a double rail  track, 20-kilometer tunnel in Oslo, and it goes through the residential area of Oslo where you can go skiing  usually.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On the other side, we had significant reduction on the cost side, in energy costs, distribution costs and also  compared to January 2015, we have laid off maybe around 1,500 people in total.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Trading, chart 22, that's what I told you. You see on the top-line, revenue down in the quarter by 61%, and for the  full year 114%, that obviously has an impact on our group line. And that has to do that the pricing for fuel, for  clinker and cement reduced significantly which brought our trading sales down. Whereas, on volumes, we are  more or less in line with last year, but the cheap prices for fuel and cement and clinker brought the top line down.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: Income tax is inside our expectations. You know that in the first two quarters, normally, we have some movement  up and down, but it will outbalance towards the end of the year. Discontinued operations now again back to the  legacy Hanson asbestos and environmental claims from U.S. no business inside and minorities have been  increased from €51 million to €67 million in the quarter.

file: HEI - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 1August2017 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-17.pdf

texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Now, if I start with the overview, maybe in a nutshell four points. How do we see the development? I think in Q2. If  you look to the result, operationally, we are flat. If you eliminate the CO2 impact from Italcementi from last year in  Q2, we are even at.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: For the Western world in Q2, we had three shipping days less due to the Easter holiday season. That's also  visible. And lastly, we had especially wet weather. I think we'll come to that later in our presentation in the  Southeast of the U.S. And if you have watched the communication from Martin, which came out this morning, they  are very strong in aggregates in the Southeast. They reported about the same weather impact which was  negative for us in South Carolina, North Carolina, and Georgia, and Alabama.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And we think that we will achieve the €500 million saving target, that's the number I already mentioned earlier.  Our official number was €470 million but we are confident that we will reach the €500 million or even more.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And in last year figures as it's mentioned in the footnote €17 million CO2 income was included, because  Italcementi in order to keep covenants or selling CO2 rights, I think it was in May and June last year, which we  obviously are not doing in Heidelberg and that shows a little bit the situation.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Chart 5 talks a little bit about the headwind in Q2. You see the timing effect in European markets where we lost  about three shipping days, Ramadan is about 600,000 tons, in the USA. Weather, and that's why we expect that  we had a better run in the second half and especially having also the benefit of the full run of the synergies.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Energy cost, we talked about that earlier. If you look back, you know that last year, we had negative price inflation  in energy of about minus 6.6%. We think this year in the cement division we will have about 9%, overall. That's  the number we have for June.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And just to be a little bit more precise, if you look to the energy impact for us is mainly in Asia and Europe. In U.S.,  we have more or less flat energy price inflation as well as for coal, gas or fuel whereas things look differently in  Asia and in Europe. And for example, if you take Asia and near our markets in Indonesia and especially also India  and China are impacted, the Newcastle index from Australia is very important.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And just to give an idea, when I was in Asia two weeks ago and three days in Indonesia, the Newcastle index  went up due to the Storm Debbie, to about $100 per ton. Last year at that time the coal price index was about 51,  52. And now the Newcastle index the last days dropped again to a level of 81. But compared to last year, we still  have an increase of about $30 per ton. Our coal contracts in Indonesia our index based Newcastle. And we buy  about 2.4 million, 2.5 million coal per year in Indonesia that gives you a little bit the dimension of the coal price  index which we have to digest in Indonesia beyond the price decrease in cement.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Prices went up all over U.S. by about $5.50 as expected. And we expect margin improvement to continue. We  had in Q2 a special problem in our plants especially in the Silicon Valley in Permanente which is at Cupertino. We  had wet weather. We had management problems. We lost about 200,000 tons of production. And we had to  import more.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And that alone already contributed to an EBITDA loss of about $12 million to $14 million and then we had also  significant wet weather, what you see on the weather chart, and that's consistent what Martin earlier on this  morning. Aggregates overall on track.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Canada. Major message is that the prairies have seen the worst. Oil and gas drilling is back in Alberta. We see  clearly improved significant more activity in the oil wells sector. Historically, we sold about 300,000 tons oil well in  western Canada that dropped to 100,000 tons. We think we will sell this year 200,000 tons. So, oil well is back,  that's good, and we have achieved also price increases except for the prairie provinces by about $5.50.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Now, if you look at – I think that's why we inserted the chart about the profit bridge for Western and Southern  Europe, if you look, we see the reported 2016, then we had the currency impact that's UK. Then, we had the one- off, that's CO2. And, provisions [ph] dissolved (17:02) by Italcementi for last year's half year figures. There was  mainly an issue on bank covenants. And then, you see Italcementi countries up by about €21 million. Half of it is  about, even more than half of it is Italy.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: At the same time, in June and July, pricing remain flat. So that's what we see in Indonesia. We see also that now, infrastructure projects are started  in Jakarta, our core market and in Central Java and Western Java. So we're relatively or let's say we are mildly  confident on Indonesia.

texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG

file: HEI - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 31July2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Yes, hello. Good afternoon here from Heidelberg. Welcome to our conference call to our Q2 result. To all of you,  I'm sitting here as usual together with Dr. Näger, CFO of the company; and our Investor Relations team with Mr.  Schaller and Mr. Kacar. And I hope you have less heat in your home places than we do here in Heidelberg. It  supposed to be the hottest day of the year in Germany.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 5 gives you the bridge from the result. You see the currency impact; deconsolidation, that's mainly the  German sand-lime brick business and the U.S. white cement business. Then you see the pricing impact, volume,  and cost, and cost, as I said, to a very large extent driven by energy. And even with that, we still achieve organic  growth.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On energy, that's a clear issue for energy intense industry. These significant price increases in energy are a  problem. It typically takes the industry a certain while to recover that via price increases in our markets. We show  you on the left side the chart for Newcastle coal, which is the key indicator for coal in the Pacific, in Asia, and you  see really how this went up. That is for us a problem in Indonesia and Thailand and, to a certain extent, also in  India. And you see how the price really went up. And when we made the budget in Indonesia in November,  beginning December 2017, the price was at around maybe $88 and now the price actual is about $123. You see  really the major movement. And the coal consumption in Indonesia for the full year is about 2.4 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And then you see also the price of oil, which went up significantly since December and that's, obviously, cost item  which hits typically the aggregates division. The petrol price in U.S. is up and that cost us typically – hits us in the  aggregates division. And you see then on the right chart how we have managed the fuel cost increase per tonne  of cement. You see compared to the increase of the key indices, our price increase is limited. How do we achieve  that?

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Typically what we do, we change fuel. For example, in U.S. we switched a lot of our plants to gas. The shale gas  is definitely cheaper than coal and shale gas had even a negative price trend in the U.S. And the other point is in  other markets, we try to shift to local coal, which has typically lower quality standards, meaning the caloric value is  lower and also the sulfur content is significantly higher. However, the price difference between local coal and, for  example, international coal, Newcastle or API in Europe, is between $32 up to $50 per tonne. That's what we  have done to a large extent what you see, for example, in Indonesia.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Canada, our business in the prairies; in Calgary, Edmonton, the market is flattish, the market has reached the  bottom, and whereas B.C. and Washington are very strong with double-digit growth in these areas, and we see  for the second half mainly two positive aspects. We hope that we will see in the Prairie Provinces a recovery on  the oil well cement. The oil drilling typically takes place in Q4 and we have budgeted for flat volumes. We see now  an upside because the oil price is up, so it's attractive again for oil drilling. And the second point is in British  Columbia we have done a second price increase of $10 by 1st of July, because the market is very strong.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you go to Western/Southern Europe and look to the results, you see Q2 operationally up 4.5%. UK first half year  was a difficult market, is more or less flattish. We had a significant inflation-related price increase in energy,  especially in bitumen. Order books are good for the second half, and we expect a strong run. We have also done  some price increases now mid-half year, especially in aggregates, and also in asphalt in order to compensate for  the increased input cost. Germany is strong, market is more or less sold out; pricing is up by about €2.50. That  looks okay. And we expect a strong clinker production in the second half.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The second point is, obviously, the price inflation in coal was a significant hit on the margin. I mentioned that  earlier. The third point is the Indonesian rupiah, similar to other emerging market countries, was weakening. That  has hit our results because of our 50% of the cost in Indonesia are dollar-based. And then we had a homemade  problem, our power plant in Tarjun in Kalimantan had a breakdown, and we had then to serve the market via  Citeureup, which has increased significantly logistics cost. So that is a one-time effect which is around maybe IDR  100 million, which will not come back in the second half.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Last chart, chart 16 look to trading. We are on record level volume and profitability. I think here three core  messages. China increased its clinker import. I think that's for first time in the history of the cement industry that  China is increasing its clinker import. I think it goes now to close to 10 million tonnes. What's the reason is that the  people – the guys from Vietnam, they can make better margins on export than in the domestic market, because,  as I told you, the pricing in China went up significantly.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The second message is the price for seaborne clinker in Asia, but also in the Mediterranean, is clearly up  between $4 and $8. So if you want to buy clinker now in Shanghai FOB, you have to pay between $36, $37, up to  $38 per tonne. It's the similar thing in the Mediterranean. That's why for the Turkish guys, for example, now  exporting clinker is, due to the weakness of the Turkish lira, more attractive than to sell domestically. And that  shows you that the domestic markets are strong and there is clear demand of clinker on the global seaborne  market. And the last point is freight trades are up between 20% to 40%, which gives a good base for strong  domestic pricing, because clinker is up, freight is up, fuel is up. That means for importers, it's much more difficult  than a year ago.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: Slide 23, a little recap of the targets we announced at Capital Market Day with respect to financial targets. We are  busy in active portfolio management. We have already reached $294 million of the total proceeds in the first six  months of this year, mainly coming from disposal, white cement assets and limestone bricks in Germany. We still  have a quite comprehensive list of assets to dispose of. These are mainly non-core assets, like white cement  activities, or we still have a paper bag factory on sale and some other of that type. We have a significant number  of idle assets, which are for disposal, such as unused land, depleted quarries, and things like that, and certainly  we have a number of, what I would call, irrelevant market positions, terminals in Sri Lanka, for example, or in very  small countries which we have on the list. So we expect the disposal proceeds to continue to grow during the  second half of the current year.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: So based on that, I would give back to Dr. Scheifele for the outlook.  Bernd Scheifele  Chairman-Managing Board, HeidelbergCement AG  Yes. Okay. The outlook is simple. It's unchanged. We stick to our outlook, to our guidance, which we gave at the  beginning of the year. I think we have headwind from the volume side. I think we have seen the worst on the  energy side, because we are running now against higher energy cost level in the second half. I think you will see  more benefit coming from the price increases, which typically applied since 1st of April, 1st of May now in Q3 and  Q4, and that's where we are.
