Africa is running very strongly on profits and volumes, yeah, and whereas Turkey, volumes, okay,  result is under pressure compared to last year that has to do about the input cost, especially  electricity, but also [inaudible] and coal and [inaudible] have been up significantly and low pricing is  still not high enough in order to compensate for that increase.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We have there a dry clean good Belgian technology of about 0.5 million ton, we are going to  expand that capacity in the future to about 1.4 million tons, we also have acquired two cement  plants at the border to Tanzania and you see the Congo is a large strategic industry, because it  gives us a good bridge between our Tanzanian operations, where we are the market leader, we  have the market about 45% and in Gabon where we are the only player in the cement industry.  These two plants, almost [inaudible] and a market share of about 80%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Okay, Group Services, that’s our trading operation, I think the financial figures are okay, more  important is always the question, what’s the worldwide balance in supply and demand for cement  and clinker. I think here we have good news. Overall, the supply and demand is well-balanced. A  key indicator as I told you in the past is always what are the FOB cement prices in Asia through  Shanghai typically is important. At the moment clinker priced free on board Shanghai is US$35 per  ton. Last time we talked I think it was 31. Forward current for actually next year are ranging at  US$37, US$39 per ton for clinker that means prices are going up just and that’s good news for our  industry.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: If we go to the different markets, we see Asia, we expect continuing strong growth especially in  China but also in India. I do not see any bubble in China, I agree that the real estate market  became a little bit hot in the hot spots like in Shanghai or in Beijing and also in Guangzhou.  However the Chinese Government as usual has taken the necessary actions and they are on track  in executing these measures in order to  cool down the market. So we expect a soft landing for  China. We expect again a GDP growth of 8% to 9%. Cement market, I would expect next year  maybe 3% to 4% due to cuts in electricity for heavy industries in order to reduce CO2 emissions.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Canada, especially the Prairies should continue to show a good growth, oil-sand industry is back,  pricing climate is positive, we see more flat. If you come to Europe and go to the single markets UK  as I told you earlier was a positive surprise. This year the austerity measures by the new U.K.  Government for our industry not as negative as we had expected, they are more or less neutral.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Positive news is that big infrastructure projects are still continuing especially the Crossrail project in  London. That’s the new underground Metro through London with an investment volume of about  £68 billion will continue, we have got big – big works in that project and four and five junction will  also start end of 2010. So overall we think UK maybe flat or slightly negative but we see also good  pricing for UK for next year. Germany, Northern Europe, Germany expect cement market to grow  by 2% or 3%. Residential is up, we expect also positive trend for Northern Europe and it looks trend  negative in Netherlands, should recover next year, Belgium slightly negative.

file: HEI - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 3November2011 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: UK, I have to say UK has surprised again positively this year. Volume wise the market had a strong first six  months. Now the market is a little bit weakening, but we still see growth of about 4%, 5% in the various segments,  driven by the southern part of the U.K., mainly the Greater London market where we have been successful in big  tender projects especially for infrastructure, so we won three contracts on the Crossrail project; that's the subway,  the new subway line through London. We got significant contracts in the Hinkley Power Plant, and we also got  contracts in the new nuclear power plant in Sizewell and Bodbury in London. Pricing in U.K. firm and up  offsetting increase in energy costs.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Germany, we stopped the negative price that includes three prices are now stable, we have announced the price  increases generally 2012, €5 per ton; volumes are okay, key targets for Germany is obviously to offset the negative  price trend which we have seen this year by a successful price increase next year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Okay. That's about for western and northern Europe. Now, if you go to Eastern Europe and Central Asia, if you  look to the figures then you see in the result wise, the result is up in the quarter compared to last year, 15% for the  full, nine months also 15%, so figures are consistent. You see in Eastern Europe-Central Asia, the cement margins  Europe and especially, but also in Ukraine and Russia, we have seen significant price increases on the coal side  and especially also in electricity. So in cement, the energy cost went up by about 12%. However, the markets are  very strong. Russia is growing double-digit 12%, 13%, especially Moscow market, Petersburg market is very  strong, also where we are in the Ural region [indiscernible] (11:54), our plants in Russia are totally sold out. The  same is true for Kazakhstan, market up 20%, Ukraine market up 24%, our cement plants are all sold out. We have  increased prices in these countries by about 15% to 25% and the outlook for next year is not too bad. Poland, we  are also totally sold out. Market has been on a record level in September. Price recovery underway, we are now on  last year's level, we have done another price increase in September and we expect pricing to be above last year in  the last quarter.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: What we see, Canada, it has a strong demand. Volume is – volumes are good especially in the Prairie Provinces,  meaning in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, and B.C. is also slowly recovering driven also by exports to  China. It is clear that raw materials and distribution cost increases have impacted our results, especially the gas  price is up about 25% on average compared to last year on a price per gallon, and that has obviously impacted our  results in cement but mainly in ready mix and in aggregates.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In the cement, the result is up in Indonesian rupiah, however, the rupiah weakened against the euro. That's why  the impact on Group level is denominated in euro is smaller. If you look to the cement margin, you see obviously a  significant drop which also explains the drop on group level and that has to do with mainly 80%, 90%. It's just  energy price. You have to see that in the cement division in Asia, energy costs all in all went up by close to 19% and  that obviously we were not able to offset by prices. In Indonesia, we have put our prices between 6% and 8% but  that's obviously not enough if your energy costs go up by 18% or even more. Okay. That's on Asia-Pacific.  Africa-Mediterranean Basin, I think solid development. You see it from operating income, up 8.5% in Q3, for the  full nine months plus 9.2%. Volume development okay. Also margins more aligned on level of last year's. Cement  slightly down, increased input cost mainly in Turkey and – due to high energy costs and – but good development.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On energy pricing, we expect the softening trend through the various categories until the end of 2012. Okay, that's  from my side and I'll hand over to Dr. Naeger.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Naeger
texts.text: Again, if we turn page and come to slide 17 where we see the profit and loss account, Dr. Scheifele has explained it  until the operating income. If we look below that line, we see the additional ordinary result was minus €28  million. This comes mainly from some asset disposals especially our company in Sweden, SRM, which is a waste  treatment company where we had a loss of €11 million. We had the closure of a cement plant in Australia, it was a  loss of €9 million and some of the restructurings in U.K. and other countries in a magnitude of €10 million.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: China obviously is the key country, because China drives then the growth in Indonesia which is for us very  important. Indonesia is a main exporter to China. They have increased exports in coal significantly, they export  gas, they export palm oil, they export also forest product that's a key partner and also for Australia for the whole  mining industry, there we have strong operations north of Perth and Brisbane, imports to -- exports to China and  India are obviously a key driver.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On the cost side we think the energy costs have peaked and are on a downward trend and obviously inflation will  remain an issue because there's not too much liquidity in all markets and for us the key focus for 2012 will be  margin and price recovery, because we want to get the margin back which we have lost this year and that's going  to be the focus point in the upcoming operational plan meetings which we have with our operational units.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And we will continue what we have done in the past. On the one side, cut costs very aggressively wherever it's  needed and on the other side continue to invest in promising emerging markets. Dr. Naeger described our three  projects [ph] Tula now producing [indiscernible] (35:10) practically finished, then the Kazakh cement plant at the  Caspian Sea in the oil rich Caspian Sea has just started and we are in our final weeks in India with our big  expansion project of 3 million tons, which will be on the market next year.

file: HEI - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 8November2012 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Okay. I'll start with chart three. I think pretty clear picture, strong operational performance in Q3. I want to  underline that we believe that the quality of our results has clearly improved. Cash generation compared to last  year has clearly improved by good cost management and better pricing and a lower trend on energy input costs.  We also believe that Q3 underlines and confirms the strategy of our company, which was always on the one side  aggressive cost management in order to create Q3 cash flow in order to reduce debt on the one side. And on the  other side, to continue to invest what we see as promising emerging markets. And we see this quarter that year- on-year, we have reduced that by about €740 million. We are heading towards aggressive net debt target of as  close as possible to €7 billion this year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Our projects are running okay. I will come back later to PERFORM, which is the margin initiative on cement  focusing on Europe and U.S. The overall target you see is to get back to our cement EBITDA margin before the  Fukushima shock. And on CLIMB Commercial, we think we have a clear improvement potential on the margin  side. But on the cost efficiency side, on the contribution margin side on aggregate and we are targeting about an  increase or an improvement of about €0.50 per tonne which will lead us to another €120 million.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Cost efficiency FOX 2012, you see later that we are clearly ahead of our target. We believe that we will deliver cash  and cost saving of about €300 million for this year against our original target of €200 million. Logistic project has  been launched, [indiscernible] (03:42) with a clear target to save another €155 million 2014.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Volumes have come back in October. Aggregates in U.S. in October is about up again 4%. Whereas in Canada, we  are facing an early winter with already snowfall in the second part of October. If you look to the volumes, so they  were more or less okay, more or less flattish or slightly negative on the overall on group level. Then you see  revenues up 9%. That shows you that pricing obviously worked its way through and you see operating income up  16%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Heidelberg, as a rather de-centralized company, had always the slogan to be very local on sales. What we do now  with this project we define minimum standards for our group on sales management in cement. We are working  with energy transport and service surcharges. We already have announced service surcharges for Germany and  Poland of €1.70 by 1st of November.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On CLIMB Commercial, we are rather bullish that we can achieve €0.50 per tonne improvement. In aggregates,  the general problem in the industry for us is that we have first of all, we are using until now from the old retention  scheme average costing and average pricing on a quarry. So, we do not know exactly what are the production cost  per product. Now, we know only the average cost and that's why we do not have the right pricing for the product.  It might be that we sell even products at a price below the reproduction cost, because the production cost of the  product can very, very much clearly depending on the geology of the quarry.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Now, LEO, we talked that earlier already. LEO is about logistics. Just to give you a figure, our logistic cost in the  company are about €2 billion. That's still north of our cost for crude, which are about €450 million or electricity  which is about €650 million. It underlines the importance of logistics. We have not taken a close look at logistics  in the last three to five years in Heidelberg. That's the first time. So, this is an area where we have not really  worked in.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Okay. If we go to Eastern Europe, Central Asia you see here that overall, figures are relatively stable. Operating  income in the quarter a little bit ahead of last year. Obviously, lower results in Poland, in Czech Republic, and in  Hungary. However, better results in Russia, Kazakhstan and Ukraine, led overall to a more or less flattish  situation. You see also the operating EBITDA margin. [ph] There's no CO2 (16:53) impact is slightly ahead of last  year supported by Tula. Also, aggregates is up. So, that looks for this quarter relatively okay.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And secondly, Coal markets are clearly coming down. That's what you saw on our end margin in cement. Just to  remind you, in 2011, we talked about the NPI coal price for Europe of about US$125 per tonne. We are talking  right now forward contracts for 2012 of about $90 million. The same for Newcastle, that's, exports up for  Australia, 2011 we talked about US$124 per tonne. Now, we talk about $90.4. That shows you the significant  downward trend in coal and we see here at the moment no trend change.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Downside, a little bit early winter start in Canada. That's in the last October. Already in the last 10 days, impact of  storm Sandy needs to be seen. Our biggest plant Union Bridge was down for two days. It's now up and working  again, so far, so good. Specifically, if we talk a little bit later, that's more something for 2013.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Our targets 2012 are unchanged. And I think we can skip that. Management priorities I think also we can keep  that short. I think we will continue with our dual strategy, deleverage, pay down debt and at the same time  continue to invest in the market and in the market position of the company in growing all emerging markets  mainly in cement. And this is a low risk profile. So, low M&A, crazy M&A deals. It's bolt-on. It's brownfield. It's  maybe greenfield but with a low risk profile.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We expect housing to grow next year in U.S. or the commercial to grow, and both sectors will outgrow the  slowdown in infrastructure due to budget reductions in the public sector, should we expect the cement market  goes maybe up 6% to 7%.

file: HEI - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 7November2013 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Energy costs; we discussed that in July. You see coal is down 7.3% year-to-date, and even electricity is only slightly  up with 2.4%. So overall, we have, in absolute terms, a reduction in the energy bill in Heidelberg, and we  discussed it last time that we have a very structured and balanced energy management, which tries not to go too  long on too long positions, but to keep a very fine balance between spot markets and long positions. And that has  paid off this year. And our target is to keep price in the energy inflation flat. If we are lucky, it might be even  slightly negative between minus 1% and maybe minus 1.5%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And if you look also to the margins, I think Aggregates' margin improved to 16.7%. That's driven by London – not  by London, by the UK. And chart 15 shows you one of our big projects in UK, that's the Crossrail project. We have  gained significant contracts for the tunneling, but also we have won now contracts for stations in Central London  due to our good position close to Canary Wharf. We can even bring in the stuff by barges. So Crossrail is a big  project, and it will continue be very important, also in 2014.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The business is strong in California, in Texas, but also the region north, which was very weak due to weather in the  first two quarters now, came back very significantly in Q3; double-digit growth in Cement, then also October again  in U.S., very strong months in our U.S. region, all regions in Cement, between 11% and 12% up. So that looks good.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Africa-Mediterranean Basin; Q3 result is slightly up. Overall, a good story; we had good markets in Turkey, as I  mentioned, Israel also very strong. In Israel, they have now started the exploitation of the gas fields in the  Mediterranean, and that is a big boost for the business in Israel. And also, the government has more income from  gas revenues, and they start spending more on infrastructure. So in Israel, we are sold out; very strong, good  development.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Group services, that's our trading activity. Heidelberg is one of the largest trading – cement trading companies.  We will have this year, broadly about 17 million tonnes traded, cement and coal, and gypsum and petcoke. Two  questions are always important in the figures. When the result is okay, the return on capital employed is one of the  highest in the Group, because there is no [indiscernible] (21:11) negative working capital. That's very good.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: So two points are important, that is; one is the freight rates. What we see are freight rates went up in the last two  months by about 20% the first time since a long time that they really moved up. What's the reason? The main  reason is that the bulk imports to China are significantly picking up. So iron ore shipments to China are about 13%  up; coal is up 9%. So there is more freight needed to China. That's the key to [indiscernible] (21:42).

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And the other point is what's the clinker price doing in Asia and the Middle East? And we see that in the Middle  East and in Asia, clinker export prices are going up, between $1.50 to $2. We talk FOB Shanghai at the moment  about $38, up from $35.5 or $36. What's the reason? The main reason is that the domestic market in some key  exporting countries are very strong, and less volume is available for export.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: But it depends still on the weather development. The longer we have the good weather we have now, the higher  the net debt figure will be. The stronger the euro, the higher the net debt will be. And also the cash-in by end of the  year; how the stock level will be? That is still an effect to be waited for; that's relatively difficult to forecast.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And our target is to keep energy costs at least flat or even slightly down. As we said at the beginning, our target is  to increase revenue and operating income. Due to the currency movements, that looks more challenging than in  July. On the earnings per share, we're confident, because we have positive one-offs this year, whereas last year we  had some negative one-offs, and efforts to reduce net debt are ongoing.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 37 shows a little bit the outlook for the markets. I think that it's clear, targets are unchanged. Expansion  programs, focus is for us at the moment – management focus is on Kazakhstan, in our new project in Shepte. We  started to produce clinker last weekend. I was there on Sunday, so this plant should come to the market beginning  of next year, and it's supposed to supply the new Kazakh oil field in the Caspian Sea.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And the other project is the Togo project with our new clinker line, which should also come in the second half next  year. Indonesia; our mill is about to be commissioned. Management priorities are unchanged.

file: HEI - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 6November2014 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Ready-mix I think is for the analysts quite interesting. Y ou see really a strong increase in the margin, and that  comes mainly from a clearly improved market environment, mainly in UK and North America. And if in ready - mix margins goes up, that means concrete prices are outpacing in speed cement price inc reases. And that's a good  signal, because then finally the end consumer or the final market accepts higher prices, and that's a good signal,  especially for UK and U.S., where we have very significant ready-mix operations.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Heidelberg has been successful in getting the contract for the biggest construction p roject in the UK. That's the  Hinkley nuclear power plant, which is now starting. We're going to supply significantly material to that project,  especially aggregates and cement.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: As you know, we have a strong position in London. In Canary Wharf, there are a couple of skyscrapers up for  bidding. We are really well located for that. We have the Thames Tideway project for the sewage slots. So London  is really very good.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Germany, first nine months, our growth is around 3.5%. In cement, pricing is up about $1.50. At the same time,  we have lower variable cost and lower electricity pricing. So a solid improvement in Germany is quite significant.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Energy cost is obviously a key impact also on the results. We expect energy costs for the full year to be, price wise  flat, and this is good news. So, especially the reduction in coal price obviously has helped us to offset some  increases in electricity in some markets, so we stick to our forecast.

file: HEI - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 5November2015 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart slide six gives you the overview on the regions. I'll come to that later in detail. We see North American  cement down. That's driven mainly by an accelerating negative market trend in Canada, where the slowdown in  the oil sand business is bigger than we anticipated at the beginning of the year. We expect now that our oil sand  volumes will go down by about 50%. We can partially compensate that by higher volumes between DC and  Washington. And we see, also a deal though – slowdown in the markets of Florida and Texas, which will both have  negative growth this year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On chart 12, you see then a little bit the split up of the synergies. Operational, that comes mainly from strict  benchmarking in cement and aggregates. We think there is a clear upside, especially on maintenance repair, but  also on heat consumption and electricity consumption. We think if we introduce our FOX initiatives and MIP,  Maintenance Improvement Program, at Italcementi, we can get a better result.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In cement, however, Canada, for September was down by about 5%, with an accelerating trend due to the oil- wells. And we have also the south, which is down by about 10%, 11%. That's mainly Texas and Florida, due to  weather in Texas and market maintenance in Florida, especially in the multi-residential area in Southern Florida.  On the other side, pricing continues to be very strong. Pricing in U.S., for us, is up by about 9.5%, or, in dollars,  $8.50 compared to last year. That's the good news. And, in Canada, pricing is up by about only 3% because we  could not do a price increase in the oil-well sector.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Positive for us is mainly Australia. In Australia, obviously, the mining project in Western Australia, north of Perth,  has come to a complete stop. No new projects, even iron ore mines are partially closed. The same is for coal. The  same is for Northern Queensland, meaning the area north of Brisbane, around Gladstone and up to Cairns airport,  there mining activity is down. But what we see is a very strong market in the multi-residential sector in Brisbane  and in Sydney and in Melbourne, where especially Chinese money is coming in the country. And this has more  than compensated the downturn in the mining industry. And we have also seen the result improvement in our  joint venture, 50-50, of Cement Australia. So result in Australia is high.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you look to the margin, we have been very careful with margin management. It's more or less stable compared  to December. What's the background? Pricing year-to-date is down by about 2%. Variable costs due to drop in coal  price and fuel costs is down by about 4.2%. Fixed costs are flat, and that has kept the margins more or less flattish.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Okay, the outlook I can keep pretty short. We're not changing our outlook. We think headwind in the Q4 by  continued weakness in volumes. But on the other side, we expect tailwind from low energy prices and weak euro;  lower interest payments; and, also, a favorable one-off. I was just visiting plants in U.S. beginning of the week, and  the wind was still very warm. A good weather forecast for this week, also for next week, so I think we will have a  strong run until Thanksgiving in the U.S., which is good for our results. Also, Europe weather is pretty good at the  moment. It's expected to be, again, a warm winter. That's normally good for our sales, but bad for the working  capital. So, overall, we stick to our outlook 2015, which we have given you at the beginning of the year.

texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Efficiency programs, we started new ones, one for all the business line ready-mix, where we have set up a global  competence center, which is run out of Brisbane from Hanson. We confirm our outlook.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: If you look to net debt to EBITDA pro forma, it's about 2.8 times, I think that's a good figure. Chart five, I think  speaks for itself, which shows you the EBITDA bridge on the operational development. I skip chart six because I  come to the regions more in detail later. You see the margin improvement, I think it's good to see that we also  could increase the Italcementi margin already in Q3. We're working with our HC efficiency programs now at full  speed in the Italcementi cement plants.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Energy costs are down, you see that on chart nine, that's clear. We saw a certain trend change in September. It  needs to be seen now with Trump what the effect mean because nobody – Trump is a pro-energy guy, whether  the American oil production will go up again with shale gas, yeah, that needs to be seen. And then what I said,  new initiatives – competence and the ready-mix €120 million, the yearly split up is we want to do €30 million next  year, and then we want to do €40 million the year after, and €50 million in the year three.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Second point, Houston, the market was weak, was negative, partially weather, partially we had the delay in big  infrastructure work, the Highway 99 is for us a big job in Houston, which was delayed, whereas the other Texas  cities like Dallas, Austin, San Antonito have been pretty strong. So, Houston was a concern.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And the third point for us was, obviously, Canada. And in Canada, it's Alberta. In Alberta, the market is down by  about 10% to 12% due to weakness in oil and gas price. Our oil well volumes in Alberta dropped. They dropped  this year to a level of about 100,000 tonnes. We are coming originally from 300,000 tonnes. Last year we did  150,000 tonnes, so we had another drop of about 40%, and that has obviously impacted our result. Whereas the  Region North remained very strong, especially Mid Atlantic, New York is very strong, Chicago is very strong.  Midwest, Indiana, Kentucky, Ohio have been very strong also with solid pricing. Region West was okay, volumes  weak, pricing okay, but California overall not very good. And Canada, as I mentioned, was OI-wise in the first nine  months, about down US$20 million because the weakness in our high margin business in Alberta could not be  offset by growing volumes, especially in Washington, in Seattle, Redmond, and also in B.C. because there the  margin is lower because cement prices in that area are clearly below the Prairie provinces. I think that's a little bit  the story. If you look to the U.S. figures overall, I think the first nine months show you very good performance. We  saw slower performance in Q3, but still on a very, I would say, very healthy and high level.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: If we look a little bit more to the countries in UK. UK, I would say is a positive surprise, except for the currency.  We had solid growth in the third quarter. If we look to the first nine months in the UK, our volumes in cement are  up by about 2.5%; pricing is up, that is okay. We still see a solid flow of infrastructure work coming in. You have  seen in the press that the Hinkley power plant – nuclear power plant is now going ahead. We have signed the  contract for Hinkley Point, a contract value for us is £120 million at a good margin. That will be good business for  us for the years to come.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: We also secured a significant contract in London, we got the big building Bishopsgate, which is a job of about  80,000 cubic meters. We got the new Land Rover factory close to Oxford, which is another 80,000 cubic meters.  And on the Thames Tideway, that's a big project for us, where we also got significant work, which is about  250,000 cubic meters. So, the infrastructure pipeline in UK, work we already have secured is okay, good outlook  for next year, and we see more work to come.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: China, volumes weak, but pricing has clearly improved. Bangladesh, result up, volumes very strong, results  slightly down, but input costs significantly down due to lower clinker price, lower slag price. Australia, result up,  good pricing. In Australia, we saw a significant growth at the East Coast, typically in Brisbane and Sydney where  the market outlook was about 6%, 7%. Melbourne was more or less flat, Perth was down about 10%, 11%, but  the strong demand in pricing in the East Coast could compensate the market weakness, especially in Perth and  Northern Queensland where we are active in the mining business for coal and pet coke.

file: HEI - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 8November2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: If we look to the markets, I think three points are important. Our U.S. business has performed very well in a  market, which is clearly below expectation. If you look to the cement market now, we are in the first nine months, I  think the U.S. market is close to zero. The PCA forecast is for a growth of 1%. When we started the year, PCA  was for about 3.54%. Last year, we did 4%. So the market is clearly slower. And then we have the hurricane  season, obviously, which has hit us a little bit in the Houston area and in Florida. And against that background  also in Q3 on a like-for-like basis, we have increased the [indiscernible] (02:49) by 10%, I think that's a very solid  performance.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Chart 7 talks a little bit about the energy build here in the cement business line for electricity and fuel. And as you  have seen, we are lowering our guidance on increase of fuel cost, mainly for two reasons. First of all, the strong  euro helps us quite a bit, because the fuel bill is typically paid in U.S. dollar. And secondly, in the operations, we  have managed successfully to a large extent shift in the fuel mix, so we have moved away from high priced, high  quality coal and petcoke to lower calorie coal or to higher sulfur petcoke. And this overall led to a saving in energy  cost of about €40 million.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: That includes also the switch from oil to coal in Egypt but also from coal to gas in a couple of U.S. plants and also  a significant increase in the alternative fuel rate in France. And that's why the energy guidance is now down to  about a full year guidance of mid-single-digit. And that's a strong performance, because you have to see the coal  price and the petcoke price in 2017 compared to 2016 is up by around 40%. You know what I mean, if you look to  petcoke, we talk now about pricing €60 per tonne; a year before, which we're now talking about €40, €41. And  also the Newcastle, the Asian coal is around €80 against last year, maybe €55. So, we had a significant increase  and so we managed that quite well.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Now MTBF, that means the meantime between failure, that means the running time of a kiln between stops, that's  a key performance indicator in the cement industry and you see that in France and Italy, under our management  we have pushed the running time already quite significantly, but we have still a lot of way to go just to give an  idea. Germany, which is from a kiln setup, very comparable to Italy and also to France, the meantime between  failure in our German plants, which have a much higher alternative fuel rate than France and Italy, is about 330  hours.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: So, our French and Italian colleagues have still some way to go, but at least the trend is positive. And as you have  seen, we have increased now the FTE reduction target by another 650 people. We're going to hit now a number  of more than 4,000. Major reductions will come from Morocco, but also from Egypt, and we still have social  planning negotiations going on in some countries in Europe. And Dr. Näger will talk about tax and refinance costs,  which have decreased in the Italcementi [indiscernible] (14:37). So, the synergy target will be clearly  overachieved. We have already reached the target for this year by end of September, and I think we will hit a  number of above €500 million.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Chart 11 shows you that the focus on productivity efficiency in Heidelberg stays high, also in the non- Italcementi  countries, so we have reduced personnel in Indonesia by close to 600 and also in other countries by 600, and that  shows you that we [ph] apparently (15:12) push efficiency productivity in order to improve the margins. And as  you know, my statement as always is we talk about cost management in this industry, we talk about body count  because in Heidelberg, the personnel costs are about €3 billion per year, the total [ph] energy business (15:33) is  about €2 billion. That shows you the importance of personnel cost, and that's the key driver of efficiency and cost  management and finally cost leadership.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: That's why we – I think we're the only one in the industry who sticks to its full year target. We know Q4, it's still a  chunk for us, but we think we are on our way. What's the reason is the October, we had the volumes for October,  October was very strong, we had in cement the strongest month in Heidelberg's history with an increase of  volumes of about 7.5%, also aggregates was up more than 5%. So, October figures should be solid and we keep  the fingers crossed that the weather is not turning crazy too early in November or December and as you know,  the comparison with last year is relatively weak, we had a disappointing Q4 last year. So, we still remain  committed to reach our targets.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: So, in October, our sales in Indocement are up by about 12.5%, which is a high number. So, we think we will have  a strong finish. And the Indonesian result has been burdened on the cost side mainly by the significant increase in  coal price, that's what I mentioned earlier. You have to know that Indonesia is for us the biggest coal consumer in  the group, they consume about 2.2 million tonnes, 2.3 million tonnes on a yearly basis. So, any movement of the  coal price by about $10 per tonne cost us – or we gain about $20 million, $23 million.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Group Services, which is our trading company, if you look to the revenue, that's always important for [ph] ones of  you (23:17) who analyze our margins, our revenue is up by about 20%. That is nice for the top line of Heidelberg,  but it is not good for the margin because the trading margin is very low, so that has a negative impact on our  group margin. The more important message is that the clinker exports from China have been reduced this year by  about 57%. That shows that the Chinese government has a clear no-export policy for clinker and cement. The  domestic market is stronger, and we have production cuts, which are ordered by the government. That also keeps  the price up. And we see also in Asia that the clinker price for export FOB is moving upwards by $1 or $2, that's  also good news for our industry. That's it from the markets.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: I mean, that's it in substance from the financial side, and I would like to give back to Dr. Scheifele for sustainability  and outlook.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Sustainability and outlook you saw, we have published our sustainability commitments in 2030, which focused on  six areas on economic strength and innovation. We have invested significantly in R&D, we have set up a new  R&D center in Heidelberg here where we are focusing mainly on CO2 reduction, emission reduction  [indiscernible] (35:25) we're looking more for product innovation. And occupational health and safety remains a  top priority, the LTI, so meaning the accident ratio is coming down, in the group, we have a LTI target of about 1,  we are now at the moment at about 1.6, 1.7, that's the key issue for us and also the fertility rate has to come  further down environmental footprint, we want to reduce CO2 emissions by 30% by 2030, we are on our way.  Circular economy, I think, we can do much more on recycled concrete and recycled aggregates. There is still a  big improvement potential and we want to be a good neighbor, so we are paying our taxes, we are not using any  tax havens, crazy island, so we are not very much concerned about the Paradise Papers, and in the countries  where we are operating we typically engage very much in social services like entertaining, schools, kindergarten,  health services, et cetera, especially in emerging markets.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Compliance and transparencies for [indiscernible] (00:36:39) we stick to the law, we also stick to all by cost  regulations whether they are in Europe or in the U.S., that is high on our agenda, and also obviously, antitrust  compliance. And then you see on the next chart our commitment to reduce CO2 emissions. In Heidelberg, we are  focusing mainly on three areas, first of all, we concentrate in one initiative on reducing the CO2 emissions by  reducing the clinker content in cement, in that way also by producing low CO2 clinker by replacing limestone as a  coal material, for example, by aluminium ash, we are relatively advanced in that respect and with that technology  we could use our existing plants and able to reduce the CO2 footprint by about 30%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: In another area, we are also running a big research project in Morocco by recycling CO2 through the production  of [indiscernible] (37:53) which then can be used again as a material for heating and the other one is kept in  carbon storage. We have a big project with the Norwegian government, [ph] in creating our Norwegian plant  (38:07) where we capture CO2 and try to store it in our [ph] undersea quarry (38:13) at the Prairie plant.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: We have a very good gross development throughout the world, whether it's in emerging markets and also in  mature markets, maybe except for UK, the outlook is pretty solid. We expect the U.S. markets to come back in  2018 to maybe growth rate in cement 3% to 4%. We will be – we will benefit from our good footprint especially in  California, Washington and also in Texas where we expect significant growth next year. We see Europe further  coming back in volume, but especially also on pricing and another key point is obviously energy cost. At the  moment, we see energy costs next year being flat. So we will not have the headwind of the energy cost as in  2017, though that's why also our outlook which is still early for 2018 at the moment looks relatively good.
