texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In cost management, traditionally Heidelberg has been always strong. FOX was a success. We had targeted for  about €200 million. We finally reached €385 million. If you look back a little bit, lean back and say what's  happened in 2011 and you look to our segments, then you will see that our margin in the segment Cement dropped  by about 3.2%. And the main reasons are two-fold. One thing is the clear increase in energy costs. And the second  point in Europe, Western Europe and Eastern Europe, is the drop in CO2 income, which was against last year a  drop of about €130 million on operating income level.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We told you that we would expect a very strong cash flow generation in Q4. Again, we have been very successful in  net debt-to-EBITDA is down to 3.3 coming from 3.6. I think a good performance and liquidity stands at 4.7.  Interest costs are a focus point for the future. We issued recently a bond for €300 million for 4%, clearly within  investment grade pricing and without additional premium for new emission which underlines the confidence of  the capital market in the company.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We continued to invest in the business. If times get tough and we reduce investments, you can do that, Heidelberg  has a lot of investment opportunities at hand. We need a lot of discipline in that. We exercised discipline again.  But our investments were at about €959 million, clearly below the original plan due to the fervor in the financial  market, but still ahead of depreciation which shows that we see good investment opportunities in our existing  markets, brownfield and greenfield without M&A. And that's what we have done in 2011.  The charts four and five just underpin what I told you. You see the volumes up in Cement by about 12% and  Ready-mix 12%, and Aggregates 6%. Aggregates is lower because of its presence in mature markets. From this  figure, what these figures tell you is also very simple. Sales up 10%, Cement up 12%, and Ready-mix also 12% and  Aggregates 6%. That shows you the top line was okay. We don't have a pricing problem. The problem on the  margin was driven by increased energies cost in the Cement division and missing CO2 income. Whereas we didn't  have a margin problem in the Aggregates business, which shows again that also our product portfolio is very good  because the Aggregates division has a clear stabilizing factor especially if markets are very volatile.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you look to the financial figures on slide six, I just want to raise your attention to two points. You see the cash  flow is up by about 16% from operating activities. And then you see the gearing is down to 57%. Normally in the  industry, gearing should be around 80% to 100%. It shows the key problem is to a much lower extent the amount  of debt is the question on the missing cash flow still from missing volumes and to price pressure in the energy  sector.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: I come to the areas, Western and Northern Europe, slide 10. I concentrate myself on the full year now. You see  volumes have been very strong in Western and Northern Europe. It's plus 12.4%. You see operating income is up  only to a plus 4.9%. The key reason, the main reason is the missing CO2 income. You see that also in the Cement  margin, the Aggregates margin unchanged, and you see that also in the Q4 result where the volumes were clearly  up but the result is behind last year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And then you will see the main effect comes obviously from the missing CO2. In the markets,

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Eastern Europe, Europe, Central Asia also yield very good volume growth, 14.5%. Russia strongly back, Ukraine  back, Kazakhstan back, results are clearly growing, Poland record sales, challenges in Romania and Hungary,  Czech Republic good volumes.  Operating income up only plus 2.6%. That has to do mainly again with CO2, which was missing in Eastern  European countries in Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland. And you see again the Cement margin was for that  reason undergo pressure.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Australia was okay. India was significantly increasing coal price above 100%, which was a problem. Market in  India over the whole year was also volume-wise relatively weak. And the Cement margin came down by 4  percentage points. That's driven by Indocement that has to do that in Indonesia and in all Asia, the energy prices  were adapted in 2011 to world market prices. And we do not expect a further drop of margin in that region. We  even expect a certain recovery.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And the last message through footprint and outlook in that respect is there's a first sector. I call them the  HeidelbergCement star countries, will continue to shine in 2012. So we do not expect negative developments for  our Western Canada business. We expect solid recovery continuing in Texas. We expect a good development in  Germany, also in Poland. We see Indonesia performing very strongly. We are confident for Australia. We are  confident for Ghana and Tanzania which are very strong countries, which have found huge gas reserves. So our  key profit-bringers are in relatively good shape and that's why we are relatively confident because our exposure to

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Aggregates between minus 1% and 2% that has to do with very strong growth rates due to weather which we  saw in Western and Northern Europe in December. So that's our picture and also pricing except for some parts in  Europe we might come back to that in the Q&A, we are relatively positive, but general message is also our target to  recoup half of the margin we lost in Cement by price increases in Cement.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Overall, we are on our way in all parts of the world. Price increases have been executed and we already see some  early successes. Also here, we are for the time being, let us be modestly optimistic, okay. Then energy, on the  energy side, as I said at the beginning that was the key problem in our Cement division last year. How do we see  that? At the moment, also here things look better than what we anticipated in our budget. To make that concrete,  we had assumed in the budget a coal price for Europe for example, [ph] FOB ARA (39:17), that's the South African  coal, of about US$120 per ton. If I look to the spot price now, it's US$100 per ton.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Petcoke, we had assumed an FOB price of about 95, it's now 75. If I look to gas prices in U.S., they are significantly  down. Electricity prices in the U.S. down to budget due to the fact that the power industry in the U.S. is gas-based,  that's the issue with the shale gas. So we see a key positive trend.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And in China and Asia, we have a special development, the Chinese government has stopped steel and cement  production for about 3 to 4 weeks in some core provinces in order to take capacity out of the markets, due to  reduced infrastructure spending in order to stabilize also the pricing, that has led to a significant lower import of  coal to China. And now we have very cheap coal, seaborne coal available in the Pacific, which we can buy on spot  markets. So, what we are doing now at the moment we buy spot coal on ships for Asia which is also an  opportunity.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: What's the downside, the oil. We had based our back sheet on Brent oil U.S. of about US$100 per barrel, we are  now at US$125 that's again gasoline price issue which we see in U.S. So, we have a couple of upsides. The key issue  is that the oil price and I mentioned that has to do with the Strait of Hormuz which is obviously beyond our  control. Overall at the moment we see 5% energy cost inflation.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: My perception is if the oil price doesn't explode for any political reason, we see a chance to go below even the 5%,  because the pricing trends also in electricity for example in Europe and in Germany are really low and the power  price in Germany's spot price, as we thought, is practically down to the level pre-Japan. So we have really come  down again and also here we see a clear relief.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On FOX, 35, okay, in order to, clear message, Heidelberg will continue to be a benchmark in the industry on cost  management. We have increased our saving targets for FOX by about €250 million to €850 million and at the  same time we've started a logistic project, which will be lead by Dr. Näger, who is the in charge for IT and Logistics  and has very much to do with IT because first of all what you need is transparency and consistent systems. And we  think we have a saving potential of about €150 million. Background information total logistic cost of Heidelberg of  about €2 billion, and normally in a McKinsey approach, you would say 10% are always possible, we are a little bit  more cautious and think €150 million is something which we can achieve over the years 2013, 2014 and then main  effects to be seen in 2015.  Now what else? On growth, we continue our policy, which has – our strategy which has been twofold. We manage  costs very effectively and at the same time a part of the free cash flow we continue to spend in greenfield and in  brownfield in emerging markets. So, we see now Damoh-Jhansi coming to the market in Central India in the  middle of the year. The Bangladesh mill comes in 2012, with full capacity. We have two expansions in Ghana and  Liberia coming. Indonesia, we are planning a new cement plant in 2014. We will have 2 million tons in 2013 in our  existing plant in Citeureup. So we will continue with our strategy to grow the business. Acquisition – major  acquisitions are not part of that strategy.

file: HEI - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 14March2013 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We started the year with a high inventory of clinker of about 1 million tonnes, which puts us in a position that we  do not have to import that much. We expect imports to play a minor role in 2013, because with a good production  performance, we can nearly produce everything what we can sell.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Germany, we had NOC surcharge in December introduced [ph] when €70, which sticks (15:25). We had also  NOC fuel surcharge in Benelux of the same amount, which keeps holding, then you have Poland about 6-zloty  NOC surcharge. And the price increases in Czech Republic and Romania already were done beginning of the  January in Germany – especially in Poland – to follow 1st of April.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 13 shows you the Cement margin. That's what I told you during the year last year – that our margin will  recover, that's what you've seen. That's the clean margin, without any pension, CO2 and whatever. And that shows  you we were back at about 24.9%. The clear target for this year is to get the margin up in the direction of 26%, so  get it back to the old level, pre-Fukushima crisis.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Same is true in Aggregates. You saw in Aggregates, the margin is at 21%. Our EBITDA margin is very competitive  in Aggregates, if you compare with our peers. And you see even volumes down 5%, we kept the margin stable, even  with a significant energy price inflation. So you see really that the client efficiency program is clearly paying off.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 15 shows you the FOX targets. I think it's more or less self-explanatory. And I think that's it.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And then the last chart is then on chart 22 on group services. Shows you that we have increased profits quite  significantly. You know that this is our trading business. [ph] Maybe to mention it (18:37) we are the second- largest cement trader in the world. We have about 300 charter ships running for us. So we trade coal and clinker,  gypsum, and cement, obviously. And we have a global sales network with offices in Istanbul, Singapore, Shanghai,  Dubai and in Malta, and these guys are doing a great job.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: And if there we look to slide 24 that's the summary of that. We have below the operating income quite a lot of one- offs and I would like to make them understood to you. First of all, we have to see that the one-off non-cash  expense are partly offset by profit from successful tax strategies and from release of an asbestos-related insurance  liability. So we have written-off some of our fixed assets and some of our preferreds, and we had some losses from  sales of assets, which are included in the additional ordinary result.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: If you go to slide 25, income statement, you see this could present the additional ordinary result. Goes from €145  million to €409 million. We have the financial result that goes from €582 million cost item to €641 million. We  have a positive effect in income taxes where expense reduced to €151 million and we have a net income from  discontinued operations as our asbestos and environmental claims which are handled in U.S. and that shows a  profit of €98 million. So the profit of the financial year goes to €545 million, up 2%. But, however, the group share  of profit goes down by 13%. The reason is that the profits in company with significant – minority shareholdings  especially in Cement has significantly increased and this leads to higher minorities.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Financial targets, I think, are clear cut on chart 39. I think nothing to be added. CapEx will go up a little bit due to  the expansion – due to the new coal line in [indiscernible] (37:52), and also the acquisition of the outstanding  49% interest in our Russian plant in [ph] Tulamatock (38:02) close to the Ural, and then we have a little bit an  impact from [ph] niche app (38:06) in North America.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Outlook, as I said, strong recovery in U.S. Europe challenging, but mitigated for Heidelberg due to superior  footprint by a solid Germany, good Scandinavia, and good Russia. Target is to keep energy cost flat. I think we're  well positioned to reach that. The first two months show a clear declining trend in energy cost, that's obviously  good news. We face price – we face cost pressure in raw materials, and especially in staffing cost. And it's clear  that we want to further reduce the debt, and also reduce interest cost and together with a improved operational  performance that should boost earnings per share in a significant way.

file: HEI - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 19March2014 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: As we saw last time, I think we had a good operational performance like -for-like without currency and  consolidation impact, we could grow the operating income and you have to take into account, that on EBITDA  level last year, we had a contribution organic growth about €62 million which came in in Q4 which we did not  have in 2013 because we made the decision not sell our CO2 rights but to bank them or transfer them in the year  of 2014. I think this decision was right because in the meantime, the price went up – the price was down €3.17 , I  think it's now at about €8 or whatever. And if on European level that will be further decisions, we think that the  price might further go up and then we might sell it at a higher price.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: I think slide 4 there is no news from last time. I'll just skip that. Slide 5, you see the EBITDA development. Again,  like-for-like, it's up 2% if you also eliminate the $62 million or $64 million from CO2 gains which we had last year.  Then you see we have operational performances up 7 %.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: We then enjoyed a really significant improvement in our risk position from our Hanson Asbestos claim liabilities  because we finally won a trial before the court in California and we finally got confirmation that all of our asbestos  risks are covered by insurance.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And then we have still a very expansionary credit policy or monetary policy especially in U.S., in the whole Euro  area with Draghi and also in the UK, and a more or less neutral one maybe in Australia. And that explains now a  little bit also our view on the markets. We think we should have a good year, a strong recovery in U.S. and UK that  will continue. And I made a trip two weeks ago through the U.S. from coast to coast, our sales people are very  confident on volumes, at the moment, weather was bad especially in the region North,  that's why – where our  sales are down. And also in Canada, we had a very harsh and long winter also last week, again, March at the  Eastern Coast, we had again snow, but as soon as the weather calms down, volumes pick up immediately.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The regions which are not touched by weather, typically, Texas at the South, and California are already, volume - wise, the first weeks of the year clearly up. So we expect the good year in the U.S. supported by, let's say, average  price increase maybe of about $5 per tonne.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: There are big projects coming. We have the Thames Tideway, that's a sewage sludge project for London, which is  coming North line subway extension, we got the contract with EDF on the Hinkley nuclear power plant, which is a  very big one, which comes now into play in the middle of the year. And we got also the only concrete plant on the  demolition of the nuclear power plant of Sellafield, which will bring us big volume, that's about a 10 years  contract. So we are also well positioned on the infrastructure side. And also on pricing, we think in the UK more or  less £1 per tonne of cement, so that looks pretty good.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If we look to the other big states where we're in is Northern Europe, we expect also again a solid year driven by  infrastructure. We have some very significant infrastructure projects in that area. We have the tunnel to the  Fehmarn Island in Copenhagen which is a huge project where we are actually bidding for with our cement plants.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: We have a new subway in Copenhagen, and we have about 7 0 projects in the outskirts of Stockholm, especially  highway projects which will drive infrastructure. And in Norway, we have in the Stavanger oil area, significant  infrastructure works on tunnels, roads, harbor extension also for the oil fields which keeps us busy.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Germany outlook is also good, we expect the growth in the market. Heidelberg benefits from the big project, what  is called Stuttgart 21, that's the new train station which will go under the Earth. We gained two big tunnel projects  through the Swabian Alp which is about 400,000 tonnes of cement. The bidding process for the train station itself  is just underway. So we are also confident for Germany, we expect a price increase in the range of about €1.50 and  €2 per tonne which is already underway.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Africa remains solid. We see a little bit more competition in Ghana and Tanzania but overall, I think Africa should  be all right. If we go to Eastern Europe, we see a clear recovery underway in Poland. Also due to weather, volumes  are significantly up in the first eight months to nine months, we are significantly up compared to last year, more  than 40%. We go now also for a price increase in Poland by 1st of April which we originally had not foreseen in our  budget by PLN 10.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Russia, weather was harsh. Volumes are at the moment, as we speak, up about 4% or 5%, and we have to wait now  for the development. In Ukraine, also volumes are up at the moment, we think we're going to have a solid fir st  quarter but then obviously we will see the impact on what's happening politically in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Key issue for us, obviously, energy cost and here I think that's the good news compared to the trading statement.  The trading statement we guided you that in our operating plan, we think that the energy cost in the cement  business might be up compared to last year, 3%. If you might recall, last year, we had a negative price inflation of  about minus 2.5%. Now, after the first two months, we are, in the cement division, again down compared to last  year about 1.6%, on the total group, 2%. That's mainly driven by cheaper coal in Europe, but also in Asia where  prices are down $7 , $8, whereas electricity is slightly up. And that's why we think for the whole year, at the  moment as we speak, we should go for a zero rise inflation on energy, which is obviously helpful on the margin  side.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 37  shows you the projects in Africa. We're going to bring about cement capacity  of about 5 million tons this  year to the market. All projects run on time and on cost. So we have no any – we have no unpleasant surprises  until now. That's especially true for our Togo clinker plant. We are ahead of schedule. We hope that we can  produce the first clinker maybe in September. And also the milling project in Burkina, in Tanzania are on track. So  we might have production already ready in Q4. Originally, the target was to do it end of the year 2014 beginning of  2015.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And the last chart shows you the expansion project we have in Indonesia. The grinding mill now in Citeureup is  running with about 1.9 million tonne. We have the brownfielding project with a new kiln line of 4.4 million  tonnes. The project has already started and we have start-up costs capitalized in our balance sheet of, I think, close  to €150 million. That project should be finished in, I think, it's June 2015, next year. And then we have two  scouting projects, one in Central Java and one in Sumatra, where it's still unclear whether we're going to go for it  or not.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And then last, our new cement plant at the Caspian Sea, which is there in order to supply the Kazakh oil field, will  come – has started to produce clinker. We are producing clinker and we are ready to enter the market b y April  when the weather picks up, and this is good news. Okay. Targets 2014, I think Dr. Näger explained the financials.

file: HEI - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 19March2015 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: We have a reduction in the risk position from asbestos. Last year, you remember we had capitalized our insurance  claim. And then we have a loss, an accounting loss this year from the transaction Hanson Building Products,  minus €236 million. So the balance this year flat, minus €12 million; and last year in the result, €420 million non- recurring. That gives you the possibility to make up your own mind how you see the net profit.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The second general point is obviously energy is also still going down. The oil price in U.S., the WTI, is now down  again to $42, $43. We expect from a decrease in energy price a conservatively assessed positive impact on OI level  between €50 million to €70 million compared to last year. And that's confirmed by the development in the first  two months. In the first two months, the cement division fuel costs overall – energy cost overall are about 4%  below last year. So that underlines our assumptions.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: I think slide 37 is self-understood. Oil price, I told about you a little of the upside. The key question, what's the  downside. I think we have to look at it market-by-market. In Canada, in Western Canada, in the prairie provinces,  we do about 300,000 tons oil well cement. At the moment, we see that oil rigs are by down about 40% so we  expect especially for the first six months where typically the oil well cement is used a drop of about 30% of these  volumes, meaning 100,000 tons. However, we have a totally sold out situation out there. So we can sell this  market – this amount in the gray cement market. On the other side what is positive, Western Canada includes  Washington, the Puget Sound area, Seattle, where the market is clearly coming back. We expect strong volumes  and also price increase in the Seattle area; and we see also B.C. Vancouver coming back.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Texas, on the Texas shale gas fields I think you also have to go a little bit area-by-area. It is so, we are a little bit  lucky here that we are not a supplier to the big well-known shale gas fields like the Bacon field in North Dakota,  we are not present; also Colorado, we are not present. And there is another big field in western Texas, close to  Amarillo. Amarillo, we're also not supplying to that field. We are mainly in, what is it called, the Eagle Ford gas  field, which is in south, San Antonio, Corpus Christi. There the number of drillings did not move a lot. It stayed  more or less stable. So we are not that exposed there.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: On the other side, we are on the East Coast, in Pennsylvania, supplier to the Marcellus gas field. Here, volumes  even go up. One of our biggest accounts is Halliburton. And they even increased their orders for 2015. We are  supplying oil well cement there from our cement plant in Evansville.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Overall oil weakness on the next slide, I told you already, chart 39. That's obviously an impact due to the fact that  we do only a small amount of our EBITDA in euro. And the debt is in euro. That obviously has a positive impact.  So, overall, we are looking forward to hopefully good year 2015. What we can control, I think, looks pretty good.  The political crisis in the world obviously is something different. That can change the picture very fast, especially  also on the energy side, but that's something we all have to live with.

file: HEI - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 17March2016 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: I forgot the line above, discontinued operation. Last year, we had the loss from the sale of Hanson Building  Products minus €179 million. This year it's down to minus €36 million. This is more or less the loss from our  asbestos and environmental obligations, which we have inherited from Hanson. And there is also a smaller part  still from building products but overall, this is the Hanson environmental and asbestos cost, which should balance  out in the future around €25 million per year.

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: On slide 31 then, we see the Italcementi refinancing. We currently have a bridge loan for €2.7 billion. Therefore we  will need for refinancing €1.9 billion. We come from a total amount of €4.8 billion, but because €500 million is  the change of control waiver for the debt inside Italcementi there we're faced now and there is no more change of  control clause in place. We then have successfully, I would say, very successfully placed a debt certificate in the  German market. This is six years maturity for a 1.8% interest rate. We expect €1 billion from asset disposals, €250  million are already done with assets, which go from inside Italcementi to the seller, Italmobiliare. This includes  the water power business in Alto Adige, and it includes an IT company Power Solutions.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Texas, we make a little bit of a question mark on Houston. It's clear that Houston is impacted by the drop of the  oil price. So residential is really slowing down, commercial is slowing down, and you would expect a further  decrease on oil well cement, however, with a very limited impact on the other side. Dallas, is, in our opinion, not  related to the oil industry. It's the corporate hub for U.S. We see Dallas very strongly performing in the first two  months. And that's not only weather driven. We see infrastructure very strong. Residential continues to be very  strong, commercial very strong. So we expect a very strong year in Northern Texas.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In Canada, we have a little bit two trends. You know that on Western Canada, we expect the Prairie provinces  volume-wise to be flat after a decrease last year due to the sluggish oil price. However, we see now projects coming  up with a new government, so we hope to keep the volumes flat. Pricing will be up. British Columbia, BC,  Vancouver area is clearly booming. Residential is very strong. Commercial is very strong. We have some  significant LNG projects along the coast north of Vancouver. So we expect a v ery good year in BC. So, overall,  Canada should be fine.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: What we see is there is price pressure due to new capacity. But on the other side we see also that our costs are  coming down significantly: variable cost, distribution cost, fuel, electricity, gas, fixed costs are down. Just to give  you an idea, our cement production cost in the first two months at Indocement are down 10% compared to last  year. So that will compensate to a large extent the pressure on the margin from the pricing. And then, finally, by  April 1, our new kiln, P14, will start production. Here we have a saving against the old kilns of about US$10 per  tonne, which should help to support our margin and that should help us.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: If you look to Western and Northern Europe, UK, I think, will have another strong year. London, which is for us  the main market is clearly close to a housing boom. Multi-residential is strong. We have lots of work in the  expansion of the Canary Wharf area. We got very good contracts in the Highway England area. We have the high - speed rail connection between London and Birmingham. We got the job for the Hinkle y Power Plant with EDF. So  we are pretty busy. Pricing is strong. We will consider in UK even a second price increase in the middle of the year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And different from some analyst views, we see the maximum exportable volume from China maybe 25 million  tonne to 30 million tonne. Clinker price for Shanghai remains under pressure. At the moment, it's about $28. You  can even get it for $27. And the landed cost of clinker to Shanghai on ship for our Chinese producer is about $25.  So it shows you that on exporting, the margin is very small and the CO2 emission is pretty strong, especially  compared to steel. That's why we do not foresee a significant pickup in Chinese exports in 2016.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Energy costs are clearly our friend. If I look to the cement division for Heidelberg, the first two months, our  energy costs are down compared to last year 10%. That helps on the margin side and we see overall trends in  Europe that the markets are coming back step by step, especially in Eastern Europe and we will co ntinue with our  successful margins enhancement programs in aggregation cement. If you look to our margin development in 2015,  we were the company who has improved the margin in cement on group level, but also in Aggregates. That's quite  in contrast to some other competitors, and we will continue to do so. So we are pretty confident that we can  continue to expand margins in 2016.

file: HEI - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 16March2017 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Chart 10 shows you again the EBITDA performance here in 2016 and then we showed again the chart on  Western and Southern Europe, there was some irritation after the trading statement call because I think we were  down in Q4 about €60 million to €70 million and the question was whether there was any problem in the  operational business. I told you in the call, there is no problem. It has to do with one-offs and the CO2 provisions  which had to be made and with PPA adjustments and also that the booking between holding cost and operational  cost was changed because to the consolidation of Italcementi and different accounting practice in Heidelberg  compared to what was done in the past in Bergamo and especially also for the central cost of Ciments Francais  Holding in Paris.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Okay. I just go back to the outlook to the last two charts, chart 36 and 37. If you look a little bit to the cement  demand globally, North America, I think we discussed. I would also expect like the PCA about 3.5% growth. I  would expect infrastructure to be relatively strong due to the FAST Act which comes now into the market. The  infrastructure, Congress has already approved. We see consumer confidence, net wealth per household on a  very high level in U.S. That's why we also expect Residential to pick-up and Commercial. We would also expect  that the weak markets of California and Coastal Texas, mainly Houston will come back in 2017. And the last point  is, when I was in Dallas, we were discussing always the issue of the oil industry, which is important for us in  Houston, but also in Western Canada. And the good news is that the frac'ing production in the U.S. is up  significantly and as you know, that's why the oil price came down over the last days here. And just to give a figure,  the number of oil rigs is up in North America by more than 100%. So, [ph] March (39:42), and we see already a  clear increase in the oil well demand in our operations in Texas Lehigh, but also in Western Canada and  obviously that has a higher [ph] country dilution (40:00) margin.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: UK, we see good infrastructure project, our order book is good. We have the nuclear power plant, we have big  projects here with the [ph] Thames Radar (40:14) in London, and also the highway – Britain Highway project of  the British Government, so UK should be all right. Europe, I talk modest recovery. Northern Europe, especially  Norway, Sweden. Sweden, we see very strong demand with big tunnel projects also in Oslo and Stavanger. And  Russia, Kazakhstan, Ukraine, recovery with double digit price increases between 10% to 15%.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.profession: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, HeidelbergCement AG
texts.text: Africa overall is okay, except for the oil countries where we see still significant economic weakness, that means  Nigeria, Angola and Gabon, and also South Africa. And in Asia, China, we would say more or less flattish on  volume, but pricing compared to last year clearly up. Pricing now in China is about RMB 230 per ton to RMB 240  per ton. That is nearly 20% up compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And the other one on the cost and other, the €348 million, a key component is energy. texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: Cash tax ratio on slide 25. So the average the three years' average is a good indicator and this one is also clearly indicating  downward. So it has now reached 24.8% which is a good figure. The best figure we saw probably in the last 10  years, but we still see cash tax payments further trending down as globally and especially in U.S., tax rates are  going down. European Union now has an average of 21% tax rate and U.S. has 21%. So there is still potential to  improve our cash position.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: The second statement and that underpins the first one is at the bottom of the page. That shows you whether there is import threat  [indiscernible] (00:26:29). At the moment, FOB clinker in Shanghai and also in the Mediterranean influenced  heavily by Turkey is around $36 up to $37 per ton of clinker. When we talked a year ago, it was about below $30  per ton. We talked about prices $27, $28 $29. So, prices for clinker are up by about 20% in Asia and in the  Mediterranean.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: In the region north, if you talk northwest, that a bit Midwest. That's about Illinois, Indiana, Wisconsin, Iowa. Here,  we see a good overall trend in residential, commercial. The markets are more or less sold out. Pricing should be  solid with up $6, $7, $8. So we're going to hit pricing around $125 up to $130 per ton. In the northeast, yeah, that  looks a little bit more difficult, that's the area of Boston, New York down to Washington. First of all, we have very  harsh winter. We have today again snowstorm in Maryland and Virginia. I was there two weeks ago. There was  also again a snowstorm. So even in March still snow. So we had a slow start and we see also a negative impact  of [indiscernible] (00:29:59) on pricing. So, I would expect for the area of Boston, New York maybe a price  increase of $2 per tonne reaching then maybe then $110, but it's clear that here, pricing environment will be more  difficult.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Overall, for the U.S., we are confident. Canada should have a strong run. In the Prairie, gas drilling is clearly up.  BC, Vancouver is very strong and also the Seattle, Portland. As for us, Washington is part of the region Canada,  very strong residential and commercial, and BC, price increases between $8 to $10 in Canada and in Washington  especially Seattle, Portland, we expect very good year, but also West Canada should be clearly up.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Question mark in Europe is UK. That's the question. Whether how the Brexit will evolve. Also here until now, if  you take the weather out because the weather, also in UK, they still had snow. In our [indiscernible] (00:33:36)  there was snow on Monday still, so. Otherwise, it was difficult. I got stuck Wednesday – a week ago I got stuck in  London because there was all over snow. We could not continue to Manchester. The country was really closed  out, but if the weather becomes normal, daily volumes are in good shape. The market is doing better than what  we have expected at the moment. Yeah.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Asia. Indonesia, there will be a lot of question about Indonesia. Indonesia, the market first two months as some of  you will know was strong. Market growth was close to 9%. We were growing in the industry about 12%. Some  competitors are trying to increase prices especially in Central Java and West Java, partially we have followed, but  new challenge in Asia, the main challenge is the energy price. Coal is still relatively expensive.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: And the second point is a little bit the energy price. As we discussed last time, in February, we discussed about  the Chinese New Year blah, blah, blah, coal price and as I told you, the coal spot price after Chinese New Year  already dropped by $10. So that moved also in our direction. In Asia, the price is still relatively high, but also coal  at the moment is trending down and that's obviously also a very important factor.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Chart 3, overview. Okay. Well, revenue overall was up 8%. First time Heidelberg exceeds €18 billion sales, so we  had overall a very good strong growth on the top line. If you look to the EBITDA [indiscernible] (00:01:43), we are  more or less flat, if you take out Carroll Canyon and the forex and the consolidation compared to last year. 2018, I  think, was the most challenging year in the industry after the financial crisis. So we had a lot of headwind from  high-energy cost inflation, exceptionally bad weather partially at the beginning of the year in Europe and in U.S.,  and then also in September again very wet weather in the UK especially in the [indiscernible] (00:02:16) in Texas.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: Deconsolidation €53 million, and then on the right side, you see the Carroll Canyon impact of about net €61  million. What's interesting to see and that is very consistent what we have seen from our competitors which have  already published their results that the price cost component was negative, meaning the industry was not in a  position by price increases to compensate the significant increase in energy cost. We had last year increased, for  example, if you take the new [indiscernible] (00:05:19) average price was up 17%, oil was up by about 30%. And  for example, in Germany, electricity which is a benchmark market for the energy in – for electricity in Western  Europe, electricity was up by about 30%

texts.speaker: Lorenz Näger
texts.text: On the other hand, from our disposal program and portfolio optimization program, we have quite a significant  amount of gain, €125 million mainly coming from the sale of the German limestone, brick business and the U.S.  white cement business.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: As you know, we have budgeted for a volume growth of 4% in Indonesia for 2019. Last year's market growth was  5.2%, 5.3%. Our budget assumption was zero growth in the first half year due to the election and about 8% in the  second half. However, we see now in the first quarter that already until now growth has been slightly positive. So  volume is okay, pricing is also good in bag cement, we are up by about 10%, bag is flat, yeah. We had assumed a  certain drop of bag cement price in the first half year due to the consolidation not being finished yet. And then, I  have assumed the price increase in bag cement, I think starting from the July 1 or August 1. At the moment bag  cement price is stable, that's good news. Our good news is the coal price is clearly down.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: You know that Indonesia is one of the large coal consumers in our group with about 2.6 million tons. The  Newcastle Index is clearly down, so we have also support from lower energy costs. And finally, the Indonesian  rupiah has clearly gained strength. It's much better performing against the U.S. dollar compared to last year. Last  year, we lost about 10%. As most of you know two-thirds of our cost base in Indonesia is dollar base, so if the  currency is weakening that hits us also on our operational result. So Indonesia at the moment things look good.  Australia is doing okay. The market – the residential sector is weak, especially in Sydney and Brisbane.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: However, the [indiscernible] (00:38:10) Perth is coming back step by step. We gained some good projects in  Perth with shopping centers but also in the mining sector. Melbourne is strong and also you know Australia  obviously the lower coal price helps us in Cement Australia which is quite significant and the other point is the  fuel, the diesel cost is down in Indonesia – in Australia, at the moment diesel in Australia is down by about €0.10  per liter and this gives us against last year, for example, a saving of about AUD 7 million because €0.01 is about  AUD 700,000, so that is quite significant because we run the big aggregates in ready-mixed business over there.

texts.speaker: Bernd Scheifele
texts.text: So, that's the message. If maybe a last point is on the volume side, we think we are okay. Pricing at the moment,  Europe, North America looks okay. Also Indonesia is okay. And then what I already said in February, energy  should be our friend this year. We see clearly lower energy costs in coal, even CO2 price in Europe is down. So  electricity is cheaper than anticipated, we see diesel also down. So, compared to our budget, we assume that  probably on the energy cost, we have an upside of about €60 million as we speak to-date.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Let me now go to the next slide. As we told you in February, we would plan for higher marketing spend. The  organic spend in the first half was 6%, up towards last year, and it goes into an array of initiatives. And I just want  to highlight with you a few of the more important ones, where the money goes to. We have been launching a new  Heineken global campaign around the theme "Open Your World." We have devoted a lot of energy, money, and  time to the activation of the brand here in the UK, launching the campaign but also organizing the Heineken Cup  and the Champions League, which the final was organized here in London, so we kind of painted the city in green  for that weekend.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, this closes our regional overview. I now go through the outlook that we released this morning. The outlook is  basically to say that organically we expect the net profit to come out at the same level as last year. That caution on  the backdrop of rather positive half-year result is motivated essentially by, first of all, weather conditions in  Europe, which has dented quite the sales in Europe – across Europe. Just have to look out of the window; July and  August have not been particularly strong. That has an effect as we go into the second half.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: On a functional level, you see that supply chain remains the largest contributor, €45 million coming from them,  55%. Less this time from brewery closures. We said we are ending the brewery closures. We have closed 47  breweries and maltries in the last 10 years. We are pretty close to the ideal footprint. But we still work on  productivity, and we have savings there. And we work also increasingly on the logistic cost impact of these savings  were made on that side. And for those who were in Zoeterwoude at the supply chain seminar or Investor Day  around supply chain, probably this is not a surprise for you.

file: HEIA - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 22August2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board/CEO, HEINEKEN Holding NV
texts.text: In Western Europe, the challenging economic conditions and unfavorable weather impacted volume. However,  effective marketing and strong marketplace execution drove market share gains in France, the Netherlands and  the UK. Despite the benefit of higher pricing, input cost pressure and lower than planned volumes impacted the  region's profitability, as you can see.

file: HEIA - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 21August2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Thank you, George, and good morning, everyone. Let's begin the presentation. Our volume performance in the  first half was impacted by a number of well documented external factors. In Europe and the U.S., consumer  confidence remained low, and that was exacerbated by unseasonable wet and cold weather.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: In Central and Eastern Europe, weak consumer sentiment and unfavorable weather including extensive flooding  impacted volumes in Russia. The effect of ongoing restrictive legislation continued to effect consumer spending in  the beer category. This led to a high single-digit volume decline in the country in line with the markets.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: In Western Europe, high unemployment and weak consumer sentiment continues to impact consumer spending  in key markets. This together with the unusually cold and wet weather led to beer volumes declining 8% and an  organic operating profit decline of 9%. However, we are committed to winning in this important region and have  solid plans in place to meet these challenges.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: At the same time, we are stepping up our focus on further reducing non-strategic or administrative costs and  further leveraging our skill for efficiencies. As a result, we have identified an additional €100 million of cost  savings under our current three-year TCM2 program, though to the end of – through to the end of 2014, this will  take the total expected savings to €625 million. This follows the earlier realization of cost savings particularly  across raw materials and packaging spend captured by the centralized purchasing group.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Secondly, increased capital expenditure as we continued to invest ahead of the anticipated growth in key  developing markets. Examples of key programs includes the investment in new capacity in countries like Nigeria  and Indonesia, and the renewal of our returnable bottle fleet in Vietnam, Nigeria, and Mexico. We are also  investing in the new greenfield brewery in Ethiopia to capitalize on attractive future gross opportunities in this  market.

file: HEIA - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 20August2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board / CEO, HEINEKEN Holding NV
texts.text: And finally, in Western Europe, our step up in commercial investment is yielding encouraging results leading to  broad-based market share gains in the region. Group volumes were up 6.5%, also reflecting favorable weather and  the positive impact from the football World Cup against a soft comparable period last year.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Member Executive Board / CFO, Heineken NV
texts.text: In July, our new 1.5 million hectoliter brewery in Ethiopia became operational, which will enable us to meet  further growing demand for our brands in that country. We are also investing in new greenfield breweries in  China and Myanmar and expanding capacity in other growth markets such as Nigeria, Vietnam and Indonesia.  For the full year, we therefore still expect a cash conversion ratio of below the 100%, primarily reflecting these  higher capital investments.

file: HEIA - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 3August2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.text: In Western Europe, the Not An Inch Back strategy continues, with cost savings reinvested back into the business  to drive growth. This was the region that, in the first half, faced the toughest comparatives, as it was the main  beneficiary of the weather and football World Cup last year. Volumes in the first half were down 3%, with positive  growth in Spain, France, and The Netherlands, more than offset by the high single-digit decline in the UK.  Revenue per hectoliter was up 0.5% organically, despite deflationary pressure and pricing pressure in the off-trade  in a number of key markets, and most notably, in the UK and France.

file: HEIA - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 1August2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-16.pdf
HEIA - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 31July2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: In Brazil, volume declined high-single digit due to the weak macroeconomic climate and tough trading conditions,  particularly in the value and mainstream segments. However, it is important to highlight that our premium portfolio  led by Heineken delivered double-digit volume growth. In the U.S. volume declined slightly, with Heineken up  slightly but offset by volume decline in our Mexican portfolio, which underperformed the category.

texts.speaker: Jean-François van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Our new partnership with Formula 1 provides an opportunity to access new consumers globally and allows us to  launch a powerful responsible drinking campaign, When You Drive, Never Drink. We have also used this  campaign to successfully promote our Heineken 0.0 variant which we launched in the second quarter.

file: HEIA - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 30July2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: In Mexico, Tecate and Dos Equis grew high-single digit and double-digit respectively, benefiting from strong  execution and effective campaigns. Heineken's largest greenfield in history, the Meoqui brewery, opened in  February 2018 and has started to contribute to the efficiency of our local operations.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: In Europe, consolidated beer volume was slightly down by 0.1%. Net revenue beia per hectoliter was up 1.4%  despite continued off-trade pricing pressure. In the UK, volume declined low-single digit, as the relisting at a large  retailer and good early summer weather helped to partially offset the impact of the cold first quarter and CO2  shortages in June.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Spain declined mid-single digit due to unseasonably cold and rainy weather impacting the on trade. The  Netherlands was marginally down, as we continue to focus on value growth, whilst the market remains promotion  driven in the off trade.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Moving now to slide 7, I would like to share some highlights of our Brewing a Better World agenda. We launched  our new global campaign, When You Drive, Never Drink with Formula 1 World Champion, Nico Rosberg, focusing  on the social pressures surrounding drinking and driving.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: As part of the Drop the C ambition to grow our renewable energy usage to 70% by 2030, several projects were  started to source wind, solar and biomass energy. Part of the investments required will be borne by our partners  as we engage in purchase price agreements. For example, in the Netherlands, we plan to install 21,800, I'm very  precise, solar panels over the next two years.

texts.speaker: Laurence Debroux
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Diluted EPS beia of €1.89 was 3.8% higher than last year. Free operating cash flow grew to €909 million, an  increase of 21.8% driven by improvement in working capital and that's coming mainly from payables. We've told  you in the past that our ambition was to come back to industry average as regards payment terms, as we did feel  that we were treated a bit less favorably, and that is what we are doing without compromising on our long term  relationships with local suppliers or our sustainability agenda. And finally, as you can see at the bottom of this  table, our net-debt-to-EBITDA beia ratio remains stable at 2.5 times, in line with our target.

texts.speaker: Laurence Debroux
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: And we don't call on one-off. There are lots of one-off in any period; positive weather, negative weather, small  things here and there. There have been indeed a few specific events in this first half that are worth mentioning  and the railway strike in France for instance increasing the cost of logistics. Still in France, the provision for a VAT  adjustment on past years. And obviously those one-off did impact our margins.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman – Executive Board

texts.text: 7 improvement of our environmental impact. It’s the empowerment of the people in the communities,  that’s a big basket where we put Medicare, education, agriculture, you name it, and the positive  impact that beer has on society.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman – Executive Board
texts.profession: So, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen for our 2010 Results Presentation. As ever, for those
texts.text: So don’t look at the alcohol producer only at the harmful way, but also at the positive way. Address  the harmful side and also work with the positive way. All these things are quantified, reported from  year-to-year, things like 40% of the reduction of our carbon footprint; 25% water reduction in the  coming 10 years to 3.7 liter per liter beer produced; our commitment to invest further down the line  only in green cooling, think about the hundreds of thousands of fridges or cooling installation that  our 135 breweries across the world are placing in the marketplace, our commitment to make these  cooling techniques and equipment more environmental friendly. Those are only examples of what  we want to do in practice.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman – Executive Board
texts.profession: So, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen for our 2010 Results Presentation. As ever, for those
texts.text: All our senior management will be incentivized on that, i.e. 500 top people at Heineken across the  world will have part of their bonus paid on what they realize on sustainability. It is not based on an  index. It is based on concrete action, because at the end of the day, we believe that sustainability  means business. This is not charity. This is nothing that you want to buy yourself a good name, no.  It is another way, a more sustainable way to make good business in the future. And that is how we  look at it, because at the end of the day, better support to the communities and lesser imprint on  your environment means that you will higher revenue and reduce costs. That’s why we all do it for,  and also, when we look at the new generations who work at Heineken, they expect us to do that  and consumers in the street will vote with their feet, if you as a brand owner, you wouldn’t do it by  the way.

file: HEIA - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 15February2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: We have also dedicated a lot of attention during the year to leverage our global scale. We did that through  investments in commercial capability building, I will give you more details about that during my presentation. We  have established a global business service organization and it's up and running. You will have also more details  about it. And we have launched, at last but not least, a new TCM program called very originally TCM2. And with  the aim over the next three years to deliver €500 million of cost savings and I will also provide you for more detail  about that.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: The U.S., on the backdrop of a market which was in decline, we were even more in decline over the whole year. We  see at the end of the year some green shoots for the Heineken brands. It's early days. We have invested a lot in our  Heineken brand in the U.S over the past year and we will continue to do so. The global brands, the global  campaign for the brand was also introduced there and we see it's gaining some traction and momentum. But in  the U.S we will never surrender. So we will continue to make progress over there. We had again strong  performance of the Dos Equis brand in the U.S. growing again 15% over last year.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: That we do alongside more traditional activation platforms as our sponsorship. The Champions League is an old  one, the Rugby World Cup is another one. We do a lot with local music festivals. We do it in Poland, in Rio and in  the U.K., in Italy. We do it in a number of countries. And we will also sponsor in this country, the London  Olympics where we are dying to come in the summer. So, if we can paint London in green like we did for the  Champions League last year, I think it will be for us again a kind of good leverage to grow the brand further in this  country.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: So this one is not about sun and sea, this one will be about authenticity and free mind. That is a bit how we want  to take it. This is a fresh campaign you can expect more of these in the year to come.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: Brewing a better future is about sustainability. Sustainability is not a hobby, it's not lip service, it's the way we do  business with HEINEKEN. Sustainability is a very simple definition: if you do it on an unsustainable way you're  going to be dead tomorrow, it's just not sustainable.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: So the whole concept of sustainability has to be deeply embedded in how we operate our business across the  world. We have launched a new 10-year program last year, in April 2010, we have set out objectives, our  sustainability report will be published in April, measured against the objectives that we set. The highlights for this  year is that we again consistently delivered on our energy and water targets and that we increased our local raw  material sourcing in Africa to 48%. We have the ambition to go to 60% and itself is the object of a conference what  we do for that. But we really do believe that is the right thing to do also because it creates the necessary economic  activity to continue to develop the country where you operate.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: It's very important for us. It's a long-haul route. It's different and it takes different dimensions because it's a lot of  movie that we released for HEINEKEN, which makes the ultimate point that it is cool not to drink too much.  Ultimately it's the guy who doesn't drink who gets the girl.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Thank you, Jean. It's extremely hot here, I get the feeling. Is it only here on stage? Warm, hot, beer weather; that's  for after the presentation. Yeah, okay, that's it. And what I will do I take you through the figures and I take you  through the main programs TCM 1, now TCM 2 and the hunt for cash.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Look at the input costs, obviously, very important for us in 2011. Total raw and packaging materials accounted for  over €3.6 billion and we had in 2011 a 2.5% increase on an per hectoliter basis, which was in line with the  guidance we gave you at the beginning of last year.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: With the establishments of the global procurement company and the implementation of that company during the  course of this year, we will further leverage our buying skill to drive cost efficiencies. But we also be in a much  better position to hedge certain positions, because you all put it in one basket and you can really start managing  that in a better way.  For 2012, we are covered for around 85% of our needs and the overall expected impact on a per hectoliter basis is  6% and that is mainly driven by malted barley. As you know, the weather conditions as well as the time of the  seeding, as at the time of harvest has not been very favorable in many of the European markets. So prices were  pushed up. Russia has much better crops, but lower quality. And also in the Americas or in Mexico, particularly,  it's not looking too good.

file: HEIA - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 13February2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-13.pdf
HEIA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 12February2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: As I mentioned earlier, we were encouraged by the improved trading performance in a number of our  key markets  in the second half of the year. This follows a soft first-half performance which has negatively impacted – which  was negatively impacted by destocking in France and the U.S., as well as unfavorable weather conditions in  several countries. In Western Europe, we are encouraged by a slight pickup in consumer confidence in a few of our  key markets coinciding with an improvement in lead economic indicators across the region.

texts.speaker: René Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: We are also investing in a new greenfield brewery in Ethiopia and in Myanmar and a soft drink plant in Indonesia  to capitalize on attractive future growth opportunities in these markets. At the same time, we have successfully  deleveraged the balance sheet from a net debt/EBITDA (beia) level of 2.8 times in 2012 immediately after the  acquisition of APB to 2.6 times by the end of last year. And we are on target to achieve our targ et net  debt/EBITDA ratio to below 2.5 times by the end of this year.

file: HEIA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 11February2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.text: In Central, Eastern Europe, unfavorable weather strongly impacted volume in the second and third quarters.  Underlying trading conditions remained challenging in a number of key markets. Revenue per hectoliter  improved 1.4% as a result of our strategic focus on driving value.

file: HEIA - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 10February2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-16.pdf
HEIA - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 15February2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board and Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: In Brazil, volume declined mid-single-digit due to the weak macroeconomic climate and tough trading conditions.  Our premiumization focus continued and Heineken volume was up double-digit, crossing the 2 million hectoliters  mark.

texts.speaker: Laurence Debroux
texts.profession: Member Executive Board and Chief Financial Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Looking at other costs, still on an organic basis, input costs, which is the sum of raw and packaging material  costs, were up 10.8%, growing more than revenue. This is a little bit due to mix, but this year, predominantly, to  transactional currency pressure in Mexico, Brazil, and Nigeria. On the other hand, and still on an organic basis,  personnel costs and logistic costs increased less than revenue due to tight cost control, and repair and  maintenance costs, as well as energy and water costs even decreased.

file: HEIA - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 12February2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean van Boxmeer]
texts.text: We continue to innovate around draught systems, The Sub, our at-home draught system is now available in eight  European markets, and the U.S., and China and is performing well. We also launched The Blade across Europe  this year, which is our proposition to extend the draught experience to small outlets. It is showing promising  results to-date in the 11 markets it was launched. And we also launched the new e-commerce initiatives for both  Business-to-Business and Business-to-Consumer platforms such as for the lager Beerwulf, which is our new Craft  & Variety online business channel for consumers in the Netherlands and we're going to extend that in Europe.

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean van Boxmeer]
texts.text: Moving to slide 8, I would like to update you on our Brewing a Better World agenda. As you see during 2017,  we've made significant progress on our focus areas on sustainability. And for example, we reduced water  consumption in water-stressed area to 3.2 liters of water per liter of beer, down from 3.8 liters in 2014. But we  also surpassed our 2020 targets for CO2 emissions. That's a 41% decline in emissions per hectoliter since 2008.  We aim to reduce this even further and have set new ambitious targets for 2030 with our Drop the C program. I  refer to you to our press release this day for more on this topic.

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean van Boxmeer]
texts.text: If I look at input costs first, raw material and packaging, they saw an organic increase of 4.7% overall and 1.8% on  a per hectoliter basis. This increase includes significant savings achieved through procurement. And with that, we  managed to offset inflation on raw material, but only partially offset significant transactional currency headwinds.

file: HEIA - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 13February2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Our strategic priorities are growth-oriented with an ever-increasing emphasis on sustainability, both socially and  environmentally. We focus on innovation and operational excellence so our consumers enjoy our brands and we  exceed our customers' expectations. At the same time, we keep seeking productivity improvements, and we are  constantly reassessing our spending behavior. Going into 2019, we expect the environment to remain uncertain  and volatile. Overall, we anticipate our operating profit beia to grow by mid-single digits on an organic basis.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Spain declined low single digit due to unseasonably cold and rainy weather in the first half and disappointing  tourism in key regional markets.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Turning to slide 6, and Brewing a Better World, last year we surpassed our 2020 commitment for CO2 emissions  and this year we reduced them further to 5.5 kilogram of CO2 equivalent per hectoliter produced, a 47% decrease  since 2008. This year, we have also surpassed our 2020 ambition on water efficiency. The average water  consumption in our breweries was 3.5 liters of water per liter of beer, a reduction of 30% compared to the same  year of 2008, and it is also 3.2 liters of water per liter of beer in water-stressed areas.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Last February, we announced Drop the C, our 2030 ambition for CO2 reduction aiming to cover 70% of all our  electric and thermal energy needs in production by renewable energy. In 2018, we launched 13 renewable energy  projects and you will find more details in our annual report that will be available next week. We're also aware of  the pressing water issues globally and here we are finalizing a new 2030 ambition which we will announce shortly.  Responsible consumption continues to be a high priority, and in 2018, 69 markets dedicated at least 10% of the  Heineken media spend to Responsible Drinking campaigns.
