HEIO - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 24August2011 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Let me now go to the next slide. As we told you in February, we would plan for higher marketing spend. The  organic spend in the first half was 6%, up towards last year, and it goes into an array of initiatives. And I just want  to highlight with you a few of the more important ones, where the money goes to. We have been launching a new  Heineken global campaign around the theme "Open Your World." We have devoted a lot of energy, money, and  time to the activation of the brand here in the UK, launching the campaign but also organizing the Heineken Cup  and the Champions League, which the final was organized here in London, so we kind of painted the city in green  for that weekend.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, this closes our regional overview. I now go through the outlook that we released this morning. The outlook is  basically to say that organically we expect the net profit to come out at the same level as last year. That caution on  the backdrop of rather positive half-year result is motivated essentially by, first of all, weather conditions in  Europe, which has dented quite the sales in Europe – across Europe. Just have to look out of the window; July and  August have not been particularly strong. That has an effect as we go into the second half.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland, Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: On a functional level, you see that supply chain remains the largest contributor, €45 million coming from them,  55%. Less this time from brewery closures. We said we are ending the brewery closures. We have closed 47  breweries and maltries in the last 10 years. We are pretty close to the ideal footprint. But we still work on  productivity, and we have savings there. And we work also increasingly on the logistic cost impact of these savings  were made on that side. And for those who were in Zoeterwoude at the supply chain seminar or Investor Day  around supply chain, probably this is not a surprise for you.

file: HEIO - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 22August2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board/CEO, HEINEKEN Holding NV
texts.text: In Western Europe, the challenging economic conditions and unfavorable weather impacted volume. However,  effective marketing and strong marketplace execution drove market share gains in France, the Netherlands and  the UK. Despite the benefit of higher pricing, input cost pressure and lower than planned volumes impacted the  region's profitability, as you can see.

file: HEIO - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 21August2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Thank you, George, and good morning, everyone. Let's begin the presentation. Our volume performance in the  first half was impacted by a number of well documented external factors. In Europe and the U.S., consumer  confidence remained low, and that was exacerbated by unseasonable wet and cold weather.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: In Central and Eastern Europe, weak consumer sentiment and unfavorable weather including extensive flooding  impacted volumes in Russia. The effect of ongoing restrictive legislation continued to effect consumer spending in  the beer category. This led to a high single-digit volume decline in the country in line with the markets.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: In Western Europe, high unemployment and weak consumer sentiment continues to impact consumer spending  in key markets. This together with the unusually cold and wet weather led to beer volumes declining 8% and an  organic operating profit decline of 9%. However, we are committed to winning in this important region and have  solid plans in place to meet these challenges.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: At the same time, we are stepping up our focus on further reducing non-strategic or administrative costs and  further leveraging our skill for efficiencies. As a result, we have identified an additional €100 million of cost  savings under our current three-year TCM2 program, though to the end of – through to the end of 2014, this will  take the total expected savings to €625 million. This follows the earlier realization of cost savings particularly  across raw materials and packaging spend captured by the centralized purchasing group.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Secondly, increased capital expenditure as we continued to invest ahead of the anticipated growth in key  developing markets. Examples of key programs includes the investment in new capacity in countries like Nigeria  and Indonesia, and the renewal of our returnable bottle fleet in Vietnam, Nigeria, and Mexico. We are also  investing in the new greenfield brewery in Ethiopia to capitalize on attractive future gross opportunities in this  market.

file: HEIO - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 20August2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman, Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken N.V.
texts.text: And finally, in Western Europe, our step up in commercial investment is yielding encouraging results leading to  broad-based market share gains in the region. Group volumes were up 6.5%, also reflecting favorable weather and  the positive impact from the football World Cup against a soft comparable period last year.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Member Executive Board / CFO, Heineken N.V.
texts.text: In July, our new 1.5 million hectoliter brewery in Ethiopia became operational, which will enable us to meet  further growing demand for our brands in that country. We are also investing in new greenfield breweries in  China and Myanmar and expanding capacity in other growth markets such as Nigeria, Vietnam and Indonesia.  For the full year, we therefore still expect a cash conversion ratio of below the 100%, primarily reflecting these  higher capital investments.

file: HEIO - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 3August2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.text: In Western Europe, the Not An Inch Back strategy continues, with cost savings reinvested back into the business  to drive growth. This was the region that, in the first half, faced the toughest comparatives, as it was the main  beneficiary of the weather and football World Cup last year. Volumes in the first half were down 3%, with positive  growth in Spain, France, and The Netherlands, more than offset by the high single-digit decline in the UK.  Revenue per hectoliter was up 0.5% organically, despite deflationary pressure and pricing pressure in the off-trade  in a number of key markets, and most notably, in the UK and France.

file: HEIO - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 1August2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-16.pdf
HEIO - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 31July2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Heineken Holding NV
texts.text: In Brazil, volume declined high-single digit due to the weak macroeconomic climate and tough trading conditions,  particularly in the value and mainstream segments. However, it is important to highlight that our premium portfolio  led by Heineken delivered double-digit volume growth. In the U.S. volume declined slightly, with Heineken up  slightly but offset by volume decline in our Mexican portfolio, which underperformed the category.

texts.speaker: Jean-François van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Heineken Holding NV
texts.text: Our new partnership with Formula 1 provides an opportunity to access new consumers globally and allows us to  launch a powerful responsible drinking campaign, When You Drive, Never Drink. We have also used this  campaign to successfully promote our Heineken 0.0 variant which we launched in the second quarter.

file: HEIO - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 30July2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean-François van Boxmeer]
texts.text: In Mexico, Tecate and Dos Equis grew high-single digit and double-digit respectively, benefiting from strong  execution and effective campaigns. Heineken's largest greenfield in history, the Meoqui brewery, opened in  February 2018 and has started to contribute to the efficiency of our local operations.

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean-François van Boxmeer]
texts.text: In Europe, consolidated beer volume was slightly down by 0.1%. Net revenue beia per hectoliter was up 1.4%  despite continued off-trade pricing pressure. In the UK, volume declined low-single digit, as the relisting at a large  retailer and good early summer weather helped to partially offset the impact of the cold first quarter and CO2  shortages in June.

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean-François van Boxmeer]
texts.text: Spain declined mid-single digit due to unseasonably cold and rainy weather impacting the on trade. The  Netherlands was marginally down, as we continue to focus on value growth, whilst the market remains promotion  driven in the off trade.

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean-François van Boxmeer]
texts.text: Moving now to slide 7, I would like to share some highlights of our Brewing a Better World agenda. We launched  our new global campaign, When You Drive, Never Drink with Formula 1 World Champion, Nico Rosberg, focusing  on the social pressures surrounding drinking and driving.

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean-François van Boxmeer]
texts.text: As part of the Drop the C ambition to grow our renewable energy usage to 70% by 2030, several projects were  started to source wind, solar and biomass energy. Part of the investments required will be borne by our partners  as we engage in purchase price agreements. For example, in the Netherlands, we plan to install 21,800, I'm very  precise, solar panels over the next two years.

texts.speaker: Laurence Debroux
texts.text: Diluted EPS beia of €1.89 was 3.8% higher than last year. Free operating cash flow grew to €909 million, an  increase of 21.8% driven by improvement in working capital and that's coming mainly from payables. We've told  you in the past that our ambition was to come back to industry average as regards payment terms, as we did feel  that we were treated a bit less favorably, and that is what we are doing without compromising on our long term  relationships with local suppliers or our sustainability agenda. And finally, as you can see at the bottom of this  table, our net-debt-to-EBITDA beia ratio remains stable at 2.5 times, in line with our target.

texts.speaker: Laurence Debroux
texts.text: And we don't call on one-off. There are lots of one-off in any period; positive weather, negative weather, small  things here and there. There have been indeed a few specific events in this first half that are worth mentioning  and the railway strike in France for instance increasing the cost of logistics. Still in France, the provision for a VAT  adjustment on past years. And obviously those one-off did impact our margins.

texts.profession: So, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen for our 2010 Results Presentation. As ever, for those
texts.text: So don’t look at the alcohol producer only at the harmful way, but also at the positive way. Address  the harmful side and also work with the positive way. All these things are quantified, reported from  year-to-year, things like 40% of the reduction of our carbon footprint; 25% water reduction in the  coming 10 years to 3.7 liter per liter beer produced; our commitment to invest further down the line  only in green cooling, think about the hundreds of thousands of fridges or cooling installation that  our 135 breweries across the world are placing in the marketplace, our commitment to make these  cooling techniques and equipment more environmental friendly. Those are only examples of what  we want to do in practice.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman – Executive Board
texts.profession: So, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen for our 2010 Results Presentation. As ever, for those
texts.text: All our senior management will be incentivized on that, i.e. 500 top people at Heineken across the  world will have part of their bonus paid on what they realize on sustainability. It is not based on an  index. It is based on concrete action, because at the end of the day, we believe that sustainability  means business. This is not charity. This is nothing that you want to buy yourself a good name, no.  It is another way, a more sustainable way to make good business in the future. And that is how we  look at it, because at the end of the day, better support to the communities and lesser imprint on  your environment means that you will higher revenue and reduce costs. That’s why we all do it for,  and also, when we look at the new generations who work at Heineken, they expect us to do that  and consumers in the street will vote with their feet, if you as a brand owner, you wouldn’t do it by  the way.

file: HEIO - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 15February2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: We have also dedicated a lot of attention during the year to leverage our global scale. We did that through  investments in commercial capability building, I will give you more details about that during my presentation. We  have established a global business service organization and it's up and running. You will have also more details  about it. And we have launched at last, but not least a new TCM program called very originally TCM2 and with the  aim over the next three years to deliver €500 million of cost savings and I will also provide you for more detail  about that.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: The U.S., on the backdrop of a market which was in decline, we were even more in decline over the whole year. We  see at the end of the year some green shoots for the Heineken brands. It's early days. We have invested a lot in our  Heineken brand in the U.S over the past year and we will continue to do so. The global brands, the global  campaign for the brand was also introduced there and we see it's gaining some traction and momentum, but in the  U.S we will near surrender. So we will continue to make progress over there. We had again strong performance of  the Dos Equis brand in the U.S growing again 15% over last year.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: That we do alongside more traditional activation platforms as our sponsorship. The Champions League is an old  one, the Rugby World Cup is another one. We do a lot with local music festivals. We do it in Poland, in Rio and in  the U.K., in Italy. We do it in a number of countries and we will also sponsor in this country, the London Olympics  where we are dying to come in the summer. So, if we can paint London in green like we did for the Champions  League last year, I think it will be for us again a kind of good leverage to grow the brand further in this country.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: Brewing a better future is about sustainability, sustainability is not a hobby, it's not lip surface, it's the way we do  business with HEINEKEN, sustainability is a very simple definition, if you do it on an unsustainable way you're  going to be dead tomorrow, it's just not sustainable.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.text: So the whole concept of sustainability has to be deeply embedded in how we operate our business across the  world. We have launched a new 10-year program last year in – or in 2000 – in April 2010, we have set out  objectives, our sustainability report will be published in April, measured against the objectives that we set. The  highlights for this year is that we again consistently delivered on our energy and water targets and that we  increased our local raw material sourcing in Africa to 48%. We have the ambition to go to 60% and itself is the  object of a conference what we do for that, but we really do believe that is the right thing to do also because it  creates the necessary economic activity to continue to develop the country where you operate.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Thank you, Jean. It's extremely hot here, I get the feeling. Is it only here on stage, warm, hot, beer weather that's  for after the presentation. Yeah, okay, that's it. And what I will do I take you through the figures and I take you  through the main programs TCM 1, now TCM 2 and hunt for cash.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: Look at the inputs costs, obviously, very important for us in 2011. Total raw and packaging materials accounted  for €3.6 billion or over €3.6 billion and we had in 2011 a 2.5% increase on an – per hectoliter basis, which was in  line with the guidance we gave you at the beginning of last year.

texts.speaker: Reinout Duco Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: For 2012, we are covered for 85%, around 85% of our needs and the overall expected impact on a per hectoliter  basis is 6% and that is mainly driven by malted barley. As you know, the weather conditions as well as the time of  pushed up. Russia has much better crops, but lower quality and also in the Americas or in Mexico, particularly, it's  not looking too good.

file: HEIO - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 13February2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-13.pdf
HEIO - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 12February2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, HEINEKEN Holding NV
texts.text: As I mentioned earlier, we were encouraged by the improved trading performance in a number of our key markets  in the second half of the year. This follows a soft first-half performance which has negatively impacted – which  was negatively impacted by destocking in France and the U.S., as well as unfavorable weather conditions in  several countries. In Western Europe, we are encouraged by a slight pickup in consumer confidence in a few of our  key markets coinciding with an improvement in lead economic indicators across the region.

texts.speaker: René Hooft Graafland
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Heineken NV
texts.text: We are also investing in a new greenfield brewery in Ethiopia and in Myanmar and a soft drink plant in Indonesia  to capitalize on attractive future growth opportunities in these markets. At the same time, we have successfully  deleveraged the balance sheet from a net debt/EBITDA (beia) level of 2.8 times in 2012 immediately after the  acquisition of APB to 2.6 times by the end of last year. And we are on target to achieve our target net  debt/EBITDA ratio to below 2.5 times by the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman, Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Central Eastern Europe, unfavorable weather strongly impacted volume in the second and third quarters.  Underlying trading conditions remained challenging in a number of key markets. Revenue per hectoliter  improved 1.4%, as a result of our strategy focused on driving value.

texts.speaker: Jean-François van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board and Chief Executive Officer, Heineken Holding NV
texts.text: In Brazil, volume declined mid-single-digit due to the weak macroeconomic climate and tough trading conditions.  Our premiumization focus continued and Heineken volume was up double-digit, crossing the 2 million hectoliters  mark.

texts.speaker: Laurence Debroux
texts.profession: Member Executive Board and Chief Financial Officer, Heineken Holding NV
texts.text: Looking at other costs, still on an organic basis, input costs, which is the sum of raw and packaging material  costs, were up 10.8%, growing more than revenue. This is a little bit due to mix, but this year, predominantly, to  transactional currency pressure in Mexico, Brazil, and Nigeria. On the other hand, and still on an organic basis,  personnel costs and logistic costs increased less than revenue due to tight cost control, and repair and  maintenance costs, as well as energy and water costs even decreased.

file: HEIO - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 12February2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean van Boxmeer]
texts.text: We continue to innovate around draught systems, The Sub, our at-home draught system is now available in eight  European markets, and the U.S., and China and is performing well. We also launched The Blade across Europe  this year, which is our proposition to extend the draught experience to small outlets. It is showing promising  results to-date in the 11 markets it was launched. And we also launched the new e-commerce initiatives for both  Business-to-Business and Business-to-Consumer platforms such as for the lager Beerwulf, which is our new Craft  & Variety online business channel for consumers in the Netherlands and we're going to extend that in Europe.

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean van Boxmeer]
texts.text: Moving to slide 8, I would like to update you on our Brewing a Better World agenda. As you see during 2017,  we've made significant progress on our focus areas on sustainability. And for example, we reduced water  consumption in water-stressed area to 3.2 liters of water per liter of beer, down from 3.8 liters in 2014. But we  also surpassed our 2020 targets for CO2 emissions. That's a 41% decline in emissions per hectoliter since 2008.  We aim to reduce this even further and have set new ambitious targets for 2030 with our Drop the C program. I  refer to you to our press release this day for more on this topic.

texts.speaker: [067VBW-E Jean van Boxmeer]
texts.text: If I look at input costs first, raw material and packaging, they saw an organic increase of 4.7% overall and 1.8% on  a per hectoliter basis. This increase includes significant savings achieved through procurement. And with that, we  managed to offset inflation on raw material, but only partially offset significant transactional currency headwinds.

file: HEIO - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 13February2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Our strategic priorities are growth-oriented with an ever-increasing emphasis on sustainability, both socially and  environmentally. We focus on innovation and operational excellence so our consumers enjoy our brands and we  exceed our customers' expectations. At the same time, we keep seeking productivity improvements, and we are  constantly reassessing our spending behavior. Going into 2019, we expect the environment to remain uncertain  and volatile. Overall, we anticipate our operating profit beia to grow by mid-single digits on an organic basis.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Spain declined low single digit due to unseasonably cold and rainy weather in the first half and disappointing  tourism in key regional markets.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Turning to slide 6, and Brewing a Better World, last year we surpassed our 2020 commitment for CO2 emissions  and this year we reduced them further to 5.5 kilogram of CO2 equivalent per hectoliter produced, a 47% decrease  since 2008. This year, we have also surpassed our 2020 ambition on water efficiency. The average water  consumption in our breweries was 3.5 liters of water per liter of beer, a reduction of 30% compared to the same  year of 2008, and it is also 3.2 liters of water per liter of beer in water-stressed areas.

texts.speaker: Jean-François M. L. van Boxmeer
texts.profession: Chairman Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Heineken NV
texts.text: Last February, we announced Drop the C, our 2030 ambition for CO2 reduction aiming to cover 70% of all our  electric and thermal energy needs in production by renewable energy. In 2018, we launched 13 renewable energy  projects and you will find more details in our annual report that will be available next week. We're also aware of  the pressing water issues globally and here we are finalizing a new 2030 ambition which we will announce shortly.  Responsible consumption continues to be a high priority, and in 2018, 69 markets dedicated at least 10% of the  Heineken media spend to Responsible Drinking campaigns.

The reinsurance result, which is  also reported in the segment was better than the previous year, mainly because of the more effective management  of currency risks. Thanks to a very cautious underwriting policy in Asia [ph] Oceania (0:13:44) and the US, as well  as efficient reinsurance cover, our reinsurance unit was hardly affected by the major natural catastrophes in 2011.  The net decline in the result of the corporate segment is explained by positive currency effects in the previous year  and from the facts mentioned before.

texts.speaker: Stefan Loacker
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Helvetia Holding AG
texts.text: As illustrated in slide nine, the non-life technical performance remains very solid. As mentioned before, Germany  is the only market reporting a combined ratio of more than 100%. Due to the higher burden of claims, the net  combined ratio rose by 1.5 percentage points to 95.6%, which is still within the target range. The claims ratio is  2.5% higher than the previous year. Of this percentage, 1.8% net and 2.1% gross can be attributed to weather- related claims.

texts.speaker: Philipp Gmür
texts.profession: Member-Group Executive Management, Helvetia Holding AG
texts.text: The net combined ratio of 86% reflects an excellent technical result in spite of a slightly higher claims burden than  in the previous year and underlines the good quality of our insurance portfolio. The year-on-year increase in the  loss ratio of more than 4 percentage points is due to hail and storm damage in the summer months. We  successfully managed, however, to reduce the cost ratio further to 26.4% in spite of the integration cost incurred  with the purchase of Alba and Phenix. This can be attributed to strong premium growth and consistent cost  discipline.

texts.speaker: Stefan Loacker
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Helvetia Holding AG
texts.text: Another example I would like to point out is being achieved in Italy where you probably know that we have, since  a couple of years, a so called roadside marketing collaboration with the industrial group Eni. It's a very big  company, some 40,000 employees. We always thought that we can multiply this concept with other big groups  and we have now, successfully, have reached an agreement with AgustaWestland, which is a helicopter  manufacturer and Terna, which is also a company in the energy sector. Both together will give us direct access to  another 7,000 employees and their families again, in a very convenient and service-driven model.

texts.speaker: Stefan Loacker
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Helvetia Holding AG
texts.text: In the medium term, we will nevertheless continue to pursue all our financial objectives without change even in  the given economic climate. With the planned measures derived from our existing strategy and the introduction of  additional steps, particularly also in Germany, we will continue to consistently work towards improving our  earning power. We are confident that Helvetia will develop profitably in the present challenging situation.

texts.text: In 2010, we launched our new vision and values. This is the last time I'll call them new, but they articulate to  culture we're trying to drive into our company. And that is important for us to build a very competitive culture. We  launched our new sustainability strategy a year ago because the target we have set ourselves for sustainability for  2012 we hit in 2010. That's why we launched a new strategy. That means today, I will not be speaking about our  sustainability strategy. We did that early on this year.

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: And in Adhesive division, we'll continue to what we call our design partnership model. That means whether it's  automotive, aerospace or electronics, we design unique solutions for our customers in one locations of the world  and execute that in a different location. Let me give you an example of I experienced three weeks ago when I was  out in California meeting with our electronics division. All of you are working with tabs whether it's iPads or  Nexus. What you feel is when you put it on the lap is that's actually the heat is too big.

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: We've now developed a shelter the basically you put inside and that it absorbs and also distribute the heat that was  developed in California. Right now, we're working with all the manufacturers in Asia to get that deployed. That is  what we mean about partnership design. We go in and design specific solutions in one location and deploy them  globally. This solution I just mentioned is of course also IP protected.

file: HEN3 - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 12November2013 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Carsten Knobel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, EVP-Finance & Purchasing, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: What are the reasons behind for this very good development? First of all, cost reduction measures, which we  continued; optimization of our efficiency in supply chain and production; continuous portfolio optimization,  especially in our adhesive sector; and finally also, slightly lower prices for our total direct material.

file: HEN3 - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 11November2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.text: We saw organic sales growth across all business groups. The Emerging Markets remained strong and Western  Europe was positive. Western Europe was predominantly driven by a very strong Germany, the strongest growth  in Germany since 2012. We saw solid improvement in our adjusted EBIT margin supported by all business groups  and we saw strong growth in our adjusted earnings per share. We also finalized acquisition of our Bergquist  Company in the U.S., which will strengthen our position in the electronics market and address a new market  segment that we're not in to so far the thermal management part which is the heat that you feel when you do  surfing on your smartphones. Bergquist Company is the leader in this on a global basis.

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.text: On the innovation, we see innovation in a number of areas, whether it's product innovation in the Packaging area,  whether it's supplier innovation with suppliers driving new raw materials into our business, or whether it's in  thermal management solutions and this is The Bergquist. We're quite excited about The Bergquist acquisition,  which is a company with more than 1,100 employees, are leaders in thermal management solutions, based in  Minneapolis in the U.S. and is an extension to our electronics business, which we're very committed to continue to  build. It's a very attractive business not only short term but also long term with very attractive margins. So, a good  extension to our electronics business and right in the core of what we're trying to do as a company of delivering  superior innovation and technology to our customers and, thereby, also allowing superior margins to be created.

texts.speaker: Carsten Knobel
texts.profession: Executive Vice President - Finance (Chief Financial Officer), Purchasing & Integrated Business Solutions
texts.text: So, overall, a solid performance within the challenges we're facing especially in the environment of the markets.

file: HEN3 - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 11November2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.text: On the innovation side, let me just mention an investment that we done with DropWise Technologies, which is a  U.S. based company that's focusing on developing of unique hydrophobic coating technologies. And we invested in  this company because we believe it will give us competitive edge move forward. So, not only do we focus on  innovation internally but, of course, we also invest in other companies that can help us make a jump in new  technologies in order to make sure that we continue to be the leader in adhesive technologies globally.

texts.speaker: Carsten Knobel
texts.profession: Executive Vice President - Finance (Chief Financial Officer), Purchasing & Integrated Business Solutions
texts.text: What are the reasons behind? The majority three to mention: first of all, the execution of saving measures or cost  reduction measures; secondly, our continuous improvement in our production and supply efficiency set up; and  thirdly, also lower prices for our total direct materials, which had the positive impact. So, especially with the  material cost impact, we could compensate the transactional impacts which we have already disclosed to you  already at the end of last year, especially in Russia and the Ukraine, where we could compensate certain effects.

file: HEN3 - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 8November2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: I will give you now some highlights regarding Adhesive Technologies. Our Transport & Metal business showed  very strong growth in the quarter. We achieved strong growth in the segment of Metal Containers & Cans. Our  innovative and sustainable solutions under the Bonderite brand strengthened our position as the market leader. In  Consumer Packaging, our business with major customers delivered a good growth, thanks to our technologies  and products for packaging and labeling under the TECHNOMELT brand, we expanded our global market leader  position. Also Electronics had a very strong quarter supported by the excellent performance and increased market  share of our Consumer Electronics business. In this segment, we are the leading supplier of innovative materials  for major smartphone manufacturers.

file: HEN3 - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 14November2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Let me highlight some examples among the initiatives that contributed to the Q3 performance of Adhesive  Technologies. In the sports and fashion business, we achieved double-digit growth, driven by our high-impact  solutions from multinational sports and lifestyle brands. Our brand portfolio of Loctite adhesives enable our  customers to enhance the efficiency in manufacturing while increasing sustainability. In the construction industry,  we delivered double-digit growth in Eastern Europe. The successful launch of fiber-forced tile adhesives  under  the Ceresit brand supported this development. In the industrial assembly business, we achieved double-digit  growth, driven by strong new business developed with customized solutions. Our innovative Loctite adhesives  solutions for broadband cables responds to the increasing demand.

texts.speaker: Carsten Knobel
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Finance (Chief Financial Officer), Purchasing & Integrated Business Solutions, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: So, excluding the acquisition, the adjusted gross margin would have been at 47.9%. This is 90 basis points below  the prior year. This decline is driven by a continued headwind from higher Darex material prices that impacts, in  particular, Adhesive Technologies and Laundry & Home Care. Additionally, and Hans pointed it out, we were  confronted with several force majeures also related to the natural disasters but we're able to limit their impact,  thanks to the extraordinary efforts of our local teams. In the bottom line, nevertheless, they showed a certain  impact on the gross margin. Despite these headwinds, we were able to further increase our adjusted EBIT  margin.

file: HEN3 - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 15November2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Let me highlight some examples among the initiatives that contribute to the continued strong performance of  Adhesive Technologies. We achieved significant growth in high impact solutions for industrial maintenance. For  example, our efficient solutions for the repair and overhaul of pipes and machine help our customers to save  costs while at the same time ensuring high safety and performance [indiscernible] (00:06:19).

file: HEN3 - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 24February2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Oliver Luckenbach, Vice President-Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our Full Year 2010 Analyst and Investor
texts.text: In 2007, we decided upon in early 2008 to set a set of sustainability targets for our business for  2012. It has been in our sustainability report in the last three years, you can see that in the reports.  What I did want to do today was just give you a brief update on, and let you know that we are  ahead of plan, and we’ve actually reached the target we set ourselves for 2012, when it comes to  sustainability.

texts.speaker: Oliver Luckenbach, Vice President-Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our Full Year 2010 Analyst and Investor
texts.text: These targets were set before our financial targets in 2008. And I do think it shows one thing that is  very important: that sustainability performance and financial performance go hand-in-hand. We  have a made a tremendous step forward in our financial performance, and in parallel we’ve also  made a tremendous step forward in our performance in sustainability. What we will be doing is that  we will be defining our new set of targets for sustainability moving forward. They will be defined this  year and probably communicated next year beyond 2012. You can read details of our current  performance in the sustainability report, which you have on your table along with the annual report.  So you’ll get the next set of sustainability targets probably before you get the next set of financial  targets.

texts.speaker: Oliver Luckenbach, Vice President-Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our Full Year 2010 Analyst and Investor
texts.text: We continue to see very strong increases in raw material cost. But I’ve taken three other raw materials out, so  when we say that the crude oil is still below 2008 level, three crucial materials or raw materials that  we are using are currently above the 2008 level. And of course these are challenges that we need  to overcome. We learned a lot in 2008 of how to overcome it; we need to make certain that we  push price increases through the market as quickly as possible and further drive efficiency gains  within the organization.

file: HEN3 - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 8March2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: We continued to see double-digit growth in the emerging markets, despite the very difficult conditions,  particularly in Middle East in the beginning of the year and in Thailand by the end of the year. We have a strong  financial discipline, which you see our balance sheet. We announced our new sustainability strategy that we'll  execute upon throughout 2012 and beyond. Overall, we laid the foundation for the performance that we will be  expecting in 2012.

texts.speaker: Lothar Steinebach
texts.profession: CFO, Executive VP-Information Technology & Legal, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Adhesives has experienced a decline pretty much because of what happened in Asia Pacific, out of which was  influenced by the natural disaster in Japan, which we were able to, I guess, compensate during most of the year,  but not completely.  From that perspective, expectation for 2012 is obviously significantly better also in our  electronic adhesives sub-segment.

texts.speaker: Lothar Steinebach
texts.profession: CFO, Executive VP-Information Technology & Legal, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Looking at operating performance by business unit, Laundry & Home Care, Cosmetics/Toiletries and Adhesive  Technologies. Starting with Laundry & Home Care, 20 basis points. Efficiency gains and cost control together with  our price increases have overcompensated impact from high increases in raw material prices.

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: We have announced our new sustainability strategy last year and we are in the process of implementing that  internally and externally. We have moved the majority of our infrastructure to the emerging market, with 54% of  all employees by now employed in the emerging markets with a sales share of 42%. So we have proactively moved  our employees to the emerging market, which has a very positive impact also on our cost structure. And we have  30% of females in management positions. We continue to have business potential customers and global team at  the focus and we still believe there's substantial room for improvement.

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: I also mentioned our new sustainability strategy, which in essence, is becoming three times more efficient with the  same footprint, Factor 3, announced last year, is in the implementation.

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: We have a great bench across the board and spend a lot of time developing our people to ensure that we can  deliver the numbers. We have a very clear vision and a set of values that we're building our business around. We  have a new sustainability strategy and we've been working now diligently for nine months on our strategy beyond  2012.

file: HEN3 - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 6March2013 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: We've also moved our manufacturing footprint to the emerging markets. We have a net reduction of plants of  more than 60. But we're today, fewer plants, larger plants and, most importantly, the plant where the future [ph]  of Henkel (24:31) will be.

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: We've also continued to optimize our portfolio. We invested more than €4 billion in our portfolio over the last four  target set for 2012. We hit those targets in 2010. We have defined a new sustainability strategy built around what  we call Factor 3. On our customer focus, we have a much more intimate customer relationship today. We know  personally all our large customers. And we've built very close collaboration with a number of partners, particularly  industry partners, where our global presence is a significant competitive advantage for us.

file: HEN3 - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 20February2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: On our Beauty Care business, we saw solid organic sales growth. Retail remains solid. And Hair Salon, for the  year, negative. So Hair Salon is heavily impacted by the economic climate in Western Europe whereas Retail  remains solid. The emerging markets OSG was very strong and we saw the growth in mature markets remain  positive.

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: We are very focused on sustainable savings from ongoing efficiency measures. And we spoke about that where you  can see we continue to develop the model within Henkel. Carsten spoke about that when it comes to our [ph] prior  (37 :54) change structure that we're now taking into account.

file: HEN3 - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 4March2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.text: And in our Adhesive business, we acquired The Bergquist Company, the leader in thermal management systems,  so the distribution of heat generated by processors in the electronics industry. Electronics industry can be  consumer electronics, of course, business electronics or automotive or aerospace. This will help expand our  position in the overall electronics market, which is very attractive not only from a growth standpoint, but also  profitability standpoint. So we believe we have invested actively in very attractive acquisitions with very attractive  P&Ls that will help the company moving forward, not only towards 2016, but also beyond.

file: HEN3 - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 25February2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Kasper B. Rorsted
texts.text: So what do we look upon and what do we describe in the environment? I tried to do it before on the macro. We see  consistent geopolitical tensions and political risks and we don't expect any improvement in our trading conditions,  particularly in Eastern Europe and the Middle East, for the year. We see moderate [ph] and continuous (41:42)  global GDP growth, as I said, around the 2.8% versus 2.5% last year. We see high volatility up and down in some  of the key currencies, but also a lower crude oil price, which has a positive impact on our raw materials.

file: HEN3 - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 23February2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: In the Electronic Industry, our Thermal Management solutions acquired with Bergquist in 2014 delivered  continued growth. Superior innovations from improved performance of consumer electronic devices and  automotive electronics contributed to the successful development.

texts.speaker: Hans Van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Somat shows very strong growth driven by the launch of Somat Phosphate-free in automatic dishwashing.  Patented formula combines sustainability with 100% performance. The innovation was launched in 30 countries in  Western and Eastern Europe.

texts.speaker: Hans Van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: In addition, we aim to promote sustainability in all our business activities, reinforcing our leading positions in the  future. We want to continue to advance our portfolio with value adding acquisitions. In summary, we have a very  clear and exciting growth strategy going forward. And we will bring this strategy to life with our four clear strategic  priorities.

file: HEN3 - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 22February2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Carsten Knobel
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Finance (Chief Financial Officer), Purchasing & Integrated Business Solutions, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: The project ONE!ViEW, the Henkel approach of zero-based budgeting started in 2017 and already delivered a  significant contribution in efficiency. I highlighted that especially in regard to our marketing, selling and distribution  expenses. And as related an approach to non-personnel costs, we have more than 120 initiatives underway to  increase our efficiency with the new cost structure.

texts.speaker: Hans Van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: We are fully committed to continue our successful development in the future. We want to generate sustainable  profitable growth through 2020 and beyond. To achieve this, we are becoming more customer-focused, more  innovative, more agile and fully digitized in our internal processes and our customer facing activities. In addition,  we are aiming to promote sustainability in all our business activities, reinforcing our leading positions in the future.  We continue to advance our portfolio with value-adding acquisitions. In summary, we have a very clear and  exciting growth strategy going forward.

file: HEN3 - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 21February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Management Board, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: In the automotive electronic business, we achieved double-digit growth, driven by our innovative solutions, for  example, in thermal heat management. Our advanced materials enable our customers to further innovate in the  areas of connectivity, e-Mobility, and autonomous driving.

texts.speaker: Carsten Knobel
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Finance (Chief Financial Officer), Purchasing & Integrated Business Solutions, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Also in Laundry & Home Care, we profited from higher prices and in both consumer goods businesses. We  implemented further saving initiative. However, we could only partially compensate for increasing direct material  prices and that particular impacted our Laundry & Home Care business.

texts.speaker: Hans van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Management Board, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Last but not least, we continued our focus on cost discipline and efficiency on our fund growth initiative.  Combined, we expect these initiatives to deliver more than €500 million in annual efficiency gains as of 2020. In  2018, Henkel has already realized more than 50% of the targeted total efficiency gains.

texts.speaker: Hans van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Management Board, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Today, we would like to provide more details behind some key initiatives. In Adhesive Technologies, we create  value through our transformative solutions, leveraging mega trends such as mobility, connectivity and  sustainability. These mega trends result in plenty of growth opportunities for us, further expanding our positions in  attractive markets by offering solutions, addressing specific innovation trend.

texts.speaker: Hans van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Management Board, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Looking at the growth driver mobility, we see for example a huge potential in the strong electric mobility trend, the  progress in autonomous driving and the increased use of lightweight materials. Connectivity is another mega  trend. This means for us business potential and a supply for mobile devices, the Internet of Things and digital  infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Hans van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Management Board, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Thirdly, we see huge trends towards more sustainable solutions. Here, we support our customers with innovations  for renewable feedstocks and efficient production and developing towards a circular economy. We are looking  forward to explain our approach to you in more detail at our Investor and Analyst Day on July 2 in Düsseldorf.

texts.speaker: Hans van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Management Board, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: We also aim to accelerate our strong momentum in hair coloration which achieved a very strong organic sales  growth of more than 5% in 2018. As we speak, we are launching OnlyLove in Western European markets our new  coloration brand with an eco-certified formula free from ammonia, silicone and alcohol and these are only a few  examples of a full-fledged innovation program we are executing across our entire hair portfolio.

texts.speaker: Hans van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Management Board, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Second, we're launching major cap initiatives, the fastest growing segment in the heavy duty detergent market.  The new Persil DISCS, which were the first ever four-chamber cap in the market, come with a patented  technology and unique enzyme blend, a clear winner in consumer use tests. We're also expanding our strongly  growing eCommerce business with fully eCommerce-ready packaging and hyper-concentrated formulas for  optimized logistics, better sustainability, and strong performance.

texts.speaker: Hans van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Management Board, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: In our Home Care business, we focus on our core brands to strengthen our profitable growth path. We will launch  our superior Somat All-in-1 Auto Dishwashing Gel for powerful cleaning in order to strengthen our leadership in  the fast-growing gel segment. Already today, we have a strong portfolio of toiletry [indiscernible] (00:39:47) which  are successfully distributed in 66 countries globally. We continue to roll out new Bref Scent Switch, which got off a  very promising start and introduce further variants with DeLuxe perfumes. Third, we are capturing the strong  sustainability trend under the Pro Nature line. We will launch new variants across all our major Home Care brands  based on eco-certified formulas and a sustainable plastic strategy.

texts.speaker: Hans van Bylen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Management Board, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA
texts.text: Building on our strong foundation, we are strongly committed to continue executing our strategy Henkel 2020+  and to deliver on our ambitions thus generating sustainable profitable growth and attractive returns. We generate  profitable growth and attractive returns, we continuously become more customer-focused, more innovative and  more agile. We strive to lead a digital transformation in all our business activities. Moreover, we promote  sustainability across the entire value chain. And last but not least, we continuously advance our portfolio with  value-adding acquisitions.

file: HER - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 13May2010 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Just two figures. We had an increase in our customer base in the energy sector, which compared to  last year is up 30,000 customers. But what is even more interesting to you, given the attention paid  this issue last year, was the significant recovery we had in the waste business, where the volumes  of special waste which was managed went up 13% compared to last year. And overall, in the waste  business, also including urban waste, we increased figures by 16%. And these are two very strong  figures which prove our capacity to increase our plant portfolio, and it also underlines the  commercial efforts made, as we had promised last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: As far as our plants are concerned, we are currently focusing on two initiatives. The first, which you  are aware of, is the completion of the Rimini waste-to-energy plant, which as you know is the last of  the major plants in our territory that we had programmed a few years ago. And I am pleased to say  that we will be fully compliant with the June deadline to start operations in the new plant, as we had  already illustrated.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The second plant we are working on is an important Biomass plant, which will be on-stream  beginning next year. We are already making our first experiments, and therefore this is another  area that we are focusing on a great deal.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Let’s go into the figures. Concerning revenues we have had a contraction, which is basically due to  two very well-known factors. The first of which is the decrease in commodity prices, which is a  general figure. And the second is a specific figure, given the fact that in the electricity trading sector  we had conditions which forced us to reduce our trading activities equal to a €180 million compared  to the previous year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of EBITDA, we had a significant growth. We have a plus 11% vis-à-vis 2009, which as I  was saying is basically due to our organic growth and all of its components, and which also can be  seen in the EBITDA margin also vis-à-vis the reduction in the electricity trading margin, and  therefore the EBITDA margin grew to 17.1%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We also have figures which are due to the seasonal nature of the gas business, and therefore they  were due to the positive business we had in the gas sector, again also due to seasonal nature and  the harsh winter we had which allowed consumption to increase. In terms of pre-tax profit, we have  plus 9.4% growth, and in terms of net income post minorities growth is equal to 5.8%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: These are the fundamental figures. We need to add the – some figures concerning the majority of  this growth in terms of drivers. As I was saying, €14 million derives from synergy and organic  growth, tariffs for the regulated businesses, volume increase and market expansion, and as I  already mentioned we also had a cold winter which increased consumption. This happened in the  gas business and also in district heating.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The remaining part of the EBIT growth is due to the contribution made by the last two plants which  were activated. The Imola cogeneration plant, which certainly Mr. Venier will be talking about, and  the Modena waste-to-energy plant, which together brought about an increase equal to €4.5 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of the various – there are no significant differences in the business contributions, besides  underlining the fact that the waste business grew compared to the previous years. We had an  increase from 25% to 28.2%, which is equal to the importance that this business had in the past  and that it will continue having in our results.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Stefano Venier, Development & Market General Department  Good evening. As usual we’ll begin by the waste business, which as you may remember is  managed by Herambiente for waste management and for waste collection. As the Chairman was  already mentioning, in this sector we had an important growth equal to €10 million in terms of the  revenue in Q1. We also had a significant growth in terms of the percentage profitability, which  increased by 3%. This is also the factor or the consequence of the increased volume, which was  managed in the waste-to-energy plants, which as you can see in the lower left hand graph grew by  25,000 tons, and which will allow us to manage figures above 800,000 tons.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: This activity was also supported by an increase in volumes, which happened in the growth in  special waste, which was up 13% compared to the previous year, and which in overall terms  reached the levels of the first quarter of 2008, meaning that we are really able to offset the effects  of the crisis. And we also had an increase in urban waste, which grew compared to Q1 last year by  some 4%. Now within these results we have to underline the fact that Herambiente contributed to –  with €39 million to the overall €52 million result.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on to the water business results. In this case the industrial fundamentals, in other words the  volume dynamics saw us going back to the distribution water levels which are in line with Q1 of  2008. And this certainly had an impact on the business, on the business’ importance, which is now  equal to €32 million. The volume effect were able to offset the lower new connections, and this  indicates that the real estate industry still hasn’t been able to recover as we have already been  seeing in other industrial sectors within our regional of reference.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on to the energy sector, which together with the waste business had some significantly  important results. Beginning with the gas business, we can notice how this specific area improved  by €4.5 million, equal to 5.9% compared to Q1 last year. This result was made possible by sales  activities equal to €28 million. Sales and trading activities are together and they are more or less  along the same line as last year, and the distribution business which increased by €60 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of volume, also due to the cold winter we had in the first quarter of the year, we had a  growth equal to 8.5% in terms of distribution and an increase equal to 20% in terms of volume sold  and wholesale trading. Now within this 20%, the sales to end customers equals to a growth of  6.5%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We also need to note the development we had in our district heating activities, which in Q1 were  able to benefit from the contribution made by the cogeneration plant in Imola, on one hand due to  the increased activities and the commercial activities which we developed last year. And on the  other, due to the cold winter we had. In this case, we had a growth equal to more than 17%, with  further 40,000 thermal gigawatt hours which was showed in Q1 of this year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: I have nothing specific to comment on the other businesses, whereas I would like to focus on the  investments. In this case we had a significant reduction in terms of absolute figures, since as you  can see we went down from 86 million to 62.8 million. In this case the most significant contribution  came from the waste business, because as we already mentioned we are now in the final stages of  the investment made to build the new waste-to-energy plants.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We have also had a general contraction or rather a general decrease in terms of CapEx, in terms of  investment in all of the sectors. As you can see in the graph by comparing the results of the waste,  gas and electricity businesses.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of our net financial situation, we closed Q1 with €1.9 billion, as we mentioned earlier,  which is slightly above the figures we had last year at year-end. This result was also due to the  results of the operating cash flow, which as you know for a company such as ours which is focused  on energy and on gas and then on particularly cold winter such as one we had this year, this  represents the quarter in which we are more exposed during the year. Variation this year was less  compared to last year and this allows us to keep our debt level at a substantially stable level, with  an improvement compared to our net working capital, which is down 1.1 times.

file: HER - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 12May2011 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of contributions, I would say there was a diversity between the various business areas,  obviously the Energy sector, and you’ll see this in the figures we’ll be highlighting, did contribute  significantly because by uniting Gas and Electricity and all of their different sectors, the growth  compared to last year was equal to 78%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Obviously this includes both the Commercial activities and the procurement and distribution  activities. As far as M&A is concerned, for the first quarter, we only had a single operation that we  had already illustrated, and as of January 1st we were able to start up a biomass plant in joint  venture with Enomondo. It’s an 120,000 ton plant and it has been fully on stream since the  beginning of the quarter. Our management results were good and we also were able to create good  cash generation, which also highlighted a further reduced – reduction in debt, also thanks to the  positive cash we have.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: This is – this effect is even more positive in terms of our cash flow, if we separate the delta  perimeter effects given by the consolidation of this joint venture, this 50% joint venture with  Enomondo, as far as the already mentioned biomass plant is concerned.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of Gas and Electricity we had an increase which almost completely covered this  development we’ve had. As you can see, Gas on the right hand side increased by €15 million,  whereas Electricity increased by €11 million for a total of €26 million out of a total €36 million in  organic growth.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The two remaining parts are two smaller contributions equal to €1.6 million each. One comes from  the waste-to-energy plant in Rimini. As we had mentioned the plant started mid last year and       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: M&A refers to the Enomondo joint venture, which is a 50:50 joint venture with the Caviro partner,  within which we have a 120,000 ton biomass and a small composting plant.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of the various business areas, in terms of the breakdown by businesses, we can begin by  the most important one, which is the Networks area, which had a €96 million EBITDA with a plus  5% growth. This is a figure which is very much in line with the performances we recorded at the end  of last year when our growth was equal to 4.1%. This is followed by the Energy sector, which is the  sector which had the most significant growth, moving from €36 million to €65 million. And I already  mentioned briefly what, how this breaks down, whereas the Waste sector had €58 million with a  plus 11% growth vis-à-vis the previous year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Even in this case, a small percentage of this was due to the contribution of the Rimini waste-to- energy plant and for the most part, it was due to the development we had as far as special waste is  concerned. And specifically, in this area of business, you can find further details on page five.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The volumes in Special Waste grew by 6% compared to last year. For the first time, we have to  highlight a small decrease in Urban Waste that we’ll be studying over the next few months even  though it is slightly different compared to the results we had last year. And therefore, perhaps it’s  due to the overall scenario.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of the contribution to the increase in profitability we have to also highlight a good  performance in Electricity which had an increase equal to 33%, due to the better use of our waste- to-energy plants, which as you can see in the graph in the lower left-hand corner, cover  approximately 18% of all of the volumes treated, with a plus 4% increase compared to the previous  year. We also had an increase in our Composting which went from 7% to 8%, and a decrease in  Landfill use.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Obviously this increase in Composting also brought about a further development in Sorted  collection which is now close to 50%, meaning that each kilo of waste we collect we can recover  half, whereas the remaining half goes into the waste-to-energy plants, for the most, part to recover  its energy content. This is a fully balanced and sustainable approach.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: On page six, you have some figures on our Water business. The elements we’d like to highlight for  Q1 are in line with our, with the trend we saw in 2010, we had a slight decrease in the volumes of  Water. This quarter was slightly above last year. Already in March though, the results were better  compared to the first two months and in April they were even better. Also because, someone was  explaining that since Easter was in April and it was a warm month we sold less gas, but we sold  more water.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 4 but it was more than offset by the Trading activities, which had 24 million cubic meters or more  which were treated.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The same climate effect, which brought about a contraction in the distributor volumes also – is also  reflected in District Heating, in which we had a decrease equal to 3%, which is lower compared to  the overall Gas figures, since in this business we are increasing our customer base progressively  so as to be able to draw the utmost advantage from the investment made in the Imola co- generation plant in terms of the number of our customers.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In the Gas business we are stable, meaning that our churn is offset by the new customers  conquered, whereas as far as the sales and margins dynamics are concerned, and I was saying a  part of this is connected to the gas procurement, which was negotiated last year which will last up  to September, whereas in the Treating sector, which contributed to the results we had in Q1, we  have to say that Q1 was able to benefit from the use of the gas that we had acquired last year,  whereas as of now we will be working to build the portfolio for next winter.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on, finally to our investments. I believe this title summarizes our situation. We have a trend  which is under control, it’s in line with our forecast and it’s in line with the indications given in the  business plan and it is further decreased compared to last year, also due to the completion of the  investment we made in our infrastructure on our plants, for instance, the completion of the waste- to-energy plant in Rimini.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In this first quarter, we had a balance between the maintenance and conservation investments  equal to 70% and certain specific developments which covered some 30% of our investment.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We’re also working on the new business plan. In April we made a further step forward that we had  already mentioned in an earlier occasion through the acquisition of a gas sales company in the  Marche region, which will be integrated into our system. It will be fully integrated as of July 1st. And       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We are not concerned as far as this point is concerned. We will have to consider our final offer for  the Florence waste-to-energy plant. That offer will be given at the end of June and therefore we’ll  be giving you further information in the months to come. Our results are very transparent and very  consistent and very good compared to our expectations. And now we can go into some Q&A and  we are very much available for any questions you may have.

file: HER - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 15May2012 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: This is one thing I'd like to mention and then Mr. Venier will be mentioning few other things when he goes into  the business by business breakdown, such as the effects of fair value of the energy businesses, which have a  negative impact, which go in contrast with the results obtained in 2011. Therefore, even this change brought about  some temporary changes because as the fair values expired last year – this year we will make a recovery on the fair  value we have in our portfolio, whereas CIP6 will have an effect up to end of the year, the fair value of variation  will be reabsorbed during the year.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Now as far as the specific factors, which happened in this period besides the downturn, the crisis, which I believe  you're all familiar with. We also have to take into account that as far as weather is concerned, we had a number of  different situations, which had an impact in different sectors. As far as waste is concerned, we had a reduction in  consumption and therefore an impact on waste. And on top of that we also had the month of February, which was  specifically negative for the waste activities, but due to the fact that for two weeks waste could not be collected  because of the locations they were situated in could not be reached by our trucks and some of our sites couldn't be  reached due to the snow, but that was a very specific event.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Another effect was due to the heat in terms of the figures on gas in the month of March. We had a strong increase  in temperatures or rather we had a very cold month in February, which helped gas, whereas in March some of the  days were so warm that it almost felt like spring. And therefore these are two factors that we will be explaining  because we obviously had an effect on the overall results.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Being that, on page two, you can see that there was a strong increase in terms of revenues due to the increase in  raw material and trading. And also in some periods of the quarter, we had a good level in terms of consumption  and in terms of our energy offers. As far as EBITDA is concerned, we are in line with the levels of last year without  taking into account the fact that we had those events that I mentioned a few minutes ago had we not had those  events 2012 would have been even better compared to 2011.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: In terms of pre-tax profit, we are at €120.3 million vis-à-vis €123 million last year. And we have the tax levels,  which as everybody knows grew significantly; which brought up our tax rate from €39.5 million last year to €42.7  this year. This tax hike is obviously due to the effects of the Robin Hood Tax and to the effect of IRAP which all in  all account for some €2.5 million.  Our net profit post minorities is at €65.3 million vis-à-vis €66.8 million last year, therefore, with a very limited  variation. As far as the drivers for this quarter are concerned, a limited number of significant things can be  highlighted. It all stems from organic growth and synergies with further €1 million coming in from M&A  operation, which took place last year, which didn't have effect on last year, which was the acquisition of Sadori Gas  in the Marche region. And another, which is typical of this period, is the acquisition of solar plants equal to 4MW,  which happened in February. This was the acquisition of four small companies that each of which had a 1MW  plant. That is part relative to M&A activities in Q1. And then, we also had the CIP6 effect that I also mentioned.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Moving into the strategic area performances as far as the energy sector is concerned, we had a significant growth.  We posted a plus 11% vis-à-vis 2011, which again was a very good year. And this was due to the good performances  we had and the expansion of our customer base that will be going in to later on.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as networks are concerned, we had a 4% increase compared to the previous year, which is mainly due to the  increase of tariffs concerning this specific sector. As far as contribution to our results from waste, we had a  reduction, which we expected, most of it stems from two factors, one is the €5 million less stemming from the  expiration of CIP6 and the GSE action concerning a Green Certificates last year for waste, where we had a  discount on delivery services and another factor was due to the market difficulties in terms of the amounts of  waste which had a significant impact of both on urban waste and on special waste, industrial waste.

texts.speaker: Luca Moroni
texts.profession: Group Director-Administration, Finance & Control, Hera SpA
texts.text: Nonetheless, the performance is positive at around €8 million. After that we have the effects of the extraordinary  operations as mentioned namely linked to the acquisitions of companies, which have managed four solar plants  and we also acquired a majority stake in the Feronia Company, which manages a landfill. The company's debt  structure is absolutely in line with what we had at year end. Most of the debt, 70% of the debt is at fixed rate with a  very long duration. The part which is ending is relatively low. We have a €140 million of the convertible bond,  which will expire in October 2013, and then we have another number of lesser financing.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As you've seen the issue of the impact of the context – of the general context – simply have an impact on special  waste, which contracted in the two most significant months, because in February at least in the Emilia-Romagna  region, waste collection was blocked by the snow storms, but even in terms of urban waste we had a contraction  equal to 5% approximately. This obviously suffered from the snow storms in February. But in general terms, as  you can see this is due to the difficult general context, one that we had never seen in previous years, not even  during the freezing months in 2008 and 2009.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: We are also working on completing the different axes for waste management, in other words by increasing the  larger assets by accompanying with energy plants with lighter plants, so that we can tackle the increase in the  sorted collection, giving value to the biomass component in waste, which as you know benefits from specific  subsidies which are also included the new decree on renewable sources.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Last, but not least, we also have some initiatives in terms of cost reduction, in terms of rationalizing the assets we  have because obviously we're facing contracting volumes, we have to look to a smaller number of plants, although  we can have an optimal level of functioning. At the same time, we also have to cut costs in terms of the operating  costs that are included in all of the waste treatment processes. This is pretty much the action plan that we have  decided to apply, which started a few months ago because the situation is not a novelty. In the last quarter's last  year, we've already seen a trend which indicated that there was a contraction.
