And therefore we feel that we will be  seeing the results of our action already in the months ahead.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving onto page six, the water business. In this case, we have some very comforting figures. Our margins  increased slightly. I use the word slightly, but as far as percentages are concerned, it's equal to 8%. And this is a  proof that our consistent approach and the consistent approach our local authorities had were positive in terms of  sticking to the tariff limits we had in certain areas such as Bologna and Modena and their provinces, which  account for 50% of our water business. These contracts flow continue up to 2014 and 2015 as we refer a new tariff  system. The visibility that we have on a significant part of this business for the years ahead allows us to continue  with the initiatives that we've already had in the past eight or nine years. In other words, when we began  managing a stable asset.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As you can see certain cyclical trends are difficult to interpret as far as consumption is concerned. We've had an  increase in Q1 compared to Q1 last year and the figure this year certainly reflects the effects of a very warm month  of March, but also a very cold month of February, because consumption was influenced by the weather conditions

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to gas on page seven. In this case once again, we have a confirmation of certain dynamics that we had  appreciated in some quarters last year, specifically in Q4 last year. We have a plus €50 million increase, and in Q1  we are at €114.4 million in terms of EBITDA. In these, I mean, €50 million are connected to distribution, which  due to the progressive increase of IRAP. We had an improvement equal to €1 million in 2012 where as the  remaining part is connected to sales for €57 million and the remaining part is linked to district heating activities,  which overall in Q1 had a sizeable growth in sold volumes above 5%.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to the electricity business and going back to the comments made on the previous business. In this case,  the revenues' dynamics has posted a growth, but not with the size we've seen previously. This is a consequence of  the typical development of our customer base besides the price reflected of the last 12 months. And in those same  months, the price of oil grew by some 20%, if I remember correctly. And if we look at the truly trading activities as  far as this business is concerned, this has reduced due to the same period last year also due to the well-known  upstream and wholesale market conditions.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: One last note on the electricity – on energy rather and gas, this is also linked to the development of our customer  base. And after the end of Q1, we launched our new commercial campaigns, which from this point of view should  be further derived to reaching the targets we have for this year, which I remind you is to bring it further 80,000  customers compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: In Q1, we also launched a significant plant in Ravenna in terms of the management of industrial sludge, thereby  strengthening our presence in that sector. We are continuing in the biodigester sector, two of these plants will be –  will go on-stream within the end of the year. And therefore as far as this profile is concerned, we continue to  strengthen our portfolio in the waste business always in line with the evolution of the market itself. And at the  same time, we have also been continuing working in Florence. We're working on the authorization phases of the  project that as you know we have influenced.

file: HER - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 15May2013 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Now, from this point of view, the sector-by-sector results are positive in all sectors, including those which had  suffered some difficulties last year, such as waste, for instance. And we will obviously be going over the  performance later on. We also had an excellent performance in the water business, and I think we had a record  result in the gas business in our Q1 performance.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: From the commercial side of things, I think both of the liberalized sectors, both on the energy and in the special- waste business, we performed well and we'll be seeing the figures later on. And to this, I'd also like to add a further  element concerning the cost performances. We paid close attention to this item simply in terms of the decline in  the trading activities which we had, which obviously had an impact on the price of raw materials, but also to  underline the commitment that we had on cost cutting and the controlling cost that we'll continue in the months  ahead.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Moving on to page two, without taking into account the pro forma basis for 2012, going into the 2013 figures  alone, as you can see, the Hera plus Acegas revenues increased 6%. Now, were we to also take into account the  Acegas effect for 2012, the equivalent of revenues would be reduced, which goes back to the issue already  mentioned, which is connected to the lower energy trading activities.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Just a couple of remarks on our commercial expansion. We have to underline the fact that with this operation and  with the growth we had in the first quarter or especially in electricity, we are now close to the 2 million energy  customer mark, which had been part of our business plan targets for quite some time. And therefore, with this  latest operation, we're now up to 1.9 million customers, meaning that we are very much on the threshold of the 2  million. And already in the last quarter, we confirmed a further 50,000 new customers on electricity, plus the  Acegas contribution.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Our regulated activities performed well, both in waste and in water especially. And Stefano will be explaining how  we posted a very good quarter indeed. As far as the strategic areas are concerned, you can see the comparison that  we have between the 2012 results and the 2013 results. In Q1, you can see that we had some sizeable increases  with the usual balance we have between the three fundamental areas of business. 23% in energy and the networks,  up to 36% in waste, which is a sector in which we were also able to take advantage of a new asset we acquired at  the end of last year.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: Thank you and good afternoon. I'll begin with the waste business as usual. I'm especially satisfied because the  signals we've been seeing at the end of last year seemed to be continuing in terms of the volume dynamics in this  quarter. And beginning with this element, beginning with the development of our activities on special waste, we'll  notice that there has been a relevant increase equal to 41,000 tons, equaled – almost to more than 12% vis-à-vis  Q1 last year in terms of the activities that we manage.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: The contribution to this volume – these volumes come from two major factors. The first of which is the  continuation of the commercial activities that we have started quite some time ago that we had the opportunity of  discussing with you over the past few months, plus the consolidation of our activities in Central Italy through the  Energonut plant, which contributed with roughly 50% to the volumes. Therefore, of the 41,000 tons, half of these  stemmed from the good functioning of this plant that we bought at the end of last year and the remaining 50%  stems from purely commercial activities. The higher volumes are also accompanied by higher production of  renewable energy, thanks to the Energonut plant and now we're up 258 gigawatts per hour.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: Obviously, all of this translates into an increased profitability in this business, which as far as Hera is concerned,  went up from €48 million to €54 million. To that, we have to add the Acegas waste contribution, which is equal to  €11.4 million for a total of €65.6 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: Just a couple of remarks on the functioning of the Acegas activities, their activities were developed with a very  good continuity. As far as Acegas is concerned, the volumes were reasonably stable vis-à-vis at the same period  last year, 60,000 tons in urban waste, whereas the functioning waste-to-energy plant performed very well both in  Padua and in Trieste.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: And in terms of the plants, as you may remember at the end of last year, we began the building of the two new bio- digesters, 1 megawatt each here in the Romagna territory. And they were completed in Q1 and we expect to have  that fully on stream within the first half of the year. So, the second half of the year can be six months in which it  would be fully on stream.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: Last remark as far as the waste business is concerned, which is the performance of our assets, our plants which  you can notice in terms of the volumes treated in the graph of page five, in which you can see that the amounts of  waste treated in waste-to-energy plants has grown further. This probably stems from the fact that we have 20,000  tons to 25,000 tons for the plant and we have the optimization of the already existing plants. And this is obviously  something which decreases the use of our landfills. We had a good performance of our selection plants, which  further improved their performances. There seems to be a small mistake in the percentages here on the graph. The  growth isn't equal to 0.3%. Since it's a growth of 15,000 tons, it's well above 10% as a matter of fact.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: Moving on to water, in this first quarter, we were able to see the full implementation of the tariff scheme. The  tariff scheme is now fully cleared or almost full cleared. There's still a number of – a limited number of elements  which still need to be clarified. But the business dynamics were good, because as you can see also vis-à-vis  revenues which were pretty stable, our profitability increased and that obviously is affected by the cost-cutting  activities.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: We had some pretty good results in the district heating sector. And since it is connected to thermal season, district  heating had some reasonably constant performances, as the winter was pretty average. It was neither too cold,  neither too warmer, it was a little bit warmer compared to last year, but those levels were stable.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: In terms of customers, as for the Hera perimeter, we have stabilized our customer base at 1.115 million customers.  Naturally, as of January 1, we also incorporated the AcegasAps gas clients and since we have a 51% share in  EstEnergy, we have further 110,000 customers of Acegas and the total now is almost 1,250,000 customers.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: General Manager-Development & Markets and A.I. Business Development & Asset Upstream, Hera SpA
texts.text: Moving on to electricity, in electricity, we have a more stable situation in the sense that we had a pretty good  performance in electricity distribution. We had some ups and downs in the liberalized market for energy. We are  aware of the difficulties in the upstream. Even though we have a modest portion of this in our portfolio, still it  gives us some amount of signals.

file: HER - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 14May2014 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Now had we been asked a few months ago to give you a forecast, a weather forecast concerning the first quarter,  despite any possible pessimism that we would never have imaged the climate to be so much higher compared to  the average in previous years, so much so that the winter behind us in terms of performance was the wo rst in the  past 30 years. Therefore, we decided to pitch in and were able to close the quarter with some results that we feel  are positive despite the impact on a specific sector namely gas.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Y ou have already had the chance to see the results and the figures, therefore you were able to appreciate the fact  that despite the impact of the climate, also in terms of revenues and by climate, obviously I'm referring to the  impact on gas sales and district heating specifically, but despite all this, beginning on EBITDA and down to the  bottom line, down to net profit, so we were able to post a growth as we always posted ever since the company was  created. This is the message that we are attempting to convey on page one of our presentation.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: The growth obviously was brought about in sectors other than gas and as we'll be seeing and hearing our results  were able to offset the gas performance and by other sectors I am referring to water, electricity and waste.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as the result posted, in terms of the financial results are concerned, which undermine the fact that we did  have a negative impact, that brought about – which had an impact on few subsidiary companies which suffered  from the performance of the gas business – the same kind of impact that we ourselves suffered.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: And, therefore, the performance in Aimag and EstEnergy – we'll be referring to those companies to tell you about  the change in accounting rules, which would applied to those companies as well , since they are co-managed  together with Asco Piave. But both of these companies also suffered due to a negative impact, which again is  brought about by the weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Then we have the third item which refers to the operation with E&I to complete the operation concerning the  electricity and gas networks and the two companies in the Gorizia province which brought about a further €5  million in the EBITDA growth. Then obviously I haven't given you the figures yet, but we have the impact of the  weather that I referred to from the qualitative standpoint.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Obviously the effect of the weather conditions was quite significant. The impact was minus €20 million as far as  EBITDA is concerned. Therefore if we do the math and had we not had the effects of the weather, our forecast was  – growth on EBITDA without considering the effects on gas, which would have been equal to 9.2%, you can see it  above the graph on Page 3.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Good afternoon. As usual, let's begin with the waste business. The most significant  element in terms of business dynamics is volumes obviously, which as you can see on the graph, has a special  impact on special waste.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: In the first quarter the volumes increased by 147 tonnes. This is a sizeable amount compared to Q1 in 2013. It is  consistent with the signals that we had already been able to record in Q4 2013 when we had underscored a certain  recovery happening in the special waste business.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Urban waste also posted a slight recovery. Obviously when it comes to urban waste the variations refer to 1.2%  increase or decrease. What we feel is worthy of being underscored is that in Q1 this year compared to 12 months  ago, urban waste had a slight recovery, which is as far as we're concerned marks the end of the slight contraction  with that we had been seeing between the end of 2011 and in the first half of 2013.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And in the waste sector that refers to the 50% joint venture in Enomondo, which as you may remember it's a joint  venture we have with a local operator, a wine maker called Caviro and it's a biomass plants that equal to 500,000  tones. This is an operation that we deconsolidated 2014 and in 2013. Therefore in homogeneous terms the €5  billion I was referring to – and the €5 million I am referring to aren't the exact outcome of the variation in  volumes. There are also the net effects stemming from contraction of the price of electricity because as you know,  this unit has a major generation of electricity specially coming from waste energy transfer, also from biogas plants,  which suffered due to the coal price which as you know in Q1 decreased significantly. Therefore, having  reabsorbed that effect of 250 terawatt hours generated, we had net increase equal to €5 million as I mentioned.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: The final aspect I'd like to underline is that we are continuing to develop our urban waste management model so  as to be able to recover waste more and more through a constant growth [ph] shorter (16:01) collection, which in  Q1 reached 52% and also in Q1 we also opened a major selection plant in the city of Bologna which required €10  million approximately in investments and which is the most modern plant in Italy in that business sector which  has few comparables in Europe.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Final piece of information I'd like to share with you to try to anticipate some of your questions, the €7 0 million  bolstered in waste management are spilt up in the €25 million for [ph] collection (16:51) and €45 million  stemming from waste treatment and waste disposal.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving onto the networks businesses, we hosted a major increase of €21 million of which as the Chairman was  saying a portion stems from M&A activities because as you know Gorizia activities referred to this area of business  and again those activity are focused on gas and electricity distribution. We also had water, which was able to post  a significant increase based on the new tariffs. Tariffs grew by 1.7% and take into account that on a yearly basis our  turnover is above €500 million and therefore that translates into an increase in profitability and furthermore  these tarrifs started to recover.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And finally we also have the distribution of electricity and gas. In this case we had a major increase. This increase  specifically also takes into account an aspect which is strictly related to these businesses, the management of  White Certificates.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: These are the most significant elements as far as the networks businesses are concerned. Another typical question  is out of the €131 million, gas refers to €58 million, water refers to some €49 million and the  remaining refers to  electricity and district heating.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: That was the good news. And moving on to the problems we faced in Q1, referring to the thermal season, what that  actually mean as far as Hera Group is concerned, what did the mild winter bring about?

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: They bought about a contraction of volumes sold to end customers equal to some 250 million cubic meters – 246  million cubic meters to be exact, without taking into account the effects on Estenergy which is consolidated as of  January 1 in that capital.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: This is a 25 percentage points – in other words last year we had sold 1 billion cubic meters, whereas this year we  sold slightly below 7 50 million cubic meters. This is the bias of the phenomenon linked to the thermal season.  This is impact that the mild winter had on Hera Group.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as our electricity sales are concerned, we had a plus €4 million improvement. But this improvement, it  doesn't stem from an increase in the sale of electricity volumes which remained pretty much stable or with a slight  contraction.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: We also have the impact of power generation. Compared to Q1 last year we were able – we had minus €2 million  plus a number of smaller, minor items worth €2 million and this is the overall picture. Therefore, the €7 0 million  in Q1 include €15 million or €16 million for electricity and the remaining portion refers to cash and connected  businesses. And therefore this is the general overview.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: In this case too, as in the waste business, the figures for 2013 were realigned. They were readjusted to give you a  homogenous view of the accounting principles and in this case the effects were more obvious because the  company that we spun off, the Estenergy Company that we have a 51% stake in, whereas 49% is owned by Asco  Piave. Especially in Q1 last year, their results have been particularly positive. Therefore the impact is equal to  some €9 million. The deconsolidation impact is equal to €9 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Plus, a final note, the warm weather didn't stop our commercial activities in terms of the number of customers.  We increased our customer base in electricity by some 65,000 customers over the past 12 months, and specifically  20 – further 20,000 customers in Q1, 2014.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Then another element concerning the annual general meeting, refers to the AMGA Udine operation. Certainly  remember the steps of the operation. And you also may remember that the main focus, the main business of the  AMGA Udine Company refers to a gas sales of electricity in the Udine products. As far as distribution is  concerned, both in Italy and in Bulgaria, those activities will be managed by AcegasAps; whereas, as far as gas,  electricity and sales, that those activities, those businesses will be governed by Hera Group directly.

file: HER - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 13May2015 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As you can see, we had a change in weather compared to the previous year. We were able to fully recover the  things that we had lost with the warm weather we had in 2014, although we did reap some benefits, and  therefore, hopefully we are now on the right path again, which isn't 100% linked to our activities. Hopefully, we're  back on track, so to speak, even concerning events which we can't control. And after the pretty self-explanatory  first page, we can move on to the results in our P&L. Basically, as far as revenues are concerned, we had a 7%  growth, which pertains to the energy division. And it goes back to what I was seeing a few minutes ago, and it's  quite clear. The recovery compared to a normal year prior to 2014 is equal to about 60% vis-à-vis the impact we  had last year given its difficulties; therefore, we still have some space to grow from this point of view.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: At the same time, we also have to deal with the depreciation. As far as provisions are concerned, that is equal to  some €2.3 million, referring to a bad debt €2.3 million from the Hera Comm, the commercial side of things in  general. We have improved as far as our cost of debt is concerned, as you can see, but Mr. Moroni will be going  into the details later. We also want to underline a more significant contribution from our associates and joint  ventures, especially in the energy sector, and I'm specifically referring to the increased results of both Est Energy  and Sgr Rimini, which as you can see, brought about €5 million.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: In the same graph, we also went a little bit beyond the Q1 results and besides the things already mentioned, we  also decided to include a piece of news, namely two operations we did from the organizational standpoint. They  will be operational as of July. They refer to the creation of a company, which we'll be referring to Herambiente,  which will be the majority shareholder, a company which will include the two waste energies in the cities of Trieste  and Padova, and also as a way to strengthen our structure in the waste asset sector. We are also working on the  100% takeover with the subsequent merger, Herambiente of the Akron company; the company which deals with  the selection of our assorted collection materials, plastic and paper especially. This is a company with a 52% or  53% stake in the company. We'll be taking over 100% of the company following the completion of the acquisition  from the private shareholders.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Good afternoon. I will be briefly going over our three business areas with the more relevant items. I'll begin with  waste, as usual. As far as the waste collection is concerned, we had a slight dip in the quarter equal to some €4.9  million since EBITDA in Q1 was equal to €64.9 million compared to the €69.8 million of the previous quarter.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: What brought about this shift are two things. The first of which is linked to the waste volumes we treated. In the  lower left-hand graph, as you can see, we treated 938,000 tons compared to 1.16 million tons in 2014 and  856,000 tons in Q1 2013. Urban waste grew by [ph] 3% (00:10:00) where special waste dipped by 90,000 tons.  What brought about these trends in special waste wasn't so much linked to market conditions, but rather it was  due to the combination of a couple of phenomena, which had an impact on our capacity, almost linked to our  waste-to-energy, two specifically, the waste-to-energy plant in Bologna and the one in Pozzilli had breakdowns  which happened during the first quarter, which brought the waste-to-energy plants to a stop for a few weeks,  which obviously reduced our available capacity by some 30,000 tons.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: The second event is linked to the exhaustion of a few landfills in 2014 and the opening of a new landfill that we  had in our program, which had been located in the Modena province, which is requiring a bit more time. Again,  this brought about a reduction in terms of our capacity, and as a consequence, we had a reduction in the volumes  treated during the quarter. Although unfortunately, we had to delay a few commercial opportunities due to these  reasons.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: The second event, which had an impact on these results is linked to the incentives and the value of electricity. As  you know, given the dip in oil prices, the prices of electricity have dropped significantly over the past six to nine  months. Therefore, year-on-year, the overall amount of profit from the sale of electricity was down approximately  €2 million year-on-year. So these are the two negative phenomena, the two phenomena which had an impact on  our results.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as the networks division is concerned, as usual, we have a pretty complex [ph] breakdown (00:13:10). Our  Executive Chairman, during his introduction, already mentioned the fact that last year we had had some  extraordinary proceeds linked to the perequazione equalization as far as electricity is concerned, but also on gas  distribution with some tariff increases and also with the reevaluation of our white certificates following a legislation  which changed the criteria last February. And we also have a stable performance as far as gas distribution is  concerned, €68 million for this year and last year. Growth as far as the water regulated revenues are concerned  from €47 million to over €50 million in 2015 plus the already mentioned dip in electricity distribution, which in Q1  this year at €9 million [ph] for the (00:14:25) contraction equal to €8 million, which refers the largest portion of the  €40 million I was mentioning.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Obviously, the results of the gas distribution business was increased by the broadening of our perimeter and  [indiscernible] (00:14:47) equal to some €6 million, as you can see on the slide. These are the most important  elements. The positive results that we posted in Q1, as far as water is concerned, is yet another step forward in  our – the process of the harmonization of the tariff schemes, which were approved by the authority for the years  2014 and 2015, which brought about an increase in proceeds from water equal to some €3 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: One final element from this point of view is part about the effects we had on tariffs both for water and for gas  distribution, especially brought about by the investment plans, which in Q1 were equal to some €47 million in the  regulated activities and [ph] IRAP-based (00:15:41) regulated activities on a total of €64 million, which was the  spending we had in the first quarter. Things went very well from the commercial side of things, not only given to a  better weather, as the Chairman was mentioning. And as you certainly heard and listening to the results of other  companies who mainly deal with the gas business and gas sales, the first quarter was better compared to Q1 last  year, but not as good as Q1 2013. Basically, it's somewhere in the middle between the two previous years.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: What does this mean? In a nutshell, it means that in Q1 this year, we sold 1 billion cubic meters in gas, which are  200 million cubic meters more than last year, 70 million cubic meters of which refer to the increase in our  perimeter following the Amga Udine transaction and the remaining 130 million cubic meters are linked to the  weather. I'm only referring to the sale of gas to end users, not considering gas trading, which are other dynamics.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as electricity is concerned, our customer base grew again. And we can say very accurately that we are now  above 800,000 customers, 808,000 as of March 31, as a matter of fact, with a further 13,000 customers in Q1,  which is equal to a total of almost 70,000 between end of March last year and the end of March this year. As far  as gas is concerned, we are stable at 1.3 million clients with a total of 2.1 million contracts in the energy division.  Not everything was positive within this business area. As often happens, there are some positive conditions and  other which are less positive.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Among the negative things, we have to underline the fact that the limited amount of generation capacity we have  had this significantly lower contribution from the ancillary services for the Central South cluster (00:18:28), minus  €4.6 million compared to the previous year. Had we not had this phenomenon, the quarter would certainly had  posted an almost €20 million growth, which is partly linked to the weather, as I said, but also linked to the  excellent commercial activities that we've been working on for quite some time now. This was a summary of the  situation we had.

texts.speaker: Luca Moroni
texts.text: The group's debt was positive €2.557 billion, which is lower compared to the €2.64 billion at year-end. And the  cost of debt also improved with the constant optimization process that the company is working on for a number of  months now and which is fully viewable in Q1 this year given the effects of the refinancing we had with the green  bond in July last year, which in the first part of this year will be having its positive effects. The cost of gross debt  moves down from 3.9% we have last year down to 3.8%.

texts.speaker: Luca Moroni
texts.text: That's it as far as we're concerned. Maybe with a couple of remarks on the more interesting elements as far as  we're concerned, also as far as future perspectives are concerned, the bounce back that Mr. Venier was  mentioning on some of the prices for material and the waste sector is something important because in 2014, our  target was to increase our treatment abilities. We had already started seeing a bounce back as far as prices are  concerned, which happened. Plus, we also confirmed our ability to expand on the customers in electricity.

texts.speaker: Luca Moroni
texts.text: This is an important element because it also allows us to further underpin the forecast in the business plan. Plus,  we've also had a good recovery in gas, which is obviously influenced by nature, by weather, but it's something  we're very pleased with. That's one of the core items in our P&L. As far as Amga is concerned, we are moving  along as we did for Padova and Trieste. We are getting ready to pay our dividend, and we will continue with our  activities in Q2 this year.

file: HER - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 10May2017 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Now, talking about the waste sector, and my colleagues will then provide further insights on this, we did not  embed the results of the Aliplast acquisition into the results that you're going to see today. We have already talked  about it, and the results would have even be more rounded up, if we have had the opportunity to consolidate the  presence of this acquisition within our accounts in Q1. But since the application phase of the contract started only  recently, then the productive results were only – haven't been embedded yet, since the contract has been formally  signed with effect as of April 1.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Having said this, if you go to page 3, you see again all the elements that contributed to this growth. The largest  portion of the growth is linked to the expansion of the market in the energy sector, but also in the other business  areas, as I've just pointed out. This is the result of our participation in different tenders in many different areas,  and this is proof once again of our capacity to be very reactive to be present on the market. And we are fully  committed to this, and we would like to continue on this path with more tenders in other sectors, at least this is our  hope. So, these are the highlights of the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Thank you and good evening. I will start off with the waste sector. If you go to page 4, you see the results. We  have already commented upon these results several times during 2016. The result is made up of several  elements. We have some negative effects due to the expiry date of some incentives. And we are talking about the  [ph] fix (00:09:01) of Pozzilli, which expired during the third quarter of 2016, and then we had some extraordinary  maintenance operations on WTE waste, the treatment plant, which determined these costs.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: These costs were completely offset by organic growth, which is mainly due to the growth of the sector of special  waste treatment and to wet, dry and hazardous waste. This is nothing new for us. We have already talked about  this in the past, and these results further consolidated during this first quarter and they're providing the full  contribution. We are talking about €7.1 million in terms of organic growth and they total €46.7 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: As our Chairman correctly pointed out, the effect of the consolidation of Aliplast will become evident in the next  few months. In terms of financial costs everything has already been integrated into the account. But at the end of  January, we also bought the assets of a company called Teseco. And their activities are complementary to waste  recycling activities and they will enable us to further enhance our activities in the local geographical territory  where the company is operating, and we will see some further positive results as in 2016.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: If we now turn to the growth of networks. Here you'll see two components that determined a growth of €6.5  million. On one hand, we made more efficiency in this field. We reduced the operating costs of the water cycle  and the energy-related activities. We use a parameter that is called PDR, and this parameter improved over the  last 12 months period by 1.3% up to 2.5%. So again, efficiency has been made and this is the result of what we  did in 2016 and what we have done in 2017. And then there has been a balancing mechanism in terms of tariffs.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: And as regards the first quarter of 2017, we were awarded some premiums in 2016 because of the good quality of  the service that we deliver. Here you'll see some further results in terms of water, plus €3.4 million; gas  distribution/district heating, plus €2.4 million; electric, energy distribution, plus €0.5 million. These are the main  items in terms of the development of investments. They did not determine a significant variation of the  [indiscernible] (00:12:36) the last quarter. So again, the results are mainly due to the factors that we have already  pointed out.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Now turning to the trading sector, to the commercial sector. First of all, we can say that we have been exceeding  the threshold of [ph] 2.5 million (00:13:03). Within clients, we have more than 900,000 clients for the gas sector.  And this determines that we exceeded the threshold of [ph] 2.5 million clients (00:13:20), that was the target for  us.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: In terms of profitability, the best result as expected came from the electricity sector, €11 million growth. They  relate to safeguarded clients to new services and the remaining portion €4 million, they are related to a better  performance in terms of trading and sales on the free market. Then, on the top of this, we also have the small  contribution on power generation. Here, again, we are reaping the fruits of what we sowed in the beginning of the  year.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: You will remember that this is linked to the situation on the French market in January and in February and better  result tells us that we managed to confirm some positive results of 2016 and we further improved this result €4  million. This is the growth of the gas sector. This growth by €4 million is partially related to the gas default market,  half of which is linked to that and half of that is linked to a better margin on – as regard to the activities on the free  market. And this enabled us to reach €111 million in this first quarter of the year. So in a nutshell, these are the  most relevant components of our financial results.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: The board of directors met for the first time today and the [ph] climate (00:20:04) Tomaso say was very positive.  We had the presentation of some private list for the first time, and I do believe, again that the representatives of  this list contributed to a very positive environment within the meeting of the board of directors. And then we have  a new representative of the private portion of the company. The ship has sailed so to speak, and all the tasks  have already been distributed. So each of us perfectly knows what awaits us.

file: HER - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 10May2018 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: So this is a summary of our figures and then we will be going into the business-by-business breakdown as usual.  As far as our profit is concerned, as our revenues are concerned we had a good expansion in trading also marked  by the recovery as far as the season was concerned. In the previous years we had a tougher time in the month of  January, whereas this year, we were able to recover the results both in February and in March. Furthermore you  will also be hearing how we worked on expanding our energy customer base, with a 28,000 increase in our  customer base in Q1, which also includes a number of operations as far as M&A is concerned in the specific  sector.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: We also did well in waste, and as thus far as waste treatment is concerned, that was a sector which allowed us to  post a higher impact despite the divestment from this sector in the Forlì province, and we'll be seeing the figures  related to this sector. And moving on to EBITDA, I already mentioned what our growth rate was, and the important  thing to note is that even as far as EBIT is concerned we grew by 5.5%. We grew almost 10% on the pre-tax level  and 10% is the net profit post tax, which means that the year was off to a good start with a contribution focused  for the most part on organic growth. In other words of the €16 million in growth, $15.2 million stem from organic  growth and we'll be seeing which sectors that relates to.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Within the result, we also took into account the conclusion of an incentive [indiscernible] (00:06:14) and it was the  energy plant worth €1.3 million and we also contributed with the further €2 million to EBITDA through M&A  activities. Now going back to the way in which organic growth was achieved. As far as energy is concerned, I  mentioned the fact that a major part of the €7.3 million stems from the increase in our customer base with some  28,000 customers through transactions that had already been announced to you in the Gorizia area and in the  Abruzzo region which allowed us to go beyond the 2.4 million energy customers in line with the trend we had  given ourselves also in a very ambitious way as included in the business plan we presented to you.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: The sales volumes increased both in gas and in electricity and also in the trading activities which had a very  positive trend with a growth equal to 75% in terms of volumes. As far as the networks are concerned, their growth  was worth €5.5 million and it benefited from efficiency and innovation projects, which were started in the sectors  which belong to the networks sector. As far as waste is concerned, I mentioned the fact that the overall result for  the strategic waste area is worth approximately €2.5 million. And as far as waste treatment is concerned €4.9  million were brought about by waste treatment activities, including the contribution from the Aliplast company  which was fully operational within our perimeter in this quarter.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as waste collection is concerned, there was a €2.5 million decrease, entirely related to the exit of the Forlì  activities from our group's perimeter. And finally, as far as the results of the others are concerned, which include  public lighting and TLC even here if we consider the size of that business area we posted a good result in the  quarter worth of €1.7 million in terms of EBITDA. This is a summary of the results, which is very straightforward,  which is exactly what characterize the quarter.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: And this year despite having values which are above average and above our budget, in the comparison it will  have a slightly negative figure. Among the other business news the more relevant refers to the new bio-methane  plant, which we have already illustrated on previous occasions and on the slide here you have a synthesis of our  upcoming deadlines. We're now in the final construction phase. We expect to upload the very first part of the  waste beginning in July and it will be followed by three months testing period and it will be fully operational over  the last quarter this year. The key figures in this project, which as you may remember, is worth 135,000 tons of  which 100,000 tons refer to organic waste and 35,000 tons refer to other types of biomass especially greenery  which will bring about 7.5 million cubic meters of methane, which in our case we chose to inject directly into these  [indiscernible] (00:12:19) network.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: The [indiscernible] (00:12:20) high-pressure network, so that it can then be used in the connection points with a  special focus on transportation. In terms of underlying business trends are concerned, I mentioned the prices, I  mentioned electricity we're still missing the volumes. As far as urban waste is concerned we're facing a stable  situation the volumes which are entirely similar to Q1 last year. As far industrial waste is concerned demand is  quite high as seen by the price dynamics and as far as we're concerned our volumes were in line with Q1 last  year or slightly below those figures. These are the essential elements in the waste sector. Moving on now to the  networks area on page 5; as usual here we have collected all of the activities, which pertain to the regulated  distribution business, which includes water, gas, electricity and district heating.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: In this case we were facing some positive dynamics with results which grew by some €5 million with different  components. The water sector grew by €2.3 million benefited slightly from some greater revenues due to the  effects of the investments made at the end of last year and also due to increased efficiencies, which brought  about roughly 50% of the result that you can see. As far as gas distribution and district heating are concerned,  certainly district heating contributed with greater volumes compared to last year thanks to a thermal quarter,  which was a slightly colder. In the gas distribution sector, we have some further revenues linked to premiums on  service and the positive contribution, which I wish to mention since it is something we seldom do, although I think  at this times it deserves to mentioned.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: And I'm referring to the activities we have in Bulgaria referring to gas distribution and sale, which accounts for  14,000 customers, a country in which we rank number two in the country. 14,000 customers, which means that it  is a sector which compared to the Italian context would be quite modest whereas in Bulgaria it is a sizable  presence, which is growing with some 2,000 customers, to 3,000 customers per year. In electricity distribution, we  also posted positive results worth €1.1 million linked to premiums and higher revenues also given the investments  made. I'll go to a typical question I amassed which is how the €139 million of EBITDA are split up for 2018.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: These stem in the following way: €57.4 million from gas distribution, €55.5 million from water services, €10 million  referred to electricity distribution and the remaining amount refers to district heating. The final business area is  energy supply therefore. As I already mentioned a few minutes ago, generally speaking the quarter was slightly  colder compared to last year, during which we sold some 22 million cubic meters more compared to last year on  the residential market, which is where some – a further 2%. It was a strange quarter, because as you may  remember January was mild and then it was very cold between the end of February and mid-March.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: This obviously brought about a certain degree of discontinuity even in the gas procurement sector and gas trading  therefore, allowing us to obtain some positive benefits, which in turn contributed to the €6 million growth, which  you can see in the left hand graph. Allow me to mention the fact that this result also has to take into account to  two negative phenomena. The first refers to the divestment from the activities we had in the City of Sassari and  Sardinia, which we sold to the Itau Gas Group in early-April, which means that that activity was deconsolidated in  Q1 this year. This was a business which had an overall year-over-year result were €3.5 million and therefore Q1  has a minus €1.2 million, plus we also had the fact that in the first three months of the year we'll have the same  situation in the second three months, given the fact that it will be up and running in the first few days of June.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: We had the most important power plant with a Hera stake, which is a Teverola plant, which is down for  maintenance. It is a plant which gives us the highest contribution in terms of production and in terms of  dispatchment and the fact that this asset was not available had an impact compared to the previous year for some  €4 million, which means that we absorbed negative impacts worth some €5 million and despite that we posted a  €6 million growth. The final element, which supports this result, is of course our customer base, which is now up  to €2.4 million. I had already commented during the yearly results conference call that at the end of February we  had gone beyond the 1 million customers in electricity. And to those we have to add 1.4 million gas customers  which increased to a grand total of 2.4 million. Now the electricity market, which is now – which now has a further  60,000 to 70,000 customers over the past 12 months is also partly reflected in the electricity volumes sold, which  were equal to 3 terawatts per hour in the first quarter with a growth equal to 500 gigawatts per hour, which  includes 300 gigawatts per hour in the business retails sector.

file: HER - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 26August2010 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Aug-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The overall growth also has a significant contribution from the electricity sector. With an internal  contribution to this result which is highly supported by a higher quantity of volume which was plus  16% in electricity and plus 5% in gas. This contribution in terms of the commercial policy which as  far as gas is concerned took advantage of the particularly cold winter in the first semester. It’s also  accompanied by the results of the regulated activities within which gas distribution contributed also  due to the decisions that you are aware of in terms of the RAB assessment by the Energy  Authority.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: All of this allowed these results to offset the competition level which in terms of our downstream  policy was noticeable in that period of time. Nonetheless you will notice that in terms of volume and  in terms of clients, our response was very positive indeed. As far as of the waste issue which had a  few critical aspects vis-à-vis the previous year, you can say that with an 8% growth of the market  waste which was processed, this was certainly a component which gave a boost to the Group’s  overall performance. And we were also able to take advantage of the full performances of the  Modena incinerator which had begun working last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of investments, we will go into how we have reduced investments with a minus 16.5%  compared to last year, which is consistent with the – a reduction of our investment on the larger on       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: As far as our revenues are concerned, we have a decrease equal to 14.8%. This was due to two  main reasons. A decrease in our trading activities of the electricity sector and on the other hand the  lower prices that raw materials have over the period, which have an impact, an impact both on  tariffs and on costs, in terms of buying raw materials which consistently reduced significantly.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: As far as EBITDA is concerned, the intervention made on the regulated part of tariffs which were  consistent with our commitments, the expansion of the market both in the energy sector and – both  in the gas sector and the expansion of activities in the waste business which grew by 8%, all of this  together with our policy which pays close attention to cost in the period allowed us to obtain an  EBITDA level which is equal to €313 million, which is equal to a plus 15.6%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Stefano Venier, Development and Market General Department  Thank you and good afternoon. As usual, we will be going into each business area going into  waste, water, gas, and energy.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: On page 4, in terms of volume; you will notice that there is a graph which shows how we have had  an increase equal to approximately 0.5 million tons in terms of the volume treated, which can be  divided into the two various sectors which is market waste and the internal waste which we manage  internally because obviously the waste production has a number of different passages. Out of the  2.9 million tons we have 1.5 million which comes from the market; the remaining part is made up of  the internal waste that we manage.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now within this 1.75 million tons we have a special waste which grew by 10% and urban waste  which as shown at the end of the year, last year grew by 6% which gives us an 8% average that the  Chairman was referring to a few minutes ago.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The other point is represented by the fact that now the Modena waste-to-energy plant is now fully  operational. It is the most important one we have completed over the past two years and therefore  its contribution is extremely visible in the first half of the year and it is equal to some €8 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now within the development of our service management, we need to highlight the fact that not only  did we not interrupt the trend of transferring volumes from the landfills to the waste-to-energy  plants, but we also have separated collection of waste which represents 2 million clients and which  is at the highest in the sector.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Now, what we will be facing in the months to come? Now the events of the first half which will be  duplicated in the second half of the year will be the start-up of the Rimini waste-to-energy plant  which was the last plant that we had committed ourselves to building a few years ago. The plant  has been up and running since June and certainly in the last quarter of the year it will be able to  fully contribute operationally.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: But we also have two other operations which are slightly smaller in terms of size but which are  important for the portfolio, the project for the biomass unit equal to 120,000 tons equal to some 12  megawatt, which is now in its start-up activities. I remind you the fact this is an initiative that we are  bringing forth with an industrial partner, we have 50% of this operation, but then we also have the  anaerobic digestion plant which is the first similar – which is the first such plant in Italy which just  last week has been fully operational and that is equal to 1 megawatt. Now, this is the overall picture  in the waste sector.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 4 Moving onto the water sector; I’ll refer to the figures on page five, the elements here are a little bit  more simple. In terms of volume, we have confirmed the volumes of the first half of 2009,  fortunately 100 million cubic meters, plus we have – and we have fortunately the same figures in  terms of the sewerage.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The most important figure in this business is a tariff increase equal to plus 3.8% which is in line with  the agreements we had reached and on the other hand the initiatives that we are still working on  which are part of the synergy and organic growth that the Chairman was referring to, which had  benefited in terms of cost and especially in terms of the cost for energy, for electricity. As you know  this sector consumes a lot of energy both in terms of sewerage and purification.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on to the gas business; as you know here we have both the regulated side of the market  and the liberalized part of the market, we are on page 6. As the Chairman was saying in his  introduction, you will notice an increase in revenues which is very significant. Here we had more  than €18 million more compared to in the first half of 2009. And this is both for the regulated  activities as we have the new tariff scheme and the new recognized RAB, which increased  compared to the first half of 2009 even in terms of the revenues of equal to some €6 million and  then in terms of the commercial and trading activities of gas and in district heating as well, which  benefits from the completion of the functioning of the – at Imola cogeneration plant. We have an  improvement in our results not only in terms of the cold winter, but also in terms of a decrease in  costs for the production of vapor equal to €5 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on to the energy sector, electricity, on page 7; in this case we have an increase of €5.8  million. The positive contribution here comes especially from the sales and trading activities with an  increase of 16%. And an increase between sale and acquisitions which was able to fully offset the  decreased contribution made by the generation which is something which all operators in the sector  had to deal with in this specific sector.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The areas which – in which there has been decline in CapEx have been waste, but also water and  gas, whereas electricity there has been an increase, the benefit of the fact that we are working on a  few initiatives, some of which are Q2 photovoltaic production and at the end of the month of June  we started a 2 megawatt plant here in the city of Bologna.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano, Chairman  Just a few more points to be made, which can be summed up in the following. The positive results  allow us to be confident that we will be able to match our year-end expectations as our business  plan showed last year. But also keeping in mind that the comparison between second half of 2010  and the second half of 2009 will be made in areas which are more similar compared to the first  halves of the two years, because at the end of 2009 some elements and, in the waste business  more specifically, had overcome some of the critical aspects which had emerged during the first  half of 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Also keep in mind that the overall results in terms of EBITDA for 2009 in the second half of the year  also had benefits of the one-off acquisition of the gas distribution networks which had taken place  at the end of the year and obviously being a one-off event this would not be replicated – duplicated  this year. So, we certainly have the opportunity of being able to match our year-end expectations.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: When we entered the electricity business we heard all of the concerns, we heard many telling us to  not exaggerate in our presence since we were newcomers and we benefited from a less, a smaller  impact also in light of the difficulties that this sector had. But our cautiousness was also – can also  be appreciated in an important business such as gas in which we decided to avoid making long- term commitments which other companies had which was certainly a difficulty for them in terms of  managing 2010. So we are doing well in terms of expanding downstream, but we are also doing  very well in terms of managing the specific era we are living in.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 6 Life moves on. Mr. Venier already mentioned the startup of the Rimini plant. We had a peak plant  that we had referred to previously which is being built in the Abruzzo region and it will be completed  by the end of the year as expected. And we are starting to work on the market opportunities outside  of our region in terms of building waste-to-energy plants.

file: HER - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 25August2011 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As we had already highlighted, in the previous report, we have to underline the fact that our growth is due to the  strong contribution made by the energy sector. Thanks to the continuation of the development of our commercial  activities. And thanks to our performances in the procurement and in the optimization of our production plants  us to overcome the effects in the gas sector of a mild winter which compared to last year didn't have some  favorable results.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as the other company activities besides continuing with our investment program as you'll be hearing and  besides our individual initiatives, the M&A sector as you may remember we concluded two operations, one of  which was in the gas commercialization sector and one of which was in the biomass sector with the new joint  venture which became operational as of January 1. And as we'll be hearing from Mr. Moroni, we also had some  positive results. Besides our financial statement, we also had some positive results in terms of the commitments  we've made on our business plan and we had positive free cash flows. And we were also able to keep our debt level  at the same level we had last year.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: More specifically going into the figures of our results, it's easy to highlight how a significant portion of our growth  which is equal 8% was due to energy prices and due to the volumes sold, which as we'll be seeing in Mr. Venier's  presentation, were particularly relevant in the electricity sector.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: In terms of new plants, we have to take into account the additional contribution of the Rimini waste-to-energy  plant which operated for the entire first half of the year this year, whereas, as you may remember in 2010, it only  went on stream for the past – for the last two months of the last semester.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as M&A is concerned, of the two operations I was mentioning previously, only the biomass operation is  taking into accounts here, end of the first half. It's a joint venture with a private operator called Enomondo, which  contributed to EBITDA growth by €3 million.  As far as our strategic areas are concerned, this brings us back to a different evaluation of the impacts that we have  had over the first half, and we'd like to highlight how the networks grew by 1.1% compared to the previous year.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: In the waste sector – in the overall waste sector, including the effects of the Rimini waste-to-energy plant and  including the effects of Enomondo and including the regulated waste services, all of these brought about an  increase equal to 8.3% compared to the previous year.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: And we have a very relevant increase driven by the energy sector compared to the previous year which is plus  32.3% which is linked to a very intense activity in terms of our commercialization and also in terms of the  optimization of our plants which, indeed, allowed us to offset the effects of the thermal and electric sector that  you're all familiar with.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Good evening, Mr. Venier speaking. I'd now like to summarize the various business areas. The trends were already  introduced by the chairman. I'll try to give you some ways to interpret the various performances and the various  businesses. Beginning on page five, where we go into the waste business, which as you know, includes  Herambiente, Marche Multiservizi and waste collection and street cleaning activities are concerned.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Our growth here was equal to 7% in terms of revenues which was mainly driven by tariffs and by waste collection,  by Special Waste volumes which performed better compared to Urban Waste. And also by the significant increase  in electricity production which is at plus 22% which is mainly driven by the plants that are now on stream and  specifically, the Rimini Waste Energy plant, but also the Enomondo plant.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as EBITDA is concerned, the growth was equal to 8 million. This result was given both by the waste disposal  and by waste collection due to the reasons that I illustrated just a few moments ago.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: I think it would be interesting to look at the volume trends because in this area, we had some differences. If you  look at the table on the left-hand side of the page, you'll notice that urban waste even in the second quarter and  overall in the first half, show a trend which is in contraction vis-à-vis the previous year. As we had seen at the end  of the previous quarter, the contraction was at 2% whereas now, we're at 2.9.  Please take into account that last year, we had had a significant growth vis-à-vis. The previous year was a growth  equal to 6%. So, obviously, as far as these figures are concerned, there is some adjustment phenomenon. But there  are also some effects based on the more general economic scenario because keep in mind that within urban waste  collection, we also have the waste which is generated by commercial activities, which as you know, are the ones  that are suffering the most currently.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And also on the same page, you'll notice that our infrastructure certainly brought about a further evolution as far  as the group's ability to dispose off waste. Our waste energy plants increased their contribution to the total by 4%  and I think it's important to see this figure especially as far as urban part of waste is concerned because most of  the waste disposed of in our incinerators, is urban waste

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Of the approximately 490 million tonnes was disposed off in waste energy plants, we have a significant portion of  this – this is urban waste, solid urban waste which represents 40% of the overall waste collected. This is a  significant figure which, again, illustrates the direction we're going in which is very much consistent with EU  legislation.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Even the figures on composting which is at 10% and growing vis-à-vis in the previous year, composting is only  limited to urban waste and if we compare it to the overall volume of Urban Waste, this is a figure which is equal to  20%. This is also the result of the development of the collection model that we're applying on the territory which is  now up to sorted waste collection which is at 50%, almost 50%.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As our chairman was mentioning, the contribution to the results of this activity also came from the joint venture  with Enomondo from the biomass point of view, and that plant is on stream as of January 1 and we have been able  to fully benefit from this new plant, which is of a sizeable dimension, which is equal to 120,000 tonnes of biomass  per year.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to the water business on page six, you'll notice that there is a confirmation of last year's results, which  is very much consistent with the volumes, which as you can see are the same, from one year to the next. That's  approximately 120 million cubic meters distributed both in 2010 and 2011. We were able to benefit from a tariff  increase equal to 2.7% in line with the agreements we signed with the local authorities, which are effective up to  2012, which can be further lengthened into Modena area.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And besides the tariff increases, we had some additional costs, especially as far as the cost of electricity is  concerned. As you know, between last year and this year, there was a significant increase in that cost.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to page seven and moving on to energy, the two areas of energy which had a very – some very exciting  growth as we had seen in the initial months of the year. Our results in terms of EBITDA were up by 11%, from  €109 million to €120 million. This result is, for the most part, due to the activities, thanks to our commercial area.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As we had already mentioned at the end of the first quarter but also in commenting the results of 2010, the  benefits from the procurement policy that we have in the gas business policy we've been working on for the past  years which is contributing very importantly in a condition in which the market is quite long and therefore it  offers those companies who are present from a commercial point of view who actually optimize on their  procurement costs.  The result could have been even better had the climate conditions in 2011 been similar to the ones in 2010, but I  don't think that we can actually – I think we can be quite satisfied with the results nevertheless.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: We're seeing some good trends from the commercial side of things and therefore, there has been a shifting  between the results we have had last year in the trading sector specifically from April and May onwards towards  commercial activities with a positive result equal to a plus €10 million. And out of the €120 million of these sales  activities that almost had the same importance as the gas distribution figures. The only anticipation I'd like to  make as far as this business area is concerned is that we signed the procurement contracts for the year to come  with some satisfactory conditions indeed.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to the electricity side of our business, even here we had a significant growth, which is similar to the one  we saw in the gas sector, equal to €10.5 million. Two or three elements contributed to this growth. First of all the  growth of our customer base, equal to 100,000 customers from one year to the next, and of these 100,000  customers, 30,000 stemmed from our safeguard, salvaguardia area, whereas the remaining customers are  customers we were able to conquer from our commercial area. And this reflects the difference between the new  customers and customers lost. And we knew that we had about 5,000 to 6,000 new customers per month.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: 4.8 of terra-watt hours sold, approximately 60% are sold on the liberalized market whereas the remaining part is  – belongs to the salvaguardia services or approximately 1 terra-watt hour under waste is on the regulated market.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Water continues to have an investment level which is fairly stable, given the simple fact that it consistently reflects  the agreements signed with local authorities and it brings about the tariff increases that we already saw, whereas  there has been a significant decrease in the waste area which is going from phase in which we had a significant  amount of investment on plants and we're now shifting to actually exploiting the plants that we built.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: We are a sound group. Our operational results are in front of you and we will continue work towards our – the  development we have in mind. We will continue working on this in the months ahead also to prepare next year.  Mr. Venier was making a comment on the investment made in the waste sector, for instance, in that sector, in the

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: For instance, we are working to increase our position as far as sorted waste is concerned, we are to continue  working on composting through digesters. We have a number of initiatives that we'll be working on in the months  and years ahead as foreseen by the business plan and similar explanations can be given as far as the other sectors  are concerned and this gives us an idea of our orderly growth. This is the message that we very much wanted to  share with you and hopefully, it will be understood because frankly, we feel that the current stock price is below  our expectations. We can't even understand why the stock price is what it is. And in our figures in, our financial  figures, we didn't even consider that possible impact of the Robin tax and the news we've read today in the  newspapers show that it will and not including the possible outcome of the Robin tax because the situation is still  being discussed, meaning that certain judgments in the sector are sometimes negative, regardless of the true  context that the sector is going through.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And I'd like to add that we're also close to the completion of the tender for the Florence waste-to-energy plant, the  initiative that you were familiar with and the commission will be beginning its assessments on September 9.

file: HER - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 28August2012 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: In terms of the contribution to the growth, the results are very much linked to an excellent performance in the  energy sector, which is, for the most part, linked to the good results coming in from the gas sector that Mr. Venier  will be going into in greater detail, both in terms of sales and trading and the margins that this business was able  to produce.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Obviously, the cold weather helped us in the first half for a short albeit intense period. And together with this, we  had a performance in the electricity business which, even though there was a reduction in volumes in the market,  which also had an impact on us compared in the previous year, nevertheless, this phenomenon has been reduced  by increasing the customer base as we had already done in the previous quarters.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Another good result is coming in from the water business, which posted a good growth which was linked for the  most part to the tariff increase which had been decided in the past. As you know, this is the last year in which  more than half of our contracts have. Therefore, in this past few months we have an increase in tariffs which was  able to recover the time it took to actually update the tariffs.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: In terms of our investments, we continued the careful selection that we have committed ourselves to over the past  two years. We've gone down from the €130 million of last year to €121 million. And the free-floating element is  further limited even though we're already seeing the first effects of the earthquake which had an impact on a  number of municipalities, especially in the Modena and Ferrara provinces.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Moving on to other elements of the balance sheet, revenues have gone up by 15.4% vis-à-vis the previous year.  Obviously there is an effect of the prices of commodities, especially in the energy sector. There was the increase of  gas volumes that I've previously referred to. We also had a small part which is also due to a hike in tariffs.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: We have also have the effects of four acquisitions in the renewable sector, in the solar sector, which were then  integrated into our company, into our renewable energies company. And in this item we also have a positive  contribution from a real estate sale, which is the last step in terms of the rationalization process that we conducted  over the past two years on the company's real estate. This allowed us to gain value from an asset we had here in  Bologna which was – where we have the largest deficits both from the point of view of the holdings headquarters  and the operational structures headquarters, who were also working on completing this activity as well.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as the breakdown by strategic areas is concerned, you'll notice that in terms of percentages and growth, the  main part comes from the almost 25% growth in the energy businesses' sales. And as far as the networks are  concerned, we have had a good increase to almost €160 million of EBITDA from the €148 million posted last year.  I'd just like to focus on a point that we feel very strongly about as far as our commitment is concerned, which is  how we are dealing with the market issues and the waste business.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as waste is concerned, we have two main phenomena which were already illustrated. On one hand, as we've  already said a number of times, we've had, at the end of CIP6 – expiry of CIP6 which at the end of the year will be  equal to some €18 million approximately. We've already paid for the first half in the first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: But regardless of this, as we can see, the result that the division has posted has had a limited contraction to minus  €13-point-something million. If we take away the €8 million or €9 million linked to subsidies, you'll see that we  have reduced this downturn significantly, and this is proof of the fact that we continue being very active in this  division. This area of business, which continues to contribute stably also in terms of disposing of urban waste,  which guarantees a good flow besides the subsidies on renewables.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
