And this allowed us to increase the  flows of dry waste that can be recycled, which is paper, cardboard, glass and so on and so forth.  And at the same time, we also grew the moist components, which could then be used in the  biofermentation plants that we built over the past two years.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In terms of our assets, as I was saying, we have the new Rimini plant, which went on stream in  June 2010. And keep in mind that in the initial months of work, we plan to use the boiler for the  production of electricity which belonged to the old plant. But beginning in early March of this year,       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 4 the new boiler, the new alternator and turbines were used which has a capacity equals to 13  megawatt hours in terms of electricity.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Also as far as our asset is concerned, we are now shareholders of the Enomondo Company, which  is a company which at the end of last year started up a biomass plant with 120,000 ton capacity, of  which we had acquired 40% initially, and at the end of January we increased our participation up to  50%. In terms of the production of electricity from these plants has now reached 530 gigawatt  hours, which gave a significant contribution to the production of energy from renewables, and in our  Group this represents 30% of the overall production.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: As far as the side of the business which pertains to regulated activities, in other words waste  collection and street cleaning, in this case we had an increase in tariff equal to 3.4%, which  represents an increase in revenues of €400,000. These industrial components brought about the  results of €195 million in terms of EBITDA for 2010, which grew by €8 million compared to the  previous year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on to the results of the water business, in this case the most significant elements we were  able to appreciate in this business is on one side the contraction in terms of volume of  approximately 1%, which was represented by a very rainy summer season, which therefore had an  impact on the volumes consumed during the months of the year in which there is highest  consumption, and not only due to the climate, but also because during the summer we had an extra  level of consumption which is determined by the flow of tourists on the Adriatic Coast, but we also  had increases in terms of tariff and in terms of efficiency.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The good performance on costs was also accompanied by a further improvement in terms of  management because leakage dropped down to 25%, whereas the national average is 35%. And  all of this was accompanied by reduced investments, which for the first time in several years went  below the €100 million threshold and are now equal to €94 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Moving on to the performance of the energy businesses, in other words gas and electricity, the  result of the gas area is striking. It improved from the €174 million EBITDA last year to €193 million,  so it’s almost €20 million more. And this improvement, as Mr. Tommasi was saying, derives from  the performance of our commercial activities, which were able to benefit from the general context.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Even the climate made its contribution. The cold we had in the two winter quarters at the beginning  and end of the year had an impact on the distributed volumes, which increased by some 70%,  equal to 2.5 billion cubic meters, which is in line with the national leverage. But this was  accompanied by a growth in the sold volumes equal to 4% approximately, up to 2.9 billion cubic  meters. This was directed to the commercial area through end users, but also as far as supplying  some thermoelectric plants.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: And another element of growth was given by district heating. As the Chairman was mentioning,  among the components of our organic growth we also had the full regime of the plants, among       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 5 which we had to say the Imola plant, which in 2010 was able to work for the first time for the entire  year. And this had an impact on the district heating sales, which grew by 12%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The final element I’d like to highlight is that we were also able to produce energy from renewable  sources, with initiatives on the territory equal to 3 megawatts. The final element I would like to  comment on vis-à-vis our performance is the one which pertains to our investments. We have  already said a number of times that this would have been the first year after a number of years we  focused on development.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Again our goal of this year was to invest less than €350 million and that’s how it was at the end of  the year. Our investment was equal to €342 million, which was distributed in the various business  areas as you can see on page eight of our presentation. And in all of the areas of business, we had  a contraction in investment. And on the waste business, this was due to the completion of our  plants in the water sector and this was due to the effect of a number of initiatives that were  completed in the previous years within the framework of the development programs, which were  defined with the local authorities, whereas in the other sectors, this was due to the maintenance of  our networks.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We were able to optimize our accrued provisions vis-à-vis the energy networks. And as a  consequence of this, we were able to take advantage of accrued provisions for the quality of credit,  which as we’re recovering from the crisis we had in 2009. So this is an effect we have to take into  account as an extraordinary effect indeed.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 7 Also in light of the ambition we have of continuing to grow also externally, and one of the cases that  Mr. Venier mentioned in the waste business and in other cases that we are assessing and  managing, one of which may already be highlighted in the gas sector in the weeks ahead. These  are further elements that strengthen our belief that our future forecasts are fully feasible.

file: HER - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 22March2012 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: The results show a growth that has been supported by all of the business areas, and especially, as we'll be seeing  later on in the details, we have had a significant growth coming in from the energy sectors, thanks to our  commercial developments and thanks to the purchase policies we've had in terms of procuring raw materials.  Some further positive elements of the financial statement include a positive cash flow performance along the lines  that we had illustrated in our business plan and also very much in line with the reduction in investments which  had, obviously, already been announced which are at €319 million for 2011. And we had a net financial position  equal to about €1,987 million which improved compared to the previous quarter.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Today, the council also approved the budget and we also approved the proposed dividend which we had  announced in March 2011 and it is at €0.09 per share. All of these elements plus another element which had a  significant impact in terms of the growth of our energy business which is the growth of our customer base. If we  look beginning in 2007 onwards, we have had an increase of 300,000 customers in the energy sectors and this  obviously brings about the increase of an often overlooked factor which is the wealth represented by these  customers, which has grown to – grown 10% up to €280 million based on market value.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as the sectors are concerned, Mr. Venier will be going into them in greater detail. But looking at the 10  years, we have a clear picture of the growth we've had in all of our business sectors and we have three sectors that  are above €150 million and up to €200 million in terms of the contribution they make to EBITDA, namely water,  gas, and waste. And then we have a separate line of growth represented by power, electricity which has started  from scratch 10 years ago and which now contributes over €73 million to the company's overall results. But just to  summarize based on the total trends and the total results, you can appreciate a stability in the performance the  company has had also vis-à-vis our competitors.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Now, having said that, let's look to the results that we've obtained to-date. In terms of revenues, we've had 11.3%  growth with a contribution coming in from the enhancement of tariffs, from energy prices, especially, as far as gas  is concerned and also due to the growth of the volumes in the various sectors.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: If we turn to page four and look at the contribution from the usual drivers, we can say that there is no real news in  the sense that the three main components of our typical growth are present yet again. We have a significant  contribution coming from organic growth of within which the contribution of our energy activity was very  significant because EBITDA grew from €107 million to €138 million. We have had the effect of new plants which  basically refers to the full capacity of the Rimini waste-to-energy plant, the last one that was completed in 2010.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: And finally, as far as M&A is concerned, we had two operations which, again, as of January 1 and then July 1  respectively. The first is the joint venture, the Enomondo joint venture. It's a biomass plant which was started at  the beginning of 2011. And the second case is the merger of Sadori Gas into Hera Comm Marche as of July 1.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: And if we look to these growth values and refer to the strategic areas, the areas that our business plan is based on,  we can appreciate that the effects of each of these strategic areas has become more homogenous in the sense that  the relative importance of energy over the past four years, the years of the crisis went from 9.5% to 21% of our  total results and it decreased the contribution coming in from our networks, therefore, from the regulated areas  and waste which went from 35% to 30% in terms of its impact on growth. This is obviously due to the three-fold  growth over the past four years that energy has been able to give us.

texts.speaker: Luca Moroni
texts.profession: Group Director-Administration, Finance & Control, Hera SpA
texts.text: Investments were made in the main business areas of the company it operates in and more specifically to the  regulated areas which are 56% of the total CapEx. All of the investments were completed in terms of introducing  electricity smart meters, and we also further enhanced our district heating networks, again, as expected by the  business plans. Therefore, our investments are in line with the development that the company had in mind with a  special focus on rationalizing and limiting investments so that we can achieve a sustainable level of investment  also from a financial standpoint.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As you know, we had already had the chance to comment on these issues in the past quarter results, and as you  know in 2011, we felt some of the effects of the economic crisis, especially in the second half of the year.  Nonetheless, our results were stable. We had an EBITDA equal to some €194 million with a slight contraction  compared to the previous year equal to €1 million. Obviously, this is a performance which is a first slowdown  compared to the previous years and that was simply driven by the volumes. And as you can see in the table, the  second table, the volumes [ph] treated (22:02) by 3rd parties, in other words, urban waste and special waste  contracted by approximately 2.6%. And in this case, it was higher in urban waste rather than special waste, and  this may come as a surprise. The reason isn't necessarily linked to the overall trends. The reason is that whereas in  terms of urban waste, we are limited by territorial elements, whereas as far as – and in terms of special waste,  we've been able to tackle things with a more aggressive commercial approach.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Now, these dynamics also reflect significant industrial decisions because as you can see in the lower part of the  table, the waste treated and waste energy plant have increased and this is obviously – it obviously has an effect on  the use of landfills. So, obviously, a choice made to be able to use our assets but because they are able to obviously  to dispose of the waste, but at the same time, they can also create electricity, which benefits from incentives.  As a consequence, this has also brought about the fact that we didn't lose any value, and we were able to keep  some of the value which is intrinsic in the landfills for the years ahead in which, hopefully, the market will recover.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as the second component of this business is concerned, there is consistent efficiency with what we have seen  in terms of our business plans and tariffs have grown by 3.3% on average in our territory which is in line with our  expectations. As you know, a part of all this is linked to costs and partly it is linked to the size of services. Services  and collection has improved and therefore we've been able to increase our sorted waste collection which on  average on the entire territory allowed us to go beyond the 50% threshold. Meaning that as of 2011, the Hera  Group was able to recycle over half of the waste it collects.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: The final important element I'd like to focus on with you after a few months is the waste-to-energy project in  Florence. As you know, we were assigned the tender. Within the next few days we will be creating the company in  partnership with the local operator called Quadrifoglio and this will bring about the process in order to obtain  authorizations in order to be able to structure a financing and everything which is necessary in order to actually  build the plant. We have already made some significant steps. We are waiting for the final decisions to be made  from a legislative point of view in terms of incentives so that we can continue working on this very important  project in a region in Tuscany which lacks similar infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to the water business. In this case, something comparable to the waste sector from a tariff point of view  is the increase equal to 3.4%, which we had already seen in the initial nine months of the year. This is, again, very  much in line with the forecast of the – with the tariff plans we had and negotiated with the authorities. Within our  territory, we had agreements which cover all of 2012 and then in two territories which are the most important  ones, the ones that have the largest amount of clients that these agreements go on to 2014 and 2015 respectively.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Meaning that in 2011 and 2012 there is full compliance with the initial agreements that we had signed with the  local authorities. And, therefore, we can wait for the drafting of the new tariff schemes and the decision on the  new authority in the sector. We – in the Water sector, we've had an increase equal to 1.2% in the volume of water  distributed in our aqueducts.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: In Waste, the contraction of urban waste is an exception to the rule of the last few years whereas in the water, this  significant growth is an exception to the trends we've seen in the past few years and – over the past few years this  depends from the cyclical nature and the droughts that we have every once in a while. Last year if on one hand we  suffered due to the heat we have and we had endured the impact it had on the energy businesses, obviously, in the  water business, due to that same heat and drought, we had a chance to increase the volume sold.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to pa ge nine, the gas business. We have a number of different elements here. The first that I'd like to  underline and which goes back to the common thread in that – that the Chairman was mentioning vis-à-vis our  history, as you've seen in the past few years, we always had a race between the waste and gas sectors. Last year,  waste had won whereas in 2011 gas is once again the leader with its €208.7 million in terms of EBITDA with a  growth equal to 7.6% compared to the previous year and we had €100 million coming in from distribution, €90  million from sales, and we also had the contribution coming in from district heating.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: District heating is the activity which suffered the most due to the mild winter, due to the higher average  temperatures we had especially in the last quarter of the year and that's due to the fact that differently from gas, a  sector in which distribution activity is actually sterilized, that the cyclicality linked to weather isn't the same in  district heating. Therefore, the results actually illustrate these dynamics. Based on all this, if we look at the  volumes, what can we actually observe? Well, we've had a total amount of volumes sold to third parties which is  above €3 billion, it's at €3.3 billion actually. €1.2 billion of this was represented by the Hera trading wholesale  have an impact compared to the previous year and significantly at that because we had a contraction equal to 120  million cubic meters, nonetheless, the results were quite satisfactory.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And then a final element that I'd like to underline is the one linked to our customers and in the Marche region  especially is a territory in which we were able to achieve some very satisfactory results. Obviously, in that region,  we don't simply have expectations vis-à-vis gas where we have 120,000 customers, but we can also have  customers coming in from electricity with a dual fuel offer. In the Marche region three years ago, we had zero  customers.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Now, we are close to 28,000 customers which means there is a one-to-four ratio compared to gas customers, and  this is yet a further proof of the fact that we have a very lively approach, which can also be seen on page 10 where  we can see that the electricity business was able to make a significant leap forward, probably one of the most  significant leaps in our history and we're at €73 million EBITDA with a growth which is above €13 million vis-à- vis 2010. Now, in commenting this figure, three factors need to be underlined, the first of which is the growth in  the free market which net of switching and new of switching from the salvaguardia market equal to 50,000  customers which is a significant number indeed, contribution to this came from the activity in the salvaguardia  sector, which as you know from the beginning of the year covers six territories vis-à-vis the previous three  territories with the one further terawatt per hour sold and these combined elements allowed us to reach year end  at 480,000 customers and according to the figures we were looking at today, we are close to reaching 0.5 million  customers.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Third factor which needs to be taken into account in looking at these figures is that, as you know, within this  activity we also have the generation activities. We have power generation assets. Therefore, the results you're  looking at is also the offspring of the reabsorption of that production percentage that as you know in 2011 but also,  currently, suffers from an overcapacity situation and there's a pressure on pricing as you are all aware of.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And I'd also like to mention what Mr. Venier just said, we've had an increase in our customer base which does  have an effect both in electricity and in gas. Therefore, my first remark is that if we look at our business plan  carefully, these targets could have been gas, so it's a way of confirming the reliability of our choices.

file: HER - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 22March2013 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Now, these were the two driving sectors in terms of the results obtained, but I'd also like to underline the fact that  despite a difficult start in 2012 in the waste business, the waste business was able to progressively improve its  performance throughout the year with a very positive fourth quarter. We are very proud of underlining this  because this is what we intend to base our forecast for the initial months of 2013 on. Now take into account that  year on year compared to 2011, we posted some negative figures, but we also need to specifically take into  account the effects of the expiry of the CIP6 in Bologna, which was implemented as of January 1, 2012, had an  impact which was much higher than the results that we are looking at in comparison to the previous year. Had we  not had the expiry of CIP6, even the waste business would have posted a positive result for 2012. This was a  signal that many of you were expecting since, many of you often ask us if the difficulties on the market over the  past few years will still continue to last or if there has been some sign of recovery.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: The first issue refers to the acquisition of a very important plant in the waste business. This was an asset that  entered the company structure only in the last quarter of the year. And this operation had an impact on the net  financial position as if they had been working for us for the entire year. Therefore, obviously, this is an element  that needs to be taken into account.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Having said that, not only do we have some positive news in terms of our figures, but also in political terms, we  continue to expand our customer base according to the targets we had. Even though the level of competition has  grown, but on the market and the energy business, we have added a further 62,000 customers, which are a  sizable amount indeed. We also made significant efforts in terms of saving on costs and on increasing efficiency  in our structures. This is something that we always looked into, but which we looked into specifically in 2012,  which allowed us to bring home a significant review of our organizational structure, the effects of which will be  visible in the coming years besides being visible in 2012. This refers to the regulated part of our business and our  territorial structures.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: The second component of these accruals refers to the decisions of the authority, of the regulator concerning the  amounts that have to be refunded or reimbursed following the outcome of the referendum for the six months  between the referendum on water and the moment in which the transitional period starts for the new regulatory  framework that the regulator has drafted. These two elements brought about a specific accrual of provisions,  which had an impact on the EBIT figures.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: On the same graph, on the left-hand side, you can see a representation of the effects of the expiry of the FEA –  CIP6 is something we've been stressing throughout the year. It's expiry of CIP6 on the Bologna, which is the  energy plant. If you consider that, as of January 1, this subsidy expired, it was a subsidy we'd had in previous  years and if we added up to the results in our financial statement, you'll notice that this is yet another amount that  has always been present in our history. As you can see, the €35 million in growth were once again achieved.  Therefore, if we add up this figure with the remaining items that brought about last year's growth. These are the  figures that we work on a daily basis, these are fundamentals and knowing that for 11 years now, we've been  growing €35 million to €40 million every year confirms that we are still convinced of being able to reach our  ambitious target for the business plan, even in the years ahead.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: One final remark, if you look at the bottom graph, refers to the topic I was mentioning a few minutes ago. We had  varying performances, albeit positive ones, in the various business areas. As far as energy is concerned, we had  a €13 million growth; in the networks, our growth was equal to €16 million. In the waste business, we had a  decrease equal to €10 million compared to the previous year; but again, €18 million out of this €10 million, refer to  the expiry of the CIP6 incentives that I mentioned a few minutes ago. Therefore, as you can see, our operational  efforts and the results obtained by each of these areas was positive in all three cases and it was absolutely  consistent with our track record.

texts.speaker: Luca Moroni
texts.text: Good afternoon. As far as cash flows are concerned, as we've already said, the major changes, vis-à-vis the  company's forecasts in its budget and its business plan, stem from two extraordinary events. One refers to  acquisitions and one refers to the group's working capital. In fact, we had expected a growth of our working capital  due to the effects of the overall scenario and this forecast of ours was also accompanied by a further €50 million  to €60 million, for the most part stemming from credits from those customers residing and the municipalities  affected by the earthquake, the earthquake which happened last May.

texts.speaker: Luca Moroni
texts.text: And on this item, the regulator has intervened by allowing a delay, a 24-month delay for these credits. We are  going along with this postponement and we have been receiving these monthly installments. We've also had a  delay in the payment of certain Green Certificates, which were then received in February, last February, which  accounts for some €10 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Good evening. Let's begin, yeah, business-by-business breakdown with the Waste business as usual. I won't be  commenting the EBITDA result, you can see it on the slide. What I would like to focus on is the quarter-by-quarter  dynamics for such activity. As we mentioned in the introduction, we find comfort in analyzing the performance in  the different quarters in 2012, both for urban waste and special waste and specifically in special waste where we  had had the sharpest decline, we have seen Q4 in 2012, which made a significant comeback vis-à-vis the  previous year, posting a plus 20%, which means over 75,000 tonnes. A part of this are obviously linked to the  acquisition of Energonut that accounts for some 20% to 25%. The rest refers to the commercial activities, which  were implemented throughout 2012.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As you may remember, our commercial activities had already shown some effects in Q3 and these were  consolidated in Q4. We also had some positive signals in the urban waste business in the last quarter of the year  also compared to a very negative Q4 in 2011.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: The treatment of special waste during the final weeks of the year allowed us to have a rate of some 9,000 tonnes  per week, vis-à-vis the 7,000 tonnes we had at the beginning of the year. The result of the waste business also  shows a good performance of the waste collection activities, which benefited from a 3.4% tariff increase, with  some good results in terms of sorted collection, which is at approximately 52%, meaning that we are at  percentages that are significantly higher compared to the national average, and they are especially relevant when  compared to the amount of customers, the amount of inhabitants we cover, which are above 2.5 million, meaning  that we're the largest company, vis-a-vis the territorial presence.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And the remaining part of the waste obviously goes to our waste-to-energy plants, which have been churning on  regularly and they have been working at full capacity throughout the year, and this has allowed us to further  increase the amount of renewable energy that was generated, which is now at approximately 700 gigawatts per  hour.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: On page 6, the Water business, the second component of our portfolio, the water business showed a stable  consumption level in 2012 vis-à-vis 2011, although it posted further growth and profitability brought about by the  progressive recovery of profitability in this business, which is clearly shown in the lower left-hand graph. As you  can see, there was a gradual and constant growth. This was also accompanied by an improvement in the quality  of service, by some actions aimed at saving on costs and also by a gradual tariff increase. And last year, we had  an increase equal to approximately 6.7%. And in 2012, we also benefited from some of the major investments we  made in previous years.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: I think it's also worthy to note that as far as investments in the water business are concerned, which is Hera  business that requires the most investment. In 2012, we invested €93 million approximately, which is a  significantly lower figure compared to the €100 or €110 million, which we had in the previous years.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: This is due to a number of reasons, but most importantly, the new tariff scheme recognizes a component of  working capital that previous schemes did not recognize, and we also have an adequate coverage on certain cost  items, which in the past also brought about a reduction in the business profitability, and I'm referring specifically to  the consumption of electricity during the three years suffered from cost effects, which were very high due to the  effects of the expiry of incentives on renewable energy, which had an impact on this tariff. We're waiting for the  final approval of this new system and we expect it to be approved by the end of April, so that we can then look at  the next four years with a reasonable optimism.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving onto the Gas business, it was an important year for us. This isn't anything new. This was something that  had already been highlighted in the previous three quarters. We confirmed the trends of the expectations we had  in this area. As you can see here, we're referring both to sales and the distribution of gas. Out of the €240 million  EBITDA we posted in 2012, which shows an improvement equal to €32 million compared to the previous year,  €110 million refer to our commercial activities, including trading, a further €111 million refer to gas distribution,  which improved by €5 million compared to the previous year, and €19 million refer to the district heating activity  which due to the thermal season, which was very cold in 2012, especially first month of the year, was able to post  a €2 million increase.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: In terms of volumes, as you can see, the volumes sold grew by approximately 5%. This is mainly due to the fact  that our trading activities increased somewhat. The trading activity managed 1.4 billion cubic meters. A major  portion of this went to the wholesale market. 300 million cubic meters went to the thermoelectric market. And  then, there was a portion which was provided to the commercial company. Our customers are at over 1.1 million.  Now, this is a figure, which deserves to be appreciated if you consider that we have a customer base, which is  very highly concentrated in our territories.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Our synergies and organic growth average for each year was reached in 2012 as well. We also made a significant  effort on waste also from the commercial standpoint and that too is starting to show some significant results. We  have continued to increase the amount of our electricity customers. That is also part of a long lasting policy now.

file: HER - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 20March2014 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Let's go into the things which happened. We had a shift in perimeter with AcegasAps, but we also had a number of  other important signals as far as the business areas are concerned. Certainly, we felt the initial positive impacts of  the water regulatory system reform. Despite some of our concerns, we were able to do well in the energy sector,  which as you know is currently affected by a number of issues in the generation field, some of which are very  serious indeed. Within it, it also has the effects of the initial cut set by the authority, and which then also affected  the gas distribution area.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Despite all this, even in that sector we are able to say that the results posted were positive. We don't want to hide  the fact that the past three summers' the temperature [ph] something to (3:53) refer to as far as gas is concerned,  but that's something we'll be going into.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as waste is concerned, we have other good news. As you know, we had had a second half of the year in 2013.  On a number of occasions I had already said that the initial figures in 2013 were in line with the growth in 2013,  and I'm referring to the major recovery we've had in waste activities.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: This is a recovery which is also linked with the broadening of our territorial presence for waste disposal, but  there's also been a recovery as far as our commercial activities are concerned, something we are focusing on a  great deal to continue to grow. But the figures we can boast in terms of volumes for the year 2013 are sizable  figures, which leave the difficulties that Hera had had in the previous two years behind us.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Waste is certainly very relevant indeed, with a plus 13% growth, with a good recovery. We had a good performance  in networks, thanks to the fact that they are a fully regulated area of business. The only two uncertainties as far as  the future is concerned is the actual calendar with which we will be dealing with the gas tenders, and we'll be  talking about that later. But, having already covered the water sector and as we wait for the upcoming tenders, I  don't think there are very many doubts vis-à-vis our global forecast.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As you can see, from one year to the other, we had a growth of EBITDA from €662 million to €831 million, and  this basically due to €414 million for networks, €47 0 million for energy and waste for €238 million. The mix  between regulated and liberalised activities is fairly constant. It's €56 million regulated to €44 million liberalised,  and therefore this is a constant element which is present, and the AcegasAps integration hasn't changed that,  since that company's portfolio, as we've underlined a number of times, is very similar to the portfolio that Hera  already had.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Obviously, due to the shift in perimeter, all of the business areas in these three groups have grown, and we'll be  going into the details for each of them, going into each component which then contributed to the growth. The  other relevant element in looking at the general 2013 overview is the size of our customer base which, as we had  already mentioned recently when we were illustrating the third quarter results, our customer base is at  approximately 2 million, with 700,000 customers in electricity and over 1.2 million in the gas business, equal to  1.94 million customers.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to page six, the networks area, this page has the breakdowns for the different businesses. In general  terms, the results in this area have improved by €104 million, of which, as you can see, €88 million refer to the  shift in perimeter from the AcegasAps operation and €60 million stem from the organic growth. In analyzing  organic growth, nevertheless, within these variations, we have some very positive results, such as t he ones we  recorded in water, which account to some €19 million, most of which refers to Hera Group's organic growth, and a  smaller portion of that came about from the AcegasAps contribution.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as electricity distribution, the growth was more modest, €2 million. The remaining €15 million out of the  total €17 million refer to the shift in perimeter, whereas in gas distribution, we had a slight contraction equal to a  few million euros. Again, as far as the results of these activities are concerned, ther e was a negative impact  stemming from the overall context since, once again, the contribution stemming from new meters set in new  households declined by some 3 million units compared to the previous year.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: One of the more relevant elements in this area and the shift between 2013 and 2014 is a better visibility as far as  tariffs are concerned. In 2013 and in early 2014, we had an adjustment on electricity distribution tariffs that will  also be covering 2015. You're all familiar with the new definition of the gas distribution tariffs as of the beginning  of this year. And also, as far as the water business is concerned, just last week a decision was made which confirms  most of the tariff hikes for 2012 and 2013, plus a definition of the framework for the 2014 a nd 2015 tariff  increases.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Going into an analysis of the business, 2012 we had an EBITDA equal to €184 million for Hera standalone, €50  million of which referred to waste collection and the remaining portion referred to waste disposal. Contribution  brought about by AcegasAps is equal to €36 million, and from a certain point of view, organic growth is striking,  and that accounts for €60 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: There are also some elements which characterize these figures. First of all, the volumes, as you can see in the  lower right-hand corner, there has been a slight contraction in terms of the comparable perimeter in urban waste,  with a very modest amount at around 1%, while, as I was saying, the special waste business was a little livelier.  And in the special waste business we are now almost practically at the levels of urban waste.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And prior to the crisis, you may recall that in the Hera perimeter, our breakdown between urban and special waste  was very similar, and actually special waste perhaps was even slightly above urban waste volumes, were at 1.8  billion (sic) [million] (24:03) for each of these two sectors. With the crisis, we had been to 1.5 million – excuse me,  1.5 million tonnes, whereas now we are back to some 2 million tonnes, with the growth equal to 160,000 tonnes  we had in 2013.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Also, in terms of the contribution of electricity production, we had some major variations, and we were now able  to achieve 1 terawatt per hour of electricity which was generated by plants in the waste area. Therefore, these are  plants which offer renewable energy. This 300 gigawatts per hour refer to 200 gigawatts per hour by AcegasAps,  and 100 gigawatts per hour refer to the production in the [indiscernible] Hera (25:05) perimeter, and in this case  we have the start-up and full functioning of the two new biodigesters that were up and running for almost the  entire year 2013, plus the optimization of the use with the energy plants, which brought about further production.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And I'd like to underline the fact that we are now above 1 million tonnes treated, which, together with the  AcegasAps volumes, allows the group to have managed 1.4 million tonnes of waste in these types of plants,  meaning that the growth was almost equal to 50% vis-à-vis what was posted in 2012.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to energy, as you know and as we've repeated a number of times, this refer s to the commercial  activities within the energy businesses. Within those figures, due to the nature of our portfolio, we have gas  activities for the most part; €110 million in our EBITDA refer to gas activities. And we have a sizable growth in our  commercial activities in our sales in electricity, beginning the results in 2012 equal to €26 million; at the end of  2013, it posted €40 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Going into the different dynamics, supply and trading activities posted positive contributions in gas and  electricity, and these two figures which are similar in absolute terms are very different in terms of their specific  components. In the gas sales, the contribution of AcegasAps was equal to some €14 million, with a net growth of  €11.6 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: This means that the Hera perimeter, given the effect of the shifts in the regulation and given the contraction of the  opportunity on the trading market, posted a negative effect equal to a €2 million, whereas in the electricity sales  and trading, the €13 million have a €3 million contribution from Acegas, whereas the rest is optimization of  marginalities on the portfolio. A minus sign for production, obviously, this is the minus sign characterizes all of  these types of activities in Italy. As far as we're concerned, we are doing better than our peers. The other services,  as you may recall, are heat and industrial cogeneration activities which are a complement to the group's  commercial activities.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as the customer base is concerned, I already introduced the overall picture . As far as volumes are  concerned, certainly the gas sector had some major shifts because, as we already mentioned, the weather wasn't  simply warm at the beginning of this year, but it was also warm at the end of last year. Therefore, in general terms,  comparing the figures to the previous years, the climate effect reduced the volumes in terms of sales by some 60  million cubic meters, most of which refer to the year's last quarter.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: There's also another important element which deserves to be underlined in the commenting, the lower right-hand  graph on page eight. Besides our contraction in trading activities equal to €440 million, we have to focus on the  mix which account for the 2.2 billion cubic meters of gas sold. Within the 2.2 million (sic) [billion] (29 :11) cubic  meters, we have a portion which refers to purely residential market which accounts for 1 billion cubic meters, and  to date, over 50% of the volumes are linked to three market contracts vis-à-vis the more regulated contracts.

file: HER - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 25March2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: But besides the more visible elements, what I do want to remind you of is that as far as the difficult year is  concerned, as far as the weather is concerned, had we not had the mild climate, our figures would have been  even higher, which is something that leads us to be confident, as far as how the group can continue to grow. The  reasons why our performance we feel has been a brilliant one, besides the figures, is also due to a qualitative  aspects. And actually from the point of view of a number of profiles, we performed above our expectations.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: The second qualitative aspect, which isn't new, although it did consolidate in the 2014 results, is that the  contribution to our results came about from all of the four main business areas with a proportion which actually  mirrors the prevalent contribution from the regulated areas which are now at around 55% of our EBITDA.  Although there hasn't been a compression, so to speak, there has been no shift in the liberalized businesses and  thanks to the contribution of the electricity sector with the acquisition of new clients. And also thanks to the good  performance in terms of volumes from the waste side of things, we were able to make sure that 45% of our results  came from the liberalized businesses.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: There are certainly a number of other factors which in a comparison with our peers, underscore our results such  as, for instance, the limited negative impacts that the past choices have on our business as far as the power  generation is concerned. Power generation obviously has a more sizable impact on other players.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: If we take a quick look at the figures, in general terms, I don't think there isn't much to say before we go into the  business-by-business breakdown. We certainly had a reduction, a further reduction in terms of revenues. From  this point of view, it was due to the impact that I was mentioning concerning the climate, the weather throughout  the year because it covers two parts of winter both in the spring and at the end of the year, both of which were  mild. Plus, we also have the decrease in commodity prices, which certainly had an influence on the overall  revenue's performance.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Financial burdens were also good. Remember the Green Bond operation, which was the most significant  operation in 2014. We were able to reduce the cost of debt even though at the same time this value, this figure  was more limited in the actual sum compared to the contribution coming from other connected activities or  connected companies. Through rationalization, we were able to reduce the number of smaller companies we had  a stake in, and therefore, their contribution on the company's activities plus a reduction in the financial burdens as  a whole.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: A final remark from the quality standpoint, which is something that I'm not particularly fond of on page 3, this is yet  again proof of the soundness of our forecasts, but it is also proof of a – the excellent contribution to the EBITDA  result as far as organic growth is concerned, which was equal to almost €30 million, which as I already  mentioned, it could have been even higher if we consider this in fact is a figure, which we were able to obtain vis- à-vis a recovery in the climate effects, which would have almost doubled the organic growth potential for the  company.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Synergies are in line with the business plan forecasts as I said, coming from the AcegasAps operation for the  most part, and as far as M&A is concerned, of the transactions were the ones which happened in the Friuli- Venezia Giulia region specifically, plus a few smaller niche operations, especially a significant transaction in  Lombardy in a waste company.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Thank you, and good morning. Now, in describing the business by business breakdown, I will go along with the  typical sequence beginning with the waste sector. In the waste sector, as you can see from the top left-hand  graph, we had some positive aspects and a few negative aspects. Overall, the growth year-on-year was equal to  €2.5 million, which was in line with the figures we had described at the end of Q3.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: If we look at how the €241.8 million result was obtained, you can see that organic growth grew by €7 million. That  was especially driven by the volumes which, as you can see in the lower left-hand graph, grew by 200,000 tons  over the year which is equal to almost 11% as far as special waste is concerned. As far as urban waste is  concerned, for the most part, we were able to confirm the previous year's volumes, proving resilience and stability  also vis-à-vis the economic cycle. In 2013, there had been a slight dip whereas in 2014, we have a slight  recovery. Therefore, for the most part, we continue to have volumes which are at around 2 million tons as far as  urban waste is concerned. And from this point of view, the evolution we've been seeing is that of further growth  and the sorted collection and recycling. Sorted collection within our entire perimeter is now up to 54%. This is the  average we've obtained in all of our territories. In the Bologna territory, we were above 55% whereas in the  Triveneto area, we're at 44%.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Therefore, as far as these volumes are concerned, as far as these sorted collection volumes are concerned,  some 500,000 tons are then selected and we are able to recover paper and plastic [indiscernible] (00:14:35)  500,000 tons are used to recover the humid part of the waste to produce compost. This is specifically interesting  because as you know, we started producing electricity power through the bio-fermentation process and then we  were able to recover the raw material.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: A company with a good saturation and with the energy plants allowed us to once again post a slight increase in  the power generation, which is above 1 terawatt per hour. And an excellent use of our waste to energy plants,  which we're able to manage 1.4 million tons of waste. And given the fact that we have a stable, pretty stable  volumes has brought about a further reduction of these landfills, which are now far below 20% of our general  volumes. Also taking into account the special waste sector. As far as the urban waste, we are close to 10%.  Therefore, we are very much in line with EU decisions leaving our company completely out of fines and sanctions,  which don't apply to our territory.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: We had a growth in the special waste volume and a significant contribution came about from a reorganization in  the group not only through the acquisition that our Chairman was mentioning referring to a company in the  Lombardy region treating a very specific type of waste, CSS, secondary solid fuel, which is a byproduct of the  waste treatment, which is used to produce concrete or cement, but we also had a commercial reorganization of  the company with the creation of a specific unit called [ph] HIS (00:16:35) Herambiente Industrial Services; a unit  which has started to implement new commercial approaches vis-à-vis major clients and multinational  corporations.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And in this, we are trying to use the quality of the infrastructure we can offer and all of the certifications and  guarantees that a major international players require in managing the waste that they produce in their plants. An  element to which limited this area as a result was due to a couple of events, which happened whenever you  manage industrial plants. We had an extended stop in one of the waste to energy plants, another one in Trieste  which kept the plant shut down for a few weeks. And therefore, for this type of machinery, this actually had a €2  million to €3 million negative impact. Another similar impact results were brought about by the fact that, last year,  we have had an extraordinary contribution, a one-off contribution of credits on grid certificates for the Padua plant,  which have brought about further profitability of equal to €3 million, which is something we weren't able to close  this year because, again, that referred to a credit from previous years.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: What contributed specifically to this result, to the €416 million results, the water business is now up to €217  million. As far as EBITDA is concerned, gas distribution equals €145 million, electricity distribution approximately  €47 million, and the remaining part is made up of a district heating, which differently from the first three  businesses, it is exposed to a volume of cyclicality.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Going into the details for each of these single individual businesses, certainly, the business which grew most is  the water business, which was able to benefit from the new tariffs introduced as we had already commented  previously. A part of this growth, which is above €20 million year-on-year came about through the consolidation of  the regulated tariffs. Whereas in other part, some further 50% came about through a tariff recovery from the  previous years.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as the water business is concerned, the results have been positive indeed. This new setup now makes  things a lot clearer. There certainly are a number of elements which need to be further clarified and further  defined. We are putting a great deal of attention on this topic and we're waiting to see how the authority will be  regulating the mechanisms to guarantee the quality of service in terms of invoicing, billing, the level of our water  losses, per kilometer of network managed, intervention time to connect to customers.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as gas distribution is concerned, as I was saying, the profitability was equal to €145 million, of which – or  rather the €145 million benefit obviously from the broadening of our perimeter. Growth in this business was above  €28 million, more than half of which came from the broadening of our perimeter, the contribution from Amga  Udine and Gorizia specifically, which as far as this point is concerned, strongly allowed our business to grow. And  currently in gas distribution, you may remember that our RAB is above €1 billion.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as electricity distribution is concerned, in this case, we had some slightly positive results. In this business,  we had two contrasting effects, we had the effects brought about by the reduction in the electricity tariffs, which  happened at the beginning of the year and the contribution from the Gorizia activities, equal to a couple million  euros, which offset each other.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And especially, in electricity distribution, in 2014, we were able to benefit from the [indiscernible] (00:23:54) on the  Gorizia businesses that we had already mentioned at the beginning of the year, which for the company equals to  some €8 million and further tariff recovery, which is obviously a one-off opportunity.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Finally, the free market sector, as we are showing that the year's last quarter was neither cold nor brilliant for the  business, you can see the overall result. As far as growth is concerned, in 2014, the results in this area,  exclusively focused on gas sales and electricity sales were equal to €10.6 million. The €10.6 million are less  compared to the €16 million that we had posted at the end of September. But we have to state quite clearly that  even the last quarter in 2014, from the climate point of view, compared to the previous year, showed a volume  contraction, which in general terms as far as the company is concerned equals over 300 million cubic tons less  overall throughout the year, equal to 18% of less volume sold.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: In this business area, we had an interplay with a number of elements besides climate and besides the weather.  As you know, last October – or rather October 2013 first and then October 2014 later, there were further fine- tuning on the regulated gas market tariffs, which certainly had an impact on the customer base part we had in that  segment.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: There have been some further developments on the electricity sales, the commercial electricity sales and most of  this result actually came from that area of business. And in the electricity business, there are two elements which  actually helped us post this result and therefore, fully offset the effects of both the weather and the crisis, because  as you know, there has been a 3% to 4% contraction in volumes, which is brought about by the downturn.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as gas is concerned, I already said how the weather was particularly warm, with a €6 million effect. We  were able to significantly offset the impact of the mild weather, both through some better margins via sales  business and through credits stemming from previous years on volume is equal to a few million euro. And the  combined effect of all this allowed the profitability for the gas sales to only dip by €10 million, whereas the  electricity sales grew by €19 million, for a general total of €10.6 million, as I said.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: We have mentioned the cost of debt shift. The net cost of debt at the end of the year was at 3.96%. Therefore,  even here, we are now below a psychological threshold, a 4% threshold. Obviously, this result was obtained both  through the Green Bond that our Chairman was mentioning, plus the refinancing operations we have had at the  end of 2013.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: The complete effects of the Green Bond, we'll be able to be appreciated this year for the prior year, whereas for  last year it was only for the final months, and therefore, this is something we're very satisfied with, but we're not  going to stop. We're going to continue looking around to see if we can continue working in this direction, but it is a  major step forward, because in the past – in the recent past, we used to be at around 4.8% to 5% a couple of  years ago. And therefore, decreasing that by 1 percentage point was no easy feat. Obviously, the context around  us helped.

file: HER - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 22March2016 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: 2015 was a year, which led us to confirm a number of important elements. Our growth didn't stop despite the  complexities of the year. For example, the weather we had in a number of months, besides the complexity in  terms of working on some of the transactions that we had imagined at the beginning of last year. Despite these  things, our growth was able to be achieved anyway from a number of different points of view.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Plus, as an effect of our M&A policy, in fact, we have been working on in recent years, we were also able to  continue in extracting synergies which is yet another way of allowing us to express organic growth. And today, we  presented at the 2015 yearly results plus the 2015 sustainability results, which is yet another way of underlining  how we focus on quality of service and sustainability. We also wish to underline the positive effects that our  results have on our company's shareholders with an added value equal to €1.6 billion.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: All of these elements allow us to have a net profit adjusted of €188 million from which we also had to subtract  €8.2 million which stem from depreciation in the energy plant sector, which means that with a net profit worth  €180 million, we were able to close a 10% growth which is a significant step forward and it concludes a  rebalancing of the top line and the bottom line which in some years in the past was a source of concern. Or it  wasn't exactly an area in which we performed as we could have. Nowadays, we were able to achieve this balance  and I'm sure you can appreciate it from the things that we have included in presentation set, specifically on page  2.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: And finally, as far as M&A is concerned, I'd like to remind you the fact that out of these almost €14 million, a  portion refers to the effects of the Amga Udine transaction. As you may remember, the Amga Udine transaction  happened half way through 2014, and therefore, we completed the entire process halfway through 2015. We also  had other major operations and transactions which happened towards the end of 2015, given the complexity of  these transactions. But despite this complexity, we were able to make three acquisitions, three transactions on  the liberalized market. The first refers to a group of customers in the energy sector. And the other two  transactions happened in the very last part of the year, and they refer to two companies operating in the waste  sector, both of which are ambitious companies, ambitions that we can go into later on, which just goes to show  that this is proof of our desire to broaden our portfolio in our asset base, including in landfills.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As you may have seen in the 2015 results, landfills had an effect on the waste sector. This was a shortcoming  that we had to solve swiftly. We had to increase the number of available landfills as we wait to restart the three  largest landfills, which in our territory were awaiting authorizations or they were waiting for the refurbishment  works to be completed. This was the first – I was referring to the first waste sector transaction.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: The second waste transaction was a lot more specific, and it too is based on our desire to broaden commercial  presence, in this case through the acquisition of a niche player, since it is a company which only focuses on  recovering industrial waste in the Tuscany region. These three transactions therefore were concluded at the end  of the year, and therefore, they contributed very little to the 2015 EBITDA. As a matter of fact, the operational start  for the work of these transactions should have begun on January 1 at least for one of them. But now, it's safe to  say that two months down the line, they have already started working and started giving an excellent contribution.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Thank you and good afternoon. I'll begin with the networks area. Networks, as you know, represent roughly 50%,  and therefore, this is a priority sector. Networks performed well. Taking into account last year's results and taking  into account some of the items that the Chairman already mentioned, overall, the business in these regulated  areas grew by €12 million net vis-à-vis the previous year results. The area which performed best in the networks  was the water sector.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Water reached €232 million of the €428 million year-end results overall with a €15 million growth vis-à-vis the  previous year. A part of this is certainly linked to the tariff increase in water, plus €6 million stemmed from  increased efficiency, €6 million of an overall result, which for the entire year was worth almost €20 million, and  therefore, its contribution was roughly one-third, and this was the area which gave us the most benefit.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: As far as the gas distribution sector is concerned, at the end of the year, the final result was equal to €144 million,  which is pretty much in line with the previous year. As you may remember, in 2014, we had some extraordinary  items, white certificates for instance worth €5 million to €6 million, which means that as a matter of fact, our  business improved organically along those lines. A part of this came from the perimeter delta. The remainder of  the growth came from increased efficiency.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: As far as the electricity business – the electricity distribution business is concerned, we suffered from the loss of  the [indiscernible] (00:16:55) business in the Gorizia Province, which is worth €10 million. The year-end result is  at €39 million, a €7.7 million decrease compared to the previous year, although we were able to recover €2 million  in terms of efficiency.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Efficiency, which in the entire networks area accounts for €15 million of the overall €20 million, and the final  contribution was brought about by district heating. Rather than the cost optimization, the district heating business  benefited from the colder winter, allowing the district heating sector to increase its results by €5.5 million, and we  were able to achieve €12.5 million at year-end 2015. So, these were the internal figures as far as this part of the  business is concerned.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Moving on to energy, in energy, we have been seeing the most exciting dynamics. The overall growth of this area  was worth €16.4 million. This is partially linked to the consolidation of the Alento Gas acquisition, an acquisition  we made in the Umbria region in the year's first quarter, plus the contribution brought about for the six months by  the Amga Udine transaction. Here, we have organic growth. We have growth of volumes, which we're able to  grow, thanks to better weather compared to 2014.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: These results could have been even better had the month of December been even colder. As we know, the  month of December was quite mild vis-à-vis the historical figures. But despite that, at the end of the year, we have  a growth of 300 million cubic meters in end customer sales. This is brought about by a better thermoelectric  market and better trading activities, these two activities, plus the higher amount of volumes sold on the electricity  market brought about by our commercial expansion, brought about the combined benefit of €11 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: The electricity market posted a significant growth, a growth which is equal to plus 60,000 new customers, which  allows us to go beyond the 860,000 customer threshold in this business. This is a significant figure if you  remember where we started from, but also vis-à-vis the electricity market, where we have over 1.3 million  customers, meaning that we are above the gas customer base here in electricity or above 50% of the gas  customer base.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: We also had good margins in commodities. The performance in power generation was less exciting. In the past,  we had benefited from some contribution from [ph] MST (00:20:59) in the Campania region from the ancillary  services. This almost disappeared in 2015, given the activities operated by Terna and the interconnections in  regions such as Apulia and Calabria, thanks to the new Matera-Santa Sofia plant.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Recently, also in the electricity business, we were able to make the acquisition of another commercial company in  the Abruzzo region, it's called Julia Servizi Più, with a further 15,000 customers who are almost exclusively gas  customers, and this is the way of increasing our positioning in the Marche and Abruzzo territory. We now have  150,000 customers in that part of the country, and this goes to show that that territory was rightly identified as a  territory which over time would have seen a major consolidation, and this is something that we feel will further  continue in the coming months.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: The final area I'd like to focus on is the waste business. In waste, there isn't anything else to add vis-à-vis  compared to the things we had already commented in the previous quarters. The difficulties that the waste area  had in terms of capacity to dispose off waste in landfills is situation which lasted for the entire year 2015. Its  impact was above €8 million, whereas €4.4 million was the impact stemming from the lower energy prices from  most energy plants. These two effects combined brought about the contraction from €242 million to €230 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: As the Chairman was saying earlier, the acquisitions we made at the end of the year still haven't unleashed their  effects in 2015, they will certainly be doing so in 2016. Hopefully, we will pursue the acquisitions we made, we're  able to increase our landfill capacity. As far as the landfills, our previous landfills are concerned, we're still moving  along in terms of increasing authorizations and hopefully things will change soon. For those of us who listened in  at the business presentation, we still have some positive signals as far as prices are concerned, especially in dry  and humid waste to the disposable waste vis-à-vis the prices at the end of 2015. In the first two months of 2016,  we've had an increase of about €2 to €3 per ton which isn't bad at all.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: As far as volumes are concerned, I mentioned the contraction we had in special waste which is something that  has been on the decline since the first quarter of the year. We've had a stable result for urban waste which  declined worth a few couple of tons. Sorted collection and recovery and recycling is increasing. We're above 55%  of the entire territory homogeneously, plus we had an increase in efficiency worth a few million euros of bringing  the results from €50 million to €20 million. This is an overview of the waste business. And I'll give the floor to  Luca, who can comment especially on the optimization of financials and tax rates which is something that the  Chairman was mentioning earlier which was something that we were very satisfied with in closing the year results.

texts.speaker: Luca Cimatti
texts.text: Thank you and good afternoon. We closed 2015 with an excellent profile in terms of the cash flows we generated,  over €200 million, which obviously stemmed from a good performance in our operational levers on the one hand,  plus a rather positive management for the financial side of things and taxes. We were able to decrease our debt  level up to 3.85% of our gross debt compared to 4.25% last year. So it's 40 to 50 basis points less. This was a  path we began in 2013 already. Then in 2014, we had the tender offer of the new green bond, which was able to  have a number of positive effects and optimizing the cost of debt in 2015.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: I don't think there is very much left to add, besides the fact that the criteria we had applied to our business plan  referred to four items and which integrated all of our growth forecasts. The first is efficiency, something that we  worked on and the results of which are obvious, also in terms of the figures achieved. Another item was the  quality of service, with the desire to strive for excellence, and many of the elements included in our sustainability  results show that we are already in the range of excellence, and this is something that our customers perceive.  We certainly have to intensify, and it is actually something we've already started to do in 2015.

file: HER - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 21March2017 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as energy is concerned, we had a very sizeable contribution with a plus €35 million growth. It was better  than the other sectors. It may have been favored by a few specificities in 2016 in terms of electricity market. But  this is also an element which is very consistent with our expectations also for 2017 and 2018 because, as we  mentioned when we illustrated the Business Plan, we mentioned some important tenders that we have been  awarded, the effects of which are beginning to become effective in 2017. So these are the sectors that benefited  from our actions, plus we also had two other transactions which you're familiar with, which happened in early  2017, which means that we focus on everything as far as we're concerned. We focus on organic growth, we focus  on acquisitions. What we're waiting for is for the finalization of the Madia Decree, which we feel will be a major  way of pushing mergers forward, especially between multi-utility companies.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: I'll now leave the floor to Stefano, who will be giving us an in-depth view of the waste business and the other  sectors before we give the floor to Mr. Moroni for an overview of our financial performance.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Thank you, and good afternoon. This is Stefano Venier speaking. This part of the presentation is titled MORE with  less, and it's a summary of what we were able to achieve this year by using less resources because, as you'll be  seeing, the company capital invested was stable in 2016. It is at the same level we had in 2015. Also thanks to  the optimization on working capital, which we will be illustrating better later on. Beginning with the waste business  on page four, we obtained the same result in 2015, which was quite important from a number of different points of  view. First of all, because we have a combined effect of the expired [indiscernible] (10:55) halfway through the  year, the review of the Green Certificates. And the first nine months of the year where supplies of electricity was  lower compared to the previous year, all of this had an impact on the business worth €16.7 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: We had to offset all this in a number of ways, through increased efficiency, of course, which was worth roughly €8  million to €9 million. We also had a contribution from the market. A number of times, with you, we mentioned how  prices were on the rise, in recovery, which was consolidated throughout the year. We had an increase in prices  worth 2% to 3% with a few exceptions such as the dry and humid part of waste due to stabilizations stemming  from those areas in a crisis which had an increase in price worth up to 10% and even 15%. This obviously gave a  positive push during the various quarters. Plus we also had the difficult process for the authorization of landfills.  The first contribution came in beginning in August 2016 with the Ravenna landfill, and this partly marked the  positive result we posted in the second half of the year, also compared to the previous year and also compared to  the first half of 2016.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Overall, volumes were positive for some 350,000 tons. These are referred to the special waste volumes  exclusively because of volumes collected, and as far as urban waste, were exactly the same in the previous year.  It was a minus 7,000 tons. So it's the same volumes. So the 350,000 tons in special waste also benefited from our  broadened perimeter, especially waste recycling and the acquisition we've mentioned a number of times. The  urban waste business was further developed in terms of assorted collection, and the use of landfills is now well  below the EU targets set for 2030, whereas the part of the business linked to recycling was above 56%, or rather  sorted collection was above 56%. 94% is the percentage of the recovered waste, both in terms of recycled raw  material and in recovered energy.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: An element, as far as 2017 is concerned, which is very closely connected with the business dynamics is an  element which will affect the coming months with the final execution of the acquisition of the Aliplast Company  which will be happening early April following the Antitrust Authority authorization which happened over the past  two weeks. And I'm referring to the consolidation of the Aliplast Company and the acquisition of the Teseco  Company in Tuscany as a way of strengthening the position we started having with the acquisition of the waste  recycling company. This is the context we're looking at, and our growth was marked positively at the end of the  year by reaching the same results we had in 2015, by recovering the €2 million to €3 million that we had been  dragging on for most part of the year.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Obviously, the deal we struck with the authority was in recognition every six months, which is 50% of what it  would have been on a yearly basis, and for this year we're expecting a value worth €5 million. And we had other  components as far as energy distribution is concerned, and district heating in which we grew by €1.5 million  compared to the previous year, thanks to efficiency and the network optimization. As far as the impact of the  WACC cut is concerned, now this is a topic you're familiar with, I don't have very much to add except for the fact  that, as far as 2017 is concerned we're continuing with our initiatives to promote innovation as a way of further  improving our efficiency and improving effectiveness, which we hope to be able to achieve, also vis-à-vis the new  regulations on technical qualities, which were anticipated in the first consultation document by a few authority over  the past few weeks.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: On page 6, we have the details concerning the Energy sector. In this sector, the year was much more exciting  compared to the other businesses. A positive tone was one that we had already perceived in the first three  quarters of the year, and the fourth quarter merely confirmed the same trend and with a result which was much  higher compared to the previous year. This is due to a number of elements that you are already familiar with,  elements we discussed in a number of other different context. Generally speaking, we had a benefit stemming  from the conditions on the French market in November and December. Not so much because we had some  production capacity that we could use, but more because we had some opportunities for interconnection with  France, opportunities which turned out to be very interesting.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
