texts.text: As far as growth is concerned, the M&A contribution was fairly modest, also because of the second of the two  acquisitions made became executive only at the end of the years, meaning that their contribution was only partial  whereas within the €34 million growth, roughly 50% stems from trading activities and power gen, whereas the  remaining 50% stems from the liberalized market, and it refers to increased customers, increased market  because the gas default market was effective as of October 2016, the consequence of which is that we were able  to post a larger volume. We already know what will happen in 2017. We've already discussed this a number of  times. The new service period on the Salvaguardia market is now effective.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: And that 1% improvement can also be recorded if we take into account the return on market cap, which moved  from 4.8% to 5.6% this year. I'm referring to capitalization, [ph] net worth (22:02) €3.7 billion. As I was mentioning,  the invested capital, the resources used are the same pretty much, €5.1 billion. This allows us to have a return on  invested capital worth 8.9% in 2016. I'll conclude my part with an item which isn't so much focused on quantities  or economics. The board of directors has been approving the sustainability budget, and taking into account the  fact that many investors are incorporating this approach in their assessments more and more. We thought it was  important to give you an innovative overview. We also wanted to underline the more important elements of how  our company operates, vis-à-vis, the various dimensions linked to sustainability.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: And page 8, as a matter of fact, underscores the fact that the company has committed to at least 10 of the 17 UN  global targets. As far as the first three are concerned, focusing on resources and our commitment concerning the  circular economy, you have a clear representation with two figures. On the one hand, we have the amount of  ways to recover it both in terms of raw materials and in terms of energy, which is above 94% and 64% of our  packaging, which is recycled. You may remember that the target set by the EU is 65% in 2025, which means that  we are almost 10 years ahead of schedule. As far as the use of resources is concerned, we take into account the  water, which isn't [ph] invoice (24:11) vis-à-vis the networks parameter in which we are leaders on the Italian  context.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: As far as the environmental issues linked to energy and resources are concerned, for the past 10 years, we  comply with the carbon disclosure. We are one of four companies this year, we have improved the company's  carbon footprint by 10% in terms of energy generated. We have reduced the overall amount of greenhouse gas  emissions by 10%. 70% is the amount of renewable energy produced and minus 2.6% or 2.6% is the energy  consumption rates which we enjoyed the past three years, which is the same amount of 4,300 families.

file: HER - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 27March2018 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: The growth post of this year was amongst the highest in recent years in terms of the growth of EBITDA. Only in  one year were we able to exceed the results we've posted this time and this again shows the strong continuity in  our track record. The contribution to this result, besides the €7 million, which we decided to include, which refers  to the negative element since in 2017 the incentive for the waste-to-energy plant in Isernia expired, whereas the  very positive results were brought about by an excellent performance as far as organic growth is concerned  during the year.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: And as you can see, this is in fact one of the best results posted over the years. And the organic growth was  brought about by all of our businesses, with the two specific businesses or two specific areas which contributed.  On the one hand, we have the market and sales, supply rather, which stem from the excellent results posted in  the Salvaguardia market and in the increase of our customer base in the energy sector, which grew by 90,000  new customers also through M&A.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: And then of course, we have the second best driver, which was the waste sector, in which we were able to grow  significantly also as far as M&A is concerned. And in fact, M&A includes the Aliplast transaction, which was  concluded in 2017, plus it also includes the Teseco transaction, this was a Tuscan company, which further  increased our presence in Tuscany, an area in which we are already [ph] present really (00:07:02) waste  recycling company. Another contribution in terms of supply is the continuation in 2017 with very focused  acquisitions of smaller companies in the Marche and Abruzzo regions, which is something which also continued in  the very first month in 2018 with two further acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Special waste, as far as volumes are concerned, are now 2.5 billion tons with a growth equal to 180,000 tons  compared to 2016, whereas urban waste were stable at around 2 million cubic meters, which is the figure we had  in 2016.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: M&A supported the development of the waste business with a further €18 million, €17.5 million were linked to  Aliplast and the remaining €0.5 million linked to Teseco. Generally speaking, these results mark a €26 million  growth, allowing us to offset the expired CIP6 incentive in [indiscernible] (00:09:50), which is worth minus €6  million, plus another €4 million worth of extraordinary operations. Therefore, generally speaking, the waste sector  grew by some €15.3 million, all the way up to €246 million. Within the business, we also have to include €170  million, which refer to the waste treatment and a recovery of material sector. The remaining part refer to the entire  sector concerning waste collection and street sweeping in the various cities served by the company. And as far as  2018 is concerned, you may remember that we are completing the construction of the bio-methane plant in  Bologna, which will start operating in Q4 2018, with a productive capacity worth 120,000 tons, with 8 million cubic  meters of methane within the company's perimeter.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Moving on to the networks sector. In this area, we posted stability as far as results are concerned, which is the  result of some positive notes and some less positive notes. The positive notes refer to the contribution of the  quality of our commercial service in the water cycle, which gave us certainly above €2 million in growth. We also  have to include organic growth as far as tariffs are concerned, stemming from the investments and [indiscernible]  (00:11:36) grew on the right-hand side. We also increased our recognized returns and considering rationalization  in cost and synergy, we are at a €7 million growth. This overall figure equal to €9 million was eroded to a certain  extent by a continuous decrease in the number of new connections, which even in 2017 posted a €3 million  reduction compared to the previous year, which means that the economic recovery is present to a certain extent  as we can see from volumes in waste and in electricity consumption.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Whereas we also have the comparison with the previous year, in which we had had profits stemming from the  sale of assets and the gas sector to rationalize the assets in that sector, especially in the Forlì-Cesena area in  view of the tenders. And in that area, those assets belong to [indiscernible] (00:13:13), which means that we had  had a €4 million surplus, which we didn't have this year.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: And to that, we also have to add a couple of lower marginalities in district heating where we've made some sales  to third-party companies, which gives us the minus €6 million as you can see in the graph as far as one-offs are  concerned, making the businesses' profile stable over the two-year period. The correct number should be €100  million, generally speaking, which isn't noted. There isn't very much else to add other than the fact that we have  continued to invest in infrastructure. And as you can see, we have increased RAB. We have slightly increased  RAB in fact in our businesses, both in energy and in water, which means that we are reinvesting more than  depreciation and we'll be seeing the effects of this on tariffs in 2018.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: Moving on to energy in conclusion, on the supply of electricity and gas, the more obvious element is of course the  contribution stemming from the Salvaguardia market, which throughout the year is equal to €38 million given the  fact that we also devaluated certain credits which were no longer cashable by us, which led us to an average of  €38 million compared to the certainly higher figures we had.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: From the free market, we had a €2 million growth. And as far as Q4 and 2017, we did have some lower gas  volumes because the thermal season was warmer than 2016. This is equal to 4% or 5% of contraction in  volumes. In Q4 2017, we also had a slight erosion on the retail gas margins since the CRRgrad (sic) [CCRgrad]  (00:15:37) period of application expired which, compared to the previous year, removed something from margins.  And within this figure, we also have to keep in mind the negative €4 million on the fair values to cover  commodities which, as you know, are assessed at the end of each individual year vis-à-vis the position in the  previous year and therefore we have a minus €4 million, which eroded part of the free market margins, whereas  the trading and assets management sector contributed to the plus €13 million. Here too, this figure could have  been even slightly higher. But in 2016, we had had an extraordinary profit stemming from the use of  interconnection with France due to the very first crisis of the nuclear asset market in France, which had given us  an extraordinary €6 million in 2016, which of course were a one-off opportunity, which did not happen in 2017.  And therefore, compared to 2016, this slightly reduced the real benefits posted during the year by the trading and  asset management activities.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Hera SpA
texts.text: We have also gone above 1 million customers in electricity. Thanks to our continuous development, which we  were able to achieve even in 2017, through which we were able to add over 100,000 customers to our customer  base. As you know, this was a year filled with news as far as non-financial results. But in fact, over the past 10  years, we have also been approving the sustainability results together with the economic results. As of this year,  thanks to the Barnier Directive, this has become mandatory for listed companies and therefore we too, as per  tradition, are now presenting to our board besides our economic results, also the results linked to environmental  and social results posted by the group. And in fact on page 7, you have a summary of the main elements in this  field. As you know, we have been reporting these things since last year based on CSV on creating shared value.  Last year, this was worth €300 million and this year, this is worth €329 million, so with a plus 10% compared to  2016 and the group's – 40% of the group's investments are in line with this approach. All of the parameters we  measure performed very well, beginning with the contribution to circular economy in which we are well above the  targets for recycled packaging set by the European Union for 2025, we are now at 68%. We have an excellent  recovery as far as recycled material is concerned. We're now up to 94.6% as far as recovered waste. We have  also reduced the carbon footprint of our activities, which last year had contracted by 10% compared to 2015. This  year, it further contracted by 16%. We had excellent performance as far as energy efficiency is concerned. The  group's overall energy consumption further reduced and you'll remember that we only used renewable energy as  of last year. We are about to further reduce energy consumption by 3.6%, which is in line with the 5% limit we are  giving ourselves by 2020.

texts.speaker: Luca Moroni
texts.profession: Group Manager-Administration, Finance & Control, Hera SpA
texts.text: As you may remember, we have some guidelines embedded in the business plan, but we are also capable of  taking any new opportunity without jeopardizing our financial soundness. I think this is an excellent starting point  for the five years included in the business plan. We have already concluded the very first year in a very good way.  In fact, 2017, also given by the market conditions, we have seen that the general economic situation has  improved with a specific focus on the liberalized markets, therefore, in the energy business and in the waste  business, which we're focused and we do hope that there may be some further positive elements and therefore  that this is the hope that we have, while we continue to work in the upcoming years. And of course, we also wish  to remind of the fact that, we also approved within the board that we will have a €0.95 dividend per share that we  will be presenting to our shareholding assembly to be paid in June. And this is a further element I wanted to  mention, besides the fact that we have also – remind you to the fact that also as far as dividends are concerned,  we continue to enter to increase the dividend in the remaining years of the business plan.

file: HER - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 27March2019 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Good afternoon, everybody. We are a little tired after a long board meeting, but here we are ready to present our  group's results for 2018. The fundamental points that we would like to highlight in our introduction refer to the very  many things done during the year. We concluded a few M&A transactions, which for the most part were focused  on the energy sector. But also in the market region, we also completed a merger with a company, which owned a  good portion of the gas networks in the Pesaro province. All of this happened in Q1. In Q2, we continued to work  with our usual commitments with a specific focus on the position that we are gaining on the topic of sustainability  with a view to expanding within our company, a special focus on sustainability in various sectors which also  allowed us to receive international recognitions of a significant kind. And also as far as obtaining credit is  concerned, we were able to work on the innovative initiatives, which were also then implemented by other  players.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: Q3 and Q4 were marked by a number of opportunities, especially as far as partnerships are concerned. One such  partnership was with Eni to manage the use of vegetable oil collected through sorted collection. The second  partnership is with the Bio-on company to launch and then produce bio-plastic. A third topic, which is entirely  different in those same quarters was a contender we were awarded in the Waste sector to clean up the Chioggia  port in the province of Venice, which is certainly a very important operation. And then, as far as the tenders are  concerned, both for the gas market and the electricity market, we reconfirmed our position in these client  segments because for the third time, we were awarded the

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: As far as Waste is concerned, despite having some difficulties especially in terms of the availability of landfills  which were a part of our traditional array of assets you're all familiar with, we did have some difficulties because  two of the landfills included in their regional wasteland due to a number of reasons encountered more difficulties  than expected in terms of obtaining the necessary authorizations. This is a complex process which was  completed for one of the two landfills mentioned, whereas for the second one we hope to be able to count on a  ruling that can allow the landfill to be up and running again.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: In any case, the results of the Waste sector, also taking into account the increase in prices which continued for  special waste. Throughout 2018, as you can see despite the negative elements, we were still able to post a  positive result as far as growth is concerned.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: And due to the reasons I mentioned earlier, we also had a good performance in public lighting. And then the TLC  sector, despite it being a smaller sector, a smaller business for us, it did contribute nonetheless to the column  marked as Other which is worth €7 million. The only negative elements in all of this scenario is due to some  negative factors in the electricity generation sector in which, per se, as you know isn't an especially relevant part  of our portfolio. Plus throughout 2018, there was a concentration of periods during which the service was  suspended, which we have not overcome but it did have an impact on production throughout the year.

texts.speaker: Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano
texts.text: You can see three spots here, which show that €12.4 million in our EBITDA equal to 27% of what we were able to  post, stemmed from the intensity of our investments, from the tariffs which were especially positive in the Waste  sector and also due to the premiums we were awarded for the very first time in terms of the quality of service  which was a major recognition.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Good afternoon, everybody. Let's go into the various business areas, page 6. I think the very first element I'd like  to focus on is the balancing between our businesses. We had a higher amount of regulated activities, as a  consequence of a very good performance the Chairman was commenting on especially concerning our Networks  performance, and all of those businesses which are a fully regulated, the largest of which is water followed by gas  distribution. The Networks which as you can see moving on to the right have improved their performance to €464  million, a €40 million more compared to the previous year with a growth equal to 9.6%. And then we will be going  into the specifics, if you go into the reasons why we have seen this increase which is maybe surprising given the  fact that last year was stable compared to 2016.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to Waste. You will notice that for the third year in a row, we are continuing with a significant growth,  marked by roughly €6 million. You may remember that in 2017, we also had an increase in perimeter with the  Aliplast transaction which has contributed to our growth. In 2018, we didn't have any sizeable increases in our  size, which means that the contribution to growth was entirely organic and as what we're seeing it stems from the  industrial waste or special waste sector.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to the Energy sector, the result was equal to €286 million, slightly lower compared to the previous year.  As we already mentioned, the reason for that is due to the lower performance we had in our production and  generation activities which is a small portion but which does contribute to the end result and that motivates the €7  million decrease which is a part of the contraction. Part of the contraction was also offset by the development of  our commercial activities. But moving – or looking back to two years ago, we did have an increase equal to €46  million compared to 2016 which means that we are still able to achieve an important result in a linear fashion.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to the business-by-business breakdown and let's begin with the most important sector, Networks which  covers almost 50% of our total EBITDA. You'll notice that half of the growth was brought about by water due to  three main reasons: First of all, there was an increase in recognized revenues, which also includes the part  stemming from our commercial quality, which in 2018 was equal to some €3 million. The second item refers to  efficiencies. Earlier, we were mentioning how, all-in-all, our efficiencies contributed to €15 million growth; half of  that growth came about from the Networks sector roughly €8 million. And finally, this refers to a one-off  component. We have some €6 million we were able to recover from previously standing situations recognized by  Authority during the 2018 year, which we were able to recover [ph] of over – (00:24:16) to previous years.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to the gas sector, even here we have been able to mark a significant growth worth some €10 million,  allowing the gas distribution final results to be equal to €261 million out of a total of €464 million. These further  €10 million once again stem from the following ways: €2 million from recognized revenues; in this case due to the  investments we made in the previous period; further €4 million came about through efficiencies bringing the grand  total of efficiencies to €12 million in the Networks sector, plus a number of other items, white certificates and  others.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Finally, district heating. The thermal season was a good one. We were able to promote certain efficiencies and  innovation initiatives, allowing us to improve the optimization of the systems we manage and their performance,  allowing us to improve the results by €6 million, so that the grand total EBITDA in district heating is equal to €16  million within the €464 million at €1 million total.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Other important things to note as far as these businesses are concerned we have the RAB value of the three  businesses we are considering, equal to €3.1 billion with a slight growth compared to the previous year. As far as  the gas tenders are concerned, as you know and as we mentioned during the business plan presentation, the  tender in Udine 2 is happening within our territory. This is a very first field test that we are dealing with as far as  the tenders are concerned.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Initially, the offers had to be sent in by February. This deadline has been postponed to May and we'll be seeing  how that goes. Finally, as I mentioned and commenting the various business areas, a part of these results came  about by the premiums we received and the quality of service I mentioned – the one for water because it is good  news for 2018. But even the two other businesses, gas distribution and electricity distribution, received a positive  contribution which is also the combined total of premiums and reduction [ph] and indeminization (00:27:25). Two  years ago, we gave ourselves a target equal [indiscernible] (00:27:31) and we are now close to that – achieving  that goal which also brought about an improvement in the overall profitability of these businesses.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to the Waste sector. First of all, at this time we wanted to underline the contribution of Aliplast equal to  €1 million. The overall profitability of the business was equal to €18 million. We expect something more in 2019  because in Q4 of the year, towards the end of the year therefore we created a new [indiscernible] (00:28:21), this  was in Q4 of 2018 and this will allow us to increase that site's ability to perform with obvious positive  repercussions on the company's performance. But we have €11 million in organic growth. This is the sum of a  number of different components, among which we have the contribution stemming from the marketplaces which  grew on average by 10% throughout the year, although we had a piece which were well above that up to 20% or  30%. This contribution was strengthened by the profitability on the production of renewable electricity, which  benefited from the price dynamics we had in 2018. Although its positive effect was eroded by the lower volumes  we were able to manage due to a limitation on the ability to dispose of waste and that was equal to some 100,000  tons over the year. This is, of course, removed a potential business, although compared to the previous year we  were still able to post – we posted a slight contraction. Special waste were equal to 2.155 million tons compared  to the 2.2 million tons roughly of the previous year whereas urban waste were 2.35 million tons with a plus 48,000  tons compared to the previous year, with an overall total of 4.5 million tons which were treated on the market.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: As far as our plants are concerned, we already started our biomethane plant. Let me just give you some  information on the waste collection sector. In this sector, we no longer manage waste collection in the Forlì city.  That municipality has a micro in-house company. This is minus €3.5 million for us which eroded our growth which  otherwise would have been equal to plus €10 million.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Despite all of this, we continue to evolve in terms of waste collection and sorted waste collection specifically. We  now stand at 62.5% of recycling, with excellent examples such as the city of Ferrara which stands at 85% and  other areas which are lagging behind especially in the mountain regions were in very specific context. We had a  good performance as far as our waste energy plants are concerned. Even last year, they were able to treat 1.3  million tons like in the previous year.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: Moving on to the Energy sector. I already mentioned everything, I think. Three dynamics in this sector marked a  slight contraction, but not as far as our core businesses are concerned. From that point of view, we increased by  €10 million given the broader perimeter on the default market in the last quarter of the year, but also due to the  almost 150,000 further customers we added throughout the year; of which 70,000 came from acquisitions, the  remaining customers came about through our commercial activities as we did in previous years. I already  mentioned the negatives. Therefore, I will not go into further details.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: And let me conclude my presentation with a brief focus on one of the topics that we have been focusing on over  the past three years, which is that of offering a full transparency concerning the €1.03 billion, and the way in which  it ties into our strategies concerning sustainable development. With the promotion of smart use of energy and  efficient use of resources and innovation and development of territorial social ecosystems, and we're very pleased  to say that this part of the margin is now up to €375 million. It now covers 36% of our total EBITDA. It is [ph] fairly  (00:35:22) in-line with the 40% target we have given ourselves to 2022, and with a major growth compared to the  results posted in 2017.

texts.speaker: Stefano Venier
texts.text: This was due to our daily activities and a number of initiatives the Chairman also mentioned such as our ability to  recover vegetable oil – used vegetable oil to produce biodiesel which we didn't use to fuel our waste collection  trucks. This is just an example of course, plus some careful choices we made on investments which in 2018 are  equal to €186 million, out of a total of €460 million which account for 40% of our investments devoted to these  areas, which means that the result we were able to post on shared value is also the consequence of our policies.  It is also the consequence of some milestone results we were able to achieve that were very important and we're  quite pleased to say that over a four-year period, we were able to reduce our energy consumption by 4.4% and  we are now in a reach of the 5% target. We have reduced our carbon footprint compared to 2015 by 16%, and  we've already reached this year another result referring to the directive on the EU Circular Economy, which  means that after the [ph] run of the use of (00:36:52) landfills and this year we have a lower percentage compared  to the previous year equal to 5%, the recycling rate of our packaging which is now up to 70%, which is the target  defined for 2030. And I could continue but you could find all of this information on our sustainability budget  presentation.

texts.speaker: Ola Rollén
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB
texts.text: Geosystems is now growing again on the back of the improving demand in all major regions including EMEA. texts.speaker: Ola Rollén
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB
texts.text: We then move to Americas. I've already explained about the large software order that we had in Canada this time  last year and that actually has a 4% impact on the region as such. And on top of that, we should experience a contraction from  the U.S. sequestration program of roughly €5.5 million per quarter for the remainder of this year and that is  another 3% in the first quarter. So the underlying trend for the rest of our business is actually more than 8% in  Americas.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB
texts.text: Slide 14 is our weather forecast and what it looks like in the first quarter in comparison to the first quarter of 2012. Middle East, North  America, South America and China is continuing to grow, whilst APAC, the red arrow has to do with the mining  industry in Australia.

texts.speaker: Ola Rollén
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB
texts.text: Power and energy is growing at good grades in all regions, but for Western Europe. Aerospace and defense are  grouped together and we have good growth from Aerospace in all regions. texts.speaker: Ola Rollén
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB

texts.speaker: Ola Rollén
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB
texts.text: And if we turn to slide 43, we find a quote from one of our first customers using SmartPlant Fusion. And they've now been able to capture 750,000 documents and record that, so that they  now have a platform to do productivity developments in this own plant. It cost 10% of what it would have  normally done and they did it, as I said, in eight months. So it's a phenomenal success, to quote the customer, and  we have great hope for this combination of products to penetrate the brownfield market for plant information and  management.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB
texts.text: Slide 47, we're starting to gain traction with the first synergy project that we launched, the Smart H2O Solution.  We now have commercial deliveries first to the Lushui Dam in China, but we also have significant projects in  Russia in connection to hydropower.

texts.speaker: Ola Rollén
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB
texts.text: Smart Agriculture is another synergy product that we talked about and we introduced that for the first time at the  Technology Expo at HxGN LIVE. It will keep the farmers abreast of crop management and production through digital workflow  that we create from geo-enabled data.

texts.text: Subsequent events, if we talk a bit about the acquisition of MSC, and I would like you to look at slide 34, please.  This is our vision for the smart connected factory. texts.speaker: Ola Rollén
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB
texts.text: Beyond that, we also see that MSC has the capability to connect to our SmartPlant CAD software in the fluids  world. And then, we could do design simulations in our SmartPlant product using parts of the MSC offering; very  exciting indeed.

texts.speaker: Ola Rollén
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Hexagon AB
texts.text: So, in summary, if we summarize this quarter – eventful quarter, growth driven by strong demand in China across  all business units and solid demand in Manufacturing Intelligence. Improved profitability  in all businesses, apart from PP&M.

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Cargotec Oyj
texts.text: So, obviously, Eeva continuing as the CFO. file: HIAB - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 28April2015 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: We also announced today additional saving measures in MacGregor on top of the profit improvement programs  we're already running, and we will cover that bit more in detail in the MacGregor part.

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: In offshore market, obviously, everybody is aware of the fact that the oil price being very [indiscernible] (04:56), a  number of oil companies had announced CapEx. The cycles are, however, very long on that one. Many of our  products go actually into production phase of the sector, and also, obviously, different markets, whether you are  sort of major oil corp or a national oil company, have slightly different investment profiles.

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: In our case, the activity level in the offshore market remained at a healthy level. Actually, about half of the order  intake in the first quarter 2015 came from the offshore sector. We still see that activity level remains fairly high for  a while at least, but it's obvious that we will not be sort of immune for the developments happening in the oil  industry and offshore sector. But we would expect, then, order intake potentially will start to slow down perhaps  in the second half of the year, at least, by 2016. And then revenue impact will slow down, then start to happen at  2016, 2017.

file: HIAB - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 29April2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: During the Q1, we also launched a HiVision product concept which is a virtually operated forestry crane for Hiab,  really I would say stealing the show in Bauma in the construction equipment, and we have had more than 1  million hits in Internet for that product, which is a pretty good for an obscure product like a forestry crane at the  moment.

file: HIAB - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 26April2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: Before going to business areas, we actually announced, in connection of our annual general meeting, the eco- efficient product portfolio for Cargotec. Why did we do that one? It's very clear that the eco-efficiency and  environmental issues are getting increasingly important in transportation and logistics, driven by end-user  demand, driven by the different government and regulation, both locally as well as globally. And with our  investments further into R&D in terms of electric products, hybrids, software and automation, we can clearly see  this is an opportunity to further leverage our investments and build further competitive advantage for Cargotec.

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: When you look at our offering in eco-efficient products, we can characterize that in four categories. One, clearly,  the biggest potential overall in industry is the overall system efficiencies. Here, our increasing software offering  gives better visibility for our customers in the logistics and transportation to optimize the cargo flows and remove  unnecessary moves and transportation as well. This is a big improvement opportunity and business opportunity  for us as well.

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: We are providing further products in environmental industries such as wind farming, waste management,  recycling, et cetera, across our three business areas. Our investments in the further product development,  especially around the hybrid technology and electric technology, are important in increasing emission efficiency,  and this is clearly becoming a clear sort of competitive advantage for us.

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: Last but not least, the resource efficiency in terms of the rebuilding, refurbishing and upgrade of our equipment  also improves eco-efficiency of the industry. Overall, the eco-efficient product category represents about 20% of  our revenues, and we expect that to increase in the coming years.

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Cargotec Oyj
texts.text: So, we start to see quite a lot of proved points coming through with the – both in terms of greenfield operation as  well so called brownfield automation operatives, i.e., turning existing port facilities into automated ports, and are  quite excited about the long-term growth potential in the automation business as well.

file: HIAB - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 21July2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: Obviously, the oil price situation, and now including of course, the potential lifting of the Iran sanctions is having  an impact overall on the offshore sector, and it's also starts to be visible in our market situation. We are in a  fortunate situation that our segments we are serving in offshore are not impacted as drastically as some of the sort  of project [indiscernible] (5:33) drilling markets have been impacted. We are mostly in the deepwater, which is  still expected to grow moving forward, as well as more into production rather than the exploration and drilling  phase as well, but it's very clearly that's the tight offshore situation and the CapEx restrictions are starting to be  visible in our operations as well.

file: HIAB - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 20July2016 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: The demand for offshore load handling, despite some recovery in oil prices in the first half of the year, still  remains low. Demand for services is satisfactory, but very clearly, we see the pressure also in services coming  from the customers who have also tried to save costs including debt maintenance.

texts.speaker: Mika Pekka Vehviläinen
texts.text: Overall, we still keep on investing and increasing our R&D expenditure. Year-on-year, our R&D expenditure is up  again by 17%. We are investing especially into the software capabilities, automation, electrification and hybrid  products as well as renewing our products, and in that way, gaining better competitive advantage as well as the  new cost points that is also visible in our revenue development both in Hiab and in Kalmar.

file: HIAB - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 20July2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-17.pdf

The investments we are doing in our R&D and  technology are actually helping us to build a clear, competitive advantage around eco-efficient solutions and  products where the demand from our market is clearly increasing. Very happy for the fact that we have now  verified and got the certification for eco-efficient portfolio from the DMV verification agency and also very proud of  the fact that the leading global rating company EcoVadis has awarded us a Gold recognition in this category as  well.

file: HIAB - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 19July2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-18.pdf

texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Cargotec Oyj
texts.text: It's a complete system delivery from us, including all the Kalmar equipment, automation software as well as the  Navis N4 terminal operating system with automation capabilities. Also all the equipment is electric showing that  technology investment and the competitive edge we have today in terms of our capability offer fully electric  offerings, and the whole terminal operation will be powered by the solar energy locally.

texts.speaker: Mikko Juhani Puolakka
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Cargotec Oyj
texts.text: Our cost savings programs are proceeding according to the plans. We have delivered so far €15 million year-to- date – project to-date savings on the group-wide €50 million savings program; €10 million in 2017; and then €5  million now in 2018. Also the MacGregor €13 million cost savings program delivered year-to-date €5 million  annual savings. And then the Kalmar products transferred from Sweden has delivered so far €4 million cost  savings. We also continue our activities in the design-to-cost activities, especially in this kind of environment  where the raw material prices are on the increasing trend.

file: HIAB - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 27October2010 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Oct-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Sales grew by 15% in terminals and -- industrial and terminal and 12% on Marine, also a good  figure. Operating margin for industrial and terminal, this was really -- I must say that this was really  the acid test that -- can we bring it back to the right track? And, yes, we were. We have been able  to do that. Long work, many years of struggling, but now it’s on the right track. As I said earlier, 4.2.  Am I happy with that? I’m happy with the curve. I’m not happy with the 4.2. No.

texts.speaker: Operator

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: If we just look at the revenue by destination. So, these are the increases for the – in each of the regions. I've  excluded the disposal we made last year from the figures, just to give you the ongoing picture. So, all sectors grew  in the UK, in particular, the water sector was strong. So, that's part of our Environmental & Analysis sector and I'd  say good performances there. Good growth in Europe. Andrew will give you a bit more color by individual sector.  Just to remind you that the majority of our business in Europe is in Northern Europe. Southern Europe is less  than 5% of the group overall. And that was relatively weak during this half year.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: We saw a lot of growth in Asia Pacific than we've seen in the past couple of years, still a decent growth, but I'd say  lower than we've seen in the past couple of years, but we saw a real mix there. We had 20%-plus growth in the  Medical and Process Safety sectors. We had Infrastructure Safety that was flat, and then we had Environmental &  Analysis that was down around 10%. And Andrew is going to talk a bit more about that Environmental & Analysis  about the regional sort of trends.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: And then we've had a lower operating margin, in particular in Environmental & Analysis. Again, something I think  Andrew is going to touch on when he talks about the trading performance in the sectors.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Take a look at the profit split, double-digit profit growth in three of the four sectors. As expected, Environmental  & Analysis is down a little, but as we'll see, good progress there made on some of the reorganization that we had  planned during the first half of the year. So, I think what you see there is a well-balanced portfolio. The diversity  we've got in our portfolio absolutely helps us to continue to deliver good overall good growth despite some of the  ups and downs we always see in the individual sectors themselves.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: U.S.A., up 15%, so we're still finding new opportunities in the U.S. A great example there is fracking. We are  developing new products particularly in the bursting disk part of our business to make that process safer, both in  terms of protecting the operators, the human operators, but also the machinery that's being used.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: So, I mentioned fracking for bursting disks. In gas detector, we've also been launching a new product line  particularly to the oil and petrochemical industry, and we're certainly gaining market share there, too.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Asia is up 69%. Just to remind you, that includes the Longer Pump acquisition. So, that's the business we acquired  in China in February 2013, clearly, giving a boost to that overall rate of growth in Asia Pacific. I'm really pleased  with the progress of Longer Pump since acquisition. The management team there who we kept on after acquiring  the business is doing a very good job now within Halma of growing their business, not just in China but looking  for opportunities to export in other parts of the world. Similar to Infrastructure Safety, not a huge amount of  information on this end-market analysis. Slightly more diversity there. So, we do sell some of our Medical fluid  technology components into science and environmental-related markets.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: And finally, Environmental & Analysis, a pretty mixed performance is fair to say during the first half of the year  with revenue up 9%, profit down 3%. Organically that was a 3% increase in revenue and a 9% decline in profit. So,  first positive point coming out here is we are maintaining a reasonable rate of revenue growth despite the  distraction of some of the reorganization going on in certain parts of this particular sector. Nonetheless, return on  sales, 18.2%, still within our 18% to 22% band, but obviously lower than last year which was 20.5%.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: And just a variety of factors at play here, no single thing. GMs were slightly lower than last half year due to  product mix, I don't see that as a long-term trend, just to do with exactly the mix that was sold during the first half  of the year. And we also had a supplier quality issue in our water business, and the net impact of that in the first  half was £0.5 million on profit. We don't expect any repeat of that obviously during the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: We then have the – we got the planned actions coming into the first half of the year. So, we increased the  investment in our selling overhead, particularly in Asia. So, we have completed the creation of a separate stand- alone photonics business in China with its full Board of Directors, local R&D capability, with a view to really  accelerating growth in that subsector in the years ahead.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: And then we had the reorganization itself particularly with the ongoing consolidation of two of our photonics  businesses in the U.S. That's going to plan that will be completed by the end of the financial year, and I see an  additional cost of £0.5 million for that reorganization in the second half of the year. So, the combined cost of  reorganization in the full year will be within the £1 million target that we established at the beginning of the year,  so very much going to plan and in line with expectation.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Revenue by destination. Some surprising trends here. A real standout number here is UK up 61%, and the real  driver here, as Kevin mentioned, is the UK water companies and, in particular, they are and continue to invest in  flow and pressure monitoring equipment in preparation for the deregulation of the commercial water market by  2017, and we are certainly seeing the benefit of that and benefiting again from new product introduction in recent  year. I think we expect that trend to continue in the second half of the year although the comparator with last year  will become increasingly tough.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Asia Pacific, on the other hand, was down 9%. Now, we did have some tough comparisons last year. We had some  big projects last year both in photonics and also in our water sector. There's the chance of some of those repeating  in the second half of the year, but, again, timing is pretty uncertain there. So, I think the key point for me is, what  are the long-term prospects like in Asia Pacific for Environmental & Analysis? And I still see these as being strong  opportunities for us. It is the reason we've established that stand-alone business in China.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Quite a diverse range of end markets that we serve here in Environmental & Analysis. And some of the H1 trends  we've seen here, utility is up very much from those UK water companies continue to invest and then really a little  bit of a switch between the process industries and the science and environmental. That's the U.S. effect. So process  industries edging up as the photonics business in particular focus on those industrial markets and U.S.  government spending suppressing the growth that we're seeing in science and environmental.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: So, where are we today? Well, this is pretty representative. We've got over 500 names on the database at the  moment. You may also remember we were targeting to try and find more safety-related businesses, more  opportunities in Asia, and we're certainly seeing more of those coming through. Although today, there's still a  majority of what we see in the database are Medical and Environmental & Analysis-related business. And  although that the timing, as always, is uncertain as to when any particular deal is going to come through, certainly,  we feel in good shape coming into 2014 with respect to the acquisition pipeline.

file: HLMAL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 18November2014 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: And Andrew is going to give you some more color on the geographic spread by sector, but M&A was certainly a  bigger factor in the two safety sectors, and currency a bigger factor especially in the medical and environmental  analysis sectors. So to get a better view, you need to strip the M&A and the currency out with the figures. And I'll  do that in just a moment. One other thing I was just going to note was that we increased revenue, Andrew  mentioned this, outside the USA, Europe and UK from 25.2% of the total last year to 26.5% this half year, that was  mostly due to the geographic spread of the acquisitions that we have made, RCS in particular, during the course of  this half year.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: Asia also quite a mix. Pleasing to see growth in Environmental & Analysis there in Asia. And China grew by low  single digits. The others, you can see, that was good performance up 9%. That's mainly a good performance in  South America, in particular in oil and gas markets.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Y ou can see a bit more of a mixed picture that we saw at the full year numbers. So there's two big factors there.  The first one is the FX impact. It's particularly or more significant on the two Safety related sectors. And then the  M&A were bigger factors in the Environmental Analysis and Medical sectors. Sorry, I got the wrong way around.  FX is a bigger impact on the Medical and Environmental Analysis sectors, and M&A were bigger factors in the  Safety sectors.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So we've really now over the last five years been driving through some very strong market-led strategies that has  led to us increasing investment in R&D, particularly in this particular sector. And we're also seeing in this sector  increased collaboration, particularly when it comes to international expansion. The net results of that is not only  are we gaining market share in some of our core markets, but also we're entering some new market niches such as  shale gas exploration in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Here's a chart now showing the revenue by destination, and this time I've chosen to show you both the organic  numbers alongside the reported numbers. In this particular case, the biggest difference between the two is the  RCS acquisition. RCS are based in the U.S., so you can see the impact there on the U.S. growth numbers. But also  they got a strong global footprint. So you can see the growth rate outside of the UK, Europe and U.S. is strong too.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: I'll draw your attention to the organic growth chart. There you can see U.S. revenue up by 33% organically, so very  strong performance in the U.S. Strong growth in the oil and gas market there, particularly in shale gas as I  mentioned earlier. But we're also seeing growth in Process industries, particularly in our explosion protection  businesses, where we're developing new technology, new devices for new applications.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: I mentioned collaboration earlier. These businesses have just established a new commercial hub in Houston to  work together to really focus on the oil and gas market in the U.S., where we see good medium to long -term  growth opportunities, particularly as safety regulation really comes through more strongly.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Process Safety has got reasonable diversity to its own market. However, three market sectors make up 88% of the  total revenue. And you can see there quite clearly, energy and resources, the biggest market now 47% of this sector  revenue in the half, that compares with 40% last year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So it's both organic growth and acquisition. I mentioned RCS earlier. They've got a real focus on the oil and gas  industry. But also, we're seeing growth, as I say, through some of the new products we launch. And I think one of  the differences perhaps for us in the oil and gas market is first of all, we're selling products into the overall value  chain there. We haven't got any particular focus perhaps on exploration or perhaps on refinery, right away along  the process.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: That Science and Environmental segment, that's where we're selling some of our Fluid Technology components  into the Science and Environmental markets, although the majority of what they sell will still go into the Medical  and Health markets.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Finally, Environmental & Analysis. As I said at the outset, we continue to see good organic and acquisition growth  opportunities in all our sectors, although it's clearly a disappointing period for Environmental & Analysis, not  helped by a 6% adverse currency impact. So our revenue was down by 8% which is 2% decline in organic, constant  currency terms, and our profit down by 21%, that's 15% decline organically. So our return on sales reduced from  18.2% last year to 15.6% this year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Now before I dive into the detail to put that into context, just a couple of things to remind ourselves of. This is our  most diverse sector in terms of end markets. I think what was interesting during the first half, we only saw  weakness in one of those markets and that was the UK water utilities market. A little bit more on that later.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Y ou can see the impact of some of those factors on these regional figures. So if you focus particularly on the  organic numbers, you can see organic decline of 11% in the UK . That's predominantly UK water utilities reducing  their spend, and you can see USA down 3%. The biggest impact there will be from Pixelteq and those management  changes.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And finally, the revenue by end market. As I said at the outset, our most diverse sector , and of the major segments  here, you can imagine utilities that was down due to the UK, and the Photonics impact would be seen most  particularly in the Science and Environmental segments and also the Other segment.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: The largest of the acquisitions was a business called RCS, Rohrback Cosasco, and they're based in California, and  they're a world leader in pipeline corrosion monitoring. They've got a particular focus on the oil and gas industry,  a really strong global footprint. And we acquired RCS for £64 million, which is a multiple of just under 10 times  their profit.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: We've got the business quite typically for us without going through an auction process despite there being strong  interest from other strategic buyers. And another key factor, very typical for Halma, is we retained the  management team. And I'm now going to show you a short film, which really tells you more about RCS and also,   really gives the management story of why they chose Halma.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: On international expansion, now 27% of revenue comes from outside UK, Europe, and the U.S. And again, we're  seeing more collaboration between the companies. So two examples in this past half year, our ophthalmic  businesses are now selling in to China under a single sales management umbrella. And as I mentioned earlier, our  Process Safety companies have established a new hub in Houston in order to work together to exploit the  opportunities we see in the oil and gas industry in the U.S. market.

file: HLMAL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 17November2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Clearly you'll see the benefit on our market diversity, sort of sector level, strong performances for infrastructure  safety, medical, environmental analysis, recovering very well in environmental analysis, more than compensating  for some of the challenges we're seeing in process safety. And also we're benefiting from our good geographic  diversity, the good balance we've got in our business, selling across major regions.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: Let's just have a look at those underlying growth rates. So, what you've got here is the organic constant currency  picture. Again, growth in all the major regions. Andrew is going to talk you through each of the sectors, but just  some headlines. So, really strong U.S. growth, double-digit growth in Infrastructure Safety and Environmental &  Analysis.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: UK showed good growth in all except Process Safety. Europe also delivered a 10% growth, more of a mix of  performances there, but we had a very strong performance in Medical in Europe. Asia Pacific, also a mix. We had  our two safety sectors down, but Medical and Environmental & Analysis up around 10%. So, quite a mixed picture  there.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: You can see clearly there very strong performances from Infrastructure Safety, Medical and Environmental &  Analysis, all increasing both revenue and profit. And if you look at Process Safety, it also increased its revenue, but  it's got lower profit. And we're certainly seeing the impact of a slowdown in demand from the oil and gas industry.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And I think our job at the moment is really balancing, managing – clearly, managing our overhead costs  effectively, but at the same time, still encouraging our businesses to invest for growth, particularly to invest in  diversifying away from the oil and gas market. I think we're already seeing some examples of that. For example,  our Bursting Disk businesses already are developing and selling new products into industries such as  pharmaceutical, other fire suppression markets, other process industries. So, they're already making that move to  diversify if they need to.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: We still see – on these figures, however, the impact of both currency and particularly the acquisitions last year. So,  let's look at the same charts, but this time in organic constant currency growth. So really impressive performance  again; double-digit growth in the Environmental & Analysis and Medical sectors, high-single-digit growth in  Infrastructure Safety, and then you'll see Process Safety of 1% organic constant currency revenue decline, which  actually, I think, in the circumstances, is a really good performance; and a 14% decline organically in profit.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: I think one other point here is we do see a very clear distinction between those businesses that already have  diversified their end markets. So, Gas Detection, those of you came to see Crowcon would have seen the diversity  of their end markets recently in September. Trapped Key Interlock businesses, they're performing very well. It's  really the Bursting Disk businesses and the Pipeline Monitoring businesses that have the majority of their revenue  coming from oil and gas that are seeing the great challenges there. But as I said before, they still got a degree of  resilience because it's still very much safety regulated products that they're selling and they still see a demand in  certain markets for those products.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: In our other regions, Kevin mentioned it earlier on, most of South America was weak, Brazil particularly so in this  sector, obviously, reflecting the fact that a lot of what we sell for this sector is into the oil and gas market.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: If we now look at the revenue by end market, energy and resources now 44% of this sector revenue, was actually  49% last year. So it's come down somewhat. And some of the other sectors have grown really well. So, process  industries was 24% of this sector last year, it's now 27%. Utilities has increased from 15% to 16% in the sector. So,  we're definitely seeing that improvement in growth in those other sectors.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, in summary, we're going to keep close control of overheard cost during the second half of the year, but to  continue to invest in diversifying into other adjacent process industries. And our view is, like many others, we  don't believe the energy and resources market is going to improve in the second half or indeed for the foreseeable  future.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And then that other segment some of our – sorry, our Science and Environmental segment, that's the sale some of  our Fluid Technology businesses not only in terms of the medical device market, they also sell to some Science and  Environmental analytical instrument businesses. And we see good growth in that segment too. So, outlook for the  second half, I think is very much more of the same backed up by that continued commitment to invest particularly  in innovation and new product development.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Finally, I'm really pleased with the recovery and Environmental & Analysis. I know this time last year, this is an  area of the group that was really quite challenged, but it's really good to see the recovery coming back quite  strongly. So, revenue up by 14%, profit up by 25% and you can see organic constant currency of 10% for revenue  and 18% for profit. And what's good to see here is that revenue figure is a record for this sector for the first half  year, and the profit is not far off the record we set was it three years ago in 2012, so a really good strong recovery.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: All three of the business areas are growing, so Photonics, analytical instruments and Water all contributed to this  growth. And for Water, we started to see some evidence that the UK water companies are now getting themselves  in a position to start investing more heavily in the second half of the year 2016-2017, as part of their five-year  AMP investment cycle. So, we haven't really seen any impact on them spending yet, but we're starting to see them  starting to place orders and that will obviously help us in the second half of the year. It's a really impressive story  of growth across all the regions. Again, highlights here U.S.A., up by 10% organic growth.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: This is really where I talked about the OEM spending more on new product developments. So our Photonics  businesses, for example, benefiting from that increased corporate spending on research. In the UK, despite the  fact that water companies haven't really started investing heavily yet, we saw strong performances from our Water  businesses there, particularly in things like water quality testing. And the EU actually was pretty consistent across  all the major countries and across all the various sectors.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Asia Pacific organic growth of 10%; China is still growing nicely for us here. So, the analytical instrument  businesses we've got, particularly where their selling to things like pollution control, are seeing good opportunities  there. And our Water businesses is still selling well particularly in things like UV water treatment, Industrial  Applications and water quality testing, again, with a focus on Industrial Applications. So, China still is a good  growth market for these kind of businesses. And others, the same as the others really, strong in the Near and  Middle East and relatively weak in South America.

file: HLMAL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 22November2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: You'll see today the benefit of our market diversity. So, three of our sectors, Infrastructure Safety, Medical Sector,  the Environmental & Analysis sector, all continuing to grow revenue and profit, more than compensating for a  more challenging first half from our Process Safety sector. You also see the benefit of our geographic diversity.  So, you'll see that we've grown our revenue in all our major regions.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: We continue to invest for growth in the medium-term. So our strategic investment, two areas I'd highlight here, our  R&D spend, up by 16%. And, I think, we saw a good growth in most of the sectors, particularly in Infrastructure  Safety and in our Medical, Environmental & Analysis sector. And overall, our R&D spend was 5.2% of revenue.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Currency translation benefits, I've mentioned, we're expecting somewhere around a 10% benefit for the full year,  say, if FX rates stay where they are and on the expected revenue and profit mix. There should also be a small  benefit in the full year from some restructuring that we've done in the Environmental & Analysis sector. Andrew  will just touch on that, give you some details.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Simple summary. Infrastructure Safety, Medical and Environmental & Analysis all increased their revenue and  profit. And then you can see lower revenue and profit in Process Safety. As expected, we still see subdue  demand from the energy resources markets. We're still balancing that control of overheads with the need to invest  to diversify those businesses into non-energy and resource markets. And I think, we expect to see the  improvements from those investments continue to emerge and expect that sectors you'll see to return to growth  as we go through the second half.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: These figures then include the contribution from currency and also from prior acquisitions. So, if we look at the  organic constant currency numbers, similar picture, but there are some differences there. So if you take each  sector in turn, you see a really strong underlying performance from Infrastructure Safety, good revenue growth in  the Medical sector with slightly lower profit growth, good revenue growth in Environmental & Analysis. But actually  disappointing profit, but as you'll see the sector is now better placed for the second half of the year. And finally, as  I mentioned earlier, that lower revenue and profit organically in Process Safety.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And now in the appendix, I've included or recalculated those figures on the weekly average basis. Obviously, the  relative performances are very much the same. The only difference you see is Environmental & Analysis goes  into positive territory in organic constant currency terms.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And when you look at the variability in these figures, particularly the growth figures, it just emphasizes that point  about the ability to be flexible and agile when you see different markets growing at different rates. If we take the  largest three end market segments, the building segments, that's the Infrastructure Safety segment  predominantly, the Health and Medical segment, that's one that's driven by our Medical sector and the Science  and Environmental segment driven by Environmental & Analysis. All three of those of our largest segments  showed good growth during the half year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And it's interesting to see the impact of Process Safety on energy and resources down 5%. But it's only 8% to the  group. Actually, the majority of our growth comes from non-energy and resource markets, even though those  markets tend to get a lot of attention from outside.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And just to remind you, what we're selling here is, 95% of what we sell goes into non-residential structures. So,  it's public places rather than domestic property. And two-thirds of what we're selling is going into refurbishment.  So, we're not reliant on new construction cycles.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: The silver lining with that delay was it really enabled us to focus CenTrak's attention on expanding their business  into new markets, whether through new applications or into new regions. So, examples of new applications are  the new products they've launched to help with the monitoring of patients, wandering patient allotment. So,  making sure patients are kept in safe places. They've launched new products for environmental monitoring, things  like blood samples and vaccines in hospitals. And they've continued to roll out some successful product trials in  the NHS in the UK because until now, they've been focused on the U.S. market. So, there's some silver lining  there to the contract delays. And certainly, I remain excited about the growth potential of CenTrak's business as  we look certainly into the next financial year and beyond.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And in environmental analysis, pleased with the progress here. Revenue up by 13%, organic constant currency  up 4%, profit up 9%, but organically a decline of 2%. What's interesting here is from a P&L point of view, it's  actually a pretty healthy position. So, increased gross margins, but also increased investments. So, R&D spend  up by 12% and now represents 6.7% of revenue. So 6.7% of revenue, so higher than the group average. It's  sitting exactly where I'd expect the R&D investment to be higher and what it meant was our return on sales  16.2%.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: But the background to that is that our environmental, our food safety and our water businesses are all doing well,  but we saw lower profit from our life science and research business, and that was predominantly due to our  optical coatings business, Pixelteq. Now, many of you remember that a couple of years ago, we consolidated  Pixelteq from two manufacturing locations in the U.S. down to one, and we did that in order to secure some  intellectual property around multi-spectral imaging.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: U.S.A. is almost half the sector. Now, it's about 46% of revenue and all of the sub-segments were up, with a  particularly good performance from our water businesses. So, our water testing and quality businesses are doing  very well in the U.S. market at the moment. And we also saw encouraging progress in Asia Pacific, also up 10%.  Very encouraging results in China. We're seeing good opportunities there in many of the environmental  monitoring markets. And we saw a good performance out of Japan, too, during the half year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: UK was down 10%. A little slow in the UK water market in the first half of the year. But actually opportunities are  still good and we expect to see better progress from those businesses in the UK in the second half of the year.  And we also saw just lower demand from other UK utilities during the first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Overheads were higher than last year. So, this is the part of the group where we've really been trying to get the  balance right between giving control of the overheads but still investing to move out of a real narrow focus on –  some of the business have already narrow focus on the oil and gas markets. That investment is helping us  develop new products in other markets.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Oil and gas was around 50% of the sector a couple of years ago. It's now around 40% of the sector revenue  today. So, I expect to see the benefits of that investment in diversifying to new regions and end markets, starting  to emerge more strong as we go through the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: On the organic constant currency side of things, you can see all regions had lower revenue. And in the U.S.A., it  was really our pipeline monitoring and pressure release businesses. So the greatest challenge is there. There's  faint signs of improvement in the shale gas market in recent months. So, now that some of those facilities are up  and running again, we're seeing some demand for our pressure release devices, as I say, only sort of faint signs  in the last couple of months.

file: HLMAL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 21November2017 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Let's just take a look at sort of the organic constant currency, so stripping out acquisitions and currency, and so  the underlying picture. And you can see again strong growth in each of the regions on that basis. Andrew will talk  you through the geographic performance in each of the sectors, but just wanted to give you an overview. We had  the U.S. growing in line with our expectations at 6%, a nice recovery in Process Safety there. UK and Mainland  Europe both delivered strong growth, 9% growth this time, and I'd say that was probably ahead of our  expectations. We saw the UK with all four sectors growing, in particular the Water businesses in Environmental &  Analysis, some strong contribution in the UK.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Cash conversion was good, it's at 84%. And then, as Andrew mentioned, R&D expenditure up 19%. It's now 5.4%  of revenue. We saw better increases in Medical and Environmental & Analysis, and that pushed up the same  percentage from 5.2% in the first half of last year. So, overall, a really good set of results, and I'll hand you back to  Andrew for a trading update.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And you see a similar picture when you look at it in organic constant currency terms. So, in overall terms 9%  revenue, 8% profit, as Kevin said, well-above our 5% KPIs. And you can see strong organic revenue and profit  grow in three sectors. It's worth pointing out Environmental & Analysis profit growth of 27%, really pleased to see  that after the reorganization we completed in the first half of last year. So, we're just seeing the benefits of that  really coming through.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, you can see, we've got growth in all of our end markets, and all of these end markets have strong regulatory  aspects to them, so either regulation driving demand for the products or regulation driving the product approvals  that we need to gain before we can sell into that market. And the sector trends really start to play out when you  look at the end markets. So, if we take buildings, for example, 7% organic growth, that's predominantly our  Infrastructure Safety sector driving that progress. And then, the Medical sector driving the 4% growth in health  and medical; the E&A sector driving demand in science and environmental and utilities markets, up 16% and 19%  organically.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: At the individual business unit level, Safety Interlocks performed well as did Pipeline Management and Pressure  Relief businesses.
