Those Pressure Relief businesses still enjoying good demand from the U.S. onshore market,  the fracking applications that we developed a few years back still going very well for us there.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, looking forward to the second half of the year, we're not expecting any big recovery in the broader Oil & Gas  markets, except obviously continued support in the U.S. onshore market. But that diversification that we bought  into this sector as we went through the last year will continue to support underlying organic growth despite  obviously a tougher second half comparator this year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And finally, we've got the Environmental & Analysis sector, and this has been another really strong half year for  this sector, which is really pleasing after some of the restructuring that we did in the first half of last year. So,  revenue was up 18% to £117 million with 11% organic constant currency growth. The profit was up 36% to £22  million, 27% organic constant currency growth and return on sales up from 16.2% to 18.7%. And we really saw  improvements across the P&L here. We saw gross margins up usefully during the first half of the year, no doubt  benefiting from R&D spend that we've really pushed up in this sector over the past few years. It's the highest  technology part of the group. And indeed, in the first half of the year, we increased our R&D spend further by 33%  which is now 7.6% of revenue in this sector.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: We saw growth in all market segments, particularly Spectroscopy & Photonics performing very well. And following  the year-end, we made an acquisition. We acquired Mini-Cam, which adds to our Water businesses, and again, I'll  give you a little bit of an insight into what Mini-Cam do a little bit later. And finally, we look at the revenue by  destination. Again, reported revenue in all the major regions slightly more of a mixed picture when you look at it  from the organic perspective, just pick up on a few of those. So, you see 28% growth in the UK. As Kevin  mentioned, the UK Water Utilities invested very well in flow monitoring, pressure monitoring, leakage detection  during the first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: We saw Asia Pacific up 22%. All the sectors really doing very well here. Environmental monitoring, the desire for  clean water, clear air, all of that is helping this sector get really good growth and even our Photonics businesses  are seeing some very nice opportunities for growth in China, in particular. Solid performance in the U.S. and then  Europe you see down slightly. This is quite interesting, in fact, most of the sectors was slightly down in Europe  over the – sorry, segments were slightly down in Europe during the half year particularly a weak area would be in  France. The Water businesses there didn't sell as well as they'd hoped. We are seeing signs of some  improvements as you come through the second half of the year, but again, it's something that we need to watch  closely and make sure we get widespread progress there.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: I talked back in June, earlier in the year about how the pipeline is certainly more evenly spread across the four  sectors, how it seems to be better in quality and quantity terms to where it was maybe a couple of years ago. So,  I'm really pleased the fact that we've completed four deals across three sectors so far this year. We've spent a  total of £94 million. We've paid an average multiple of around 10.5 to 11 times trailing EBIT. And it's just giving us  good evidence that we can still find good small- to medium-sized businesses in and around our existing markets  at sensible prices. What's also been good to see is that the M&A teams between the sectors are working together.  So, the Mini-Cam acquisition, even though Mini-Cam has joined our Environmental & Analysis sector was actually  found by the Process Safety sector who then work closely with the E&A team to get that business into the group,  even though it ultimately ended up in a different sector.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And then we got Cardios, which is Halma's first-ever acquisition in Brazil. They're a market leader in Brazil for  both ECG and blood pressure monitoring monitors, and they not only bring some new technology, some improved  technology particularly in blood pressure monitoring to the group, but also they gave us a new channel into the  South American market for some of our Medical Device businesses. And obviously, we're going to be working  hard to help Cardios grow their business internationally, again by sharing channels or indeed using some of the  Halma infrastructure in places such as China and India. And then we've got down the bottom here Mini-Cam; this  is the largest acquisition since the half year end. We've paid £62 million for Mini-Cam with a £23 million earn-out.  And they're a UK-based wastewater pipeline monitoring business.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, waste water monitoring is really a core market in our Environmental & Analysis sector. We've got many  companies such as HWM and Hydreka who have been operating there for many years. So, immediately, we've  got good cross-selling opportunities both in the UK and internationally. And I think in the medium to long term, it  may well be that we may need to add new imaging and sensing technologies to their devices to maybe do new  things in terms of pipeline monitoring of waste water in the future. So, some good short, medium, and long-term  growth opportunities with Mini-Cam joining the group. And then finally, the acquisition we announced today, Setco  trades under the name of Microkey. So, we spent €17 million to that business. It makes around €1.7 million, €1.8  million of profit. And they are based in Spain, and they're a manufacturer of wireless communication devices for  elevator safety.

file: HLMAL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 13June2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Jun-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: In particular, our Medical businesses and our Infrastructure Safety businesses did particularly well and that offset  some decline in the Environmental & Analysis sector.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Let's look at the performances of each of the four sectors now. So I've got a summary here of the revenue. And  here's the revenue growth for the four sectors. So you can see a standout performance from the Medical sector.  Solid progress from our two safety sectors and a disappointing year there, Environmental & Analysis, revenue  down 1% as I'll discuss, part of that's down to reduced spend by the UK water companies and partly down to  reduced spend from U.S. government research projects.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: You'll remember last year I showed you a film of a new bursting disk that we have developed for the fracking  process in the U.S. That product, for example, is selling very well now in that particular market. What we're also  seeing is increased investments in international expansion, improving the overall performance of this sector; so  good headline results, but a very, very impressive underlying performance.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Here's a new chart to the presentation, which is looking at the sector by end market. Originally, a diverse range of  end markets, here you can see in Process Safety. Largest of which is energy and resources, not surprisingly that's  39% of the sector and we're seeing strong growth there during the year particularly in the Middle East,  particularly from new products like that fracking bursting disk that I touched on earlier.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: And this is the revenue by end market. Not a huge amount of information here. I suppose just to add to it a bit  more color. Two-thirds of what we're selling is, as I say, existing buildings, so it's not a sector which is reliant on  new construction. And over 95% of what we sell is non-residential buildings. So it's in the commercial  environmental. The blue part there, we call others, that's really selling sensors into transportation markets. For  example, in the past, we've been selling in to the high-speed train projects in China. But I expect another solid  year for Infrastructure Safety in the coming year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: And another end-market chart which is dominated by a single sector, quite clearly healthcare/medical. A little bit  of what we sell goes into science and environmental markets, mainly that's crossover of technology between our  Fluid Technology companies selling into the different market areas. So overall, a very strong performance from  Medical, it's certainly a part of the group that I see further opportunities for M&A growth and also continued  strong organic growth in the short-term and also the longer term.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Let's finish off then with Environmental & Analysis. A disappointing year here compared to the other three sectors  with revenue down 1% and profit down 4%. Return on sales is still strong, it's 19.9% compares with 20.6% last  year, so still a good returns business, but obviously we wanted to see better growth coming through.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: And two major factors there, which I touched on at the beginning. So the UK water utilities moving towards the  mid to later part of their five-year investment cycle. So as expected, we saw less investment from them during the  year, particularly in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: And on the other hand, we're also refocusing some of our senior management resource on some of the higher  potential opportunities. So in this sector, for example, we've got some great new UV LED technology that we're  looking to use in water treatment in some new industrial applications. And we're also looking at the growth  opportunities in Asia relative to other parts of the world, so spinning off one or two of our Asian businesses to be  standalone subsidiaries in the group so that we can invest more specifically in the growth opportunity that we see  ahead of them.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: That reorganization is going to come with a cost. I estimate it's going to cost us around £1 million this year to carry  out that reorganization. Mainly, that'll fall in the first half of the year, so I'm expecting overall that to impact on  the overall result for the year. And so we're kind of expecting a flattish year from Environmental & Analysis in  2013-2014.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Look at the regional trends and the growth rates here, given what I've just said, no great surprises. UK down,  that's because the water utilities are mainly based in the UK, in terms of where we are selling. And then in the  U.S., you see a flat performance there, government research spend impacting, encouraging progress, however, in  Asia Pacific, up 13%. We continue to make good progress there. And whilst, the absolute percentages, I'm sure will  be different this year, I think the relative strength of the various parts of the world will probably be similar this  year, with perhaps a little bit of improvement in the UK in year-on-year terms.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: Interestingly, our most diverse sector, so a range of end markets that we serve. You can imagine that utilities and  science and environmental down this year because of what we just talked through. And I think the overall theme  here with the companies is just making sure that we're not just focusing on their technology and selling their  technology to any market. It's getting them to focus on markets that have got those Halma growth drivers and  ensure that those are the areas where they're – I'd say focusing most of their R&D investment on. But I'm  confident that the actions we're taking here are going to improve the performance as we move through the year  and certainly, as we go into 2014, we should be in a much better shape to sustain our growth on a more consistent  basis.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: And then two in Environmental & Analysis, Sensorex, water quality testing, and then ASL here on the bottom row,  making wireless technology for water and energy applications. All are trading well. The integration is going well.  And what's pleasing me is we're already seeing some of these companies collaborate with the existing Halma  businesses. So, for example, SunTech already looking to cross-sell their blood pressure monitoring businesses  with our German blood pressure monitoring business, Riester, it's good to see them coming in to the group and  trying to actively take advantage of what the group has to offer them.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: You saw at the end there, the Innovation Award winners. So every year, it's the 10th year, actually, we've had the  Annual Innovation Awards, top price is £20,000 to the individual team that come with the best innovation idea  during the year and this year, as you saw at the end of clip, won by Hanovia, they made a UV water treatment  product for ballast water treatment in marine shipping.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: We also had then the runners up, Oseco did a new bursting disk for fluid and gas applications, outdoor sensor  business, BA who made a new sliding door sensor, which is the easiest to install product on the market, so very  strong range of entries and a great way for the group to celebrate the innovation successes.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: CEO, Executive Director & Head-Investor Relations, Halma Plc
texts.text: In people development, we've got the HGDP, the second year of that. In international expansion, we've got things  like the Process Safety hub in Brazil, so increasing investment in organic growth. And finally, we'll be looking for  improvement for Environmental & Analysis. As we go through the year particularly during the second half, see  some of the benefits coming through from the reorganization in the first half year and obviously wanting to enter  the year – sorry, finish the year go into next year in really good shape to deliver more sustainable growth.

file: HLMAL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 12June2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Jun-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Now, Andrew's going to give you a bit more color on how this geography breaks down by sector, but just some  overall comments. All sectors grew in the U.S., Medical, in particular, was boosted by those prior year  acquisitions. Environmental & Analysis was a standout performer in the UK, in particular, our water businesses.  And in Europe, we saw a small decline in the previous year, but that actually became solid growth in these results,  as you can see, they're 8% up. And then in Asia, we had a strong performance in Medical and a weaker  performance in Environmental & Analysis.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: This is the first half/second half split. And you can see, growth 9% at the headline level, but you can see much  stronger underlying growth in the second half of the year over there in the right-hand column. You may recall we  had a supplier quality problem in the first half in our water business. That's now resolved.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: And also, in the first half, we started the reorganization in our photonics businesses, which is now nearing  completion, and at less than the £1 million that we forecast. And we are starting to see the benefits of that  reorganization in the Environmental & Analysis sector in the performance that we've seen increasingly through  the year. And we also saw a strong finish to the year. So the first half/second half split here is 46/54, same as it  was in the previous year, and also that's our current forecast for the coming year.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: It's also worth noting that the currency translation has a different impact on our sectors. So in the full year, on the  same basis, so using current exchange rates, expect about a 2% to 3% adverse impact on the two safety sectors,  and more like a 4% adverse impact on Medical and Environmental & Analysis. I've put more information in the  appendix on currency rates, currency impacts, all those things, just [ph] in rough (10:44) figures that I've just  been giving, to give more color on that.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Let's look at the overall portfolio first, and you can see we have a pretty balanced portfolio. So half of the group, if  you like, is in safety, our two safety sectors, Process Safety and Infrastructure Safety, and half of it, Medical and  Environmental & Analysis. So, health and safety regulation driving, if you like, the right hand side as you look at  it, and then increasing demand for healthcare, increasing demand for life-critical resources like water on the left  hand side.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: So let's look at where that growth is coming from. Here's the revenue by destination for the sector and these are  the growth rates we achieved in the past year. So you can see, USA up 13%. We're getting particularly good growth  in oil and gas in the U.S. and especially in shale gas and fracking, where we're finding new safety applications for  our businesses. We also saw 12% growth in Asia Pacific. Here we saw China and South Korea performing very  well, offsetting some weakness that we experienced in Australia.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: And in combination, the UK and Europe, you see there is pretty flat performance. So oil and gas has been okay, a  more of a mixed picture there with some of the general process industries. These are the revenue – or this is the  revenue by end market for Process Safety. So 40% of what we sell here goes into energy and resources. And just to  remind you, it's mainly oil and gas, not so much mining, and the products we sell are mainly part of the OpEx  expenditure by customers rather than part of that CapEx expenditure.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: If you look at the major segments there, utilities, process industries, and energy and resources, we saw a good  growth in all three of those major segments during the past year. So, overall, another excellent year for Process  Safety. And I think, looking forward, it's going to be about new product launches, driving growth, as well as  continued international expansion, both in developed and developing markets, supplemented of course by the  recent acquisition of RCS, and I'll speak about that in a few moments.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Infrastructure, as you know, a majority of what we saw here goes into buildings. Two-thirds of what we sell goes  into existing buildings. So the demand driver here is health and safety regulation.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: So this sector is dominated by demand driven by increasing demand for healthcare globally. We also sell some of  our medical fluidic devices, so pumps and valves. We also sell into some science and environmental markets,  which as well – they're growing pretty well too. So, overall, for our Medical sector, it's been another year of high  growth. I'm pleased to see that the recent acquisitions are bedding down well in the organization, and I say,  promising to contribute strongly to growth in the future.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Finally, our Environmental & Analysis sector, and after last year's disappointing performance, I'm really pleased  to stand here now and say, look, we delivered growth, revenue up 9% to £167 million, profit up 4% to £32 million,  and also good to see organic growth. So organic growth of 5% for revenue and 2% for profit.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Geographic trends are interesting. If you look at those, you see some similarities and contrast with the other  sectors. In actual fact, these are very similar to the trends we saw at the half-year. So UK very strong at 53%. Kevin  mentioned the UK water utilities buying more flow and pressure monitoring devices in preparation for the  deregulation of the commercial water market by 2017. And we've had some help from one of acquisitions last year,  the business called ASL. If we strip that out, however, UK still grew in this sector organically by 24% during the  year. Now, I don't expect to see that rate of growth maintained, but we still see good growth opportunities in that  market in the year to come.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Solid performances in the U.S. and Europe; interestingly, Asia Pacific down 5% here. That's actually an  improvement on the half-year, where it was down 9%. Just to remind you there, we've had some major projects in  the prior year in photonics and water that came to an end. Obviously, we look for other projects to come through  now in the year ahead.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: And this is one of our more diverse sectors in terms of the end markets. Utilities grew well this year, mainly on the  back of that UK water growth. And that Process segment, that 9%, is actually growing well. We're increasingly  finding new industrial applications for technologies that we developed in the past for R&D. So, an example of that  would be customers who are developing LCD panels. In the past, we sold instrumentation to their development  engineers to develop new products. Now they've developed those new products. We can sell those same systems to  the manufacturing plant to be able to control the quality of manufacture, obviously in greater quantities.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: So, overall for Environmental & Analysis, I'd say really good results after a pretty tough year, steady improvement,  looking for a better contribution over the coming years from developing markets, increase the growth rate there,  and also new product launches. Those are the two things that are likely to sustain improved performance in the  future.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Let's look for a brief moment at the most recent acquisition we've made, which was the RCS, Rohrback Cosasco  Systems business, that was recently acquired by the Neil Quinn, our Process Safety CEO. So RCS make devices  and systems which are used for monitoring corrosion in pipelines, both invasively and non-invasively,  predominantly for oil and gas industry. And we found them because just over two years ago we bought a business  called Sensorex in California.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: And almost as soon as we bought Sensorex, they said you want to take a look at the safety company up the road  called RCS. And we met with the owners, saw what they did and saw actually there's a lot in common here. They  sell into markets that we understand very well because we're selling to the oil and gas industry. They got  technology that we understand, ultrasonic technology, communications technology that we use quite extensively  elsewhere in the Group, but obviously it's a new application, corrosion monitoring, which we don't know much  about. So they ticked a lot of boxes.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: The other thing it's given us is a corporate infrastructure in China, which is starting to help us find more  acquisition opportunities and have a structure in place, which will allow us to start acquiring businesses too. So,  for me, the excitement comes from the fact that you look forward and say, well, the demand for healthcare,  environmental control for safety is going to increase still in the future in China as that country grows socially. So  we have that organic growth opportunity, but also now we're building our infrastructure to start finding and  acquiring businesses, just as we did with Longer Pump last year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Those of you who came to the HITE exhibition in Orlando back in May last year will have seen how the Group's  culture is changing in that way. And we recognize innovation – one of the ways we recognize innovation in the  Group is through Annual Innovation Award. And this year it was won by a collaborative project between Avo  Photonics and Aquionics, who developed this product called PearlSense. And PearlSense uses UV LED technology  to monitor UV water treatment plants.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: So compared to the way it's done previously, it's a smaller, safer, more accurate product, but also environmentally  friendly, does not use mercury-based lamp technology to measure the UV light, it uses LEDs. So the ultimate  benefit to the customer is it gives them a more efficient disinfection process so they can appropriately dose up the  UV according to the purity of the water, and it's a cheaper process because their energy costs come down too.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: We would not achieved that product development if it wasn't for Aquionics' expertise in UV water treatments and  LED technology and Avo Photonics' expertise in miniature photonics design and manufacture. So great to see  collaboration actually being recognized within the Group through the awards and also by the customers in the  market.

file: HLMAL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 11June2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Jun-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: In the second half, that reversed currency had a positive impact. So with the greater benefit from acquisitions, we  saw in the second half of the year we had a 12% headline growth second half. What you can also see here is the  organic constant currency figures over on the right, so there was 6% growth in second half, following 4% in the  first half. And in the second half, organic constant currency, we had all four sectors growing including  Environmental & Analysis, all growing well in the second half, but Process Safety and Medical were the fastest  growers.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: Europe was mixed. But when you look at it at organic constant currency, and I'll touch on that in a minute, all of  the sectors grew in Europe. Asia growth was a little lower than we've seen in the past few years, but we've got some  growth there, and also had Environmental & Analysis growing well, a good performer in Asia Pacific.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: Y ou can see here the other regions grew strongly. I think three main factors there. We had the RCS acquisition  within Process Safety, and that certainly had a good geographic footprint, boosted our other market sale s. There  was good progress in Africa, Near and Middle East, in particular in the two safety sectors, and good growth in  South America this year including an oil and gas project.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: So here's the first half, second half split. Similar to revenue, we had a big adverse currency hit in the first half,  which reversed somewhat in the second half, and we also benefited from more second half acquisitions or the  benefit of them coming through in the second half. We also start to see the reorganization in Environmental &  Analysis, giving more benefit as the year went through. But the growth rate in the second half came from the other  three sectors, so Infrastructure Safety, Process Safety and Medical growing well.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: Currency impacts vary by sector, but Medical and Environmental & Analysis are the two that are most set toward  to changes in the dollar. So in the appendix, there's more information on currencies, the currency rates, the  impacts of currency movement, so you can navigate your way through as the currencies move.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, here are the four sectors. Revenue and profit contributions, if you like, over the past years, th is is as reported  including all the M&A. And you can see we've got a pretty well-balanced portfolio. We've got the two safety sectors  on the top there, Medical sector, Environmental & Analysis sector. All four of these sectors have got good growth  opportunities. All four of these sectors deliver good high returns, both return on sales and return on capital. This  is story of the past year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And I just remind you, it's something I really talked about in great detail at the end of the first half, so two major  issues in the first half. One was completing the consolidation of two of our U.S. photonics optical coating  businesses that was complete in October 2014. And the second point was, as we expect to be, so lower spending  from the UK water utilities during the year. And obviously, that continues in the second half. That's something we  expect to improve as we go through this financial year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Just to remind you, here, we sell into quite diverse end markets, but they're all driven by increase in health and  safety regulation. That's a good long-term growth driver there. And in the year, we saw our Bursting Disk  businesses performed well. Our Valve Interlock businesses performed very well, so both strong organically. And  we also had a really good performance from RCS, the pipeline corrosion monitoring business, that we bought in  May 2014.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And here are the reported growth rates, the revenue growth rates by sector. So, America, USA, up 34%. That's a  combination of the RCS acquisition, a California-based business, but also strong organic growth, I'd say,  particularly in Bursting Disk. They're selling into new niches both in process industries and also into oil and gas.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Both UK and Europe, they're growing at 2% and 8% respectively, UK certainly slower growth than we saw in  previous years, so we saw a certainly slowing demand from the North Sea oil industry during the second half of  the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And finally 8% growth in Europe. I think that's encouraging, again quite broad based in terms of the growth there,  but it's pleasing to see progress coming through in Europe. And finally, we see revenue by end markets. So, almost  half of what we sell here is into energy including the oil and gas industries.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: However, we're realistic. It's likely to be a tougher year this year for these businesses particularly as the continuing  lower oil price has an impact on investment. I think we've got some resilience in there, not just because of the  growth drivers, but also we tend to sell products that are in the OpEx part of customers' budget rather than being  part of big CapEx projects. But nonetheless, I think it's going to be a year where we got to keep working hard at  new product development, keep working hard in international expansions to maintain a good rate of growth.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So summarize, Process Safety had a very good year, boosted by strong organic growth, a good acquisition in RCS,  and we expect to make further progress this year, although we are expecting some headwinds in the oil and gas  industries.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And we got a small segment 6% we sell into science and environmental markets. That really comes from our fluid  technology component businesses, selling some of their medical pumps and valves and connectors through to  other OEMs in the science and environmental market space. So in summary, the Medical sector had a strong year,  and we expect that to continue in the year ahead.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Finally, a challenging year for Environmental & Analysis but strong improvement coming through in the second  half of the year. So, look at the full-year figures, our revenue down by 1% to £164 million, but actually that was  very slight organic constant currency growth. And our profit was down by 14%, organically down by 12% to give us  £27 million of profit for the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And our return on sales, 16.7%, obviously below the group 18% to 22% range. But as we'll see, we're makin g good  progress towards getting back into that this current year. So, we had the cost and disruption of the photonics U.S.  consolidation in the first half of the year, which is now behind us, and we started the recovery from that. And as I  said earlier on in the presentation, we had the – got lack of investment as expected from the UK water utilities.  Again, we expect that to improve as we go through the current financial year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, let's take the developed markets first, so strongest growth in Europe. Actually, that's mid single -digit organic  growth if you take into effect the euro. And I think what drove the growth here, very much the photonics business  is actually growing in Europe and also, our water quality test kit companies getting good growth in some of the  European territories. On the other hand, UK was down that's predominantly the UK water u tilities, and the USA  was down that's mainly the disruption in cost of the photonics consolidation, both of which should be behind us  now.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Then we've got Asia Pacific and Other, so developing regions, good growth here. Asia Pacific, good mid single -digit  growth. Again, the water quality business is doing well. Another part of the group that's doing well here is our UV  water treatment businesses. They've established a good strong position in the bottled drinking water market in  China, so selling to the people who are disinfecting bottling drinking water, and that's obviously a fast growing  market in that region.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And then we see the diversity of this sector. It's probably a bit more diverse than other the four sectors. Utilities  obviously was down this year with the UK water companies actually come back this year. Biggest part of the sector  though was science and environmental. That's a substantial end market for our photonics businesses. It's also a  good market for our specialist gas conditioning business. We've got a couple of small business in the U.S., good  strong businesses, they continue to perform well in that segment.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So in summary, I expect to see the improvement that we saw during the second half of the year continue into the  current year and then get further boosted by improved spending from the UK water utilities as we get into the  second half of the current financial year. So, those are the four sectors [indiscernible] (35:22) in the past.

file: HLMAL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 14June2016 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Jun-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: So, this is the revenue by destination shows the proportion in each region and the revenue growth around the  outside. Andrew is going to talk about the individual sector performances, their geographic performances, but I  want to give you some comments about the regions overall. So you can see here, the USA, it's now more than a  third of revenue, up from 31% last year with 22% growth this year. I think what's for now to me is not only all  sectors growing, but we had Environmental & Analysis and Medical growing by more than 20%, Infrastructure  Safety grew by nearly 40%. So the last two sectors, Medical and Infrastructure Safety had the benefit of  acquisitions, but strong growths in the U.S. All four sectors had mid-single digit growth in the UK and again all  sectors grew, Europe with particularly strong medical sales.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: Asia grew well overall, including 10% growth in China, 29% growth in India, but Asia was more of a mixed picture.  So, we had Medical and Environmental & Analysis growing strongly, flat in infrastructure and a decline in process  safety.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: Then the other regions up 7%, so strong growth in Africa, Near and Middle East, and particularly Infrastructure  Safety and Environmental & Analysis growing well in the Middle East. The South America was tough for all of the  sectors, particularly Process Safety, potentially all sectors found tough there.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: Next here's the revenue by destination but organic constant currency, so taking out acquisitions and currency  effects. Y ou can see growth in all the main regions, USA growth was similar to the first half 9% and 9% for the year  overall. There was a slight decline in Process Safety but good growth elsewhere across the U.S. All sectors grew in  the UK and in Mainland, Europe measured to organic constant currency and Asia again was mixed, but again,  good performances in Medical and Environmental & Analysis. The other decline you see here is again South  America.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: So you can see here organic constant currency growth was 4% for the year – sorry 4% in the first half and 3% for  the year overall. Thing as we expected Process Safety declined in the second half with similar percentage to the  first half at organic constant currency. But the other sectors grew well in the second half at organic constant  currency in particular Environmental & Analysis had very strong growth.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.text: So, as medical, environment analysis revenue and profit translation that we will benefit most from exchange rates  at those levels, that there is more information on exchange rates FX movements in the appendices.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Three of the sectors, Infrastructure Safety, the Medical sector and Environmental & Analysis achieved record  results. And then we saw resilient demand in Process Safety, so still impacted by the low oil price. And what you  will also see is a bigger profit drop than revenue drop. And that wasn't just about operational gearing, there's two  other factors really at play there, first one was that we carried on increasing our investment to diversify. So, for  example, our R&D investment in that sector increased by over 4% despite the reduction in revenue. And secondly,  a mixed issue, so the average margin – gross margin we make from products we sell into oil and gas industry are,  in general, higher than the margins we sell into – the margins we make selling to non-oil and gas customers, and  we saw that impact on the trading in that sector during the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: These are the organic constant currency figures, quite a similar picture particularly in relative terms, very pleased  with the recovery in Environmental & Analysis that you can down the bottom left there, strong double -digit  organic growth in both revenue and profit. Good to see strong underlying growth in Infrastructure Safety and the  Medical sectors, so it's not just about the acquisitions they made during the year and Process Safety, I've already  explained the – the difference there between the revenue and the profit figures.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And then we got 5% others, that's really transportation. So, our door safety business is historically sold into that  market, things like transportation, train transportation systems, that kind of stuff, Firetrace will add to that. So,  Firetrace with some of their fire suppression solutions goes into transportation applications too.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And then those other markets, the small segment was down slightly as Kevin mentioned earlier on, in fact, all our  sectors saw some challenges in South America and that's what really driving that figure there. And here, the  revenue by end market, dominated by healthcare and medical applications, and obviously the addition of CenTrak  and Visiometrics during the year will only add to that, 6% goes into science and environmental markets, that's  really our are fluid component businesses, predominantly selling into Medical markets but also finding some  applications with OEMs in science and environmental applications.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, in summary, a very strong year, three acquisitions, good growth in both developing and developed markets,  and obviously very well placed to make further progress this coming year. And then, we go t our Environmental &  Analysis sector, I'm really pleased with the turnaround in the sector this year and not only has it recovered what it  lost last year, which had a challenging year last year, but also it's delivered a record year both in terms of reven ue  and profit.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: To remind you, the demand here is driven by the need for life-critical resources. So, is to do our technology, if you  like, improves the quality of the air we breathe, the water we drink, the food we eat, so a variety of science and  environmental applications, and all the subsectors in this sector contributed to the growth this past year. So our  Water businesses, as expected, started to see an increase in investment from the UK water companies, as we  moved through the second half of the year. And our Photonics business is really building on the innovation that  they've done both in processes and products over the past couple of years, and started to find new OEMs both in  the U.S. and also in some developing markets too, so good widespread growth.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: When we look at it by destination, you can see there's strong growth again in all regions both as reported and  indeed organically, especially outside the UK and Europe. So, the UK was particularly – sorry the U.S. is  particularly strong across all our subsectors, organic growth of 14%. Asia-Pacific, again, widespread growth, some  examples there. We're finding some interesting environmental monitoring applications in India, and we're seeing  our Water Technology businesses continue to find good growth in China, both in terms of setting to water utilities  and also setting to industrial users.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And I look at other regions up 26% organically, strong growth in the Middle East from both our Water and  Photonics businesses, so a good contribution from everyone there regionally. This is our most diverse sector by  end market, you can see that on this chart. So, science and environmental is the most substantial market for the  sector, it's the most substantial market for our Photonics business, and our fluidics business, and that was actually  pretty steady year-on-year up from 41% of the sector last year to 42% for the sector this year. Utilities is the area  where we saw relative growth, so that was 23% for the sector last year; it's now 26% this year and that's where the  improved UK demand, the improved demand from China for our water products contributing there. So, in  summary very pleased with this recovery year. I think there's still a lot more we can do to improve our  performance both in product development and international expansion, but I expect the [indiscernible] (31:56) to  make further progress in this coming year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, the decline we saw year-on-year, to remind you was just those dual factors, some operational gearing, but  sustained investment in R&D. So, we increased R&D investment and also the GM mix of moving some of our  sales, if you like, from oil and gas into other process industries.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: I'm pleased to see how quickly the companies have been able to diversify into new markets. So, the two business  areas that really got impacted by the low oil price are our [indiscernible] (33:18) business and our pipeline  monitoring businesses, and for example, our [indiscernible] (33:23) business was able to shift a lot of it's resource  away from shale gas into new application such as pharmaceutical manufacturing, some fire suppression  applications, chemical process plants. And then, I think the other factor, remember, is over half a sector does not  have significant exposure to oil and gas. So, our Gas Detection business and our Interlock businesses, they  continue to grow nicely over the past year without that, downside exposure.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Here's the revenue by destination. Interestingly, they're all kind of single digit [indiscernible] (33:57) except in the  other markets, which as Kevin alluded to earlier on is really the South America impact. A more positive picture in  developed markets, UK was up, our Gas Detection business did well there, Europe was up, more geographical  picture here. We saw interestingly, France down a bit, Germany down a bit, a stronger growth in Russia. And if  you look at Asia-Pacific, down 9% organically, that was really the story there with Australia, so most of our   businesses fell into energy and resources in Australia, that was down significantly. Although we are seeing some  bright spots emerging, so we saw some progress and useful progress in South Korea, which is an area we haven't  typically done so well in, and also India and China continue to grow year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And here is the revenue by end market. And you can see energy and resources continues to be a substantial part of  the group, but to remind you, it's 49% of the sector last year, its 41% of the sector this year, which means we did  make good progress in those other markets considering we're only 2% down overall in revenue. So, process  industries, the dark blue segment there was 24% of the sector last year, it's 28% of the sector this year. And we will  keep investing on that – in that diversification because we do see some good opportunities for growth. And of  course, as and when we see recovery in the energy and resources market, we'll be even better placed than we are  now to really benefit from that improvement too.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So in summary here, I think the sector is better positioned than it was a year ago in terms of diversity of the  markets it serves. It is more diversified and we will be in a position to benefit from and improve in the energy  market as and when that happens, but I think realistically looking at the year ahead, it's going to be three sectors  that are really going to drive the growth of the group overall. [indiscernible] (35:51) review of the sectors and  review of the group, just want to change gear a bit now and look to the future, and just give you a little bit of an  insight in what we've been doing in terms of investing for the future.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And I think one of the reasons behind our ability to sustain that growth and those returns over such a long period  of time, and the fact [indiscernible] (44:57) been a key differentiator for the group, a big part of that has come  through things like our sustained increase in R&D investment over that period of time. And we've got some great  examples, we've talked about over the years. I talk about the Halma Innovation Awards and the people who've  won that award. I think this year again another exciting winner is an Environmental & Analysis business, HWM,  and they've developed a remote leak monitoring and pinpointing system for the water industry, a product called  PermaNet, plus another great example of how Halma companies are harnessing the value of digital and  communication technologies to really drive competitive advantage and growth in their market. So, here is an idea  of how this works.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, this is on the [ph] pit – diagram (45:45) you see there is, you've got a grey sensor, which is connected to the  water pipe either directly to the water itself through the water column or just fitted by a magnet onto the pipe. It's  connected to the blue box which is the data logger, which in itself is then connected to an antenn a which is all  underground, but it's got the ability to send a signal through GSM communication back to the water utility office.  Each of these senses an acoustic sensor.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So, it's listening for leak noise and it is intelligent. So, it can tell whether a leak is close by or not. And when it  detects that leak is close by, it sends a signal to the GSM system back to the – your water utility to say that the leak  close by, and it sends a recording of the leak noise itself because you can tell by listening to it  whether it's a leak or  whether it's some other source of noise. So, the water companies have got thousands of these sensors under the  grant.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Obviously, they then use their mapping system to put where the location of each of the sensors are. And when they   see, they got to neighboring sensors both in alarm mode, they can send a signal to the GSM – through the GSM  system to say, right, let's synchronize, let's record the leak noise. And through that, they've got a novel or we've  developed a novel time synchronization algorithm that allows the water utility to then pinpoint exactly on the  street where that leak is, so localizing it or pinpointing it right down to the nearest few meters. We believe this is  the first system in the water industry which has got entirely underground architecture and we're already winning  contracts with UK water utilities and obviously seeing some good global growth opportunities too.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And finally then international expansion. Over the last few years, I've talked a lot about China, and as you've  heard, we're still – we are still getting good growth in China, but I thought I just pick up on what's happening in  India, because I do think it's slowly picking up in terms of the operating company's agenda, and we're starting to  see some companies start to get some good growth there. It's clearly still a positive economy environment. It's still  a place where safety, health and environmental concerns are starting to get more visibility within society there,  but obviously at a slower rate of growth than we're seeing in a place like China.

file: HLMAL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 13June2017 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Jun-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: We had Medical and Environmental & Analysis growing strongly in the second half. We had Infrastructure Safety  finishing the year with good profit growth at organic constant currency, having had an exceptional first half. And as  expected, Process Safety recovered well in the second half with some good momentum.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Now if the U.S. dollar were around $1.30, the euro were around €1.15 relative to sterling over the next year and  based on the mix of profits that we had in 2016 and 2017, we'd expect a 1% positive currency translation impact  through in 2017 and 2018 coming through next year. And that will be maybe a 4% benefit in the first half,  reversing somewhat in the second half. And just to note that it's Medical and Environmental & Analysis that get  the biggest benefit from weaker sterling.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: If you look at the profit, it's interesting to see that Infrastructure Safety had a really strong year in profit growth  terms. But, actually, Medical sector became our largest profit contributor for the first time this year. Environmental  & Analysis built on its strong recovery last year with a good year this year. And I was really pleased to see  Process Safety get back to growth after a more challenging year last year. So, those were the reported figures.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: If we look at those in organic constant currency terms, you start to see some of the underlying stories there. But,  again, good organic constant currency profit growth in Infrastructure Safety, in Medical and Environmental &  Analysis.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: But again, let's focus on the organic constant currency figures. And really, you can see the sector stories playing  through. Because Buildings, which is our larger segment up 8%, that's really the Infrastructure Safety growth.  Health and Medical at 5%. Obviously, our Medial sector is strong there. We see the Environmental & Analysis  sector boosting revenue, particularly Utilities. Good performance from our Water business in the second half of  the year in particular. And then Process Safety's recovery shows through in both Process Industries which were  up 5%, and also interesting Energy and Resources up 2% organic constant currency through the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Here's the regional split of our revenue and revenue growth. So, let's look at the organic constant currency chart  on the right-hand side again. You can see U.S.A. slightly up. So, our pipeline management business is still seeing  challenging market conditions. But where we saw growth was in Safety Interlocks and also in our pressure relief  devices, and the latter in particular benefiting from some recovery in the U.S. onshore energy market in the  second half of the year, which is also high margin business for us.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: UK was down slightly, so still very quiet particularly in the North Sea oil and gas, and Europe was a solid  performance up 3%. Asia Pacific still quite tough. Within those figures, we've got Australasia and we continue to  see challenging market conditions in the Energy and Resources markets in Australasia.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And finally, we've got Environmental & Analysis. Revenue up 16% to £219 million, 4% organic growth, profit up  21% to £42 million pounds, 6% organic growth, both record results. Return on sales improved to 19% and now  getting more comfortably within that 18% to 22% target range. And again, R&D investment continues to increase,  up 22%. It's now 6.9% of sector revenue. It's the highest technology sector that we have. So, that's no surprise,  but it's good again to see the group company seeing good opportunities for investment there.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: We've got three subsectors in this sector. We've got the Life Sciences/Research sector, Water and Food Safety,  and Environmental Safety. And all three of those sectors increased both revenue and profit and we also had our  one acquisition this year in this sector with the acquisition of FluxData in the fourth quarter. That brings some  really good multi-spectral imaging technology to our Life Sciences/Research subsector, and there's good  collaborative opportunities with some of our photonics businesses that we've had in that sector for quite a while.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And then the revenue by destination figures show very strong growth particularly in U.S.A. and Asia Pacific. So,  organically, the U.S.A. was up 6%, Asia Pacific up 13%. China is particularly strong in this sector. We saw 20%  organic constant currency growth. So, the Chinese governments push to improve air quality, food safety, water  quality. That plays right into many of our activities in this sector.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Europe was down 4%. A bit of a mixed picture, difficult to pick out any big trends there. And to some extent, the  same goes in the UK. We were up 2%. The one area I'd say where we saw improvement during the year was in  Water. So, UK water utilities, certainly spent – invested more in the second half of the year and they're kind of  halfway through their five-year [indiscernible] (33:55) investment cycle. So, we'd expect to see a continued  improved investment as we go through certainly the first part of the current year. So, in summary, very happy with  where we are with environmental analysis, particularly after recovery last year. And again, it's a sector that's well  positioned for growth in the year ahead.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: We've continued to increase in investment. We completed the acquisition of FluxData in the fourth quarter, adding  new technology to the Environmental & Analysis sector. We had record R&D spend across all the four sectors,  and we increased our revenue from outside UK, Europe and U.S. The rest of the world now are becoming more  substantial part of our business.

file: HLMAL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 12June2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Jun-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: Now this is the picture if you take out acquisitions and currency translation, you get this picture of the underlying  trends. That's what we refer to as organic constant currency growth. And again, you can see really good growth  across all the regions. U.S.A. grew by 9%. You may recall that U.S.A. was up 6% in the first half and that  accelerated growth in the second half to 12%. Environmental & Analysis, really strong second half in the U.S. UK  grew by 9%, pretty even growth across the year. Mainland Europe up 8%, similar growth to that in the first half.  We had France down but Germany, Holland, Scandinavia all nicely up. And Asia Pacific grew well throughout the  year. It was up 14%. China was up 18% with growth in all four sectors. And the Other regions were up. We were  strong in Near and Middle East, otherwise good in Canada which we count in the other territories, mixed across  much of South and Central America but actually a strong performance in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: And this is the first half/second half split of profit. Headline adjusted profit was higher in the first half due to that  5% currency contribution sort of reversing in the second half. The first half/second half split was 44%/56%, very  close to our typical 45%/55% first half/second half split. And again, you see on the right hand side of the chart  here the organic constant currency profit growth increased from 8% in the first half to 9% in the second half,  giving 9% for the year overall. Breaking down that organic constant currency performance, we saw Environmental  & Analysis growing strongly through the year, Process Safety growing in the second half but not as fast as in the  first half, solid performance from Infrastructure Safety, and Medical as we expected recovering to growth in the  second half.

texts.speaker: Kevin J. Thompson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Halma Plc
texts.text: So just pulling together the strands on currency, as I say currency translation a neutral impact for the year overall  after a 5% benefit in the first half. The main currencies for us are the U.S. dollar and euro, to a lesser extent the  Swiss franc and the Chinese renminbi; all of that relative to sterling. So if we look forward in 2018-2019, if the  U.S. dollar relative to sterling was around $1.35, and that compares to $1.33 average rate in 2017-2018, and if  the euro is around €1.13 then if we based on last year's 2017-2018 mix of profits we probably expect a 1%  adverse currency translation impact for the year, bringing more like 2% in the first half and then reversing  somewhat in the second half. Just a reminder that it's Medical and Environmental & Analysis that have the most  benefit from a weaker sterling. But obviously sterling has been quite volatile over the past months. What I've just  given you is one potential 2018-2019 version of impacts on one set of assumptions. There's more information in  the appendices to the slide pack including the impact to 1% changes in currency on the results. So I think it's  worth having a look at your models to update your own models based on your own assumptions.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Both the Safety sectors performed really well even though Process Safety didn't quite beat the record profit it  achieved in 2015. Our Medical sector had really good revenue growth throughout the year, and as expected it  improved its profitability in the second half of the year. And then Environment & Analysis, you can see the  outstanding performance even if you exclude the benefit of the reorganization of Pixelteq in the prior year; very  strong underlying growth there. As Kevin mentioned, there's currency and M&A impacts on all these figures. So if  we have to look at the organic constant currency growth figures, you get a better sense of the underlying  progress. But it's a similar picture in many sense because you've got good organic constant currency revenue  growth in all sectors, good organic constant currency profit growth in all but the Medical sector which is marginally  down organically for the full year. Just to put that into context, at the end of H1 the Medical sector had a 6%  organic constant currency decline in profit, so we saw a 4% organic constant currency improvement in profit in the  second half of the year to finish up where we did. So overall I'm very pleased with the organic growth we've  achieved across the four sectors particularly against the backdrop of the increased investment that we've been  making this past year. I'm going to talk a little bit about the digital investment in a moment but also our R&D spend  was up by 12% at the group level during the year, just underpinning the fact that the companies are still investing  growing their core.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Let's briefly look at the revenue then by end market. So here we've got the reported revenue on the left and then  underlying organic constant currency figures on the right. So you can see growth in all of our industries, all of our  end markets, very much of similar patents what you'll see in the sector. So our highest rate of growth is in science  and environmental which is a key part of our Environmental & Analysis sector. Energy was up nicely; that's part of  our Process Safety sector, a big part of that sector. Buildings is the core of our Infrastructure Safety sector. And  then the progress that we've made in our Medical sector is reflected in the growth there in the health and medical  end market. And for me, this demonstrates a couple of things. The obvious point is the diversity of the group in  the markets we serve but also the value of those long-term growth drivers, so increasing health and safety  regulation, increasing demand for health care and life critical resources you see playing out when you look at the  widespread growth we've got across all of these end markets. So certainly I'm very pleased with both the diversity  we've got and the growth we're seeing across the group.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: So here we can see the sector revenue now by region. So we've got the reported figures as you look on the left,  organic constant currency on the right. So you can see U.S.A. perform very strongly, strong organic constant  currency growth, continue to see improving demand particularly in the onshore energy market in the U.S. which is  a big part of this sector. But also excellent performances in Asia Pacific and Other regions which include the  Middle East. Solid growth in Mainland Europe. More modest growth in the UK; that's a big market for our Gas  Sensor business which I mentioned earlier had a slightly lower rate of growth than elsewhere in the sector. But  overall, good performance in Process Safety. The sector's going to continue to invest in new products, in new  markets, in building out its organization because we still want to make it more resilient to sustain growth almost  whatever happens in the oil and gas market. But we expect this sector to make progress in the year ahead with  the momentum that it has.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And finally, the outstanding performer of the year, Environmental & Analysis. And again, as I said at the  beginning, even excluding the benefit of the reorganization of Pixelteq last year, both the cost and the disruption  caused by that, you can see very strong underlying growth here. Revenue up 18% to £259 million. That's 15%  organic constant currency revenue growth. A 3% contribution from acquisition. And then we've got profit up 32%  to £55 million. That's 28% organic constant currency growth with a 6% acquisition contribution. There was some  currency impact here, very little on revenue, but a 2% adverse impact on the profit figures from currency  movements.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: The Photonics businesses, the Water businesses, the Environmental Monitoring businesses all contributing  strongly to this growth as well as the Mini-Cam acquisition. This is the wastewater pipeline inspection business  that we acquired at the start of the second half of the year; again, that's doing well.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: And then finally looking at the revenue by destination, as at the half year, we saw good and strong organic growth  in all the regions except the relatively small Other region, which is around 6% of the sector. U.S.A saw strong  organic growth. Good contributions here from our Photonics businesses. And our Water businesses helped the  UK deliver a very strong performance, up 22% organically. Solid progress in Mainland Europe, which is actually a  significant improvement because it had some organic revenue decline in the first half of the year. And then finally,  Asia Pacific continues to thrive. We really see good sustainability for growth here as we see stronger  environmental regulatory drives and, in fact, social pressures pushing through in developing markets for better  environmental control whether it's air pollution monitoring, clean water, food, safety, all of those things are  benefiting this sector.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: I'll just give you some simple examples of how it works. So, here, we have a U.S. company. One of our medical  businesses that wants to improve its project management. So, it puts out a question, anyone know how to – any  great tools for improving project management. And then we have a series of conversations going on very quickly  and ultimately ends up with one of our UK businesses, in the Environmental & Analysis sector, saying, well, we're  using a new tool called LiquidPlanner that we're having a lot of success with improving our project management,  which is a very simple example where someone in the U.S., in a totally different sector, needs some help with a  particular part of their business and it can very quickly get answered by someone else over in the UK.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. Williams
texts.text: Another capability is that you can search it. So, as we build up the knowledge on this Halma Hub, in this case,  someone's put in, can we find out about collaboration agreements. And, in fact, it was a – we had a U.S. safety  business that had sensors and also had a lot of application knowledge and they wanted to work with an external  partner, but they wanted to have a very simple agreement to protect their IP during this partnership. Put the  question out there, one of our divisional chief executives, actually from the Environment & Analysis sector, came  back with, well, I know one of my companies got a lot of experience in this Ocean Optics, why don't you speak to  Ocean Optics. The guys from Ocean Optics saw that and then we're able to immediately post the template that  they've been using that elsewhere could be used by the safety business elsewhere in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Please turn to the slide First Quarter 2011. Spanning from December to February, the first quarter  was demanding in many ways. The weather was unfavorable in several markets, primarily in  December.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: We have strong collections for the upcoming season. In mid April we are launching Conscious, a  spring and summer collection made of environmentally smarter materials, such as organic cotton,  organic linen, recycled polyester and Tencel.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Sustainability is becoming an increasingly important part of H&M’s offering. With Conscious  Collection we are following up on the Garden Collection which was a great success last year in  March. Only this time the collection will be available for the whole family.       corrected transcript

file: HM.B - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 29March2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Before we start the Q&A session, a few comments on the future. We have great collections in our stores for spring  and summer. One example is our new Conscious collection, where our designers combine environmentally  smarter materials with high fashion content. Conscious collection will be launched on the 12th of April. We  continue strengthening our position and we take market share. The customer service that we conduct in all our  markets, show that never before do we have such a strong position as we do today.

file: HM.B - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 21March2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: And, not least, today we have published our new sustainability report. Our sustainability work is very important  for us, and we recommend you to read the report which is available on our website, hm.com.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: And now, in March, the unusually cold weather with snow storms has delayed the start of the spring season in  many of our markets. Furthermore, sales in March, which will be published on 15th of April 2013, should be seen  in the light of very strong sales increase of 26% in March 2012.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Concept development like this enables us to further strengthen our customer offering as well as the H&M brand. A  strong customer offering also includes that H&M should be the more sustainable choice for our increasingly aware  customers. Sustainability is therefore high on our daily agenda and has been an integral part of our business for  some time.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Please turn to the next slide. We invest substantial resources and work actively in order to promote social  development and reduce environmental impact in the communities in which H&M is active, as well as to ensure a  sustainable development for H&M long term.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: We also encourage our customers to make more sustainable choices. And today, we're launching our yearly spring  collection under the label Conscious collection. This collection, for women and men, includes garments with  materials such as organic cotton, recycled polyester and Tencel. The collection will be accompanied by a red carpet  collection for women, the Conscious Exclusive collection, that will be launched on the 4th of April.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: H&M is already the world's largest user of organic cotton since a couple of years. Our goal is that by the year of  2020, all cotton in H&M's garments should come from more sustainable sources. Sustainable sources include,  above all, cotton grown under the Better Cotton Initiative, BCI, an initiative which works to improve social,  economic as well as environmental aspects of traditional cotton cultivating. But more sustainable sources also  include organic as well as recycled cotton.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: H&M is the first fashion brand in the world to offer customers the opportunity to hand in old clothes for recycling.  We offer this garment-collecting initiative in selected stores in all our markets worldwide. Further ahead,  garment-collecting will be expanded to more H&M stores.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: To learn more about our extensive sustainability work, please visit hm.com, where you can read and download the  H&M Sustainability Report.

file: HM.B - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 20June2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jun-12.pdf
HM.B - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 19June2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jun-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: It's been a challenging period for fashion retail in many markets. H&M sales grew strongly in Asia, for example, in  China, Hong Kong and Japan. This was mainly due to the tough  macroeconomic climate that continued to affect market conditions in many countries, as well as unfavorable  weather in March and large parts of April in several of our large markets.

HM.B - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 25June2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jun-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: This winter, two subsidiary collections would also be added, a premium beauty line for body care and a conscious  range of Ecocert-approved sustainable products. H&M Beauty is one example of all the investments we're making  in order to broaden H&M's product range even further.

file: HM.B - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 22June2016 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jun-16.pdf
