texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: So if we should sum up before we take your questions, we delivered strong sales and strong results  in the third quarter. Sales have been very satisfactory thus far in September. Looking ahead, our  designers have created new, attractive collections for the upcoming season, with a growing focus  on more sustainable materials.

file: HM.B - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 29September2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Sep-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Like we state in the report, the weather was unfavorable this summer, with wet and cold weather in many  important European markets, followed by a heat wave across large parts of Europe in the second half of August.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Stock-in-trade was well composed with the large portion of new arrivals. However, the weather has been  unseasonably warm in many European markets in September which has affected sales negatively. From the 1st to  the 27th September, sales increased 3% in local currencies compared to the same period last year.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Looking at the rest of the year, we have strong collections for the autumn and winter season. We're using more  sustainable materials and after yearly increases, H&M is today the world's largest user of organic cotton, which  we're of course very proud of. This is one example of how we act long term to constantly improve our customer  offering.

file: HM.B - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 27September2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Sep-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Sales were strong throughout most of the third quarter in June and July. August, however, did not live up to our  expectations. This was mainly due to the heat wave that swept across many of our markets in August, primarily in  Europe. We saw that weather-dependent items such as heavy-knit garments did not sell according to plan. As  weather has normalized, sales have improved nicely. Looking at current trading after the end of the third quarter,  from the 1st to the 25th of September, sales increased by 14% in local currencies compared to the same period last  year and calendar adjusted. Net sales in the third quarter grew by 7% to SEK 28.8 billion. The strengthening of the  Swedish krona, mainly against the euro, our biggest sales currency, had a large negative impact on sales and  results in SEK.

file: HM.B - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 26September2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Sep-13.pdf
HM.B - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 25September2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Sep-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: This year, sales in the second half of August were helped by cooler weather, while sales in September so far have  been affected by unusually warm weather in most of our markets. The weather effect in September is clearly  reflected in available external market data like, for example, from Germany. But we have an exciting autumn  ahead of us.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Please turn to the next slide. Already next week, H&M is launching a collection that we're very proud of, H&M  Conscious Denim. It is a denim collection that is made of more sustainable materials such as organic cotton,  recycled cotton and TENCEL. Two of the pieces also include recycled fibers from clothes that we have collected  under H&M's global garment collecting initiative. So far, customers have handed in more than 8,000 tons of used  garments for reuse or recycling. Garment collection is part of our work to close the loop for materials. It is one of  the many initiatives that we invest in for a more sustainable future.

file: HM.B - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 24September2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Sep-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Translating to SEK, sales including VAT amounted to SEK 53.4 billion, an increase of 18% compared to last year.  Sales were strong in June and July, but in August, sales were negatively affected by the unseasonably warm  weather in many of our large European markets.

HM.B - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 28January2010 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The autumn was unseasonably mild, which had a negative effect on sales of weather dependent  sales such as jackets and heavy knitwear.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: As sales were weak during the fourth quarter, the stock-in-trade for the 30th of November contains  a larger proportion of mainly weather dependent garments compared to the same time a year  before. This will lead to larger markdowns during the first quarter 2009, 2010, compared to the first  quarter of last year. In relation to sales, the stock-in-trade was 10.1%. Historically, it’s still a good  level.

file: HM.B - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 27January2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jan-11.pdf
HM.B - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 26January2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jan-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.profession: Head, Investor Relations, Hennes & Mauritz AB
texts.text: Now please return to the slide, fourth quarter 2011. The unusually warm autumn led to increased markdowns on  weather-related garments. Therefore, markdowns in relation to sales increased compared to Q4 2010. The effect  on the gross margin was 60 basis points negative year on year.

file: HM.B - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 30January2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: Still, H&M increased sales including VAT by 9% in local currencies in the fourth quarter. In comparable units,  sales were unchanged. We view the performance as satisfactory given the tough macroeconomic climate, and the  effect it's had on consumption in many countries.

texts.speaker: Nils Vinge
texts.text: And looking at current trading, sales in local currencies increased by 8% in December and sales in January are  expected to increase by 5% in local currencies compared to the same month last year. From mid-January onwards,  sales were negatively affected by very cold weather in many of H&Ms markets in Europe.

texts.speaker: Karl-Johan Persson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Hennes & Mauritz AB
texts.text: We must always have the best customer offering for all brands, and the most important part is our assortment, our  products. And so the best offering and to improve and to have more relevant assortment when it comes to the mix  of the products, the design of the products, value for money, and also to sustainability. We also need to improve  our physical stores. They need to be more inspiring and more convenient customer experience, and be more  customized to local needs. We have tested a number of new things in various locations globally with successful  results in the form of positive customer feedback and sales. And based on these learnings, we're setting a plan to  be able to scale this up.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & CEO, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: Yes, good afternoon ladies and gentleman. Again, also from my side, a welcome to our 1st January 2013 Non-Life  Treaty Renewal Call, and I'm joined by my colleague, Jürgen Gräber, who is our Chief Operating Officer for our  Non-Life business who will give you most of the explanation.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Gräber
texts.profession: Member-Executive Board & COO-Non-Life Reinsurance, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: If we then go on to the next page where we measure the temperature of the improvements versus the  deteriorations, I explained this a bit longer because we will see this kind of graph later on again and again. You  will see on the left hand side of the page that on the proportional side, most of the contracts were not really seeing  any improvement or deterioration. The terms stood unchanged and that is what the dark blue color indicates. And  there were some deteriorations and some improvements.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Gräber
texts.profession: Member-Executive Board & COO-Non-Life Reinsurance, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: If we now look at our non-proportional business, we measure here the water temperature so to say by the so called  rate on line, i.e. premium divided through the liability of various non-proportional treaties. And we saw quite a  significant amount of increases over and above the decreases in the rate on lines. And what I said before, it is  worth noting that we have two years in a row, i.e. the renewal in 2012 and now the renewal in 2013 where we saw  these increases, this is quite different to what we actually saw after KRW in 2005, and subsequently with the  renewals in 2006. So, we are quite pleased in what we are seeing on the U.S. non-proportional business.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Gräber
texts.profession: Member-Executive Board & COO-Non-Life Reinsurance, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: If we move on to our global catastrophe business, well, we all had expected that rates could drop because up and  until hurricane or super storm Sandy occurred, there was a limited amount of loss activity, but Sandy avoided  further drops in the catastrophe business and you will notice that we are actually up 11%, which is a combination  of various reasons, first, our shares are up by plus 5%, price and volume up 1% on what is regarded as a technically

file: HNR1 - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 4May2010 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The first quarter of 2010 was shaped above all by catastrophe losses, which had a significant  negative impact on our results. These were largely offset by a very good result of our life and health  reinsurance business, good investment income and reserve releases, which became necessary  from our non-life business. Special mentioning should be made here to the devastating earthquake  in Chile as well as the European winter storm “Xynthia.”

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: I would briefly like to touch on the recent loss from an oil rig that had – that sunk in the Gulf of  Mexico in April. We have publicized our number for that loss with an expected net loss of €40  million. This is a broad estimate. There’s a lot of uncertainties at this point in time. It basically takes  into account our estimated involvement in the insured values of the rig itself, ancillary coverages on  the main package that the rig – where the rig was covered under and to the extent known to us, a  liability element, which of course, also stemmed from the still developing tragic pollution in the Gulf  of Mexico.

file: HNR1 - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 3May2011 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: This is clearly a development more positive than we have expected. The burden of large losses  continues to be very high. While the first quarter numbers last year showed a strain of €264 million,  this figure climbed to €572 million in the first quarter 2011. It is, therefore, well above our expected  losses for the first quarter of €120 million. The addition to this budget actually amounts to €452  million, the most notable losses for the earthquakes in Japan and New Zealand.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: On the basis of the very high capital charges for listed equity return expectations have to be  remarkably higher to achieve the same ROEs compared to other asset classes. And also the major  loss in Japan with a nuclear cloud potentially hitting one of the financial centers of this world, return  expectations decreased as well as volatility expectations increased. And we had also to take into  account that losses from the large losses could accumulate with write offs in the equities portfolio.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Probably catastrophe, a few excessive losses of course were a factor, and they showed much  higher increases. Of course on the quake side, but also increases on the wind side of 5% to 25%.  The fast other Asian markets are concerning, this particularly also to Korea. And of course they  have not been affected by major losses, but nonetheless we have seen to some extent relatively  significant increases.

file: HNR1 - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 3May2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: Moreover, we have also seen a damage on an oil platform on the coast of Nigeria. And the second thing you might  ask yourself, if the net loss for a listed storm in the U.S. (it's not a typo) this is a claim coming from an ILS fund  based on a collateralized fronting arrangement. And as the loss is incurred on the cross side, it made it to the list,  but it retroceded to 100%. So we have not net retention. And as we have the collateral, we also have no default  risk. This is why we have this zero net loss here on our large losses.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: It is fair to say that the Japanese ceding company has made an effort in their endeavor to pay back the losses  incurred by their loyal reinsurers, not least because of the effect of the unexpected size of the Thai flood loss which  has affected the reinsurance result of the entire Southeast Asian region. We saw meaningful rate increases also in  South Korea and India. Regarding the US renewals, they were very much in line with what we have seen at  January 1.

file: HNR1 - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 7May2013 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & CEO, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: The main drivers of the positive outcome have been our agricultural business and our Japanese business. The  agricultural business from the U.S., of course, last year saw significant losses from the drought in the Midwest.  And as a result, the reinsurance market reacted this improved terms and conditions. We were able to benefit from  these improvements and therefore had very good growth on our U.S. agricultural business.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & CEO, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: Quarter Japanese business grew by a meaningful percentage based on continued attractive rates, following the  losses in 2011, mainly the earthquake loss, there's a Tohoku earthquake and the Thai flood loss has also affected  the Japanese treaty. We saw significant rate increases off the Japanese business in 2011 and 2012. Despite the  increasing competition, these rather high rating levels, which were achieved in those two years for the most part  could be defended so the business remained attractive.

file: HNR1 - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 7May2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.text: On the other hand, we were able to maintain, or even slightly increase our market position and market share, as  we in fact we're able to write some new attractive business. The renewal of the agro business saw increased  competition on that line of business. It has actually been a little bit of a disappointment when i t comes to the  MPCI business in the U.S., because you may recall that we had two big losses in 2011, due to the drought, and then  2012 everything looked great, except that the, since the commodity prices and the prices for the agricultural goods  have actually decreased and this had a negative effect on the results, not so much on the non-proportional, which  we largely write, but we took a rather conservative approach on the U.S. MPCI as a result. However, we saw good  growth in China and India, for example, where the margins are actually quite attractive. Overall, our volume  remained quite stable.

file: HNR1 - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 6May2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.text: If we look at the capital side, we have just recently announced the early redemption of a €500 million perpetual  bond on the 1 June 2015. Just as a reminder, we had already refinanced this bond in September last year. So,  therefore, the green part of this column on the slide should be reduced in Q2 to a level that will likely be  sustainable, and with that also the interest claimants will of course be reduced in the future.

file: HNR1 - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 10May2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: CEO, Chairman of the Executive Board
texts.text: The book value per share at the end of the first quarter stood at €69.42, and it's, as I said, increased compared to  year-end of last year. Following four consecutive years of low major natural catastrophe losses and very good  results, the property/casualty reinsurance business continues to be fiercely competitive. As a result, we continue  to write our business highly selective in accordance with our profit-orientated underwriting policy, which is also  reflected in slightly reduced premium volume.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board - Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Our facultative business was particularly impacted by a few single large losses and that already leads us  immediately to the large loss slide here on the next page. We can go through that next slide rather quickly  because, as already mentioned, major losses were well below average on budget. Overall, the bulk of the €134  million in unused budget is to be carried forward for the remainder of the year. Still, we should bear in mind that  the year has only just begun and we have already had two earthquakes; one in Japan and one in Ecuador in the  second quarter. And those may show up on the large loss lists for the first half year then. And we will have to wait  and see what the impact from the fires in Alberta will be. Still, these losses should be comfortably covered by the  unused part of our Q1 large loss budget in addition to the budget for the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: CEO, Chairman of the Executive Board
texts.text: Also, our natural catastrophe business, we wrote some new business, which is a diversifying business. And that  actually resulted in – also an increase in our cat business, but only very small increase.

file: HNR1 - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 10May2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: North America impacted by a series of tornadoes and a rather large property loss. Worldwide treaty business also  affected by large losses, namely, the wildfires in China and Cyclone Debbie. This slide also demonstrates what I  already mentioned earlier. The structured reinsurance block has a high MtCR so that the growth of the business  lines of that business impacts the combined ratio without affecting the economic profitability.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: Aviation pricing pressure remains intense even though there is some hesitation of further decreases on the direct  airline business. But on the non-proportionate business, which effectively last year pretty good results due to lack  of losses, further rate decreases are the norm. On the marine business, overall, we're quite happy with our marine  portfolio even though that it continues to reduce some size a little bit due to our very disciplined underwriting  policy there.

file: HNR1 - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 7May2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: Major losses were significantly lower than in the previous year despite the fact that the net loss from natural  catastrophes and man-made events in the first quarter 2017 had already been below the expected level,  therefore, the annual budget amounts to approximately €94 million. As usual, the list of major losses in the first  quarter is comparatively low. Next, to Friederike, only one property and one credit claim made it on large loss list  in Q1.

file: HNR1 - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 7May2019 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: Loss affected wind and flood programs in Japan which were the majority of those programs that the loss affected  as well as the combined wind and flood and earthquake cover, loss affected increased anywhere between 10%  and 30%. Some higher increases were even seen with some of the aggregate excess of loss cover, most of which  had a total loss last year.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: Due to selective underwriting, we saw some meaningful decreases of our premium volume and market share in  the agricultural business, where we also saw some increased exposure to a certain [indiscernible] (00:23:32)  phenomena. On the marine side, the most significant renewal in the first quarter was the marine liability renewal,  which is rather large program, also known as protection and indemnity business. On this program, we increased  our volume quite significantly based on our proprietary terms. However, if we look at the marine business  including the January 1 renewal, we [indiscernible] (00:24:08) premiums largely unchanged.

file: HNR1 - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 10August2010 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Aug-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: While the underlying loss experience continued to be favorable partly also as a result of the low  inflation rates that we can observe, the impact of large losses has already been heavy in the first  quarter and the increase above the expectation has continued into the second quarter of 2010.  Here, the largest single event has been the loss of the drilling rig Deepwater Horizon, hence the  resultant devastating oil pollution in the Gulf of Mexico. As it’s well known, this loss occurred in April  this year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Page five shows the individual losses. Chile is still the year’s major event but Deepwater Horizon of  the floods in Eastern Europe were additional large losses in Q2. Ulrich had already explained what  drove the increase for Deepwater Horizon in comparison to our pervious publications. Here we felt  that the uncertainty around the liability questioned cause for additional IBNRs to cover also the  more remote potential liability claims, which we will see whether they will materialize in the long run.  We view that as a conservative view to the potential U.S. liabilities, which may come up in the long  run.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: As far as the pricing is concerned, this year basically a stable development which is a result of our  rather selective underwriting policy which we have to exercise in the current market climate  whereby trying to particularly emphasize those parts of the business which offer us good  profitability.

file: HNR1 - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 8August2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: So our retrocession protected us obviously from 48% of the large losses within the first half year end and that  might trigger the question of what capacity is left. The remaining capacity of our whole account cover and the K6  program as well as the K6 aggregate XL then our large loss aggregate XLs all together amount to approximately  €320 million. Please bear in mind, in addition we have several other covers, covers for specific risk in place and  also those remain unimpaired up to now, as well as the new additional cover of some $100 million for U.S. natural  perils, which we bought in June. So all in all, we see us quite well protected for the events to come and which  might come here. And I might also remind you of the €295 million, which I already mentioned before, which  would be the budget for the second half year and would also have to incur up until we see our guidance in  jeopardy.

file: HNR1 - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 10August2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & CEO, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: On the large loss list, you see that the second quarter was a little bit below the budget of €90 million. The  earthquakes in Italy are the major part of it, and caused some significant damages in some regions. We have  reserved these losses rather conservatively, so the risk of a negative runoff should be very remote in these cases.  The fire claim mentioned to you stems from a chemical factory in Japan. And overall, our retrocessions covered  around 36% of the gross loss.

file: HNR1 - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 7August2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & CEO, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: The largest losses were the floods in Germany and some other European countries occurring in May and  continuing into June, where we have a net loss of €137  million. This was, as I said, the largest loss. There were  some other losses, mainly some hail storms in Germany in June, we had further ones in July and we had some  flooding in Canada, and there was further flooding in Canada in July as well.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: Finally, E+S, our Germany subsidiary, showed a relatively strong result leading to an increase in minority interest.  This may be a bit surprising, but the majority of the flood losses in Germany were written on a broader basis as cat  business from Bermuda.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: On the large loss list, you can see 13 major losses in excess of €10 million, 12 of which were incurred in the second  quarter, adding up to a burden of €246 million, which is far more than twice our Q2 standalone budget of €91  million. However, we were in a position to absorb most of it by using the remaining part of the unused Q1 budget.  We have to bear in mind that especially here the loss estimates for the June losses, namely the hail in Germany as  well as the Canada floods are still rough estimates and may move into one or the other  direction in the future, but  we do not expect major movements.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & CEO, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: On the rating outlook for Germany, I would expect that that will have to wait until 2014. On the natural  catastrophe business, actually some meaningful increases because Germany has been particularly hard hit by the  cat losses that we experienced so far in this year, mainly hail and floo d loss.

file: HNR1 - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 6August2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: We can go through the next slide rather quickly because major losses were well below the average and the budget.  As mentioned, part of the remaining large loss budget of €565 million is required to cover the two large losses  mentioned early – the two large losses from early in the third quarter. But this should be, again, more than  comfortably covered. This is an important and a positive message to take away with the hurricane season just  beginning.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.text: Looking at the development in more details, rate erosions, in particular in U.S. natural catastrophe business and  in the property excessive-of-loss areas in the U.S. were about 5% to 15% on loss free programs.

file: HNR1 - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 5August2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.text: And this has meant that the growth of our capital has been reduced and slowed a little bit. This, as far as the  special dividend is concerned, of course, was the intention of it. So, book value per share is now €63.62, and that  is for the end of June. The overall business developed especially gratifying because the general environment  international reinsurers are facing continues to be challenging.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board - Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Aviation impacted by three large losses that incurred in the first six months. In Marine too, we experienced a  number of large manmade losses. Here you have to bear in mind that those claims, to a larger extent, also  impacted the Facultative business line.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board - Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: After six months, 12 major losses are showing up on the large loss list. The impact from natural catastrophes  rather benign, and more than half of the net losses are result of manmade losses. Here, the biggest part is coming  from the Marine, with three out of these four claims being damages from oil platforms that is dominated by the  Pemex loss of €33 million net in our account.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.text: Despite significant capacities in the natural catastrophe market, both actually for treaties on a proportional as well  as on a non-proportional basis, due to our extensive product range, we are able to offer our clients, we saw new  opportunities in Latin America and the Caribbean. And we were able also to further diversify our agricultural book  of business with actually quite significantly new additions to our business.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.text: While this is in particular some Indian business, but also some business from the US. North American rates and  conditions remain under pressure. So, rate reductions were somewhat smaller than anticipated by some. Further  demand driven by improved state of the economy was a key factor here. Despite below average natural  catastrophe expenditure and relatively modest fire losses, the renewal for US property business passed off  favorably.

file: HNR1 - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 4August2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: CEO, Chairman of the Executive Board
texts.text: In addition, the tax rate for the quarter and indeed the half year has been a little higher than normally because the  majority of the losses from the Canadian wildfire impacted the results of our P&C subsidiary in Bermuda.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: CEO, Chairman of the Executive Board
texts.text: The underlying earnings of the business have developed quite favorable, however, we continue to see some  negative claims experience from yearly renewable [ph] term (3:53) business from some older underwriting years  of our U.S. mortality business. We deal with this problem by increasing rates, they're necessary and appropriate.  The results from our investments under management are fully in line with expectations with an ROI of 2.9%.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board - Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: After six months, 11 major losses are showing up on the large loss list. They include significant events also on the  net cap, as well as on the man-made side. With a net loss of €132 million, the wildfires in Canada were, by far,  the largest loss in the first half year. And at our Q1 results, we had already [ph] flagged (14:23) the fact that  Hannover Re has a particularly high market share in Ecuador. And accordingly, the net loss from the earthquake  there is €57 million for our own account. When you add the overall numbers, it's good to see that our  repossession protection is working well, resulting in a release of around €140 million.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board - Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Our business for North America, in particular contributes favorably [indiscernible] (15:28) very positively to our  results. The Cat XL combined ratio is now over and above the MtCR having been especially hit hard by the  wildfires in Canada. The earthquake loss in Ecuador on the other hand is mainly accounted under worldwide  treaty business hence [indiscernible] (15:50) rather high combined ratio in this segment. Credit and surety was  mainly affected by one large claim. And it's still good to see that with all this effects, the P&C portfolio as a whole  remains to perform below the maximum tolerable combined ratio overall.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: When it comes to the profitability, we continue to expect the margin requirements to be fulfilled. And we continue  results of profitability, in excess of the cost of capital. So, we expect to earn above the cost of capital, and the same is true for the marine business, as well as  our facultative business. With aviation, UK and Ireland due to the Ogden rate table changes and natural  catastrophe business, below the cost of capital, however, this would only come true, other than UK and Ireland, if  we actually hit the expected losses. I suppose aviation and the catastrophe excess of loss business are, of  course, non-proportional business. It needs exceptional losses in order to achieve the expected loss levels. So,  overall, at this point, it's a soft market, still quite a good picture on our P&C business.

file: HNR1 - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 9November2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: These increases do underline the current favorable market environment for reinsurers and are, of course, to a  large extent, the result of heavy losses in the first quarter in particular from Australia, New Zealand and Japan,  but also the weather-related losses in the U.S. in the second and third quarter have put upward pressure on rate.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Hannover Rückversicherung AG
texts.text: In this respect, I feel it would be prudent to mention the still developing flooding situation in Thailand, which will  most likely result in insured market losses, which could be significant. The situation is still developing and for the  most part, the damages of insured property have not yet been assessed. Therefore, any well-founded numbers are  not yet available. On the other hand, there can be little doubt that the insured losses would go into the billions of  U.S. dollars with the majority of those losses being reinsured. But we at Hannover Re have a rather small market  share in Thailand that our premium volume is well below €4 million and we consider that that would probably  make up a market share of about 2%.  Nevertheless, even these small numbers are able to create relatively sizable losses. And based on a bottom-up  analysis and very many assumptions, we feel that our loss could reach or even slightly exceed the mark of €100  million. This in itself does not jeopardize our guidance for the net income of more than €500 million. But as I  explained, the situation is still far from being clear.

file: HNR1 - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 10November2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-16.pdf
HNR1 - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 8November2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: After years of moderate losses, we saw an accumulation of severe natural catastrophes in the third quarter,  particularly in the U.S., Mexico and the Caribbean. Protecting against the consequences of such events is the  central goal of reinsurance. For us as a reinsurer, our top priority is the efficiently resettling of the incurred claims  and the support of our clients. This way, reinsurance can also play a part in alleviating the humanitarian and  economic impacts of natural disasters such as the ones of the third quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: The natural catastrophe losses in the third quarter resulted in a large loss burden for Hannover Re of €766 million.  This number – Hurricanes Harvey, Irma and Maria together with two Mexican quakes amount to €222 million of  net losses.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: Whilst these figures are subject to significant uncertainty and recognizing that the reported losses from the  industry fell short of the industry losses estimated by the various cat modeling firms, this nevertheless would  suggest that Hannover Re's market share in the losses is well below its market share in the reinsurance business  overall, which is around 5%. This confirms our strategy we followed in recent years to have lower market share in  the natural catastrophe expose business as compared to the overall reinsurance business.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: The sale was not only motivated to absorb part of the negative effects of the natural catastrophe losses, but also  to free up capital which can be utilized in taking increased underwriting risks based on the expected improvement  in the conditions of the property/casualty reinsurance markets.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: Apart from such considerations, run-off profits have not been extraordinary and we expect the level of  redundancies to be at the Q2 level. The ordinary investment income was slightly ahead of expectations, mainly  driven by a strong contribution from private equity and real estate; and on top of that, of course, the disposal of  the listed equities boosted the good investment result even further in this segment. The achieved EBIT margin of  8.9% is a little bit below our target, but given the frequency of the natural catastrophe losses, the number is a  good one, especially if compared with the industry.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: If you count the three major hurricanes together, we are estimating our loss currently at €650 million. If you add  the two earthquakes to the numbers, this would be in the region of €720 million. Including the ILS contracts, we  overall had a 45% relief from our retrocession.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: The next slide looks completely different if we compare that with the Q2 conference call, as the natural  catastrophe losses have impacted various markets. Overall, the total combined ratio came in clearly above the  MtCR.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: The remainder of the targets in particular regarding the profits, the impact is naturally by the high loss burn of  natural catastrophes in the third quarter. In order to avoid any confusion, let me emphasize that this target matrix  is still the one from the strategy cycle 2015 to 2017 and therefore, it's a slightly different from the new one which  we presented on our Investor Day in October.

Although, of course, it should be noted that it also includes our activity in the ILS market where we are one of the  larger players in the collateralized fronting business, and that also leads to a higher difference in gross and net.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: [audio gap] (00:03:53) and welcome. Yeah. Thank you for coming to our investor's presentation for the 2017  result. You can see that we have chosen a smaller room compared to last year. But on that note, I would rather want the expense ratio be higher rather  than lower. But that's not an option. I mean, why is the result down? Of course, because of the exceptional  hurricanes which dominated the 2017 results. Particular, of course, well-publicized, the so called HIM losses,  Harvey, Irma and Maria. And then we also had some wildfires in California which were quite expensive,  earthquakes in Mexico and also in Australia. We had Cyclone Debbie, which also did not come entirely for free.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: Let's start with the operating cash flow, an important number. You see it, nearly €1.7 billion which is, from our  point of view, a good cash flow number still. It is lower than it was in the previous years. What is the reason for the  decrease? We've seen payouts for the hurricane losses in Q4 already. That amounts to approximately €400  million. So, here, we also see the impact of the hurricanes. Apart from that, one should also bear in mind that with  the impressive P&C growth, which we will be discussing in a minute, one should assume or potentially has  expected a higher positive cash flow number. But as this growth is driven by the Advanced Solutions business  which is not really cash-rich, these are usually quota shares. They are accounted on the quarterly, half, yearly –  or even yearly basis, and you would only get a balance from these quarter shares.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: I think we have asked our actuaries to come up with a new kind of long-term sustainable number. Some of you  might remember that we once mentioned €200 million a year, €50 million per quarter. That is a number with the  large increases which we have seen here over the last years in the redundancy numbers. Also, of course, the  regular runoff numbers have increased. The latest numbers which we heard and we will confirm and might have a  little bit more details in October with that regard is around €400 million. That is what we expect these days as a  regular runoff number.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: The single events here on the next page, not that much which is to be said here. We've all seen the numbers,  we've all seen the developments. I think it is worth mentioning that the Californian wildfires, the two of the fourth  quarter amount to €100 million overall. So we had a budget of €200 million for the fourth quarter, so that was  below. But still, with the €100 million, also the wildfires had been a large loss in the year 2017. And without them,  the impact of the hurricanes would have been lower.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: So a brief look at the MtCR and the business lines, how they performed on the P&C side, I think this is also not  really a surprise what we can see here, the hurricanes and the fires hit North America. This is why here, the  combined ratios is remarkably over the hurdle. We also see aviation a negative combined ratio, I think not too  many instance where I saw a negative combined ratio. This is explained by the positive run-off results, which we  have already mentioned. UK and London market, that is impacted by the Ogden rate. You might ask, well, if you  had decreased your IBNRs, why is it that this exceeds the MtCR so much. I think the release of the large loss of  the redundant reserves came from other segments as well, not only from UK and the London market. This is why  Ogden can be seen here so pronounced.

texts.speaker: Roland Vogel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: And of course, so the cat lines are impacted by the hurricanes. The structured reinsurance as you see, large,  higher combined ratios as expected but still very profitable, so the 97.7% reflects our profit expectations fully.  These are risk-limited exposures, where the margin, which we make here, make it really sufficient.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Board, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: Absolutely, Roland. And I will of course do that. Thank you. So, I mean you can see even in a year like 2017, we  have more ticks than [ph] not (00:48:54), which if you want to put it positively, shows the resilience of our  business model situations like we had seen in 2017. That's actually good that we show this resilience, because  it's not really a tail event what happened in 2017, but something we have to expect, I would say, every five to  seven years from a natural catastrophe point of view. And therefore, you better apply risk management that  prepares us to those kind of years.

texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: So, we will come to the large losses on the usual pages and slides in a minute. Let me comment on the runoff  result and the initial reserving and the confidence level. You, or most of you have seen, that the table in our  annual report shows a runoff result of nearly €1 billion, a little bit down from last year. The initial reserves, as we  usually set them up, we stuck to our usual policy. We will also see in a second that two lines of business were  affected by positive runoff, that it was marine and credit and surety. Marine, it is really quite obviously on one of  the slides because the combined ratio there was only a 9% combined ratio.

texts.speaker: Roland Helmut Vogel
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: So usually we come with one page of large losses. That was not sufficient this year. We have brought with us two  pages, one for the natural catastrophes and one for the man-made losses. Here you see the natural catastrophes,  it started in Europe with Friederike, but of course over the course of the year it ended with a very, very busy Q4,  which started with Michael, had the Camp wildfire as the nearly largest loss. It turned out that Jebi also developed  a little bit over the course of the fourth quarter into the real largest loss. You see that €135 million on a net basis,  followed by Camp, the wildfire in the U.S., by €130 million, followed by the others. So a lot of frequency, again,  the retro structure which we have in place, the K quota share, the whole account protection, plus the aggregate  large loss cover, was very sufficient and that should also be the reason as to why future development is  potentially really limited.

texts.speaker: Roland Helmut Vogel
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: Here you see on the next page then the man-made losses, with accumulation of credit claims. It was interesting, I  think we never had four credit claims which made it on the large loss list, still it is interesting to see that credit was  seeing a positive runoff, it saw the credit claims, but even without the positive runoff, it would have been still be  possible so it was – it is still a very attractive returns in that line of business. But you also see that as we are  protected for natural catastrophes, here are the numbers between gross and net of Hannover to each other.

texts.speaker: Roland Helmut Vogel
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: That brings us to the various lines of business and of course one could see the impact of the large losses here,  North America was affected. Also the facultative business, the worldwide treaty, what is, from our point of view,  remarkable is that our Bermudian Cat business was still within the target combined ratios with 88%, but of course  this is where the natural catastrophe has landed. And this is where also the good protection of the retro program  had its impact.

texts.speaker: Roland Helmut Vogel
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, Hannover Rück SE
texts.text: I had already mentioned the very, very positive result in marine here. We didn't have a lot of losses, so it would  have been good anyway and we had the positive runoff. It looks very impressive. We should be aware that marine  these days for us accounts for a good €200 million in premium. So we shouldn't overestimate the impact from  such a combined ratio, also aviation, which had benefited from the reserve releases from the WTC disaster last  year. Premium in that line of business also, a little bit more than €200 million only that is different for credit and  surety. Here we are talking about €750 million, also as I mentioned, a very positive result. And even without the  positive runoff and including the large losses, we would have seen a good result here as well.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Luc Vigneron, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer  Hello. Thank you for joining us today. I will talk about Thales results for ‘09 and our outlook for the  year-end. 2009 was a difficult year for Thales. The global economic environment and the crisis in  the air transit sector had the negative impact on the volume of orders for some of our civil  businesses and therefore on their profitability.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Revenues were down by 7%, that’s €2.6 billion, in the civil and military businesses alike. Over and  above that – over and above the unfavorable climate in civil aviation, a number of negative factors  combined to push down the EBIT, which came out negative at minus €389 million, which is, roughly  speaking, a €500 million gap compared with last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: In security systems, Thales won, for instance, a security contract in Mexico City. But together with  these big orders, which went on fairly well in terms of order intake, there was a sharp downturn in  order intake in areas directly affected by the global economic climate. I’m referring here to industry  and services, critical information systems, special components, which registered a decrease of up  to 25%, or even a decrease of more than 50% in simulation.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Luc Vigneron, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer  Thank you, Patrice. So let’s move on to page 23, and make a comment about our environment. So,  we are facing some serious challenges today both because of external factors and because of  internal factors within the Group itself.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: 6 Now, about the internal environment, what we call non-quality costs is mainly cost overruns on our  contracts but also warranty costs, for example, have reached excessive levels at Thales. We were  at 8% of revenues in 2008, and we have jumped to the level of 11% in 2009. Our purchasing and  industrial processes must be optimized, as well as our general costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: To reduce our non-quality costs, we will start by improving the way we manage and deliver our  programs. We have to ensure tighter control commitments at the at the bid phase, which are the  cause of many subsequent difficulties. We have decided to run systematically independent peer  reviews, combined with the transition review prior to program launch in order to monitor closely risk  reduction plans. We will be also implementing proven practices in program management, which  speed-up the deployment of program management tools and provide more training to our program  managers.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: First; the still unfavorable global economic climate, both in air transport and also in various other  civil market segments. As we said a moment ago, this factor alone eroded our profit margin by  more than 1% in 2009. We may face the same in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: The EBIT of the air operations domain decreased also significantly, mainly due to additional  charges booked on Lorads III and to increasing our ending costs linked to the development of new  radars. I must say that we are in the middle of the way of renewing in our radar offering in  [inaudible].

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: Page 25, this graphic shows you how we are building up our Probasis €1.3 billion global gross  saving target by 2014. The implementation of our Probasis actions allow us to lock in savings that  we’ll then see through the P&L over time. This phenomenon is easy to explain. We are a company  involved in multi-year contracts. So when we make a savings, let’s say on purchasing item in a  contract, we will see this saving go down to the P&L as the project progresses year after year, even  if we have secured, we say locked in that saving, the year end. So 2010 was the operational launch  of Probasis, and we are pleased to say that we have locked in close to 25% of our saving actions       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.text: So the key word is seize growth opportunities in emerging markets. And as you can see on the  following page 32, we have room for growth as energy markets represent only 30% of our revenues  today. And we have room to grow in the civil domain as it represents 45% of our revenues.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: During the first quarter, we also had a quite big rebuild at the Braviken Paper Mill, PM 53, and also maintenance  stop at the Workington Mill, which has costed roughly SEK 130 million. An operating in a climate like Holmen  Paper where there is a constant price pressure has, during the first quarter, led to lower pricing. And also, when it  comes to the Timber business compared to year ago, it has been some price pressure, which I'll come back to.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: Looking at the first quarter, we also had a very good result from our forest division. And, of course, it's also partly  explained by that we don't do everything in the forest during the first quarter.

file: HOLM.B - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 26April2016 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: As I said, we have the divestiture of our Madrid mill. You also know about the fire we had at Hallsta. We have had  a big rebuild of the Workington Mill, where we have increased the capacity. And we also reached an extended  inspection interval for the recovery boiler at the Iggesund Mill, to 24 months. And we also have repayment of  water charges concerning the Workington Mill, which I will come back to.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Starting off with the group. We believe this is a strong performance. We have had good deliveries. We have had  quite good production. And as I said, the effects of the Workington rebuild has been balanced by the water  repayment. We also had quite high timber trading revenues. That's something that over the year should not give  substantial money, but in the first quarter, it's a bit higher than normal.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Going to our forest, the forest is free from surprises. It's a good quarter, but it's also quite normal quarter when it  comes to both demand. We also see stable prices in the market. As I said before, we have a bit higher trading  revenues, which is a seasonal effect partly, but also something we cannot count on during the whole year.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We also have lower harvesting volumes compared to one year ago and also, if we compare to the fourth quarter,  of course, we have a bit lower cost, that's the seasonal effect we normally have in the first quarter. All in all, we  believe the forest operation is, I would say, it's in a good move. We have reduced cost over the year and this is  something we also see in result and we are fairly happy about.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Even though, we haven't had a stop at Workington Mill, we have had to rebuild the press section. We believe after  rebuild, we'll be able to increase the production by some 20,000 tones. We said before, at the last meeting that  we see the cost that's roughly SEK 100 million for the stop. We have SEK 60 million in the first quarter. And as I  said before, we also have the water repayment compensating for the stop connected to the rebuild of the mill.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Looking at Iggesund Mill, we have good news when it comes to our boiler that we now will be running the whole of  2016 without big maintenance stop. The next one will be 2017 after having reached 24 month inspection into it.  And I said, when it comes to Workington Mill that rebuild costs roughly SEK 100 million, we have SEK 50 million  or SEK 60 million in the first quarter which means that we expect something like SEK 40 million in the second  quarter.

file: HOLM.B - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 3May2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Also within the wood products segment, we have strengthened our position by the acquisition of the Linghem  Sawmill. And in total, return on capital employed for our company is now 10% for the quarter. I think it's also time  to remind you a bit about coming quarter, the second quarter, which will be impacted by the maintenance  shutdown we have at Workington Mill, which will end up costing roughly SEK 50 million, which we have guided  before. We will also have seasonally lower energy production. It's very difficult to say how much it's going to  range. We can't guide about that, but the production is normally a bit lower than in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Going then into our business areas, starting with forest. It's a quarter which is free from surprises, as it should be,  with the normal demand, stable pricing, at least for our products where we sell it. We have an EBIT result of SEK  283 million, which is slightly better than in the fourth quarter. We have SEK 219 million before change in value.  We see normal harvesting volumes. We have lower cost in the first quarter, which is also seasonal effect. We also  sold off a smaller property, which is included in the result. Adding up to rolling 12-month cash flow yield of 4%.  And looking at the first quarter, the cash flow yield is actually 5%.

file: HOLM.B - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 25April2018 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And then when I go into the first quarter of 2018 based on the same logic, the cost curve should go down towards  something similar as 2016, but it has not. For two reasons, it should have been SEK 70 million to SEK 80 million  lower than where we are if we would have followed the same path and then the same logic. Of that a bit more  than half is price inflation from higher cost from wood, higher cost for chemicals, but it's also that we have had  higher consumption rates. We burned a bit more oil, a bit more gas and we have spent some more money when it  comes to maintenance for example.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: So if we summarize what we see when it comes to the paperboard performance in the first quarter fairly stable  prices, good deliveries, but we are faced with a high cost level. At the same time, as we have been working on  increasing deliveries et cetera, we're also been running a project to see if there's potential to increase production  and sales when it comes to our solid bleached board at the Iggesund Mill and we've come to the conclusion after  having run a pre-study that, yes we believe there is the potential to increase the capacity by 100,000 tonnes,  which means that we today have taken a decision in the board of Holmen to go from the phase of a pre-study into  a pre-project, with the aim to take a decision to go ahead with an investment within one year. A rough estimate of  the cost increase in that capacity by 100,000 tonne is roughly SEK 1.5 billion.

file: HOLM.B - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 8May2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: So, let's start with some highlights for the quarter. The operating profit for the Holmen Group for the first quarter  landed on SEK 643 million, which is SEK 30 million more than the fourth quarter of last year. It's thanks to better  prices for paper and also seasonally higher hydropower production. At the same time, we've had a situation  where we have had production disturbances in our paperboard division, which have negatively impacted result.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We also seeing that we have been able to carry on a good operating profit level in our wood products division.  And in our forest, we have established earnings on the higher level thanks to higher prices. And when you look at  the total profit from the forest, it accounts now for almost half of the profit of the group. The financial position for  the company is strong. If you look at our balance sheet, two-thirds of the balance sheet consists of forest and  renewable energy. We have had decent or good cash flow and we have a really low net debt situation in the  company.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: If we then continue with our business areas starting off with forest, I think you all remember last year, which was a  rather difficult year with difficult weather conditions, higher costs for people trying to get out wood from the forest  into the industry. And now when we are in the first quarter of 2019 we can see that things are back to a more  normal situation.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Pulp prices are – pulpwood prices are stabilized in the first quarter and has not changed much. And if you look at  sawlog prices we can see that in the southern parts of Sweden we see prices going down slightly. If you compare,  we talked a lot about the prices in Sweden, but also price for imported pulpwood. We have described the situation  in earlier reports where we showed what we pay in the Baltic states compared to Sweden and the situation right  now in the market is that also in the Baltic states, the cost for imported wood is coming down with a price for  imported wood is coming down some 10% to 25% [ph] grossly (00:03:10).

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: If we then continue to talk a bit more about sawlogs, we have a situation in the south of Sweden where I think you  have seen in newspapers and media that we talk about spruce bark beetle, which we need to handle in the forest.  In Sweden, we see it in the south of Sweden. It's been some million cubic meters affected in total last year and we  see the effects of that partly in this year now.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: But the big effect is not in Sweden. It has been in Central Europe where the bark beetles have caused damaged  wood in the region of some 40 million cubic meters, which is quite a lot. It's not all sawlogs, it's also of course  pulpwood.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: The situation in Sweden now is that farmers need to harvest in order to take care of the bark beetle-damaged  forest for the trees to make sure that they're taken out of the forest. That's the way to take care of the problem,  which means that there is a lot of supply of sawlogs for the moment – also pulpwood, but maybe – mainly  sawlogs, which means that the sawmills are running full. And it means also there is the pressure on first of all  sawlog prices in south of Sweden. But also there is pressure on wood products.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: If we then summarize on this, the financials for the forest business in the first quarter?

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yeah. We have now established profitability of the forest business at around SEK 300 million thanks to the price  increases. Henrik mentioned of some. Now we earned some 10% more for the pulpwood and timber that we sell.  And when you look at the figures you note that the profitability is a bit lower than it was a year ago, but that's due  to sales of forest property a year ago, that gave us a one-off revenue of SEK 70 million.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yeah, both you and we are disappointed at the result, SEK 112 million. It's a poor result from the paperboard  business. When comparing to Q1 or Q4, it's some SEK 60 million lower. We are impacted by higher wood cost,  especially when comparing to a year ago. We also have slightly high wood costs than last quarter. But first and  foremost, it's the production determines that Henrik talks about – talked about that they're both were disturbances  and somewhat weak order books means that we can't produce in an optimal way, which cost us more – increases  variable costs when producing. This in fact in total is some SEK 50 million compared to the more normal  production situation.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Holmen AB
texts.text: Also in the paper business we see higher wood costs both compared to a year ago and Q4. What we do see is  that wood cost for our industry, it has stabilized. We don't expect wood cost for paper or paperboard to increase  any more. When comparing the result, Q1 to Q4, it's only not the – the price increase is not the only positive  effect. We also have gotten back to normal cost level for maintenance. It was a bit inflated in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Thank you. All right. Wood products, we have three assortments, one in Braviken and one in Iggesund and one  outside Braviken [indiscernible] (00:11:47). This is a market where we haven't seen the price decreases for a  couple of years here either. Actually prices have slowly gone up until late last year when we felt that the market's  a bit weaker. Where we are right now is that – actually underlying demand for wood products is not bad. But right  now, it's supply-driven price decline that we see.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And remember, I talked about bark beetles before and also Central Europe where a lot of the forest, a lot of wood  is affected by the bark beetle and the farmers just need to take it out to the forest to save the value of the forest.  And that means that there has been quite a lot of availability of sawlogs – [indiscernible] (00:12:36) sawmills that  they'd been running full and that means that the market is slightly oversupplied at the moment. At the same time  as demand in some parts of the world is a bit lower. So we are in a situation where it's not bad, but prices are  slowly on its way down.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We've one sawmill we have talked about the number of times, Braviken Sawmill, one of the biggest in Sweden,  where we also have expansion plans. We are in the middle of an investment. We are building right now the  capacity to increase from some [ph] 450 cubic meters, 500 (00:13:14) cubic meters up to 600 cubic meters. And I  think with this expansions of course, now when prices are going down et cetera, it could seem like a bad idea. But  in our case it's not. We do this. We had good control over the raw material thanks to the forest holdings we have  ourselves and also the possibility we have now to actually move the raw material and making better use of the  wood from our own forest, even though the forest is not, maybe next to the sawmill, but we take it from up north.  That expansion is right on track and we expect it to come on stream during next year.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yes, we are recording another good quarter profit wise from the timber business despite prices going down as  Henrik mentioned. Prices are still at a higher level than they were a year ago. We have also ramped up  production by temporary measures at the Braviken Sawmill ahead of the expansion, which means that we are on  a bit more money from a higher volume. Compared to Q4 prices have declined some 2%, 3% on average. That  has taken the toll on profits, but it has been balanced by a good delivery in this first quarter. We have no wood on  stocks and the increased deliveries have contributed nicely to the profit.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Thank you. Then we have renewable energy. It's all about rain and wind mainly rain and in the first quarter, we've  seasonally higher production than in the fourth quarter, which means that we produce a bit more. We also have  seen higher prices and we've in this year and others that when it comes to reducing the property tax. Comparing  to the first quarter last year actually we produced a bit less, but more than in the fourth quarter, which means that  I think we are quite happy with the result on SEK 96 million that we performed in the first quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: That's it. Then some priorities from this presentation. We are focusing extremely hard to re-establish production  stability in paperboard, which meaning coming back to 550,000 tons production for the two mills in total annually.  And we are on the right track, we can say, when it comes to deliver on the cost savings program we have in the  paperboard division.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We are also seeing a possibility later on to increase pulp sales by removing bottlenecks. Most of these  bottlenecks we will remove when we have the maintenance stop later on this year at Iggesund Board Mill.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And then, it's the Braviken Mill expansion which is on track, as I said. So if we then summarize how we feel about  the results in the first quarter, I think the level at such of SEK 643 million is a good level. We see though that the  activity in our industry is slowing down somewhat, but based on our big forest holdings, our renewable energy,  our strong financial position, we are standing really strong and we have the chance to continue to develop our  business areas. It's also in a situation where the market is not maybe as strong as we have seen in the last  couple of years.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
