file: HOLM.B - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 13August2014 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: If we start with the group, we had slightly better results, January-June this year than last year, mainly thanks to  better pricing when it comes to both paper and also sawn timber. We had lower costs. As you may remember from  last time, we have now our bio boilers. I think it's in Workington. And also, at Iggesund Board, the mill in Sweden,  it's now up and running, and production as such has also been a bit better, which means lower costs.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: On the negative side, if you look at Q2, you know that we had seasonally lower hydro power production an d we  also have some lower prices. If we then look into – or maybe we should also add that if you look at the currency,  the Swedish krona is a bit weaker. So, if you look at the first half year, the effect for the Holmen Group is roughly  SEK 7 0 million, and that's fairly evenly spread between Holmen Paper and Iggesund Paperboard.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: We also have, if we look forward, a shutdown at the Hallsta Paper Mill. We have, as you might remember, a quite  big project at Hallsta where we are restructuring the whole energy side. It also cost quite a lot of money.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: For the producers who are depending on recovered paper for production, the RCP prices have been rather stable,  actually been stable all the way through 2012, 2013 and now a bit in 2014 as well, which means production cost  has not changed dramatically.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: If then now switch to Paperboard, which is a totally different situation, at least when it comes to the market, here  again we have had a situation where our production costs have been lower than compared to a year ago. I think  you also remember that when we started up the – especially the bio boiler at Iggesund mill, we had some  production disturbances in the first quarter of 2013, which also went on into the second quarter. Now production  is running better. Both the boilers and also the production as such is running much better.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: We should also remember that we had in the first quarter, of course, an adjustment on our renewable obligation  and credits rocks for our English operations and the bio boiler and the work permit, which had a negative effect of  SEK 40 million in the first quarter, which we do not have in the second quarter. But as such, production is better,  and we are fairly happy with the situation we have when it comes to the production side, but still some  improvements, of course.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: If you look at Iggesund Paperboard, we have more to do when it comes to growing by organic trimming and  removing some bottlenecks we have in the production side. There is not so much maybe in energy. It's much more  in pulp, or much more it's more in pulp. We have a number of programs running when it comes to reducing the  manning. We have, more or less, fulfilled the program in Workington and we are right now working  on the  Iggesund Board mill in Sweden. And we are on our way, and we're taking it step by step.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: If we switch over to sawn timber, as you can see, everything is – the sun is shining on us, and we have the wind in  the backs. And if you look at what has happened the first half year compared to last year, it's of course – it's better  this year. Price increases are roughly 10%. Higher deliveries also roughly 10%; increased productivity at both  sawmills. On the negative side, of course, when all sawmills are running more or less full, there is some pressure,  upward pressure on the raw material prices when it comes to timber.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: It's a quite different situation in south of Sweden compared to north of Sweden. We had the storms up north  which makes much more raw material available for the moment, but that will, of course, in the long run, change  again. But we experience right now some pressure when it comes to – especially our operations in the Braviken  sawmills. Looking at the price increases in the second quarter, we estimate that we got roughly 2% to 3%.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: I said there is a bit of a difference between pine and spruce. Y ou c an also see that on this slide, which is export  prices from Sweden, where you can see that spruce is – this is the springtime where it's a little bit deviating from  the curve, which is the pine, where prices went up during the springtime. That's the situat ion we have right now.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: And then, we have one very difficult question. I said there is an upward pressure on timber prices in Southern  Sweden. And of course, it's also a different situation when it comes to competition for the timber in Southern  Sweden compared to how it is up north.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: If we then move over to the forest side, no dramatic changes between this year and last year. And as you  can see,  no dramatic change between the first and second quarter either. We have lower harvesting volume this year, and  we have some higher costs due to the storm selling. And also the lower harvesting volume is, to some extent,  connected to the higher – we need for taking care of the timber that fell in the storms we have up north. And as  you know, we have to use the summer when it's daylight to do a lot of silviculture in our forest. We have made that  this year as well.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: If we then look at the harvesting rights we buy and the price development, I said before that there is some  pressure on the timber prices for our Braviken mill or South Sweden. On the other hand, if we look at pulpwood  prices, we do not see the same trend. We have contributed from slightly lower pulpwood prices during the first  half for the year. But there is a question mark where the market is going now. It's not given. And you know also  that the storm up north definitely has an effect on this market here.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: Going over to the energy side. The electricity prices are lower than a year ago, and that has, of course, a negative  effect on the result for Holmen Energi. We should also remember that we made a deal regarding the Varsvik wind  farm, which is a JV, which meant that we incurred SEK 102 million in last year's result in quarter two.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: If you look at the second quarter this year, we have normally seasonally lower production, especially hydro  production, and we have also lower sales prices as also electricity prices going on a lower level.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.text: And then the tricky question I just explained about sourcing to the sawmill we hav e in South Sweden at Braviken.  It's not easy. We try to move some of our organization a bit further north to see if we can even out and reduce a bit  for the competition for the local wood sourcing down there.

file: HOLM.B - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 17August2017 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Starting off with some highlights and results for the group, second quarter profit, SEK 525 million, roughly SEK  100 million less than in the first quarter, mainly explained by maintenance stop we had at the Workington Mill,  which cost about SEK 50 million. And also we have had seasonally lower hydropower production.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: If we look at first half year, however, we are some SEK 90 million better than last year, mainly thanks to higher  prices for timber, for wood products, and also, that we no longer have the Madrid Mill in our books. Production  increased in all our businesses. We have been able to establish production on a higher level and also sales. And I  would say, also, the sales mix has improved during the quarter.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: If then move to our business areas starting with the Forest, first, looking at the result, we have the operating profit  of SEK 280 million which is in line with the first quarter more or less. We see rather good demand both when it  comes to pulpwood and timber. Prices in the market are moving up slowly beginning in the south, both for timber  and for pulpwood which means that we have had bit better prices and also we've been able to continue the trend  that we keep costs on a low level or slightly decreasing.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: When it comes to cash flow, our cash flow yield is currently 4.3% year-to-date. And that's our EBIT excluding  change in value divided by pre-tax book value on the Forest we have. This is a very important parameter for us to  follow to see how we are actually doing when it comes to our business in the Forest.

file: HOLM.B - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 15August2018 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: So let's start with some highlights for the second quarter. If we look at overall result of SEK 618 million and return  on capital employed of 10% is actually a good result, especially given the fact that we have two-thirds of our  assets in forest and hydro power. We said last quarter that we weren't really happy with the performance of  paperboard, but we see now in the second quarter that we have a really good production level in both mills, which  I will come back to.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We also see that we have a positive price trend, both for wood products, but also for paper and more or less flat  development when it comes to the paperboard. And very important, you know that we have had a difficult period  when it comes to the weather conditions in Sweden, which means also very difficult to source raw material  pulpwood especially to our mills but we can now see that we have been able to manage that during the second  quarter.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Continuing down with the forest division. You remember I guess from the first quarter when we discussed the  increase in cost for our production units, our paper mill and board mills. This is the Swedish situation and you can  see the cost for the second quarter when it comes to pulpwood is on the same level as for the first quarter. When  we were in the first quarter, we said that we see increased cost of SEK 60 million going from the fourth quarter  last year to the first quarter this year. Reason for that was that imported wood has became really expensive and  we also had some extra cost related to the weather.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: If we then look a bit at the challenging weather conditions we have had in 2018, it started off in a very difficult way  with too much water, too mild weather, after that we got too much snow and extremely cold weather for some  period. We had a few weeks when we had no disturbances, but in total this meant that we didn't have enough  transport capacity and it was not easy to harvest in the forest during these conditions. And on top of that, we now  have had forest fires during the summer. In the case of our company, we have had roughly 2,500 hectares of land  that has been affected by the forest fires and the 2,000 hectares of productive forest land that we actively  manage.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: When we look at the extra cost we have both to take care of damaged wood, but also cost for replanting on the  land that has been affected by the fires. We estimate that cost to roughly SEK 30 million, which will come then in  the third quarter. This is just to give you a bit of an idea what we have done ourselves in order to contain the  effects of the fires. We have up in the north where a couple of bigger fires has hit us, we have seen tremendous  efforts both from our own personnel but also from others to do anything what's possible to make sure that the fires  don't spread more than necessary.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: This has been a really tough work and you can get an idea the way we have worked if you look at these pictures.  We have [indiscernible] (04:46) forest lanes in order to make sure that the forest can't spread from one area to the  other and we have done a lot of other things as well. It's been a tough situation, but again even though we have  had a very tough weather conditions and also then later on we have had these fires, the effects on our forests has  not been that great. And the most important part is that when we look forward, we do not see any effect on future  harvesting levels.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: So, Anders, if you summarize the effects both for the industry and our own forest with some financial details.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yeah, Henrik, thank you. The first half year for the forest business, we earned close to SEK 600 million. This does  include SEK 70 million in capital gains from sale of forest land. And last year, we had a SEK 20 million gain in the  books. This explains the increase in profit that we see the SEK 50 million increase in profit year-to-date. We have  had positive impact on our industry of roughly 5% higher prices this year compared to last year, but this has been  accounted by higher costs related to the difficult weather conditions Henrik talked about.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Looking into the second quarter, we earned SEK 271 million. We saw some price increases coming through in the  second quarter but we still had quite a high cost level in our harvesting operations, roughly on the same level as  in the first quarter. And looking forward into this Q3 as Henrik mentioned, we will take a cost of SEK 30 million  related to the fires in our forest of course.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Still, we see that the cost level as such is affected by inflation which we also mentioned in the first quarter that we  see inflation mainly in wood, chemicals and to some extent also in energy that's more related to paper.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yeah. As you mentioned Henrik, we had a good development in production, volumes and deliveries, they are up  6%, which has contributed at that's one too far on the slide. Yeah, now we are on the left side again and – but we  have higher input costs. As you mentioned, we have price inflation on wood, chemicals and actually also energy  which is both price inflation and usage and this adds up to SEK 100 million cost increase. And when it comes to  energy, we have been very good at ramping up the board production, but the pulp production we have not been  able to ramp up at the same pace, which I've meant that we need to buy more energy in to support the board  machines.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: However, we have been really good at selling our products in competition with our other more expensive products  using the properties of the fresh virgin fibers we have here up in Scandinavia and especially in Sweden and we  have constantly improved our product mix which means that the idea of the future is to continuing that path and  make sure that we compete more and more with wood free paper and less with newsprint like papers.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yeah. Year-to-date, we are on par profit-wise with previous year that we have, as Henrik mentioned, we have a  good price development of 7% up. We do have the positive development of the product mix which have added to  profits, but we see a high cost inflation, wood especially is going up and we also see bleaching chemicals  becoming more expensive and energy. Well, these are the three main input goods for producing paper.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Looking at the second quarter, profit went up roughly SEK 10 million. We had good new contracts, price contracts  at higher levels that kicked in in the beginning of the quarters. We had a good product development, but we had a  higher cost for maintenance. This was not really planned, was normal maintenance stops, but they became a bit  more expensive than we expected and we also had high costs for bleaching the wood when arriving at the mills  and that's partly related to or to a large extent related to the difficult weather conditions that it costed more to treat  the wood.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Thank you. Continuing with wood products, you can see a few pictures of our saw mill in Braviken outside  Norrköping. You can also see that we have at least one picture with our new treatment plant, which if you look  into the facility itself, you can also see the way we actually pressurize and make treat – how we treat the wood.  This one has been up and running now since beginning of the summer and it's been a very good startup not only  volume wise but also well received by our customers. I think it's known to most people that the prices for wood  products have gone up for some period. It's actually a very long period if you looked upon it in a historical  perspective. It's now over two years' time that we see the prices slowly ticking up.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Still we are not at the same level as the previous peaks. And maybe we can also make another comparison as we  know wood products are mainly used for building in wood houses, flats et cetera and other materials such as  concrete, steel and aluminium are also used for that. So even if we think that we have come to a point where well  we have increased the price for wood, quite a lot for wood products, still that's nothing compared to, for example,  concrete or steel for that sake or even aluminium.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We talk about a lot about that there are lot of people showing interest in building in wood and I guess finally it's a  matter of cost, which material you choose, it's also the total cost of course. But if you look upon this over some  time at least it doesn't look as the cost competitiveness would have deteriorated rather the opposite, it looks  better. So we had hoped for more building in wood in the future, that's clear. Anders, financials for wood  products?

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Looking at the second quarter, we doubled the profit and that's as a result of a good price development, a very  good mix in sales mix and also from a seasonal perspective a very strong quarter, and a high demand for wood in  the second quarter ahead of this summer season when a lot of people do projects on their homes. And it's also –  Q2 is also a good production quarter normally coming out of the tough winter where production cost normal or a  bit higher, so that has been beneficial for the result in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Thank you. Going into renewable energy which in our case is mainly hydro power, we have a situation where we  had very high production in the first quarter and we had a lot of snow melting, but melting really fast, which meant  that the production in the second quarter is on the normal level even though it's higher than for the same period  last year. We should also mention that somewhere in June, we were actually running out of water. We did not  totally, but the water levels in our reservoirs, our magazines are on the low level when we entered the third  quarter.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: During the second quarter, we've also seen a bit higher electricity prices. And of course, we are also in a period  now where we successfully or step by step are taking down the property tax which has an effect on the result. So  result is such, year-to-date SEK 120 million and the second quarter SEK 33 million is a rather good level if we  compare it to historic levels. That finalizes the different business areas.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: So before we take questions, I would just like to underline the priorities of our company going forward. Managed  wood cost inflation is extremely important. It's important not only to, of course, make sure that we source wood to  our industries, using our own forest in the best possible way that could also mean that we used out a Northern  forest land ownership in a slightly different way in the future to make sure that our own industries have enough  wood to run full.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Second priority, very important as well is, of course, to continue and to finalize the cost reduction program we  have in paperboard where an important part of that is the cost reductions we're looking at the Iggesund Paper  Mill. And then at parallel with that same time, we're also looking into the possibilities of increasing capacity of the  Iggesund – sorry this one, of the Iggesund Paper Mill with another hundred thousand tons of solid dashboard.

file: HOLM.B - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 26October2010 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Magnus Hall, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Ladies and gentlemen, it’s my pleasure to welcome you here today to the Holmen Third
texts.text: The situation here is of course our main target, we can say for what is – what can substantially  change the Holmen situation in terms of profitability is the very poor pricing situation we now have  on newsprint. And you can see here this picture is clearly showing how much we lost in terms of the  pricing between 2009 and 2010. And since then, we have also had an increase in the waste paper,  one of the main raw materials at probably between 85 and 90% of newsprint produced in Europe,  probably more is today based on recovered papers, raw material based and it has pushed a whole  cost base up. So anybody can understand that the pressure for increased prices is quite severe.

texts.speaker: Magnus Hall, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Ladies and gentlemen, it’s my pleasure to welcome you here today to the Holmen Third
texts.text: This last picture here shows that the waste paper prices, actually they have leveled out. They  increased quite a lot at the beginning of the year, they have leveled out now from a raw material  deinking versus there is a feeling now that also the brown grades stocks to slide down cost wise a  little bit. And normally you would have the brown corrugated grades and on top of that, you would  have to pay a surplus resorting to get your deinking grade out. So if that starts moving down, that  could be sort of at least leveling out the cost situation.

texts.speaker: Magnus Hall, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Ladies and gentlemen, it’s my pleasure to welcome you here today to the Holmen Third
texts.text: But on the other hand, this market has now been much more affected by buying from the Chinese  than ever before. So if prices starting to come down, and we don’t see any slowing down in the  actual demand for waste paper from China, they will come back and continue buying and the  capacity is in China is increasing, as we speak in all grades and specifically of course also the  brown grades, where they need a lot of packaging. So there will be a need to continue to export out  of Europe and that will most probably keep the pressure on waster paper fairly high in my opinion.

file: HOLM.B - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 26October2011 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The result for the first nine months this year amounted to SEK1.570 billion, that's quite a significant increase on  last year's SEK971 million. Of course, all the reasons behind that is high prices for newsprint and for board. It  could have been better if we didn't have increased cost also for wood and recycled paper, which have taken away a  big part of the possibility of an increased profit, especially in Holmen Paper.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: If you go to Q3, it's SEK519 million, little bit better than the second quarter of this year and mainly it could be  derived from the result in Holmen Energi where we have had a lot of [indiscernible] (01:51) where we have power  problems. And we also had normally a good result with seasonally lower personnel costs. But on the other hand,  which we already forewarned of before, we have had a big maintenance shut in Iggesund mill and I can say already  from the beginning it has went – it has gone very well with regard to what we have planned, we have done

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We go straight into Holmen Paper, and there we have the SEK231 million. I will not – I mean of course, high  newsprint prices and again the increased cost of recycled paper and partly also due to wood. And then if you  compare the fact, that the third quarter we had SEK105 million compared to SEK70 million in Q2, which mainly is  related to lower personnel costs, which I mentioned earlier.

file: HOLM.B - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 26October2012 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So let's start this report for the first – for the nine months of this year, we report a profit of SEK1.442 billion,  which is a little bit less than last year but we have two differences in between the years, one is that we have much  lower contribution from currency hedges this year, plus we also have a different valuation of the forest where we  are – we value the growth to the forest more than we actually did before. So those two are more or less not fully  but offsetting each other in different directions.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our current items, I mean basic – strategically, continue to grow in MF Magazine and book products. We  published a decision close to a month ago about focusing the Hallsta Paper Mill more on the MF Magazine grades,  because we are closing – we intend to close the PM 3 machine producing 140,000 tons of SC paper, that's for all  next year and in the meantime, we would invest and rebuild part of the energy supply situation, it enables us, at  the end, to close both the paper machine but also to close a big part of the heavy energy supply side. And we  expect a total of some 230 people – that we can actually reduce the costs and the personnel by 230. So for us, this  is a good move. It's not normally not so easy to just close the machine and get a good – better situation, but we  will get a better situation, we will refocus the mill on those two machines making book paper and MF Magazine, so  for us, it's a good move.  Then we work, of course, across the line with increased productivity at the same time, and we have a good  development, specifically in Spain, as Spain has been – sort of have been in a tough situation for many years. But  now, since we closed the machine and we have worked with productivity, we can actually see that we are earning  money in Spain, and we are very happy with that.

file: HOLM.B - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 24October2013 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Magnus Hall
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And if you look at the quarter three result, it's SEK 326 million. It's a little bit on top of the Q2 result mainly with a  much better result from the paperboard business as we also had SEK 102 million in profit from the establishment  of the wind farm in Q2.

texts.speaker: Magnus Hall
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We are running efficiency programs to counteract this, that's a plus, and we also had some help with lower wood  prices because the wood costs in Sweden have gone down during the year and we have had some help from that.

texts.speaker: Magnus Hall
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: So Holmen Paper current items, we're going forward with our program to reduce manning with about 400 people.  We have started the process, of course, now with the two closures. We also have one big step ahead of us in next  year when we will close the energy plant of our Hallsta Mill. And then after that, we have made the full program of  closures. And we will focus in on MF special grades in Sweden, book paper grades and MF Magazine grades, and  we will focus – of course, continuously, we will focus on newsprint in the mill in Spain, but we will have then   roughly 1.45 million tonnes of capacity and we will produce around 1.45 – 1,400 tonnes per employee in the  company. So we will have a significant difference in terms of productivity when it's – when we compare to five  years ago.

file: HOLM.B - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 26October2016 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Moving to forest, stable market, good demand for both timber and pulpwood; the profit level at the normal level.  Comparing to last year, we have slightly lower cost which we have said, thanks to good cost cutting within the  forest division. We also have slightly higher prices, mainly due to that last year was affected by some storm effect  which means that year-on-year comparison is a bit easy. And we have a cash flow yield over roughly 3.7%, rolling  12-month basis. Any questions about the forest?

file: HOLM.B - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 24October2017 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-17.pdf
HOLM.B - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 24October2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We will start off with highlights for the third quarter. We have a stable performance and an operating profit of SEK  591 million, which gives us return on capital employed in the quarter of a bit over 9% and 10% for the first nine  months. During the quarter, we have had a big maintenance stop, which we will come back to, at the Iggesund  Mill which has costed SEK 60 million, and we also have had effect of the forest fires during the summers which  has costed us roughly SEK 30 million.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Turning then into the different business areas, I will start off with forests. And in the forest, we have showed a  slide before which shows the market for pulpwood. On the left-hand side, you will see the cost, the average cost,  total cost for us in Holmen, what we buy in Sweden and also the cost for imported wood. On the other hand, on  the right-hand side, you also see the price we pay in Sweden and also the cost for the imported wood. And as you  can see, it's quite big difference.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: If you look at our situation, we had some extra cost during the second quarter. In the second quarter, we said that  we'll not have any extra cost, but we see that prices in general in the forest, actually they go up. So in the third  quarter, we have an impact of that, which means, and what you also can see, that our average cost is slightly  higher.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: When we come into the fourth quarter though we don't see that pulpwood cost will go up for us. We will work hard  on using our own forest land in order to take down wood from the north and to supply our industries and make  more use of the wood we have in our own forest. And we'll do that in a way that we will use vessels, like we do  today, but we will also establish a train connection or logistics setups with train in order to also be able to take  down little bit bigger volumes of pulpwood from our own forest down south.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And if we look at right-hand side of the chart again and the difference between the Swedish price and the Baltic  Sea price or the Baltic States price, of course, you might think that there over time must be either that imported  wood will become a bit cheaper or you will see some further price pressure in Sweden. It's too early to say, but at  least for us we see that we have a chance to takedown or not change our cost by using our own forest in a better  way.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We had a strategy in Holmen, and we are quite keen on making sure that we have sufficient control over our raw  material supply. And for that reason, it is also a quite natural step to invest in forest land when it's possible.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And, therefore, we also showed a slide here with the forest land we actually bought during the third quarter, which  is 5,700 hectares of productive forest land, very close to our industries in Iggesund. It will improve our situation  locally of course and it's also something we're really glad to have finalized as we believe long-term it is increasing  our possibilities to have better and better control over the raw material situation.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Anders, if we sum up situation financially for the forest division?

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yes. So far this year, Henrik, we have earned SEK 50 million more from the forest division, and that's due to  higher prices of wood and especially pulpwood have increased in price. What we have seen also this year is a  number of unusual items. We've had high harvesting costs due to harsh winter weather. We also had high cost  due to forest fires, but we also sold more forest properties than we normally do. These unusual items more or less  balances each other out. So the performance of SEK 859 million this year is reflecting the underlying  performance.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Looking into Q3, we took a SEK 30 million charge there related to the forest fires this summer. And so, the  underlying performance Q3 of 2019 reflects what we do earn now from our forest operations with the current price  level for the wood, timber and pulpwood in Sweden.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: If we take the next slide, we can compare the current price level that we have in the market with the so-called  trend price that we use when valuing the forest in our books according to IAS 41. You can notice that currently  prices are 10% higher than what we use in our model. That is, as such, nothing unusual. We have been deviating  by even 20% in the past, so it will not trigger any reevaluation of our forest. But it's worth noting that we now trade  at a higher price than what we use in our valuation.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: And if you look at this graph, it starts 2005; and 2005 was when we introduced the IAS 41 valuation in our books.  And if you do the math over this almost 15-year period, you can see – or you reach an average price increase of  2.5% per year over this time period and that we have been able to increase wood prices in Sweden.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Thank you. Then, moving on to renewable energy. I think most people are aware of that we had a very dry  summer in Sweden. And when you look at the situation for our hydro production, we have had low water flows in  our hydro-generating plants, and we also have had low production, which is not very strange then. And we're also  on a low level when it comes to how much water we have in our water reservoirs, which most probably will have  an impact on production in the fourth quarter; meaning, it will be most probably bit lower than normal.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yes. We have seen the result go down by SEK 150 million, and this is due to high cost inflation on wood and  chemicals. The prices have risen roughly 10% to 15%. We have also seen higher fixed costs, and that's why we  are doing this fixed cost program that Henrik mentioned. We have had higher production that has partly been  balancing out the negative effect of the high fixed cost. But by far, not enough.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: This quarter is seasonally a low-cost quarter for personnel, and that's roughly SEK 20 million positive effect. We  have seen higher wood cost. They have been rising, as Henrik mentioned, roughly SEK 20 million negative effect  this quarter. But we also are seeing signs that we're actually able to take down the cost a bit in the paperboard  division, and that has been a positive effect on the profit in Q3.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yeah. We see some increase in profit. We have had a very nice development of prices, as Henrik mentioned,  both market prices have increased, but on top of that this strong market situation has enabled us to switch over to  better paper products, have a clearly better product mix this year than last year. All in all, prices in SEK has been  10% higher for us. This has, however, been balanced by high cost of wood, chemicals and electricity, which is an  important input good when producing paper.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Looking into Q3, we have SEK 30 million increase in profit. We see some effects of price increase coming  through. And we have seasonally lower cost, some SEK 20 million. But we have faced high wood cost, SEK 20  million, and also electricity cost. We do hedge 80% of our electricity exposure in this division. The 20% that has  been unhedged, we have bought at a very high level in Q3, and that has costed us some extra SEK 10 million to  SEK 15 million in Q3.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Thank you. Last but not least, wood products. Here, we have had a period of over more than two years now with  increasing prices. But look at the chart now. You have a slight dip at the end. And it's not that the market is  dramatically changing, but we have to be honest and say that we see some – at least it's more difficult to increase  prices further when it comes to China where prices now are eroding a little bit; and also when it comes to U.S.,  where prices have changed a little bit more.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Thanks. Today at the board meeting, we also decided to expand in the Braviken sawmill. This sawmill was built to  produce more than it is currently. On the other hand, we have taken it step by step in order to improve the  business we have. And we have today decided to invest SEK 170 million in order to increase the production by  some 150,000 cubic meters, bringing up the total production in the Holmen sawmills to 3 million cubic meters.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We have up to 1 million cubic meters, one, it's done and finalized, and we are up and running. And the idea is to  reach the new level somewhere during 2020. The idea behind this is, as I said, the sawmill is designed for higher  capacity, but also that we have a chance to buy – investing in sorting and drying. We takeaway a couple of  bottlenecks, and we can increase the capacity to a really low marginal cost, not adding extra fixed cost or very low  extra fixed cost.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And as we mentioned, when we talked about pulpwood, introducing logistic solution by train. That train, we will  also use in order to bring down the timber we need to supply the expansion at the Braviken sawmill. Meaning,  when we increase the capacity, the raw material will not be taken from the local market, will not disturb the local  market, but will come from our own forest holdings up further north. This is something we believe in. And it also  gives us flexibility both on the, of course, production side, but also on the supply side of raw material.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: All right. If we then conclude by summarizing the most and prioritized areas we see when we stand as we do  today after the third quarter. Extremely important is to manage wood sourcing. We believe really that the market  in Sweden is tightening. We had a tough period with difficult weather. We had forest fires, but now we are out of  that tunnel. And still when we look ahead, we see a situation where it's quite important to have control of raw  material, and Sweden is an import country when it comes to pulpwood.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, we start this picture, I think, you know very, very well; the set-up of the Holmen Group. And there, we are  reporting a profit for 2011 of SEK1.98 billion. And of course, higher newsprint prices, which were coming out of  the negotiations in front of 2011, and also, board – increased prices on the board side, has been positive factors,  whereas we have been fighting against higher wood prices and also continuously increasing recycled paper costs.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Holmen Forest, a small decrease. And Energi also decreased. Just remember, last year we had much higher prices  than this year, and it's reflected of course in the results.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And then as a non-recurring item, which we have reported on in December is the re-evaluation, the IFRS re- evaluation of our forest resources, which amounted to about SEK3.6 billion, totally amounting with non-recurring  items to SEK5.6 billion.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: MF Magazine, which is again operate green, our best – where we are the best, that market increased quite  considerably last year. But this year, it was more it started well off, but it has been weaker and weaker, and ended  up with a 0% increase. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

We can now see that the brown grades are actually now bottoming out a little bit, that's the  feeling we have in the market. And the risk, of course, now is also that the continued price decrease on recovered  paper for our products will actually bottom out because there is certainly – is never going to go down below with  the brown pricing.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We will continue our growth strategy in MF Magazine and book products, and we also have few cost reduction  programs that we'll of course continue to execute; one in the Braviken mill and in [indiscernible] (09:50) where  we have discussions with the units about the reduction of 85% – 85 people. And also, we are taking down the  manning in our Spanish operations a little bit further than we did last year.  Okay. I think, we can take a break there and see if there are any questions. Yes, please. I think we have a  microphone.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So we go into the Holmen Paper operation, we are seeing here a lower result compared to last year. We are in both  our big areas, of course, affected by the Swedish currency changes. We are running efficiency programs. They have  helped us in fixed costs. We have improved product mix that also has helped us in terms of over value-added  component. And we had had enjoyed some lower recycled paper prices helping us, but even so, the profit has gone  down and we have had some price decreases going into 2012 as you might well remember.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, Holmen Paper's cash flow case. And you can see from this picture that the EBITDA levels coming out of  Holmen Paper businesses is still quite strong and we are trying to invest as little as possible. We today advised of a  new investment that we are taking into Hallsta because we are closing down one paper machine and we are also  closing down a big part of the energy.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, the old energy supply operations that where we had to – if we were to continue then we invest quite a lot of  money. So, in total, it's a very good change, but it will cost us an initial investment of about SEK200 million to do  this. We will, by that, reduce the personnel by about 230 people, roughly two-thirds of that will be coming in the  fall of this year and another third of it just before summer of next year when we will close the full – the energy  supply side as well.
