texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And then also I'd like to remind that we have been quite successful in cutting cost in the forest, which means  –  which is also a reminder that actually after harvesting, we also have 1% more volumes standing in the forest at  the end of the year than when the year started.

file: HOLM.B - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 30January2018 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Looking at the full year, we have been able to increase both production and sales by 5% to 10% in all our  industrial business areas. At the same time as we have had some headwind from increased wood costs,  chemicals and some freight costs, and we have also been able to compensate the large maintenance stops we  had, which is not only the one at Iggesund Paper Mill, it's also the one in Workington, in total some SEK 220  million. So the results are more or less the same in 2017 as where we landed in 2016.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Looking at the return on capital employed, we are also roughly the same level, meaning 8.7%. And to remind you  that in our company forest and hydro power actually accounts for two-thirds of the capital we have.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And then moving on to the business area starting with our forest operations, which is free from surprises as it  should be. We have an operating profit in the fourth quarter of some SEK 258 million. Here, it's more or less the  same as we had in the third quarter. Looking at the whole year, we are doing a little bit better than last year,  mainly thanks to the price increases we have from cutting, harvesting and selling from our own forests, and also  some lower costs. We had a cash flow yield of 3.7%, and reminding you that we sold off a bit of property at the  end of last year and that will come into the books in the first quarter of 2018, which [ph] landed an (03:21) impact  of net SEK 70 million.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Maybe we should mention a few words about the weather situation also. The possibility to actually get the wood  out of the forest to our industries, not only for us but I think you've heard or read about other industries also being  affected by the weather situation we have now. That's mainly in the middle part of Sweden and the South of  Sweden. And it's same for us. We do feel it. We have commented before and we have said that that's within what  we see as normal variation during the winter. The situation is still a bit – it's not easy to know exactly where it's  going, but you know what the weather is like. It's [ph] no real (04:04) winter in middle of South Sweden and that  has affected the situation.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Looking at the market as such, as I said it's not so easy to feed the mills, we had everything we need. It's good  demand both for timber and for pulpwood in the market.

file: HOLM.B - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 31January2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: And if we then go into our business or different business areas starting off with our forest division. When it comes  to the forest, it's been good demand all over. And if we start by saying a few words about the part of the forest  business which is sourcing to our own industries, we all know that we have had a quite difficult year when it  comes to the weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: In the beginning, there was a lot of snow. And then, later on, we had a very dry summer with forest fires, etcetera  which has affected the possibility to get wood out to the forest but also the cost. On the left-hand chart you see  our average cost sourcing pulpwood to our Swedish industries. On the right hand chart we have split the cost into  what we pay for domestic deliveries and what we pay for imports from the Baltic States. In our case, we buy  pulpwood for roughly SEK 2 billion and the import share is roughly 10%.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: If we then look at the other part of the forest business, which is what we own from our own forest, we see  increased prices. And if we look at the combined situation for pulpwood and timber, the price increase is roughly  9%, which has also resulted in an improved operating profit for that business area by roughly SEK 100 million. So  if you summarize the forest operations, Anders, financially.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yeah. You have already mentioned that the price increases make up the bulk of the improvement of slightly more  than SEK 100 million in EBIT for forest business. We have had a number of unusual items this year. We started  off with selling of forest property, which made a gain of SEK 70 million. Then we encountered very high harvesting  cost during the spring period or the winter and spring period. And it was followed by forest fires during the  summer that cost us some extra money. If you take all these three unusual items together, they more or less  balances each there. So the underlying profit improvement with the profit increasing to almost SEK 1.2 billion is  due to higher price level.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: If we look into the fourth quarter, you can see that profit jumped up, but you have to remember that we took SEK  30 million cost in Q3, so the increase is a bit more modest going to Q4, but we had a high timber log share of our  harvesting in the Q4, unusually high, which contributed positively, and we also saw some price increases. We  have now established a new level for profitability in this business area. It's not as high as SEK 326 million, but it's  slightly above SEK 300 million per quarter. And that's the run rate we are at right now for the forest business.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: We have said before also that we're looking into the possibilities of increasing the production at the Iggesund Mill  by 100,000 tons by rather big investment. We have now when we have finalized our project come to the  conclusion that we will postpone that. It's quite high CapEx, and we do not judge the market timing to be very  good.

texts.speaker: Anders Jernhall
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yes. We saw a profit of SEK 14 million increase. We had a good price development on average and on the total  deliveries 10% price increase. In this 10%, we have a fair share that actually is not a pure price increase; it's  rather that we've improved the product mix that Henrik alluded to. But we – a lot of this positive price momentum  has been evened out by a high – rising cost for wood, chemicals, and also energy has been very expensive this  year, and is at a relatively high level right now.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Thank you. Then looking into wood products, I think everyone is aware of that we had a very strong situation for  some time now. And when it comes to pricing during the whole of 2018, we experienced higher prices. Our price  increases in 2018 or the price level compared to 2017 is roughly 15% higher. But at the end of the year, we  experienced like most players in this segment that the market got a bit weaker, especially in Asia and in Northern  Africa, Middle East, we saw some price erosions, which is also seen in this chart when you look at it.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Going forward, from – sorry, we have to take this one, which is very important of course. It's always good to  remember how wood products actually is standing out compared to other construction materials. And what has  happened lately and if you look at the chart here, you can see that if anything, construction wood has been more  cost effective than before.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: So if we summarize wood products, Anders?  Anders Jernhall  Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Holmen AB  It's very good profit development as we have seen this year driven by the large price increase that Henrik has  been talking about. And we have a rather modest cost inflation on the raw material, the timber. Until the latter part  of this year, we have seen very small price increases on the raw material. Going in Q4, as Henrik had mentioned,  we have seen some price declines on lower quality grades, and we have also had a weaker market mix. That's  not unusual. In a normal market, Q4 has quite a weak market mix. What we did also face in this quarter was a rise  in log costs. And we are now in the phase where the log raw material costs are going up at the same time as we  are a bit uncertain on where the selling price is on the finished product is heading.

texts.speaker: Henrik Sjölund
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Holmen AB
texts.text: Yeah. As I continue with renewable energy, which is mainly hydro power in our case. And as you can see on the  chart actually, we are- we had produced as much in 2018 as in 2017 even though we had a quiet dry summer.  But we're ending the year with the level in our water reservoirs a little bit lower than normal, and you can also see  that the production level as such is slightly lower than a normal year.

file: HOLN - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 12May2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Third, China, Indonesia and India turnarounds are underway, and we are starting to reap the benefits of the  decisive cost initiatives we have put in place. China and Indonesia results stabilized in the first quarter and in  India, we saw visible results of cost-cutting, notably coming from our fuel strategy.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: And finally, all this is happening in a favorable environment where we see demand in our markets overall growing  in all product lines. We see declining fuel prices, changing the fuel mix and lower energy prices helped us reduce  our energy costs this quarter by more than 9% or CHF 65 million. And we will seek further opportunities to reduce  energy costs in the coming quarters.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In China, our ongoing focus on cost is bearing its first results. We have successfully renegotiated coal energy  contract and increased the use of petcoke. These measures allowed us to more than offset the negative impact  from lower market prices and to turn in a profitable quarter.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Margin improvement in Indonesia and Vietnam partially offset low profitability in Australia, where a number of  larger projects including the Gorgon LNG project concluded in the quarter. In Europe, we saw encouraging  volumes in some Eastern European markets like Serbia and Romania, and some resilience in Switzerland and  France.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Adjusted operating EBITDA was negatively impacted by the effect of lower comparable pricing versus Q1 2015 in  many markets including France, Poland and Switzerland. Pricing amounted with CHF 35 million for the negative  variant in the quarter. Additionally, we have CHF 9 million lower CO2 sales and the absence of the Q1 2015  positive items, which accounted for another CHF 23 million. Cash flow from operating activities improved, while  total CapEx declined compared to a year ago.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In the first quarter of this year, we recorded a negative forex effect of some CHF 43 million, and on net sales, the  impact was around CHF 240 million. We also did not sell any CO2 credits, hence, another CFH 17 million of  negative variance compared to last year. Merger, restructuring and other one-offs amounted for CHF 50 million in  the quarter, and we continue to expect a total of CHF 400 million of such costs in 2016. The underlying  performance of the group is encouraging, and let me use the next slide to further demonstrate this.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: The fourth pillar is sustainability. This is a critical part of our business model, bringing a significant differentiation  potential. This is also an area where you have to look far ahead. This is why we have launched just last month our  2030 Plan. The plan sets out clear challenging but necessary goals for how we do business. One target, for  example, is to produce 40% less CO2 per tonne of cement than we did in 1990 and help our customers avoid  releasing 10 million tonnes of CO2 annually by using our innovations. The 2030 Plan is broad and deep and has  far too much detail and scope to go into here. However, I encourage you all to go and look at the detail on our  website.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: We've reached an inflection point on prices and our actions will gain momentum in the quarters to come. We are  on track to exceed our 2016 synergy target, and we will fully deliver our divestment target. The turnaround of  difficult countries like China, Indonesia and India is well underway. And our cash flow generation is strong. And  we are operating in a favorable environment with sustained demand in all our product lines and lower energy  costs.

file: HOLN - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 3May2017 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: In the first quarter, we have seen sustained price and margin improvements as a result of a turnaround plan  based largely on three dimensions: first, fuel flexibility which plays an important role in reducing dependency on  gas and fuel oil; secondly, increasing our clinker capacity with the start of the second kiln line in Calabar in  southeastern Nigeria with much lower production costs; and, third, improved efficiency of our logistics operations  to reduce our exposure to the dollar through local sourcing.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: We also continue to see positive momentum in our margins overall. Although margins in Q1 are always impacted  by the timing of maintenance work off of a relatively small base of activity, this trend reflects the positive pricing  momentum and the impact of cost reductions which more than offset cost and energy inflation.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: In Malaysia, we are also focusing on vertical integration and modernizing our retail presence. In Indonesia, we are  optimizing our route-to-market flows. We are also implementing a range of cost initiatives in both markets in terms  of energy efficiency, logistics and sales. While we expect the challenging conditions in these two markets to  continue throughout 2017, we are confident that we will see improved margins by the end of this year as a result  of these actions.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: The group is in great shape and on track for the coming 18 months with clear action plans in place to deliver on  the 2018 targets. I'm highly confident in the ability of our teams to deliver on them and it is, therefore, a good time  for a transition.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: The third point is that on the costs side, we were impacted by the inflation on both energy and other cost  categories. Overall, inflation accounted for around CHF213 million, out of which between CHF60 million to CHF70  million for energy alone, which is consistent with our overall guidance for the full year of 10% energy price  increase. The underlying cost inflation was around 3.7% excluding energy this quarter.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In Switzerland, performance was impacted by harsh weather at the beginning of the quarter. Overall though,  cement volumes were up offsetting declines in aggregates and ready mix, impacted by the completion of some  large projects in 2016.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In Brazil, while the environment remains challenging, ongoing cost optimization helps to mitigate the impact from  both lower volumes and lower prices. In Colombia, we experienced a tough quarter in difficult market conditions.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In other markets, Algeria continued to deliver strong results, supported by the ramp-up of the Biskra plant. Egypt  delivered a resilient performance in Q4, but market conditions remain challenging following the currency  devaluation. High inflation and higher exports are impacting the performance. Strong mitigation actions are taken  with maximization of local energy sourcing and an increase of close to 10% of the alternative fuel in the energy  mix.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Slide 21. More specifically, in order to drive our 2017 targets, we assume the following elements: Synergies in  excess of CHF1 billion by end 2017 with an incremental amount of CHF400 million of operating EBITDA for 2017  alone; CapEx below CHF1.8 million; an increase in energy prices of around 10%; this should be partly mitigated  by energy consumption optimization, but also by our work on alternative fuels which you'll continue to see strong  progress in 2017.

file: HOLN - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 29July2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Thomas Aebischer
texts.text: Ready-mix concrete deliveries increased slightly by 0.6% and reached 18.2 million cubic meters, as improvements  in Europe and Asia Pacific could compensate for slight declines in North America and Latin America as well as  Africa Middle East.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Thank you, Thomas, and thank you, Jean-Jacques. So before turning to our roadmap for the second half, let me  summarize with a word about the environment. You've seen in the results posted by both Legacy Holcim and  Legacy Lafarge as well as from the comments of Thomas and Jean-Jacques that we have continued to face a  contrasted and overall rather soft environment in the first half. We have seen very good developments in some  countries, but also a handful number of markets facing a really challenging environment.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Looking in more detail at the dynamics by region, I would highlight the following. First, North America, there the  recovery in the U.S. is well underway, still driven by the housing segment. Canada continues to be resilient with  good dynamics in the East. In Western Canada, the impact of declining oil prices has still not been seen, as we had  a strong backlog already. However, I would expect to see some slowdown in the coming months, which is  embedded in the outlook.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Overall, I would say that the environment is certainly less supportive than what people may have thought earlier  this year. To address the most challenging situations and disconnected from what we expect from the merger, we  have launched targeted cost reduction actions in Indonesia, India, Brazil and Egypt. The current short-term  market challenges do not impair in any way the long-term growth potential in these countries and the perspectives  of our markets.

file: HOLN - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 5August2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: In the second quarter, the adjusted operating EBITDA of CHF 1.7 billion is up 6% like-for-like on the same quarter  last year. If we exclude Nigeria, where our operations had to deal with the effect of severe gas shortages,  adjusted operating EBITDA would have been up 13% on a like-for-like basis.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: We are working full speed to fix the situation, and I expect our plants to be in a position to reduce their  dependence on gas before the end of the year. And we see price increases happening as well. This will enable us  to increase supply and capture growth. In October, we also expect to open the new line at our plant in Calabar, in  the southeast of Nigeria, providing us with additional capacity to serve that part of the country.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: We also benefited from lower energy costs. Energy savings were CHF 80 million in Q2 2016, up from CHF 60  million in Q1, as we continue to benefit from lower energy prices and an improved fuel mix. The combination of  robust pricing, delivery of synergies and cost management has visibly improved profitability, delivering an  adjusted operating EBITDA margin of 23.4%, up 210 basis points on the same quarter in 2015.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: On the cost side, we have continued to benefit from lower fuel prices and from the fuel-mix optimization from coal  to petcoke. Overall, we achieved 530 basis points improvement in adjusted operating EBITDA margin.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In China, our ongoing focus on cost has continued to deliver impressive results, while we are able to increase  volumes by 1.8% in Q2. Production costs are still positively impacted by lower coal and power prices, while a  higher usage of limestone instead of fly ash is impacting positively raw material cost. All-in-all, we improved the  adjusted operating EBITDA margin by 10 percentage points.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Despite the price recovery initiated in Q1, our asset base was disproportionately impacted by gas shortages  due  to pipeline attacks. Significant currency depreciation also weighed on our cost base. Against these challenging  headwinds, we expect to benefit in the second half from a new line ramping up, while we are also reducing the  dependence on gas in our plants, which should produce positive effects in early 2017.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In addition to CHF 27 million of synergies achieved through fuel-mix optimization, we delivered CHF 53 million  savings on energy costs, driven by lower fuel prices. The contribution from lower energy cost was therefore CHF  60 million in Q1. At the end of the first half, we are therefore in a much more encouraging situation than at the end  of Q1.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Synergies are well on track, and we expect to deliver at least our CHF 450 million target for the full year, after  delivering CHF 274 million in the first half. In addition, we expect to deliver energy-related cost savings in the  range of CHF 100 million in the second half, out of which CHF 20 million related to synergies and operational  performance, after delivering CHF 140 million in the first half.

file: HOLN - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 26July2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Roland Köhler
texts.profession: Interim Chief Operating Officer & Regional Head of Europe, Australia/NZ & Trading, LafargeHolcim Ltd.
texts.text: While we are talking about turnaround, I'd like to mention Brazil. There, we are seeing the first times that our cost  saving action plan is having a positive impact on earnings. Although the environment remains very difficult, we are  confident that Brazil will contribute to the overall progression of our group operating EBITDA in the second half.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: On slide 11, let me start with North America where we once again strongly improved our adjusted operating  EBITDA. In North America, the adjusted operating EBITDA margin increased by around 550 basis points to 31%  in Q2. Net sales were down 3.2% on a like-for-like basis, and adjusted operating EBITDA amounted to CHF 465  million. In the U.S., our results continue to benefit from successful pricing and ongoing cost saving actions despite  lower cement volumes, which were due to adverse weather and a slow start in the construction industry in the first  months of the year. The picture was similar for the U.S. aggregates business where volumes were impacted by  quarry flooding, notably in Louisiana and Mississippi, but delivered a strong improvement on the back of cost  discipline.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Despite the flooding that impacted shipments in April and May, since [indiscernible] (18:21) is set to have a record  year in terms of production demonstrating efficient industrial performance. Our plant in Ravena, upstate New York  has just started to produce clinkers and will progressively ramp up in the coming months. The picture continue to  be mixed in Canada with sales being impacted by harsh weather in the east of the country and signs of economic  stabilization in the west.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Aggregates and ready-mix sales were down in the quarter, mostly impacted by weather in the east and a one- week strike in the construction sector. Overall though, Canada posted an improvement in the margin in the  quarter benefiting from production cost reductions in the recently commissioned Exshaw kiln line network  optimization carried out in 2016 and favorable geographic mix in aggregates.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In India, cement volumes grew 7.9% in the quarter confirming the recovery observed post-demonetization.  Growth accelerated at both Ambuja and ACC with ACC volumes benefiting from the ramp-up of our newly  commissioned capacities at Jamul and Sindri. Additionally, cost management helped mitigate energy inflation.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Operating net working capital needs increased by CHF 290 million. This is mostly the result of a rise in inventories  explained by a number of factors, among which, bad weather in the U.S., which led to inventory buildup, notably  because of the floodings in the Mississippi area; weaker sales in Southeast Asia in June; and the Middle East  Africa June sales which were impacted by Ramadan timing.

file: HOLN - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 27July2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.text: Our CHF 400 million cost saving program is well on track. We have already closed down Singapore and Miami  last month. We have announced the closing of Paris and Zurich and this will be happening in the near future. And  also further cost saving from the countryside so we can confirm again that the CHF 400 million are well on track  and will be delivered as promised.

texts.speaker: Géraldine Picaud
texts.text: However, H1 remained negatively impacted by a difficult market trend in Middle East Africa and some industrial  issues in Western Europe. Overall, price increase contributed positively, did not fully offset the cost increase,  particularly on energy and distribution costs, but as Jan mentioned, price increases are now gradually passing  through.

texts.speaker: Géraldine Picaud
texts.text: The strong growth in contribution was actually driven by three factors. First one is the supply side structural  reforms pushed by the government that led to an improvement in the supply/demand balance and to a rise in  prices. Two, unique waste treatment solutions that support municipalities in their efforts to reduce pollution. And  third, the improvement in operation management with eco disposal and fuel substitution.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.text: Yeah. Thanks, Géraldine, for the information more in detail. I think I touched on the outlook already at the  beginning. We are very confident the momentum in Q2 will be continuing into the second half of the year. We  believe, from the pricing, the margin side, but also from our cost mitigation action plans, we are confident that we  will see the right level of margins in the second half, and also we will see our restructuring and strategy execution  well on plan.

file: HOLN - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 25November2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: With regards to our target, it's my ambition that by the end of 2018, LafargeHolcim would have changed the game  in free cash flow generation in our industry, and in returning value to our shareholders. So let's first look at our  nine-month results. As you saw, our net sales are stable like-for-like, and our adjusted EBITDA decreased by 3%  compared to the same period last year based on the pro forma figures for 2014. In the third quarter, operating  EBITDA adjusted for one-offs was down 9% like-for-like and 7% when restated for the CHF 36 million of CO2  rights that we sold in Q3 last year versus no sales of CO2 rights in 2015. These are not satisfactory results.  However, many of our markets delivered a good performance, but in contrast, some markets under delivered  significantly.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: France and Switzerland's market conditions were still challenging. However, some markets confirmed the positive  trends experienced in the first half, and have seen accelerated improvements in results. This was the case for the  U.S., Mexico, Argentina and the Philippines. Solid market trends combined with our efforts to reduce costs and  promote innovation supported this performance. By contrast, three markets came from a positive contribution in  H1 into a negative variation in Q3 compared to last year. First, Nigeria, due to the competitive environment and  the impact of oil prices on the overall economy. Secondly, Western Canada, the impact of oil prices, primarily in  aggregates, due to the end of large infrastructure projects, volumes were down 3% in Q3, but down 15% in  aggregates.

file: HOLN - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 4November2016 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Secondly, and as we've said, we are not limiting our cost savings to synergies alone. In the quarter, we have  delivered approximately CHF 100 million in ongoing cost savings through tight management of costs and  productivity improvements. This excludes the benefit of lower cost of energy compared to last year, which  translated into an additional net cost decline of approximately CHF 40 million in Q3.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Coming back to our CapEx commitment, I'd like to highlight one important thing. The reduction of our CapEx is  coming from lower expansion CapEx, as we completed several large CapEx projects in the last year which we are  now able to benefit from going forward. However, about CHF 70 million of additional maintenance CapEx is  included in our year-to-date numbers compared to last year. The reduction in expansion CapEx is fully in line with  our asset-light strategy.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: In the U.S., our operations delivered a strong performance, despite softer volumes in the market in the third  quarter as a result of delays in some project spending and difficult weather conditions in a few regions, like Texas.  However, higher prices, combined with synergy delivery, notably on logistics, resulted in a strong increase in  EBITDA margin and underpinning solid like-for-like improvement in results. Going forward, we expect the U.S.  market to continue to be on a solid recovery path.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In other markets, business performance in Q3 was stronger year-on-year, particularly in the Philippines as a result  of favorable market conditions, while in China the ongoing work on cost continued to pay off, for example, through  pooling of local coal purchases. Overcapacity and deteriorating market conditions led to profit declines in  Indonesia and Malaysia.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Slide 10. Europe recorded a strong performance this quarter. Adjusted operating EBITDA margin grew by more  than 300 basis points to 22.1% in Q3. This represents a 16.3% like-for-like increase in adjusted operating EBITDA  and a decrease in like-for-like net sales of 1.6%. We delivered a resilient performance in most countries, with  improving overall trends in cement and aggregate volumes, supported by a mild weather in September. That  being said, the environment remains challenging in Spain, Italy and Poland.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: After a very strong Q1, which was partly driven by favorable weather conditions, we saw volume declines in Q3  after a flat trend in Q2. The volume decrease was triggered by a combination of unfavorable weather conditions  and delayed start in some projects. In Canada, the situation remains challenging in the West, which continued to  suffer from the lower demand generated by a commodity-driven recession in Alberta and Saskatchewan.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: The key performance driver has thus been the significant cost improvement due to faster synergies delivery and  ongoing cost discipline. More specifically, we delivered CHF 183 million of synergies in Q3 versus CHF 274  million in the first half. We've also recorded CHF 60 million of energy-related cost savings in Q3 versus CHF 140  million in the first half, as we still benefit from lower energy prices and fuel mix optimization.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: At the end of the first nine months, we are, therefore, well on track to deliver further like-for-like adjusted operating  EBITDA increase. We have already secured our initial full-year ambition of CHF 450 million incremental synergies  in just nine months. This outperformance makes us confident that we can deliver another CHF 100 million of  synergies in 2016. In addition, we expect to deliver further cost savings in Q4, with another CHF 30 million  expected for energy-related savings.

file: HOLN - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 27October2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.text: My goal is clear for the company. And I want to develop a true global blue-chip company, not only with leading  margins, but also with a growth profile. And when I say blue chip, not only for building materials, but a real blue- chip company across all sectors in the future.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.text: On the building material market, it's one of the, I think, best industry sectors you can invest in. It's not only a huge  market potential, you also have a growing market. World population is growing. It's growing in the cities, and this  whole urbanization gives us a lot of opportunities because the mega cities are built with much more concrete  solution, much more LafargeHolcim solutions compared to rural areas. And we will fully exploit this potential in the  future.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Third, on the cost side, we continue to be impacted by the inflation on both energy and other cost categories.  Overall, inflation accounted for around CHF 240 million, out of which CHF 81 million was for energy alone. We  could offset a fourth of the energy inflation due to operational performance and improved fuel flexibility. As a  result, our underlying cost inflation, excluding energy, was 3.4% in the quarter. The underlying cost improvement  mitigated around half of the inflation in the quarter. I would remind you that the like-for-like contribution from joint  ventures is included in our EBITDA, in costs and others, and accounted for CHF 12 million of improvement for the  quarter.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Margin slightly improved over last year, benefiting from favorable pricing and effective cost management that  mitigated energy inflation. In Indonesia, cement demand in the county was up in the quarter marking a strong  rebound after Ramadan. This is mostly led by the execution of infrastructure projects in several micro markets.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: The uptick in volumes did not, however, benefit pricing, which remained under pressure in a context of an  oversupplied market. Margin, nevertheless, was up for the first time this year on a year-on-year basis. In  Malaysia, volumes were down over last year. Cement demands continue to be impacted by delayed infrastructure  projects and capacity additions commissioned in 2016. In the Philippines, [ph] sub (11:30) demand for cement  persisted in the quarter and competitive pressure from imported cement continued to impact prices. This,  combined with rising energy costs led the margin deterioration in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: And finally, in Belgium, the clinker production started again in August with the reactivation of the old kiln line. Our  Q3 results in Belgium includes insurance premium which compensated for the operational losses in the country  since the end of Q2.

file: HOLN - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 17March2016 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: On the other side, the Swiss market was negatively impacted by the strong Swiss franc, making imports  significantly more competitive. France experienced a declining housing market and sluggish government spending  despite lower energy prices. In Russia, the combination of the steep oil price decline and economic sanctions  resulted in a sharp fall in cement volumes. Overall, here, like-for-like sales fell 1.2% in Q4 versus 2014.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: Cement volume in Kenya were backed by construction activity which was supported by government efforts to  modernize transport infrastructure. Broadly speaking, the oil-dependent economies tended weaker such as  Nigeria where depressed energy prices affected investments. Sales for the quarter rose to 3.7% on a like -for-like  basis against 2014.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In East Canada, construction projects and increased exports to the U.S. resulted in a good market mix and pricing  gains. Low oil prices affected areas including the western provinces of Canada. Overall volumes there were down  9%. However, we are working on cost improvements to mitigate the effects on results going forward. Net sales in  North America were positive, with a 3.1% like-for-like rise in Q4 versus a year ago.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: For example, China suffers from a cooling economy with over capacity. Egypt has significant over capacity in the  market which resulted in a very competitive pricing environment despite strong volume growth. In India, demand  increased by 3 million tonnes but capacity increased by 23 million tonnes, driving pricing down. Switzerland had a  unique issue with a strong Swiss franc, as I said earlier, making the imports significantly more competitive. The  impact of cost and others, CO2 and negative ForEx impact offset the positive synergies number.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: On cost, as you see, we had a negative CHF127 million cost variance. The main drivers of this variance were the  correction for a one-off event, increased fixed overhead absorptions due to lower inventory levels in Q4, or the  high level of inflation in Argentina. These factors more than offset the positive contribution from lower energy  cost.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: The Middle East and Africa will still be impacted by oil price weakness. But offsetting this, we see resilient  markets across the region. In Algeria, for example, we have responded to robust demand by bringing on a new  plant in Biskra to capitalize on the upturn. North American volumes are expected to remain robust as they were in  2015 and again in Eastern Canada and the U.S.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Thanks a lot, Ron. Before we conclude and we go to questions, I'd like to take a step back and another look at  LafargeHolcim. Longer-term, you can see on this map that our portfolio is uniquely positioned to capture the  growth of the major trend that underpins the demand for our solutions, which is global urbanization. According to  the UN, from where we are today, the population in cities will double by 2050. Sophisticated building solutions  will be required to create a sustainable urban environment for the future. We will have a critical role to play in  building this sustainable urban environment.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: This is an outstanding opportunity for us to differentiate, and following the merger we have everything we need to  be successful. We have a portfolio of activities ideally positioned to serve this global urbanization trend. We have  best-in-class R&D capabilities. We have industry-leading sustainability standards in our operations. We've got  products and solutions that can raise the standard of sustainable construction for our customers, and we have the  best talent in the industry.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Our strategic pillars are very clear. A market-driven strategy based on maximizing the value for our products  through differentiation and customer focus. Cost excellence which is the entry ticket in our industry. Asset  optimization which means leveraging our existing asset and growing with less capital going forward. And fourth,  sustainability, a differentiating factor which is embedded in the way we operate and in the products and building  solutions that we offer.

file: HOLN - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 2March2017 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: In Q4, for example, our volumes were down 5% or 3.5 million tonnes, of which more than 3 million tonnes impact  came from the following: the impact of the demonetization in India, which took place in the first month of  November; less favorable weather conditions in the U.S.; excess capacity in Malaysia and Indonesia; and a  market slowdown in Egypt, following the significant currency devaluation in November.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: The fifth takeaway. In 2016, we have demonstrated our ability to turn around our businesses in the face of rapid  and significant changes in the environment. You will see this with India and Nigeria, for instance. In times of  volatility, this ability to adapt our business swiftly and effectively is a real strength.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Beyond 2017, we expect further upside from government infrastructure spending. We saw an announcement this  week of $1 trillion investment in infrastructure spending in the U.S. to be spent over the next five years.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: And after hitting a low point in terms of cement consumption per capita back in 2010, we expect U.S. cement –  the U.S. cement market to break the 100-million-ton threshold again in 2018, driven by new housing and  infrastructure demand.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: And after a leadership change in February, we started executing our turnaround plan. We successfully introduced  better pricing and reduced costs as a result of a change in the fuel mix with increased use of petcoke and a focus  on logistics to mitigate the impact of increased fuel costs. The demonetization came as a surprise to everyone  and impacted badly our Q4. We estimate that the impact at approximately CHF 60 million that we partially offset  through cost measures.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: The main levers of this turnaround plan will be, first, around fuel flexibility, which plays an important role in  reducing our dependency on gas and fuel oil, showing a great example. And I personally witnessed it when I went  in – visited the plant. A great example of what is possible here, the Ewekoro plant ramped up from 0% alternative  fuels to 40% in a period of two months in the fourth quarter of 2016, 0% to 40% in a period of two months burning  largely biomass.

texts.speaker: Eric C. Olsen
texts.text: Secondly, we have increased clinker capacity with the start of a second kiln in Calabar, which is in South East  Nigeria with much lower production costs. And finally, we have improved the efficiency of our logistics operation  and try as much as possible to reduce our exposure to the dollar by sourcing our costs locally as much as  possible.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: On the cost side for the full year, we benefited from CHF 245 million of positive energy cost savings, out of which  half corresponds to our performance actions.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: In the U.S., we continue to benefit from successful pricing improvement and ongoing cost-saving initiatives. This  was realized despite lower volumes on the back of a tough compare to the exceptionally mild weather in Q4 of  2015. This was more specifically in the Northeast. We continue to capture synergies through plant network  optimization, manufacturing and procurement, with renegotiation of post-merger purchasing contracts.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa
texts.text: The environment continued to be tough in Indonesia and Malaysia. In Indonesia, cost-saving initiatives help  mitigate the top line pressure. In Australia, our consolidated business continued to suffer from high comparables  after the end of the Gorgon gas project in the previous year.

texts.speaker: Ron H. Wirahadiraksa

file: HOT - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 17August2011 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: In the first half, we booked €13 billion of new orders and we have with us a book-to-bill ratio of 1.1, meaning that  we have higher new orders than we turn into sales, and we are still continuing to add backlog and work to our  backlog. We have confirmed and will confirm our group guidance for 2011, '12, and '13. And we have, going  forward, strong expectations in growth markets. That is something I will discuss later. The main areas we look  into is the energy markets and the requirements and the demands for our business as a result of the discussions  and the decisions here in Germany and other parts of the world. It will talk about mobility and transportation,  whether it's road traffic, whether it's rail traffic, whether it's ship, or whether it's airplane traffic. And we talk  about urbanities, developments of cities and places to live and places to work, which goes far beyond just building  a single building that goes to developing city quarters and areas in cities and places.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: Victoria Desalination, the assumption is that we have to – that we cannot make up for the delay, we have  originally – actually, we need more efforts and more costs to get the project completed and basis for this is that we  have experienced at the end of last quarter, again bad weather and again arguments with the trade unions. And  this has caused us to be even more conservative on the cost to complete assumptions and on the timing, and that  has caused the additional provisions we've set up to cover the going forward cost.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: And not only that with these new orders the backlog is now almost at two years, so providing a lot of workload for  this business unit. And this business unit is the home of what we have developed on the offshore wind, and energy  business, but we also see that we now managed that the construction part of this business has achieved a profit  margin of 4.7%. And you can see those details on page 24.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: Which brings me to page 13. So what is it – what is the direction of HOCHTIEF going forward? And, first of all,  we've looked to our knowledge, our experience and to what the markets do going forward. And we see not only in  Germany, but around the globe, a huge demand on three areas, on three fields. First of all is energy and I do not I  think go to point – there's the decisions which have been made in Germany which actually bring us to the position  that the huge investments are needed to secure energy supply within just Germany.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: Let's go to the first one which is the growth strategy, focus on growth markets. The situation is – and I'll start with  Germany. We've had a decision after long debates to shut down the nuclear power plants. [ph] Edison (35:47)  have been shut down straight away. Not only since this decision, but before that, it becomes obvious that we need  to renovate ways and reinvent ways we generate energy. And that requires actually huge investment. And this  investment through the renewable side requires enormous activities on wind energy side, the offshore wind  energy side. And we'll probably get an understanding regardless whether it's offshore wind or whether it's gas- fired power plant or whether it's water power generation. All this comes with an enormous effort of construction  work and logistical work.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: And we believe we are convinced that there is a very high need of contribution to the different countries around  the world to actually manage that transfer. Otherwise, we will be in trouble with the nuclear power plants being  shut down and having no new energy supply in place. And the same is true in the UK when you just look to the  amount of wind farms they have already approved, permitted, and brought to market just for the UK. Those things  don't build just from themselves. You need to have a logistical concept to transport 100 meter wind blades – 100  meter long wind blades, across the country to a shipping harbor. And you may end up finding out that you have no  suitable harbor close by a wind park.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: And it makes a huge difference in terms of cost and time whether the harbor is 100 sea miles or 200 sea miles or  500 sea miles away from the place where you want to put it, because you need double the number of ships, you  bring them. And we actually can build harbor and we've built harbor. And we actually have ordered ships and will  have the first ship innovation being delivered in 2012 to do the transport and not only the transport but also the  installation of these wind farms and have not even started to discuss the need for power transmission and grids.  With this new concept, we have a situation that all the traditional power plants were sitting close by the  consumers. So we have here in the rural area, we have in Southern Germany, whether it's the Stuttgart or the  Munich area, all of a sudden the power generation is about 500 kilometers, 800 kilometers away from those  consumers. We need to bring power, but we have no net, no transmission net lines. So we need to build these  transmission lines. In Germany it's 3,600 kilometers.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: Similar is mobility concepts. I don't need to explain how it looks on the streets. [ph] Ever came here by car knows  it. I have a belief here that a car knows it (39:19). And we have seen over the years a steep increase in traffic and  that traffic was not just limited to the roads. It goes to the railway traffic. It goes to the need for complex  structures to allow the traffic to flow in terms of bridges. And you see that expanding traffic in densely populated  areas. Give you example like London for the Olympic Games. Give you example Stockholm with all the water  around the city. You can no longer build this in a traditional way. You need to almost tunnel everything.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: The seaports – and I've just discussed briefly what I believe will happen just because of the wind energy. If you go  to the fact that the container, the volume of the container, shipment in Germany until 2020 will increase by more  than 50%, get an idea which amount of investments is necessary to handle that. And last but not least, airports  traffic is forecasted to be increased by another 50% in the next 10 years.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: And the third one area we focus in is development of metropolis [ph] or energy (41:52). You can see that the cities  are changing dramatically because a huge number of old infrastructure like freight rail stations which were  formerly in the center of the city move out of it and no longer need it. And you have vast areas which are currently  not occupied and not developed. You have the same with old application yards and with old construction sites  whether it's in Duisburg along the Rhine River or whether it's the old freight stations in Düsseldorf here. And all  this calls for redevelopment. And it's no longer the single building which HOCHTIEF also does, of course, but  which does not call for the capability of HOCHTIEF.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: And all this will be the way HOCHTIEF will develop, where we can bring in our competence on building, but also  in developing these structures in a way that the customers actually benefit from this and not even touch our  200th building completed, which has been certified under the LEED certification. That is the area where we  believe we will generate growth. How we want to secure that? We have the competence, explains the second slide,  which is page 15 of the presentation. We are, at HOCHTIEF, the construction company with the highest share of  international business. The opportunity in this is we have the capability to do successfully business in many, many  countries around the world and we have competencies around the world.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.text: The PPP business, which is the remaining part of Concessions, will be integrated into HOCHTIEF Solutions.  Standalone, it doesn't make any sense. And actually, we believe there are lots of synergies to be generated because  this part of business places most of its work to the other parts of the business. And to have this under one  management makes quite some sense. And the capabilities range from develop, plan, construct, and operate, and  we will extend this to not only the traditional developments like roads and social infrastructure, but we will go to  energy development as well, for example, offshore wind farms where there is a huge need for early involvement of  companies who understand what it takes to build a wind farm 200 miles offshore and 40 meter water depths.  The concept for this business is no longer to build up a portfolio of assets, which we hold and manage, but actually  to develop the assets to increase the value of those assets when we develop them because we believe that this is  what we can really well; to have a concept, to have a plan, to get the plan approved and to construct and start  operations. And after completing this, we have added 95% of what we can add to the value of an asset, and then  it's time for us to sell the asset, take the money to develop a new one.

file: HOT - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 25March2010 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Mar-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: Despite the difficult economic climate, we achieved sales of €18.2 billion. Profit before tax also  increased substantially to €600.5 million clearly exceeding the previous year’s result.  Net profit  rose as well, reaching €195 million.  My colleague, Burkhard Lohr, is going to explain some  adjustments made to the ‘08 figures. But these figures mean we have either reached or we have  exceeded all of our targets we have set ourselves for the business year 2009.  Our group has once  again proved its sustainable strength and the challenging conditions.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: The strategy we have been applying in recent years has once again proved its worth.  We have  broadened the basis of our business through a series of strategic acquisitions and have expanded  into new growth markets.  Today, HOCHTIEF is excellently positioned in attractive markets  worldwide.  We have developed a diversified service portfolio that allows us to offer our clients  complete problem solutions and we have also positioned ourselves as pioneers in innovations such  as sustainable construction and energy-efficient construction and operation.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: According to the jury composed of high-ranking members, HOCHTIEF coped with the economic  crisis so well because the company changed its strategy in good times early enough.  Furthermore,  we are once again the only driven construction company in the prestigious Dow Jones  Sustainability Indices.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: Please turn to page five now.  HOCHTIEF, ladies and gentlemen, is a project developer, a  construction company, a marketer, a property manager and even in some cases a shareholder.   This is our comprehensive life cycle approach, which has proved itself on a sustainable basis.  And  we have enhanced it further under the motto, “One roof – all solutions.”  We have chosen this as  the theme for our current annual report.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: Please turn to page six now.  I’d like to start with HOCHTIEF Americas.  Our subsidiary Turner was  able to reinforce its position as the number one general builder in the United States benefiting from  its specialization in relatively stable market segments such as education and healthcare and cross- segment green buildings.  New contracts included two campus facilities in Los Angeles and New  York, a hospital at Princeton University, a Cancer Research Center for the University of Chicago  and construction of Yale University’s Yale New Haven Hospital.  Thanks to such projects, Turner  has been able to compensate to a certain extent the weakness of the private construction market in  the United States.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: I would just like to mention three of the many projects we have won.  The consortium around  Leighton’s subsidiary Thiess is designing, financing, and construction of Australia’s most modern  seawater desalination plant near Melbourne.  The contract has a volume of roughly €2.1 billion.  At  the Australian Duralie mine, Leighton contractors will act for further seven years as project  manager, the €251 million contract, with an annual production volume of 1.8 million tons of coal.   On the island of Saadiyat off the coast of Abu Dhabi, the joint venture around the Al Habtoor  Leighton Group will be realizing the St. Regis Hotel and Residences project, half of the contract  value of just under €345 million is attributable to Al Habtoor Leighton.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: Our Australian subsidiary strategy includes focusing on strong growth markets.  These increasingly  also include offshore oil and gas projects.  One example of this is the Gorgon project, which is  aiming to open up a gas field off the West Coast of Australia.  Thiess and Leighton contractors  have won some important contracts in this area including the construction of a residential complex  for around 3,300 employees.  These Gorgon projects, which we have won already have a total  value of over €1.1 billion.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: On page 21 and 22 of our presentation, you will find details regarding the calculated NPV, the  projects included and also the usual sensitivity analysis.  Despite the general declines in business  travel, our six airport holdings still handled about 89 million passengers.  This is just 1.4% below the  ‘08 figure.  This is a very good development in view of the current economic climate.  Sydney and  Tirana were even able to increase passenger numbers compared to ‘08 and Düsseldorf Airport set  a new passenger record in the second half of ‘09.  Our roads and social infrastructure segment also       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: 4 strengthened its position.  We were awarded the contract to construct and subsequently operate  secondary schools in the towns of Wigan and Salford.  This contract is part of the British  Government’s so-called Building Schools for the Future program, under which all 3,500 secondary  schools in the country will be either refurbished or even newly constructed.  We have put ourselves  in a good starting position to take on further projects under this program.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: As you know, the so-called Dubai crisis which occurred in the middle of our book building process  in late November, early December considerably worsened the capital market climate.  One of our  options at that point in time was to accept significant markdowns on what we and our analysts had  identified as a fair value.  However, we did not and still do not see any reason to sell below value.   This would have significantly contradicted our intention namely to show and to generate value.  And  as my colleague Burkhard Lohr is going to point out in a few minutes, we were and we still are  under no pressure at all to sell.  Therefore, we are confident that we made the right decision in  stopping the IPO and several investors confirmed to us immediately after that, that we were indeed  – that we have indeed made the right decision.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: We were already involved by the way in advising the client during the project’s design phase. And  as we communicated earlier, this contract only is worth €1.3 billion.  Further important  developments are the expansion of our high yield construction business and the reinforcement of  our strong position with regard to green buildings.  HOCHTIEF Construction was active in both the  expanding offshore wind power plant market and in the field of geothermal energy.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: While we expect the official, indeed the office rental climate to remain difficult this year, we foresee  a slight upturn in investment markets.  With our high pre-let rates in our projects currently being  under development, we see ourselves to be well equipped.  The effects of the financial crisis on  real estate demand are still hard to predict at present.  However, for ongoing business in ‘010,  we’re planning to achieve a good profit before taxes at the same level as the previous year.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: Energy Management, ladies and gentlemen, won good project as well such as the energy saving  program for the Berlin Senate.  Over a period of 10 years, we are going to save around €4.5 million  and cut CO2 emissions by a total of 22,000 tons.  The properties we manage include Berlin’s Red  City Hall, several court houses and tax offices, and other state-owned buildings.  For ‘010, we are  expecting moderate growth for HOCHTIEF Services.  Costs, pressure and restructuring at client  companies, especially the industry will increase their willingness to outsource.  We want to expand  our international activities with a focus on Eastern Europe and we are expecting profit before taxes  to exceed that of the previous year.  This was my quick run through the divisions.  Thank you for  your attention and I would now like to hand over to my colleague, Burkhard Lohr.

texts.speaker: Dr. Lars Petzold, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: I welcome you to HOCHTIEF Results Presentation for the Full Year 2009.  My name is Lars
texts.text: Dr. Herbert Lütkestratkötter, Chairman of the Executive Board  Okay, Burkhard, thank you.  Ladies and gentlemen, let me summarize.  We’ve made our  homework.  Despite the financial crisis and the resulting unsettled economic climate, our business  developed very well during the last year.  Thanks to our integrated life cycle approach, our clients  remain convinced of our high performance and our competence when it comes to providing  solutions.
